By the time he died there in 1865, Notman had made an enduring contribution to the architectural heritage of both his adopted city and his adopted country.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Profit For Boat Builder
description: The big French pleasure boat builder, Bnteau, said it expected net profit to rise almost 3 percent, to 58.5 million euros, or $50.3 million, in its current financial year ending Aug. 31, on a 7 percent revenue increase, to 610.8 million euros, ''despite a difficult international environment.'' Annette Roux, the chairwoman of Bnteau, which builds boats in France and in Marion, S.C., said the pleasure boat market had ''become a lot less sensitive to cyclical movements.'' Bnteau said it would raise its dividend this year 35 percent, to 1.96 euros. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: NEC Doubles Loss Forecast

The company also lowered its sales target by 4.3 percent, to 5.1 trillion yen ($38 billion). The cuts follow similar steps taken this week by two rivals, Toshiba and Fujitsu. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Students Protest Proposed Cuts
description: High school students protested in downtown Portland against proposed cuts of more than $300 million in the statewide schools budget. The cuts would come on top of several years of budget shortfalls that have resulted in class sizes higher than 28 pupils, teacher layoffs and extensive program cuts. The students said the proposed cuts, to help the state close an $875 million budget deficit, would mean a 14 percent reduction in Portland's public schools budget, and belied statements by the governor and the Legislature that schools were a top priority.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Suspected Case Of Assisted Suicide
description: The police said they believed that an Irish woman found dead in a Dublin apartment last Saturday had paid two American men more than $5,000 to help her commit suicide after meeting through an Internet chat room. Officials said the death may be the first such assisted suicide in Ireland, a crime that carries a 14-year prison sentence. The police, who have asked Interpol to help find the two men, said they had obtained e-mail messages discussing the arrangements and other evidence at the scene. News reports said the woman, in her late 40's, had a history of mental illness and had talked of killing herself. Brian Lavery (NYT)

Unfortunately, Saudi Arabia's rulers remain reluctant to reckon with deformities in their own society that fuel the violent Islamic fundamentalism of Osama bin Laden and his followers.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Path Station Contract
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday that it had awarded a $300 million contract to rebuild the partly destroyed PATH station beneath the World Trade Center site. The contract goes to a partnership of Tully Construction, the Yonkers Contracting Company and A. J. Pegno Construction. The PATH station, set to reopen in 18 months, is a temporary solution to allow passengers from New Jersey and elsewhere to get to Lower Manhattan. A permanent station will be built, most likely a little farther to the east. The contract awarded yesterday is part of a $544 million emergency plan that also includes repairs to waterlogged tunnels and other work in Jersey City. Randy Kennedy (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: McLeodUSA Files For Bankruptcy
description: McLeodUSA Inc., a local telephone and Internet service company backed by the buyout firm Forstmann Little & Company, filed a prepackaged bankruptcy plan that wipes out $3.3 billion in debt and gives Forstmann control. Forstmann Little will invest an additional $175 million in the company and get a 58 percent stake. McLeodUSA, based in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, listed $4.79 billion in assets and $4.56 billion of debts in Chapter 11 documents filed late Wednesday in the United States bankruptcy court in Wilmington, Del. McLeodUSA bondholders, who are owed about $3 billion, will get as much as $670 million in cash under the plan. They will also get $175 million in preferred stock convertible into 15 percent of common stock and five-year warrants to buy an additional 6 percent of common stock for $30 million, the company said. Common-stock owners are expected to get 17 percent of the shares after the reorganization, down from 30 percent under an earlier plan. Customers and employees will not be affected by the bankruptcy filing, McLeodUSA said.

description: A series of power cutoffs at military bases on the Pacific Coast occurred because the government lacked the money to pay for electricity after the region's power rates leaped last year by as much as 45 percent, Defense Minister Sergei Ivanov said. ''We simply do not have the cash to pay such prices,'' Mr. Ivanov told the Itar-Tass news service. Mr. Ivanov had been called to the Kremlin to explain the cutoffs, which struck military offices and a satellite control center. They were ordered by Unified Energy Systems, the national electricity monopoly, which has become increasingly tough on deadbeats. The utility says the military owed it $85 million as of Jan. 1.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TABORI, SUZANNE S.
description: TABORI-Suzanne S., 74. Of Manhattan, nee Sarah Dajch in Paris, France, died yesterday of cancer, surrounded by her family at her daughter's home in Los Angeles. Mrs. Tabori was an educator in the New York City Board of Education Auxiliary Services for High Schools, where she taught and developed programs for Frenchspeaking students that made it possible to acquire a high school diploma or equivalent in either English or their native French. Mrs. Tabori's efforts encouraged her students, many of whom were Haitian immigrants, to go on to higher education and become doctors, lawyers and teachers, while others pursued careers in health care, business and politics. A large number of her students became leading members of their communities and were then able to assist others in need thanks to the many opportunities that she helped make possible. As a young Jewish girl living in France during WW II Mrs. Tabori escaped the horrors of the Holocaust by hiding in small towns and villages while carrying false papers that identified her as non-Jewish. She immigrated with her family to the United States in 1957 and became an American citizen. Her wartime and immigration experiences helped her define a vision of America as a haven for all those who have suffered from oppression. She strongly believed that as an American, she should do all that she could to assist her students from Haiti who came here in search of safety from a repressive regime. Therefore, Mrs. Tabori went to great lengths to help as many Haitian immigrants as she could to acquire proper documentation, and even financial support, that would have otherwise been unattainable for those seeking admission to colleges and universities. She worked in schools in Brooklyn, the Lower East Side, and the Upper West Side of Manhattan, where she was well known and admired. Services for Mrs. Tabori are being held today at Hillside Memorial Park in Los Angeles. She is survived by her daughter, Rachel Tabori Myerson of Los Angeles, her son Michel Tabori of Santa Monica, her daughter Sylvie Tabori also of Los Angeles and her grandchildren Zoe Myerson and Zachary Tabori.

title: F.D.A. APPROVES NEW FORM OF AMGEN CHEMOTHERAPY DRUG
description: Amgen won approval of a longer-acting version of Neupogen, its chemotherapy drug, the Food and Drug Administration said yesterday. Neupogen is used daily during chemotherapy to prevent a drop in infection-fighting white blood cells. The new form, to be sold as Neulasta, can be taken once during a chemotherapy cycle, which is typically three to four weeks, the company said. The new medicine circulates longer in the bloodstream before being removed by the kidneys, said Graham Molineux, associate director for clinical pharmacology at Amgen. Neupogen had $1.3 billion in sales in 2001.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Austria: Haider Apologizes To Jewish Leader
description: Jrg Haider, the far-right politician, issued written apologies to the leader of the country's largest association of Jews and withdrew derogatory remarks about him. Mr. Haider had accused Ariel Muzicant of having a dishonest past, faking anti-Semitic letters and opposing democracy after Mr. Muzicant led a chorus of criticism against the participation of Mr. Haider's Freedom Party in the national government. Mr. Muzicant's first name is also that of a well-known laundry soap, and Mr. Haider had said: ''I don't understand how someone whose name is Ariel can have so much dirt sticking to him.'' In return for the five written statements of apology, Mr. Muzicant dropped legal action against Mr. Haider.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Anti-Arab Slogan Banned
description: The attorney general ruled that an anti-Arab slogan used by militant rightists constitutes incitement to racism, an offense punishable by five years in jail, the justice ministry said. The slogan, ''No Arabs, No Terrorist Attacks,'' appears on bumper stickers distributed by Jewish militants advocating the expulsion of Palestinians from the West Bank and Gaza Strip, and has been chanted at the sites of attacks. A directive from Attorney General Elyakim Rubinstein was transmitted to the police so they ''can act accordingly,'' the ministry said.

description: A group of Harvard students and alumni called yesterday for the university to investigate whether a member of its governing body might have given insider information to an investment fund that manages part of Harvard's endowment, permitting it to profit from the fall in Enron's stock price late last year.

title: Shy Neat-Freak With Kinky Leanings? Sounds Like the Perfect Victim
description: Nicole Kidman's dalliance with accents -- she sometimes seems to be a tomboy version of Meryl Streep -- works in her favor in ''Birthday Girl,'' a collision course of plot twists. Ben Chaplin, saddled with a nerd's close-cropped coif to signal his inability to relate to others (as well as expose his ears, which makes him look even nerdier), plays John, a neat-freak bank clerk in England. John has such a passion for organization that he even categorizes his collection of fetishistic pornography. He has just subscribed to an online Russian mail-order bride service, and he gets Nadia (Ms. Kidman).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LONDON, THEODORE
description: LONDON-Theodore. We mourn the passing of Theodore London who died on Friday, January 25, 2002 of a heart attack in his home in Rishon Letzion, Israel. Teddy possessed all of the special qualities that a great human being should have. He was benevolent with his time and resources, selfless with his ability to help others, and humble and asked nothing in return for his generosity. Most of all, he was a true friend. We had experienced these loving qualities in his friendship with us and our beloved mother, Ellin Mitchell, particularly in her tragic battle fighting cancer. Teddy moved from New York to Israel three years ago to be closer to his family. He is survived by his daughter, Rona, and her children. His memory will be a blessing for us and others. Fondly, David, Alexander and Oliver Mitchell

title: VERIZON REPORTS FOURTH-QUARTER LOSS OF $2 BILLION
description: Verizon Communications, the nation's biggest local telephone company, posted a $2 billion fourth-quarter loss because of investment declines and costs to eliminate 8,700 jobs. The loss, 75 cents a share, was in contrast to net income of $1.9 billion, or 70 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose less than 1 percent, to $17 billion. The number of local phone lines dropped for a third quarter as corporate layoffs crimped demand and consumers relied more on mobile phones. Phone lines in service fell 2.1 percent, to 61.6 million. Expenses included $1.93 billion from a decline in the value of investments, including Verizon's stake in Genuity Inc. It also had $1 billion in severance costs.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Banking Law Passed, I.M.F. Aid To Follow
description: President Ahmet Necdet Sezer signed a new banking law, sought by the International Monetary Fund in exchange for $16 billion in loans, after Parliament passed the legislation for a second time. The measure will inject up to $5 billion into the country's ailing banking system. Mr. Sezer vetoed the bill last month but signed the same law when Parliament approved it again. The fund is expected to approve the loans next week.

title: LYONDELL AGREES TO BUY OCCIDENTAL'S STAKE IN EQUISTAR
description: Lyondell Chemical said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Occidental Petroleum's 29.5 percent stake in Equistar Chemicals, increasing Lyondell's interest to 70.5 percent. Equistar makes chemicals used in plastic film, bags and bottles. Occidental, based in Los Angeles, will get a 21 percent stake in Lyondell, a producer of petrochemicals used in plastic bags and packaging. Millennium Chemicals of Red Bank, N.J., holds the rest of Equistar. Lyondell, based in Houston, will pay Occidental 30 million to 34 million shares, give it five-year warrants to buy Lyondell stock for $25 a share, and make a contingent payment of as much as $35 million.

description: Deutsche Bank had its first quarterly loss since 1997 because of costs tied to possible loan defaults and cutting 2,100 investment banking jobs. title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: Regulators Reject Power Plant
description: State regulators voted unanimously to deny an application for a $1 billion power plant. The Arizona Corporate Commission said there was not enough proof of a need for the power, or buyers, to balance the potential environmental harm of the 1,800 megawatt power station. Commissioners, who had never before ruled against a power plant because the energy was not needed, noted that they were setting the ''environmental bar higher'' for new projects. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: StorageNetworks Loss Narrows
description: Shares in StorageNetworks, a three-year-old data-storage company based in Waltham, Mass., jumped over 25 percent yesterday after it reported a fourth-quarter loss that was narrower than analysts had forecast and announced a deal with Electronic Data Systems, the big computer services company. Excluding $114.4 million in costs associated with retrieving equipment from bankrupt companies like Exodus Communications Inc., Storage Networks said its loss would have been 19 cents a share. Analysts expected the company to lose 25 cents on that basis. Sales rose 49 percent from a year earlier, to $31.6 million. Its shares rose $1.06, to $5.14. Shares in StorageNetworks ended the day at $5.14, up $1.06. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Residential Real Estate; Not Even Terror Attack Dims Manhattan Market
description: Despite the recession and tremors from the World Trade Center attack, the prices of co-op and condominium apartments in most of Manhattan ended last year with a 5.2 percent gain, reaching a median of $505,000, according to a leading market report. And while closings slipped from the year before, the number of sales contracts has bounced back in the past two months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AGEE, ROBERT CECIL
description: AGEE-Robert Cecil. A 40 year resident of Bronxville died of lung cancer on January 30, 2002 at his home. He was 70 years old. Mr. Agee, an attorney with a varied appellate practice, was a graduate of Phillips Andover Academy, Princeton University and Harvard Law School. He had long been associated as Of Counsel with the law firm of Walter J. Handelman in White Plains. At Princeton, where he graduated Summa Cum Laude and Phi Beta Kappa, he was editor of the Nassau Lit and was the first to write a novel for his senior thesis under the Special Program for the Humanities. After being stationed in Inchon, Korea as Disbursing Officer in the Navy aboard the USS Consolation Hospital Ship during the Korean War, he returned to Westchester County where he was Special Feature Writer on the County News Bureau for the Macy Chain of newspapers-precursor to the Journal News-and then became an editor for Horizon Magazine. Long active in the Democratic Party, he first served as aide to the Governor of Massachusetts. Later he headed Research and Records in Westchester for Democrat William F. Luddy, the first County Chairman to support the selection of John F. Kennedy as a candidate for President. Mr. Agee subsequently became Environmental Advisor to Senator Robert F. Kennedy. Later as the first Democrat on the Bronxville Board of Trustees, he wrote important land use legislation. Mr. Agee is survived by his wife of 47 years Anne Stanford Agee, daughter Elizabeth Macon Agee, son Christopher Robert Agee & two grandchildren, Indigo Kalilu Agee, 3, and Jacob Eoin Agee, 9, a brother William Cameron Agee, niece Cintra Cady Agee & a nephew Titus Matthew Agee. Visiting hours at the Westchester Funeral Home, 190 Main St., Eastchester, NY will be from 79PM Friday, February 1 and the funeral will be at the Reformed Church, Bronxville, New York at 4 P.M. Saturday, February 2.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: East Quogue: Children Allowed Into U.S.
description: Four of nine Vietnamese children adopted by American parents but blocked from entering the United States by the Immigration and Naturalization Service will be allowed to enter the country, the agency announced yesterday. The adoptive parents, including an East Quogue couple, were among eight families blocked from bringing the children into America by the I.N.S. because it questioned what it termed irregularities in the Vietnamese adoption process. After a seven-week delay, agency officials said yesterday that they had concluded that the four children had been voluntarily given up for adoption. The five other children will continue to be denied visas while the agency completes its investigation, an agency spokesman said. It is to decide by the end of next week. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

description: Lower attendance at Disney-owned theme parks combined with lackluster performance at the ABC television network continue to ail the Walt Disney Company, although earnings for the last three months of 2001 were better than expected, executives said today.

description: An ice storm that transformed this city into a winter wonderland, frosting trees, cars and buildings, also showed an ugly side today by knocking out power for hundreds of thousands of people across Oklahoma, Kansas and Missouri before moving east.

title: Plan to Stop Missile Threat Could Cost $238 Billion
description: Building and operating the major missile defense programs now under development by the Bush administration could cost as much as $238 billion by 2025, according to a study released today by the Congressional Budget Office.

title: Red Cross Announces Plans For Rest of Disaster Funds
description: The American Red Cross yesterday announced how it would distribute another $360 million from its giant Liberty Disaster Fund for victims of the Sept. 11 terror attacks. Former United States Senator George J. Mitchell, who now oversees the fund, said $240 million would be paid in direct financial assistance to families, $80 million would go for long-term services like mental health treatment, and $25 million would be spent on immediate disaster relief, like the maintenance of support centers.

title: California Assembly Passes Bill to Limit a Greenhouse Gas
description: The California Assembly passed a bill on Wednesday that would set the first standards in the nation for regulating automotive emissions of a greenhouse gas. Environmentalists viewed the action as a major victory, but automakers, which are expected to challenge regulation in court if the bill becomes law, criticized it.

title: A Landfill in the Eyes Of Artists Who Beheld It
description: The 2,200-acre Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island is said to be one of two man-made structures on earth visible to the naked eye from space. (The other, supposedly, is the Great Wall of China; the claims are denied by NASA.) Created in 1948, Fresh Kills was the brainchild of Robert Moses, who used it as part of a plan to have the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge built. In 1974 the landfill was ingesting half of all the garbage produced by New York City. In 1995 the Environmental Protection Agency estimated that it was generating almost 2 percent of all the world's methane. Today that gas is being extracted, bottled and sold for heating fuel. New York City's last landfill, Fresh Kills closed in March, only to reopen shortly after Sept. 11 to accept rubble from the destroyed World Trade Center buildings.

title: Nabokov Ineligible To Play for Russia
description: San Jose Sharks goalie Yevgeny Nabokov, the N.H.L.'s top rookie last season, was ruled ineligible to play for Russia in the Winter Olympics by the International Ice Hockey Federation yesterday.

title: Youth Game Postponed After Fight by Parents
description: The Ice Warriors of Arapahoe County and Arvada Hockey were scheduled to play a youth hockey game on Sunday, but officials said today that the game would be postponed. That's because the last time the two suburban teams met, just last Sunday, a melee broke out among more than a dozen parents.

title: Paper Giants As a Voice For Ideas
description: Looking like an arts and crafts teacher who had been dropped into a Fellini film, David Taylor was struggling to clothe a papier-mch giant and simultaneously direct paint-splattered volunteers when yet another reporter asked the question: Were he and his fellow protesters planning to clash with the police over the next few days? Mr. Taylor, a 24-year-old computer programmer from Oakland, Calif., put down the puppet he was wrestling and tried to stifle his indignation.

title: Valentine's Day in Charleston
description: Because not everyone is ready to pair up on Valentine's Day, the Planters Inn, a 62-room hotel in an 1844 building in the Historic District of Charleston, S.C., has something for solo travelers. The Away Alone plan, $500 for a queen bed, $534 for a king, includes a Teddy bear, flowers, in-room massage, a cocktail, dinner at a communal table at Hank's restaurant, a Palm Pilot, a movie rental with munchies and breakfast in bed. Rates do not include tax and tip. Packages are also available for couples. Information: (800) 845-7082 or www.plantersinn.com .

title: CREDIT SUISSE WARNS OF LOWER 2001 EARNINGS
description: The Credit Suisse Group warned yesterday that its 2001 results would be lower than expected because of a $1 billion fourth-quarter loss at its Credit Suisse First Boston investment banking unit, as well as exposure to Argentina and Enron. First Boston also said that Stephen R. Volk had been named chairman, succeeding Joe L. Roby, who became chairman emeritus in December. Mr. Volk, a vice chairman, was the first major hire of John J. Mack, First Boston's chief executive. Credit Suisse said it expected to report a loss of $468 million for the fourth quarter. The full results will be released on March 12. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Editorial Observer; Enter Patty Hearst, and Some Other Ghosts From the 60's
description: The process through which 60's-era peaceniks embraced bomb-throwing terrorists (like the Weathermen), murderous stickup gangs (like Kathy Boudin and the Black Liberation Army) and cold-blooded hit squads (like the Huey Newton faction of the Black Panthers) has yet to be fully understood. The former radical Peter Collier got it partly right when he described it as ''an Oedipal revolt on a grand scale; a no-fault acting out . . . whose mischief turned homicidal somewhere along the way.''

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Backer Cuts E*Trade Stake
description: The E*Trade Group's biggest backer, the Softbank Corporation of Japan, sold more than half its remaining stake in the No. 2 online broker, reducing its ownership position to 4.1 percent from 8.9 percent. A United States affiliate of Softbank sold 18 million E*Trade shares in block trades on Wednesday for $8.80 apiece, or a total of $158.4 million, according to a filing it made with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday. Goldman, Sachs & Company bought 16 million of the shares while Jefferies & Company purchased two million. In block trades, securities firms function as underwriters, buying the shares for later resale to investors. Softbank -- Japan's biggest Internet investor and a backer of E*Trade before the company, which is based in Menlo Park, Calif., went public in 1996 -- is left with 15.4 million shares, according to the S.E.C. filing. Its shares fell 28 cents, to $8.97.

title: The Perils of Too Big a Hall

The last stop was Tuesday night at Avery Fisher Hall as part of the Great Performers series. It was a rewarding but frustrating evening.

title: One Last Big Game, And Then It's Over

They were united for good halfway through the 1981 season at CBS (Madden spent the first half with Vin Scully) and left for Fox in 1994. And on Sunday, after St. Louis plays New England in Super Bowl XXXVI, Summerall will step down from a professional marriage that lasted an estimated 450 games.

title: Album of the Week
description: JOHN MORTON: ''Outlier: New Music for Music Boxes'' (Innova/ American Composers Forum, www.innovaRecordings.com). Bjork, with her album ''Vespertine,'' wasn't the only one to rediscover the pleasures of music-box music in 2001. The composer John Morton's atmospheric instrumental pieces use the muscular plink of intimately recorded music boxes for repeating patterns and glassy textures, then breach the prettiness with dissonant guitar or sound processing that melts down the tinkling. ''Slurry,'' a piece for clarinet trio, puts breath behind the contemplative and quizzical mood of the other compositions. The album's only misfire is a cloying quasi-jazz ballad that's conveniently relegated to the CD's last track. JON PARELES

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: No Votes For Lawmaker
description: A judge has temporarily barred a Westchester County legislator who is also a police chief from voting on county matters under an injunction in a lawsuit that contends he cannot be a legislator and a police chief at the same time. The injunction was issued on Tuesday by Justice John DiBlasi of State Supreme Court against the legislator, David Hall of District 6, representing Port Chester, Rye and Harrison. In December, three county residents sued, asserting that the county charter prevented legislators from holding other public office. Mr. Hall is also the chief of the Harrison police. He said yesterday that he believed the judge had made a mistake. Justice DiBlasi will make a final determination of the case on March 5. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Bledsoe Accepts His Backup Role With Class

But the doleful expression on Bledsoe's face as he met with reporters today made it clear that he is crestfallen to be going back to the bench.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Gaza Strip: Two Palestinians Killed
description: Israeli troops killed two Palestinian gunmen after they set off a roadside bomb near a truck carrying Thai laborers to work in Jewish settlements. None of the laborers were hurt. The militant group Hamas took responsibility for the attack. Palestinians later fired three mortar shells at Israeli settlements in the area, causing some damage but no casualties. title: WATCHING MOVIES WITH/Sissy Spacek; In the Arms Of Memory
description: SISSY SPACEK remembers wandering down to the drug store in Quitman, the small East Texas town where she grew up, and picking out an empty cigar box that she could use to hide her treasures. ''I think I had a couple of school pictures of secret boyfriends, stuff like that,'' Ms. Spacek said. ''I took it out in the back yard and buried it, but I used my feet to measure where I did it. I even made a map. But when I went back to dig it up, my feet had grown and I never could find it again. It's still out there, I guess.''

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Netegrity Profit Beats Estimate

Excluding amortization and research and development costs, the company had profit of $739,000, or 2 cents a share. That is down from $2.86 million, or 8 cents, a year earlier, said Netegrity, which is based in Waltham, Mass. Analysts had expected the company to earn 1 cent. Sales fell 11 percent, to $19.1 million, from $21.5 million. Including the costs, there was a loss of $2.4 million, or 8 cents.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Alexis Lyn Copland was named media relations specialist at the New York office of Carmichael Lynch Spong, a division of Carmichael Lynch. She had worked in media relations at M Booth & Associates, New York. Carmichael Lynch is part of the Partnership unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Touching Panama and China and Much in Between
description: Over the weekend at Alice Tully Hall, as part of ''As of Now,'' Jazz at Lincoln Center's commission series, Danilo Perez presented, if you like, West African-Panamanian-Cuban-Brazilian jazz built on complex rhythmic schemes and glittering with tricky chromatic melodies. And Randy Weston brought out a 10-piece band to play North African-Chinese-Ellington-Coltrane blues.

title: A Journalist's Abduction
description: Daniel Pearl, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal, remains in captivity in Pakistan. Mr. Pearl was apparently drawn into a well-laid trap by a shadowy Pakistani group that has since threatened to kill him if the United States fails to meet certain demands, most regarding Pakistani prisoners. The Journal, the United States government and various human rights groups have appealed for his release. We join in that appeal. Mr. Pearl should be released immediately, for obvious humanitarian reasons. The kidnappers should realize that his release would serve their interests as well.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Princeton: University Fees Up 4 Percent
description: Princeton University students will pay more than $35,000 for room, board and tuition next school year, up more than $1,300, or 3.9 percent, the university has announced. The increase, approved by the board of trustees on Saturday as part of the $800 million budget for 2002, is larger than in the past three years. But, the university said, it is lower than the nationwide increase among private institutions of 5.5 percent. Graduate tuition will increase by 4.1 percent to $27,230, plus unspecified room and board charges. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Mets Will Stay On Channel 11
description: Channel 11, which first began carrying the Mets in 1999, will continue to show 50 games a season through 2003, the station said yesterday.

title: Man Accused of Sex Abuse
description: A literacy consultant was arrested yesterday and charged with sexually abusing an 8-year-old girl in a Bronx public school, the authorities said.

title: City Plans to Prohibit Turns Onto Broadway in Times Sq.
description: As the final part of a plan to ease congestion and make the streets safer for pedestrians in Times Square, the city plans to prohibit vehicles from turning onto Broadway from 44th through 47th Streets beginning later this month.

title: World Briefing
description: MIDDLE EAST

title: Panel of Politicians Is to Advise in Rebuilding
description: The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation said yesterday that it had enlisted several high-ranking state and city political officials, as well as business and community leaders, as advisers in its effort to form a consensus on how to proceed with rebuilding Lower Manhattan.

title: Religious Orders Offer $110 Million to Irish Sex Abuse Victims
description: The Roman Catholic religious orders that ran schools and child care institutions for most of the 20th century in Ireland have offered $110 million to compensate thousands of people who suffered sexual or physical abuse while in their care as children.

title: What Will Downtown Look Like?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Neediest Cases; In a Difficult Year, Readers Rally to Help the Neediest
description: Despite an economy battered by the first recession in a decade and the deadliest terrorist attack in history, this year's annual appeal for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which ends today, has generated more money for New York's poor than any previous appeal in the fund's 90-year history.

title: 'Axis of Evil'
description: To the Editor:

title: PHYCOR, MEDICAL PRACTICE MANAGER, FILES CHAPTER 11
description: PhyCor Inc., once one of the biggest managers of doctors' practices, filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday after nine straight money-losing quarters. The company filed a Chapter 11 petition and a negotiated plan with creditors in bankruptcy court in New York. PhyCor said the filing included 48 subsidiaries. The chief executive, Thompson S. Dent, resigned but will remain chairman until the reorganization is completed, the company said. PhyCor's North American Medical Management and PrimeCare businesses are not covered by the filing, PhyCor said.

title: Colombia Fears Ties Between Its Rebels and Venezuela Military
description: Colombia's government announced today that it would investigate reports that Venezuelan military officers met with Colombian rebels inside Colombian territory, in an episode that has strained relations between the two neighbors.

title: Maine Is Back on Track
description: A season that started with an event as unsettling as the death of a head coach would be difficult for any team. But Maine is showing signs it has found its focus in the aftermath of the death of its longtime coach, Shawn Walsh, on Sept. 24, 2001, from cancer.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LESCHER, MARY CANTWELL
description: LESCHER-Mary Cantwell. 5/10/30-2/1/00. To Mom with so much love. Margaret, Jon, Anna

title: ELIZABETH ARDEN PLANS TO CUT 10% OF ITS WORK FORCE
description: Elizabeth Arden Inc., the maker of cosmetics and fragrances, said yesterday that it planned to cut 100 jobs, or 10 percent of its work force, and that it might not be in compliance with credit terms after fourth-quarter sales dropped. Elizabeth Arden's credit facility, of which about $90 million is available, is secured by its receivables and inventory. Weaker sales led to a 10 percent drop in inventory in the company's fiscal year. As a result, it will seek a credit waiver for the fourth quarter, the company said. Shares of Elizabeth Arden, based in Miami Lakes, Fla., fell $3.94, or 28 percent, to $10.06.

title: What Will Downtown Look Like?

title: On the Air
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: On the Street: the Color Cure for Winter Blues
World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Debt Package Rejected
description: Creditors of the Asia Pulp and Paper Company rejected a proposal to repay them about $13 billion over 13 years, a move that may damage confidence in Indonesia's ability to attract investment. The Singapore-based company had offered to repay ''in full'' creditors including ABN-Amro Holding, Crdit Lyonnais, Deutsche Bank, Bayerische Hypo-und Vereinsbank, Rabobank and others, according to documents the paper maker distributed at a Jakarta meeting with creditors yesterday. ''Creditors have long lost trust in Asia Pulp,'' said Li Ming Suryaputra, a money manager for PT Manulife Indonesia.

title: Corrections
description: A schedule yesterday for the World Economic Forum in Manhattan misstated the times for two listed events. The Answer Coalition rally outside the Waldorf-Astoria will start at 11 a.m. today; it was not yesterday. The Countersummit at Columbia University ended yesterday; it does not continue over the weekend.

title: In the Millrose Games Mile, the First Move Is Good Enough to Win
description: The women's 800 meters was fast, the women's mile not that fast and the men's 800 slow. The men's pole vault produced a meet record by Jeff Hartwig and the women's pole vault a shaky victory by Stacy Dragila.

title: WHITE HOUSE TOLD TO SAVE RECORDS
description: The Justice Department directed the White House staff tonight to preserve records of contacts between government officials and Enron executives over the last three years, a sign that federal prosecutors have significantly broadened their criminal investigation to include the company's political dealings in Washington.

title: Economic Forum Is New York's Gain
description: To the Editor:

title: A Second Day of Waiting, And Still No Major Protests
description: Like characters in a world drawn by Beckett, police officers waited and waited and waited some more yesterday for protesters who for the most part never came.

title: Finding Equal Opportunity For the Musicians to Shine
description: At heart the experimental dance choreographer Bill T. Jones is a storyteller. His tales have included danced memoirs, but more often they are hermetic and buried within musical or theatrical images.

title: Fassel: Do Not Fear the Rams
description: Forgive Giants Coach Jim Fassel and Jets Coach Herman Edwards if they look at the teams in the Super Bowl and remember when they were just regular-season opponents. The Jets and the Giants know the teams too well. The Giants led the Rams for most of the game in St. Louis, eventually losing by a point. The Giants also played the Patriots in the preseason after spending three days in New England competing in joint practices. In an interview, Jim Fassel broke down the Rams, a team the Giants have played in each of the past three seasons.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Pataki Urges Reassessment Of Safety Plan
description: Gov. George E. Pataki called on the federal government today to reassess its guidelines for dealing with an emergency at the Indian Point nuclear power plant in Westchester County. He also announced that the state had asked the Nuclear Regulatory Commission for 1.2 million tablets of potassium iodide to protect residents from radiation-induced thyroid cancer.

title: From Mouse Ears to Poetic Pop, Work by Blacks
description: A big philosophical question always hovers over the National Black Fine Art Show, on view through tomorrow at the Puck Building in SoHo: are race-based exhibitions a good idea? The standard argument against them is that they tend to ghettoize, giving the impression that minority artists, like Outsider artists, are to be judged by standards different from those of the mainstream art world.

title: Extraordinary Security Praised by Tagliabue
description: Paul Tagliabue, the National Football League commissioner, said today that the extreme security measures taken for Super Bowl XXXVI, which make parts of the city resemble a militarized zone, have created a safe atmosphere for fans and that Sunday's game should go off without a hitch.

title: History Repeats Itself As Princeton Hangs On
description: The scoreboard was hinting at a story that defied historical precedent, if not common sense. Columbia led Princeton, 25-12, with less than four minutes to play in the first half, whetting the appetites of a Lion team that wins here about as often as a February heat wave occurs.

title: Latvia's Prusis Barred From Games
description: The International Olympic Committee banned the Latvian bobsledder Sandis Prusis from the Winter Olympics last night, sending a message to federations that custom-design penalties and to athletes who blame supplement contamination for a positive drug test.

title: Asking Americans to Monitor Americans
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Trade: W.T.O. Resolves Dispute
description: Member countries of the World Trade Organization resolved a dispute on how to structure negotiations on a new round of talks aimed at opening global markets. The 144-member group agreed that the body's director general, Mike Moore, should head the committee overseeing the three-year negotiations, rejecting a proposal to have their Geneva-based delegates take over the job. The European Union trade chief, Pascal Lamy, issued a statement welcoming the move as a ''first, important, indeed necessary, step'' in starting the trade round. However, a dispute continues over the chairmanships of the powerful subcommittees, where much of the real work is done.

title: Sharon vs. Arafat: A Long History

title: CIGARETTE TRACKING STOCK OF LOEWS SELLS BRISKLY
description: Shares of the Carolina Group rose as much as 7.3 percent in their first day of trading after its parent, the Loews Corporation, found enough demand to increase to $980 million the sale of stock in the company, which makes Newport and Kent cigarettes. The shares rose $1.10, to $29.10. Loews increased the offering 12 percent Thursday, selling 35 million shares at $28 each. The shares track the performance of Loews' Lorillard Inc. unit. A dividend yield as high as 6 percent and a price-to-earnings ratio of 7 offset investor concerns about tobacco-related lawsuits and limited voting rights.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Terrorism really flourishes in areas of poverty, despair and hopelessness, where people see no future. ''

title: Hildegard Knef, 76, Actress Who Escaped P.O.W. Camp
description: Hildegard Knef, the actress whose career emerged from the dark realism of German filmmaking that followed Hitler's defeat and then grew to encompass Broadway, recordings and a best-selling memoir, died yesterday in Berlin. She was 76.

title: Economic Forum Is New York's Gain
description: To the Editor:

title: Villagers Say Errors by U.S. Causing Grief For Innocent
description: When allied soldiers arrived by helicopter in the dead of night last week to seize him and three other family members for questioning, a villager named Serajuddin may well have thought he was the most blighted man in Afghanistan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWAR, ELINOR
description: BROWAR-Elinor. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to her family. Temple Israel of Great Neck Rabbi Mordecai Waxman Steven Markowitz, President

title: SULZER MEDICA PAYS TO SETTLE U.S. CLAIMS OVER IMPLANTS
description: Sulzer Medica A.G. and its former parent have settled thousands of claims in United States courts over faulty hip and knee implants, paying as much as $1 billion to head off suits the company said might have brought bankruptcy. Sulzer Medica and its former parent, Sulzer A.G., agreed to pay about $1 billion in cash and other payments, said Eric Kennedy, a lawyer for the plaintiffs. The company agreed last summer to settle class-action claims in federal court for $783 million. That agreement fell apart when individuals suing in state court balked. Sulzer Medica, Europe's biggest orthopedics maker, reached the most recent accord before the expiration of a court order barring individual lawsuits from proceeding.

title: St. John's Bangura Won't Face Hokies
description: St. John's will attempt to snap a three-game losing streak tomorrow when it plays at Virginia Tech, and it will do so without Alpha Bangura.

title: Recent Spills Underline Dangers of the Sport
description: He finally saw the videotape, finally watched how two 1,200-pound horses traveling at 30 miles an hour kicked him in the head. Still, all Heberto Castillo Jr. remembers about last Friday is the sickening sound that he knew came from the leg of his horse, Madame Viceroy B B. The last thing he recalls was flying between the filly's ears and onto the track in the homestretch of Aqueduct.

description: To the Editor:

title: Return the Parthenon Marbles
description: By the time Lord Elgin obtained the authority to remove ''pieces of stone with old inscriptions and figures'' from the Greek Parthenon, that remarkable building was already more than 2,200 years old. The year was 1801, and Lord Elgin's authority came from the Turks, who occupied Greece. For the next decade, workmen in Athens removed enormous sections of architectural sculpture from the buildings on the Acropolis, including friezes from the Parthenon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLYNN, ELIZABETH
description: FLYNN-Elizabeth. On January 31, 2002, in her 93rd year. Beloved wife of the late Judge John Flynn. Loving mother of Frederick, John, Elizabeth, & Valentina Abrahams. She is also survived by ten grand and nine great-grandchildren. Reposing at Fives Smithtown Funeral Home, 31 Landing Ave., Smithtown. Visiting Sunday, 2-4 & 7-9 P.M. Mass Monday at 9:45 A.M. St. Patricks R.C. Church. Interment in Calvary Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Salesian Missions, 2 Lefevre Lane, New Rochelle, New York 10801.

title: Pataki Says He Won't Sign Bill on Lights That Dim Sky
description: Gov. George E. Pataki said today that he would kill a bill that would reduce, over time, the light that obscures the stars over cities and highways. He said the measure would have cost the state and local governments too much to enforce and carry out.

description: To the Editor:

title: Nets Get a New Read From the Old School
description: The Hall of Fame basketball coach Pete Carril answered his phone in Sacramento last summer and was pleased to hear the voice on the other end. But he could not offer much help. Eddie Jordan, the Nets' assistant coach, was on the line.

title: Tyson Seeks License To Box in California
description: Mike Tyson has applied to the California State Athletic Commission for a license to fight.

title: Accord in Legal War Over Sondheim Musical
description: Stephen Sondheim and John Weidman, the creators of the musical ''Gold!,'' said yesterday that they had settled their lawsuit against the producer Scott Rudin, clearing the way for future productions of the oft-delayed show.

title: 'West Wing' Withdraws Ad for Show
description: An NBC advertisement promoting next week's episode of the network's hit drama ''The West Wing,'' in which an American reporter is kidnapped, was pulled after viewers pointed out the disturbing resemblance to the plight of Daniel Pearl, The Wall Street Journal correspondent who has been held captive.

description: WEST

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELPERN, LEONA
description: HELPERN-Leona. The Board of Governors and the Members of the Seawayne Club record with sorrow the loss of our beloved member Leona Helpern. We extend heartfelt sympathy to her family. Stuart Herz, President

title: Amtrak Sets Austerity Plan And Seeks Aid
description: Facing mounting debts, Amtrak announced a sweeping austerity plan yesterday while threatening to end legendary long-haul passenger routes like the Empire Builder if Congress does not provide $1.2 billion in financing next year.

title: Connections; Artists Seeking Their Inner Nazi
description: During the last few decades, a great battle has been raging. It has been fought in the academy, in museums, in popular culture and in Jewish communities. The battle is over how the Holocaust (or in Hebrew, the Shoah), the Nazi murder of six million Jews, is to be understood.

title: Ira Waldbaum, 74; Built Northeast Grocery Chain
description: Ira Waldbaum, who dropped out of college to help run his family's six small grocery stores in Brooklyn and ended up building what was at one time the nation's 12th largest supermarket chain, died Wednesday at a hospital in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 74.

title: Most Recent E-Mail On Seized Reporter Sends Grim Message
description: The fate of Daniel Pearl, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal who was abducted in Pakistan 10 days ago, remained unknown yesterday after a telephone demand for a $2 million ransom was followed a few hours later by an e-mail message saying Mr. Pearl had been executed.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BUTLER MANUFACTURING CO., Kansas City, Mo., a maker of building systems and components, said it had agreed to sell its metal buildings operation in Europe and would close offices in Germany and Britain and lay off some workers as part of the accord. Terms of the agreement with an unidentified European buyer were not disclosed.

title: Carnival Urges Vote Delay
description: The Carnival Corporation said today that P&O Princess Cruises shareholders could adjourn a meeting to vote on a combination with Royal Caribbean Cruises without causing a breakup fee to be paid.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Layoffs At Tape Maker
description: The world largest maker of magnetic tapes and ferrite, the TDK Corporation, will eliminate 400 jobs by the end of March in response to the steep downturn in global sales. The company already plans 9,360 layoffs at its subsidiaries by March 2004. The two rounds of job cuts will slash the company's work force 28 percent. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Brse Makes Acquisition
description: Deutsche Brse A.G. agreed to buy the rest of Clearstream International, giving it control over arranging the payment and transfer of securities in Germany that were worth 4.4 trillion euros ($3.8 trillion) last year. The Brse, Europe's third-biggest stock exchange, agreed to pay Cedel International 1.75 billion euros in cash or shares for its Clearstream stake and other smaller assets, said Walter Allwicher, a Deutsche Brse spokesman. The offer values Clearstream at 3.2 billion euros.

description: To the Editor:

title: Iginla Is Being Noticed For Standout Season
description: On the eve of his first National Hockey League All-Star Game, Jarome Iginla, the powerful 24-year-old forward for the Calgary Flames, leads the league with 32 goals and is tied with Vancouver's Markus Naslund for the league lead in points with 58.

description: POTTER-Ruth Yankauer. Beloved wife of the late Albert. Loving mother of Richard (Linda) Potter & Joan (Mark) Nathanson. Cherished grandmother of David and Tamara Potter, Harvey, Deborah Nathanson & David (Gloria) Nathanson. Services on Sunday, February 3, 2002 at 9:00 AM in Mt. Sinai Chapel, Mt. Sinai Mortuaries and Memorial Parks, Los Angeles.

title: ADOBE SYSTEMS IS ACQUIRING CANADIAN SOFTWARE MAKER
description: Adobe Systems, the maker of Acrobat digital-publishing software, agreed to buy the money-losing Accelio Corporation of Canada for $72 million in stock to add products that help companies work with electronic forms. The purchase will add $30 million to $35 million in sales for Adobe this year and decrease its profit, excluding certain costs, by 2 cents a share, the chief financial officer, Murray Demo, said on a conference call. Adobe's bid is about 65 percent higher than a hostile offer of $43 million that the Open Text Corporation made last December. Adobe, based in San Jose, Calif., plans to cut about 200 of Accelio's 650 jobs, Shantanu Narayen, an Adobe executive vice president, said.

title: Starting at Ground Zero
description: The news that the developer Larry Silverstein is gearing up to break ground on a new 7 World Trade Center should be a warning bell for all New Yorkers concerned with the redevelopment of Lower Manhattan. The city-state agency created to oversee that redevelopment must finally get organized. The public's views need to be officially heard, and planners should begin working with all deliberate speed. Otherwise the city is not going to get what it really deserves -- a magnificently designed and masterly coordinated downtown Manhattan.

title: Parcells Gets Second Shot at Hall of Fame
description: Bill Parcells will get a second chance at pro football's Hall of Fame on Saturday, but will have to hope that his recent declaration that he will not coach again will sway voters who kept him out last year because they suspected he would return to the sidelines.

title: Corrections
description: A credit in Business Day on Thursday for a picture of two professors who studied the Enron Corporation before it collapsed misstated the photographer's given name. He was Joe Mahoney, not John.

title: Corrections
description: The Home Video column in Weekend yesterday misstated the availability of the film ''Moulin Rouge'' on videotape. It was released in December; it is not among those still to be released.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, DORIS L.
description: ROSENBERG-Doris L., 83. Died on January 29, 2002 at Mt. Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. Daughter of the late Paul F. Lowinger of Vienna, Austria & Claire Lowinger of Jacksonville, Florida. Wife of the late Irwin H. Rosenberg, of New York. A passionate advocate of the rights of children and the elderly, a great friend to scores of men and women, a devoted New Yorker, and a polymath of enormous range and depth, Doris Rosenberg left an indelible mark on the life of this City. She is survived by her son and daughter-inlaw, Gerald & Rosalind Rosenberg of Manhattan, two grandsons, Clifford and Nicholas, a granddaughter-in-law, Kim, and one greatgrandson, Henry. Services will be at Frank E. Campbell (Madison Avenue & 81st Street) on Sunday, February 3 at 2:30. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Barnard College (the Doris Lowinger Rosenberg Fund Class of 1939), 3009 Broadway, New York, NY 10027, or the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services, 120 West 57th Street, New York, New York 10019.

title: New Orleans, Amid Revelry, Makes Time to Vote Today
description: They cannot intrude upon the fantasy world of a Mardi Gras parade without defying a local taboo against Carnival campaigning. They can barely claw onto the airwaves without being engulfed in a fog of news about the most carefully guarded Super Bowl in history.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Opposition Falls Apart
description: The main opposition alliance dissolved in a dispute over campaign debts, probably ensuring victory for the governing coalition in parliamentary elections in June. Polls show voters are weary of alliance's constant bickering, and are shifting their support to former Prime Minister Vaclav Klaus, the chairman of Parliament, whose Civic Democrats Party governs with the Social Democrats. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: A Search for Clues In Towers' Collapse; Engineers Volunteer to Examine Steel Debris Taken to Scrapyards
description: Cranes with super magnets toss smashed washing machines, junked cars and rusted train tracks like paper clips. Trucks with tires as tall as an elephant slop through the stinking, oil-fouled mud, dumping new loads with an unceremonious crash.

description: Forgive Giants Coach Jim Fassel and Jets Coach Herman Edwards if they look at the teams in the Super Bowl and remember when they were just regular-season opponents. The Jets and the Giants know the teams too well. The Jets played both, losing in a rout to the Rams and splitting their two games with the Patriots. In an interview, Herman Edwards dissected the Patriots, his team's frequent divisional rival.

title: $25,000 Raised by Artists Helps Sept. 11 Charities
description: More than $25,000 has been raised by more than 400 illustrators and other artists from around the world who have lent their work and donated money to a grass-roots exhibition to benefit three Sept. 11 charities.

title: New Laws Make Mark on Zimbabwe
description: The first casualties of a raft of new laws tightening the grip of President Robert Mugabe before March elections lay this week in a hospital in Zimbabwe's capital, Harare.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORATH, INGE
description: MORATH-Inge. The entire Leica community mourns the loss of Inge Morath who, for more than a half century, was one of the brightest stars in the constellation of the world's master photographers. Her brilliant spirit will forever remain reflected in her timeless images. Inge was a very special woman and it was our privilege to have known her. Roger Horn, President, Leica Camera, Inc. Rose and Jay Deutsch, Leica Gallery, New York City

title: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Gypsies Sue I.B.M.
description: A Gypsy group sued I.B.M. because it leased punch-card tabulating machinery to the Nazis, enabling them to identify and kill at least 600,000 Gypsies. Gypsy International Recognition and Compensation Action sued in Geneva, the location of the company's European headquarters, on behalf of five Gypsies whose parents died in concentration camps. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Study Puts Finland First, and U.S. 51st, in Environmental Health
description: A new study of 142 countries has found that Finland ranks first in the world for its environmental health and the United Arab Emirates ranks last, with the United States coming in at 51.

title: Idaho Legislature Repeals Term Limit Law, Undoing Voter-Approved Measure
description: Idaho yesterday became the first state to repeal its term limit laws, which voters had approved in 1994 and affirmed in three elections since then.

title: U.S. and Britain Agree on Expanding the International Security Force in Afghanistan
description: Top officials in Britain and at the State Department have endorsed the idea of expanding the international security force in Afghanistan, which is now restricted to Kabul and limited to 5,000 soldiers.

title: Gunman Robs Post Office
description: Aman posing as a job seeker robbed a Queens post office at gunpoint yesterday afternoon, fleeing with $34,000, police officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NORTON, JOHN PATRICK
description: NORTON-John Patrick. 1/16/022/15/92. Happy 100th Birthday. Memories of your smiling Irish eyes never fade. Love, Pat & Ear

description: Kathy Wistrom's cellphone rings. People magazine is calling; turns out its reporter is running a bit late. ''I think I can work around their schedule,'' she says, joking, after hanging up, smiling an ''I can't believe People magazine is calling'' smile.

description: A pop review on Wednesday about a tribute to Margaret Whiting misattributed the quotation that included the phrase ''a song makes you feel a thought.'' It was from Yip Harburg, not Harold Arlen.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JAFFE, EDDA
description: JAFFE-Edda. In our hearts, minds, and souls, you are forever loved. Susanne and Brett

title: Forgotten Prisoners of War
description: While the world's attention has been focused on the living conditions and legal status of Qaeda suspects in Guantnamo Bay, a much larger group of Taliban prisoners in Afghanistan is at risk of dying in detention. Some 3,500 Afghan and Pakistani Taliban men are being held in dangerously squalid conditions in the Shebarghan prison in northern Afghanistan. In our visit to the prison on Jan. 20, we found cell blocks designed for 20 prisoners holding up to 100 men; 8 to 10 toilets for each 1,000 men; bathing facilities outdoors in the mud; and grossly inadequate food and medical care. Dysentery is epidemic. The prison's commander, General Jarobak, told us that ''many, many, many men'' had already died.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUINNESS, MURTOGH D.
description: GUINNESS-Murtogh D. Died January 30th, 2002 in his home in New York City at age 88. He is survived by his sister Grania, Dowager Marchioness of Normandy, and sixteen nieces and nephews. A collector and longtime benefactor of the arts, he was a former President of the Music Box Society. Funeral services will be held at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, 921 Madison Avenue, on Monday, February 4th, at 10 AM. Contributions may be made to Weill Medical College of Cornell University, Division of Geriatric Medicine, 525 East 68 St, Box 39, New York, NY, 10021. Attention: Weill Home Care Program.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Abortion Referendum Next Month
description: The government set March 6 as the date for a referendum on whether to tighten the nearly total ban on abortion, already the most restrictive in Europe. The announcement came after two students lost a legal challenge to the proposed constitutional amendment, which would rule out as grounds for abortion the threat of suicide by a pregnant woman. Polls indicated a slim majority favor the amendment. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about complaints by lawyers for Robert A. Durst, the New York real estate heir, that he was being hounded by Westchester County prosecutors, misidentified the investigation in which prosecutors said there was substantial forensic evidence of Mr. Durst's guilt. It was the murder case in which he faces charges in Texas, not the disappearance of his wife 20 years ago. As stated earlier in the article, Westchester prosecutors have never named Mr. Durst as a suspect in his wife's disappearance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERDBERG, CARL B.
description: ERDBERG-Carl B. 85. On January 31, 2002 in Durham, NC. Beloved and devoted husband of the late Betty. Cherished father of Erica Erdberg and Claudia and Jim Warburg. Adored grandfather of Emily and Anya Warburg. Honorary grandfather of Nina and Michael Frieman and Shana Frieman Bloom. Special ''GreatGrandpa Carl'' to Madisen Faye Anderson. Revered uncle and great-uncle of Laurel and Edward Gordon, Frederick and Susan Gang, Barbara Schlachet, Myra and Cyrus Segal and all of their children. Longtime companion of Claire Raff. Dr. Erdberg was an esteemed educator, the consummate teacher and administrator, a leader among ''the best and the brightest'' who devoted their lives to creating and maintaining the incomparable New York City Public School system during its golden age. He was a graduate of Townsend Harris High School and the City College. He began teaching high school in 1937; became Chairman of English and Social Studies in 1953; elementary school principal in 1955; conducted two federal programs in 1966, one to prepare African-American teachers from the South to enter the New York City school system and the other, to train new high school principals to work successfully in the inner city. Dr. Erdberg became a high school principal in 1967 and then in 1970, Superintendent of District 1, Manhattan. He retired from the school system in 1973 to become a professor at Pace University and ultimately their Chairman of the Department of Educational Administration from which he retired in 1995. He was a consultant to the New York City school system's Board of Examiners and was Principal of the Rodeph Sholom Religious School for several decades. Dr. Erdberg was a longtime resident of Manhattan and had homes in Lake Worth, FL and Durham, NC. A man of enormous knowledge, talent and distinction who possessed as well, a warmth, caring and sense of humor that drew all to him. He will be missed greatly by his family, many friends and the legions of students, teachers and administrators who were fortunate enough to partake of his passionate brilliance. Services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street, Sunday, February 3rd, 11:15AM. Family visiting at the Chapel on Saturday evening, February 2nd, from 7-9 PM.

title: Edwards: Patriots Are Deceiving
description: FORGIVE Giants Coach Jim Fassel and Jets Coach Herman Edwards if they look at the teams in tomorrow's Super Bowl and remember when they were just regular-season opponents, another September, October, November or December roadblock. Neither Edwards nor Fassel is surprised at the ascent of the New England Patriots and the St. Louis Rams. Neither coach is awed, either. The Jets and the Giants know these teams too well. The Jets played both, losing in a rout to the Rams and splitting their two games with the Patriots. The Giants led the Rams for most of the game in St. Louis, eventually losing by a point. The Giants also played the Patriots in the preseason after spending three days in New England competing in joint practices. Familiarity in this case has bred insight, because in interviews conducted with Edwards and Fassel, it was apparent that each coach felt confident he had the right scouting report. Edwards dissected the Patriots, his team's frequent divisional rival. Fassel broke down the Rams, a team the Giants have played in each of the past three seasons. By BILL PENNINGTON

title: QUICK BITE/Highland Park; Like Home, if Home Included Chocolate Shakes
description: A new mother, a long-time customer, returned to Penny's Restaurant in Highland Park recently. ''It's just like coming home,'' she told Rita Valeri, one of the owners. And that's just how Rita and her husband, Romano, like their place on Raritan Avenue to be known. ''Homey, mom-and-pop type,'' said Mrs. Valeri of the restaurant they bought from her cousin, Penny Frandsen, 16 years ago. A peek behind the cash register at a bulletin board filled with photos of customers' children emphasizes the point. Unlike some other restaurants that open at 6 in the morning, Penny's stays open for lunch and dinner, till 7 p.m. (weekdays), serving 200 to 250 patrons each day at 15 tables and a seven-stool counter. Dinners include a variety of meat and chicken dishes, none much more than $10. ''A lot of the old and a bit of the new,'' is how Mrs. Valeri further describes Penny's. Included are wraps ($4.95 to $6.95), Greek salad, sweet-potato fries. Then there are at least 10 different kinds of homemade soups, plus fresh fruits bought daily from farm markets by Mr. Romano, who does all the cooking. Penny's -- serving breakfast all day -- sits in the middle of downtown, only minutes from the turnpike and Routes 1 and 18. Mrs. Valeri -- who used to work at a Howard Johnson's, so she should know -- mentions still another delicacy: ''a perfect chocolate shake.'' I can vouch for that. Norm Oshrin

It has not said which stores will be closed, but only one in New Jersey is likely to be affected, said Ursula H. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGERS, ANDREW Y.
description: ROGERS-Andrew Y. Age 90, died on Sunday, January 27, 2002, in Scarborough, ME. He was born in Madison, NJ on January 28, 1911. Educated at Phillips Academy, Yale, and the Yale Law/Harvard Business School program, he was a partner for more than 60 years at the law firm of Davis, Polk & Wardwell. During World War II, he served as a navy intelligence officer in the Aleutian Islands. He served on the Ethics Committee of the Bar Overseers of the City of NY, as chairman of the NYC Parks Association/Council, as an elder of the Brick Presbyterian Church of NYC, as a corporator of the Maine Medical Center, and on the boards of the International Grenfell Association; American Hospital, Istanbul; Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts; the DryDock Savings Bank; and the Wm. Matheus Sullivan Musical Foundation. He was a member of the Prouts Neck Association and the Prouts Neck Country Club, where he served as president. He was also a member of the Union Club in NYC, the Yale Club of NY, the Downtown Association, and the Meadow Brook Club. Active in alumni affairs at both Yale University and its law school, he served as chairman of both the Yale Alumni and the Yale Law School Funds, and was awarded the Yale Medal in 1977. He was married to Polly Porteous from 1937 until her death in 1982, and to Barbara Sizer from 1985 until her death in 1995. He is survived by his identical twin Arthur M. Rogers, M.D., of Charlotte, NC; four children, Polly Larned, of Scarborough, ME; Andrew Y. Rogers, Jr. of Maplewood, NJ; Malcolm P. Rogers, M.D. of Cambridge, MA; and Frances P. Zilkha, of Portland, ME; thirteen grandchildren; and twelve great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at State Street Church, 159 State Street, Portland, ME, Saturday, February 23rd, 11:00 AM. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Boys and Girls Clubs of Greater Portland, 277 Cumberland Avenue, P.O. Box 7830, Portland, ME, 04112.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCHFELD, MEYER
description: HIRSCHFELD-Meyer. Died December 28, 2001 in Tel Aviv, Israel. Meyer, son of Shimon HaLevi and Sarah was born in Tarnow, Poland, March 22nd, 1928, the youngest of three brothers. His family emigrated to Palestine in 1934. Meyer served in The Haganah & The Israeli Army. He was employed by The Dan (Bus Transport) Cooperative until his retirement. Meyer was a fine and sincere person, devoted to his family and synagogue. He loved to tutor and to prepare boys for their bar mitzvah. He was loved and respected by all. He is survived in Israel by his sons, Eitan (and Anat) Hirschfeld, and Eli (and Sarit) Hirschfeld, and his daughter, Irit (and Chaim) Amiram, and many grandchildren. Meyer is also survived by his brothers, Menashe (and Judy) Hirschfeld, of Montreal, and Palm Beach, FL, and by Abraham (and Tziporah) Hirschfeld, of New York. Abraham Hirschfeld, oldest brother of the deceased is well-known within the New York and Miami, FL communities. Real estate developer and often political candidate, Abe is known for building open air urban garages and for designing, building, and operating the famous New York Vertical Sports Club. Abe also made major contributions to New York City as a member of The Public Development Corporation and The Tri-State Regional Planning Commission. Abe was inducted into The Immigrant Hall of Fame, and recognized by Time Magazine as one of the most influential business geniuses of The Twenty-First Century. A former Treasurer of The State Democratic Committee, Abe once owned The New York Post. Abe recently contributed $350,000 to The World Trade Center Fund of The New York Daily News. Condolences can be sent: C/O Abraham Hirschfeld Realty Inc., 328 East 61st Street, New York, New York 10021.

They did it again after the plane landed in New York, and Camby was driven home in a van.

title: Picking the Blues In the Ohio Hills
description: AFTER a high-powered career as lead guitarist for bands like the Jefferson Airplane and Hot Tuna, Jorma Kaukonen knew what he wanted to do, and it wasn't to play big arenas with smoke machines and light shows while his hair turned gray. His idea was to start a guitar camp here in the rolling hills of Ohio, where students could commune with nature and immerse themselves in the pure, acoustic blues made famous by musicians like Robert Johnson and Mr. Kaukonen's idol, the Rev. Gary Davis.

title: 30-Second Auteur
description: On a bright morning in early January, a wound-up and highly competitive man named Bryan Buckley arrives for work in an industrial section of Queens not long after sunrise. He is preparing for his fourth consecutive appearance in the Super Bowl. He wears Nikes, a pair of sagging nylon running pants, a white T-shirt and a baseball cap. He is surrounded by carpenters, electricians, designers, costumers, stylists, men perched at computer monitors and wearing headsets, men holding binders and wearing worried expressions, caterers, corporate executives, recipients of Academy and Tony Awards, a greasy-looking fellow in a tuxedo and ruffled shirt and 9 or 10 young women dressed as beauty queens. Buckley, 38, directs television commercials. This one, promoting Oxygen Media, owners of a cable channel aimed at female viewers, involves a lavish tongue-in-cheek reconstruction of three generations of beauty pageants. Hence Buckley's workplace -- a cavernous sound stage at Silvercup Studios -- is littered with artifacts that might belong in a pop-culture shrine: a green wall covered with a spray of vibrantly fake flowers; a corkscrew-shaped red velvet lounge chair; an enormous Pop Art cutout of the face of the Statue of Liberty.

title: Bush Administration Approves $700 Million Grant to Help Rebuild Lower Manhattan

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: A LOT of films have been made about dinner parties, but the gathering in THE CELEBRATION (1998), Thomas Vinterberg's powerful, occasionally ripping Danish drama, is the one I'd least like to attend. Helge (Henning Moritzen) has just turned 60 and everyone has assembled at the family-owned chateau-hotel to honor him. But when his son Christian (Ulrich Thomsen) stands to propose a toast, he decides to reveal Helge's darkest secret: the sexual abuse of his children. What's strange is that most of the people at the table just sit there. It takes a suicide note to get their full attention - Wednesday at midnight and Thursday at 6 a.m. on IFC.

title: Mother Love: Perspectives On the Virgin
description: HOW the Virgin Mary has been regarded since the late Middle Ages is the subject of ''Divine Mirrors: The Virgin Mary in the Visual Arts'' at the Katonah Museum of Art. The contention of the show is that her image in art has changed to reflect a shifting emphasis of her role in human affairs. Her images include both her theological and secular personas as she has evolved from the remote, ineffable mother of God into a role model for women in their daily lives.

Kurt Warner, quarterback for the favored St. Louis Rams, has bruised ribs and may need a painkilling injection to get through today's game. Tom Brady, quarterback for the underdog New England Patriots, limped off the field with a sprained left ankle last week and may well need a painkiller if he is to endure further punishment today. Other players suffering an assortment of injuries will almost certainly need painkillers to make it through this culminating point in a long, bruising season.

title: When House Plants Are Growing Too Large
description: ''ROOT pruning'' sounds like an awful way to treat a plant. Nonetheless, it's a periodic necessity for any houseplant once it has grown as large as you want it. Unrestricted, many houseplants could grow quite large, but while a 30-foot-tall weeping fig is a glorious sight on a Caribbean island, my living room ceiling can't accommodate such growth. In addition to slowing stem growth, root pruning makes room for new soil and new root growth without having to shift a plant to a larger pot.

title: Jan.27-Feb. 2; FRONT LINES
description: THE BUSH AGENDA -- In his State of the Union address, President Bush broadened his theme of national defense beyond antiterrorism. He pinpointed Iran, Iraq and North Korea, which are either known or believed to be developing biological, chemical and nuclear weapons, saying, ''states like these and their terrorist allies constitute an axis of evil.'' Terrorism remains a looming threat, he said, with Al Qaeda's trainees numbering tens of thousands, and with plans of American water supply systems and nuclear power plants among the documents unearthed in Afghanistan. He did not, however, mention two prominent fugitives: Osama bin Laden or Mullah Muhammad Omar.

The next morning, the horror of the surreal images of the crumbling towers had not yet sunk in on the film crew, made up mostly of New Zealanders. ''Some people were running around laughing, saying, 'It was just like a movie,' '' Ms. Libman recalled. ''I said, 'Yeah, it's just like a movie I made.' ''

title: The Short Game
description: So it's February and it's a bit frosty on the golf course. Golfers can play -- or at least putt -- their way through office buildings in downtown Newark instead, as part of the second Newark Technology Group Winter Golf Classic on Feb. 27. In six buildings, including the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, Riverfront Stadium and, in some cases, more than one floor in some high-rises, there will be 18 putting greens individually designed by each host company for the 100 or more people expected to enter. The event, sponsored by the Newark Technology Group, a nonprofit organization formed to promote technology businesses in Newark, is open to the public. An entry fee of $75 includes breakfast, lunch and a putter to keep. A drawing of business cards will select one golfer who will have an opportunity to shoot a hole in one to win a BMW. Reservations: (201) 656-7939, golf@newarktechgroup.com or www.newarktechgroup.com/ events.htm Karen DeMasters

title: 'Warrior Politics'

The Nazi party began as a crusade for workers' rights organized by a Munich locksmith, Anton Drexler, in 1919, before Hitler took it over the following year. The Bolsheviks also emerged amid emancipating political upheaval and, like the Nazis, exploited the dream of social renewal. Once the Nazis and Bolsheviks were in power, the inventions of the Industrial Age became crucial to their crimes. title: Ideas & Trends; The One True Faith: Is It Tolerance?
description: ONCE upon a time, there was a religion whose adherents thought it to be the only true one. Toward those who refused to bow to the ''true'' religion, these true believers took different tacks at different times. Sometimes, they hemmed in the infidels (as they were called) with civil disabilities, limiting their license to practice their own religion, forcing them to listen to propaganda and otherwise restricting their freedom; at other times they became more aggressive, burning holy books, smashing sacred statues and even engaging in wholesale slaughter of infidels -- men, women and children -- as if they were rats carrying plague.

title: A Sheen Reburnished
description: For women unwilling -- to lop their tresses into razored bobs like the Sarahs (Sarah Jessica Parker and Sarah Michelle Gellar), the spring style is Breck Girl hair: smooth, luxuriant locks recalling 1960's Breck shampoo models like Jaclyn Smith and Kim Basinger. ''There's been a major resurgence of the retro-Breck Girl style,'' said Edward Tricomi of the Warren Tricomi Salon in Midtown. ''Customers want something more playful and free spirited than the usual stick-straight look.'' Steve Berg, a stylist at Pierre Michel Salon, agreed. ''The flat-ironed, dead-end look is tired,'' he said ''People are moving back to pretty, shiny hair with volume at the crown, curves around the face and a wave at the ends.'' Seen on Nicole Kidman (far right, top) and Kate Hudson (lower right) at the Golden Globe Awards last month, the style works best with a cut that's slightly curved in the back and has long layers in front. Mr. Berg recommends applying a light mousse, like John Frieda Quick Coif, to nearly dry hair and rolling the hair with hot curlers or a round metal brush and blow-dryer in six sections (two rolled away from the face at the crown, two rolled under in the back and on each side). After brushing the hair smooth, control flyaways with a dab of styling cream like Kiehl's Silk Groom. ''Be sure the rollers or brush are oversize,'' Mr. Berg said. ''Otherwise, you end up with curly wings, akin to Miss U.S.A., circa 1976.''
