description: One by one, four members of the United States speedskating team stepped forward inside a conference room with white walls, a long table and a single chair up front.

title: Leave Your Wallet At the X-Ray Machine
description: Domestic air passengers began paying a new fee of up to $10 per round trip Friday to help pay for increased security checks following Sept. 11. The fee, imposed as part of the new Aviation and Transportation Security Act, is $2.50 per flight segment with a maximum of $5 each way on a round-trip ticket. For passengers leaving the United States on international flights, the fee is $2.50 even if there are multiple segments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, LINDA RUTH
description: KLEIN-Linda Ruth. On January 30, 2002, at age 64. Cherished daughter of the late David and Blanche Goodman. Loving mother of Tracy Klein and her husband Greg Jackson. Beloved sister of Paul Goodman and his wife Eva. Dear friend of Christine Duffey. Memorial visiting at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81st St, Monday 1-3 and 6-8 PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Investing; Russia's Stock Market Comes of Age
description: RUSSIA'S young stock market has been more a casino than a place to invest since its inception seven years ago. Last year, the market's performance was second only to China's, but in 1998, it was the worst-performing emerging market in the world.

title: O'Neill's List
description: Michael Lewis's profile of Paul O'Neill (Jan. 13) reminded me of your recent article on another maverick, Bernadine Healy. Each has taken controversial stands on a variety of issues and challenged the establishment of his or her respective institution. Healy got the boot, and the article on O'Neill hints that his time may come. Nevertheless, I suspect that with his brains and remarkable leadership abilities, O'Neill will have his job for a long time to come.

title: When Modern Married Money
description: J CARTER BROWN, the longtime director of the National Gallery of Art, was going through the archives of the architect Richard Neutra when he came upon a photo of a man lying face down in a pile of rubble. Mr. Brown immediately recognized the man as his father: ''He was 6-foot-6; that gangly frame -- it couldn't be anyone else,'' Mr. Brown said in a recent telephone interview. And he surmised that his father, scion of the family for which Brown University was named, was hiding his face because he was in tears.

title: Maternal Woe
description: My 82-year-old mother vows to commit suicide rather than ever go into a nursing home. She is happy, enthusiastic and pain-free. She is also rapidly losing her memory. While she is aware this is happening, she is not aware to what extent. Do I tell her the truth now, while she could still act on it, or let her slip into dementia and nursing-home care? Claudia Lewis, Berkeley, Calif.

title: Notes from Salt Lake City; Tiptoeing Out to Meet the World
description: As Salt Lake City whips its citizenry into a fraternal frenzy for the 2002 Winter Olympics, there is no loss of irony in the rallying cry, ''This is the Place.'' But the place for what?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CULLINANE, MARGARET
description: CULLINANE-Margaret. 10th Anniversay. Mom, you are daily in my thoughts, forever in my heart. Love, Ann

description: Farah Khan Pervez, a daughter of Dr. Nina Watkins of Greer, S.C., and Najmuddin Pervez of New York, was married last evening to George Paige Hoyt, a son of Dr. Anna McLellan of Rhinebeck, N.Y., and Dr. Charles Hoyt of Millbrook, N.Y. The Rev. Susanna Stefanachi Macomb, an interfaith minister, officiated at the Essex House in New York.

title: What Price Success for a Newly Popular BBC?
description: THE British Broadcasting Corporation had good reason to celebrate. Television ratings released last month showed that in 2001 its flagship channel, BBC1, had beaten its main commercial rival, ITV, for the first time since privately owned television was introduced here in 1954. The difference was minimal, just 0.1 percent, but it was no less a watershed: 40 years ago, ITV had twice as many viewers as the BBC.

title: Jeanine Pirro's Pursuit
description: THE high-profile murder case of the Manhattan real-estate scion, Robert A. Durst, is approaching in Galveston, Tex., but one of the case's principal protagonists -- or as some argue, antagonist -- is right here on Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Boulevard.

title: Like a Flying Dutchman, 2nd Ave. Subway Reappears
description: Contrary to popular belief, the perennial plan to build a Second Avenue subway is not stalled. Over the past two months, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has unveiled an ambitious blueprint for an eight-mile subway line that would tunnel under Second Avenue, from 125th Street in East Harlem to the southern tip of the financial district.

description: They rolled onto Bourbon Street by the thousands Friday night with their numbered jerseys and football war paint, aware that they were expected to carouse, but lacking the slightest bit of tutoring in the act, hailing as they do from the sedate streets of Boston or St. Louis.

title: Washington Sq.: First in Their Hearts
description: The blight is worse than the drug dealing, neighbors of Washington Square Park say. The outer path is a joggers' minefield of cracked asphalt. Grass lawns are bald and rat-infested. The comfort stations are anything but comfortable.

Anecdotally, I would argue that I have seen a strong correlation between the intensity and overzealousness of hockey parents and the athletic shortcomings many of the parents feel about themselves.

But as the Olympic Winter Games in Salt Lake City approach, some prices are dropping as demand hasn't quite met expectations. For those still undecided on a trip to the Games (the opening ceremony is Friday, the finale Feb. 24), here are a few more incentives.

F. Bell, were shown at the American Antiques Show, sponsored by the American Folk Art Museum, which ended two weeks ago.

She has been speaking around the country for nearly a decade since shortly after the condition was diagnosed when she was 11.

title: FOOTNOTES
description: 1. Definitions of simplicity change with time. Somehow, for some people, the simple balloons of one's childhood become one perfect diamond in adulthood. ''All I care about is diamonds and a sunburn,'' a socialite in 1920's Newport once remarked on the way to her ''cottage,'' which was anything but simple, unless you think a French-style chteau on a cliff overlooking the Atlantic Ocean qualifies. The latest in ''simple'' diamonds? The new ''Lucida'' from Tiffany & Company, a square mixed cut with a high crown intended to reveal the stone's inner sparkle.

description: He has been a private citizen for a month now, but the world still regards him as synonymous with New York City. He is known simply by his first name, though out of habit and respect, he is still called Mr. Mayor. Crowds and television cameras still swarm around him at every opportunity -- perhaps now more than ever.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: THE BODY ARTIST, by Don DeLillo. (Scribner, $12.) This metaphysical ghost story tells of a newly widowed woman -- a ''body artist'' who is part actress, part mime, part human artwork -- living alone in a large beach house, where she discovers in an unused room a mysterious man with the ability to speak in her voice. In barely more than 100 pages, DeLillo tackles some large themes, like how we structure time and how an artist copes with calamity. Last year our reviewer, Adam Begley, admired the book's ''exquisite beauty,'' calling it an ''intimate affair, quiet, spare and strange -- but not so strange as to distract from the glories of the chiseled prose.''

title: DAVOS IN NEW YORK
description: For the first time since it was founded in a Swiss ski village three decades ago, the World Economic Forum, came to New York City. More than 2,500 bigwigs from more than 100 countries met at the Waldorf-Astoria to swap business cards and big thoughts on how to handle ''leadership in fragile times.'' There were also plenty of parties, including an exclusive concert by Elton John. And protests that the global economy helps the rich at the expense of the poor, which have become violent in recent years, were contained -- at least at first. Todd S. Purdum

title: 'Lazy B'
description: The earliest memory is of sounds. In a place of all-encompassing silence, any sound is something to be noted and remembered. When the wind is not blowing, it is so quiet you can hear a beetle scurrying across the ground or a fly landing on a bush. Occasionally an airplane flies overhead-a high-tech intrusion penetrating the agrarian peace.

The Rev. Anthony Kuzniewski performed the ceremony at St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church in New York.

description: With its traditional political parties discredited by the country's collapse, Argentina is confronting a political vacuum. Daniel Algarbe is no politician, but he is convinced that he and thousands of middle-class people like him have found a way to fill it.

title: BackTalk; Undiminished, That Sporting Connection Lives On
description: The love of sports, as fan and participant, is a joyful thread woven through so many of the lives that ended Sept. 11. It is also a comforting thread: the rugby star on the plane that crashed in western Pennsylvania, the Yankee lover in Rescue 1, the soccer player in the Pentagon, the golfer at Cantor Fitzgerald were bound by more than an act of terrorism. It seems fitting to celebrate their sporting lives on this Super Bowl Sunday, the holiest day of the American sports calendar.

title: Bringing Hope for Early Music
description: AS the once thriving early-music scene in New York becomes an ever smaller pond, what is needed, some think, is a big fish. Questioned about the shrinkage several years ago, some in the field bemoaned the lack of a charismatic leader like John Eliot Gardiner in London or William Christie (alas, an expatriate American) in Paris.

title: Airlines' Cost Cutting Extends to Fliers' Clubs
description: AS a professional speaker, Laura Pedersen of New York flies so frequently that she buys memberships in the airport clubs of six airlines so that between flights she can always have access to a work carrel where she can pay bills, make telephone calls or plug her laptop into a data port to access the Internet. But since Sept. 11, she said, even that costly strategy has not always worked.

title: What's Going On at Wesleyan? It's That 70's Show
description: THE 1970's was a momentous decade for art, and the scope and influence of art made then is still not fully understood. The difficulty is that it was so varied; after succeeding decades ruled by a major style -- first Abstract Expressionism and then Pop -- artists could work in any conceivable style. There was an explosion of printmaking, and artists made use of large print ateliers for their work.

title: Spit Out by the Star-Making Machinery
description: SHE knows there's no success like failure,'' Bob Dylan sang in ''Love Minus Zero/ No Limit,'' doubtless anticipating Mariah Carey, who just got a lottery-size payoff, $28 million, to leave Virgin Records. The double disappointment of the movie ''Glitter'' and its tie-in soundtrack album, along with Ms. Carey's breakdown under a nonstop promotional schedule, convinced Virgin that the $21 million it had already paid her for ''Glitter,'' plus about $60 million it had promised for Ms. Carey's next four albums, would add up to an unprofitable investment. Under new management at its parent company, EMI, Virgin treated her like a depleted oil field.

title: Remembering Paterson in 1902: 'A Whirlwind of Flames'
description: JUST after midnight on Feb. 9, 1902, an overheated stove in a trolley shed in Paterson caught fire. Fanned by 60-mile-an-hour winds, the blaze tore through downtown Paterson and leapfrogged into Sandy Hill, a residential neighborhood to the east. Although there were only two deaths connected with the fire, it destroyed 459 buildings, more than a quarter of the city's structures, and 26 city blocks. Homes, stores, churches and banks were burned to the ground. The library, the city hall and the posh Hamilton Club were in ruins. The blaze finally burned itself out outside a cemetery at 1 p.m.

title: 2 East Hampton Clinics, 1 Empty, 1 Full
description: FOR all its glitter, flash and hefty supply of multimillionaires, the Town of East Hampton has long been considered poor when it comes to medical care. It was miles from Southampton Hospital and had just a handful of primary-care physicians and even fewer specialists. Its residents faced long drives if they needed much more than a prescription.

title: A Sauvignon For Salads
description: Osprey's Dominion's 2000 sauvignon blanc is a signature North Fork white -- light, zippy, fruity, food-friendly -- that tastes like a New Zealand wine. Fans of grassy sauvignons can drink it with salads. Densely aromatic, it drenches the palate with flavors, among them honeydew melon.

title: Ice Sturm
description: 'What is it with hockey?'' McGrath asks. As the father of a peewee goalie, I'll tell him. Hockey is a passionate game that requires commitment and character. It requires toughness, both mental and physical. McGrath asks why, in an age of parental effort to reduce risks, we would let our kids play such a rough and aggressive game. I would remind him of the men of Delta Force, on the ground in Somalia and now in Afghanistan, who routinely wear tricked-out hockey helmets. I would remind him of the citizen-athletes in Pennsylvania who prevented even more casualties on Sept. 11 thanks to their teamwork and commitment. I would remind him that life is risk.

title: SAUDI SPEAKS
description: Since Sept. 11, Crown Prince Abdullah bin Abdul Aziz, the de facto Saudi ruler, has blamed criticism of the kingdom on Western media. The prince finally launched a counteroffensive, receiving reporters from The New York Times and The Washington Post at one of his residential palaces. He called the U.S. a friend, branded its policy toward Palestinians inhumane and called Saudi-born Osama bin Laden a ''deviant.'' He sent regards to President Bush and the American people, and then departed for a ceremonial sword dance. Elaine Sciolino

title: Jan. 27 - Feb. 2
description: ON THE DOCKET The standoff between the General Accounting Office and the White House is going to court. The G.A.O. said it would sue to force Vice President Dick Cheney to release a list of Enron executives and other industry leaders who helped shape national energy policy last year. The White House says it wants to ensure that it can continue to receive "unvarnished" advice. But the G.A.O. is not seeking details of conversations, only to find out "who met with whom, when and about what."

title: The Elton John Fringe
description: Elton John's new album, -- ''Songs From the West Coast,'' may not be topping the charts, but it seems to have spurred nostalgia in the fashion world for his sounds and style. The fashion photographer David LaChapelle directed Mr. John's latest video, ''This Train Don't Stop There Anymore,'' with Justin Timberlake of 'N Sync dressed as a retro Elton John. Mr. John will appear in the M.A.C. cosmetics Viva Glam ad campaign. Clothing styles are having an Elton moment: there's a revival of his Vegaslike fringe, studs and boldness, said Stacey Mayesh, the senior fashion editor at Marie Claire magazine. The eyewear company Facial Index fell under the sway of old-school Elton in creating a line of colorful, oversize sunglasses. Mr. John is to appear with 'N Sync on March 26 at a Saks Fifth Avenue and Cedars-Sinai benefit for women's cancer research, a yearly Los Angeles event attended by fashion-world insiders and post-Oscar stars. KAREN ROBINOVITZ

title: The Nation; Finding Gems of Genius Among Enron's Crumbs

title: Private Sector; He Loves New York, Up to a Point
description: Milton Glaser, the graphic designer who revised and copyrighted his famous ''I New York'' logo after the Sept. 11 attacks, has chosen not to pursue what he calls ''rogue manufacturers'' who have appropriated the new design for bootleg T-shirts and souvenirs. But Mr. Glaser, 72, expressed dismay last week over the competing memorial proposals for the World Trade Center site. In a telephone interview, Mr. Glaser, who had worked on the design of the Windows on the World restaurant, said: ''There's such an odd rush to judgment here, it gives me the creeps. The process has been very disturbing. It's very early in the game to come to an understanding of what has to be done.'' Any memorial, he said, ''should be an artistic expression that really says what the city excels in, the use of the imagination.'' Jane L. Levere

title: ENRON PANEL FINDS INFLATED PROFITS AND SELF-DEALING

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERDBERG, CARL B.
description: ERDBERG-Carl B. 85. On January 31, 2002 in Durham, NC. Beloved and devoted husband of the late Betty. Cherished father of Erica Erdberg and Claudia and Jim Warburg. Adored grandfather of Emily and Anya Warburg. Honorary grandfather of Nina and Michael Frieman and Shana Frieman Bloom. Special ''GreatGrandpa Carl'' to Madisen Faye Anderson. Revered uncle and great-uncle of Laurel and Edward Gordon, Frederick and Susan Gang, Barbara Schlachet, Myra and Cyrus Segal and all of their children. Longtime companion of Claire Raff. Dr. Erdberg was an esteemed educator, the consummate teacher and administrator, a leader among ''the best and the brightest'' who devoted their lives to creating and maintaining the incomparable New York City Public School system during it's golden age. He was a graduate of Townsend Harris High School and the City College. He began teaching high school in 1937; became Chairman of English and Social Studies in 1953; elementary school principal in 1955; conducted two federal programs in 1966, one to prepare African-American teachers from the South to enter the New York City school system and the other, to train new high school principals to work successfully in the inner city. Dr. Erdberg became a high school principal in 1967 and then in 1970, Superintendent of District 1, Manhattan. He retired from the school system in 1973 to become a professor at Pace University and ultimately their Chairman of the Department of Educational Administration from which he retired in 1995. He was a consultant to the New York City school system's Board of Examiners and was Principal of the Rodeph Sholom Religious School for several decades. Dr. Erdberg was a longtime resident of Manhattan and had homes in Lake Worth, FL and Durham, NC. A man of enormous knowledge, talent and distinction who possessed as well, a warmth, caring and sense of humor that drew all to him. He will be missed greatly by his family, many friends and the legions of students, teachers and administrators who were fortunate enough to partake of his passionate brilliance. Services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street, Sunday, February 3rd, 11:15AM. Family visiting at the Chapel Saturday evening, February 2nd, from 7-9PM.

title: 'A Season in Dornoch'
description: There is a point, far out on the links of the Royal Dornoch Golf Club in the Scottish Highlands, on the edge of the North Sea, where the world opens up in all directions. If you stand on the seventh tee, on the high ridge overlooking much of the course, you will see the sweep of this ancient linksland. If you look just left, beyond the course, you will see on top of Ben Bhraggie a monument to the first Duke of Sutherland, an infamous personage in the "empty lands," as writer Tom Atkinson calls them in his book The Northern Highlands. The colossal statue of the duke — contemptuously called "the Mannie" by people hereabouts — commemorates a man who was at the forefront of the Highland Clearances in the early part of the nineteenth century. The Clearances emptied these high lands of some fifteen thousand people, most of them crofters, or tenant farmers, whose ancestors had lived here for generations. Sheep, it was argued by the duke and his minions, would prove far more profitable than people.

title: Hit 'Em With a Lizard!
description: You don't have to be a rock 'n' roll fan to find BASKET CASE (Knopf, $25.95), Carl Hiaasen's caper about murder in the music business a rollicking good time, but it helps. In laying out the tale of Jack Tagger, a maladjusted, middle-aged Florida obituary writer who stumbles across a hot news story in the supposed scuba-diving death of Jimmy Stoma, former lead singer for a band called Jimmy and the Slut Puppies, Hiaasen skewers both corporate media operations and the world of pop stardom. Anyone who's read a Rolling Stone interview or perused enough rock lyrics will admire his mocking sendups. (Stoma -- a seeming amalgam of Jimmy Buffett and Kurt Cobain -- titles his Grammy-winning album ''A Painful Burning Sensation.'') More mainstream crime enthusiasts will admire Tagger's dogged pursuit of what really happened to Jimmy, and relish a cast that includes a female cop who poses for Internet porn and Jimmy's Courtney Love-like widow. Hiaasen goes over the top in solving Tagger's personal quest for the death notice of the father he never knew, and errs in having Tagger repeatedly insist Elvis Presley died at the age of 46 instead of 42, something any self-respecting obit writer would know. But you have to forgive a guy who has a character put out the eye of an intruder with a frozen lizard named Colonel Tom. Alanna Nash

A brilliant sun glinted off metal debris in the dirt streets of the Rafah refugee camp and bathed that desperate place in an unusual glow. It was, in fact, downright tranquil inside the camp. The shebabs, the youths, who had spent much of the previous 15 months hurling stones, were bent over books in a ramshackle library. Their leader, a grown-up named Abed al-Raouf Barbakh, had slicked his hair with pomade and donned a tie. ''I dressed up for the cease-fire,'' he said, as he strode through the camp waving left and right, palming the heads of some boys and chasing others off with a hiss.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Union Group Urges Boycott
description: A clergyman and a union group yesterday criticized the movie ''Collateral Damage,'' which stars Arnold Schwarzenegger and is scheduled to open on Friday. The Rev. Brian Jordan, a Roman Catholic priest ministering to recovery workers at the World Trade Center site, said the movie exploits the Sept. 11 attacks and discriminates against Colombians. Father Jordan, of the Church of St. Francis of Assisi, was joined by Colombian immigrants, including the widow of a man who was killed on Sept. 11. Jose Peralta, a spokesman for the New York City Central Labor Council, urged a boycott of the film. Spokesmen for Warner Brothers Pictures, which produced the film, did not respond to a call seeking comment last night. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

The House speaker, Dennis Hastert, and the chief Republican fund-raiser, Tom DeLay, are trying hard to kill the Shays-Meehan soft-money ban now that reformers in the House have signed a petition to force it to the floor. Meanwhile, some old supporters are suddenly backing a version of the bill that, if approved, would actually derail true reform. In effect, these gullible lawmakers are doing Mr. DeLay's work for him.

During the first four songs she played at Radio City Music Hall on Friday night, she borrowed the theme from Beethoven's Fifth Symphony, appropriated two beats from the Notorious B.I.G., swiped a chorus (and a few dance moves) from Michael Jackson, quoted Marvin Gaye, covered a song by Prince and brought out an old Roy Ayers hook. Ms. Keys, the most successful new singer of 2001, has been praised as a fresh new voice in R & B, but this was a night of celebration, not innovation.

Lamster, Columbia University School of Dental and Oral Surgery, records with deep sorrow the death of our colleague, Dr. David Kaplan, Special Lecturer in Dentistry, on January 31, 2002. She died at 30, deemed insane and incurable, and was buried in the fields outside what was, in 1852, the Ulster County Poorhouse. Today, children play near her headstone, and parents spread their beach towels on the ground over dozens of other people buried here.

title: America and Anti-Americans

America's war against terror has entered its second phase, a phase characterized by the storm over the status and human rights of the prisoners held at Camp X-Ray and by the frustrating failure of the United States to find Osama bin Laden and Mullah Omar. Additionally, if America now attacks other countries suspected of harboring terrorists it will almost certainly do so alone. In spite of the military successes, America finds itself facing a broader ideological adversary that may turn out to be as hard to defeat as militant Islam: anti-Americanism, which is presently becoming more evident everywhere.

Survived by son Paul, grandchildren Claude, Leslie, David, Stefanie and eight great-grandchildren; ''grandnana'' will be missed, but we are comforted knowing she finally is united with her husband Jacob, sister Edith and son Zalman. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNAL, OLGA
description: BERNAL-Olga. Died in Cazoul Les Beziers, France, Thursday, January 24, 2002. Born in Czechoslovakia in 1929, deported to Auschwitz at the age of 14, she was the soul survivor of her family. After the war, she received her doctorate in French Literature at Columbia University and subsequently taught at Vassar College and SUNY Buffalo. She published several books with Gallimard in France. In 1980, she moved to the south of France and dedicated herself entirely to the creation of sculpture. Her radiant presence will continue to cast its light upon the lives of her friends and admirers.

title: Under Fire, Andersen Puts Trust In Volcker
description: Searching for a savior, Arthur Andersen managed to enlist Paul A. Volcker Jr., who may be one of the few public figures with enough prestige and moral authority in the world of finance to bring the giant accounting firm back to reputable standing.

title: Compressed Data; At Motley Fool Site, Talk Will Now Carry a Price
description: Investors who go looking for free advice from Motley Fool, the financial investment Web site, are in for a disappointment. The site, renowned for bringing stock-picking to the masses, said last week that access to its discussion areas would soon cost $4.95 a month, or $29.95 for an annual subscription. The new fees take effect on Feb. 14, and members who sign up before then can get two years for the price of one (30-day trial memberships are available).

title: Corrections

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Prison Term for Paralegal

The paralegal, Said Ferraj, who worked for the firm of Orrick, Herrington & Sutcliffe, pleaded guilty to conspiracy and other charges in federal court in September. He was sentenced Wednesday to two and a half years in prison. He was indicted after lawyers for the American Tobacco Company told the authorities that he had approached them with an offer to sell the plan. Jane Fritsch (NYT)

Born on September 20, 1923, died February 4, 2002 in South Nassau Hospital after a short illness. Prior to her retirement in December, 1992, she had been a Secretary to the Principal of South Side Middle School and Junior High School for 31 years. Survivors, in addition to her adoring husband, include her daughter Sherry Ann, two sisters Estelle Feldman and Janet Waters, both of Florida and her loving sister-in-law Bertine Fields. Services will be private with interment to follow in Mount Lebanon Cemetery in Queens.

title: Ratings for Super Bowl Seem on a Slippery Slope
description: What's wrong with this picture?

title: Silent Earthlings Onstage, Bach's Celestial Vision in the Pit
description: Here at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion, Bach's B minor Mass is paying a visit to the theater. Bach never quite makes it to the stage, but there is plenty of room to submerge his chorus, orchestra and vocal soloists in the pit. There, out of sight and relatively out of earshot, they can provide support for the German director Achim Freyer's somnolent stage pictures above and behind them.

title: Devils Bring Back Vanbiesbrouck
description: John Vanbiesbrouck has ended his retirement after eight months to rejoin the Devils as a backup goaltender. He agreed to terms with the team today, then worked out with the goaltending coach Jacques Caron at South Mountain Arena.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Saturday about business dealings between the Enron Corporation and the sister and a son of Kenneth L. Lay, the former chairman and chief executive, included an incorrect paraphrase of remarks by the son, Mark Lay, about a criminal investigation into one of his companies. Mark Lay said that he thought the inquiry had concluded in 1995, not that he and his father knew there was an investigation in 1997. The investigation continued until 2001, according to lawyers involved in the case.

title: Israeli's Dual Job: Chief of Defense, and Dissent
description: After 16 months of grinding conflict with the Palestinians, a few signs of dissent are appearing in Israeli society.

title: Lindros Practices But Is Day to Day
description: Center Eric Lindros, who missed the Rangers' last game and the N.H.L. All-Star Game last Saturday with a sprained right knee, practiced with the team yesterday in Rye, N.Y. He is still listed as day to day by the team, which is scheduled to play again tomorrow night against the Red Wings in Detroit.

title: Left Alone, 2 Die in Fire; Absent Father Is Charged
description: Two girls, ages 6 and 8, were killed early today in a fire that swept through five apartment buildings here, and their father faces criminal charges for leaving them home alone, the authorities said.

title: N.H.L. Teammates Will Part Company in the Quest for Gold
description: Five hockey seasons ago, when Michael Peca played for Buffalo and Aleksei Yashin played for Ottawa, the Sabres and the Senators met in the first round of the Stanley Cup playoffs. Both men were centers with different physiques and different playing styles. At 6 feet 3 inches and 225 pounds, Yashin's strength was offense. At 5-11 and 190 pounds, Peca's strength was defense. Peca was assigned to check Yashin.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Burundi: Another Step In Peace Effort
description: A new senate, equally divided between Hutus and Tutsis, was formally installed as part of the country's continuing effort to end ethnic strife. A power-sharing government took office in November but rebels from the Hutu majority have continued to wage war in the countryside. The senate, together with an assembly and a shared presidency, is part of a peace accord signed in 2000. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: City College's Rebirth
description: To the Editor:

title: Carlos Is Now Making A Different Statement
description: He is 57, and his trim beard and retreating hair are gray. He is a New Yorker who now lives in California and works with youngsters there.

title: Airplane Noise Hurts More Than Ears
description: People living near the Stockholm airport were more likely to have high blood pressure than people who lived outside the zone of greatest noise, a new study in Sweden has found.

title: Mostly Pleased, but Knowing Few Heard Their Message
description: They came, they marched, they chanted (and a few landed in jail). But as the last of the rallies and teach-ins petered out yesterday afternoon, the demonstrators who came to New York to rail against the World Economic Forum expressed exhilaration, vindication and yet frustration, saying that their cause had produced larger-than-expected crowds and had defied predictions of violence -- but that their voices had fallen on largely indifferent ears.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NATHANSON, BLANCHE
description: NATHANSON-Blanche. Beloved wife of the late Herman. Loving mother of Mark and Lauren and grandmother of Ariel, Rae Anne and Jacob. Services ''BoulevardRiverside'', Hewlett, Long Island, 12:30 PM Wednesday. Donations to American Red Cross, G.N.Y.C. would be appreciated.

title: Madison Ave. Opts to Entertain Super Bowl's TV Fans
description: Madison Avenue, take a bow.

title: Call the Firehouse, and a Tow Truck; Volunteers Can't Afford to Fix Engine Damaged on Sept. 11
description: There is a handwritten note taped to the door inside the tiny firehouse in the Harding Park section of the Bronx. It reads:

title: Varied Roles Cause Some Conflicts, Brokers Say
description: Investors may have been astonished to learn that the Enron Corporation allowed its former chief financial officer, Andrew S. Fastow, to wear two hats. But Wall Street insiders could have shrugged and said, ''Is that all?''

title: BOBSLED
description: THE TYPICAL TURMOIL surrounding the United States bobsled federation is over, at least for the moment. Two weeks before the Winter Games, Jen Davidson withdrew her complaint against her former best friend, Jean Racine, for dumping her as the crew's brakewoman without warning. She even wished Racine well with her new brakewoman, Gea Johnson.

title: Auditor Proposes Changes
description: Ernst & Young said it would stop selling information services to clients and quit being internal accountant and external auditor. Page C1.

title: INSIDE
description: Sell-Off on Audit Fears

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I got 3,500 over 10 years, but our friend, Kay Bailey Hutchison, she got 99,000. Heck, I'm the chairman of the committee. That wasn't a contribution. That was an insult.''

title: Australia and Refugees
description: To the Editor:

title: 8-Year Investigation of Corruption at French Oil Company Ends
description: An eight-year investigation into a web of corruption linked to the once state-owned French oil company, Elf Aquitaine, formally ended today. It implicated more than 40 people, including a former minister who is a presidential candidate.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Arson Suspected In Fires
description: An abandoned house and eight parked vehicles including a school bus were set afire within an hour in Staten Island early yesterday morning, investigators said. No injuries were reported. The first fire started in a house on St. Austin Place before 5 a.m. An unidentified accelerant was used in the vehicle fires, destroying six of the eight. Once the fires started, a police helicopter was deployed and saw more start, said Officer Jennara Everleth, a police spokeswoman, but investigators have not located any witnesses. The targets may have been selected at random. Kevin Flynn (NYT)

title: PRESIDENT SUBMITS $2 TRILLION BUDGET THAT RAISES DEFICIT
description: President Bush sent Congress a $2.13 trillion budget proposal today that would squeeze much of government to bolster national security and continue cutting taxes, even at the cost of increased deficits for a few years.

title: MEN'S HOCKEY
description: FOR THE SECOND consecutive Olympics, the National Hockey League will break from its regular-season schedule for almost two weeks to allow many of its best players to play in the Winter Games.

title: I.M.F. Offers Turkey $16 Billion in Loan Aid
description: The International Monetary Fund agreed yesterday to lend Turkey $16 billion over the next three years, greatly increasing financial aid to a nation seen as a front-line state in the battle against terrorism.

title: Excerpts From Testimony Before House Subcommittee on Enron Collapse
description: Following are excerpts from a prepared statement by William C. Powers Jr., who led an Enron investigation of the company's collapse, and testimony by Harvey L. Pitt, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, at a hearing yesterday by a subcommittee of the House Financial Services Committee, as provided by Federal News Service:

title: Kings Just The Latest Conquest For the Nets
description: The Sacramento Kings have the highest aspirations. They had the N.B.A.'s best record entering tonight's game with the Nets, and after watching their past two playoff appearances end against the Lakers, the Kings are trying to figure out how to win a championship.

title: Posada Joins the Yankees' Inner Sanctum
description: Jorge Posada's bold wish has always been for people to include him in the same category as Derek Jeter, Bernie Williams, Mariano Rivera, Paul O'Neill and Tino Martinez when they recall the Yankees who won four World Series in six years. Posada was an important part of that run, but he cannot be considered as pivotal as those linchpin players because his fellow catcher Joe Girardi was on three of the championship teams.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDRES, GAIL
description: LANDRES-Gail. On February 1, 2002. Beloved mother of Jordana; sister of Elliott & Joyce; daughter of Claire. Mom, I love you. You will always be with me.

title: National Briefing | West: Hawaii: Slump Costs Hotels $251 Million
description: The decline in tourism after the Sept. 11 attacks cost hotels here $261 million in 2001, a study has found. Occupancy fell nearly seven percentage points from 2000 levels, to 70 percent. Oahu was hit hardest, said the study, by Hospitality Advisers and Smith Travel Research. From Sept. 11 to Dec. 31, hotel occupancy was off 20 percent to 30 percent compared with the same period in 2000. Hotel revenues totaled $3.96 billion in 2001. Michele Kayal (NYT)

title: Olympics and a Disputed Land Swap Bolster a Utah Resort's Prospects
description: Nearly two decades ago, R. Earl Holding reluctantly went to look at a money-losing ski resort in the Wasatch Mountains that Peter Seibert, the co-founder of Vail, wanted to sell. The resort, about 35 miles north of here, had just four chairlifts. Mr. Holding, owner of the Sun Valley Resort in Idaho, was not interested.

title: Alpine Skiing
description: From Jean-Claude Killy to Franz Klammer to Picabo Street to Hermann Maier, the Alpine skiing events frequently bestow upon an Olympic Games its enduring glamour names. It could be the dashing speed or the manifest danger, but the skiing of dozens of gates and in the case of the downhill, an entire mountain, has always embodied the essence of the Winter Games.

title: Pakistan's Leader Condemns India for Its 'Brinkmanship' in Crisis
description: MUZAFFARABAD, Kashmir, Feb. 5  On a high-profile visit to Kashmir, Pakistan's president today bitterly denounced India's refusal to accept reconciliation efforts in a crisis that began in December and has left the two nuclear-armed neighbors facing off across a tense frontier.

title: SENATE PANEL SAYS IT WILL SUBPOENA EX-CHIEF OF ENRON
description: After Kenneth L. Lay, the former chairman and chief executive of Enron, refused to testify before the Senate Commerce Committee this morning, Republicans and Democrats on the panel said they would vote Tuesday to issue a subpoena to compel his appearance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELTZER, ROSE
description: SELTZER-Rose. Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to our member Susan Seltzer upon the loss of her beloved mother. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi David Sable, President

title: Buckets for Bioterrorism, But Less for Catalog of Ills
description: While President Bush is proposing a major increase in spending to defend against bioterrorism, other public health programs, like preventing chronic diseases and birth defects and controlling infectious diseases, would be cut under the 2003 budget the White House unveiled today.

title: Bush's Aggressive Accounting
description: Senator Kent Conrad actually got it wrong yesterday when he criticized the Bush administration's new budget for its Enron-like accounting. Last year's budget, the one that included that big tax cut, was the one with a strong touch of Enron about it. This year's budget involves a different, though equally pernicious, kind of aggressive accounting.

title: Bush Budget Renews Battle Over Pledge Of Aid to City
description: President Bush did not include any more of the $20 billion he had promised in federal aid for rebuilding New York in the budget plan he issued today, an omission that New York lawmakers were quick to point out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, PAULINE (BOBBY)
description: SCHWARTZ-Pauline (Bobby) in her 95th year. Beloved wife of the late Ben. Devoted mother of Martin and Diana Blender, Judith and Murray Braunstein. Cherished grandmother and great grandmother. A lady of great style who loved her family, asked nothing for herself and derived great pleasure in helping and giving to others. Graveside services Tuesday, February 5, 11 AM, Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, L.I. (Exit 33 Southern State Parkway).

title: Nursing Home Employees Reach Tentative Agreement on Raises
description: Helped by money from the state's new health care bill, an association of New York City nursing homes and 1199, the health workers' union, announced a tentative accord yesterday that provides raises of a bit more than 13 percent over three years.

title: ELECTRICITY CRISIS EASES IN NEW YORK
description: New York City, which faced a looming electricity crisis last summer as more computers and air-conditioners bought in a booming economy bumped up against the limits of the local power supply, now has all the energy it needs through at least the middle of next year and perhaps beyond, electricity experts say.

title: Pakistan Optimistic That Abducted Reporter Is Alive, Casting Doubt on Contrary Claims
description: As a senior American emissary arrived for meetings with top Pakistani officials, the government of Pakistan said today that it was ''optimistic'' that the American journalist Daniel Pearl would be found alive.

title: So Long New York, and Thanks for a Mostly Well-Ordered Bash
description: The World Economic Forum closed its five-day conference yesterday afternoon with panel discussions on things like ''recommended priorities to reconcile environmental and development agendas'' and the ''psychosocial factors on health and healing.'' Then came one final cocktail reception, and that was it.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Questron Files for Bankruptcy
description: Questron Technology, an inventory and supplies management company, has filed for bankruptcy protection, company officials said, while the QTI Acquisition Corporation said it would buy the company. QTI, a unit of Sun Capital Partners, said that it had agreed to assume about $81 million of Questron Technology's debt and to keep the company's management team and its roughly 400 other employees. The sale is subject to approval by a federal bankruptcy court in Wilmington, Del., company officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HITCH, STEWART
description: HITCH-Stewart. Died on February 3, 2002 at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital of liver cancer, surrounded by his close friends, at age 61. A good friend and a great painter, he will be profoundly missed.

title: FIGURE SKATING
description: A GREAT DEAL of the attention in figure skating will be concentrated on 21-year-old Michelle Kwan's attempt to complete her amazing career with the one element she is missing -- a gold medal.

title: Making Order Out of Apparent Chaos
description: Susan Rethorst's long, intensely committed years as a choreographer come into full play in ''Behold Bold Sam Dog,'' an exquisitely right-feeling piece that she presented on Saturday night at the Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church. Ms. Rethorst creates a complete small universe in a way that has tempted and sunk countless less experienced or gifted dance artists: the weaving together of shards of highly detailed movement and nuance in seemingly illogical sequence.

title: Temerlin McClain Names Director
description: Eric McClellan has been named executive creative director at Temerlin McClain in Irving, Tex., taking over a position that had been held by Dennis McClain, the chief executive who continues in that post. Mr. McClellan, 42, had most recently been a freelancer and before that was executive creative director at the New York office of TBWA/Chiat/ Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group ( news/quote ). Temerlin McClain is part of the McCann- Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies ( news/quote ).

title: Temerlin McClain Names Director
description: Eric McClellan has been named executive creative director at Temerlin McClain in Irving, Tex., taking over a position that had been held by Dennis McClain, the chief executive who continues in that post. Mr. McClellan, 42, had most recently been a freelancer and before that was executive creative director at the New York office of TBWA/Chiat/ Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group. Temerlin McClain is part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Sports of The Times; The Introverted Coach Is Finally Out of His Shell
description: BILL BELICHICK always knew football, but he didn't always know people or himself. He was an introvert, a glowering genius scientist known as Dr. Doom. In his laboratory, his test tubes were X's and O's. He was the ultimate assistant coach under Bill Parcells with the Giants and later with the Patriots and the Jets. In between, he failed in five seasons as the Cleveland Browns' head coach. Too mysterious. Too secretive.

title: Ernst & Young Latest Auditor Moving to Alter Some Practices
description: The accounting firm Ernst & Young announced yesterday that it would stop selling information technology services to companies it audits and that it would no longer serve as internal accountant and external auditor at the same company.

title: Henry Kloss, 72, Innovator In Audio and Video, Dies
description: Henry Kloss, an inventor of innovative audio and video components who became a hero to audiophiles, died on Thursday in Cambridge, Mass. He was 72.

title: In Albany, School Boards Lose Backing
description: After championing New York City's community school boards for three decades, black and Hispanic members of the State Assembly are now saying the boards have failed minority communities and are calling for a less political system in which parents play a leading role.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Atom Plant Closing Urged
description: Andrew M. Cuomo, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for governor, and Robert F. Kennedy Jr., left, a lawyer for Riverkeeper, an environmental group, called yesterday for the closing of the Indian Point 2 nuclear plant in Westchester, citing safety concerns. Mr. Cuomo criticized state officials including Gov. George E. Pataki, who is seeking re-election, for approving evacuation plans for the counties around Indian Point last week even though they expressed concern about the reactor. State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, who is also a Democratic candidate for governor, has also urged that the plant be closed. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Choosing to Have Annual Mammograms
description: It has been said that the only certainties in life are death and taxes. And so, it appears, we are likely to have to endure continued declarations of uncertainty about the health-saving and lifesaving benefits of screening mammography, which has been mired in controversy for decades, even as the nation's leading cancer organizations have recommended that all women 40 and older avail themselves annually of this early detection tool.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: A Rabid Raccoon Warning
description: The mystery of the rabid Bronx raccoon persisted yesterday, officials said. On Jan. 26, a sickly raccoon was left in a box outside the Abbey Veterinary Hospital in Riverdale. After the raccoon died, it was routinely tested for disease and found to be rabid. Over the weekend, the City Department of Health appealed for anyone who came into contact with the raccoon to seek medical assistance and telephone the department at (212) 764-7667. So far, said Sandra Mullin, a department spokeswoman, no one has called. Rabies is a dangerous but treatable viral disease that attacks the human central nervous system.

title: History, History, History
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Commerzbank Barely Makes Profit
description: Germany's fourth-largest bank, Commerzbank, posted a pretax loss of 189 million euros ($164 million) in the fourth quarter and barely made a profit for all of last year. The biggest reason for the quarterly loss was a restructuring charge that stemmed from the bank's plan to close 200 local branches and eliminate 3,400 jobs. About half of those reductions have already taken place, and bank officials said that additional charges may be necessary as the process continues. Commerzbank is not alone. Reeling from the downturn in investment banking, Deutsche Bank, Germany's biggest bank, said last week that it lost 100 million euros in the fourth quarter. Credit Suisseof Switzerland, which is suffering from the overall downturn as well as from losses in Argentina and in loans to the Enron Corporation, estimated last week that it lost 800 million Swiss francs or about $468 million. Ed Andrews (NYT)

title: Arafat's 'Vision': Clear or Blurry?
description: To the Editor:

title: Cutting Taxes Faster Would Help Everyone
description: The bulk of President Bush's tax cut won't take effect until at least 2004. It is scheduled to disappear in 2011. The president may have been pushed into this deal politically last year, but it was a mistake. Fortunately, in his State of the Union address last week, he asked Congress to correct this problem by speeding up the tax cut and making it permanent, even though opponents like Senator Edward Kennedy want to head in the opposite direction, proposing to postpone tax rate reductions scheduled to take effect in 2004 and 2006.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: William F. Gloede was named editor at Cable World magazine, New York, part of the Media Central division of Primedia Business-to-Business. He succeeds Scott Collins, who left, the company said, to pursue other interests. Mr. Gloede had been group editor at Mediaweek and Editor & Publisher magazines, New York, part of the VNU Business Media division of VNU. Primedia Business-to-Business is a division of Primedia. At Mediaweek, Brian Moran, executive editor, is being promoted to editor.

title: Criticism Is Leveled At U.S. Drug Testing
description: Dick Pound, the chairman of the World Anti-Doping Agency, yesterday urged track and field's world governing body and the United States Olympic Committee to throw out USA Track and Field for refusing to name the American athletes who had tested positive for drugs before the 2000 Sydney Olympics. But Nick Davies, a spokesman for track's world body, said, ''We will not expel the United States.''

title: A Bold Move on AIDS in South Africa
description: He is an unlikely renegade, this courtly, balding man who sips tea from gilded teacups and favors sober suits and measured words.

title: National Portrait Gallery Shows Celebrity Photographs : Mario Testino, Larger Than Life
description: LONDON  My experience of being photographed by Mario Testino gives the measure of the man who was feted last week at the opening of his show at the National Portrait Gallery here. Dodging into a restaurant from a soaking Paris street, I found a cheery lunch party: Testino and his team taking time off from the nearby studio to create a fete champetre out of a solid bistro menu.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Search For Quake Survivors Ends
description: The search for survivors from the earthquake on Sunday in central Turkey was called off as victims were buried and soldiers and aid workers turned their efforts to providing food and shelter for survivors. Officials said 43 people had been killed in the quake, more than 300 injured and more than 600 buildings damaged in several towns and villages in the province of Afyon. Hundreds of people were living in tents as nighttime temperatures dropped below freezing. Douglas Frantz (NYT)

title: A Yawn, a Grumble, and After All It's Just Not Europe, Is It?
description: The very private Elton John concert in New York last Friday did not draw much notice, nor did the marchers in the streets. Nor did anyone seem surprised that New York proved, once and for all, that it was open for business despite the events of Sept. 11.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, FLORENCE
description: MANDEL - Florence. American Friends of The Hebrew University deeply mourns the passing of Florence Mandel, wife of Joseph Mandel. Through the Mandel Foundation many programs at the University have benefited from their generosity. We extend our deepest condolences to her husband Joseph, daughters Michele Beyer and Penni Weinberg, and the entire family. American Friends of The Hebrew University Ira Lee Sorkin, President Keith L. Sachs, Chairman of the Board

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LARKIN, JAMES J.
description: LARKIN-James J. Age 75, of Verona, NJ on Feb. 3, 2002. Beloved husband of Joan (nee Gerard) Larkin. Dear brother of Leo Larkin. Also survived by six nieces and nephews, 13 grandnieces & grand nephews. Mr. Larkin was formerly employed with Morse Diesel, NY, NY and most recently employed with Maitra Associates., P.C., NY, NY. Funeral from Quinn Hopping Funeral Home, Livingston, NJ on Thursday at 9:30AM. Funeral Liturgy at Our Lady of the Lake Church, Verona, NJ at 11AM. Visiting, Tuesday, 7-9, Wednesday 2-4 & 7-9PM at the funeral home. Interment, Immaculate Conception Cemetery, Upper Montclair, NJ. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts to St. John's Feed the Poor and Our Lady of the Lake Youth Ministry would be appreciated.

title: Warner Cites Mistakes, But Credits the Patriots
description: Kurt Warner carried a Bible in his left hand, his fingers curled around the binding, as he walked into the Superdome about three hours before the Super Bowl Sunday. He is deeply religious, and because of his faith, Warner has a strong belief in destiny.

title: After Hysterectomy: Long-Term Fatigue
description: Fatigue is the most common, most debilitating and longest-lasting symptom for women recovering from hysterectomies, according to a new study, which suggests that physicians take a more active role in counseling and treating patients after surgery.

title: Arafat's 'Vision': Clear or Blurry?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CODDON, DAVID R., M.D.
description: CODDON-David R., M.D. Of Engelwood NJ. Director and Founder of The Headache Clinic at Mount Sinai Hospital, NY NY. Beloved husband of Nancy (nee Frank). Devoted father of Jonathan and Susan. Loving grandfather of four grandchildren. Services Tuesday 1PM at the Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, Paramus NJ. Memorial service Thursday, February 7, 3PM at ''The Riverside'', Amsterdam Avenue at 76 St. For info ''Wien & Wien'', 1-800-322-0533.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Satellite Goes Astray
description: The country's effort to enter the commercial satellite launching business suffered a major setback when the space agency lost contact with one of two satellites that the H2-A rocket, Japan's biggest, was trying to place into orbit. Scientists said it was possible that the satellite had failed to separate from the rocket; the other did go into orbit. The satellite program has been plagued with problems since a calamity in 1999 resulted in the loss of a $75 million prototype. Despite the failure, the National Space Development Agency said it would press ahead with plans for 11 commercial launches through 2005. Howard W. French (NYT)

title: Studies of the Infirmities of Aging Dogs Offer Insights for Humans
description: Having an old dog is akin to having a newborn baby, only worse. Babies, at least, become easier to care for and more fun to be with as they get older. The dog gets harder and less amusing. No owner can get a continuous night's sleep when every whimper may be an announcement that the dog, no longer continent, needs to go out in a hurry.

title: Patients Get on Fast Track to Treatment
description: Traditionally in emergency rooms minor injuries mean long waits. But more and more hospitals are setting up a fast track, assigning one doctor to do nothing but handle the simple cases. Now, a new study in England has found that the practice has cut waiting times without delaying the care of more urgent cases.

title: No Matter the Sport, Hardaway Is Always Moving
description: The MTV cameras have been following the moguls skier Hannah Hardaway around the world for the last several weeks. Glib, telegenic and America's best chance for a medal in a sport that the United States has traditionally dominated, the 23-year-old, Ivy League-educated Hardaway is a natural, a television producer's dream. As for MTV's angle, well, Hardaway does listen to music just before stepping into the start house of competitions.

title: SPEED SKATING
description: SPEED IS THE optimal word here. The Utah Olympic Oval, set 4,675 feet above sea level, with the ice only 55 feet from the arena's ceiling, is the highest indoor speedskating oval in the world. Because of that, it is considered a record-breaking venue. In its first competition, last March, 5 world records were set in 11 events. The ceiling is very low, providing near-perfect ice conditions. The higher the altitude, the denser the ice is. And harder ice translates to a faster surface. The United States team has been training there for the past year.

title: Leading Democrats Open Fire on Plan to Dip Into Social Security Surplus
description: Congressional Democrats sharply criticized President Bush's $2.13 trillion budget today as a plan that returns the nation to deficit spending and drains the Social Security surplus just when the government should be preparing for the retirement of the baby boom generation.

title: The Axis-of-Inefficiency Budget
description: President Bush's proposed $2.1 trillion budget embraces the word ''security'' at every turn. It provides more spending for military security and domestic security and more tax cuts for ''economic security.'' But the budget undermines the security of the nation's social safety net and the government's ability to carry out some of its basic responsibilities over the next two decades. It jeopardizes the future of Social Security and Medicare, whose trust funds would be siphoned away to underwrite outmoded military projects and tax reductions favoring the rich. The budget embodies a divisive agenda for which Mr. Bush has no mandate, in spite of his popularity.

title: Jidda Journal; Muslims Feel Sept. 11 Chill As Mecca Plays It Cautious
description: As the hajj pilgrimage season gets under way, the Saudis are seeking security in the blink of an eye.

title: Restoration Of a Leonardo Is Ruled Out
description: Toward the back of an Uffizi Gallery warehouse here, an overstuffed storage closet for minor or damaged works of art, Leonardo da Vinci's unfinished masterpiece ''The Adoration of the Magi'' stands propped against a far wall, where it has been during months of diagnostic tests.

title: Moscow Stakes Claim to Afghan Role With High-Level Visit
description: Russia signaled its claims to influence in the new, post-Taliban Afghanistan today with a quick visit by the highest Moscow official to set foot here since the Soviet Union withdrew its last troops from the country nearly 13 years ago.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cruise Bid Rejected
description: P&O Princess Cruises rejected the Carnival Corporation's latest hostile takeover offer, and instead continued to recommend a rival deal between P&O Princess and Royal Caribbean Cruises. Carnival revised its offer last week by removing many of the conditions that P&O Princess had rejected, including Carnival's ability to find favorable financing and the ease with which P&O could dissolve a joint venture with Royal Caribbean in Southern Europe. Micky Arison, Carnival's chief executive, said the P&O board's focus on the Royal Caribbean proposal ''operates to the detriment of P&O Princess shareholders' interests.'' Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Twins Probably Safe This Year, and Contraction May Be Out
description: Major League Baseball asked the Minnesota Supreme Court for expedited action in its attempt to jettison the Minnesota Twins, and yesterday baseball got it. The action, however, was not what baseball wanted.

title: FREESTYLE SKIING
description: Ice, Snow and the Stars

title: A Solo for Piano, Complemented by 'Optional Drone'
description: The Contrasts Quartet played a concert of mostly new music last Tuesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, and the one oldie on the program, a 1919 work by Stravinsky, was not worlds away from the more recent pieces. This ensemble's instrumentation allows for considerable flexibility: the players are Vadim Lando, clarinetist; Monica Bauchwitz, violinist; Ariane Lallemand, cellist; and Evelyne Luest, pianist. And indeed the first two of the four works on the program were solo pieces.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sunday about Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's visit to Staten Island Chuck, a groundhog, misstated the animal's response in some copies. He failed to see his shadow and thus, tradition holds, foretold an early spring. He did not predict six more weeks of winter.

title: NORDIC COMBINED
description: EVERYONE WHO HAS won a medal in this event has come from a Norwegian hamlet, a Finnish village or a Japanese mountain retreat -- anywhere but a United States slope. Enter a 25-year-old from Steamboat Springs, Colo. More than any other American in the Nordic combined, Todd Lodwick has a shot to win a medal. Lodwick won his fifth World Cup event in Norway this season. When he finished 13th in Lillehammer in '94 and 20th in Nagano in '98, Lodwick excelled in the ski jumping but struggled with the cross-country portion. As he has grown, he has become one of the fastest skiers while trying to overcome jumping problems. While not a favorite, Lodwick is certainly the Americans' best hope.

title: ALPINE SKIING
description: FROM JEAN-CLAUDE KILLY to Franz Klammer to Picabo Street to Hermann Maier, the Alpine skiing events frequently bestow upon an Olympic Games its enduring glamour names. It could be the dashing speed or the manifest danger, but the skiing of dozens of gates and in the case of the downhill, an entire mountain, has always embodied the essence of the Winter Games.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Government And Rebels Meet
description: Representatives of the government and of the two main rebel groups met in Geneva to lay the groundwork for peace talks this month in South Africa. The meeting, held under United Nations auspices, included Congo's delegate to the United Nations in Geneva, and officials from the Movement for the Liberation of Congo and the Congolese Rally for Democracy. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: Oklahomans Try to Save Their California Culture
description: The relentless geometry of the farm fields still vanishes into infinity. When Earl Shelton, a 68-year-old retired oil refinery mechanic, walks the grounds of the former Weedpatch camp to which he and thousands of other Okies migrated during the Depression, the scrapbook in his mind turns to the image of Slab 529. That spit of concrete with a tent on it was home, on and off, for 13 years.

description: Senate Committee to Vote To Subpoena Ex-Enron Chief

title: Security Kicks In Before the Winter Games
description: Thirty minutes from landing, not the usual 15, the pilot of a United Airlines jet bound for Salt Lake City today told his passengers that they must be seated and buckled in for the rest of the flight.

title: A Game Named for Hyperbole Is Super
description: In the maniacal moments after New England's improbable victory over St. Louis, the Patriots' loquacious cornerback Ty Law, who never met an adjective he did not like, was asked where Super Bowl XXXVI ranked in N.F.L. championship history.

description: Good luck, Salt Lake City.

title: CROSS-COUNTRY SKIING
description: FRONT AND CENTER in Scandinavia, land of long winters and low mountains, cross-country events will be held way out in Soldier Hollow, an hour's drive from the Olympic stadium. It's traditionally a low priority for American television networks, but remember that while you are watching Michelle Kwan's triple-triple combination on the ice, Norwegians and Finns would rather watch low-body-fat men and women push their limits in the woods.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLOTKIN, HELEN
description: PLOTKIN-Helen. The officers, Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Helen Plotkin, a cherished friend who expressed an admirable commitment to Jewish and other humanitarian causes. Mrs. Plotkin's legacy lives on in the continuing efforts and exceptional generosity of the Plotkin family. We extend our deepest sympathies to her husband, Samuel; to her son, Fred, and his wife, Janet; to her son, Stuart, and his wife, Anita; to her daughter, Gail Staal, and her husband, Murray; to her daughter, Talib Ilutzi, and her husband, Herb Schwartz; to her eight grandchildren; to her two great-grandchildren; & to the entire Plotkin family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO Joan Ginsburg, Chair of the Women's Campaign

title: How an Eccentric Australian Found Motherhood at a Cambodian Orphanage
description: Unable to accept medical opinion that she would be unable to bear children, an Australian named Geraldine Cox began a procreative binge. She went through a series of lovers of various types, hoping one of them would help her defy the doctors. Still barren, she went to Bangkok, where, she says, she spent several months sleeping with gay male prostitutes, whom she hired to make her pregnant. When that failed, she adopted a baby girl with such severe disabilities that Ms. Cox felt compelled to part with her after years of trying to make it work.

title: Lindh Indicted on Terrorism Charges
description: John Walker Lindh, the 20-year-old Californian who fought against America with the Taliban and Al Qaeda in Afghanistan, was indicted today on charges that he conspired to murder American citizens.

title: Students Romp Fearlessly Through Serial Territory
description: The 12 tones were up and dancing in all kinds of ways last week at Juilliard Theater, where students, ably pointed by Joel Sachs, were making a series of forays into the serial legacy in the music of the last half century.

description: To the Editor:

title: Letting Forgiveness Prevail In Spite of All the Screaming
description: Although the new album by Sevendust is called ''Animosity,'' this quintet from Georgia made plenty of angry noises at the Hammerstein Ballroom last Tuesday night, but most of the songs ended on notes of forgiveness, not resentment. Early on, the lead singer, Lajon Witherspoon, delivered a mea culpa that reeked of pop psychology: ''Insensitive to all your needs/Did you ever want to stay with me?'' Perhaps John Gray has replaced Aleister Crowley on the heavy-metal reading list.

title: Hughes Won't Let Critics Slow Her Competitive Drive
description: Far removed from the hallways, classrooms and parking lots of Great Neck North High School, where typical teenagers inspect one another's taste in mall fashions, it's as if an anonymous note has been passed around about Sarah Hughes.

title: World Financial Center Reopens a Bit
description: For a while yesterday, office workers near ground zero could entertain the illusion that life was back to normal at the World Financial Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MESSINGER, DR. HENRY
description: MESSINGER-Dr. Henry. Age 89, of Southport, CT., a highly respected and much loved family practioner, died Sunday, February 3, 2002. He is survived by his wife, Beatrice Koblin Messinger and his daughter, Maris Messinger, both of Southport and his son, Dr. Barry Messinger and his wife, Geri of Manchester, CT. Services Tuesday, February 5, 2002, 11:00 AM from Abraham L. Green and Son 88 Beach Road, Fairfield, CT. Friends may call at 10:00 AM, with interment at Temple Israel Memorial Park in Blauvelt, NY.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Enterasys Shares Plunge
description: Shares in Enterasys Networks, a company that sells routers and switches to large corporations, fell 61.1 percent yesterday, after the company was downgraded by at least eight analysts. On Friday, the company said it was undergoing two accounting inquiries, one by KPMG, its internal auditor, and another by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Enterasys Networks also issued revenue estimates that were less than analysts had expected. The company, based in Rochester, N.H., said the two inquiries were unrelated. Enterasys shares ended the day at $4.20, down $6.60.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Bridgeton: 2 Prisoners Escape
description: The police and canine units are searching for two inmates who escaped on Saturday from the minimum-security prison where they were being held. The inmates, Michael Evans and Pedro Aviles, both 31 and considered nonviolent, were spotted less than a quarter of a mile from the South Woods State Prison at 8:55 a.m. on Sunday by a driver stopped at a red light. The driver notified the police, who informed the prison of the escape. Mr. Evans, who was in jail for drug possession, was due to be paroled on April 1, a Corrections Department spokeswoman said yesterday. Mr. Aviles, in jail for violating parole, was due to serve several more years. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Powell Says Administration Is Serious on 'Axis of Evil' Nations
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that President Bush's linkage of Iraq, Iran and North Korea into an "axis of evil," was "not a rhetorical flourish  he meant it," and he said that Iraq's overture to the United Nations to resume talks should amount to "a very short discussion," because weapons inspectors should immediately be allowed back in that country without conditions.

title: Tyco Shares Plunge On Growing Worries Of a Cash Squeeze
description: Wall Street grew increasingly nervous yesterday about the prospect of a cash squeeze at Tyco International after the company lost access to the commercial paper market, which is a major source of financing for big companies, and two debt rating agencies lowered their ratings on Tyco's bonds.

title: Orthopedics and Art Unite At (Where Else?) the U.N.
description: Bones -- fragile, misshapen, diseased and healed -- are the subject of an art exhibit that opened Jan. 22 at the United Nations. The artists are orthopedic patients, the doctors who treat them or people whose lives have been touched in some way by the human orthopedic condition. The ''Crouching Figure'' at right reflects an artist's struggle with scoliosis. In ''Structural Abnormalities,'' top far right, an artist depicts his painful disorder, Gaucher's disease, with a skeleton trying to break free from an uncomfortable space. The works of 85 artists, which are on an international tour, will be on display in the visitors' lobby of the General Assembly through Feb. 26. ''eMotion Pictures: an Exhibition of Orthopedics in Art'' was created and produced by the American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, JOEL
description: RUBIN-Joel. Devoted husband of the late Ruth. Adored father of Mel and Ellen, Ava and Edward, Donna and the late Karen. Loving Grandpa of Christopher and Joshua. Loving brother to his sisters and brothers. A most devoted son to his late parents, Sadie and Meyer Rubin. He will be sorely missed by all those who loved him. Graveside services today at 1:00 PM at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, New York.

description: ''Black Hawk Down'' is, regrettably, a pretty good movie.

description: GORDON-Jay. Of San Diego, CA, formerly of Great Neck, NY, died on February 2, 2002, at his home with his adoring family around him. Beloved soul mate of Sophia and devoted & dedicated father of James, Janina, and son-in-law, Jason. He was a professor of history at Queens College of the City University of New York for 33 years and will always be in the hearts and memories of his loving family.

title: Korean Organizers Upset by Bush's Speech
description: Officials in South Korea, which will be a co-host of the 2002 World Cup beginning May 31, were shocked last week when PRESIDENT BUSH included North Korea among the countries he labeled an ''axis of evil'' during his State of the Union address.

title: Anti-Tax Leader Confesses He Used Campaign Money
description: As the driving force behind several tax-cutting initiatives, Tim Eyman has sometimes been called the ''unelected governor'' of Washington State.

title: Shrewd Anticipation Helped Avert Trouble
description: Like a fastball pitcher brushing back a batter, the Police Department staked out a claim to its home plate -- the streets of New York City -- before the World Economic Forum even began, with a carefully choreographed strategy that officials say helped keep the peace by keeping protesters off balance.

title: Camby Out And Knicks Have No Easy Fixes
description: Even as a disembodied voice coming through a speakerphone in the Knicks' offices at Purchase College, Marcus Camby's pain, frustration, and resignation were evident.

title: Rise in Budget Is Not Enough, General Plans To Testify
description: Even with the $48 billion increase in military spending that President Bush has requested, the Pentagon will still fall tens of billions of dollars short of what is needed to replace aging aircraft, ships and tanks, senior military officials said today.

description: LUXENBERG-Leon. On February 3, 2002, of Elmont, NY. Devoted husband of Dorothy. Devoted father of Alan (Jan) and Michael (Joan). Brother of Selma. Grandfather of Harlan, Rebecca, Ben and Sam.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Protection From Radiation
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has signed a $1 million contract with a Branchville, N.J., company, Anbex.com, to supply up to six million doses of potassium iodide, a drug that can protect the human thyroid gland from a radioactive gas that can be released in a reactor accident. The order is the largest ever placed for the drug in this country, but is a small fraction of what might be required in a large-scale nuclear accident. In such an accident, children and adults under 40 might be advised to take the drug for two weeks, experts say. Matthew L. Wald (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, MARTHA
description: BERNSTEIN-Martha. An extraordinary life has ended, nearly a century after it began, and we are poorer for it. As matriarch of the Bernstein clan, she had the steely resolve to encourage and support her sons as they founded Sanford C. Bernstein and Co., and a tender touch to spread her love throughout her extensive family. Survived by son Paul, grandchildren Claude, Leslie, David, Stefanie and eight great-grandchildren; ''grandnana'' will be missed, but we are comforted knowing she finally is united with her husband Jacob, sister Edith and son Zalman. Paul, Peggy, Elaine, David and Stephanie

title: Some of the Many Views of Mammography
description: The news that some researchers were challenging the benefits of yearly screening mammograms has provoked widespread confusion and debate.

title: The Middle Class Struggles to Find Dollars
description: With banks and exchange houses closed today, the first day of a two-day emergency bank holiday declared this weekend, black market dollar-dealers -- known as arbolitos, or little trees, for all of their green -- are doing brisk business in the city center.

In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The First Battle Revival Alliance/Old Stone House, PO Box 150613, Brooklyn, New York 11215.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Airline Posts Loss
description: British Airways lost 44 million ($62.5 million) in the third quarter, in contrast to a profit of 36 million a year earlier. The carrier, which says it accounts for 14 percent of seats on flights between Europe and the United States, was one of the hardest hit after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, when many passengers canceled or delayed trips. British Airways has also felt the pinch from budget airlines like Ryanair and EasyJet, which are winning business on short-haul routes between European cities with cut-rate fares. Rod Eddington, British Airways chief executive, said he expected to finish a review of the business by the end of the month and would propose some ways to compete with the low-cost carriers. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Ex-Officer in the Louima Case Protests Conditions in Prison
description: Charles Schwarz, a former police officer who is serving a 15-year prison term for the assault on Abner Louima, filed legal papers yesterday asserting that prison authorities are holding him in inhumane conditions, including keeping him in a solitary-confinement ''hole'' with a concrete slab for a bed and limiting his recreation to ''one hour a day in an animal cage.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Sulzer's Shares Surge
description: Shares in Sulzer Medica rose 21 percent to 111 Swiss francs ($65.34), the highest level in more than four months, after the company, Europe's largest orthopedics maker, said it and its parent company, the machinery maker Sulzer, had agreed to a $1 billion settlement of faulty hip and knee implant claims. The agreement, which requires court approval, would settle lawsuits by thousands of claimants in the United States. Sulzer said it settled to avoid the cost of lengthy litigation. Claimants may still drop out of the class if they are dissatisfied with the terms. Sulzer still faces hundreds of claims outside the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRISHMAN, ARTHUR, M.D.
description: GRISHMAN-Arthur, M.D. The Association of the Attending Staff of the Mount Sinai Hospital mourns the passing of a beloved colleague, teacher, and friend. Dr. Grishman was an internationally known Cardiologist and a prominent member of the attending staff for more than 30 years. He received his early medical training in Heidelberg and Berlin and began his Cardiology training at Mount Sinai in 1939. He was recognized as an authority in Vectorcardiography and as a brilliant clinician and teacher. We extend our sincere condolences to his entire family. Anthony Squire, M.D., President Vicki Lopachin, M.D., Secretary Amy Weinstein, Administrator

title: School Board Revises Plans For Most New Construction
description: Facing the possibility of a 26 percent cut in its capital budget, the Board of Education has submitted a revised construction plan to the Bloomberg administration that would delay by one year the construction of all but three new Queens high schools listed in the budget that the board passed in December.

title: Acrobatic Ape in Java Is in High-Wire Survival Struggle
description: Their heads and bare faces fringed by Bozo the Clown hair, high-flying gibbons are often called the greatest acrobats of the animal kingdom. Using their hands like hooks, these small apes swing through the canopies of Southeast Asian rain forests at breakneck speed, often leaping 30 feet between tree limbs.
