title: Bush Visits Troops to Open Drive for Arms Budget Rise
description: President Bush invoked the threat of terrorism and a sense of patriotism today to try to sell the nation and Congress on supporting the biggest increase in the nation's military budget in a generation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOCHFELD, ALEX
description: GOCHFELD-Alex. Age 88 on January 26, 2002. He lived most of his life at Mohegan Lake where he died surrounded by his family. Born in Paris, France in 1913, he was educated at CCNY. A gifted linguist, he worked as an interpreter at the United Nations and was proud of his involvement in the debates leading to the ''Universal Declaration of Human Rights''. He founded Alex Gochfeld Associates to provide marketing research to the non-profit sector. He served on the Mohegan Colony board, including as president. In retirement he enjoyed painting, photography, nature, and he loved leading his discussion group on ethics and world affairs. He is survived by Anne, his cherished wife of 64 years, and by loving children Michael and Robert, their wives Joanna and Elizabeth, by grandchildren Deborah, Jennifer, David, Douglas, and by nephews, nieces and grandnieces all of whom will miss him greatly. A Memorial Service February 23rd, 1 P.M. at Mohegan Colony Nursery School. Call 914-528-4402.

title: Sell That Dress: Back To Basics In Spring Advertising
description: Last fall, the advertising campaign Tom Ford created for Gucci revolved around a blond model who seemed to need an anger-management seminar. In one image she was seated on wall-to-wall carpeting in an unfurnished room, her hand aggressively on her jutting hip. She wore nothing that had not begun its life in a cow pen: black leather boots, a black leather miniskirt, a black leather blazer buttoned just at the rib cage, to reveal a chest no one would mistake for Sophia Loren's. Central to Mr. Ford's ethos is that women should dress for men, though this woman seemed to have styled herself for the kind of man who could help her enter the arms-peddling business.

title: Sighs of Relief Mix With Cheers in Boston
description: Nobody knows the cringing pain of defeat better than the Boston sports fan.

title: Students Return to Two Elementary Schools Shut Down After Terror Attack
description: On Friday, Brook Peters and his mother, Michelle, walked through Public School 150 for the first time since Sept. 11, just to see what it would be like.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, LIPKA, SARA
description: WEISS-LIPKA-Sara. Of Tamarac, Florida, formerly of Sea Gate Harbor, New York. Died February 2, 2002. A woman who was passionately devoted to her family. Loving wife to her husband Morris Lipka and her deceased husband Max Weiss. Mother to Jeffrey Weiss & Louise Kornfeld. Motherin-law to Stephen Kornfeld and Nancy Weiss. Survived by her brother David Fils and sister Bella Schwartz. Grandmother to Adam, Karyn, Joanna, Darren & Lauren. Services Schwartz Bros., Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, February 5th, at 1:30 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAURICE, JULIEN
description: MAURICE-Julien, 65. Of New York City, beloved nephew of Sadye Aaronson and loving friend of Gregory Bogert, Yael Gani, Michael Gary, and Jacqueline Palmer, died on Sunday, February 3, after a long illness. title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday of Harvey Matusow, a paid F.B.I. informer who recanted his accusations of Communist associations in the 1950's, misspelled the surname of the author of "The Great Fear," who wrote that such paid witnesses sold hunches as inside knowledge. He was David Caute, not Cante.

title: Nala Najan, 69, Advocate of Indian Dance
description: Nala Najan, an American-born choreographer and performer who also wrote about the traditional dances of India, died on Jan. 7. He was 69 and lived in Manhattan.

title: As Troubles Multiply, the Equation Changes
description: Do the math, President Bush told Congress a year ago. The projected budget surplus, he said, was so large that the nation could afford the biggest tax cut in two decades and still have plenty left over to address its other needs and keep a buffer in reserve.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Another Jail Term For Legislator
description: A member of Parliament who has already served two one-week jail sentences was sentenced to one month in prison and ordered to pay an $11,000 fine for failing to provide a corruption investigation with details of his dozens of bank accounts and other documents. Liam Lawlor, who also faces a censure motion in Parliament, is being investigated along with other politicians and business figures in connection with corruption in planning and zoning. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: IT'S WIN OR WIPE OUT
description: Inside the high-tech moat built to secure the Salt Lake Winter Games, past the magnetometers and checkpoints, a world of spectators will find the way to a free-spirited American skier who was reared in a cabin lighted by kerosene lamps.

title: A Rare Day: The Movies Get Mental Illness Right
description: It was 1980 and the patient in Dr. Glen Gabbard's consulting room had a pressing request.

title: Global Crossing Denies Charge By Employee
description: Global Crossing Ltd., the fiber optic network operator that sought bankruptcy protection, said today that an employee who questioned its accounting practices demanded cash to drop a lawsuit over his dismissal in a round of layoffs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERRINI, HONORABLE JOSEPH J.
description: PERRINI-Honorable Joseph J. The Queens County Bar Association records with deep sorrow the passing on February 2, 2002 of its distinguished member and past president from 1958-1959. Seymour W. James, Jr., President

title: Freestyle Skiing
description: Once known as hot-dog skiing, freestyle is now so mainstream it has fostered its own third-generation splinter movement, the X Games.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERRELONGE, LYNN R.
description: TERRELONGE-Lynn R. We are deeply saddened by the loss of Lynn R. Terrelonge, President of the Brooklyn Bar Association, beloved wife, mother, grandmother, relative, friend & mentor to many.

title: Making the Most of Positive Role Models
description: Mentoring programs and other efforts to provide positive role models to adolescents in the hope of steering them away from risky behavior have been on the rise, although over the years there has been little solid evidence on the effectiveness of positive role models.

title: CURLING
description: CURLING traces its origins to 16th century Scotland, but the first Olympic gold medal in the contests of intense concentration, strategy and skill were not awarded until the 1998 Nagano Games.

title: Annan Cautions Business as Forum Ends
description: United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan closed the World Economic Forum yesterday with a stern message from the devastation of Sept. 11, which had brought the gathering to New York and posed many of the issues that dominated the five-day meeting of business and political leaders from around the world.

title: Decoding Enron
description: As the evidence of financial abuses at Enron grows, the more it looks as though the company was an intricate Ponzi scheme designed to enrich top executives and defraud stockholders. That, at least, is the impression left by a scalding examination of the company's operations prepared by a special committee of Enron's board of directors. The report, issued over the weekend, suggests that rather than being a thriving corporation brought down by accounting shenanigans, Enron at its core may have been a corporate mirage created to deceive the public while enriching insiders. Enron's leadership comes across as having been more concerned with managing the stock price, and profiting from it, than with running a real company.

title: BIATHLON
description: SOLDIER HOLLOW is an appropriate name for an Olympic biathlon site. The sport developed because it honed the skills of Scandinavian military men, who needed to ski fast and shoot accurately. The first race on record was in 1767, and the Norwegian military began organizing regular competitions in the early 20th century. Though Americans have little interest in biathlon, it gets significant coverage in Europe, where commentators can make a missed target seem like a matter of major import.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUTLER, PAUL
description: BUTLER-Paul. On February 3, 2002. Retired NYPD Sergeant. Beloved husband of Myrna. Devoted father of Tommy and Joey, and stepfather of JoAnn Vazquez and Debbie Panso. Dear father-in-law of Suzi and Patti. Loving brother of Mary Farrell. Cherished grandfather of 7. Visitation Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Service on Wednesday, 11:30AM, at ''The Riverside.''

title: Iraq Proposes U.N. Talks, And Gets a Wary Reply
description: Confronted with growing threats from Washington, Iraq has offered to have a dialogue ''without preconditions'' with Secretary General Kofi Annan, the United Nations reported today. Mr. Annan replied that ''he will check his calendar,'' a United Nations statement said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOSEE, THOMAS P., JR.
description: LOSEE-Thomas P., Jr. We loved him like a brother. His incredible spirit will be with us forever. Alan and Suzanne Waxenberg

title: Study Discounts Halting Irrigation to Protect Fish
description: Government efforts to save rare fish in the Klamath River basin last year by stopping irrigation, which enraged farmers along the Oregon-California border, are not supported by science, according to a National Academy of Sciences study requested by the Bush administration.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Technology Concerns To Aid Foundation
description: The Markle Foundation and the United Nations Development Program plan to announce today that they have secured support from an initial group of technology companies and nonprofit organizations for a project aimed at bridging the digital divide in the developing world. The group, which includes Sun Microsystems, Hewlett-Packard, AOL Time Warner and the Harvard Center for International Development, has pledged to spend about $10 million in cash, resources and labor the next two years on strategies that use technology to improve the quality of life in 12 developing nations. Markle, which focuses on financing projects that use technology to improve social welfare, began promoting the Global Digital Opportunity Initiative with the United Nations when the governments of the group of eight industrialized nations created a task force on the global digital divide in July 2000. Amy Harmon (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEB, THELMA
description: LOEB-Thelma. Suddenly Jan. 20, in Boca Raton. Formerly of Borough Park, Brooklyn. Mourned by her loving family, many friends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROLNICK, STANLEY
description: ROLNICK-Stanley. A truly wonderful friend who will be greatly missed. Loved by all who knew him. Millie and Danny

title: SKELETON
description: DEPENDING ON HOW one looks at it, skeleton has either the most intriguing or the most morbid name of any sport in the Olympics. Maybe it is deserving of that, because it also happens to be the most extreme event in the Winter Games. A Latvian rider was killed during a run in October when, going 36 miles an hour, he slammed headfirst into the blade of an errant sled.

title: Keeping the Focus, Amid Grief, a Lawsuit and a Fire
description: SOMETIMES running a diocese is a little like handling mercury, said Bishop Mark S. Sisk, the new Episcopal leader in New York. The work can be difficult to pin down, hard to define.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Oil Strategy Emphasized
description: Russia may scrap reductions in crude oil exports in the second quarter if American and European economies show signs of growth, Mikhail Kasyanov, the Russian prime minister, said after meeting with President Bush in Washington, according to Russia's Itar-Tass news agency. The comment followed a similar statement over the weekend, when Mr. Kasyanov, at the World Economic Forum in New York, said the country's energy strategy is to increase oil production. Russia is flexing its muscles as the world's No. 2 oil producer and its stance has created tension with the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, which has been pushing for cuts in output to help support prices. Sabrina Tavernese (NYT)

title: Turmoil Grows as Argentine Fiscal Crisis Deepens
description: The Argentine government ordered the country's banks to stop dealing in foreign currency today and to hand over all the dollars they had to the central bank. The moves extended the steps the government took on Sunday to convert all dollar-denominated debts and deposits in the country to pesos at rates far below those offered on the open market.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Credit Ratings Downgraded
description: The Toshiba Corporation and the NEC Corporation, two of Japan's largest electronics makers, had their credit ratings slashed after they reported losses in their chip businesses during the October-to-December quarter and lowered their forecasts for the full fiscal year. Moody's Investors Service cut Toshiba's long-term debt rating to Baa1, three notches above junk status, from A3, while NEC's rating fell to Baa2 from Baa1. Toshiba could face another downgrade, while the outlook for NEC is stable. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Alaska: Ultrasound System To Count Salmon
description: State fishery managers are planning to test a system this summer that will use ultrasound to estimate runs of sockeye and king salmon up the Copper, Kenai and Wood River systems. Private fisheries are providing $10,000 for testing the technology, developed at the University of Washington, in July. If the system works, Alaska will buy it for $80,000, Debby Burwen, the state biologist, said. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: A No-Frills Champion
description: Tom Brady seemed genuinely surprised when the National Football League gave him the Most Valuable Player award and a fancy Cadillac S.U.V. after he helped engineer the New England Patriots' astonishing 20-17 upset of the St. Louis Rams in Sunday night's Super Bowl. ''That's my car?'' he asked. It was one of the many nice touches in this year's game: in an arena full of multimillionaire superstars who probably have at least two Porsches in the driveway, the star of the show turns out to be a low-paid, second-year quarterback to whom a $50,000 car still makes a difference. On top of that he called it a ''team car'' and said that everyone could take a turn at the wheel, a tribute to his fellow Patriots that would have been cloying were it not so unaffected.

A three-day Sydney Explorer Pass, with unlimited use of buses, ferries and trains, is $50 more. Hotel upgrades are available; departures through March 31. A plan that combines the five nights in Sydney with two nights each in the New Zealand cities of Auckland and Rotorua (with a traditional Maori dinner) starts at $1,699 a person, with air fare from Los Angeles and the Explorer Pass. Departures through August; from New York, $425 extra. Call (800) 571-1102.

title: It Was Clinton at Waldorf Instead of Dessert

But at 10:10 p.m. Sunday, just as diners savored the last scraps of braised veal cheeks, the word came down: ''If you are going to the Clinton nightcap, it's completely full, and the buses are leaving for the Waldorf right now!''

title: VISTEON TO SELL AIR BAG SENSOR UNIT TO AUTOLIV
description: The Visteon Corporation, a leading maker of auto parts, agreed to sell its Restraint Electronics air bag sensor unit to Autoliv Inc., an air bag maker, for $25 million to focus on larger businesses. About 1,000 Visteon workers at a plant in Markham, Ontario, will lose their jobs and about 200 engineers in Dearborn, Mich., will probably shift to Autoliv, a Visteon spokesman, Greg Gardner, said. Autoliv will get about $150 million in annual sales to Ford Motor and affiliates in Europe and North America. Visteon is cutting back because Ford, its largest customer, is building fewer vehicles as its sales slow. Visteon, spun off by Ford in June 2000, had a fourth-quarter loss of $14 million.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Global Job Cuts At Gemplus
description: The maker of chip-embedded smart cards, Gemplus, is announcing plans this week to cut as many as 1,200 jobs globally, or 18 percent of its work force, according to French labor representatives, because of collapsed sales to cellphone makers, who account for roughly half of total revenue. Gemplus, which already cut 900 jobs last year, is expected to report a loss for 2001 of 120 million euros, or $103 million, when it reports financial results tomorrow.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Sales Fell In December
description: Global chip sales in December declined 4 percent from November, bringing to an end the worst year in the industry's history, according to the Semiconductor Industry Association. It said chip makers recorded sales of $10.18 billion, a slight decline from $10.6 billion in November and a 43 percent plunge from $17.89 billion in December 2000. Sales for 2001 were down 32 percent. Despite growth in the United States, Europe and Asia, fourth-quarter sales were flat versus the third quarter because the slumping Japanese economy dragged down sales by 12 percent there, the association said. George Scalise, the association's president, predicted that first-quarter sales would be flat or slightly up from the fourth quarter, instead of the flat-to-down sales common for that period. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEALESSANDRO, JOSEPH P.
description: DeALESSANDRO-Joseph P., 71. On February 2, 2002 in Westfield, NJ. Beloved and devoted husband of the late Dorothy. Cherished son of the late Peter Charles and Lucy Rose. Beloved brother of Frank and Barbara. Revered and loved uncle of Joseph, Joan & Howard. Dedicated companion of Jeanette. Dr. DeAlessandro began his career in the insurance industry specializing in automobile and fire insurance. He honed his skills in many companies including American Insurance Company, 1952-60, Century Insurance Company, 196062, St. Paul Insurance Company, 1962-67. Became president of National Union Fire Insurance Company in 1967, also Director, Senior Vice President of American International underwriters, 1970; Executive Vice President, Director American Home Insurance Co. 1973; President, Director of American International Global Assistance Corp; Chairman of the Board, American International Group Political Risk, Inc., President and Director, American International Group Entertainment; President and Director, American International Group Assistance Incorporated; Director, United Guarantee Company; Senior Vice President, American International Underwriters. Most of the innovations he was involved in were developed in the 20 years he spent at the American International Group, Inc. In that time, he and his team at the AIG subsidiary, National Union Fire Insurance Co. of Pittsburgh, PA., where he became president, helped nurture directors and officers liability coverage from a fledgling product to indispensable insurance protection for corporations; created Employee Retirement Income Security Act fiduciary liability coverage; developed kidnap and ransom insurance for bankers; and developed private political risk insurance in the United States. After he retired from AIG in the mid 1980's, Mr. DeAlessandro helped Sanford Weill build Commercial Credit into the Travelers Group through a series of takeovers. After retiring again, he took on his present job in the early 1990's as a partner in American European Group, which specializes in taking over and turning around insurance companies, including Kentucky National Insurance Co. and Rutgers Casualty Insurance Co. Mr. DeAlessandro was president and CEO of both companies. Received the Professional Liability Underwriting Society's 1992 PLUS 1 award. Appointed to the President's Counsel of Brandeis University in 1990. Received Brandeis Distinguished Community Services Award in 1988. Elected Knight Commander, Order of Saint John and Knight Commander Grand Cross of Honor and Merit, named Man of the Year by the UJA Federation in 1987 and UJA Jericho, NY in 1986. Received an Honorary Doctorate in Fine Arts from the Culinary Institute of America in 1999. A man of enormous knowledge, talent and distinction. He will be missed greatly by his family, many friends and colleagues. Services at Dooley Colonial Home, 556 Westfield Ave., Westfield, NJ., Tuesday, February 5, 2002, 7-9 PM, Wednesday, February 6, 2002, 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM. Holy Mass at St. Helen RC Church, Thursday, February 7, 2002, 10 AM. Interment at Fairview Cemetery, Westfield, NJ. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the American Diabetes Assn.

The 90-year-old tradition of stacking logs as high as 60 feet for a bonfire before an annual football game with the University of Texas was suspended after 11 students and a former student were killed when the logs collapsed in 1999. Dr. Bowen said students should create a safer tradition. Ross E. Milloy (NYT)

title: SKI JUMPING
description: STILL THE MOST breathtaking event at the Winter Games, ski jumping has been dominated by the Nordic nations since a Norwegian daredevil by the name of Sondre Nordheim became the first measured ski jumper in 1860. But the Japanese, swelling with national pride in 1998, conquered the sport in Nagano. Japan won four of nine medals, including the team competition. The Germans, Austrians and Finns are now considered the sport's elite. Sven Hannawald of Germany this season became the first skier in its 50 years to sweep the Four Hills competition in Germany and Austria, the sport's biggest non-Olympic event. But Adam Malysz of Poland won 6 of 13 World Cup events to lead in the point standing this season. He is viewed as a national hero and should become the first Pole to bring home a medal in the event in 30 years.

title: SHORT-TRACK SPEEDSKATING
description: FORGET ABOUT roller derby on ice. This sport is more like ''Survivor'' on ice. Competitors race counterclockwise in a pack, jockey for position at speeds up to 40 miles an hour and inevitably crash, always in danger of being gashed by another skater's blade. First one to complete the requisite number of laps wins. Unlike long track speedskating, the athletes compete against one another and not the clock.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Jersey City: 3 Charged In Killing
description: Three robbery suspects were accused of murder yesterday, after a store owner who had been beaten unconscious died over the weekend. The suspects -- Patrina Crawford, 19, and James Williams, 28, both of Jersey City, and Dennis Goldberg, 27, of Linden -- had been charged with armed robbery and aggravated assault, said Terrence Hull, the first assistant Hudson County prosecutor. He said the suspects used a pellet gun to beat Robert Chute, 61, the owner of High Tec Dry Cleaning in Bayonne, on Jan. 13. Mr. Chute died of head injuries on Saturday at Jersey City Medical Center, Mr. Hull said. The suspects did not have lawyers and could not be reached for comment. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: The Big City; Beer, Football, And a Glut Of Patriotism

Some people took their flags down when the Taliban fell; others waited until the end of the year; many others kept them up. But now we have as good an answer as we are going to get: after the Super Bowl.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Backlog at Dna Laboratory
description: Demand for DNA testing in rape cases has led to a growing backlog at the state's forensic laboratory, according to an Essex Country prosecutor. Reports that the countries are working on a joint sovereignty arrangement to end a dispute that has soured relations between the European allies and held up European Union legislation have prompted the colony's chief minister, Peter Caruana, who wants Britain to retain full sovereignty, to boycott the talks. Britain said it would keep its pledge to hold a referendum on any new plan among Gibraltar's 30,000 English-speaking residents, who insist that they want to remain solely British. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEIDT, JOHN C, JR.
description: SCHEIDT-John C, Jr. Major General (USAF Retired). Age 67, passed away on Friday, February 1, 2002. General Scheidt was born in 1934, in Brooklyn, N.Y., where he graduated from Brooklyn Technical High School in 1952. He received a Bachelor's Degree from New York University in 1958 and a Master of Arts Degree in Business Administration from Auburn University in 1970. General Scheidt was commissioned as a second lieutenant through the Air Force Reserve Officer Training Corps program and entered primary pilot training in July 1958. During his 32 years of active duty, General Scheidt served in numerous important flying and staff assignments until he retired on August 1, 1990. General Scheidt, call sign ''Hunter,'' was a Command Pilot with more than 3,600 flying hours. His military awards and decorations include the Distinguished Service Medal, Defense Superior Service Medal, Legion of Merit, Distinguished Flying Cross with oak leaf cluster, Meritorious Service Medal with oak leaf cluster, Air Medal with 13 oak leaf clusters, Air Force Commendation Medal, Combat Readiness Medal, National Defense Service Medal, Vietnam Service Medal with five service stars, Republic of Vietnam Gallantry Cross with Palm, and Republic of Vietnam Campaign Medal. Known fondly to family and friends as ''Jack'', General Scheidt's immediate family survivors include his loving wife of 43 years, Vivian Scheidt of Green Valley, AZ; son John Scheidt and his wife Vera of Tucson, AZ; daughter Susan Scheidt of San Diego, CA; son TSgt. Stephen Scheidt of Kunsan, Korea; daughter Jackie Ankley and her husband Jeff of Virginia Beach, VA; son Michael Scheidt and his wife Megan of Sterling, VA; and four granddaughters, Jackie, Susanna, Sarah and Joanna Scheidt of Tucson, AZ. In addition to immediate family, Jack is survived by three sisters-in-law, Dorothy Schneider of Maspeth, NY, Clare Connors of Spring, TX, and Jackie Jorgenson and her husband Chris of Las Vegas, NV. Jack is also survived by his dearest friend and most cherished fellow ''Warrior'' in the U.S. Air Force; Colonel Steve Kelley of San Antonio, TX. A funeral mass will be said at Our Lady of the Valley Catholic Church in Green Valley, AZ at 1 P.M. on Thursday, February 7, 2002, followed immediately by burial. Flowers may be sent to Our Lady of the Valley Catholic Church in Green Valley, AZ, or a memorial donation may be made to the American Cancer Society in Jack's name.

Romance, a late-harvest seyval, is the lightest. Desire is blackberry, and Embrace is raspberry; both are excellent added to Champagne. All are fortified with grape spirits and have a pleasing hint of tartness. Ben and Phyllis Feder, the owners of the vineyard, wanted to put hearts on the labels, but the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms -- diligent, but unromantic about such matters -- said no, because they could imply that the wine was good for the heart. The set of three 375-milliliter bottles is $79.50 at Vintage New York, 482 Broome Street (Wooster Street); Astor Wines & Spirits, 12 Astor Place (Lafayette Street); and McCabe's Wines & Spirits, 1347 Third Avenue (77th Street).

TiVo said the action was in response to a patent suit that SonicBlue filed against TiVo after SonicBlue received its own patent. ''We take litigation very seriously and feel that this action is the appropriate legal response,'' TiVo said. The SonicBlue chief executive, Ken Potashner, denied that the company had infringed the patent named in TiVo's suit. When the market for beamed money proved elusive, it switched to enabling people to e-mail each other cash. Mr. Thiel and Mr. Levchin, who declared that their little start-up would revolutionize commerce, persuaded venture capitalists to pour in more than $225 million.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Ryanair Posts Profit
description: The Irish discount air carrier Ryanair announced a 35 percent increase in after-tax profits for the three months ended in December, to 28.8 million euros ($32.5 million), while passenger numbers rose 30 percent, to 2.7 million. Operating costs rose more slowly than revenue, at 15 percent. The chief executive, Michael O'Leary, credited the strong figures to aggressive ticket pricing and controlling fuel costs.

title: Korean Spareribs That Sing With Spice
description: THOUGH many of us consider spareribs -- especially the barbecued kind -- strictly American, they are prepared all over the world in a variety of ways: braised, stir-fried or grilled with no seasonings at all. No technique makes more sense, however, than the one used in Korea, where ribs are first poached and then dry-roasted in their own fat, with a dose of strong seasonings.

title: KENNY ALBERT TO REPLACE EMRICK
description: Kenny Albert, the radio voice of the Rangers, will replace Mike Emrick on NBC's hockey telecasts from the Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City. Emrick, who calls Devils games on Fox Sports New York, asked to be replaced because of his dog's illness.

title: 2 Officials Are Expected To Leave the Company
description: Two of the senior Enron executives who were sharply criticized in a report by a special committee of the board are expected to leave the company.

title: World Business Briefing | Middle East: Saudi Arabia: Recession Expected
description: Saudi Arabia will suffer its worst recession this year since 1985 because of a decline in oil production and prices, stalling efforts to cut unemployment, the Saudi American Bank reported. The gross domestic product of the country, the world's largest oil exporter, is expected to contract 2 percent, compared with growth of 1.5 percent in 2001, the bank's chief economist, Brad Bourland, said. The economy contracted 4 percent in 1985.

title: U.S. Frees 27 Afghan Detainees Mistakenly Identified as Taliban
description: Twenty-seven detainees were freed by American forces in Afghanistan today after it was determined that they were not Taliban forces and did not have any links to Osama bin Laden's Al Qaeda terror network.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROSBY, AMANDA T.
description: CROSBY-Amanda T. On February 4th, 2002, of New York City, formerly of Summit, NJ, daughter of John and Betsy Crosby of Summit, NJ, sister of Jay Crosby of Brooklyn, NY. A Memorial Service will be held on Saturday, February 9, 2002 at 3 PM at the Kent Place School Field House, Summit, NJ. Please omit flowers. Anyone so desiring may contribute in her name to the Raptor Trust, 1390 White Bridge Road, Millington, New Jersey 07946.

title: Tenet's Testimony Before Senate Committee
description: Following is the testimony of George J. Tenet, director of central intelligence, to the Senate Select Intelligence Committee yesterday as transcribed by the Federal News Service Inc.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Fraying Ties With Blacks, Los Angeles Mayor Opposes Rehiring Police Chief
description: Mayor James K. Hahn stunned many here today when he announced that he opposed giving a new contract to the police chief, Bernard Parks, angering many of the black leaders who helped Mr. Hahn win election last year.

title: Fatal House Fire Quiets a Newark Street and Leaves a Father in Jail
description: Traffic moved slowly along the 700 block of Mount Prospect Avenue today, where an impromptu shrine of candles, balloons and dolls had been set up in front of the bulldozed remains of a house where two little girls died in a fire Monday morning.

title: Deloitte Is Last Big Audit Firm To Revamp Consulting Business
description: Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu announced yesterday that it would separate its accounting business from its consulting business in response to growing pressure from investors, regulators and clients in the wake of the Enron collapse.

title: Satellite Agreement For Yankees Games
description: The YES Network made its first deal yesterday to guarantee that viewers can see Yankees games, but it was not with local cable companies like Time Warner, Cablevision or Comcast.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: A Sit-On Part?

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Oversight Of School District
description: State lawmakers will take up legislation to give a ''crisis management'' panel control of the personnel and financial decisions for the school system in Prince George's County, a move that would strip the school board of power in one of the nation's biggest districts. The move came after a Circuit Court judge ruled that the school board violated its contract with Superintendent Iris T. Metts when it voted on Saturday to end her term immediately. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: Street Wants to Carry The American Flag
description: Picabo Street does not need a publicity campaign to raise her Olympic profile in Utah, her adopted state. Street's face is already visible on billboards all over Salt Lake City and nearby Park City, her hometown in the last several years.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Jan. 30 about Nevada's decision to deny Mike Tyson a license to fight there misspelled the name of the boxer's lawyer. He is Robert Faiss, not Fraiss.

title: Enron Is Grist for Business School Courses
description: Business school professors across the country say they are latching onto the Enron scandal as a way to make courses on everything from Accounting 101 to crisis management come alive.

title: Baseball Won't Drop Teams in 2002
description: Unable to hurdle legal roadblocks, Major League Baseball yesterday abandoned its plan to eliminate the Minnesota Twins and the Montreal Expos for the coming season. Commissioner Bud Selig strongly stated his intention to shed at least two teams and as many as four for the 2003 season, but circumstances, including more legal challenges, could also short-circuit the new plan.

title: Bridge at Olympics Reaches Semifinals
description: A Canadian team and three European teams qualified for playoffs in the men's division at the International Olympic Committee's bridge championship in Salt Lake City on Monday. Italy was a clear winner in the qualifying competition despite the absence of Norberto Bocchi, one of its key players.

title: Knicks Let One Get Away At Garden
description: The talented and nimble opponent was reeling like a dazed prizefighter. Deflated by the Knicks' pinpoint execution and razor-sharp shooting, the Los Angeles Clippers had all but recorded last night's game in the loss column.

title: Will Autos Be a Part Of the Future For Fiat?
description: First it began diversifying, scaling back the car division's share of total revenue. Then, losses year after year made it clear that the auto division was the sick man in the portfolio. Now the big question about Fiat, the Italian conglomerate, is whether it has an independent future making cars.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Designed to Stand Out in a Crowd
description: The builders and operators of the new Westin Hotel, which is scheduled to open this November at Eighth Avenue and 43rd Street in Manhattan, wanted to draw attention to the building. So they commissioned the Miami firm of Arquitectonica to design a building that would cry look at me even over the profusion of brightly lighted signs in Times Square.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Editor Won't Be Prosecuted
description: Prosecutors declined to press charges against Basildon Peta, a newspaper editor who was arrested under new security laws, his lawyers said. Mr. Peta, who was arrested and released on Monday, was initially charged with organizing a demonstration without notifying the police. But prosecutors found that the law allows for professional groups to hold public meetings without permission from the authorities. Mr. Peta is the secretary general of the Zimbabwe Union of Journalists and his organization was protesting the country's tough new media law. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: At 80, McKay Is Set For Another Stint
description: Jim McKay is 80 now and jokes about being smaller than in his younger days. He is under contract to ABC Sports, but there is no work on his schedule. He has traveled four and a half million miles to work over the past 40 years and now prefers a life of serenity here in a 19th-century farmhouse in horse country with his wife, Margaret, who thrills him still after 53 years.

title: Mideast Peace Formula
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: School Bus Struck By Car
description: Six young children suffered minor injuries yesterday when their school bus was struck by a car, the police said. The bus, run by a private company, flipped on its side after it was hit by the car at 17th Avenue and 149th Street in Whitestone, Queens, about 2:20 p.m. The children, students at the Clearview School, were taken to Booth Memorial Hospital. Three were released yesterday, and the police said they expected the others to be sent home. The bus driver, Bart Silverman, 42, received a summons because he lacked the required license, they said. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: A Renewed Pledge of Aid, and a Mea Culpa
description: Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., the White House budget director, said today that he regretted the way he had characterized New York's efforts to wring money from Washington to help it rebuild from the attack on the World Trade Center.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Montana: A Talk With The Governor
description: Environmentalists seek a meeting with Gov. Judy Martz after she called them obstructionists in a recent talk with loggers. Governor Martz, a Republican, said she would lobby on the loggers' behalf, blaming environmentalists for their financial problems. The dispute concerns plans to salvage burned timber in the Bitterroot National Forest. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: President of Yemen Says It Is Pursuing 2 Men Wanted by the U.S.
description: President Ali Abdullah Saleh said today that his security forces were closing in on two suspected Qaeda terrorists sought by the United States, but that he was depending for the moment on tribal chieftains to locate the men and persuade them to surrender.

title: Full Text: Government Response to Lindh Petition
description: IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT FOR THE EASTERN DISTRICT OF VIRGINIA

title: A Judge Denies Bail to Lindh, Who Will Stay Jailed During Trial
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Feb. 6  In a swift and firm ruling, a federal magistrate said today that John Walker Lindh, the Californian captured with anti-American forces in Afghanistan, had to stay in prison while he awaited trial on charges that he conspired to kill his countrymen.

title: Circling the Mammography Wagons
description: As the debate over the value of mammography intensifies, it is disappointing that key organizations and individuals in the cancer establishment have mostly chosen to draw their wagons in a defensive circle. Now that recent studies have raised serious challenges to the value of mammograms, other experts need to examine the data with an open mind if the public is to retain its faith in the recommendations of prestigious medical organizations.

title: Shares of Sprint PCS And Nextel Plummet
description: Shares of Nextel Communications tumbled 26 percent and those of the Sprint PCS Group slid 20 percent on concern that slower growth in subscribers would make it harder for the companies to reduce debt.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the distribution of prepaid MasterCards at the World Economic Forum in New York misspelled the surname of a Harvard Law School professor who commented on the promotion. He was Jonathan L. Zittrain, not Zittorain.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: New State Treasurer
description: The General Assembly elected Nancy K. Kopp, a longtime state delegate, as the next state treasurer. Ms. Kopp, a 58-year-old Democrat, has represented Montgomery County, just outside Washington, since 1975. She succeeds Richard N. Dixon, who resigned last week because of diabetes-related illness. Ms. Kopp will oversee the state's $28 billion pension system and serve on the Board of Public Works, which has final say on major state contracts. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: Levy Seeks More Albany Aid
description: Chancellor HAROLD O. LEVY went to Albany yesterday to warn lawmakers that GOV. GEORGE E. PATAKI's budget proposal could harm city schools, even though the plan appears to reduce aid to the Board of Education only slightly. Mr. Levy said that building aid to New York City would sharply decline, a factor that he said was not addressed in the governor's budget proposal. He also said that Mr. Pataki's staff had overestimated by $27 million the amount of transportation aid that New York was to get. He said it was especially crucial that the state allot more funds for teacher recruitment. Abby Goodnough

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Contraceptive Bill Advances
description: The State Senate passed a bill yesterday requiring health insurers to cover contraceptives for women, after greatly narrowing an exemption it had created for the Roman Catholic Church. But the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, left, called the bill inadequate, and called for the two houses to resolve their differences in a conference committee. The bill's main sticking point is whether insurers should be allowed to charge deductibles for mammograms. The bill has also become the central issue in the special election next Tuesday for a Senate seat from the Upper East Side of Manhattan. Legislative leaders said no compromise was likely before then. Richard Prez-Pea (NYT)

title: Not in Finland Anymore? More Like Nokialand
description: After the company town, behold the corporate nation.

title: Olympic Balancing Act Over a Symbolic Flag
description: The Super Bowl and Emmy productions gushed patriotism after the events of Sept. 11. But today, the United States team discovered how complicated even the smallest act of patriotism can be at the Olympics, the consummate international sports event.

title: Ed Jucker, 85, Who Coached Cincinnati to Basketball Titles
description: Ed Jucker, who coached the University of Cincinnati basketball team to three consecutive N.C.A.A. tournament finals and won the first two, died Saturday at his home on Callawassie Island, S.C., near Hilton Head Island.

title: Trader Is Said to Have Defrauded Irish Bank of $750 Million
description: DUBLIN, Feb. 6  A trader for the Baltimore-based treasury arm of Allfirst, an American retail subsidiary of Allied Irish Banks P.L.C. ( news/quote ), defrauded Ireland's largest financial institution of $750 million over the last year through bogus foreign exchange trading, and he has since disappeared, the bank said today.

title: A Marble Glory That Was Greece
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 2 Big Names Said to Drop Idea of Bidding For WorldCom
description: Verizon and SBC Communications, the two biggest local telephone companies, each considered bidding to acquire WorldCom Inc. in recent months but backed out amid concerns that WorldCom's core long-distance businesses face continued difficulties, people close to Verizon and SBC said yesterday.

title: Giuliani Defends Removing Papers From City Control
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday defended the removal of his mayoral papers from the custody of the city's Department of Records and Information Services and said private archivists would catalog the documents according to professional standards without influence from him, his aides or his supporters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JANIS, EDWARD
description: JANIS-Edward. Beloved husband of Hilda. Father of Phyllis and Kenneth Finkel. Adored grandfather of Marc and Ariane. Services at ''Riverside Chapel'', 76th St and Amsterdam Avenue on Thursday, February 7 at 11:30AM.

title: Bush Budget's Low Growth Rate for Medicare Is Questioned by Lawmakers
description: President Bush's new budget shows extraordinarily slow growth in Medicare over the next decade, puzzling members of Congress and health policy experts, who say the numbers appear to be unrealistic.

title: Three Quotations From a Scandal
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IRELAND, R.L. III.
description: IRELAND-R.L. III. The Board of Trustees, Trustees Emeriti and the entire Phillips Academy community in Andover, MA. express deepest sympathy at the death of R.L. Ireland III, Trustee Emeritus. A member of the Class of 1938, Tim was a Charter Trustee from 1960-1990 and founding chairman of the Andover Development Board. He will be missed.

title: The Pentagon Spending Spree
description: With the nation at war, everyone expected a healthy but reasonable increase in next year's defense budget. Instead the Bush administration has presented a bloated and unbalanced proposal that would deepen future budget deficits, distort national priorities and slow the transformation of America's military forces to respond to the novel needs of 21st-century warfare. Congress must summon the courage to reshape and reduce this undisciplined budget.

title: Failing to Save For Bad Times During Boom
description: For years, New York has ranked near the bottom among the states in saving money to pay unemployment claims, setting aside less than one-third of what the federal government recommends to guard against an economic downturn.

title: 8 Cities Bid for 2010
description: Among the eight cities competing to hold the 2010 Olympics is Sarajevo, which staged the 1984 Winter Olympics before being devastated after the breakup of Yugoslavia.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article yesterday about the reaction of Boston fans to the Patriots' Super Bowl victory misattributed the closing comment, ''Now that the Patriots have won the Super Bowl, there's the thought that just possibly the Red Sox could slay the Yankee dragon.'' The speaker was Richard Johnson, curator of the Sports Museum of New England, who was also quoted earlier in the article, not Maureen Heywood, a fan.

title: Man Behind a Museum Tempest; A Curator Defends His Show Exploring Nazi Imagery
description: Norman L. Kleeblatt, the Susan and Elihu Rose curator of fine arts at the Jewish Museum in New York, is drawn to controversy as a moth to a flame -- and almost as innocently.

title: CUNY, Short on Faculty, Is to End Free Term for Seniors
description: Trying to raise money to hire more full-time professors, the City University of New York plans to end a 10-year-old policy of not charging four-year college students for their last semester of school.

title: Recipe: Oven-Glazed Black Salsify
description: Time: 45 minutes 3 pounds black salsify (25 to 30 10- to 12-inch roots)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASSELL, EVE
description: CASSELL-Eve. Age 92 on February 4, 2002. Adored by all her family. Wife of the late Irwin Cassell. Sister of the late Rose (Louis) Magram, Harry (Sylvia) Miller and Benjamin S. (Ann) Miller. Aunt of Saul Magram and the late Herbert Magram, Kathlyn Megram, William (Gloria) Miller, the late Ann (Emanuel) Mostov, Deborah (Ami) Glasberg, Wendy Miller, John Wielgosz, and great nieces and nephews. Burial private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEEGAN, JAMES B.
description: KEEGAN-James B. On February 3, 2002. In Columbus, OH, age 86. Beloved husband of the late Margaret (Peggy Fahey). Father of Patricia Hagen and James, Jr. Grandfather of four. Family will receive friends today 2-5 and 79PM at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave. (at 20th St), NYC. Funeral Mass at Immaculate Conception Church, Thursday 11A.M. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: A Prima Donna, in Root Form
description: THE family of root vegetables is not a comely bunch, inspiring love, if at all, only at the end of a long, sober courtship. Small wonder then, that black salsify, a hardy European rarely grown and barely known in this country, gives shoppers little pause when they come across it. Yet scratch the surface of this cocoa-brown root, and you may find yourself in the throes of a powerful attraction.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Settlement In Bus Crash
description: Sixteen students injured on a school bus that ran a stoplight and crashed into a dump truck in 1999 will receive a total of almost $5 million, a lawyer for the school bus company said yesterday. Most of the money, $2.6 million, will go to a student who was brain-damaged. The lawyer, Peter J. Hickey, said the insurance company for Kinnicutt Bus Company would pay 80 percent of the settlement, and the insurer of MVF Construction, the company that owned the truck, would pay the rest. The agreement was reached on Monday just as a trial against the insurers and the companies was about to begin. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: White House and Senate Agree on Church Charities
description: Senate negotiators have reached agreement with the White House over President Bush's proposal to give federal money to religious charities, Congressional aides said tonight.

title: Our Towns; In Nassau, Handcuffs Are Golden
description: IT wasn't hard for Thomas R. Suozzi to get the public on his side in tackling Nassau County's incredible expanding fiscal crisis. Three years of headlines about Republican budget deficits, and two Democratic landslides at the ballot box -- the latter got him elected county executive -- had pretty well seen to that.

title: Arthur D. Little Plans Bankruptcy Filing
description: Arthur D. Little, the oldest consulting firm in the country, announced yesterday that it would file for bankruptcy protection as a precursor to its acquisition by an investment management firm.

title: Three Quotations From a Scandal
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Shopping For Warplanes Suspended
description: The defense ministry is reconsidering its plan for a new generation of fighter planes after deciding that all four bids for the project were too high. The ministry said it had rejected bids from Boeing, Dassault of France, the Eurofighter consortium and the Russian producer Sukhoi. The ministry has been reviewing proposals for 40 planes estimated to cost between $3 billion and $4 billion. An advanced version of the Boeing F-15 and a Dassault plane have been regarded as the leading candidates. A military official said the project might be postponed or canceled if the bidders did not substantially reduce their prices. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Convict's DNA Sways Labs, Not a Determined Prosecutor
description: In the summer of 1986, two women who did not know each other were raped in the same housing complex in King of Prussia, a suburb of Philadelphia.

title: New-School Dinner Raises $1.3 Million
description: Demonstrating some of his legendary drawing power, BOB KERREY, below, president of New School University and former senator from Nebraska, attracted a host of luminaries to the university's annual La Guardia Award benefit dinner last week, which raised nearly $1.3 million for scholarships and to support the university's Milano Graduate School of Management and Urban Policy. Benefit chairmen included PETE PETERSON, chairman of the Blackstone Group; BRIAN ROBERTS, president of Comcast Inc.; and JOHN L. TISHMAN, chairman of Tishman Realty and Construction and chairman of the university's board. GOV. GEORGE E. PATAKI delivered the keynote address. The 2002 Fiorello H. La Guardia award was given to FELIX G. ROHATYN, the former United States ambassador to France. Mr. Royatyn took the lead in helping to bail New York City out of its mid-1970's financial crisis. Karen W. Arenson

title: JetBlue Is Said To Revive Plans To Sell Shares
description: JetBlue Airways, the fast-growing low-fare airline, has revived its plans for a public stock offering, people close to the airline said yesterday, a sign that investor confidence is returning to the airline industry after the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Long-Vanished U.S. Student, And a Clue on a Kabul Floor
description: At Perth Amboy High, Hiram Torres was the valedictorian of the class of 1993, the son of a seamstress who charted a course from his hard-edged industrial hometown in New Jersey to Yale University.

title: Technology Briefing
description: INTERNET

title: George Vecsey's Postcards
description: Adaily feature from George Vecsey on the scene in Salt Lake City.

title: A Not-Just-Clam Chowder
description: Calling the Nantucket seafood chowder at Wild Tuna a soup is like saying foie gras is merely liver. The restaurant, at 1081 Third Avenue (63rd Street), has a small retail counter, where the chowder is sold to go. For $17.95, you get a pint of creamy, silken soup flecked with herbs and clams, and a container of freshly cooked seafood: half a small lobster, three jumbo shrimp, and sea scallops, oysters and mussels. The soup can be quickly reheated, and the seafood needs 45 seconds in a microwave oven or a steamer. Place the seafood in a soup plate and pour the hot chowder on top. It's a generous main dish for one or a first course to serve two. Free delivery is available from 50th to 72nd Streets, between Park and First Avenues, or for the cost of cab fare elsewhere in Manhattan. To order: (212) 838-7570.

description: To the Editor:

title: Fire Company, Hurt Sept. 11, Is to Get Truck And Quarters
description: The Fire Department announced yesterday that Ladder 10, the only paid city fire company out of service since Sept. 11, would soon return to duty with a new truck and share quarters with another company until its station at the rim of ground zero is repaired.

title: THE CHEF
description: MY tafelspitz is a dish with a lot going on: it's hot, cold, spicy, creamy, crunchy and soft. It is essentially boiled beef, but it becomes something more because of the garnishes served with it. It was Emperor Franz Josef's favorite dish.

title: Anti-Jewish Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Salt Lake City Is All Aquiver
description: They love Jell-O in Salt Lake City, which has the highest rate of Jell-O eating of any city in the country -- 21 boxes a family a year. And just in time for the start of the Olympic Games on Friday, Salt Lake City has an exhibition of memorabilia from the Jell-O museum in Le Roy, N.Y. It includes the Maxfield Parrish illustration at right, used on the cover of a 1924 cookbook. The exhibition will be at the ZCMI Center Mall until March 5.

title: MCI Names Deutsch For Consumer Ads
description: MCI, a unit of WorldCom Inc., said yesterday that it had expanded its agency roster by shifting consumer advertising for the MCI brand without a review to Deutsch in New York, part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies. The assignment had been held by Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG in New York, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide division of Havas Advertising.

title: Politics Keep Shifting in the Gas-Mileage Debate
description: Over the weekend, Tom Brady, the quarterback of the New England Patriots, won a new pickup truck, the first model ever made by Cadillac, for being named the Super Bowl's most valuable player.

title: Bush Plans Early Warning System for Terror
description: President Bush said today that he envisioned a broad emergency alert system to warn the country of biological attacks, calling for an updating of the cold war's Distant Early Warning system for an age of terrorism.

title: Sweet Clouds Brought Down to Earth
description: GREAT homemade marshmallows are like plush, soft pillows that dissolve on your tongue as you bite down. Springy and airy without being rubbery, they are sophisticated sweets meant to be taken seriously, confections rather than candy.

title: Tehran's Foreign Minister Says U.S. Should Offer Assistance, Not Accusations
description: The Iranian foreign minister, Kamal Kharrazi, suggested today that the effort to stabilize Afghanistan would be better served if the United States gave his country details rather than accusing it of giving safe harbor to Taliban and Al Qaeda fighters fleeing to Iranian territory.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LOCKHEED MARTIN CORP., Bethesda, Md., the military contractor, said it had signed a $50 million contract with the Egyptian government to build a 13-vessel search-and-rescue system with specialized electronic equipment for the Gulf of Suez.

title: Cornell Trustees Get New Chairman
description: Cornell University's trustees have elected a new chairman, PETER C. MEINIG, a 1962 Cornell graduate and chief executive of H M International Inc., a privately held company in Tulsa, Okla., that includes various manufacturing and service businesses. He succeeds HAROLD TANNER, who has been chairman since 1997, beginning on July 1. Karen W. Arenson

title: Bristol-Myers Wants to Change ImClone Pact
description: Five months after pledging to invest $2 billion in ImClone Systems and its new cancer drug, Bristol-Myers Squibb said yesterday that it wanted to ''fundamentally restructure'' its relationship with the company, including changing its top management.

title: Ex-Head of Hale House and Husband Charged With Theft
description: The former head of Hale House and her husband surrendered yesterday to face charges that they had stolen or misappropriated more than $1 million from the Harlem charity that was once acclaimed for its work with the children of drug-addicted or imprisoned mothers.

title: Where Citizens Are Guilty, but Always With an Explanation
description: Remote places have a claim on the romantic spirit, as if the more distant and isolated they are, the greater the pull on the imagination. By that standard, ''Further Than the Furthest Thing,'' a play by the young Scottish playwright Zinnie Harris, which opened yesterday at the Manhattan Theater Club, should be a soaring delight.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Ciena Cutting 400 Jobs
description: Shares in Ciena, the optical networking equipment maker, slumped after the company said it would cut 400 jobs, almost 12 percent of its work force, and post a first-quarter loss that will be wider than expected. Citing reduced purchases by several major customers, Ciena said its loss would be 19 to 22 cents a share. Analysts expected a loss of 11 cents. Ciena said first-quarter revenue would total $160 million, well below forecasts of about $225 million. It also said it would close its research and development center in Marlborough, Mass. The shares dropped $1.12, to $9. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the Television section on Sunday with the movie listings for tomorrow reversed the identities of two actresses in ''The Land Girls.'' Rachel Weisz is at the center of the picture, Catherine McCormack at the right.

title: When the Three-Timer Is a Twit
description: ME TIMES THREE

title: World Briefing | Africa: Sierra Leone: No Freedom For Rebel Leader
description: Foday Sankoh, the leader of the rebel group responsible for killing and mutilating thousands of civilians, will not be freed even after a state of emergency is lifted across the country, Justice Minister Solomon Berewa announced. He will be kept in detention despite the rebel group's insistence that he be released. The government and the rebels have declared the civil war over. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: Meth Building Its Hell's Kitchen in Rural America
description: Just about every day, Sheriff Rick Bart is called about a crime that makes absolutely no sense, even within the universe of lawlessness.

title: A Long-Sought Rally Takes the Chill Off a Boston Winter
description: Like color rushing back to the cheeks of a weary patient, a parade of red, white and blue flushed the winter-gray landscape here today. The Patriots' victory lap, along a two-mile downtown route before an estimated 1.2 million people, could not have arrived at a better time for Gail Chamberlain, who just received a pink slip from her employer, Lucent Technologies.

title: Mafia-Tinged Dispute, but Fought in Court
description: On the surface, it appeared to be a brawl over a girl, a beef between neighborhood boys from opposite sides of the tracks that turned violent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINDEBAND, SEYMOUR JAY
description: SINDEBAND-Seymour Jay. The Fu Foundation School of Engineering and Applied Science of Columbia University expresses its sorrow at the loss of its counselor, benefactor, and friend, Seymour Jay Sindeband. After receiving his A.B., B.S., and M.S. degrees from Columbia, and serving as a Naval officer during World War II, Mr. Sindeband pioneered computer applications that included systems for airlines, banks, railroads, and the American Stock Exchange. At Columbia he served on the Advisory Council of the Engineering School, and in a rare honor, received both the John Jay Award and, like his father, the Egleston Medal. The Fu Foundation School of Engineering and Applied Science extends deepest sympathy to the Sindeband family. Zvi Galil, Dean, The Fu Foundation School of Engineering and Applied Science, Columbia University

title: Same Old Knight Is Getting Results In West Texas
description: Bob Knight likes his Red Raiders. He believes they should have cracked the top 25 long before last week and says that they are more talented than the last five teams he put on the floor for Indiana. But in a practice session at United Spirit Arena, he was frustrated, disappointed and, yes, perhaps a little angry with them.

description: DUBLIN, Feb. 6  A trader for the Baltimore-based treasury arm of Allfirst, an American retail subsidiary of Allied Irish Banks P.L.C. ( news/quote ), defrauded Ireland's largest financial institution of $750 million over the last year through bogus foreign exchange trading, and he has since disappeared, the bank said today.

title: Disappearance of Girl, 7, Unsettles San Diego Neighborhood
description: The disappearance of a 7-year-old San Diego girl who has not been seen since going to bed on Friday has put her well-to-do neighborhood on edge as the police have turned their attention to a man who lives nearby.

title: Sports of The Times; Winter Games Belong To All the Competitors
description: FROM within the barricades, the electric buzz of the athletes' village never changes -- or maybe it's the ping from the game room or maybe it's the clatter from the cafeteria.

title: Fifth Big Accountant Changes Its Practices
description: After initial reluctance, Deloitte & Touche has decided to separate its accounting and consulting businesses, becoming the last of the Big Five firms to announce significant changes in policies in the wake of Enron's collapse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCOTT, DOROTHY SULLIVAN
description: SCOTT-Dorothy Sullivan. Of New York City died February 5, 2002, at age 96. Widow of S. Lytton Scott and daughter of Dr. Eugene C. Sullivan, former Chairman and President of the Corning Glass Works. She attended Antioch College where she was the first woman editor of the student newspaper. Later she wrote a column Lobbing with Lucy in Tennis Week Magazine for 15 years. She is survived by two sons, Timothy S. Scott of Kent, CT, and Eugene L. Scott of New York City, 5 grandchildren, Timothy Jr, Eldon, Katherine, Lucy and Sam and two greatgrandchildren, Drew and Dana Rae. A memorial service will be announced.

title: CBS to Broadcast Videotape Shot Inside Towers During Trade Center Attack
description: CBS announced yesterday that it would broadcast a two-hour documentary special on March 10 culled from the videotape footage shot inside the World Trade Center by two young French filmmakers during the terrorist attack on Sept. 11.

title: Clorox Profit Is Off 20%
description: The Clorox Company, the maker of bleach, said today that profit fell 20 percent in its most recent quarter because of the costs of eliminating as many as 585 jobs.

title: Olympic Deals
description: At the Games' Web site, www.saltlake2002.com (also the place to look for remaining tickets), the listing of available hotels and condos is updated regularly, and you can watch as some rates go down. During the week of Jan. 20, for example, the Crystal Inn Brigham City, about 40 miles from Salt Lake City, went from a range of $195 to $295 a night for a four-night minimum to $145 to $245 (not all Olympic dates are available). The Powder Ridge condos in the same area fell from a range of $275 to $500 down to $99 to $139, with some days unavailable. For those who don't mind a120-mile drive, the Econo Lodge Wendover dropped from $120 to $90.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Saturday about plans by the Enron Corporation to sell an electric utility in Oregon misstated the surname of a member of the Oregon Public Utility Commission, who missed part of a hearing on the matter on Jan. 29. He is Lee Beyer, not Byers.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: 'Mlife' Draws Super Bowl Traffic
description: The annual analysis by Jupiter Media Metrix of Web site traffic surrounding the Super Bowl showed big increases for the sites of two advertisers. One was AT&T Wireless, which promoted a site (www.mlife.com) related to a campaign, ''Welcome to mlife,'' that was introduced in commercials during Super Bowl XXXVI on Sunday. Traffic to the site rose to 681,000 so-called unique visitors on Sunday, the analysis found, from 34,000 on Saturday, even though some computer users reported trouble reaching the site. The other site, www.pepsi.yahoo.com, which had 135,000 visitors on Sunday after negligible visitors on Saturday, was set up by Yahoo and the Pepsi-Cola division of PepsiCo. At the site, viewers could vote for a Pepsi commercial to be shown during the game's second quarter. Traffic to other sites with Super Bowl commercials showed no significant gains. Stuart Elliott (NYT)

description: NORTHWEST

title: ENRON EXECUTIVES SAY THEY DEBATED FREEZE ON PENSION
description: Enron executives acknowledged today that before they temporarily prevented employees from selling company stock in their retirement accounts last fall, the executives had sharply debated delaying the moratorium because employees could suffer heavy losses from a plunging stock price.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAZE, STANLEY
description: MAZE-Stanley. February 4, 2002. Beloved husband of Judith. Loving father of Stephanie Maze-Hsu and Andrew Maze. Adored grandfather of Alexandra and Robert Hsu, and Joshua and Noah Maze.

description: AMERICAS

title: Big and Sweet: Who'd Think It's a Lemon?
description: They look like golden navel oranges, but they are actually sweet Meyer lemons, about twice the usual size. The grower, Armand Bryl of Samsula, Fla., near Daytona Beach, said, "I just use natural fish and seaweed fertilizer and then let the ladybugs do their job." Only some of his lemons are giants, and those he sends to Grace's Marketplace, 1237 Third Avenue (71st Street), where they are $2.99 a pound. Each of the lemons yields about a cup of juice. For granita, combine two cups Meyer lemon juice with seven tablespoons sugar dissolved in a cup of simmering water. Put in the freezer in a metal pan. Mix with a fork when slushy, and occasionally until frozen. Remove pulp from juiced lemons, and serve granita in the shells.

title: To Stem Crisis, Tyco Is Moving Fast To Shed Finance Unit
description: Tyco International Ltd. moved quickly yesterday to sell or spin off the CIT Group, its finance unit, to stem a crisis of confidence that has caused its stock to fall by more than half in the last month, executives close to the company said.

title: Let Them Profile Me
description: I have probably been through more ethnic profiling at airports than anyone who has protested the practice on television. My American passport says I was born in Lebanon. I have an unusual name and a classic Mediterranean appearance. And for my research in Middle Eastern studies, I have hopped between Iraq and Tunis; Syria and the United Arab Emirates; Kuwait, Egypt and Morocco. Trips like these leave telltale marks on your passport, and even my fair-haired, blue-eyed husband, traveling with me, has been subject to lengthy interrogations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKOWITZ, FRED C.
description: BERKOWITZ-Fred C. Died at the age of eighty-two on February 5, 2002 of cancer. Devoted father of Bruce and Howard, grandfather of Elana, Etan and Shayna. Beloved friend of Amerac Lodge, Bell Park Manor Terrace, and Bell Park Jewish Center. Services Thursday, February 7, 9:45 AM at ''Plaza Jewish Community Chapel,'' 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: 3 Held and Computer Seized In Case of Missing Reporter
description: The Pakistani police said today that they had arrested two men suspected of sending e-mail messages with photographs of Daniel Pearl, the American reporter kidnapped in the southern city of Karachi two weeks ago, and a United States law enforcement official confirmed last night that Pakistani police had the computer used to send those messages.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRICOT, JEAN A.
description: DRICOT-Jean A. Died in Falmouth, ME, February 2, 2002 after a long illness with Alzheimer's disease. Born Heliopolis, Egypt, February 15, 1923, he served in the Piron Brigade of the Belgium Army (1940-1945) and participated in the Normandy invasion. Proud veteran, he returned to Belgium for yearly reunions of his Brigade. Graduated from the University of Brussels. Jean was employed by A.C.E.C., & in 1950 was sent to the New York subsidiary. In 1960 he joined Cogenel, Inc. a subsidiary of Alcatel, Inc. Jean was CEO of Cogenel, Inc. at the time of his retirement in 1990. Jean was a member of the Belgium & French Chambers of Commerce, the Paris American Club, and started the Alumni Club for University of Brussels. He is survived by his wife of 48 years, Molly Bamonte, 2 daughters, Francesca of NYC, and Claudia of Cape Elizabeth, ME, 2 grandsons and a brother Georges of Brussels, Belgium. His kindness, humor, generosity & wisdom will be remembered by all who knew him. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, 919 N. Michigan Avenue, Chicago, IL. 60611.

title: Afghan Flag Is Unfurled As Dark Threats Swirl
description: Less than 50 days in office and already under challenge from the warlords who helped make the miseries of its past, Afghanistan's new government turned today to the symbolism of a flag-raising ceremony at the old royal palace to showcase its hopes for a happier future.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hewlett Sets Vote
description: Pushing ahead with its appeal to shareholders, Hewlett-Packard set March 19 for a meeting of stockholders to vote on its contested merger with Compaq Computer. The leading opponent, Walter B. Hewlett, an heir of the co-founder, began mailing out his proxy materials to shareholders yesterday, urging them to vote against what he termed a ''bet-the-company transaction.'' The European Commission gave the deal its nod last week, eliminating the possibility of a lengthy review. The Federal Trade Commission is also expected to approve the merger plan shortly. Hewlett filed its final proxy with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday and set the voting date after announcing on Monday that quarterly earnings would substantially exceed Wall Street estimates. The steady progress toward a vote, encouraging earnings news and absence of regulatory problems are positive for Hewlett-Packard management, said A. M. Sacconaghi, an analyst for Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. But he still thinks Mr. Hewlett's camp will prevail. Steve Lohr (NYT)

title: Weaker Yen and U.S. Sales Help Increase Honda's Profit
description: While many other Japanese manufacturers struggled, Honda Motor posted robust sales and profits in the last quarter of 2001, buoyed by a weaker yen and the popularity of new models in the United States and at home.

title: Administration Shifts Focus on Colombia Aid
description: The Bush administration is proposing to expand military aid to this war-racked nation by training the Colombian Army to protect a 500-mile-long oil pipeline from leftist rebels, senior American officials visiting Colombia said today. Such a program would be a sharp departure from a policy that until now has focused on eradicating drugs.

title: Diving Deeply Into Life's Sweet Waters
description: Memorials need not be solemn. That was demonstrated on Sunday afternoon when the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center and the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company once again joined forces at Alice Tully Hall.

description: GALLAGHER-James Charles. Of Bradford, VT, formerly of Saddle River, NJ, 42 years old. Entered into eternal rest on February 3rd. Beloved son of Grace (nee Guthy) and the late Daniel J. Cherished brother of Daniel J. Jr., Caroline, and Rita. The family will gather with relatives and friends 10AM Friday, February 8th at St. Gabriel's Church, Saddle River, NJ (201) 327-5663 for a Funeral Mass. Interment to follow at Maryrest Cemetery, Mahwah NJ. In lieu of flowers the family asks that contributions in memory of James be sent to The National Alliance for the Mentally Ill, 1901 N. Fort Myers Dr. Suite #

title: Fight Over Judicial Nominee Resumes
description: The case of Judge Charles W. Pickering of Mississippi, who has been nominated to a federal appeals court post, may be the beginning of the long-expected war over judicial nominations in the Bush presidency.

title: Nets Pass Another Test, Taking Kings to School
description: Standing at practice today and smiling about the Nets' ascent to the top of the Eastern Conference, Coach Byron Scott had plenty to be happy about. Still, he sounded as if he had been slighted.

title: Astros Cry Foul and Try for an Enron Pickoff Play
description: It is not often that a Major League Baseball team wants to prevent a corporation from buying box seats and other stadium goodies, but then, it is not often that a big company loses billions of dollars in shareholder equity before going spectacularly bankrupt in an exploding accounting scandal.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Arrests Criticized
description: Some protesters arrested during demonstrations against the World Economic Forum were unfairly incarcerated in what amounted to preventive detention, one of their lawyers charged yesterday. The lawyer, Leslie A. Brody, said some of the 201 people arrested were held too long in jail before being arraigned. Some were also charged with infractions that do not appear to be supported by the evidence in the complaints, Ms. Brody said. She said further study was needed to determine how many protesters should have gotten summonses instead. Michael A. Cardozo, the city's corporation counsel, said the allegations ''have no merit.'' Al Baker (NYT)

title: Shareholders' Doubts Shake Elan and the Irish Market
description: Investors who think that they detect the whiff of another Enron at the Elan Corporation have beaten the company's share price down by two-thirds in a week, despite a report of strong sales growth.

title: Contemporary Art Moves Into a Parisian Fixer-Upper
description: The question was asked throughout the 1990's: why is France not more prominent in contemporary art? And the favorite answer was to blame the government. So the Culture Ministry formed commissions and issued reports, but still the art scene remained moribund. Now the government has turned the Palais de Tokyo into a vast space for the display, creation and celebration of contemporary art. Will this do the trick?

title: Choosing The Right Enemies
description: In his State of the Union address, President Bush took aim at what he called an ''axis of evil'' -- countries like Iraq, Iran and North Korea together with their terrorist associates. He implied that the United States might take strong action against all parts of this global collection of unpalatable actors.

title: Bush Reaffirms Pledge to Provide $20 Billion to New York City
description: Citing the importance of New York City's recovery and growth in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, President Bush asserted today that he would fulfill his promise to provide the city with $20 billion in federal money to help rebuild Lower Manhattan.

description: After months of internal debate, the Bush administration has outlined a climate policy that calls for a far more gradual approach to global warming than the one in a 1997 treaty endorsed by most nations.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: New City Data Center
description: The city's Human Resources Administration signed a deal this week to move its data center from Manhattan to a building under construction in Downtown Brooklyn. The agency will join Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield at 9 Metro Tech Center, set to open in spring 2003. The agency, which was represented by Cushman & Wakefield, signed a lease for 220,000 square feet with the developer, Forest City Ratner Companies. It now occupies space at 111 Eighth Avenue, between 15th and 16th Streets. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

Wednesday, 7-9PM. Service in Church 12:30PM Thursday, Donations preferred to Cooper Union Annual Fund or Children's Aid Society Warriors Program.

title: National Briefing | Plains: Nebraska: Prisons Become No-Smoking Zones
description: A smoking ban went into effect this week for inmates and guards at state prisons. Corrections officials expect the ban to improve inmate health, lower taxpayer costs and cut the number of secondhand-smoke lawsuits brought against the department. Officials said smoking-cessation devices like nicotine patches would be available to inmates. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: After Closing, Longing for the Old School
description: There was considerable strife in affluent Armonk when, in the 1980's, the Byram Hills Central School District decided to sell the Bear Ridge School, one of its three elementary schools. A big notion held the day: the district's enrollment was declining and the decline would not reverse itself in the foreseeable future.

title: Car Restriction Into Manhattan Is Extended
description: The city's transportation commissioner said yesterday that the ban on single-occupant cars during the morning on several bridges and tunnels into Manhattan would remain in place at least until May, when the city hopes to fully reopen the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel.

title: Trader Is Said to Have Defrauded Irish Bank of $750 Million
description: DUBLIN, Feb. 6  A trader for the Baltimore-based treasury arm of Allfirst, an American retail subsidiary of Allied Irish Banks P.L.C. ( news/quote ), defrauded Ireland's largest financial institution of $750 million over the last year through bogus foreign exchange trading, and he has since disappeared, the bank said today.
