title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: EMI Expects Lower Profit
description: The EMI Group said full-year profit would fall 42 percent, as music sales faltered. Pretax profit will be about 150 million ($214 million), less than analysts had expected and down from the 260 million the company earned the previous year. EMI and rivals have been hurt by the soft economy, slowing sales of compact discs and the ability of customers to copy music from the Internet free. Since Alain Levy took over at EMI in October he has dropped artists like Mariah Carey and reorganized management. Last week, EMI said its Virgin Records unit would move to New York from Los Angeles and would be led by Matt Serletic. EMI also named Roger Faxon as chief financial officer. David Munns, who Mr. Levy hired after he came on board last October, will be the chief executive of EMI Recorded Music North America. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Palm Update
description: The hand-held computer maker Palm Inc. said it would deliver a new version of its operating system to computer makers in June or July as it vies with Microsoft for corporate customers. Palm said tests showed programs would run as much as 20 times faster on the new system. Palm's infrequent improvements have made it vulnerable to competition from Microsoft's Pocket PC, analysts said.

title: Business Travel; Do-it-yourself bookings are on the rise at companies.
description: ATTENTION, those of you who are not yet making your own business travel arrangements online. Time is running out. The online-travel-booking exponents who now control many company travel departments are ready to track you down.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAUG, FREDERICK J.
description: HAUG-Frederick J., 91. Formerly of Manhasset, N.Y. Died February 5, 2002 in New York City. Beloved husband of Dorothy. Devoted and adored father of Gretchen Stone, Hedi White and father-in-law of Lewis Stone and Thomas White. Cherished grandfather of Pamela Stone-Humphrey and her husband Jim, Bart Stone and Timothy White. Proud great-grandfather of Riley Humphrey. Dear brother of Bertha Dean, Mina Cory and Elsie Haug. Caring uncle and granduncle of David Cory, Mina Kahofer, Daniel Cory, John Cory, Robert Dean, Frederick Dean and Barbara Dalally and their children. For over 50 years he owned and operated the George Haug Company, Inc. He was especially proud of transforming the harness shop established by his father in 1904 into Manhattan's premier auto service facility with factory appointments for both Rolls-Royce and Jaguar Motorcars. After his retirement in 1977, he began a second family business Haug Realty Corp, in which he was active to the end of his life. A former trustee of the Congregational Church of Manhasset, he was a past master and lifelong member of Hiram Masonic Lodge/a longtime member and past president of the Yorkville Lion's Club and a Director of the Manhattan Chamber of Commerce. He was an enthusiastic member of the Rolls-Royce owner's Club, where he was both a past National director and past president of the Atlantic region. Born in Yorkville and an alumnus of Stuyvesant High School, he was a passionate lover of New York City. He will always be remembered for his colorful and detailed memories of the Upper East Side and its many changes since his boyhood, as well as the history of the automobile as he experienced it firsthand. His larger than life personality and courtly manner attracted everyone. His clear insights and generosity changed many lives. He will be missed. Family will receive friends Friday. 2 to 4 and 6 to 8PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. Funeral services Saturday, 11AM at Congregational Church of Manhasset, 1845 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, N.Y. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CODDON, DR. DAVID
description: CODDON-Dr. David. Congregation Ahavath Torah of Englewood, NJ mourns the passing of our esteemed member. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Shmuel Goldin, Rabbi Jeffrey R. Parker, President

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zambia: Too Many Eggs In Copper Basket
description: The World Bank has urged the government to speed up its effort to diversify the economy and to reduce its dependence on copper, the country's biggest export earner. Last month, Anglo American, the global mining giant, pulled out of Zambia, where the company had been struggling to revive the crumbling mines it acquired 23 months ago. The move was a staggering blow to Zambia, which is one of the world's poorest countries and now faces the prospect of thousands of lost jobs. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, RITA
description: BERNSTEIN-Rita. Suddenly on February 1, 2002. Cherished wife of Leonard. Loving and always supportive mother of Larry, Audrey and Laura. Services Thursday, 11:45 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLOTKIN, HELEN
description: PLOTKIN-Helen. Congregation Rodeph Sholom notes with sorrow the passing of Helen Plotkin. Helen was the beloved mother of Fred Plotkin, our dear friend and benefactor. Our deepest sympathy is extended to Fred, his wife Janet and all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, Sr. Rabbi Mark Biderman, President

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Recipient Of Artificial Heart Suffers Stroke
description: A third recipient of the world's first self-contained artificial heart has suffered a stroke. The patient, Bobby Harrison, one of five patients to receive the AbioCor device, suffered the stroke on Friday, officials at the Texas Heart Institute in Houston said on Monday. The institute said Mr. Harrison, who received the device on Sept. 26, was recovering well. Because the clots might have formed in the device, its manufacturer, Abiomed Inc. of Danvers, Mass., is modifying the AbioCor before any additional implants. Lawrence K. Altman (NYT)

description: The six members of United States men's short-track speedskating team sat on the podium this afternoon, one wearing earrings, one wearing bandanna, but all wearing their team uniform and smiling about their team goals.

description: President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan, on a high-profile visit to Kashmir, bitterly denounced India today for refusing to accept his reconciliation efforts in a crisis that began in December and has left the two neighbors facing off across a tense frontier.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Job Cuts At Phone Concern
description: Mm02, the mobile phone company spun off from British Telecommunications in November, said it would cut 1,900 jobs, or 13 percent of its work force. The layoffs, most of which will be in Britain and Germany, are just one step the company is taking to cut costs. Mm02, like other wireless operators, has also agreed to share networks to reduce the costs of building infrastructure for the next wave of wireless technology that provides a continuous connection to the Internet. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: 11-Point First Half Puts Providence In Too Deep a Hole
description: Providence set a Big East record for first-half scoring futility tonight, notching only 11 points. The Friars rallied in the second half, but it wasn't enough. Connecticut snapped a two-game losing streak by beating Providence, 67-56, before a crowd of 16,294 at the Hartford Civic Center.

title: What Does $3.75 Buy? Lunch and a Trip Through Time
description: HEMLINES, like the economy, may rise and fall, but the look of the garment center has barely changed in decades. A pedestrian, wandering the West 30's, can get lost in time, dodging rolling racks of clothes while gazing through the storefronts of wholesale showrooms, glancing at the button and spandex emporiums and wondering at the whirligig activity in the hidden upper floors of the squat and dingy buildings.

title: Happy, Happy, Happy Birthday
description: Philip Glass turned 65 on Thursday, and on Sunday afternoon the conductor Dennis Russell Davies and the American Composers Orchestra celebrated the occasion at Carnegie Hall with a program of Mr. Glass's orchestral works. Included were the United States premiere of three movements from ''Passages,'' a 1990 collaboration between Mr. Glass and Ravi Shankar, and the world premiere of the Symphony No. 6 (2001), a setting of Allen Ginsberg's ''Plutonian Ode.''

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Loan Loss Provisions
description: Argentina's economic problems and lower-than-expected recoveries on loans in the North American telecommunications sector have led TD Bank Financial Group to increase its estimated loan-loss provisions by 35 percent, to 1.1 billion to 1.2 billion Canadian dollars ($689 million) for the fiscal year, which ends Oct. 31. The bank said it had exposure of $175 million in Argentina. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Bangladesh: Proposal On Acid Attacks
description: Prime Minister Khaleda Zia has proposed tougher laws in a nation where hundreds of women have been disfigured by acid attacks by rejected suitors. But advocates for women say that the proposed legislation, even if approved by Parliament, is unlikely to bring significant change. They say that tough laws are already on the books but that enforcement is lax and few attackers are brought to trial. Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about efforts by the accounting firm Ernst & Young to change some practices misstated part of its plans. The firm did not say it would stop providing information technology services to companies it audits; it has not provided such services since it sold its consulting business in 2000. Ernst & Young does, however, support an industry proposal to prohibit accounting firms from selling consulting services to companies they audit.

title: Levy Seeks More Albany Aid
description: Chancellor HAROLD O. LEVY went to Albany yesterday to warn lawmakers that GOV. GEORGE E. PATAKI's budget proposal could harm city schools, even though the plan appears to reduce aid to the Board of Education only slightly. Mr. Levy said that building aid to New York City would sharply decline, a factor that he said was not addressed in the governor's budget proposal. He also said that Mr. Pataki's staff had overestimated by $27 million the amount of transportation aid that New York was to get. He said it was especially crucial that the state allot more funds for teacher recruitment.

title: Devils' Defense Is Airtight, but Canadiens' Is Better
description: Kevin Constantine does not have the time or a laboratory to repair the Devils. He must work quickly, like a pit crew at a car race. He has had to scribble a list of priorities in the eight days he has been the Devils' coach, and the team's power play was not high on his list.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Murder Fugitive Sentenced
description: A man who fled to Jamaica after killing his girlfriend in their Mount Vernon apartment and was then persuaded by the police to return and face trial has been sentenced to 18 years to life in prison, the Westchester district attorney's office said yesterday. The man, Rohan Myers, 30, was convicted of second-degree murder in December for shooting his girlfriend, Christine Ferguson, 26, in the face in August 1998. He was sentenced on Monday in Westchester County Court by Judge Lester Adler. At trial, Mr. Myers argued that the 9-millimeter handgun had discharged accidentally. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Green Assails Bloomberg As Taking Easy Road
description: Mark Green yesterday attacked Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg for the first time since he lost the mayoral election, asserting that his rival had failed to produce a single new idea since he took office, and declaring that Mr. Bloomberg had followed a safe route that accounted for his political popularity to date.

title: Adding a Bit More Luster To a Polished Diamond
description: George Balanchine's ''Tchaikovsky Suite No. 3'' is essentially three-quarters unabashed mauve chiffon and one-quarter hard diamond sparkle. But the piece, presented by the New York City Ballet on Friday night at the New York State Theater, does build almost imperceptibly through three sections that Balanchine added in 1970 to the culminating movement, his signature 1947 ''Theme and Variations.'' And Gitte Lindstrom, a guest artist from the Royal Danish Ballet, embodied the sharpening pace and thrust in a role debut as the lead ballerina in the second movement.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about demonstrators at the World Economic Forum in New York misspelled the surname of a woman who said the protests had awakened her to the issue of globalization. She was Beth Oram, not Orem.

title: Two New Leads Are on the Way to 'The Producers'
description: In a decision that may set off yet another scramble for ''Producers'' tickets, the producers of that blockbuster musical confirmed yesterday that the matinee on Sunday, March 17, would be the last performance for its two above-the-title stars, Nathan Lane and Matthew Broderick, who originated the roles of Max Bialystock and Leo Bloom, the feckless producers at the story's center.

title: Corrections
description: An article in World Business yesterday about efforts by middle-class Argentines to cope with government restrictions on bank accounts misidentified a bank executive held by the authorities in an investigation of international money transfers. He is Carlos Rohm, vice president of the Banco General de Negocios. Jos Rohm, his brother and the bank's chairman, has not been identified as a subject of the investigation.

title: Onstage at the Algonquin, 18 and Going on Legend
description: PETER CINCOTTI doesn't just tickle the ivories of the Steinway grand that dominates his mother's Park Avenue apartment; posing with the instrument that made him Harry Connick Jr.'s instant protg a decade ago at age 7, he pats its treble keys affectionately, much the way he ruffles the head of Montana, the family poodle.

title: Pentagon Is Seeking New Antiterror Command
description: The Pentagon is preparing to send to President Bush a recommendation calling for the creation of a new command to coordinate the military's response to terrorist attacks within the nation's borders, senior military officials said today.

title: Lindh Coerced After Capture, Lawyers Assert
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  Lawyers for John Walker Lindh, the American captured with anti-American forces in Afghanistan, said today that Mr. Lindh had been treated harshly in "highly coercive conditions" by his American captors after being abused by forces friendly to the United States.

title: Isles' Victory Reflects Their Troubles in Goal
description: The Islanders ended a 24-hour stretch of strange goaltending tonight by producing a 4-3 victory over the St. Louis Blues.

title: Ursuline School Dedicates Arts Center
description: The Ursuline School, a private Catholic girls' school in New Rochelle, is dedicating its new $7 million arts center on Feb. 10 in honor of ELLEN MOONEY HANCOCK, a 1961 Ursuline graduate and computer industry executive, who has pledged $1.5 million for the building. The 27,000-square-foot, four-story building features a state-of-the-art 300-seat theater, four studio classrooms, an art gallery and dance and music rehearsal spaces that will serve the school's 750 students in grades 6 through 12. Merri Rosenberg

title: C.I.A. Director Defends Agency and Warns of Al Qaeda Threat
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 — George Tenet, the director of central intelligence, defended his agency before lawmakers today and told them that Osama bin Laden's Al Qaeda terrorist network remains a potent threat.

title: This Time, Chocolate Takes a Powder
description: COCOA has always had an image problem.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Fewer Bad Loans
description: Government officials said banks had cut their bad-loan ratio to 3.4 percent last year as part of the drive to restructure since the financial crisis of 1997 and 1998. The Financial Supervisory Service said bad loans held by banks at the end of December had fallen to $14.3 billion as a result of write-offs and sales of bad assets. The bad-loan ratio a year earlier was 8 percent. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: In New York, Our Men From Havana
description: IN New York, the hunt for a good Cubano turns up many that are filling but few that are superb. The reason, in part, is a dwindling demand.

title: Auction Sites In Japan Fear Move to Limit Online Sales
description: The Japanese National Police Agency is circulating a proposal to require sellers of used goods through Internet auctions to obtain licenses, raising new fears among American online auction companies that they may face more stringent international control.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the distribution of prepaid MasterCards at the World Economic Forum in New York misspelled the surname of a Harvard Law School professor who commented on the promotion. He was Jonathan L. Zittrain, not Zittorain.

title: Bronx Little League Cuts Ties
description: The Rolando Paulino Little League in the Bronx, whose use of an overage player set off a scandal last August, has apparently dropped out of Little League baseball and will take its players on the road.

title: Innovator Named Principal in Mamaroneck
description: NAOMI HILL, who led the 1980's revival of Upper West Side public schools as the principal of Public School 87, is returning to school administration. She has been appointed principal of Central School, an elementary school in Mamaroneck, N.Y., where she has been consulting since the fall. ''I think I'm as surprised as anybody that I am a principal again,'' Ms. Hill said yesterday. ''I think the world of schools -- with teachers and children and parents -- is a comfortable world for me.'' Ms. Hill helped turn P.S. 87 from a run-of-the-mill school into one that parents lined up at 6 a.m. to apply for. She took a retirement incentive in 1991, after 11 years in the job, and became the principal of the Malcolm Mackay School in Tenafly, N.J., and then the director of the lower school at Dalton. She is now director of a program at Columbia University that consults with teachers and principals. She lives in Larchmont, which is part of the Mamaroneck school system, and has a new granddaughter, born Friday, who is a future Mamaroneck student. Anemona Hartocollis

title: Excerpt From Lawyers' Filing for Lindh: 'Threatened Him With Death'
description: Following is an excerpt from a document filed in federal District Court by lawyers for John Walker Lindh to support their motion that he be released from jail pending his trial on charges of conspiring with Al Qaeda to kill Americans:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Columbus Circle Deal Set
description: Equinox Fitness Clubs has leased 25,000 square feet in the complex under construction at Columbus Circle. And a related company, Elizabeth Arden Red Door Salon and Spa, is expected to sign a deal for an additional 15,000 square feet, according to real estate executives. The Columbus Circle complex, known as AOL Time Warner Center, is expected to cost $1.7 billion and is scheduled to open late next year. Robert F. Futterman, the broker for the deal, did not return calls requesting comment. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: First-Time Jobless Filings Drop
description: Oregon, which has the nation's highest unemployment rate, 7.5 percent, reported the first encouraging numbers since the recession began. Filings for initial unemployment benefits declined 2,190, to 10,455, for the week ending Jan. 26, from the week earlier. The figures remain higher than this time last year, but state officials said the new numbers could be the start of a positive trend. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: OXFORD HEALTH POSTS 12% DROP IN 4TH-QUARTER PROFIT
description: Oxford Health Plans Inc., one of the biggest health insurers in the New York area, said fourth-quarter profit fell 12 percent as medical costs rose. Net income fell to $94.3 million, or $1 a share, from $107.4 million, or 59 cents, a year earlier, the company said. Revenue rose 7.9 percent, to $1.12 billion. Oxford expects to add customers through employer health plans this year because rivals like Aetna Inc. are announcing bigger premium increases to catch up with the cost of medical care. Oxford, which is based in Trumbull, Conn., had 1.37 million members in fully insured employer health plans as of Dec. 31, the company said, an increase of 35,300 members from the previous year.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Zimbabwe Press Law Criticized
description: The United Nations investigator for press freedom says Zimbabwe's new restrictions on journalists violate international human rights law. Abid Hussain, who examines freedom of opinion and expression for the United Nations, said he had written to the government urging the repeal of the new law limiting foreign journalists' access to the country and requiring licenses for the local news media. He said those provisions, which include jail sentences for violators, ''infringe on the right to freedom of opinion and expression.'' Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Ferreting Out The Loopholes In Oscar Rules
description: As in any kind of campaign that involves hustling for votes, the race for Academy Awards has its own rules, built up over many years, to protect the process from taint by forbidding gift giving, wining and dining and outright bribery.

title: 57 at Grammar School Report Itchiness
description: Fifty-two elementary school children and five adults were taken to the hospital yesterday from a school in Queens, complaining of itching and, in some cases, a rash. They were treated, some with Benadryl, at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center and released, said Tara Fleming, a hospital spokeswoman.

title: A Marble Glory That Was Greece
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Jails Couple in Baby Case
description: A couple who belong to a religious sect were put in jail today after they refused to cooperate with Massachusetts officials trying to determine whether the couple had a baby late last year.

title: Nassau's Disaster Command Post Looks a Lot Like a Disaster Site Itself
description: Nassau County's emergency command center for dealing with disasters is hidden amid a maze of hallways and tunnels some 25 feet beneath Police Headquarters here. But these days it is the center itself that looks as if it had been hit by a disaster.

title: A Marble Glory That Was Greece
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IRWIN, JANE DARLINGTON
description: IRWIN-Jane Darlington. February 2, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Major Charles J. Irwin. Loving and devoted mother of Charles D. Irwin and his wife Dona. Cherished grandmother of Carter, Robert and Roger. A graduate of Chapin School Class of 1938, Vassar College Class of 1942, and later a 1st Lieutenant Navy WAVES. Former president of the Colonial Dames of America and the Society for the Relief of Women and Children, the oldest charitable organization in the United States, organized 1797. A graceful and loving lady who will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Service on Friday, February 8, 11 AM at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, 5th Ave. at 53 St. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory may be made to the Society for the Relief of Women and Children, 260 Madison Avenue, C/O McLaughlin & Stern, New York, New York 10016.

title: Lindros Set to Face Detroit
description: Eric Lindros is expected to return to the lineup Wednesday night when the Rangers face the Detroit Red Wings. ''As far as I know, I'm going to play,'' Lindros said. ''It feels all good.''

title: Life Savers?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Slide Show: Currents
Slide Show: Chandeliers Are Back
French Minister Calls U.S. Policy 'Simplistic'
description: Frustration with President Bush's worldview burst into the open here today, as Foreign Minister Hubert Vdrine openly criticized Washington's approach to terrorism as ''simplistic.''

title: Geneva Convention to Be Applied to Captured Taliban Fighters
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  Apparently deferring to international criticism, President Bush has decided to apply the Geneva Convention to Taliban fighters captured in Afghanistan, the White House announced today.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Sentence For Big Mac Attacker
description: The highest appeals court upheld a three-month jail term for Jos Bov for his ransacking of a McDonald's restaurant site in Millau in 1999 to protest American trade policy. The judges rejected his argument that the attack was ''legal and necessary'' civil resistance to punitive United States taxes on certain European farm products. But Mr. Bov said election-year politics might play a role in whether the police ever come to get him. He is also fighting a six-month term for hacking down genetically modified rice plants in 1999. Suzanne Daley (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PROSKE, BEATRICE GILMAN
description: PROSKE-Beatrice Gilman. Died February 2, at the age of 102. She was curator of sculpture at The Hispanic Society of America in New York City for 53 years and an honorary trustee at Brookgreen Gardens in South Carolina. Memorial contributions may be sent to The Hispanic Society of America, 613 West 155th Street, NY, NY 10032 or Brookgreen Gardens, Murrells Inlet, S.C. 29576.

title: No Fiber Optic Link? Try a Leapfrogging Laser Beam
description: AS many a city pigeon gliding from one window ledge to another knows, some space is still free for the taking.

title: Contraction Plans? Anyone's Guess
description: What evil lurks in the hearts of men? If the Shadow knows, he should tell Jeffrey Loria whether anyone in Major League Baseball's hierarchy has any evil thoughts about contraction.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Neptune: 2 Indicted In Killing
description: Two high school sweethearts have been charged in the fatal shooting of a Marlboro pharmacist two years ago. The defendants, Jaron D. Reevey, 20, and Sabrina Wright, were indicted Tuesday on murder charges in the killing of George J. Lockhart Jr., who was shot in the head on May 9, 2000, in the parking lot of the Neptune Rite Aid pharmacy. Prosecutors did not immediately give details linking the suspects to the killing, but said it was part of a larger crime spree. The defendants also face kidnapping and carjacking charges filed last month in Baltimore. During a chase there last month in which the couple were pursued by the police, Mr. Reevey was shot several times by the pursuing officers. He remains in critical but stable condition at Johns Hopkins Medical Center in Baltimore.

title: Cuba, Too, Felt the Sept. 11 Shock Waves, With a More Genial Castro Offering Help
description: In the wake of the terrorist attacks on the United States, President Fidel Castro of Cuba has muted his hostile remarks about Washington and offered to cooperate with the Bush administration's war on terrorism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, GERALD N.
description: ROSENBERG-Gerald N. February 6, 2002 of NY and Boca Raton, FL. Beloved husband of Joyce. Loving and always supportive father of William, Jane and Nancy. Dear father-in-law of Harris Udell. Adored grandfather of Elizabeth and Kelli. Cherished brother of Malcolm and Helen May. A graduate of Brooklyn Law School, he practiced law and was a mortgage broker from 1954 until retirement in 1996. He will be greatly missed. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the National Brain Tumor Foundation 1-800-934-CURE.

title: For the Olympics, a Most Athletic Curtain
description: THOUGH he will not take home gold, silver or bronze, Chuck Hoberman, 45, will feel a rush of excitement on Saturday evening as the Olympic medal ceremonies begin. If all goes as planned, at exactly 8:06 Mr. Hoberman's Unfolding Arch, a steel, aluminum and acrylic curtain 36 feet high and 72 feet wide, will glide open like a giant mechanical iris, revealing the stage where victorious athletes will stand for their national anthems.

title: Model Student. All-American Kicker. No Scholarship.
description: Erik Hinterbichler plays the cello, has a black belt in karate, is the senior class valedictorian at Albuquerque High School and will turn 18 in May. He can also kick a field goal from 55 yards.

title: California Officers Will Fly Armed and Specially Trained
description: In a legacy of Sept. 11, officers of the California Highway Patrol will be trained to thwart airline hijackings and will carry loaded weapons aboard flights within the state when they travel on official business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARIN, WILLIAM HARVEY
description: MARIN-William Harvey. Beloved brother of Carol Marin Zeles. Brother-in-law of Bob Zeles. Uncle of Michelle and Joe Zeles of Littleton, Colorado. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Musician's Assistance Program, 817 Vine St., Hollywood, CA. 90038.

title: SBA COMMUNICATIONS TO CLOSE OFFICES AND CUT WORKERS
description: The SBA Communications Corporation, which leases antenna space to mobile-phone service providers, plans to cut an unspecified number of jobs, close offices and build fewer towers this year. The company expects to build or buy 250 to 350 towers this year, instead of 400 to 600, it said in a statement. The company, which is based in Boca Raton, Fla., anticipates a loss of $2.90 to $3.20 a share in 2002, wider than the $2 to $2.20 it forecast earlier. SBA Communications said it expected to have costs for severance and office closings of $35 million to $65 million in the first quarter. The company will report final fourth-quarter results on Feb. 27.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Paypal Offering Delayed
description: PayPal, which was to have set a price for its initial public stock offering yesterday after the close of trading, has postponed the offering, the lead underwriter on the offering said. The timing of the offering now is unclear, according to the underwriter, the Salomon Smith Barney unit of Citigroup. The delay came after a lawsuit was filed against PayPal, a leading online payment company, people close to the offering said. A PayPal rival, CertCo, filed the lawsuit earlier this week, claiming patent infringement.

title: In Her World, the Galleries Are Merely Entrances
description: PENNY PRODDOW whisked down the corridor of the Greek and Roman galleries in the Metropolitan Museum of Art. She clutched an oversize Vuitton handbag with a large Swiss Army pocket watch dangling from the strap. A trail of two dozen children gripping sketchbooks wove its away around onlookers and statues like a serpentine tail behind her. She halted. The children pushed forward and plopped down around a glass case holding a small marble Cycladic figure of a harp player seated on a high-backed chair.

title: Johnson May Get A Role in Ceremony
description: Bill Johnson, the American Olympic gold medal-winning skier whose attempt to qualify for the 2002 Olympics at age 40 ended last March with a near-fatal crash in competition, is scheduled to be among the notable participants in the opening ceremonies of the Salt Lake Games on Friday. It was not clear what role Johnson would play since the final details of the opening ceremonies are always hidden from the public, but several Olympic officials said Johnson had been flown to Utah today to take part in the ceremony's final rehearsals.

title: Human Rights: The Long View
description: To the Editor:

title: Professor Who Led Audit Panel Failed to Spot Smoke and Mirrors
description: Frustrated Enron investors have directed some of their anger at Robert K. Jaedicke, an accounting professor emeritus who ran the board committee that oversaw the company's auditors and financial statements. Of all the directors, they say, he should have been able to detect chicanery.

title: Backyard Grills Give Way to Ice-Skating Rinks
description: Steve and Helen Maxwell have a simple suburban backyard -- swing set, patio, barbecue grill. The basic summertime survival kit, obsolete until winter dissolves into spring. But this winter, Mr. Maxwell dreamed of something else.

title: Economic Scene; The president wants Americans to volunteer to pick up the slack in social services. But will that be enough?
description: FROM an economic perspective, the most interesting proposal in last week's State of the Union address was President Bush's call ''for every American to commit at least two years -- 4,000 hours over the rest of your lifetime -- to the service of your neighbors and your nation.'' That works out to around 80 hours a year for every adult. Although that sounds like -- and is -- a lot, by some counts the average American is already volunteering that much. Why do so many people give away so much of their time?

title: Solving Modern's Midlife Crisis
description: FOR over 40 years, midcentury modern has been the look of youth, promise and progress. It's time to move on.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Advanced Micro Aims At Hand-Held Market
description: Advanced Micro Devices said yesterday that it would acquire Alchemy Semiconductor, a privately held maker of low-power chips for hand-held devices like wireless personal digital assistants. Advanced Micro hopes Alchemy's chips will help it gain ground in the emerging market for portable Internet access devices, where it faces stiff competition. The companies declined to provide financial details. Alchemy, based in Austin, Tex., was founded in 1999 by Rich Witek and Greg Hoeppner, both of whom helped develop the Alpha processor for the Digital Equipment Corporation and both of whom will join Advanced Micro's new personal connectivity solutions business unit. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Commercial Lending Increased in 2001
description: Commercial mortgage lending rose 19 percent in 2001 as property owners took advantage of falling interest rates to refinance loans, the Mortgage Bankers Association of America says.

title: German Unemployment Is Growing Problem for Schrder
description: The German chancellor, Gerhard Schrder, suffered an expected but still stinging political blow today when it was announced that German unemployment figures rose sharply in January, above the psychologically important four million total.

title: Transition Game
description: With dazed stares, the dozen basketball players from a college town nestled in the rugged hills of upstate New York wandered around the fabled arena in North Carolina.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSH, SHEILA R.
description: HIRSH-Sheila R. On February 5, 2002. Beloved wife of the late David. Devoted mother of Gary & Karen, Fred and Mindy. Cherished grandmother of Carly, Neil, Douglas, Nicole and Matthew.
