description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Bush, in New York, Affirms $20 Billion Aid Pledge
description: President Bush flew into New York yesterday and declared that he would stand by his pledge to provide the city with at least $20 billion to help rebuild from last summer's terrorist attacks, moving to dispel doubts raised by Democrats about the depth of the White House's commitment to help New York recover.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARSHAUER, ARLINE
description: WARSHAUER-Arline. Of Little Silver, N.J. and Tarpon Springs, FL. Beloved wife of Martin. Loving mother of Dr. Lewis, and James of Rumson, and Dr. Bruce of Fairhaven. Devoted sister of Gloria Reamer of Coconut Creek, FL. and step-brother of Robert Haskell, New York. Cherished grandmother of eight. Services 10AM Friday from the BloomfieldCooper Jewish Chapels, Ocean Township, N.J.

title: WHIRLPOOL SHARES FALL ON ACCOUNTING CONCERNS
description: Shares in the Whirlpool Corporation fell 9.7 percent, their biggest drop since September, amid questions about the earnings report the company released on Tuesday. Questions emerged after an Internet-based research company, Briefing.com, reported that stock traders speculated that the company had included ''nonoperating items'' in its report. Whirlpool denied the speculation and reaffirmed its 2001 earnings results and its forecast for 5 percent to 10 percent profit growth this year. The company's stock fell $7.04, to $65.50 a share.

title: Great Museums' Mission
description: To the Editor:

title: An Indefensible Military Budget
description: Congress cheered President Bush's pledge, in the State of the Union address, to spend ''whatever it costs to defend our country.'' But here's the secret. Mr. Bush already has most of the money he seeks. And absent real reform, most of the additional money Congress ultimately approves -- the president has requested a quarter of a trillion dollars more over the next five years -- will never reach our fighting men and women in the field.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the appointment of Dr. Kenneth I. Berns to head Mount Sinai Medical Center referred incorrectly to his title. He was appointed chief executive, not also president. Because of an editing error, the article referred imprecisely to the institution he will lead. It is the medical center -- comprising Mount Sinai Hospital and the Mount Sinai School of Medicine -- not just the hospital.

title: Briefly Noted; SECURITY FORCE
description: The senior United Nations official for Afghanistan, Lakhdar Brahimi, added his voice to those of Afghan leaders in appealing for an expanded international security force. The United States and the countries providing the bulk of the force -- Britain, France and Germany -- have all resisted calls to expand the 4,500-member unit beyond Kabul. Instead, they have pressed for an Afghan Army and police force. Serge Schmemann (NYT)

title: Of Mice and Men And Novelists
description: John Steinbeck is making a comeback. Which is a strange thing to say about an author whose books still sell about two million copies a year, but it is true. The list of Nobel laureates in literature is filled with who's, as in ''who is that?'' Steinbeck is not one of them, but he has never been too popular among the higher academics of literature, his work considered too sentimental for great art, his writing simply not good enough.

title: More Get Rich and Pay Less in Taxes
description: The number of Americans with million-dollar incomes more than doubled from 1995 through 1999, as their salaries and their profits from stocks soared, government figures to be published today show. The percentage of their income that went to federal income taxes, however, fell by 11 percent.

title: As Suicide Approvals Rise In Oregon, Half Go Unused
description: As the Bush administration prepares to go to court to overturn Oregon's assisted-suicide law, state officials said today that 44 terminally ill residents received prescriptions for lethal medication last year, the most since the law took effect in 1997.

title: Cisco Recovers, Reporting Profit in Quarter
description: Showing a return to the steady performance that made it a favorite among investors, the technology bellwether Cisco Systems reported second-quarter earnings today that nearly doubled Wall Street's expectations.

title: A Muskrat and a Mad Dash In Vast and Detailed Worlds
description: JAK AND DAXTER: THE PRECURSOR LEGACY

title: S.E.C. REQUESTS INFORMATION FROM CALPINE
description: The Calpine Corporation said it received an ''informal request for information'' from the Securities and Exchange Commission on disclosures to analysts. The request, from the S.E.C.'s enforcement division, followed a Jan. 4 Dow Jones Newswire report that the company had made selective disclosures to analysts on capital spending and earnings expectations, a Calpine spokesman, Bill Highlander, said. On Jan. 16, Calpine reduced its 2001 and 2002 earnings forecasts and put off $2 billion of capital projects. ''We contend we've made no selective disclosures, and we'll work with the S.E.C. to clarify it,'' Mr. Highlander said.

title: Parolees and Security
description: To the Editor:

title: New Twist on Physicist's Role in Nazi Bomb
description: The leader of Hitler's atomic bomb program, Werner Heisenberg, portrayed himself after World War II as a kind of scientific resistance hero who sabotaged Hitler's efforts to build a nuclear weapon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILCOX, STANLEY PAUL
description: WILCOX-Stanley Paul. Businessman Stanley Paul Wilcox, 77, of Palm Beach and Charlottesville, died February 4. He received his B.S. from Northwestern University and did graduate work at SeaburyWestern Theological Seminary. He entered the U.S. Navy in 1943 as Apprentice Seaman, was Honor Man of his Naval Training Company 308, was a Radio-Gunner in Fleet Air Wing 11, and was honorably discharged as a Lt. (jg) Line Officer in 1951. In 1963 he became President of United Service Industries, a health care company in Virginia; he sold the company in 1984. From 1964-1984, Mr. Wilcox served as President of the VA Nursing Home Association; on the original Board of Examiners for Nursing Home Administrators; on the Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Virginia board; and for 2 terms on the Provider Reimbursement Review Board. He was Secretary of the Albemarle Electoral Board and Chair of the county's Republican Committee. An ardent yachtsman, Mr. Wilcox's boats sported red hulls and the name ''Mustang,'' to include an 83-foot sailboat commissioned from Camper & Nicholson International, in which he sailed the world and was featured in The World's Best Sail Boats and Yachting Magazine. He was a 16year member of the New York Yacht Club and a member of the Palm Beach Yacht Club. Survivors include his wife, Alice Freer Wilcox; daughter, Marjorie Weeks, Baltimore, MD; sons Gregory, Atlanta, GA, and Stanford and Douglas, Charlottesville, VA; and eight grandchildren. A private memorial service and interment will be held in Palm Beach.

title: In Quest for Wrinkle-Free Future, Frown Becomes Thing of the Past
description: It is a staple for affluent professionals, television talking heads, ladies who lunch and actors who refuse to age. Without a peep of promotion, it has become the most popular cosmetic medical procedure in the country, despite the fact that it involves injecting the neurotoxin that causes botulism directly into muscles in the face, paralyzing them and thus erasing wrinkles.

title: Conductor Comes Home to America, Barcelona Orchestra in Tow
description: Lawrence Foster, the American who took over as music director of the Barcelona Symphony five seasons ago, seemed thrilled to be bringing his musicians to Carnegie Hall on Friday evening, and they sounded thoroughly pleased to be there playing for him. The sound was lively, forward, exuberant. It often also flew by rather fast. But if some of the finer points of polish were thereby lost, the effect of this orchestra was strong and winning, in the mass (not least in their unanimous slow crescendos) and in the detail of some well-projected solo playing.

title: Deficit Fuels Nassau Debate On Income Tax
description: Although Nassau County residents already pay among the nation's highest property and sales taxes, some people are proposing yet another tax -- on personal income.

title: Fire Dept. Is Seeking Free Study Of Sept. 11
description: The Fire Department, acting on its pledge of a sweeping outside appraisal of its response to the World Trade Center attack, has begun interviewing large management consulting firms about a study of the department's command procedures, communications and other operations.

title: Anjuna Beach Journal; Toe Rings, Rave Music and India (Just for Israelis)
description: Hebrew-language banners flutter improbably in the sea breeze here while a poster of Rabbi Menachem M. Schneerson, the Lubavitcher sage from Brooklyn, keeps a watchful eye on the youngsters on their way to the next full-moon trance party on the beach.

title: Bright Lights, Big Mountains, Big Dreams
description: Michael Peters of Manhattan remembers when the notice went up in his school offering six weeks of free snowboarding lessons.

title: Dubai's Airline Plans Rapid Growth
description: The terror attacks on Sept. 11 and the fighting in Afghanistan would appear to be major blows to the international expansion plans of any airline based in the Middle East. But Emirates Airlines disagrees.

title: CUNY's Excellence
description: To the Editor:

title: Rash at School Is a Mystery, But Anthrax Is Ruled Out
description: They are calling it ''the Itch'' because, at this point, there is no other name for the mysterious rash that broke out Tuesday among a group of Queens fifth graders, causing splotchy redness on small arms and faces and panic among parents, some of whom had unfounded fears that anthrax spores were lurking in a textbook.

title: Grandparent Caregivers
description: To the Editor:

title: Simon & Schuster Says It Laid Off 20 Workers
description: As the major book publishers tighten their belts to adjust to flagging sales, the Simon & Schuster books division of Viacom said yesterday that it had laid off about 20 staff members.

title: CARNIVAL TO SWEETEN OFFER FOR P&O PRINCESS
description: The Carnival Corporation is preparing to raise its hostile bid for P&O Princess Cruises, people close to the companies said yesterday. Carnival is expected to announce the sweetened offer as early as Thursday, these people said. Micky Arison, the chief executive of Carnival, has been meeting with P&O Princess shareholders this week in Britain to convince them of the merits of his $5 billion offer and head off a rival deal. P&O Princess shareholders are scheduled to vote at a meeting next Thursday whether to approve a $2.9 billion takeover by Royal Caribbean Cruises of Miami. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Really Old Stuff, in Storage Till You Buy It
description: A mini-storage unit may seem an unusual place to go shopping, but when Ani Antreasyan, a garden designer, opened Canyan Antiques, she tucked it into a 750-square-foot room on the second floor of a Chelsea warehouse otherwise devoted to the overflow from crowded New York apartments. She has filled her ''store'' with antique marble sinks, fountains, urns, outdoor tables and chairs, butterflies under glass, 18th-century crystal sconces and white ceramic pots. But her biggest cache consists of hundreds of olive jars from Turkey, some as old as 200 years, she said. They are rough-surfaced terra-cotta or glazed olive green; some are small enough to hold wooden spoons, while others are large enough to hold a potted palm ($50 to $150). The 19th-century marble sinks were salvaged from Turkish bathhouses and Italian villas, Ms. Antreasyan said. Ones with ornately scalloped edges and carved rosettes ($500 to $2,800) seem destined for fashionable bathroom renovations. While the shop is open to the public, the building is not, so appointments are necessary: (212) 722-5342. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: AT HOME WITH/Candice Olson; Trading Places: C.E.O. Does Mrs. Mom
description: ''I FEEL like I spend my whole life annoying people,'' Candice Olson said last week, sitting on a couch in her Park Avenue apartment. She grinned, because she knows she's probably right. And she couldn't care less.

title: CARMAX EXPECTS TO BEAT FORECASTS IN FOURTH QUARTER
description: The CarMax Auto Superstores unit of Circuit City Stores Inc. expects fiscal fourth-quarter earnings to beat forecasts because the company is selling more used cars than estimated. Net income in the quarter ending Feb. 28 is expected to be 16 cents or 17 cents a share, the company said. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call expected the company to earn 7 cents, matching its profit a year earlier. CarMax expects fourth-quarter same-store used-car sales to rise 20 percent from a year earlier, barring bad weather this month. New- and used-car sales rose in December as no-interest loans offered by automakers increased customer traffic, the company said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATHIS, ROBERT T.
description: MATHIS-Robert T. Of Greenwich, CT, died February 5. A graduate of Columbia College and the Harvard Business School, he was an investment banker at Blyth Eastman Dillon and Paine Webber; and served as a missionary to the Diocese of Mount Kilimanjaro. He is survived by his daughters, Liliana, Bronwyn and Kane; their mother, Laurelle Sheedy Mathis, all of Riverside, CT. A memorial service will be held Friday, February 8 at 2PM at Christ Church, Greenwich.

title: Hearing on Union's Grievance Is Put Off
description: The threat of contraction for the coming season has ended but not necessarily its effects.

title: National Briefing | Washington: G.O.P. Budget Dispute
description: The Republican chairman of the House Appropriations Committee wrote to the White House budget director, Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., rejecting his proposal to pay for a $1.3 billion shortfall in the Pell Grant program by eliminating projects designated by members of Congress for their districts. The chairman, Representative C. W. Bill Young of Florida, said members of Congress often knew the real needs of their constituents better than executive branch officials. Adam Clymer (NYT)

title: Whatever You Do, Don't Breathe
description: Here we are at the Winter Olympics, the symbol of all that is healthy and upright, and they are warning us about the oily particles and other gunk that currently passes for air in this town.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIANETTINO, LAWRENCE D.
description: GIANETTINO-Lawrence D. Ricco/Maresca Gallery is saddened by the loss of our close friend and colleague, Larry Gianettino (1956-2002). It will be a quieter, less ebullient, and much less colorful world without him.

title: Ridge Meeting Opposition From Agencies
description: Four months into his tenure as director of homeland security, Tom Ridge is facing significant doubts about his authority and ability to do his job.

title: INSIDE
description: 3 Israeli Settlers Killed

title: Officials Overlooked Dire Signs At Charity
description: For years, it seemed, Hale House could do no wrong. Politicians of all stripes championed its work with the babies of drug-addicted or imprisoned mothers. Millions of dollars, from celebrities, corporate donors, national charities and just plain people, poured in to the Harlem shelter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALDHAM, SYDNEY H.
description: ALDHAM-Sydney H. On February 5, 2002, beloved husband of the late Frances Alice (nee Cihelka), loving father of Carol and Albert, dear brother of C.V. Aldham. Past President of The General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen, Lifetime Member of The New York Power Squadron.

title: Doubts on Changes Planned by Big Five
description: The changes the Big Five accounting firms have announced since Enron's collapse will not go far enough to stop another such problem, say former regulators, accounting experts and even executives at the accounting firms themselves.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Accord In Nurses' Strike
description: A tentative agreement was reached after a 15-hour negotiating session between representatives of 1,300 striking nurses and Oregon Health and Science University. The agreement calls for a 20.5 percent wage increase over three years as well as improved insurance and retirement benefits, and tuition reimbursement. The nurses, who have been striking for 53 days, will vote on the agreement on Sunday.

title: Cynical Use of Tragedy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHRISTMAS, WALTER
description: CHRISTMAS-Walter. The Sophie Davis School of Biomedical Education/CUNY Medical School deeply regrets the recent death of Walter Christmas, husband of our esteemed colleague, Dr. June Jackson Christmas. Our condolences to the entire family. Stanford A. Roman, Jr, MD, Dean

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Budget Shortfall
description: For the second straight year, Gov. Mike F. Easley has invoked emergency powers to deal with a shortfall in the state budget, which is projected to exceed $900 million by the end of the fiscal year. Legislators based the current $14.4 billion budget on a projected 4 percent growth in tax revenue, but revenue growth is now projected to fall 3.1 percent below last year, Governor Easley said. He plans to save $1.2 billion by asking agencies to cut their budgets by up to 7 percent, freezing travel and purchases, using $313 million in the state's reserve and suspending $209 million in reimbursements to local governments.

title: Smithsonian Pluses and Minuses
description: This has been a week of ups and downs for the Smithsonian Institution. On Monday, in its fiscal 2003 budget, the Bush administration proposed an additional $9 million for the Smithsonian, bringing its annual appropriation to a record $528 million. On the same day, Catherine Reynolds announced that she would withdraw the bulk of a $38 million gift offered to the Smithsonian last May, money that would have been used to create a hall of American achievement in the National Museum of American History. Writing to Lawrence Small, secretary of the Smithsonian, Ms. Reynolds said she had never dreamed that her plan would be so controversial.

title: Briefly Noted
description: FRACTIOUS NATION Hamid Karzai, chairman of the interim government, visited Herat, in western Afghanistan, on his first trip to the countryside since taking office in December. Mr. Karzai was given a warm welcome in the city, which is in one of the country's most troubled regions. But government efforts to end a bloody power struggle in Gardez, in the east, were set back when the ousted governor declined an offer of mediation. (Reuters)

title: U.S. RELEASING 27 CAPTURED IN RAID
description: American forces in Afghanistan today released to the Afghan authorities 27 prisoners captured in a raid north of Kandahar last month, saying they were not Taliban or Qaeda fighters as the Pentagon originally said.

title: Wheelchair Users Achieve Milestone in 2 Ordinances
description: The next time Bill Malleris goes to a party at a new home here, he will drink as much as he wants without worry.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Took Care of the Kids (And Very Good Notes)
description: EMMA MCLAUGHLIN, who became a nanny for wealthy families on the Upper East Side while she was still in college, realized she was in a different world right away. ''I'm from upstate New York, so one step into the lobby and it's an instantaneous moment,'' she said.

title: Sports of The Times; Jingoism Is the Way of the Olympics
description: WHO lights the caldron for the always emotional wrap to the opening ceremony tomorrow night remains a secret, but we do know it won't be the most deserving American athlete in Winter Olympics history.

title: When All Else Fails, Check the Cord
description: Over the years, I've fielded my share of hilarious tech-support calls. In fact, I consider myself a connoisseur of the funniest help-line tales, having compiled a book of them a couple of years ago. (You know: "Hello, Apple? My cup holder broke off!" "Um, sir, that's your CD-ROM tray.")

title: Holmes's Horse's Dog
description: ''It is my business to know what other people don't know.''

title: Darth Vader. Machiavelli. Skilling Set Intense Pace.
description: To many people inside Enron, Jeffrey K. Skilling was the ultimate control freak -- the sort of hands-on corporate leader who kept his fingers on all the pieces of the puzzle. As the leading protg of the genial Kenneth L. Lay when Mr. Lay was chairman, the intense Mr. Skilling built the company in his own demanding image: some co-workers called him Darth Vader, a nickname he was said to be particularly proud of.

title: Assessing Pornography, Brashly Yet Gingerly
description: You know you're dealing with a rough world when Larry Flynt is its elder statesman. In ''Frontline: American Porn,'' Mr. Flynt, the founder of Hustler magazine, says, ''You can now see on television material just as explicit as we were publishing in Hustler in 1974.'' Ambitious but intellectually half-baked, ''American Porn'' goes a long way toward demonstrating that amazing transformation of standards.

title: Fixtures That Move Starlight Indoors
description: FROM fixtures dripping with Austrian crystals to pendants shaped like spiny sea urchins, chandeliers are back in style.

title: U.S. Commander Orders Moves to Protect Friendly Afghan Forces
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  Stung by criticism that American commandos might have mistakenly killed anti-Taliban forces in a raid last month, the commander of the military operation in Afghanistan said today he had ordered his top ground officers to tighten their coordination with friendly Afghan forces to prevent another incident.

title: Duisenberg to Step Down as Head of Europe's Central Bank
description: Wim Duisenberg will retire as president of the European Central Bank on July 9, 2003, the ECB announced on Thursday, ending months of uncertainty over how long the Bank's first president would stay in office.

title: Problems on the Street, Solvable With a Pencil
description: In a drizzling rain, a 63-year-old professor, George Nobl, stood on a stretch of Times Square sidewalk the other day beside an easel blithely daring passers-by to solve a math problem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REISS, SYLVIA
description: REISS-Sylvia. Beloved mother of Helen and Wally, Elinor, Alan and Esther. Cherished grandmother to Melanie and Michael, Hal and Susie, Holly, Jayne and Hunter, Robert, David and Renee. Greatgrandmother to Jesse, Kimmy, Tory, Reed, Samantha, Joey and Talia. Services will be held Friday at ''The Riverside'', at 76th Street at ll:15 A.M.

title: India Reacts With Anger To a Speech By Pakistani
description: India's two most powerful political leaders reacted harshly today to a speech Pakistan's military ruler gave Tuesday that has heightened doubts here about whether Pakistan will end its support for Islamic groups waging a guerrilla war against India in Kashmir.

title: London's Preening in a Rearview Mirror
description: The advice, offered by a well-dressed thug to his drunken employer, is brisk, peremptory and unlikely to be heeded: ''Don't look back.''

title: Tokens of Love, Found by Sailors On Shifting Sands
description: Ships cruising the Caribbean in the mid-19th century often returned home with sailors' valentines: shellwork rosettes and hearts in octagonal cedar boxes the size of dinner plates. ''They must have been the most romantic gifts imaginable,'' said John Fondas, a collector in the Bahamas whose new book, ''Sailors' Valentines'' (Rizzoli, $50), is fittingly on octagonal pages. He easily envisions ''the look on the face of the beloved back home the first time she opened this absolutely austere box and found a colorful, exotic wonder world inside.'' Sailors didn't actually make most of the valentines. Barbadians did, using beach finds and sometimes incorporating clients' names and photographs. Loved ones rarely minded having a memento made by a stranger's hand, Mr. Fondas said, because they knew sailors were too busy trimming and furling sails to glue shells together. The smart ones passed down their souvenirs: the best examples are now valued at up to $45,000, he said. EVE M. KAHN

title: MGM Says Profit Tripled in 4th Quarter
description: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc., owner of one of the largest film libraries, said today that its fourth-quarter profit had tripled as sales of movies on digital video discs rose more than expected.

title: Footlights
description: Sister Acts

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LLANO, MARGARET (NEE THOMPSON)
description: LLANO-Margaret (nee Thompson). Widow of Adolfo Llano and daughter of the late Dr. Arthur W. and Clara (nee Coard) Thompson. Died January 31 in Southbury, CT. Mrs. Llano was born in Flushing, NY. She graduated from PS 20 Elementary School in Flushing at age 11 and from Flushing H.S. at age 14, the youngest graduate in all the high schools in NYC. She obtained her BS in Elementary Education and her MA in Personnel Administration at NYU. She began her business career as Secretary to the Foreign Trade Manager at the Denver Chemical Manufacturing Company in NYC. At the age of 38 she was chosen to serve as CEO and Acting President for an interim period and then as Executive VP until Denver Chemical moved to Connecticut. Her professional career continued for ten years at the American Institution of Physics in the Education and Manpower Division. As a teenager Mrs. Llano played tennis at the Bayside, Long Island Tennis Club. Mr. and Mrs. Llano were avid golfers, members of Westchester Country Club for 18 years and Heritage Village Country Club for 20 years. In 1969 she retired from business and with her husband toured golf courses in Europe and England. They moved to Heritage Village in Southbury, CT in 1971. The youngest of nine children she is survived by many nieces and nephews. Services will be private and burial will be in the Thompson family plot at Flushing Cemetery, Flushing, NY.

title: DaimlerChrysler Dividend May Be Cut More Than Half
description: The management board at DaimlerChrysler proposed today that the company's dividend be cut by more than half in the first reduction since the merger of DaimlerBenz and Chrysler in 1998.

title: Health of the Mother
description: It is encouraging that the Bush administration seems to support the goal of providing prenatal care to uninsured women. But the best way to do this is not by extending a children's health program to cover ''unborn children,'' as President Bush wants to do. Rather, it is by providing health care directly to pregnant women. For the sake of both mother and baby, women need full and appropriate prenatal and postpartum care that focuses on their own needs as they become mothers, as well as on keeping the fetus healthy.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Poughkeepsie: Adopted Child Goes Home
description: A Poughkeepsie woman and her adopted Vietnamese daughter returned home Tuesday night, after a nearly two-month delay in which the Immigration and Naturalization Service questioned whether the 4-month-old baby had been properly put up for adoption. The woman, the Rev. Sharon L. Williams, and her husband, the Rev. J. Wayne Hanrattie, were among eight American families who had traveled to Vietnam to adopt nine children. The children were denied visas at first because of the I.N.S. inquiry. In the past week, the I.N.S. has granted visas to seven of the children, but the status of the last two is in doubt. ''We have found serious concerns,'' an I.N.S. spokesman said yesterday. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Bits of History Are Stolen at Mansions
description: THE silver's missing and the police are wondering: Was it the guests? Burglars hit two historic houses in the Hudson Valley last week, making off with more than $100,000 in silver and parlor knickknacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IRWIN, JANE DARLINGTON
description: IRWIN-Jane Darlington. February 2, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Major Charles J. Irwin. Loving and devoted mother of Charles D. Irwin and his wife Dona. Cherished grandmother of Carter, Robert and Roger. A graduate of Chapin School Class of 1938, Vassar College Class of 1942, and later a 1st Lieutenant Navy WAVES. Former president of the Colonial Dames of America and the Society for the Relief of Women and Children, the oldest charitable organization in the United States, organized 1797. A graceful and loving lady who will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Service on Friday, February 8, 11 AM at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, 5th Ave. at 53 St. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory may be made to the Society for the Relief of Women and Children, 260 Madison Avenue, C/O McLaughlin & Stern, New York, New York 10016.

title: Judge Quickly Turns Down Lindh's Request for Bail
description: In a swift and firm ruling, a federal magistrate said today that John Walker Lindh, the Californian captured with anti-American forces in Afghanistan, must stay in prison while he awaits trial on charges that he conspired to kill his countrymen.

title: Besieged S.E.C. Is on Verge of a Major Revamping
description: Under siege for its early political mishandling of the Enron collapse and facing a far-reaching array of regulatory decisions, the Securities and Exchange Commission is about to undergo a major makeover.

title: Varying the Subject Line To Fool the Spam Filter
description: Q. I often get spam messages that contain some sort of code or sequence of numbers on the far right side of the Subject line. Do these numbers mean anything?

title: Judge Quickly Turns Down Lindh's Request for Bail
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Feb. 6  In a swift and firm ruling, a federal magistrate said today that John Walker Lindh, the Californian captured with anti-American forces in Afghanistan, must stay in prison while he awaits trial on charges that he conspired to kill his countrymen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEALESSANDRO, JOSEPH P.
description: DeALESSANDRO-Joseph P. The trustees, faculty, staff and students of The Culinary Institute of America (CIA) mourn the death of Joseph P. DeAlessandro, Honorary Member of the Board of Trustees and Honorary Alumnus. Mr. DeAlessandro received an Honorary Doctorate of Humane Letters from the college in 1999 in recognition of his generous support of culinary education. The main dining room in the CIA's Ristorante Caterina de' Medici is named in his honor. Our deepest sympathies are extended to Mr. DeAlessandro's family, friends, and colleagues.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, STELLA
description: BERNSTEIN-Stella, 97. Hollywood, FL. Formerly of West Hartford, on February 5, 2002. An extraordinary life has ended and we are all poorer for it. Devoted wife of the late Sidney, adored mother of Dick and Sonny, Mark & Arlene, David and Patty; grandchildren Lori, Robert, Jeffrey, Michael, Emily and Brad; and four great grandchildren. Also survived by her cherished sister-in-law Ethel Goodman. Graveside service on Friday, February 8th, 10:30AM Beth El Cemetery, Avon, CT.

title: Computer Associates' Share Price Drops 13.5%
description: Computer Associates' stock plunged yesterday after Moody's Investors Service said it might lower the rating of the company's bonds because its cash flow is falling.

title: Cheney Plans to Visit Middle East in March
description: Vice President Dick Cheney will visit Israel and 10 other countries next month for talks about terrorism and regional security, the White House announced today.

title: U.S. Weighs Tackling Iraq On Its Own, Powell Says
description: In his sharpest comments yet on the next phase of the war on terrorism, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell told Congress today that President Bush was set on a ''regime change'' in Iraq and warned that it was something the United States ''might have to do alone.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about Russia's relations with Iraq referred incorrectly to Shiite Muslims who are being protected from Saddam Hussein's military by American and British air patrols. Shiites in Iraq are a majority, not a minority.

title: Phones Can Name That Tune In Two Digital Beeps
description: If pop music sounds increasingly similar to you, fear not. Your cellphone may soon be able to distinguish between the Backstreet Boys and 'N Sync, even if you can't.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: TB Strikes Livestock
description: Federal and state officials are planning to slaughter more than 800 elk and cattle to contain the state's first case of tuberculosis in livestock since 1975. The federal Department of Agriculture will buy 500 elk and cattle from a private ranch where an elk died of the disease in November, paying about $10,000 per elk and $1,000 per head of cattle. Meanwhile, Oregon plans to spend as much as $200,000 to capture and kill 350 elk in nearby wilderness to find out if the disease has spread to the wild. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Faded Memories Revived With a Scanner's Magic
description: TIME has done little to rehabilitate the family slide show. My late father, like countless other parents during the 1960's, recorded our family history on color slide film, but 40 years later, there is little enthusiasm for dragging out the aged slide projector and wrestling the screen into position. It has certainly made my mother's duties as family archivist much lighter.

title: QAEDA STILL ABLE TO STRIKE THE U.S., HEAD OF C.I.A. SAYS
description: George J. Tenet, the director of central intelligence, said today that Al Qaeda was trying to reconstitute itself and remained capable of another large-scale attack against the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, ROSE
description: GOLDBERG-Rose. Wife of the late David J. Goldberg. Died February 2, 2002 in Miami Beach, FL. She was a founder of Mount Sinai Hospital, a Life Member of Amit Women, Hadassah, Technion and Jewish National Fund, Vice President of the Bialystoker Home for the Aged in New York and a Life Member of the Women's League for Cancer Research and the Cancer Life Line affiliated with Mount Sinai Hospital. She is survived by a son, Gary, of Suffern, N.Y., and three grandsons, Andrew, Mark and Justin. She is also survived by a sister, Shirley Elphand of Scarsdale, N.Y. Services were held on February 3rd in Miami Beach.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Destructive Ivy

title: A Painterly Light Cast on Mourning
description: Donlin Foreman and Jacqulyn Buglisi have toiled patiently for more than a decade as choreographers, presenting their work even before they formed their company, Buglisi/ Foreman Dance, in 1994.

title: Vintage Cards to Set the Heart Aflutter
description: HERE is how my mother, who grew up in the 1940's in an isolated eastern Kentucky hill town, celebrated Valentine's Day.

title: Computing Chameleon In a Little Black Box
description: THE history of the computing equivalent of the concept car -- pioneering ideas embodied on the drawing board or in a research prototype -- is rich, even inspiring. Examples include Charles Babbage's 19th-century Analytical Engine (a forerunner of the modern computer), Alan Kay's Dynabook of the late 1960's (a dream machine, rendered in cardboard, of a wireless notebook PC, which pointed toward what personal computing might become) and Xerox's Alto in the 1970's (a sturdy working prototype that brought accessible, point-and-click computing to life).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELF, EDWARD BALDWIN, M.D.
description: SELF-Edward Baldwin, M.D., 91. Of Edgartown, MA, January 18, 2002. Beloved husband of Beatrice Bellinger Self, father of Karen Self Osler of Hingham, MA, Edward B. Self, Jr., MD of Ridgewood, NJ and Kiawah, SC, and Judy Self Murphy of Old Saybrook, CT, also survived by nine grandchildren. Memorial Service on Saturday, February 9, 2002, 12:30 PM at the Federated Church, Edgartown, MA. Donations may be made to the Vineyard Conservation Society, P.O. Box 2189, Vineyard Haven, MA, 02568, Hospice of Martha's Vineyard, PO. Box 2549, Oak Bluffs, MA, 02557, or charity of your choice. Information Chapman, Cole & Gleason Funeral Home, Martha's Vineyard.

title: Expenses of Quaker Takeover Reduce Earnings at PepsiCo
description: PepsiCo Inc. posted a 4.4 percent decline in fourth-quarter earnings yesterday, largely because of costs associated with its acquisition of Quaker Oats.

title: States of Silliness
description: To the Editor:

title: Unwanted Role: Celebrity Widow; Loss and Politics Give Actress Different Kind of Fame
description: Marian Fontana, struggling writer and actress, has found fame. Or rather, fame has found her.

title: VISA AND MASTERCARD WIN STAY OF RULING IN RIVALS CASE
description: Visa International Inc. and MasterCard International Inc. won a stay of a ruling that ordered them to let member banks distribute the credit cards of two rivals, the American Express Company and Discover Financial Services. Judge Barbara Jones of United States District Court in New York granted the credit card associations' request to suspend her Oct. 9 ruling until an appeals court reviews the case, company officials said. The Justice Department had sued under antitrust laws to force Visa and MasterCard, the two largest credit card brands, to allow the associations' 6,000 member banks to distribute other cards. Visa and MasterCard together control 75 percent of the $1.3 trillion credit card market.

title: Hill, Holliday Ending Cisco Ties
description: The San Francisco office of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos is ending its relationship with Cisco Systems, the computer networking company, by declining to take part in a review that Cisco began last week for its account. Cisco spent $22.7 million for the first nine months of 2001, according to CMR, a unit of Taylor Nelson Sofres that tracks ad spending.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Earthlink Drops Overture
description: Shares of Overture Services plunged 41 percent after the Internet search engine lost its contract with EarthLink, an Internet service provider. Shares of Overture, which is based in Pasadena, Calif., slid $12.50, to $17.92, on word that EarthLink had named Google its search engine after permitting its contract with Overture to lapse. Overture provides a search engine where businesses can pay to have their Web sites listed more prominently in results. EarthLink said it had decided to let its contract with Overture end on Jan. 1 after deciding to expand its relationship with Google.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Parolees and Security

title: Revisiting Homeland Security
description: In naming Tom Ridge to head the newly created Office of Homeland Security last fall, President Bush essentially asked the nation to make a leap of faith that the former Pennsylvania governor could bring order to the multitude of federal, state and local agencies that play a role in protecting the home front from attack. Four months and a rash of anthrax attacks later, that remains the case. As far as we can tell, Mr. Ridge has done a vigorous and commendable job of trying to redirect and coordinate the work of these organizations and has just proposed a hefty but reasonable increase in spending by many of them. But Mr. Ridge's job description is so amorphous and his powers so opaque that even Congress is having trouble determining how much he has accomplished.

title: A Filmmaker Who Valued Art More Than Fame
description: The filmmaker Morris Engel, at 83 somewhat stooped with age, still living in the faded apartment on Central Park West he shared with his wife, the photographer Ruth Orkin, has no regrets. Long ago, in 1953, he made a dramatic film called ''Little Fugitive'' with Orkin and a friend, Ray Ashley.

title: Cable Company's Reality Check
description: Quick to outgun rivals at the negotiating table, Barclay Knapp built a European cable empire through a dizzying acquisition spree. Charmed by Mr. Knapp's boyish looks and his reputation as a financial whiz, investors were willing to overlook large losses at his company, NTL, and financed deals on the promise of big payouts in the future.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Profit At Hyundai
description: By consolidating its grip on its home market and moving up-market in the United States, Hyundai Motor earned $896 million last year, 75 percent more than the year before, the company reported. Hyundai said it increased unit sales in the United States by 42 percent, to 346,000 vehicles. Analysts said the sales increase was a sign that the company was overcoming an earlier reputation for poor design and quality with popular new models like the Sonata sedan.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a development project in Arverne on the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens misspelled the surname of the area's newly elected city councilman, who is involved in talks about the project. He is James Sanders Jr., not Saunders.

title: Beanpot Goes High-Tech
description: The Beanpot Tournament, which matches the Boston area's four major-college programs -- Boston University, Boston College, Northeastern and Harvard -- began 50 years ago, when coaches and players had names like John (Snooks) Kelley, Ralph (Cooney) Weiland and Tom (Red) Martin. Wayne (Beanpot) Turner earned his nickname for his overtime goal in 1980 that gave Northeastern its first Beanpot title.

title: Out of the Horror, a Tribute on the Street
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEVY, SENATOR NORMAN J.
description: LEVY-Senator Norman J. 2/7/98 Fourth anniversary in Heaven. To my beloved Norman: On the anniversary of your departure, you should know that your name and spirit live on through those who honor you; your legacy is preserved through all who loved and respected you; and above all you remain forever in my heart. Love, Jo

title: Foreign Born in U.S. at Record High
description: The number of foreign-born residents and children of immigrants in the United States has reached the highest level in history, according to a Census Bureau report released yesterday. It found that the number had leapt to 56 million from 34 million in the last three decades.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of yesterday, 3,067 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11, not including 19 hijackers.

title: Russia Praises U.S. Stand on Arms Pact, but Differences Remain
description: Senior Russian officials heaped praise on the Bush administration today for consenting to be legally bound by a future nuclear arms agreement, and one said a pact dictating sweeping cuts in the two nations' nuclear arsenals was now likely within months.

title: Camera Hears 'Cheese' and Later Says It Back
description: Fuji is promoting the relatively small size of its latest digital camera as well as its ability to act as an MP3 music player. But the camera, the FinePix 30i, along with several other cameras from Fuji, might be of greater interest to forgetful photographers.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times on Tuesday about tree diseases from abroad misstated the name of the species blighted by Dutch elm disease. It is the American elm; Dutch elm is the name of the disease, not the tree.

title: Archivists Demand That City Take Back Giuliani's Papers
description: A group of archivists and historians yesterday angrily denounced the transfer of Rudolph W. Giuliani's mayoral papers out of city custody and said that they intended to hold Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg responsible for retrieving the documents, which are being stored at a warehouse in Queens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERTHOLET, MARC B.
description: BERTHOLET-Marc B. February 3, 2002. A memorial service will be held in New York City at a time to be announced. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to the Huntington's Disease Society of America, 158 West 29th Street, 7th Floor, NY, NY 10001.

title: Teenager Who Crashed Plane Praised Terrorists
description: The 15-year-old boy who flew a plane into a downtown high-rise office building in Tampa last month left a note saying he was acting alone but supported the efforts of Al Qaeda, the terrorism network.

title: Tenet Testimony: 'A Nation at War'
description: Following are excerpts from the testimony of George J. Tenet, director of central intelligence, to the Senate Select Intelligence Committee yesterday as transcribed by the Federal News Service Inc. The full text is available at The New York Times on the Web at nytimes.com/world:

title: Postal Service Team Won't Aid Inquiry
description: A French judicial inquiry into possible drug-taking by Lance Armstrong and his teammates is set to collapse after the United States Postal Service team withdrew its cooperation. Armstrong said the probe was unfair and had gone on too long.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Thomas V. Butta was named to the new post of chief marketing officer at PTC, Needham, Mass., a product development company. He had most recently been a consultant. Bigfoot Interactive, New York, hired two employees to new posts. Paul Beck was named vice president for sales and John Mathew was named vice president for operations. Mr. Beck had been vice president for interactive strategic solutions at Dimac Marketing Partners, New York. Mr. Mathew had been vice president for operations at Return Path, New York. Annette Cerbone was named senior vice president and director for national broadcast at Universal McCann, New York, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies. She succeeds Donna Wolfe, executive vice president, who is now director for broadcast for North American operations. Ms. Cerbone had been vice president for business development and national sales at the New York office of Discovery Networks, part of Discovery Communications. Joseph Dondanville was named to the new post of vice president for strategic development at the Chicago office of American Profile magazine. Mr. Dondanville had been president and chief executive at Alertz, which closed. American Profile is published by Publishing Group of America. David Imhoff, executive vice president for worldwide licensing and merchandising at New Line Cinema, New York, was promoted to senior executive vice president. Also, Marianne Dugan, manager for domestic licensing and merchandising, was promoted to director. New Line Cinema is part of AOL Time Warner. Ogilvy Public Relations Worldwide, New York, owned by the WPP Group, agreed to acquire 28.4 percent of PRAP Japan, Tokyo, an international public relations agency with 200 employees and revenue estimated at $18.8 million from clients like British Airways, Mars and Nike. Terms were not disclosed.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Not Gone, Not Forgotten
description: A statue of former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher wearing a long skirt and holding a handbag will be able to take its place in the House of Commons at the end of the year. An outcry has provoked the changing of a rule against displaying a statue of a former prime minister in the building until five years after his or her death. Such statues will now be allowed in provided their subjects have been out of office for at least 12 years. The decision means that the statue will not be temporarily placed in Grantham, Lady Thatcher's hometown, which had offered to take it. Nor will it go to Lake Havasu City, Ariz., a retirement community whose Republican residents had said they would be honored. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: Why Not Pull Up a Vase And Take a Load Off Your Feet?
description: One of Philippe Starck's latest visual wordplays is a vase that is actually a seat. Or is it a table? The transparent plastic urn-shaped stools come in four jewel-like colors -- yellow, red, purple or green -- as well as in clear. They are available in three whimsically classical shapes, one with a wide top, another with a wide base and a third with a long neck. Called Bohem, the stools are 17 inches high with seats 11 inches wide. They can be used indoors or on a terrace or a patio. Manufactured in Italy by Kartell, they are $96 each at the Kartell store at 45 Greene Street (Broome Street). MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about Russia's relations with Iraq referred incorrectly to Shiite Muslims who are being protected from Saddam Hussein's military by American and British air patrols. Shiites in Iraq are a majority, not a minority.

title: U.S. Adds 3 Games To Schedule
description: The United States men's national team will wrap up its most intensive preparations for the World Cup finals with three international matches in May.

title: U.S. Team Picks Flagbearer
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 7  Amy Peterson, a four-time Olympic speed skater, was elected by the American athletes to carry their delegation's flag in the opening ceremonies, despite a months-long campaign to win the honor by the skier Picabo Street.

title: Some Winter Stars Prefer Green to Gold
description: Tara Dakides sat comfortably behind the wheel of her Cadillac Escalade as it gulped down the paper-clip bends in the mountain roads before her earlier this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORGHESE, MARCHELLA, PRINCESS
description: BORGHESE-Marchella, Princess. Dutchess of Bomarzo, creator of a luxury cosmetics line by the same name, died peacefully on January 19, 2002 in Montreux. Switzerland. She was buried after a private funeral in the Borghese family chapel in the Basilica of Santa Maria Maggiore in Rome. Born in Foligno, in Umbria, the daughter of Francesco and Anita Fazi, she married Prince Paolo Borghese in 1937 and later had twin sons Livio and Francesco Borghese. She was introduced to the late Charles Revson with whom she co-founded Princess Marchella Borghese, Inc. in 1958 a wholly owned subsidiary of Revelon, Inc. In addition to her sons and their wives, she is survived by seven grandchildren as well as by a daughter living in Rome, Anita Maurizi. A memorial Mass wil be held at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York on February 19th at 10AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to The Boys Town of Italy, 250 East 63 St, Suite 204, NY, NY 10021 or to the Inner-City Scholarship Fund, Inc., 1011 First Ave, Suite 1400, NY, NY 10022 Attn: St. Athanasius School.

title: Human Rights: The Long View
description: To the Editor:

title: R. Hanbury Brown, 85, Dies; Took Measure of Distant Stars
description: Dr. Robert Hanbury Brown, an engineer who drew on his pioneering work in radar to invent a way of measuring stars in distant galaxies, died Jan. 16 at a hospice in England. He was 85 and lived in Penton Mewsey, a small parish in Hampshire.

title: Lay Off the Sirens, Bloomberg Tells Officials
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg enjoys the perquisites of his mayoralty, but not the flashing lights and sirens in the back of his car. Now, he is warning other city officials to follow his lead.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Haven: New York Fugitive Arrested
description: A Suffolk County fugitive indicted in the 1997 killing of the driver of an armored truck has been arrested in Connecticut after residents recognized him from the television program ''America's Most Wanted,'' the police said. The fugitive, Jamal Starks, 31, fled Suffolk County after the crime and was taken into custody Tuesday in New Haven, Lt. John Gierasch, commander of Suffolk County's homicide detectives, said yesterday. Mr. Starks had apparently been living under an alias with a significantly altered appearance.

title: A Glow in the Night
description: Ithought I was going to have to get up early today and go out in the snow and dark to get one more look at the Olympic torch wending its way through America.

title: Rights Group Condemns Conditions at Australian Refugee Camp
description: An Australian human rights group issued a report today condemning conditions at the country's largest immigration detention center, which for months has been roiled by hunger strikes and other disturbances, and it said the government was violating an international treaty on the rights of children.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Stakes In Retailer Cut
description: Two large shareholders of Marks & Spencer reduced their stakes after a jump in the share price of the company, a leading retailer. Brandes Investment Partners, Marks & Spencer's largest shareholder, slashed its stake by a third, to 6.9 percent as of Jan. 29, down from 10.2 percent in July, British regulatory filings show. Franklin Resources held 2.75 percent as of Jan. 29, down from 4.9 percent in July. Since joining the company as chairman in February 2000, Luc Vandevelde has stemmed declining sales and sold international business to focus on rebuilding the brand at home.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-18

title: Empty Airport Hurts Operators Getting the Rent
description: When the soaring new Terminal 4 opened last spring at Kennedy International Airport, the mantra of its operators was ''passenger service'' -- a nod to the wide array of shops, restaurants and other services that would cater to a growing surge of air travelers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, ARTHUR
description: SHAPIRO-Arthur, 88. On February 5, 2002. Devoted husband of the late Muriel. Loving father of James and Nancy, and Richard; grandfather, ''Pop'' of Jeffrey and Victoria, Bryan, Michael, and Michele; brother of Ascher; and friend and companion of Eliane Bukantz. Service Thursday, 9:45AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Ricoh Raises Forecast
description: The Ricoh Company, Japan's second-largest copier maker, said strong sales in the United States and a weak yen increased profit in the fourth quarter and were enough for the company to raise its full-year forecasts. Ricoh's net profit jumped 19.4 percent in the October-December period compared with the previous year as sales in the United States rose 18.7 percent. Ricoh did not change its sales forecast for the year ending March 31, but it expects a weaker yen to help the company earn 61.5 billion yen ($462 million), 4.2 percent above earlier forecasts. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKLIN, LILLIAN
description: FRANKLIN-Lillian. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Loving mother of Martin & Larry. Loving motherin-law of Isabel and Beverly. Loving grandmother of Teri and Peter, Ticker and John, Ellen and Roy, and Beth and John. Loving great grandmother of Jordan, Michlyn and Josh, Jenny, David, Jonathan, Jill, Ali & Suzie. Services at ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island 9:30 A.M. Friday.

title: To Learn History
description: To the Editor:

title: Rowland, Setting a Tone of Restraint, Proposes a 4 Percent Increase in State Spending
description: In his annual budget address to the Connecticut General Assembly, Gov. John G. Rowland today proposed a $13.49 billion budget for the fiscal year 2003, a 4.1 percent increase over the 2002 spending plan but roughly $200 million less than what lawmakers had previously approved for 2003.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Killer Seeks Parole Transfer
description: Thomas Trantino, the convicted killer of two police officers who is scheduled for release next week, has asked to be transferred from parole supervision in New Jersey to New York State, where he has relatives in Staten Island. Mr. Trantino, 63, is due to be released from a halfway house in Camden on Tuesday. He petitioned the New Jersey Parole Board three weeks ago, said Kenneth Connolly, executive director of the board. Thomas Grant, assistant to the chairman of New York's board, said the request was under review. Mr. Trantino was sentenced to death for the 1963 killings, but his sentence was changed to life imprisonment in 1972 when New Jersey abolished the death penalty. Mr. Trantino's lawyer, Roger A. Lowenstein, was unavailable for comment yesterday. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Memo Says Andersen Sought, But Didn't Get, Crucial Data
description: Arthur Andersen signed off on a crucial Enron transaction in 1998 without seeing critical documents, the auditing firm has told Congressional investigators. Andersen said that it had asked for the documents but accepted Enron's statement that it did not have access to them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEDNER, MAY
description: LEDNER-May. Deceased January 31, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Charles Oppenheim and the late Milton Ledner. Cherished mother of Elaine Mazlish and son-in-law Robert Mazlish. Beloved stepmother of Dr. Robert Ledner and his wife Lucy. Beloved grandmother of Katherine, Liz, and John. Valued wise friend of many, young as well as old. She will indeed be missed. Private memorial service. Any donations in her memory should be made to the charity of your choice.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COCOA RISES. Cocoa rose on concern that supplies would tighten after an early end to harvesting in Ivory Coast, the largest grower. In New York, cocoa for March delivery rose $12, or 0.9 percent, to $1,392 a ton.

title: Officials Agree on Role For Trade Center Flag
description: Softening their stance after negotiations that stretched over two days, international Olympic officials said today that they had reached what they repeatedly called a dignified solution for how best to display a flag that has become a symbol of the victims and heroes of Sept. 11.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the World Business Briefing column yesterday about the quarterly results for Ryanair, the Irish discount airline, misstated the profit in dollars. The company earned 28.8 million euros, or $25 million, not $32.5 million.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Airplane Deal
description: Japan's largest machinery maker, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, will jointly develop a new business jet with Bombardier Inc. of Canada. Mitsubishi Heavy plans to build the wing and fuselage for the Global 5000, a plane capable of flying nonstop between Europe and North America with eight passengers and three crew members. The company plans to start deliveries by the end of 2004. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GMAC COMMERCIAL MORTGAGE CORP., a subsidiary of GMAC Commercial Holding Corp., Horsham, Pa., acquired the operating assets of Proctor Mortgage Services, Bloomfield Hills, Mich. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Where PowerPoint Meets 'Buffy the Vampire Slayer'
description: Sometimes it seems like a dilemma as old as time itself: what rectangle should you devotedly stare at all day, the computer or the television? A recent spate of dual-purpose flat-panel monitors means that you'll never again have to turn your head when Michael Jordan hits a three-pointer.

title: Gliding Above Chimneys To Revisit Neverland
description: Mother love and loss -- of that very love, as well as the loss of innocence, youth and life itself -- color the remarkable and poignant revival of the prize-winning Mabou Mines production of ''Peter and Wendy'' that is the latest lustrous attraction at the New Victory Theater.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JANIS, EDWARD
description: JANIS-Edward. Beloved husband of Hilda. Father of Phyllis and Kenneth Finkel. Adored grandfather of Marc and Ariane. Services at ''Riverside Chapel'', 76th St and Amsterdam Avenue on Thursday, February 7 at 11:30AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, AURORA B.
description: STONE-Aurora B. Who lived with spunk, determination and decency, died peacefully, at 85, at her home in Brooklyn on Feb. 5. She is remembered lovingly by her daughters, Elizabeth Stone and Virginia Jerome; her grandchildren, Paul and Gabe Stone-Jansen and Erin and Kira Jerome; and her sons-in-law, Reamy Jansen and Joel Jerome. She is survived by her sister, Ellen Marchese, and preceded in death by her husband, William, and her much-loved siblings, Jean Chaves, Joe Bonney, Nancy Olivo and Bart Bonney. Aurora Stone's family thank those who added great comfort to her final years-Joan Morris, Mary Radigan & the staff of the Jacob Perlow Hospice (Beth Israel Medical Center, 1st Ave. at 16th Street, NYC 10003) to whom donations in Aurora's memory may be made. Services private.

title: Brazil Forum More Local Than Worldly
description: The 40,000 people who gathered here for the World Social Forum, the antiglobalization alternative to the World Economic Forum in New York, had adopted the motto, ''Another world is possible.''

title: New Hand-Helds With Color To Make a Peacock Blush
description: The Palm and Pocket PC operating systems are the Hatfields and McCoys of the hand-held-computer world. Recently, two new hand-helds emerged, one from each side of the valley. At half an inch thick, Sony's Cli PEG-T615C ($399) combines the slim T-series shape with a sharp color screen that Sony says is more vivid, especially in harsh light. The new Cli comes with 16 megabytes of memory, most of the usual features of a Palm hand-held and a few extras, like Cli Paint, which allows you to save whatever you draw freehand on the screen. By contrast, Casio's new Cassiopeia E-200 is bigger (0.68 inches wide compared with the Cli's 0.5 inches) and more expensive ($599) and has more memory (64 megabytes). It also has a vivid, reflective color screen and two slots for additional memory. The biggest difference, of course, is that the Cassiopeia runs on Microsoft's Pocket PC operating system. So choose: your pocket's not big enough for both of them. Bruce Headlam

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: Olympic Bus Fares Drop
description: The Salt Lake Organizing Committee set up the Mountain Venue Express, a network of bus routes throughout the Olympic region, to reduce traffic during the Games. But at $20 round trip, the original ticket price didn't have enough takers. So, because of concern over gridlock on certain peak competition days, the committee cut the price to $5, for those who make reservations at (866) 566-4428, and some dates are sold out. Anyone who bought $20 tickets will be refunded the difference. Besides reducing traffic hassles, the bus system mad render a rental car unnecessary, a saving in itself.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: The Aegis Group, London, acquired Market and More, a European market research company with operations in Belgium, France, Germany and the Netherlands that works for clients like the Danone Group and Procter & Gamble. The deal involves an initial cash payment of $5.2 million plus possible additional payments over three years based on performance.

title: Austrian Rightist Is Working on His Comeback
description: ''The biggest problem with Jrg Haider,'' the populist right-winger whose party shares power in Austria, ''is that he has two words -- 'Auslnder raus!' ('Foreigners Out!'), but we need two hours to answer it,'' said Dieter Bogner, a museum designer and one of Vienna's great and good.

title: Lessons for Nation-Builders
description: Nation-building aided by outsiders is a project many believe is doomed to fail. Yet international attempts to create a society from the ground up have sometimes succeeded. A recent example is East Timor, which offers a few lessons for future efforts in places like Afghanistan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLAGHER, JOHN J.
description: GALLAGHER-John J. On February 4. Trustees of First Battle Revival Alliance/Old Stone House mourn our co-founder and friend: artist-writer-scholar-soldier-guide.

description: SEE NO EVIL

title: TBWA/Chiat/Day Undergoing Changes
description: Three offices of TBWA/Chiat/ Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide division of the Omnicom Group, are undergoing changes.

description: Sense of Dj Vu

title: Fleury Has Some Words For Chelios
description: Rangers right wing Theo Fleury and Detroit defenseman Chris Chelios engaged in a shouting and shoving match on the ice during the third period of tonight's game, a 3-1 Red Wings victory.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: Knick Stars In Reversal Of Roles
description: It seems that the Knicks' two best players have switched roles, at least for the time being.

title: Key European Banker to Retire, Raising Questions on Successor
description: FRANKFURT, Feb. 7  Wim Duisenberg, president of the European Central Bank, announced today that he would retire in July 2003, opening a new phase in what has already become a tangled succession struggle.

title: To Cut Deficit, McGreevey Suggests Furloughs
description: Seeking to close New Jersey's budget deficit without resorting to additional layoffs, Gov. James E. McGreevey said today that he had instructed members of his cabinet to urge state employees to consider taking unpaid furloughs of up to 90 days.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Sheep And Goat Exports To Resume
description: European Union veterinarians approved resumption of British exports of live sheep and goats, banned since last year's epidemic of foot-and-mouth disease. Animals will have to be quarantined for 30 days before export. The end of the ban still needs approval by the European Union's commission. Britain was declared free of the disease on Jan. 23. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Playboy's Patron
description: Hugh Hefner's mother lent him $1,000 to help put out the first issue of Playboy magazine. Though the magazine made her a millionaire, Mrs. Hefner never read it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLOTKIN, HELEN
description: PLOTKIN-Helen. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family acknowledges with sadness the passing of Helen Plotkin, beloved mother of our dear friend and benefactor, Fred Plotkin, who has provided generous support to many programs and services of the Medical Center. To Fred, his family and all his mother's loved ones, we extend heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman, Board of Trustees Matthew E. Fink, M.D., President and CEO Robert G. Newman, M.D. President Emeritus

title: Closings Set for the Museum Company
description: Plagued by one of the worst retailing seasons in more than a decade, the Museum Company -- a chain of 99 shops and an Internet site that sell museum-related products -- is closing eight of its stores by the end of the month, including its two flagship stores in Manhattan: one on Fifth Avenue and 53rd Street and the other on 42nd Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues. It has also filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.

title: 2 Harvard Students Accused of Embezzling From Theater Club
description: Two Harvard seniors embezzled about $100,000 from the Hasty Pudding Theatricals club, the oldest undergraduate theater organization in the country, to finance ''lavish lifestyles,'' prosecutors here say.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Lawyer's Warnings to Enron On Deals Went Unheeded

title: Conjuring A Shadow On Drums
description: Jazz is strewn with undiscovered talent. But there's a special class of true could-have-beens: those who were recognized by their peers and singled out as geniuses, yet stayed put in their own locales and recorded little, possibly because they made life difficult for people around them.

title: Muir, Offensive Line Coach, Leaves Jets to Join the Bucs
description: Bill Muir started coaching the Jets' offensive line when Rich Kotite was the head coach and served in that role under three other head coaches. But yesterday he left the Jets to join Tampa Bay even though the Buccaneers still do not have a coach after having fired Tony Dungy and having been turned down by Bill Parcells.

title: Panel Says Amtrak Should Be Broken Up
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 — A panel appointed by Congress two years ago to decide what to do about Amtrak said today that the railroad should be broken up and that the job of running trains should be opened to competition. But most of its members quickly added that their report was unlikely to be more than a starting point for a major national debate on the future of passenger rail.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Currency Move Delayed
description: The Argentine government postponed the reopening of the foreign exchange market until Monday to complete details of the transition to a fully floating peso. The government also said that a freeze on bank withdrawals, which was expected to be lifted yesterday, would continue until Monday. The government declared a bank and foreign- exchange holiday early this week to avoid a run on the banks after the Supreme Court ruled that bank withdrawal restrictions were unconstitutional.

title: 2 Candidates For Senate Rely on Clout Of Party Stars
description: In less than a month, it has become an intensely hectic campaign, with incessant advertising on television and radio. The candidates are fixtures at subway stations and at civic meetings. They spend hours on the telephone, soliciting campaign contributions.

title: Ex-Chief Says He Didn't Know About Enron's Accounting Woes
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 - The former chief executive of the Enron Corporation insisted today, in the face of skeptical questioning by lawmakers, that he thought right up to the moment he left the company that it was healthy and that he knew nothing of accounting tricks meant to conceal losses.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Phone Concern Considers Bids
description: The board of Blu, an Italian mobile phone operator, will meet today to consider bids received for all or part of the company. Blu, a consortium of five wireless operators, failed to win a license for the next wave of radio spectrum, and has said it will either be sold or liquidated. Roger Westbury, a spokesman for British Telecommunications, which owns 29 percent of Blu, said ''a liquidation is an extreme option and not in the cards at the moment.'' Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Imperiling Playoff Spot, Rangers Continue Slide
description: The time for moral victories has passed. The Rangers were quick to point out that they had battled the Detroit Red Wings evenly for most of tonight's match, but it was not enough. They dropped their third straight game, 3-1, and what had almost been a certain playoff berth is slipping away with each game.

title: Bristol-Myers Is Backtracking On ImClone Deal
description: In the summer of 2000, Bristol-Myers Squibb, the nation's leading seller of cancer drugs, considered a deal with ImClone Systems Inc., a biotechnology company developing a new type of cancer drug with the potential to save thousands of lives.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Interior Dept. Says Online Woes Continue
description: Interior Secretary Gale A. Norton told a Congressional panel that department officials were working to improve its computer systems but were not certain when some computers would be permitted access to the Internet. In December, a federal court ordered the department to shut down its Internet access and some computer connections after American Indian tribes filed a class-action lawsuit seeking to block the department computer sites on grounds that they were dangerously insecure. Judge Royce C. Lamberth ruled that hundreds of millions of dollars in a trust fund for Indians administered by the department were vulnerable to security breaches via the Internet. About 90 percent of the department is still cut off from the Internet, Ms. Norton said.

title: LAWYER AT ENRON WARNED OFFICIALS OF DUBIOUS DEALS
description: In a series of memorandums to high-ranking Enron executives that began nearly a year before the company's collapse, a senior lawyer warned about the appearance of sweetheart deals and dubious transactions.

title: National Briefing | New England: New Hampshire: Senate Race
description: Gov. Jeanne Shaheen, a Democrat, confirmed that she would seek the Senate seat held by Robert C. Smith, a conservative Republican. Should Ms. Shaheen become the state's first Democratic senator since 1980, she could affect which party controls the Senate. Democrats now hold the majority by a single seat. Recent polls indicate that Ms. Shaheen would do well against Mr. Smith but would fall short in a race against another Republican, Representative John E. Sununu. Ms. Shaheen, who has already raised $1.1 million, said she was not adhering to voluntary campaign spending limit because she expected her competitors to exceed it. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: Making a Killing in Real Estate Is One Thing, Murder Is Another
description: It would not be a good idea to arrive late to ''Finder's Fee,'' a new play at the Rattlestick Theater, given what happens in the first 60 seconds. Which is odd, because the play itself feels as if it has arrived a bit late.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Tyco says its earnings will fall short, and the company backs away from a planned deal.
description: TYCO INTERNATIONAL LTD., whose shares have plunged this year on investor concerns about its accounting practices and cash position, said yesterday that its earnings would fall short of its previous forecasts and that it would not complete a takeover previously announced.

title: Excerpts From Government's Response to the Petition by Lindh's Lawyers
description: Following are excerpts from the government's response to a petition by lawyers for John Walker Lindh that he be released on bail pending his trial on charges of conspiring to kill Americans:

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR SLIPS. The dollar was little changed against the euro and the yen. In New York, the euro settled at 86.85 cents, up from 86.85 cents on Tuesday. The dollar traded at 133.56 yen, down from 133.86 yen.

title: Prominent Muslim Militant Is Named a Suspect in Pearl Case
description: Pakistani and American officials identified a leader of a Pakistani militant Muslim group today as the chief suspect in the disappearance of the American journalist Daniel Pearl, saying that he came to their attention because of his role in the kidnapping of four Western tourists in India in 1994.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Liechtenstein: Money Laundering Cases Increase
description: Tougher enforcement in the tiny principality of Liechtenstein resulted in a doubling of reports of suspected money laundering by banks last year, authorities said. A new watchdog agency was set up after Liechtenstein was listed on an international roll of countries that failed to adequately fight corrupt money flows; it has since been dropped from the list. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERLA, JOYCE LENORE FEIMAN
description: GERLA-Joyce Lenore Feiman. On February 5, 2002. Beloved wife of Stanley. Devoted mother of Steven and Juliet, Bonnie and Bernard and Pamela. Cherished grandmother of Gabrielle, Gregory and Michelle. Loving sister of Richard and Pat Feiman and Donald and Len Feiman. Services Friday 11am at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza, (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, New York. Donations in her memory may be made to Lymphoma Research Foundation of America, 8800 Venice Blvd., Suite 207, Los Angeles, CA. 90034.

title: Text of Morning Session of Hearing on Enron
description: The following is the text of the morning session of a hearing of the oversight and investigations subcommittee of the House Energy and Commerce Committee on the findings of Enrons special investigative committee as recorded by the Federal News Service.

title: Cendant Posts Loss as Travel Business Falls
description: The Cendant Corporation, the owner of the Avis car rental business and the franchiser of Ramada Inn hotels, had a fourth-quarter loss as it took charges of $520 million mainly to cut jobs and write down the value of assets.

title: A Heartstrings Tug of War: Husband vs. Homeland
description: It's the story of a woman, abducted from her native land, who's forced to choose between love and country: the stuff of which operas are made. It's based on a historical figure, Cai Wenji, whose life has inspired many stage works. And since ''Wenji: Eighteen Songs of a Nomad Flute'' by Bun-Ching Lam portrays a heroine caught between two linguistic and artistic idioms, unsure which represents her true home, it has contemporary autobiographical overtones as well.

title: Wear Me, Use Me, Flaunt Me: Hitching a Product to the Stars
description: THE advantages of being rich and famous have long included certain, um, courtesies: the best tables at choice restaurants, donations of designer clothing, box tickets to concerts and sporting events.

title: New Sources Of Offense At St. John's
description: Donald Emanuel popped 3-pointers last night as if he had been an offensive star his entire career. Sharif Fordham ran the court as if he had never spent huge chunks of time on the bench.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the arts pages on Tuesday about the possibility of programming changes at WNYC-FM misstated the position of John Schaefer, who commented about listeners' desire for more news. He is a senior producer and the host of ''New Sounds''; the music director is Hester Furman.

title: Campaign aims to demystify and popularize high-definition television.
description: IT has been called the greatest innovation in television technology since the arrival of color back in the 1950's. But digital television has gotten off to something of a rocky start in the United States. Today, most Americans know very little about it. And only a relative few are buying the new, still costly digital television sets and electronic decoder boxes that are capable of receiving it.

title: How 2 Filmmakers Got a Glow From Their Bath
description: Loch Phillipps, 41, and his wife, Lee Skaife, 40, are independent filmmakers who make offbeat works like ''The Voyagers,'' a documentary about an artist who lived in his own hot-pink and green installation in Queens for a week. When it came time to renovate the top half of their four-story Brooklyn brownstone, above left, they wanted to create a similarly lively backdrop for themselves. Their architect, Alden Maddry (Mr. Phillipps's cousin), created a colored light box on the top floor, above center and right. The walls, which enclose a bathroom, are made of two layers of acrylic panels, clear or amber inside and frosted outside. They are broken up by thinner panels of clear acrylic that hold images by John Rae, a New York photographer. The panels are removable, which means the couple, who have a daughter, Circe, 3, can change color, composition and artwork whenever they want. ''Just unscrew the panels, take them out and replace them,'' Mr. Maddry said. Most of the light box panels are 18 by 52 inches and cost $26 each at E & T Plastics in Long Island City, Queens. (Some Canal Street plastics shops also stock them.) They were relatively easy to install in the brownstone because they required no wiring: the light they diffuse comes from either the bathroom or a skylight in the new roof.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Fiat's Shares Fall

Investors are concerned that Fiat is accumulating debt without turning around its car business.
