title: The East Way and the West Way Of Academic Succession
description: The Southern California Institute of Architecture in Los Angeles, better known as SCI-Arc, has moved swiftly to name a new director, Eric Owen Moss, 58, after the resignation of Neil Denari in late December following a faculty vote of no confidence. Mr. Denari presided over the school's difficult move last year from Marina del Rey to a former freight depot downtown. Mr. Moss, above right, a longtime professor at the school and a key player in the city's design renaissance (his office renovation in Culver City, is at above left), took over on Friday. He promises to reinstate SCI-Arc's ''tradition of nontradition'' and to move away from design driven by intellectual theory, which is perceived as an East Coast obsession. Indeed, deciding which coast has the hottest talent is the architecture world's favorite parlor game. On the East Coast, the focus is on the Princeton University School of Architecture, which has been searching since July for a new dean. The contenders are rumored to include the architect Charles Gwathmey; Sylvia Lavin, an architectural historian at U.C.L.A.; and Mario Gandelsonas, the acting dean. A decision is expected this summer. JULIE V. IOVINE

title: Messages for the Ages, Using a Chisel, Not the 'Send' Key
description: In a time of sandblasted lettering and laser carving, Karin Sprague, 37, of North Scituate, R.I., is one of the very few artisans who still carve gravestones the old-fashioned way: by hand, with mallet and chisel. Her clients share her appreciation of the 17th- and 18th-century markers that now list in many a New England cemetery -- stones with flowing italic or beautifully spaced block lettering, sentimental verses, skulls, cherubs, weeping willows and stray chisel marks. ''None of the letters match, and if you look closely, you can see the hand of the carver,'' Ms. Sprague said. ''Some of them really poured their souls into it.'' One woman in northwest Connecticut commissioned her to redo all the stones in the family plot. Ms. Sprague also carves more contemporary-looking stones, including one for an artist who wanted to see hers while she was still alive. The cost is $3,000 to $12,000, and the wait is about a year; (401) 934-3105 or www.karinsprague.com. SUSAN GUERRERO

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Mashantucket: Indian Map Is Missing
description: The original map outlining the Indian reservation where the Foxwoods Resort Casino is situated is missing. Legislators from Connecticut towns critical of Indian casinos say the map's absence calls into question the legality of the Mashantucket Pequot reservation and its casino. The 1983 Settlement Act, which gave the outlined land back to the tribe, states that the original map must be filed with the secretary of state, and it is not, the lawmakers said in a letter dated Jan. 29 to Connecticut's House and Senate. They requested federal help to find the map and confirm that the casino is on lawfully ceded land. Hope Reeves (NYT)

description: The 45-page account, written out in small, tight longhand seven years ago, could be called the confessions of a 20-year-old kidnapper. In it, a gregarious protagonist lays out a plan that bears striking resemblances to the kidnapping of Daniel Pearl, a Wall Street Journal reporter, 15 days ago in Karachi, Pakistan.

title: Brand Consultants Expand Company
description: FutureBrand, a brand and corporate identity consulting company, is reorganizing a division, the Marketing Corporation of America in Westport, Conn.

title: From the Smithsonian, A Modern Tasting Menu
description: It doesn't yet top a must-see list of 20th-century art in Washington. But thanks to some generous donors in recent years, the Smithsonian American Art Museum turns out to have accumulated an impressive if small collection of 20th-century American works. It is strongest in Modernism and Abstract Expressionism, but also has a few choice examples from earlier and later periods.

title: Excerpts From House Subcommittee Hearings on the Enron Collapse
description: Following are excerpts from a House Energy and Commerce subcommittee hearing yesterday on the Enron collapse, as recorded by Federal News Service Inc. The witnesses -- Jordan Mintz, Jeffrey McMahon, Robert K. Jaedicke, Herbert S. Winokur Jr. and Jeffrey K. Skilling -- were questioned by Representatives Bart Stupak, James C. Greenwood, Cliff Stearns, Diana DeGette, Richard M. Burr, Chris John and Billy Tauzin. A full transcript is available online: nytimes.com/business

title: Fair Is Fowl and Fowl Is Fair In Rural Pennsylvania
description: ''Scotland, Pa.,'' a clever comic riff on ''Macbeth,'' is so infatuated with its own whimsy that most of the drama in Shakespeare's tragedy is diluted by the movie's joking condescension toward its characters. As great a storyteller as Shakespeare was, his language was ultimately more important than any plot. But ''Scotland, Pa.,'' which is set in a fast-food outlet in rural Pennsylvania during the 1970's, doesn't have a language other than the desultory slang of 70's Middle America. The dialogue is witty in the manner of vintage ''Saturday Night Live'' skits in which the hip cast members sneakily parody the poor, clueless schlubs out in the sticks.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about an Iraqi offer to open a dialogue with the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, gave an outdated title for Hans Blix, who attended a meeting on the offer. He is executive chairman of the United Nations Monitoring, Verification and Inspection Commission, no longer director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency.

title: Bush in Political Hot Spot In Picking an F.D.A. Chief
description: As President Bush tries to fill the long-vacant job of commissioner of food and drugs, he is caught in a political quandary. If he names someone from the drug industry, he risks the wrath of Senate Democrats, and if he names someone outside the industry, he risks the wrath of pharmaceutical manufacturers, who contributed heavily to his presidential campaign.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MILANA, MARY C.
description: MILANA-Mary C. 7/13/1900-2/ 8/1997. Dear Mom it has been 5 years since you left us. We pray for you and miss you so much. In loving memory, your daughters Marie, Catherine, and Norma.

title: City Reconsidering Moving Museum Into Tweed Courthouse
description: Backing away from another major initiative of his predecessor, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg acknowledged yesterday that he was reconsidering a controversial plan to move the Museum of the City of New York from East Harlem to the lavishly renovated Tweed Courthouse in Lower Manhattan.

title: Devils Squander Lead, Then Hold On for Tie
description: It is never too early to start watching the out-of-town scoreboard.

title: Olympic Air Fare
description: Getting from your hotel to the competition sites is one thing. Getting from your home to Salt Lake City is quite another challenge. To help, the Web site Orbitz.com , set up by the major United States airlines, says it has round-trip fares to the city during the Olympic period starting at $251 from New York, $159 from Los Angeles, $211 from Washington and $316 from Chicago. These are for the period Feb. 9 to 13. Sample fares from Feb. 21 to 25 start at $249 from New York and $349 from Washington. These fares, available as of Jan. 28, are limited; some conditions apply.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Deficit Shortfall Grows
description: Gov. John Kitzhaber projected an additional $100 million shortfall in state revenues. Legislators are to meet on Friday to tackle a deficit that now totals more than $900 million. The governor, in his last term, asked for additional cuts of $10 million to education and $20 million for health services and public safety, along with a 50-cent cigarette tax. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELDON, CAROL P.
description: WELDON-Carol P. Of Port Washington, L.I. on February 6, 2002. Beloved wife of Gerard J. Weldon. Beloved mother of Cathleen E. Weldon. Cherished daughter of Ralph and the late Eileen Tramposch. Fond step daughter of Heika. Dear sister of Kenneth and Annette, Ronald and Theresa and Brett. Barrell School, 11 Laurel Lane, Levittown, New York 11756.

title: Cozier and More Costly, Olympics Open Tonight

description: Wim Duisenberg, president of the European Central Bank, said today that he would retire in July 2003, opening a new phase in what was already a tangled succession struggle.

title: Sports of The Times; One Man's Lifeblood of the Games
description: EVERYONE at the Olympics has a drug story to tell. The biggest and bloodiest comes from Doug Rollins, who is working his way toward the first record-shattering performance of the Salt Lake Games: most vials filled by an attendant medical director of doping control.

title: Corrections

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LIBERTY INTERNATIONAL, London, Britain's fifth-largest real estate company, said it had bought the 850,000-square-foot Serramonte Shopping Center in Daly City, Calif., for $119 million.

title: U.S. Supports Bid to Uphold Ohio Limits On Abortions
description: Staking out its legal position in an abortion case for the first time, the Bush administration asked the federal appeals court in Cincinnati this week to uphold Ohio's latest version of a ban on a medical procedure that opponents call partial-birth abortion.

title: In the Shadow Of Extinction
description: I can't vouch for the old chestnut about atheists in foxholes. But I do know that there are no pessimists in the search for the ivory-billed woodpecker. When your feet are always wet, optimism is a necessary alternative to dry socks.

title: Racism in a 1940's Riot Over Outlandish Suits
description: In ''City of Nets,'' his insightful 1986 book about Hollywood in the 1940's, Otto Friedrich describes how Rita Hayworth became a movie star after she changed her name from Margarita Carmen Dolores Cansino and took care of her ''hair problems.'' Her thick dark hair and low hairline were deemed too Hispanic, but nothing that couldn't be fixed with red dye and electrolysis.

title: St. Merryn Journal; Europe Decrees. British Bristle. Iceboxes Heaved.
description: The used refrigerators began appearing, as if from thin air, on the edges of Bob Partridge's farm late last fall. By Christmas, he had discovered more than 50 dumped there, cleverly secreted in deserted buildings, behind trees and under bracken across his property in this windswept corner of Cornwall.

title: Testimony From Enron Executives Is Contradictory
description: Lawmakers heard sharply conflicting testimony today from Enron's former chief executive, Jeffrey K. Skilling, who portrayed himself as ignorant of the company's questionable practices, and other executives who said Mr. Skilling received numerous and specific warnings that Enron's off-the-books partnerships were improper.

title: A.H. Weiler, 93, Editor and Critic
description: A. H. Weiler, a writer, editor and critic whose career at The New York Times spanned more than 50 years, died on July 22 at his home in Astoria, Queens. He was 93.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Rise In Unwed Parents
description: Nearly one in three Irish children born in 2000 was born to unmarried parents, up from one in 20 in 1980, according to the Economic and Social Research Institute. Single-parent families are raising 12 percent of all children under 15, nearly double the rate 20 years ago. Ireland has the highest fertility rate in Europe, and marriage rates are rising after a 20-year decline. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Rangers Confront A Familiar Scenario
description: Mark Messi er, Brian Leetch and Mike Richter the three most recognizable Rangers of the last decade -- could be excused for feeling as if they have been through this before.

title: Will S.E.C.'s Needs Be Met? Not by Bush
description: 'Tis a gift to be simple, 'Tis a gift to be free.

title: Top Defense Lawyer With Low Profile Represents Enron's Former Chief
description: Earl J. Silbert, the former Watergate prosecutor hired to defend Kenneth L. Lay, has already passed the first hurdle in his case: making sure Mr. Lay did not testify before Congress. From now on, Mr. Silbert can focus on what he does best, getting a white-collar client out of a jam.

title: Dots, Dashes and Doodles In a Multi-Media Ferment
description: From the looks of the compressed drawing retrospective at the Drawing Center, the Italian-born Brazilian artist Anna Maria Miaolino took almost two decades to find herself as an artist, and has since then been exploring ideas that have been around since the early 1970's. You could say the show is, at heart, about the triumph of authenticity over the urge toward originality, or perhaps the impossibility of originality without authenticity.

title: Jeep to Hummer: Wipe That Grin Off Your Face
description: Tt is not Tyson vs. Lewis, but Jeep and Hummer bared their teeth this week in United States District Court in South Bend, Ind.

title: Accord Reached on Charity Aid Bill After Bush Gives In on Hiring
description: President Bush and Senate negotiators announced an agreement today on a bill to give federal money to religious charities, but only after Mr. Bush made major concessions to Democrats on what had been a central proposal of his ''compassionate conservative'' presidential campaign.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a tentative labor agreement that would raise wages at 28 nursing homes misstated the given name of the president of the Greater New York Health Care Facilities Association, which negotiated for the employers. He is Bartholomew Lawson, not Bernard.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Camden: Journalist Is Fined
description: A journalist found in contempt of court for speaking to a juror during the deliberations of a murder trial avoided a jail sentence yesterday. The journalist, Carol Saline, a reporter for Philadelphia magazine, was fined $1,000 and given a 30-day suspended sentence. Judge Theodore Z. Davis of Superior Court, who issued the sentence, heard from 15 character witnesses, including a United States representative and several prominent lawyers. Ms. Saline covered the trial of Rabbi Fred J. Neulander, who is accused of arranging his wife's murder. The jury later deadlocked and Rabbi Neulander faces a new trial.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDER, ARTHUR
description: LINDER-Arthur. Educator Arthur Linder, 81, died February 6, 2002. A lifetime resident of New York City, he was the Chairman of Biology at Stuyvesant High School for thirtyfive years. He loved his students and continued a tutoring practice up to the time of his death. A Renaissance man with a passion for life, he will be sorely missed. He is survived by his wife, Barbara, and his son, Donald. Services are at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, today, 12 Noon.

title: His Mission, Accepted: Defending Art From Danger
description: FORMALDEHYDE fumes from the biology lab down the hall tease the office door of James Beck, a Columbia art history professor, but this is happenstance, not a desire to render the inhabitant mute as a pickled pig, which one might expect.

title: Suzanne Bloch, Performer of Early Music, Dies at 94
description: Suzanne Bloch, a musician and teacher who spurred interest in early music through her performances on the lute and other instruments, and who promoted the music of her father, Ernest Bloch, died on Jan. 29 in Manhattan, where she lived. She was 94.

title: Advisory Panel Tells Congress That Amtrak Should Be Split
description: A panel created by Congress in 1997 to advise on the future of Amtrak said today that the railroad should be broken up and that the job of running trains should be opened to competition.

title: Sharon Tells Bush He Expects Creation of Palestinian State
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel said today that he expected to see a Palestinian state at the end of the Middle East peace process -- though that process is now moribund -- even as President Bush said the United States would keep up pressure on Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, to crack down on violence.

title: VISTEON TO CUT 1,600 JOBS AND TAKE $95 MILLION CHARGE
description: The Visteon Corporation is eliminating 1,600 jobs, or 2 percent of its work force, and will have $95 million in first-quarter costs as it reorganizes engineering operations and sells a unit. Visteon, a maker of auto parts, plans to eliminate about 400 engineering jobs to cut research and development expenses, and 825 jobs as part of a plan to sell its air bag sensor business to Autoliv Inc., a spokesman said; 350 other employees will transfer to Autoliv. The 400 engineering jobs include 150 cut last week. The remainder will be eliminated by the end of the second quarter. The company has about 80,000 employees.

title: As You Live and Breathe, With, Um, a Couple of Adjustments
description: Bodily functions. You have to love them, because without them you're dead. Two of the most basic, which figure prominently in separate exhibitions downtown, are the extremely complex taken-for-granted processes of breathing and eating. Breathing involves taking oxygen into the lungs and exhaling carbon monoxide. Eating requires consuming food, getting nourishment from it and expelling what cannot be digested. Both proceed almost unthinkingly, if we are lucky, day in and day out.

title: Terminal Evacuated In a False Alarm
description: A false alarm attributed to a malfunction by a luggage-screening device led today to the evacuation of 1,500 people from a concourse at Baltimore-Washington International Airport and from five Southwest Airlines jets waiting at the gates.

title: Suitors Try Carrots and Sticks In P&O Princess Cruises Battle
description: Rival suitors for P&O Princess Cruises raised the stakes today, one by sweetening its offer, the other by suggesting that it might walk away from a proposed merger if shareholders do not vote to approve it next week.

title: Senate Votes to Cap Farm Subsidies at $275,000, Citing Need to Save Program's Credibility
description: Saying large payments to rich farmers jeopardized the credibility of farm subsidies, the Senate voted today to cut in half the amount of money the biggest farmers could receive.

title: Nigeria's President Fears for His Fledgling Democracy
description: President Olusegun Obasanjo told an anxious nation today that rising violence and lawlessness were dangerously undermining its three-year-old democracy. The warning was his direst since Nigeria, Africa's most populous nation, emerged from nearly 16 years of military dictatorship in 1999.

title: Spinning Off Rodeo Drive
description: Last year Paramount released the three ''Godfather'' films on DVD, and now the studio has discs of the three ''Beverly Hills Cop'' movies. If they represent a plunge in venerability, the three Eddie Murphy vehicles nicely exemplify the degenerative consequences that usually overtake spinoffs of hit movies.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Daewoo Bid Is Revised
description: The General Motors Corporation has submitted a revised bid for Daewoo Motor, Jung Keun Yong, governor of the Bank of Korea, told members of the National Assembly in Seoul. The proposal, in negotiation with Daewoo's lead creditor, the government-owned Korea Development Bank, reportedly asks for guarantees in case of discovery of hidden debts accumulated by the bankrupt manufacturer overseas. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Six Priests Suspended After Claims Of Sex Abuse
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston said today that it had suspended six more priests from all assignments because of accusations that they had sexually molested children in the past.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Interest Rates Are Unchanged
description: The Bank of England and the European Central Bank left their benchmark interest rates unchanged, signaling that both institutions are expecting inflationary pressures. The Bank of England, which cut rates seven times last year, left its main rate at 4 percent. The more cautious European Central Bank, which cut rates four times last year and sets interest rates for the 12-nation euro zone, maintained the benchmark rate at 3.25 percent. Alan Cowell (NYT)

description: As early as Saturday, the White House is expected to announce the choice of Yucca Mountain, 100 miles northwest of Las Vegas, as the place to bury decades of accumulated nuclear waste safely. Some years later, if all goes well, the government will figure out just how to do it.

description: Consumer debt unexpectedly dropped at a 3.7 percent annual rate in December, a month after borrowing increased more than at any time in almost six decades, Federal Reserve figures showed today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COGAN, DAVID J.
description: COGAN-David J. Died Thursday, February 7 at his home in Bedford, New York. Beloved husband of Arline, loving father of Sharon and Carol whose mother is Ferne, father-in-law of Joel Cogan-Beck and Burt Savitsky, devoted grandfather of Jessica, Nicole, Samuel, and Katrina, caring brother of Esther and family. title: Betraying the Unemployed
description: President Bush and members of Congress all said they wanted a bill this winter to revive the economy. Yet the chances of passing such a bill died in the Senate on Wednesday, despite bipartisan support. Instead the Senate passed a narrower measure to extend jobless benefits for 13 weeks beyond the 26-week limit. Congress has approved these extensions almost reflexively in recent recessions, but incredibly, House Republicans now threaten to block the bill unless it includes tax cuts for corporations and wealthy individuals. Their obstructionism must not be allowed to defeat a measure needed by those hit hardest by the recession.

title: IN SHIFT, BUSH SAYS GENEVA RULES FIT TALIBAN CAPTIVES
description: President Bush decided today that the Geneva Convention would be applied to the Taliban captives being held in Cuba but not to Al Qaeda detainees, a decision that will make little difference in the day-to-day treatment of either but may help protect American soldiers captured in foreign conflicts.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Hackensack: Whistleblower Suit Settled
description: Bergen County has agreed to pay $1.43 million to settle a lawsuit with a former assistant county prosecutor who said he was dismissed for criticizing a supervisor in 1994. The assistant prosecutor, Robert Hennessey, charged that he was dismissed by Charles R. Schuber, said the county would seek reimbursement from the state, because prosecutors are supervised by the state attorney general.

title: In Mahler, Relishing the Ambiguities
description: When Mahler wasn't obsessing about death in his symphonies, he was trying to translate the beauty and power of nature into sound. That was his principal agenda in the Symphony No. 3, although were it not for Mahler's various attempts to ascribe titles to the work and its movements (``The Happy Life'' was one idea), a listener could easily take the Third for an essay on mortality. After all, Mahler being Mahler, there are ruminations about the afterlife in the two vocal movements and a finale that has a weighty, soul- searching quality that prefigures the finale of the Ninth. Even the work's opening bars - a stately theme for eight horns, sharply punctuated by strings, winds and percussion - can be heard as an ominous rumbling of dark things to come.

description: In his five decades of building up one of Germany's biggest media empires, Leo Kirch acquired more than a few enemies.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Heroin Named After Bin Laden
description: First, the police in Brooklyn discovered that drug dealers were peddling a brand of heroin called Twin Towers, which officials said appeared soon after Sept. 11. Now authorities in Queens say they have found a brand of the drug called bin Laden, as in Osama. Yesterday, four women were arrested and charged with drug possession after police in Hollis discovered they were carrying cocaine, marijuana and the bin Laden heroin. It was in glassine envelopes with bin Laden in red letters on the front and the image of an airplane heading toward the World Trade Center on the back. Sarah Kershaw (NYT)

title: Ad sales for the home-court Olympic Games happily surprise NBC.
description: REMEMBER the millionaire who surprised Auntie Mame by leaving a cab with the meter running in the middle of the Depression? Well, in one of the worst advertising markets since then, the three NBC networks carrying the Winter Olympic Games have run up a surprisingly robust $720 million on the sales meter for commercial time during the 375.5 hours of coverage from Salt Lake City starting tonight.

title: Fed Up and Going After the Terrorist Himself
description: Arnold Schwarzenegger as a man of feeling? His eyes puffy with tears? That's just one of the unforgettable, yet strangely irrelevant images from ''Collateral Damage,'' in which Mr. Schwarzenegger plays Gordy, a Los Angeles firefighter who finds out exactly how ineffectual the United States government is when his wife and young son are killed by a Colombian terrorist, Claudio (Cliff Curtis).

title: Extreme Sport in Kazakhstan: In-Line Skates, Motorcycles and a Metal Ball
description: With ''Rollerball,'' John McTiernan takes on his second remake of a Norman Jewison picture, the first being ''The Thomas Crown Affair.'' ''Affair'' was Mr. McTiernan's 1999 redesign of Jewison's 1968 stylized pearl. Perhaps Mr. McTiernan will soon get around to giving us a remake of Jewison's ''Soldier's Story,'' with Pierce Brosnan in the Howard E. Rollins role. Such a gambit would make about as much sense as this extreme-sports revisit of Jewison's lumbering 1975 ''Rollerball,'' a well-intentioned though heavy-handed assault on capitalism and sanctioned blood lust.

title: Radiance and Refinement In a Triumphant Voice

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Oil Profit Falls
description: Royal Dutch/Shell, the biggest oil company in Europe, said fourth-quarter profit excluding one-time items slumped almost 50 percent as economies slowed after the Sept. 11 terror attacks and oil and gas prices fell. The slide in quarterly net profit to $1.91 billion from $3.58 billion a year ago was steeper than analysts had forecast. Royal Dutch/Shell said lower crude oil prices were responsible for the reduced profit.

description: To the Editor:

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Film; Before the World Spotlight Homed In
description: Long before the television correspondents with their satellite videophones descended on Afghanistan, a few intrepid documentary filmmakers from Europe, armed with handheld video and eight-millimeter cameras, were bearing witness to that country's endless wars and to the indomitability of its people. They saw their work, dangerous and lonely but also evidently thrilling, as an antidote to the rest of the world's indifference.

title: Spectators Urged to Arrive Early and to Bundle Up
description: The opening ceremony for the 2002 Salt Lake Olympics on Friday night is scheduled to last three hours, perhaps a bit longer if cheering for the United States team does not subside in a reasonable amount of time.

title: Belated Justice in Egypt
description: A Cairo appeals court affirmed the rule of law yesterday by overturning the unjust conviction of Saad Eddin Ibrahim, Egypt's most eminent campaigner for democracy and human rights. Mr. Ibrahim, a sociologist holding both Egyptian and American citizenship, had been serving a seven-year sentence for defaming Egypt's image and accepting European Union research funding without government permission. His real offense was criticizing the rigging of Egypt's 1995 elections and setting up a group to monitor the 2000 vote.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRACHMAN, MARK
description: DRACHMAN-Mark. Died suddenly. Loving and devoted son of Harvey and Suzanne. Dearest brother of Debbie. Wonderful and faithful friend to all. Interment private.

title: Lawmakers Look at Wall Street's Role
description: Enron promised bond underwriting business to Merrill Lynch and Wachovia in return for investments in some of its partnerships, Representative Billy Tauzin said during hearings today as lawmakers look at the role Wall Street firms played in the company's rise.

title: Spinning Off Rodeo Drive
description: Last year Paramount released the three "Godfather" films on DVD, and now the studio has discs of the three "Beverly Hills Cop" movies. If they represent a plunge in venerability, the three Eddie Murphy vehicles nicely exemplify the degenerative consequences that usually overtake spinoffs of hit movies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARLSTEIN, JEANNETTE F.
description: CARLSTEIN-Jeannette F. On February 7, 2002. Music educator and teacher for almost 60 years. Lifelong student of music and world traveler. Beloved wife of the late Martin. Devoted mother of Ellen Carlstein Roth and mother-in-law of Stephen Roth. Cherished grandmother of David and Serena. Loving sister of Norma Elliott and the late Dorothy Haydon. Services Sunday 2 PM at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: From Any Position on the Floor, Jason Kidd Can See Tomorrow
description: He saw it before anybody else, of course.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DRUCKER, ELLA
description: DRUCKER-Ella. February 8, 1989. Missing you so much; loving you always. Kisses, V.

title: Israel Says Palestinian Woman Intended to Kill Herself in Blast
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 8  An Israeli government investigation has concluded that a Palestinian woman who died when she set off a huge explosion in downtown Jerusalem on Jan. 28 was in fact a suicide bomber, a senior Israeli military official said here today.

title: City Agrees To Settle Captain's Suit Against Police
description: The city has agreed to pay nearly $500,000 to settle a federal civil rights lawsuit filed by a police captain who charged that the Police Department had retaliated against him for refusing to revise a report that criticized its handling of a sexual harassment case, the captain's lawyer said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article yesterday about high school football players who are signing with colleges referred incorrectly in some copies to the track and field event in which one player, I-Perfection Harris of Brooklyn, exceeded 24 feet. It was the long jump, not the high jump.

title: Max Perutz, Father of Molecular Biology, Dies at 87
description: Dr. Max Perutz, whose success in elucidating the structure of the hemoglobin molecule helped give birth to the field of molecular biology and brought him the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1962, died on Wednesday at a hospital near his home in Cambridge, England. He was 87.

title: Britain Proposes Changes in Asylum Process
description: Britain proposed today that future immigrants would have to demonstrate language skills and knowledge of British values to obtain citizenship.

title: Two Big Insurers Say Enron's Fall Harmed Profits
description: Two big insurers, the American International Group and the Chubb Corporation, reported fourth-quarter results yesterday that were hurt by losses related to the collapse of Enron.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JENKINS, CLIFFORD J.
description: JENKINS-Clifford J. Of Port Washington, NY. Passed away peacefully on February 4, 2002. Survived by his wife Ulla, his godchild Loretta Ward & her husband Frank, the Johanssons and the Loggerts of Sweden, and many nieces and nephews. Private funeral services were held.

title: Bad Guys, Beware
description: In Andrew Davis's new action film, ''Collateral Damage,'' which was made before Sept. 11, Arnold Schwarzenegger (below) plays Gordy Brewer, a Los Angeles firefighter whose family is murdered by a Colombian terrorist. Vowing revenge, Brewer hunts for the killer in South America.

title: Team Thailand Starts And Ends With Skier
description: When Prawat Nagvajara carries the flag for Thailand in the parade of athletes Friday night at the opening ceremony of the Winter Games, he will wear a royal blue jacket he purchased in town this week, with the humble letters he sewed onto the back -- ''Thailand,'' with ''owg '02 team'' below it.

title: Argentina Paying Heavily For Squandering Blessings
description: Everywhere they gather in these days of crisis and collapse, Argentines are asking themselves the same question: how could it have come to this? How has this country, whose name derives from a Latin word meaning money and whose elegant capital faces an estuary called the River of Silver, managed to go bankrupt?

title: ImClone Rejection Focuses Debate on Testing of Cancer Drugs
description: At a major meeting on cancer last May, ImClone Systems announced that its experimental cancer drug, combined with another medicine, shrank tumors in 22.5 percent of the patients in a study, for whom existing treatments had failed. ImClone executives were ecstatic, saying they would immediately seek government approval.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies last Friday about the appointment of Japan's new foreign minister, Yoriko Kawaguchi, misstated the economics degree she received from Yale. It was a master's, not a doctorate.

title: Good Bill, Bad Politics
description: There is nothing like a truly contested election to put the usually somnolent New York State Legislature into a flurry of activity. With much back-slapping, the State Senate passed a good bill this week on women's health care that it had been stonewalling for years. This has everything to do with next Tuesday's special State Senate election on Manhattan's East Side, in which the Democratic candidate, Liz Krueger, has made the Senate's intransigence an issue. The Republican Senate majority, which is desperate to maintain its hold on that seat, suddenly dropped its longstanding opposition to the bill. But now the Democratic majority in the Assembly, with an eye on the same election, is trying to stall action. They should stop playing games and give it final passage.

title: Earnings Increase at E.D.S., But Sales Are Below Estimates
description: Continuing its run of strong earnings in the face of a tough economy, the Electronic Data Systems Corporation reported fourth-quarter profits yesterday that rose 26 percent and beat analysts' expectations.

title: Author Develops a Passion for Her Subject
description: HESTER AMONG THE RUINS

title: Is Profiling Fair? Does It Work?
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Drug Maker's Profit Rises
description: Novartis posted record results, bolstered by pharmaceutical sales, particularly in the United States where sales rose 24 percent. Novartis's net profit climbed 8 percent, to $4.1 billion, and its sales over all were up 10 percent over the previous year, to $19 billion. The company, based in Basel, said sales were driven by six brands, including its hypertension medicine, Diovan. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Lighter of Caldron Remains the Biggest Mystery in Opening Extravaganza
description: The Olympic Five have a secret that can neither be coaxed out with a thick dose of truth serum nor cracked with a cereal-box decoder ring.

title: New Jersey Schools Commissioner Suggests Eliminating Some Tests
description: Responding to concerns among parents and teachers, New Jersey's new education commissioner has proposed eliminating several of the state's assessment tests for grades 4, 8 and 11.

title: Advice From Ground Level on How to Rebuild
description: Chuck Perry, a retired schoolteacher and a one-time restaurant owner, fingered the keypad on the table in front of him at a crowded hall at the South Street Seaport, where he was weighing in on the redevelopment of Lower Manhattan.

title: Scientists Report Initial Success With a Blood Test for Ovarian Cancer
description: Researchers are reporting that they have taken the first step toward developing a reliable blood test for ovarian cancer, including cases that are still early enough to be curable.

title: Money-Grubbing Games
description: First there is a promise. Then there is no promise. Then there is a promise -- until your attention is diverted again.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Loss At Electronics Maker
description: Royal Philips Electronics, Europe's biggest manufacturer of consumer electronics, had its first annual loss since 1996, but its shares rose sharply as the chief executive, Gerard Kleisterlee, forecast that Royal Philips Electronics would return to profit this year. The net loss for 2001 was 2.6 billion euros ($2.3 billion), compared with a record profit of 9.6 billion euros in 2000 as sales of semiconductors, computer screens and other products declined. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Near Enron Field, Cries of Foul
description: ''Jeff Skilling said nothing,'' said Jessie Patterson, one of several former Enron employees who gathered in sports bars and other old after-work haunts to watch their former boss testify before Congress today.

title: Jonathan Rhoads, 94, Medical Innovator, Dies
description: Dr. Jonathan Evans Rhoads, a Philadelphia surgeon who made crucial breakthroughs in the development of intravenous feeding, died on Jan. 3. He was 94 and lived in Haverford, Pa.

title: Magazine Ad Pages Continue to Decline
description: Magazine advertising pages continued to decline into the new year, according to data released yesterday by the Publishers Information Bureau in New York.

title: Learning From Enron
description: To the Editor:

title: But the Limousine Ate My Homework!
description: A quick, biting wit is not a quality normally associated with pubescent actors and the characters they play. But Frankie Muniz, the star of the hit television series ''Malcolm in the Middle,'' and Amanda Bynes, who has her own show on Nickelodeon, both convey a keen, roving intelligence that doesn't wander off into quiz-kid geekiness. Teamed as best friends who travel from Michigan to Hollywood in the comedy ''Big Fat Liar,'' these two young actors display an easygoing, screwball rapport as they dash around Tinseltown, wreaking ludicrous havoc.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: P.L.O. Offices To Remain Closed
description: The Israeli authorities have extended the closing of Orient House, the headquarters of the Palestine Liberation Organization in East Jerusalem, by six months. The Israelis shut the building in August after a suicide bombing in Jerusalem. Officials said the extension, along with the closing of two offices linked to the Palestinian Authority, were meant to assert Israeli authority over East Jerusalem, which Palestinians consider the future capital of their hoped-for state. Joel Greenberg (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about an Iraqi offer to open a dialogue with the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, gave an outdated title for Hans Blix, who attended a meeting on the offer. He is executive chairman of the United Nations Monitoring, Verification and Inspection Commission, no longer director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency.

title: Kelly Plans to Hire Outside Consultant to Speed Police Recruiting
description: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday that he was planning to hire a full-time outside consultant to recruit potential police officers, in part because of the difficulty the Police Department has had in attracting interest in the job.

title: Giants Name Lynn Defensive Coordinator
description: The Giants promoted Johnnie Lynn, the defensive backs coach, to defensive coordinator yesterday, replacing the departed John Fox with another longtime assistant to Coach Jim Fassel.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Central Bank Meets
description: The Bank of Japan policy board started its two-day meeting amid expectations that it might ease monetary policy again. The central bank's short-term interest rates are already near zero, but fears about the nation's weak banking system have made additional steps more likely. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELTZER, CARL
description: SELTZER-Carl. Born June 20, 1936. Died January 29, 2002. Director of Seltzer Sound in N.Y. City. Survived by family & life partner

title: New York State Files Suit Against Maker of Software
description: The State of New York said yesterday that it had sued Network Associates, a maker of antivirus software, accusing the company of restricting free speech by forcing consumers and journalists to get permission before publishing reviews of its products.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Lady Macbeth, Medium Rare

title: Union Members Are Charged With Creating No-Show Jobs
description: At first glance, some of the members of the International Union of Elevator Constructors appeared to be incredibly hard-working people.

title: Notes From Chicago; The City of Big Shoulders (and Readers)
description: For the second time in less than a year, the city plans to read a book. And not just any book: in the ''One Book, One Chicago'' project, a panel of librarians decides which book the entire city will read. So when a large mustachioed man in a Bears cap sits beside me on the 66 bus to Pulaski and asks whether I think Holden Caulfield is really crazy, he's going to be expecting some answers.

title: Corrections
description: A review of Buglisi/Foreman Dance at the Joyce Theater yesterday misidentified the lighting designer of Jacqulyn Buglisi's work ''Requiem.'' He is Clifton Taylor; Debora Mach is the set designer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEBBIA, CARMEN J.
description: GEBBIA-Carmen J. Of Toms River, NJ, passed away Tuesday, February 5, 2002 at home. Age 88. Born in New York City in 1913, Mr. Gebbia was a resident of Totowa, NJ from 1958 to 1987 when he retired from his career as a make-up artist to the stars. Mr. Gebbia moved to Toms River, NJ in 1987. Mr. Gebbia began his career in make-up in 1953 when he worked on TV in the early days of black and white. He brought his talent to such programs as; The Howdy Doody Show, To Tell The Truth, What's My Line, Edward R. Murrow's-Person To Person, The Arthur Godfrey Show, The 64 Thousand Dollar Question, Studio One and The Soupy Sales Show. Mr. Gebbia also worked on The Ed Sullivan Show from 1955 to 1971. Over his 35 year career he made up celebrities such as; Ella Fitzgerald, Bob Hope, Bing Crosby, Liz Taylor, Frank Sinatra, Fred Astaire, Gloria Swanson, Tony Bennett, Patty Duke, James Kennedy, Marlon Brando, Jack Lemmon, Sophia Loren and many, many more. Mr. Gebbia was head of the make-up department at FOX-TV for 25 years until his retirement in 1987. He taught make-up classes at the famous Neighborhood Playhouse acting school for 20 years. He also taught privately to students from as far away as Japan. He volunteered his talent to the New York Police Department, taught undercover detectives how to use disguises in their assignments. Mr. Gebbia's hobbies included photography, painting and sculpting. He is survived by his wife of 57 years Michelina (LeCerva) Gebbia, three children; Josephine Wismar of Beachwood, NJ, Salvatore Gebbia of Kennebunk, Maine and Paul Gebbia of Little Falls, NJ. He is also survived by four grandchildren; William Wismar of Beachwood, NJ, Christopher Wismar of Toms River, NJ, Paul Wismar of Beachwood, NJ, Heather Gebbia of Boston, MA and a great-granddaughter, Angela Wismar of Beachwood, NJ. A sister Josephine and her husband Anthony Percivalle of Queens, NY, also survive him. A memorial mass will be celebrated Saturday, February 23, 10:00 AM, at St. Joseph RC Church, Toms River, NJ. A memorial mass will be celebrated Saturday, February 23, 10:00 AM at St. Joseph RC Church, Toms River, NJ. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to The Actors Fund of America, 729 Seventh Avenue, 10th Floor, New York, New York 10019.

title: Gigante Has Few Words at Hearing on Charges
description: Making his first court appearance in four years, Vincent Gigante, the convicted Mafia boss famed for wandering the streets in his bathrobe, allowed a federal judge in Brooklyn to enter a not guilty plea on his behalf yesterday on charges of racketeering and obstructing justice by faking dementia.

title: How Citigroup Hedged Bets On Enron
description: At the time, 18 months ago, the idea seemed unthinkable: Enron, the highflying energy company, in bankruptcy. But Citigroup wanted to hedge its bets.

title: After January Raid, Gen. Franks Promises to Do Better
description: Stung by criticism that American commandos might have mistakenly killed anti-Taliban troops in a raid last month, the commander of the war in Afghanistan said today that he had ordered top ground officers to tighten coordination with Afghan allies to prevent a recurrence.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Classical Music and Dance Listings
description: Aselective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Judicial Confirmation Hearing Evokes Civil Rights Struggle
description: A Senate Judiciary Committee hearing on the nomination of Charles W. Pickering to be a federal appeals court judge turned quickly today into a pained retrospective of the turbulent civil rights era in Mississippi, his home state, and an examination of his behavior in those days.

title: Tribes to Get Their '15 Minutes'
description: Clifford Duncan sat in a breakfast nook in a downtown hotel, poking at a bowl of oatmeal, nibbling on sourdough toast and recalling his great-grandfather.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Via Emilia has managed to insinuate itself into the crowded precincts of Park Avenue South with scarcely a peep. It is a country mouse come to the city, a humble trattoria with brick walls, a few small tables and austere black and white photographs on the walls that show sturdy peasants making Parmesan cheese, or Italian mamas behind the stove. The place does not even take credit cards.

title: Houston Steps Up and Brings Knicks With Him
description: He is the Knicks' most criticized player, especially since signing a $100.4 million contract last summer. Fans say he disappears in the fourth quarter and that he is too tentative. Some even call him too nice, too clean cut or too soft.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAUG, FREDERICK J.
description: HAUG-Frederick J., 91. Formerly of Manhasset, N.Y. Died February 5, 2002 in New York City. Beloved husband of Dorothy. Devoted and adored father of Gretchen Stone, Hedi White and father-in-law of Lewis Stone and Thomas White. Cherished grandfather of Pamela Stone-Humphrey and her husband Jim, Bart Stone and Timothy White. Proud great-grandfather of Riley Humphrey. Dear brother of Bertha Dean, Mina Cory and Elsie Haug. Caring uncle and granduncle of David Cory, Mina Kahofer, Daniel Cory, John Cory, Robert Dean, Frederick Dean and Barbara Dalally and their children. Family will receive friends Friday. 2 to 4 and 6 to 8PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. Funeral services Saturday, 11AM at Congregational Church of Manhasset, 1845 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, N.Y. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, family requests donations to be made to the charity of your choice.

description: Theater

description: To the Editor:

title: WHIRLPOOL LASHES OUT AT SPECULATION ON ITS EARNINGS
description: The Whirlpool Corporation affirmed the accuracy of its quarterly earnings yesterday and said it was considering legal remedies after its shares dropped 9.7 percent Wednesday on speculation that it inflated profit. The stock decline ''appears to have been intentionally triggered by totally unfounded misinformation,'' the chief executive, David R. Whitwam, said, adding, ''We cannot stand by and allow such behavior to destroy significant shareholder value.'' The company's shares fell to $65.50 Wednesday after Briefing.com reported that stock traders speculated Whirlpool's earnings included ''nonoperating items.'' The stock fell $2.04, or 3 percent, to $63.46, yesterday.

title: Charges Fly in Senate Election on the East Side
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg added his voice to the heated special election to replace State Senator Roy M. Goodman yesterday, saying a vote for Liz Krueger, the Democratic candidate, to represent the East Side of Manhattan, was a ''wasted vote'' because the State Senate is controlled by Republicans.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: The Aegis Group, London, acquired Market and More, a European market research company with operations in Belgium, France, Germany and the Netherlands that works for clients like the Danone Group and Procter & Gamble. The deal involves an initial cash payment of $5.2 million plus possible additional payments over three years based on performance.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, NATALIE
description: HOFFMAN-Natalie. Beloved wife of the late Frank. Loving mother of Richard and Gail, Peter and Nancy, Neil and Barbara, and Gregg and Kathy. Dear sister of Ralph Kaplan. Cherished grandmother of Billy, A.J., Samantha, Mollie & Frankie. Service Sunday, 10:15 AM, at The Riverside, 21 West Broad St, Mount Vernon, NY.

title: Lobo Tries New League In Rebound
description: Rebecca Lobo would like to forget last season with the Liberty of the Women's National Basketball Association, when she appeared in only 16 of the team's 32 games and averaged 1.1 points. In fact, she would like to forget all five of her injury-marred seasons with the Liberty after leading Connecticut to the national title in 1995, when she was the consensus player of the year.

title: Mexico to Release Army General Jailed in Rights Case
description: The government of Mexico announced tonight that it would free Brig. Gen. Jos Francisco Gallardo, a dissident army officer jailed eight years ago after he criticized rights abuses by the military.

title: While Hastert Turns to Bush, Backers of Campaign Overhaul Mull Delay of Its Effect
description: As the House prepared for a fierce battle over campaign finance, Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, opposing broad change, huddled with President Bush today while supporters of overhaul considered making their legislation effective only after the fall elections.

title: Images of Time's Flight by Robert Frank
description: Since Sept. 11 we look differently at so much we used to take for granted: tall buildings, commercial airplanes, fire trucks, ambulances, the American flag. To come across a majestically large print of Robert Frank's ''Fourth of July -- Jay, New York'' (1954) at Pace/MacGill in Chelsea is to experience the shock of seeing the unfamiliar in the familiar.

title: Peterson, Not Street, Will Carry The Flag
description: Amy Peterson, a four-time Olympic short-track speedskater, has been elected by her fellow American athletes to carry the flag at the head of the United States delegation in the parade of athletes at Friday night's elaborate opening ceremony. Peterson got the nod despite a monthslong campaign by the skier Picabo Street, a local favorite, to win the honor.

title: An Erotic Revolution Made Tame by Time
description: THE Metropolitan Museum of Art's big new ''Surrealism: Desire Unbound'' begins logically enough (shall we say ''logically'' about a Surrealism show?) with Dada and de Chirico; it ends with the vast international Surrealist exhibition organized by Andr Breton and Marcel Duchamp in 1959.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, STELLA
description: BERNSTEIN-Stella. Beloved aunt of Claudia and Emil Buckner. Heartfelt condolences to the Bernstein family in Hartford, CT. and New York City.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: New Overseer For Courts In Brooklyn
description: Reacting to inquiries into the conduct of at least five State Supreme Court justices in Brooklyn, the state's top judges appointed a new administrative judge yesterday to oversee the problem-plagued court in the city's most populous borough.

title: More Than 50 U.S. Troops Examine Missile Attack Site
description: More than 50 American military personnel have been sent in to the site in eastern Afghanistan where suspected members of Al Qaeda might have been killed in an antitank missile attack, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff said today.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sun To Sell Linux Servers
description: A top executive of Sun Microsystems said the company would soon offer inexpensive server computers that would run the Linux operating system. Analysts had warned that the growing market for such servers might hurt Sun's sales. The company will disclose details of dates and pricing ''in the coming weeks and months,'' the president of Sun, Ed Zander, told investors and analysts on a conference call. The aim is ''to offer users an alternative,'' he said. Analysts have questioned whether Sun may be vulnerable as smaller servers, running Linux and Windows software, become more reliable. Sun's main products run a proprietary operating system, Solaris.

title: E-Mail Sent to Flight School Gave Terror Suspect's 'Goal'
description: Zacarias Moussaoui's e-mail message brimmed with ambition. He wanted to ''pilot one of these Big Bird,'' he wrote in broken English, even though he did not have a private pilot's license. He described flying airliners as ''my 'Goal' my dream,'' yet he admitted his qualifications ''could be better.''

title: Playing Power Politics, From Bar Car to Caboose
description: To the victors go the choice seats.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Winslow Township: Four Found Slain
description: The bodies of two men and two women were discovered yesterday evening in a home in Winslow Township, and law enforcement officials said they had been shot to death. The victims, who were in their 30's, were found in various parts of the house, which also contained drugs and drug paraphenalia, the authorities said. The police went to the house on Wednesday in search of a woman who had been reported missing, and who did not live there. They could not get a key to the house from its elderly owner until yesterday, said Sgt. Frank Perrone of the Winslow Township police. Investigators are trying to determine if the murders were connected to another homicide about a week and a half ago in the same neighborhood of the Camden County township. Tina Kelley (NYT)

description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 9.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELSTEIN, ROBERT
description: FINKELSTEIN-Robert. January 29, 2002. Beloved husband of Phyllis Liniado, best friend and adoring father of Jennifer, caring brother of Cynthia Ader and Allen Stone. Dear friend of sisters and brothers-in-law, Marion and Fred Cuba and David Herzog and the late Judy Liniado. Loving uncle of Stephanie and Jonathan Cuba. A graduate of Cornell University and a U.S. Naval officer.

title: Airline Passenger Is Subdued After Trying to Enter Cockpit
description: An unarmed passenger aboard a United Airlines flight on its way from Miami to Buenos Aires early today tried to break down the door to the cockpit, but was subdued by crew members, including a co-pilot who hit him on the head with a small ax.

title: After Sloppy First Half, Duke Avenges Its Loss
description: The Duke Blue Devils will keep the nameplates attached to their lockers after they finally defeated Florida State, 80-49. They will also have chairs to sit in when Coach Mike Krzyzewski has something to tell them. These are significant because the last time the Blue Devils played Florida State, they returned to their plush locker room to find it stripped down to Y.M.C.A. chic.

description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Forest Service and Environmentalists Settle Logging Dispute
description: After nearly three days of court-ordered negotiations, the United States Forest Service agreed to reduce substantially the size of a timber sale on large tracts of the Bitterroot National Forest that burned in wildfires in 2000. In exchange, environmentalists agreed to end their appeals on the remaining acreage and allow logging to take place.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAUBE, JOSEPH
description: DAUBE-Joseph. We deeply mourn the passing of our dear secretary, Joseph Daube. He was a devoted longtime member of our organizations who always gave us his utmost support. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to his dear wife, Bea, his sons, Jeffrey and Michael, and their families. Henry Wimpfheimer, President Gemiluth Chessed of Greater New York Inc. and Palisades Gardens Foundation, Inc.

title: Remarks on Microsoft Case Mostly Oppose Settlement
description: The public -- along with a predictable collection of lawyers and lobbyists -- has delivered its verdict on the government's settlement plan in the Microsoft case. Thumbs down, it seems, according to the sprawling democratic cacophony found in some 30,000 public comments received by the Justice Department.

title: Eye Cells May Help Regulate Body's Clock
description: With the help of three kinds of blind mice and some ugly frogs, scientists have discovered a new class of light-sensing cells in the retina.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Gunfire Wounds 3 At School
description: Three teenagers were wounded at Theodore Roosevelt High School in Chicago in a shooting shortly after school was dismissed, the police said. The victims, all 16, were taken to hospitals. John W. Fountain (NYT)

title: Isles Rediscover Season-Opening Formula
description: These Islanders suddenly look like the old Islanders. No, not the Islanders of 20 years ago. Not yet. The comparisons to the glory years will have to wait at least until well into the spring, when the games really mean something.

title: Skilling Gives His Version Of Reality To Congress
description: There were no problems at Enron while Jeffrey K. Skilling was running the company. Or at least none that he noticed.

title: Party-Line Split Over Pensions Reappears as 401(k) Fears Grow
description: A new partisan fault line is opening over one of the most durable domestic political issues: how to protect the pensions of working Americans.

title: Bush Administration Allows Oil Drilling Near Utah Parks
description: The Bush administration is opening the red rock country near two of Utah's popular national parks to oil and gas drilling, over the objections of some park rangers in the Southwest and government scientists.

title: DNA That Freed Three Matches New Suspects
description: The police said today that they had arrested two men in the 1986 rape and murder of a medical student for which three wrongly convicted men were freed from prison in December after being cleared by DNA evidence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPLINGER, HAROLD
description: RAPLINGER-Harold. On Feb. 4, 2002. Beloved husband of the late Florence. Memorial service will be held 11:00 AM Saturday, February 9, at Fort Washington Collegiate Church, 181st Street and Fort Washington Avenue, NYC.

title: The Big City; Olympic Boon? More Likely A Boondoggle
description: ALREADY Donny Osmond has taught Katie Couric and Matt Lauer how to pronounce ''Utahan,'' and the Mormon Tabernacle Choir has done the Wave on national television. During the next two weeks, as Salt Lake City's skyline dominates the global village, its proud residents will be quoted repeatedly using the phrase ''world-class city.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONOVAN, JANE, M.D., F.A.P. (HATHEWAY)
description: DONOVAN-Jane, M.D., F.A.P. (Hatheway). 83, of Woodcliff Lake, NJ on Thursday, February 7, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Daniel B., devoted mother of Daniel of Cookeville, TN, John of Mason, NH, and Andrew of NYC, dear sister of Ann Shafnacker of Truro, MA and Elizabeth Rich of Sterling, VA, loving grandmother of seven grandchildren. Funeral service 10 AM and visiting 9 AM to 12 noon on Saturday at the Robert Spearing Funeral Home, Inc. 155 Kinderkamack Rd, Park Ridge, NJ. Interment to follow at Saddle River Reformed Church Cemetery, Upper Saddle River, NJ. In lieu of flowers kindly make contributions to the Convenant House, 460 W. 41 St, NYC 10036. Before retiring Mrs. Donovan was a practicing psychiatrist for over 50 years. She was President of the North Jersey Women's Psychiatric Association, a Life Fellow of the American Psychiatric Association, and was a clinical professor for 30 years at Hackensack Medical Center, Hackensack, NJ.

title: John Cooper, 83; Led Medical Colleges Group
description: Dr. John A. D. Cooper, a medical educator who helped shape national policy as the first full-time physician president of the American Association of Medical Colleges, died on Jan. 27 in Birmingham, Ala. He was 83 and lived in Birmingham.

title: Poetry Academy, After Budget Uproar, Gets New Chief
description: The Academy of American Poets yesterday named Tree Swenson its executive director, succeeding William Wadsworth, whose departure after a dispute with the organization's board last fall provoked angry protests from some prominent poets.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Disney To Supply Content
description: The Walt Disney Company has agreed to provide content from various Disney businesses to the BellSouth Corporation's Internet service in hopes of making money from subscribers to fast World Wide Web services. Articles, video clips and audio clips from ABC.com, ABCNews.com, Disney.com and FamilyFun.com will be available on the home page of BellSouth's service, which has more than a million subscribers, the two companies said. BellSouth will pay Disney for the video and audio clips its fast Internet subscribers watch or listen to, Disney said. The BellSouth deal is the first agreement Disney has made where it is paid per subscriber, it said.

title: Ignorance Was Bliss
description: Two key masterminds of Enron's meteoric rise and fall took center stage at a dramatic Congressional hearing yesterday, and the American people actually got to hear from one of them.

title: WATCHGUARD IS BUYING RAPIDSTREAM FOR $48 MILLION
description: WatchGuard Technologies, a maker of Internet-security software and hardware, said yesterday that it planned to buy RapidStream Inc. for $48 million. WatchGuard, based in Seattle, will pay $31 million in stock and $17 million in cash for RapidStream and may increase its cash portion to as much as $24 million. The purchase is expected to be completed in the second quarter. The acquisition of RapidStream, based in San Jose, Calif., would give WatchGuard access to hardware that allows employees to contact their offices using the Internet without paying for a dial-up Internet service provider or a dedicated line, WatchGuard's chief executive, James A. Cady, said.

title: Erie County's Democratic Leader Endorses Cuomo
description: Andrew M. Cuomo continued yesterday to pick up important backers in his campaign for governor, collecting the endorsement of the Buffalo-area Democratic Party chief a day after winning his first major union endorsement.

title: U.S. Wants More Use of South Asian Bases
description: SINGAPORE  With the war against terrorism providing new impetus, the United States is seeking to expand its use of Southeast Asian countries' bases so its military can move into or through the region more easily and quickly in a crisis, officials and analysts say.

title: Magazine Ad Pages Continue to Decline
description: Magazine advertising pages continued to decline into the new year, according to data released yesterday by the Publishers Information Bureau in New York.

description: Adalbert de Segonzac, a French journalist who was the Washington correspondent of the daily France-Soir from 1956 to 1976, died Dec. 27 at his home in Neuilly-sur-Seine, a Paris suburb. He was 89.

title: Behind the Kidnapping: Pakistan Feels Pressure
description: The mixture of bravado and inscrutability with which Pakistani officials are addressing the case of the kidnapped American journalist is being closely watched here as a clue to the intense pressures the abduction has placed on a government only beginning to feel its way into new territory.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens Village: Body Found After Standoff
description: An emotionally disturbed man barricaded himself in the basement of a residence in Queens Village, and when the police removed him,, they found a dead woman, Juliet Srigam, 34, inside, the police said. Two Emergency Service officers received minor injuries while trying to remove the man from the building, on Hollis Court Boulevard. They were taken to Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, where they were treated and released. The man was taken to Queens Hospital Center. He had not been charged with a crime as of early today. Sergeant Ralph Carone said he had come after the officers with a sharp object. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASCHER, ROBERT CONRAD
description: ASCHER-Robert Conrad. On February 5. Psychiatrist and psychoanalyst in private practice in Manhattan for 50 years. Died peacefully at home surrounded by the family who adored him. He was 77. Born in New York City in 1924, he graduated from the Lincoln School of Teachers College, Columbia University, Long Island College of Medicine and the New York Psychoanalytic Institute. At the time of his death he was Clinical Associate Professor of Psychiatry at Weill Medical College of Cornell University and Clinical Associate Professor of Psychiatry at New York Presbyterian Hospital. A passionate sailor as well as physician, Dr. Ascher was a founder of the Cat Boat Association and member of the New York, New Bedford, and Cuttyhunk Yacht Clubs. His philosophy was ''life is a love story'' for which his survivors, his wife of 35 years Barbara Lazear Ascher, four children Elizabeth and Steven Ascher of Cambridge, Mass., Ellen Ascher of San Diego, Calif., Rebecca AscherWalsh of Manhattan and four grandchildren will be forever grateful. A memorial service will be held Friday, February 22 at 6PM at All Souls Church, 1157 Lexington Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory to the Academy of American Poets, 588 Broadway, Suite 1203, New York, N.Y. 10012.

title: Post-Mortem on a Raid
description: Stung by criticism that Americans might have mistakenly killed anti-Taliban troops in a raid last month, the commander of the war in Afghanistan said he had ordered tighter coordination with Afghan allies to prevent a recurrence.

title: QUEST TO BUY AMERICAN MEDICAL FOR $340 MILLION
description: Quest Diagnostics, which provides medical laboratory tests, has agreed to buy American Medical Laboratories for $340 million, expanding its specialty and gene-based testing. Quest, based in Teterboro, N.J., will gain 2 of American Medical's laboratories and 51 clinics. Under the deal, Quest will also assume $160 million in debt. American Medical, which is closely held, provides specialty and diagnostic testing services in Nevada and the Washington area. As part of the transaction, American Medical will acquire an affiliate, LabPortal Inc., which connects labs with health care providers online.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Special-Education Lawsuit
description: A federal judge has ruled that a lawsuit charging that the state failed to properly include six elementary school students in special-education programs can proceed. The suit was filed in July by the Education Law Center in Newark on behalf of the children, ages 8 and 9. Newark is one of 30 low-income districts under court order to provide certain programs, including enhanced special education. On Wednesday, Judge Katherine S. Hayden of Federal District Court in Newark denied a motion by the state to dismiss the case. The judge has not yet ruled on the law center's request for class-action status.

title: Britain Downgrades Status of Iran's Ambassador
description: LONDON, Feb. 8 — Iran has turned down Britain's choice of ambassador to Tehran after hardline newspapers there accused him of being "a Jew and a member of M.I.6," the British intelligence agency. Britain retaliated tonight by downgrading the status of the Iranian envoy here and placing relations with Tehran on a "more critical" basis.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Game Industry Sales Surge
description: Even as other industries suffered through a slumping economy, sales of video game systems and software rose 43 percent in 2001, to $9.4 billion, the NPD Group, a research firm, said yesterday. Sony's year-old PlayStation2 dominated the market, which received a strong lift in November from new consoles from Nintendo and Microsoft. After record sales of $6.9 billion in 1999, the game industry retrenched slightly in 2000, with revenue of $6.6 billion. But game makers sold 39 percent more consoles in 2001 than the previous year, and the higher prices of the three next-generation systems drove revenue up 120 percent. Sales of entertainment software, which included games for consoles and personal computers, rose 11 percent, to $6 billion. The NPD Group, formerly known as NPD Intelect, said the industry would have trouble beating the 2001 results because most of the sales growth came from the introduction of the new, more expensive consoles. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Cargo Unit Sold
description: The bankrupt Swissair Group has sold its cargo-handling unit, Swissport, to a British investment firm, Candover Investments, for $343 million. Candover paid $162 million, and a consortium of banks led by the Royal Bank of Scotland put up the rest. The unit, which had sales of $710 million last year, is being sold as part of the revamping of Swissair, which filed for bankruptcy protection in October. The airline business is being partly taken over by its former subsidiary, Crossair, under the name Swiss. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: A Truce in New Jersey's School War
description: James McGreevey took office as New Jersey's governor less than a month ago, but he has already made history by moving to settle one of the most bitterly fought education lawsuits in America. After 20 years of foot-dragging and obfuscation by governors and legislators of both parties, Mr. McGreevey has told the state's Supreme Court that he will abide by the court's rulings in Abbott v. Burke. That suit, which challenged the state for failing to provide poor children with a quality education, may be the most significant education case since the Supreme Court's desegregation ruling nearly 50 years ago. Mr. McGreevey's decision to institute the ruling should clear the air on this racially charged issue and set New Jersey on the road to full educational opportunity in 30 underprivileged districts.

title: NIKE SUES SEGA OVER CONCEPT OF MICHAEL JORDAN AD
description: Nike Inc. sued the Sega Corporation, accusing it of stealing Nike's 1996 ''Frozen Moment'' advertisement to promote Sega's NBA 2K2 videogame. The Nike commercial shows a game between the Chicago Bulls and Los Angeles Lakers, switching to slow motion as Michael Jordan flies toward a slam-dunk basket. Sega's new ad, first broadcast Jan. 10, cop es the ''sequence, theme, tone, characters, mood, pace, music and setting of 'Frozen Moment,' '' Nike said in a suit filed in Federal District Court against Sega of America Dreamcast and the advertising agency Leagas Delaney. The suit, filed Thursday, seeks a court order to block use of the commercial, as well as damages.

Unless at least 15 percent of shareholders voted to adjourn, Carnival said this week, its sweetened offer was off. Richard D. But Mr. Masur, who had some leeway about the timing of the procedure, badly wanted to conduct these scheduled performances of excerpts from Wagner's ''Tristan und Isolde,'' including the complete Act II, with Deborah Voigt and Stig Andersen in the title roles.

description: Kenneth L. Lay, Enron's former chairman and chief executive, is scheduled to appear under subpoena before a Senate subcommittee on Tuesday, but there is no assurance that he will subject himself to questioning.
