description: An article in World Business on Feb. 1 about annual financial results for the French telecommunications manufacturer Alcatel misspelled the name of a company in which it sold a stake to help reduce debt. The company was Thomson Multimedia, not Thompson.

title: U.S. Team Has Load Of Talent In Wall
description: As the youngest member of the United States women's hockey team, 16-year-old Lyndsay Wall has experienced exhilarating moments while scaling the learning curve the past six months.

title: Fashion Statement: Hip-Hop on Runway
description: He has been Sean Combs and Puff Daddy and now styles himself P. Diddy. He has been a rap mogul, a multiplatinum-selling recording artist and producer, a celebrity consort and also a criminal defendant. Now, as Fashion Week begins, Sean John Combs, 32, originally of Yonkers, is the biggest comer on Seventh Avenue.

title: Civility, by Bloomberg
description: To the Editor:

title: Botched  Siege Under Scrutiny In Philippines
description: On a moonlit night last June, 30 heavily armed guerrillas forced nearly a score of hostages -- including Martin and Gracia Burnham, an American missionary couple -- into a village hospital here on the island of Basilan.

title: Australian Eyed for Food Post, Lowering U.S. Presence at U.N.
description: The United Nations is poised to announce that the American who is stepping down as head of the World Food Program will be succeeded by an Australian official -- further lowering the American profile in the United Nations leadership, senior Congressional aides say.

title: Frayn Takes Stock Of Bohr Revelations
description: Niels Bohr, the great Danish physicist, was known to push his scientific debates mercilessly, pursuing at least one colleague to his sickbed to drive home a point. Michael Frayn portrayed him exactly that way in a play about an argument between the dead spirits of Bohr and two others over what happened in a hazily recalled meeting that they had in September 1941 in Copenhagen, which was then occupied by the Nazis.

title: Dr. John Slade, 52, Fighter For Regulation of Cigarettes
description: Dr. John Slade, an expert in the treatment of alcohol, tobacco and drug addictions and an early and ardent supporter of government regulation of cigarettes, died on Jan. 29 at a family home on Lake Burton in Rabun County, Ga. He was 52.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHENDELMAN, GEORGE
description: SHENDELMAN-George. The National Board of Hadassah, WZOA, mourns the death of George Shendelman, husband of Esther Shendelman, father of Deborah Shendelman and Trisha Shendelman Margulies, our esteemed colleagues. Our heartfelt condolences go to the entire famiily. May his memory be for a blessing. Bonnie Lipton, National President

title: On War Criminals' Trail, an Unflagging Hunter
description: CARLA DEL PONTE does not like to talk about herself because her business is others. Tracking down and prosecuting others.

title: Caldron Is Ignited With Little Hype
description: Shocking news: NBC did not shamelessly tease viewers about who would light the Olympic caldron last night during the opening ceremony of the Salt Lake Winter Games.

title: S.E.C. SCRUTINIZING ANOTHER COMPANY
description: Global Crossing, the fiber optic network operator whose recent bankruptcy filing was the largest ever by a telecommunications company, said yesterday that it had been notified by the Securities and Exchange Commission of an investigation into its accounting after accusations that the company improperly inflated its revenue.

title: Esiason Expected to Join CBS
description: CBS Sports is expected to announce next week that Boomer Esiason will join the ''NFL Today'' studio show that has undergone a nearly annual overhaul, according to an industry executive.

title: HIGH TALIBAN AIDE IS IN U.S. CUSTODY AT KANDAHAR BASE
description: The man who served the Taliban as foreign minister surrendered today to the Afghan authorities in Kandahar, where he was transferred to American custody and was being held tonight in the United States detention compound at the city's airport, military and intelligence officials said.

title: Endgame? Some Enron Board Members Quit or Face Ouster at Other Companies
description: The door is closing behind some Enron directors.

title: Surgeon General, in Farewell, Pleads for a 'Meaningful Budget'
description: Surgeon General David Satcher, who took on President Bill Clinton over needle exchanges for drug addicts and President Bush over sex education, warned in a parting interview today that the ''lack of a meaningful budget'' might diminish the independence of his office.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about John Rusnak, a currency trader for Allfirst Financial in Baltimore who the company says lost $750 million and concealed the losses with fictitious trades, misspelled the surname of a neighbor who commented. He is Michael O'Connell, not O'Connel.

title: Microsoft And 9 States Spar in Filings
description: In a court filing yesterday, the nine states opposing the government's proposed antitrust settlement with Microsoft said the pact was riddled with flaws and, if approved, would extinguish competition and lock computer users into ''a Microsoft-controlled world.''

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Blame In Fire Deaths
description: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration has found that Forest Service commanders disregarded safety regulations in June in a fire that killed four firefighters in the Okanogan National Forest in eastern Washington. The agency said Forest Service fire managers violated all 10 Standard Fire Orders and 10 of 18 emergency guidelines in the Thirty Mile Fire. Rules for rest and deploying fire shelters were also not followed, the report said.

title: Newark Landlord Arrested After Fatal Apartment Fire
description: Four days after an apartment fire killed two young sisters, the police arrested the building's landlord late Thursday on a nine-month-old warrant that accused him of failing to provide heat to his tenants.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Punishment In Police Hazing
description: Members of an elite unit of the Portland Police Bureau will be disciplined for inappropriate behavior at an initiation ritual, Chief Mark Kroeker announced. The city began investigating hazing in the Special Emergency Reaction team last month when a female officer in the unit retired after complaining of sexual jokes. The chief would not give details of the behavior. Mayor Vera Katz called the activities ''unacceptable.'' Chief Kroeker said 20 past and present members of the unit would receive letters of reprimands. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: BANK OF AMERICA SETTLES SUITS BY SHAREHOLDERS
description: The Bank of America Corporation agreed to pay $490 million to settle lawsuits claiming it hid losses from loans to a hedge fund before combining with the NationsBank Corporation in 1998. Shareholders accused Bank of America of concealing a write-off of $372 million stemming from a loan to the hedge fund, D. E. Shaw & Company of New York. Some plaintiffs' lawyers said bank executives hid the losses because they did not want to derail NationsBank's purchase of BankAmerica. The bank, based in Charlotte, N.C., did not admit any wrongdoing under the settlement.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Independent Investigation Planned
description: Allied Irish Banks announced an independent investigation into how controls at its American subsidiary, Allfirst, failed to detect losses of $750 million that were believed to have been concealed with fictitious transactions created by the Baltimore-based trader John Rusnak. The Irish state broadcaster, RTE, reported that in 2000, Allied Irish executives who also served as directors of Allfirst failed to attend the 75 percent of board meetings required under Maryland state law. Through his lawyers, Mr. Rusnak, 37, has denied stealing the money, and has told the Federal Bureau of Investigation that he lost it while trying to cover for his losses in currency trading. Allied Irish Banks also centralized all of its international treasury operations under its capital markets division. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: McGreevey Is Expected to Tap Two Party Insiders for Top Posts
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey is expected to name longtime Democratic Party insiders to head two important state agencies, the Department of Transportation and the Department of Human Services, officials close to the nomination process said today.

title: Russia Says It Is Upholding Promise on Oil Export Curbs
description: Russia said today that it was keeping to the letter of its promise to the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, reducing the official count of its exports of crude oil by 150,000 barrels a day. But oil production is still surging, exports of refined products are still rising, and few people here think there is any chance of export restraint after March 31, when the promise to OPEC expires.

title: D.E.A. Extends Its Deadline For Banning Hemp in Food
description: Hoping to give an appeals court time to rule, the Drug Enforcement Administration said yesterday that it would extend a grace period for companies to dispose of food products made from hemp, a plant containing small amounts of the same psychoactive substance found in marijuana.

title: William T. Dillard, Founder Of a Retail Chain, Dies at 87
description: William T. Dillard, who founded the Dillard's department store chain, built it into the nation's third largest and then presided as his stores lost prestige and profits, died yesterday at his home in Little Rock, Ark. He was 87.

title: Challenging The Dogmas Of Free Trade
description: The moderator was blunt, almost tactless. Dani Rodrik, Harvard economist, could have just three minutes at the podium -- less time than other panelists -- to speak out as the designated challenger of globalization as it is practiced today.

title: Las Vegas Is Going to East Asia: A Gamble, Maybe, for All Sides
description: Hoping to shower Las Vegas stardust on its somewhat shabby gambling industry, the former Portuguese colony of Macao granted licenses today to two American casino operators.

title: Excerpts From Judge's Taped Discussion
description: Following is an excerpt from a transcript, filed in court by prosecutors, of a secret tape-recording made by Gary Berenholtz, a lawyer and cooperating witness identified as G., of his conversation with Justice Victor I. Barron, identified as J., in a robing room at State Supreme Court in Brooklyn on Jan. 18.

title: Pataki Veto Leaves Intact Restrictions On Fireworks
description: Gov. George E. Pataki vetoed a bill today that would have legalized many small fireworks, after a fierce lobbying campaign against the bill by New York City, fire officials and consumer advocates.

title: Neal W. O'Connor, 76, Executive at Ad Agency
description: Neal W. O'Connor, a longtime advertising executive who in the 1960's and 1970's helped revive the agency now known as N. W. Ayer & Partners by, among other things, moving its headquarters to New York from Philadelphia, died on Friday, Jan. 18 in Newtown, Pa. He was 76 and lived in Princeton, N.J.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Mobile Phone Growth
description: The number of mobile phones worldwide grew 40 percent last year and will soon outstrip the number of fixed lines, the International Telecommunication Union said yesterday. The statistics show 1.045 billion fixed lines at the end of 2001, according to the United Nations agency. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: China Bars Japan's Salvage Of Ship
description: China will not allow Japan to salvage a North Korean ship that sank in the East China Sea on Dec. 22 after a gun battle with the Japan Coast Guard, according to a report from Beijing in Sankei Shimbun, a conservative Japanese newspaper. All crew members, believed to number about 15, died. Japan wants to study the ship to determine its origin and mission, but Chinese public opinion opposes salvage at the site, which is within China's economic zone. James Brooke (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A sports article last Saturday about the parents of Grant Wistrom, a St. Louis Rams lineman, and their travels to watch their football-playing sons, misstated the location of the University of Nebraska. It is in Lincoln, not Omaha.

title: California Leads Chorus of Sounded-Out Syllables
description: More than a dozen years after California dropped phonics for what it felt was the more imaginative approach to teaching reading known as whole language, it is returning to basic phonics in a big way.

title: PHARMACIA STOPS TRIALS ON A CANCER DRUG
description: The Pharmacia Corporation is ending clinical trials of a colorectal cancer drug under development by its subsidiary Sugen Inc., the company said yesterday. An interim analysis of trial data showed patients receiving the drug, semaxanib, along with chemotherapy showed no increased survival rate in advanced-stage colorectal cancer compared with those who received chemotherapy alone, Sugen's president, Laura K. Shawver, said. Semaxanib was a pioneer drug in a class of compounds that cause tumors to starve. Ms. Shawver said the company would not try to redevelop semaxanib but would apply lessons learned to two other compounds it is developing.

title: The Nazi Bomb: Riddle Solved?
description: To the Editor:

title: Korea Veteran Is Charged With Fraud
description: A Korean War veteran who apparently lied about his role in a massacre of civilians that came to light 50 years after it occurred was charged today with filing false claims at the Veterans Affairs Department.

title: Lodwick Aims to Give Obscure Event a Lift
description: Howelson Hill is one of those fabled mountains where, as a kid, you either learn to become an Olympian or a toboggan instructor. Nestled in self-proclaimed Ski Town U.S.A., Steamboat Springs, Colo., it was named for Carl Howelson, the Norwegian who introduced skiing to the small mountain town in 1909.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Telecom Profit Falls
description: Singapore Telecommunications said net profit in the last three months of 2001 fell 56 percent, to 290.3 million Singapore dollars ($158.5 million), on expenses related to its $7 billion purchase of the Australian operator Cable and Wireless Optus as well as rising competition and a recession at home. The company said sales in its fiscal third quarter nearly doubled to 2.42 billion Singapore dollars, thanks to contributions from Optus, now known as SingTel Optus. Sales in Singapore fell 1.6 percent, to 1.21 billion Singapore dollars. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Excerpts From the House Subcommittee Hearings on the Enron Collapse
description: Following are additional excerpts from the testimony of Enron's former chief executive, Jeffrey K. Skilling, before a hearing of the House Energy and Commerce subcommittee on Thursday, as recorded by Federal News Service Inc. (A full transcript was not available Thursday night.) Mr. Skilling was questioned by Representatives Henry A. Waxman, Democrat of California; James C. Greenwood, Republican of Pennsylvania; Billy Tauzin, Republican of Louisiana; and Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts. A full transcript is available online: nytimes.com/business.

title: Inquiry on Antimissile Contract Is Sought
description: Saying the competition to build the top weapon for the nation's antimissile effort was apparently decided not on technical merit but in the fallout over an incident of industrial spying, a California congressman is calling for an investigation into how the contract was awarded.

title: An Institutional Group Is Close to Switching Its Stance on Stock Options
description: A large association of institutional investors is on the verge of switching its position and supporting an effort to force companies to count stock-option awards as an expense that cuts into profits.

title: Israelis Declare Arab Woman Was in Fact a Suicide Bomber
description: An Israeli government investigation has concluded that a Palestinian woman who died when she detonated a huge explosion in downtown Jerusalem on Jan. 28 was in fact a suicide bomber, a senior Israeli military official said here today.

title: The Islanders Are Playing With a Sense of Purpose Once Again
description: The Islanders have a board in the hallway outside their dressing room with the Eastern Conference standing. The board is updated as often as a Web site, especially after big victories. But that, it turns out, is not really necessary.

title: A Saxophonist's Streamlined Return
description: The alto saxophonist Steve Coleman brought his cool-headed, trancelike group sound to the Knitting Factory on Monday. It was a rare local sighting and a reminder of how much he's been missed here.

title: Iran Turns Down Britain's Choice of an Envoy, Straining Ties
description: Iran has turned down Britain's choice of ambassador to Tehran after hard-line newspapers there accused him of being ''a Jew and a member of MI6,'' the British intelligence agency.

title: TV Catch Phrase From the 1960's Is Evoked in a Hearing Over Enron
description: ''I know nothing.''

title: Costs of Twin Towers Fund Draws Criticism
description: Officials of the Twin Towers Fund, the charity created by Rudolph W. Giuliani to benefit the families of firefighters and police officers who died in the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center, yesterday defended their plans to spend more than $1 million a year on administrative and overhead expenses.

title: Let Women Compete for Best Actor
description: Nominations for the Academy Awards will be announced Tuesday, and the safest prediction is that everyone will find something to complain about. But of course the Oscars are not ''fair.'' They have always been more about spectacle and hype than about the legitimate recognition of talent. That's been clear at least since ''Wings'' beat out ''Sunrise'' for the top award in the very first Oscar ceremony in 1929.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRACCHIA, ALFRED A., M.D.
description: FRACCHIA-Alfred A., M.D. The staff of the Department of Surgery and Breast Surgery Service of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center notes with sadness the death of their colleague, Dr. Alfred Fracchia. Dr. Fracchia's career at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center began as a Surgical Fellow in 1950. From 1950-1998, he brightened the outlook for his patients. Today's patients benefit from his many years of devoted service. He will be missed. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. The Staff of the Breast Surgery Service and Department of Surgery Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center

title: Students Stage Play as 9/11 Therapy
description: There had been much talk about moving on. There had been constant mentions of getting back to normal. But students at Stuyvesant High School, only five blocks away from ground zero, could not quite shake off the turbulent feelings left by the disaster and decided to seek solace and strength in the form of theater.

title: Prosecutor Says Tape Shows Brooklyn Judge Took a Bribe
description: At the arraignment yesterday of a Brooklyn judge charged with accepting a bribe, prosecutors filed a secret tape recording that caught the judge laughing as he prodded a lawyer for what both men seemed to understand was an overdue payoff.

title: Radio for Music Lovers
description: To the Editor:

title: Diluting the Geneva Convention
description: The White House gave Secretary of State Colin Powell a limited victory Thursday by acknowledging that the Geneva Convention applies to the Afghanistan conflict and therefore broadly governs the treatment of captured Taliban fighters, though not Al Qaeda terrorists, detained in Guantnamo, Cuba. Earlier administration declarations seemed to place the United States outside the convention, troubling European and other allies already concerned about Mr. Bush's disdain for a wide range of international agreements.

title: Enronitis
description: Reports that federal investigators are looking into allegations of accounting irregularities at Global Crossing, another high flier gone bankrupt, should only worsen Wall Street's case of Enronitis. Investors who spent much of the late 1990's buying stocks on faith, often of companies whose financial statements were indecipherable even to sophisticated analysts, are suddenly wary, and with good reason, of accounting gimmicks. Companies unable to explain the math behind their polished bottom-line numbers are seeing their stocks punished in the wake of Enron's collapse. It is a painful yet healthy process, not unlike the breaking of a fever.

title: U.S. War Victim Rode Into Afghan Turf Fight
description: As dusk fell, a local storekeeper walked to the spot where he had witnessed the shooting of Sgt. First Class Nathan Ross Chapman, the only American serviceman to die from hostile fire in the war in Afghanistan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, WINIFRED BEACH
description: ADAMS-Winifred Beach. Born June 3, 1908 died February 6, 2002. Great-granddaughter of Alfred Ely Beach, inventor of the first New York subway. Devoted and loving mother and friend. She had a special excitement and love of life that was hers alone. Precious memories will linger with all who knew her. She was preceded in death by her husbands, Leonard Martin and Walter Adams, grandson Scott Campagna, and greatgrandson Kenneth Fahle. Survived by her daughter Winifred Mae Campagna and son Stan Martin. Grandchildren include Frank Campagna, Leonard Martin and Wendy Fahle, and great-grandchildren Frank A. and Amber Campagna, Scott and Erin Fahle, Perry and Eric Martin. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St., Saturday, February 9th, 2-5 and 7-9PM and Sunday 7-9 P.M. with service Sunday 2 PM.

title: A Girl Innocent Enough to Believe a Puppet Is Alive
description: What's a nice girl like Lili doing in the carnival of ''Carnival''? The question keeps coming up with good reason in this shiny soap bubble of a musical, which has been given a charming concert staging by the essential Encores! series at City Center.

title: The Monster in The Dock
description: In the courtrooms at the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia you find the Euro-utilitarian furnishings and sober drone of a Dutch insurance company, which is exactly what the building housed until a few years ago. The defendants, too, are surprisingly ordinary, deprived of whatever strut and menace they had when they were lords of the Balkans. The other day I looked in on the trial of one Stanislav Galic, who reminded me of my high school swimming coach. Mr. Galic is accused of commanding the Bosnian Serb sadists who turned the streets of civilized Sarajevo into a shooting gallery, shelling families as they queued for bread or attended funerals. The trial, like most trials, is a tedious accumulation of detail, the bookkeeping of heartbreak. Hours are spent pinning down the precise location of a tram at the moment sniper bullets pierced its windows, hitting a woman and her 4-year-old daughter. This is where the banality of evil meets the banality of justice.

title: Regular Mammograms Remain a Crucial Tool
description: At the heart of the current debate over the value of annual mammograms are seven clinical trials conducted 20 to 40 years ago. In those trials, women were randomly chosen either to undergo routine screening mammography or to wait until the appearance of symptoms, such as a lump in the breast.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GREENBRIER COS., Lake Oswego, Ore., the third-largest maker of railroad freight cars, said it had orders for 900 railcars, valued at about $50 million, and would decide within a week whether to build them in Portland, Ore., or Trenton, Nova Scotia. The work could add up to 500 jobs.

title: Grim Scavenger Hunt for DNA Drags On for Sept. 11 Families
description: The hairbrushes and toothbrushes, it turns out, did not yield enough clues.

title: Upset in Salt Lake City: Canadians Beat Polish Team
description: A team of Canadians won the fourth I.O.C. Grand Prix in Salt Lake City Wednesday night, completing a string of upset victories by defeating Poland in the final.

title: Active Investors Take European Boards to Task
description: LONDON  With the Enron affair throwing a spotlight on how companies are managed, European stockholders, long considered more docile than their American counterparts, are mounting a vigorous quest for improved accountability.

title: Beliefs; Lessons from the past complicate disclosures of sexual abuse by Roman Catholic priests.
description: From 1985 to 1993, the Roman Catholic Church in this country was rocked by disclosures that some of its priests -- estimates of how many are still debated -- had sexually molested minors.

title: Fugitive, 73, Returned to U.S. for 1986 Killing
description: Law enforcement authorities have arrested the former owner of a chain of Manhattan bars, tracking him down 13 years after he fled the country following his conviction for killing a man in a dispute over a mutual acquaintance.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I found crumpled tissues in his jacket. Is it any good? I don't know.''

title: HONEYWELL ORDERED TO PAY IN ASBESTOS SUIT
description: Honeywell International Inc. was one of three dozen companies ordered by a jury to pay the widow of a brake mechanic $53.5 million for failing to warn him about asbestos risks, lawyers and the company said. The amount Honeywell owes is in dispute. Plaintiffs' lawyers said it was more than $10 million, but a company spokesman, Thomas Crane, estimated the amount was about $1.06 million. The award by a state jury in Manhattan is the largest compensatory damage for a single asbestos victim, a plaintiff's lawyer, Michael Roberts, said. The suit was filed by Patricia Brown, whose husband, Stephen, was exposed to asbestos while working for a company that Honeywell later acquired. Mr. Brown died of asbestos-related cancer in 2000.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Budget Deficit Debate
description: Legislators began a special session divided over how to deal with a budget deficit that has grown to more than $900 million. Gov. John Kitzhaber, a Democrat, has proposed trimming state programs, including education and health services, while increasing taxes on cigarettes and alcohol. While the Republicans who control the House and Senate agree in general with the proposed cuts, they strongly oppose the proposed tax increases, preferring instead to borrow from the state's education fund and halt payments for new school programs. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A list of sites in Weekend on Jan. 25 with an article about New York City memorials and monuments credited the 2001 renovation of Vietnam Veterans Plaza in Lower Manhattan incompletely. E. Timothy Marshall & Associates worked on the design with Jeffrey S. Poor Landscape Architecture.

title: Movement on Meat Safety
description: Promising efforts are under way in Congress to repair the damage caused by a recent federal appeals court decision that weakened the government's ability to combat bacterial contamination at the nation's meat plants.

title: The Nazi Bomb: Riddle Solved?
description: To the Editor:

title: For the Mayor, Jokes Are Part Of the Routine; Though His Delivery Is Not Always Smooth, Bloomberg Gets Laughs
description: During his first week in office, Michael R. Bloomberg was asked if it had dawned on him what a difficult job he had taken on. ''It's hitting me at this press conference,'' he said, then exited, stage left.

title: A Radical Idea to Keep Venice Dry
description: After more than 20 years of bickering over how to prevent the flooding of Venice, it seemed that Italy had finally made up its mind. In December, the Council of Ministers approved the ''Moses'' project, a system of 79 panels that would lie flat on the floor of the Venetian lagoon in normal seas and swing up on great hinges during extremely high tides to form a protective wall at each of the lagoon's three openings to the sea.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Tuesday with an article about efforts to expand the distribution of AIDS drugs in South Africa misspelled the surname of the head of government in KwaZulu-Natal Province. He is Lionel Mtshali, not Mishali.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Governor Has Surgery
description: Gov. Parris N. Glendening had a malignant melanoma removed from his scalp at Johns Hopkins Hospital. Doctors called the six-hour operation successful and said they doubted that Mr. Glendening, 59, would need follow-up chemotherapy. Mr. Glendening will stay at Hopkins for a few days and should be well enough to return to work in a week, said Dr. Richard Lilly, the governor's physician. Lt. Gov. Kathleen Kennedy Townsend is serving as governor until Mr. Glendening's return. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: Cohen and Kwan Maintain Stormy Path
description: The rink was about as wide open as an abandoned warehouse when the music for Michelle Kwan's short program began today at a practice session inside the Salt Lake Ice Center.

title: Enron, Preaching Deregulation, Worked the Statehouse Circuit
description: When it came to lobbying, the Enron Corporation, and Kenneth L. Lay, its former chairman, were about as persistent as anyone had ever seen in California -- or Texas, Tennessee, Oregon and Pennsylvania.

title: Corrections
description: Apicture caption on Tuesday with an article about efforts to expand the distribution of AIDS drugs in South Africa misspelled the surname of the head of government in KwaZulu-Natal Province. He is Lionel Mtshali, not Mishali.

title: Pomp and Patriotism as Games Begin
description: An emotional opening ceremony was punctuated tonight when the 1980 United States hockey team lighted the Olympic caldron to signal the arrival of the 2002 Salt Lake Winter Games.

title: Leetch's Deft Execution Lifts Rangers to Victory
description: One day after acknowledging the season was slipping away, Brian Leetch took it upon himself tonight to help the Rangers snap out of their funk with a singular move. It helped the Rangers break a three-game losing streak with a 2-1 victory over the Atlanta Thrashers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGORRY, GERARD M.
description: McGORRY-Gerard M. On Feb. 7, 2002. Of St. James, formerly of Bayside, NY. Beloved husband of Connie (nee Nicolson). Devoted father of Bill, Mary McMullan, Gerard, Jr., Carol Kratchman, Virginia McGorry, Kathleen Heinegg, Jane Guttridge and Michael. Dear brother of Thomas and Jack. Also survived by 19 grandchildren and 7 great-grandchildren. Reposing at Lloyd Funeral Home, 39th Avenue at 215 Street, Bayside, New York, Saturday and Sunday from 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass at Sacred Heart Church, Monday at 9:45 A.M.

title: Afghan and Pakistani Pledge To Move Beyond Old Grudges
description: The leaders of Afghanistan and Pakistan today reached back more than a decade to find common ground for their countries' future relationship, agreeing that ''misunderstandings and misperceptions'' of the past should be left behind.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULHAUSER, GEORGE C.
description: MULHAUSER-George C., 79. Of Paramus, NJ, a renowned contemporary furniture designer, died Feb. 7, 2002. He was a veteran of W.W. II and served in Okinawa. Beloved husband of Mary. Loving father of Dan and Chris, Paul and Linda, Mary Ann and Jeff, and George and Christine; and nine grandchildren. Also survived by dear brother Rev. Daniel J. Mulhauser, S.J. and his sister Mary Everts. Family will receive friends Sunday, February 10, from 2-4 and 7-9 PM at Zander Plaat Memorial Home, S-113 Farview Avenue, Paramus, NJ. Funeral Mass Monday 9:30 AM, Our Lady of Visitation, Paramus. Interment in George Washington Memorial Park.

title: B Sky B Will Write Off a German Pay Television Investment
description: Rupert Murdoch threw down a gauntlet to the Kirch Group today, essentially writing off a $1.5 billion investment in Kirch's pay television network in Germany.

description: A front-page article on Thursday about the anti-wrinkle drug Botox misstated the profession of Dr. Debra Jaliman, who warned against some of its pitfalls. She is a dermatologist, not a plastic surgeon.

title: Police Say Officer's Helmet Shielded Him From Cleaver
description: Lt. Lawrence Serras was lucky to be alive yesterday, one day after he was struck in the head with a meat cleaver while trying to subdue an emotionally disturbed man who was later charged with killing his wife.

description: Global Crossing Faces 2 Federal Investigations

title: San Diego Neighbors Search for Girl, 7, and a Reason to Hope
description: In folklore, stories of children spirited away in the middle of the night are the stuff of hobgoblins and hungry wolves, of demons that frequent bad dreams.

title: Oregon Doctor Stands Out In Marijuana Prescriptions
description: There are 8,300 active doctors in Oregon. Of these, 777 have authorized at least one patient to use marijuana, under terms of a voter-approved medical-marijuana law. There are 272 who have authorized more than one patient; several have approved a handful; one is up to 61, another 65.

title: Creating a Stir Wherever She Goes
description: Gayatri Chakravorty Spivak had been invited by a group of scholars on this chilly January evening to give a talk at the Penniman Library of the University of Pennsylvania, in Philadelphia. ''They have read Gayatri's paper,'' said Ms. Spivak, a professor in the humanities at Columbia University who sometimes refers to herself in the third person. ''And they said they couldn't understand it.''

description: To the Editor:

title: Olympian Hero Worship
description: Everybody has a personal high point from the opening ceremony Friday night. Mine was Robbie Robertson. I really wasn't into all the turgid symbolism of the good old West, but I can always go for a good concert.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: The State of the Column Is Forlorn
description: MORE or less unscathed, we have emerged from the season when the political big shots check our collective pulse, by way of informing us about the State of the Union, the State of the State, the State of the City, even the State of the Parks. With inspiration like that, how can one resist delivering the first, and in all likelihood the last, State of the Column address?

title: National Briefing | West: Hawaii: Remembering Japanese Ship
description: A memorial for nine people killed when a Navy submarine sank a Japanese fishing vessel was scheduled to be unveiled today, the one-year anniversary of the accident. Japanese groups arranged for the monument, which incorporates an anchor from the ship, the Ehime Maru. Representatives of the Navy, families of the dead and the governors of Hawaii and Ehime prefecture in Japan planned to attend the ceremony, at a hilltop park overlooking the ship's resting place off Oahu. A $60 million salvage operation by the Navy ended in November after recovering all but one victim. Michele Kayal (NYT)

title: A Lean but Not So Mean Champ

For her next trick, minutes after accepting a congratulatory bouquet of flowers, Traa had the Norwegian team's press attache, 6-foot-3-inch Lars Otto Bjoernland, hop on her back so she could carrying him down the mountain in a dash to the lodge.

Sales rose 8 percent, to 31.9 billion kronor.

title: Needing to
description: In discussing the rising use of ''need'' (On Language, Jan. 27), William Safire might have mentioned its popularity as a transitive verb, in which the person who ''needs'' to do something is seldom the speaker. At home, for example, a mother may exhort a child, ''I need you to clean your room.'' The expression is common at the office, too, as in ''I need you to copy me on that memo.'' The genius of this expression is that it conceals the power relationship between addressor and addressee.

title: And Now, Unveiling RCA Battery Park

Bloomberg announced last week that to reduce a projected $4 billion budget gap, New York would sell the naming rights to parts of city parks, it opened a door other cities walked through long ago. For years, New Yorkers have seen their tax dollars subsidize institutions with stodgy names like Yankee Stadium (in the multicultural Bronx, what's so special about ''Yankee''?), while the citizens of Houston, for example, enjoy the trendy frisson of local names like Enron Field.

title: 'The Sweetest Dream'
description: An early evening in autumn, and the street below was a scene of small yellow lights that suggested intimacy, and people already bundled up for winter. Behind her the room was filling with a chilly dark, but nothing could dismay her: she was floating, as high as a summer cloud, as happy as a child who had just learned to walk. The reason for this uncharacteristic lightness of heart was a telegram from her former husband, Johnny Lennox — Comrade Johnny — three days ago. SIGNED CONTRACT FOR FIDEL FILM ALL ARREARS AND CURRENT PAYMENT TO YOU SUNDAY. Today was Sunday. The 'all arrears' had been due, she knew, to something like the fever of elation she was feeling now: there was no question of his paying 'all' which by now must amount to so much money she no longer bothered to keep an account. But he surely must be expecting a really big sum to sound so confident. Here a little breeze — apprehension? — did reach her. Confidence was his — no, she must not say stock-in-trade, even if she had often in her life felt that, but could she remember him ever being outfaced by circumstances, even discomfited?

title: How to Fake a Passport

He holds another Belgian passport under the spooky purple light. The image on this one is printed in a special reactive ink. It glows brightly. ''The first one's a complete counterfeit,'' he announces.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: IF you're expecting deep, thought-provoking cinema from Lasse Hallstrom's CHOCOLAT (2000), you'll be disappointed. But if you're in the mood for a light indulgence and don't mind being manipulated into one of the least shocking messages of our time (that sensuality is good and repression is bad), this is the film for you. Juliette Binoche stars as a single mother who moves to a tranquil French village, opens a chocolate shop there and transforms everyone. Alfred Molina is the stern and disapproving mayor, who ends up enjoying a personal orgy of chocoholism. Judi Dench is a cranky old lady rejuvenated by hot chocolate and memories. Lena Olin is a mousy villager who discovers a new aphrodisiac. Johnny Depp is the handsome Gypsy who comes to town - Tuesday at 2 and 10:20 p.m. on Starz.

title: A 1930's Roadside Attraction Blooms Again
description: IN its gravy days of the 1950's, the McKee Jungle Gardens was hailed as one of the botanical wonders of the world -- with 2,000 species of native and exotic plants and enough alligators and monkeys to keep the children happy. The 80-acre roadside attraction, cinched in between U.S. 1 and the Atlantic Ocean, had everything from a Hall of Giants and bathing beauties to the country's greatest orchid collection, and it pulled in 100,000 people a day. But by the 1960's, bigger inland highways and the snazzier attractions of Sea World and Disney World, drew the crowds from McKee, which closed in 1976.

title: Sexy Feast
description: Strip away the trimmings and you will find that the essential structure of all living things, from the dainty amoeba to the boisterous elephant, from the stately elm to Donald Rumsfeld, is an alimentary system supporting a reproductive system. Why or even how this of all possible arrangements should exist defies ordinary human understanding. But it is plain to see that in the great game of survival every living thing must eat in order to replicate itself and so sustain the precarious grip of its species on its place in nature. What strong desires impel this behavior among the lesser sentient creatures we can only imagine. We may assume, however, that these other living things, unlike ourselves, rely upon instinct to moderate their hunger and lust, for unregulated desire means conflict and eventual extinction. But for us, when we encounter a pretty face or fowl, the moderating instinct is not nearly as dependable, if dependable at all. Hence our collective willingness, older than recorded time, to rely upon priests, magistrates and sacred texts to govern our appetites: a survival strategy embedded in our laws and rituals and known as civilization, a strategy that our fellow creatures, governed by instinct, can forgo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, RICHARD
description: ROSEN-Richard. On February 8, 2002, Richard Rosen passed away in Hilton Head Island, South Carolina, after a brief, but hard-fought battle with congestive heart failure. Dick was a self-made man. Born in 1930 and raised in Brooklyn, Dick earned himself a place at Brooklyn Technical High School and graduated from Cornell University in 1953 with a degree in civil engineering. After a two-year tour as an Army engineer, Dick worked as a civil engineer. Finding engineering insufficiently challenging, Dick put himself through NYU's business school at night. Dick went on to become a management consultant and a partner in the New York accounting firm of Anchin, Block & Anchin. Dick married Goldy Meresman in 1956, and they moved to Garden City, New York, in 1957, where they raised three children, Robert, Susan, and Stephen. After Dick's retirement to Hilton Head Island in 1996, he became an avid, but not always successful golfer. After Goldy's death, Dick and Maxine Uttal fell in love and spent a happy year together. Most of all, Dick will be remembered as a man who loved his many old friends, a gentle giant, a towering intellect, a man who did not suffer fools gladly, and a great provider by Maxine, his three children, and his six grandchildren. Memorial services will be held on Tuesday, February 12 at 3 PM, at Temple Beth Yam, Hilton Head Island.

Yet there was another, unspoken, explanation: the election of 2004. Since Florida was the most contested state in the 2000 election, White House officials are already doing all they can to shore up support there for 2004.

title: 'Lincoln's Virtues'
description: In the summer of 1830 the great preacher, evangelist, and politician Peter Cartwright, renowned throughout central Illinois, made a stop in a cornfield in Macon County while campaigning for the state legislature. Cartwright, "a tremendous cultural force in central Illinois" in those years, was "dressed as became his station" as a presiding elder in the Methodist Church. In the audience there was a "shambling and shabbily dressed" youth, only a few months beyond his twenty-first birthday and only a few months a resident of the state of Illinois and Macon County. This young man was working as a hired hand breaking prairie on a nearby farm, while still residing at his father's home, not yet having struck out on his own. To the amazement of the great preacher, the unlikely youngster presumed to engage him in argument, and made points that were remarkably intelligent. "The Great Methodist," it was later to be written, "was equally astonished at the close reasoning and the uncouth figure of Mr. Brown's extraordinary hired hand."

title: A 1930's Florida Attraction Blooms Again
description: IN its gravy days of the 1950's, the McKee Jungle Gardens was hailed as one of the botanical wonders of the world -- with 2,000 species of native and exotic plants and enough alligators and monkeys to keep the children happy. The 80-acre roadside attraction, cinched in between U.S. 1 and the Atlantic Ocean, had everything from a Hall of Giants and bathing beauties to the country's greatest orchid collection, and it pulled in 100,000 people a day. But by the 1960's, bigger inland highways and the snazzier attractions of Sea World and Disney World, drew the crowds from McKee, which closed in 1976.

title: Staying Clean
description: Patrick T. is prone to citing Oscar Wilde and the physicist Michio Kaku. He's so well spoken, his manners polished to such a high gloss, that -- aside from the fact that he's been a methamphetamine addict and career criminal since age 13 whose only formal education is a high-school degree earned in juvenile detention -- he could blend easily into a gathering of witty young professionals. Certainly he is equally engaged by his work. Until recently, Patrick often earned his living robbing drug dealers and the occasional small business. ''There's a lot of thought and energy that goes into getting loaded and planning a crime,'' he explains. ''It's dramatic -- the excitement, the carefree feeling that comes when you succeed. That's not something that happens in the monotone of everyday life. That's why for me, feeding my mind and spirit will be as important as anything I do in terms of abstaining. Because if I get bored. . . . '' He lets the threat hang, unspoken.

title: 'Lincoln's Greatest Speech'
description: At this second appearing, to take the oath of the presidential office, there is less occasion for an extended address than there was at the first. Then a statement, somewhat in detail, of a course to be pursued, seemed fitting and proper. Now, at the expiration of four years, during which public declarations have been constantly called forth on every point and phase of the great contest which still absorbs the attention, and engrosses the enerergies [sic] of the nation, little that is new could be presented. The progress of our arms, upon which all else chiefly depends, is as well known to the public as to myself; and it is, I trust, reasonably satisfactory and encouraging to all. With high hope for the future, no prediction in regard to it is ventured.

title: Claude Brown's Harlem, Still on the Mind

His streets were ravaged by hustlers and heroin, gang violence and poverty. In 1965, he wrote about his street life in ''Manchild in the Promised Land,'' a brutally poetic narrative now considered a classic of American literature.

title: Chicago Celebrates A Gift From the Maya
description: An American consumes an average of 12 pounds of chocolate a year, according to the Chocolate Manufacturers Association, of Vienna, Va. But the story of chocolate did not begin with the Hershey bar. The Field Museum in Chicago explores that story in an exhibition beginning Thursday (through Dec. 31). ''Chocolate'' views the subject from several angles -- including botanical, economic and anthropological -- to illustrate how different societies have cultivated and enjoyed chocolate. It describes how anthropologists traced the roots of chocolate to the ancient Maya, the first to turn the seeds of the cacao tree into a spicy drink for ceremonial purposes. At the Aztec marketplace, visitors can learn to use cacao seeds as currency.

title: SUPER SUPER BOWL

The Rams entered as a team full of stars. The Patriots entered as simply a team and left as champions. Thomas George

title: 'The River's Tale'
description: As I spread my blanket-sized map of northwestern China on the dining table in the comfort of Hong Kong, I ran my finger west through Qinghai Province, across the thick paper, tracing the route I hoped to take over the coming days. Past Xining, the provincial capital, west to Jyekundo (in small type) and then farther on. A faint red line marking the narrowest and least maintained of the region's roads expired at a small dot labeled Dzatoe. Beyond Dzatoe, a spidery map trace of blue-the Dzachu, or Mekong-extended into a ganglia of tributaries, streams and rivulets, to the very sources of the river itself.

title: 'Edward Abbey: A Life'
description: Demythologizing Edward Abbey starts at birth. Key to the persuasive myth that he created about himself, as reinforced in several of his essays and books, was the impression that he had been born and reared entirely on a hardscrabble Appalachian farm that had been in the family for generations, near a village with the strikingly appropriate and charming name of Home, Pennsylvania. In addition to book jackets, even Abbey's academic vita listed him as "born in Home." And in his private diary as late as 1983, Abbey whimsically recalled "the night of January 29th, 1927, in that lamp-lit room in the old farmhouse near Home, Pennsylvania, when I was born" (308). In fact, that night at 10:30, weighing in at nine pounds, three ounces, Abbey was born in the hospital of the good-sized town of Indiana, Pennsylvania, with doctor and nurse in attendance, as recorded on his birth certificate and noted in the baby book that his mother kept. Mildred and Paul Abbey's baby, the first of five who survived, went home not to any farm but to their small rented house on North Third Street in a cramped neighborhood in Indiana, the county seat of Indiana County, in the foothills of the Allegheny Mountains fifty-five miles northeast of Pittsburgh.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARD, ANNE PHILOMENA
description: WARD-Anne Philomena. On February 7, 2002. Daughter of the late Daniel and Bridget (nee Bonner). Predeceased in 1949 by sister, Baby Margie. Survived by brothers, Daniel and Manus. Also survived by sister-in-law, three nieces and one grandniece in VA. Predeceased by nephew Danny. In Ireland and England, Anne is survived by nine aunts and uncles. Cousins too numerous to mention survive her at home and abroad. A product of Washington Heights, NY, Anne graduated from St. Rose of Lima, St. Vincent Ferrer High School, Columbia University and N.Y.U. She lived nine years in Geneva, Switzerland and thirteen years in New Mexico. Not only an art historian, she was an artist of mixed media. She was a member of the Rainbow Artists in NM. Retired from teaching, Anne worked as a docent in the Corrales/Rio Rancho area, where she leaves countless friends. Fluent in three languages, she never drifted far from her Donegal roots. Anne almost died alone in Albuquerque; instead, due to the timely, selfless, and decisive actions of Rose Forker Ewings, she died in the company of loving family members in Cape Coral, FL. Once again Rose proved herself to be a pillar of strength to the Ward/Bonner family, and we are deeply indebted to her. Interment, with parents, in Our Lady of Mount Carmel Cemetery, Tenafly, NJ. Memorial service to be held at a later date.
