title: 9/11: Balm and Bane of Relationships
description: DR. MAURICE KOUGUELL could hardly believe the man with the cello was actually sitting next to him in same room. ''This has been my dream for years and years,'' he said. The cellist, 81-year-old Alexander Kouguell, looked equally happy as he smiled at his 71-year-old baby brother.

title: Joint Effort Sought To Deal With Attacks
description: QUIETLY but with a rising sense of urgency, the highest elected officials of Nassau and Suffolk Counties are discussing what they say is an increasingly apparent need to coordinate emergency planning on Long Island for possible terrorist attacks.

title: Scandal's Ripple Effect: Earnings Under Threat
description: WHEN Enron caved in last December, investors with the good fortune to have none of the energy giant's stock in their portfolios no doubt breathed a collective sigh of relief.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYO, SMITH, MARGARET
description: MAYO-SMITH-Margaret. Writer, painter, and conservationist, of Bedford, NY died on February 8, 2002. On graduation from Smith College, she worked as a writer for Vogue Magazine in New York, Paris and London. Subsequently, she was a writer and editor at the Institute of International Education in New York. Her paintings have been exhibited at the Salmagundi Club in New York, Gallery East in Easthampton, the Silvermine Guild, and the Katonah Gallery, among others. Conservation activities have included the National Board of the Girl Scouts, on which she worked to expand the outdoors program, the Rails-to-Trails Conservancy, in which she worked as an advocate for Westchester's Acquisition of the North County Trailway, the Sierra Club, the Westchester Land Trust, the John Jay Homestead and the Bedford Conservation Board. She is married to Worthington Mayo-Smith and has three children, Sabina of Topanga, CA, Bill of Weston, MA, and John of Rye, NY and seven grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at St. Matthew's Church, Bedford, NY on Friday, February 15 at 2 PM. Donations in her memory may be sent to the Oncology Nurses Education Fund, Northern Westchester Hospital, Mt. Kisco, NY 10549.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-18

title: This Woman Has Been Sentenced to Death by Stoning
description: Dowden offers a revealing account of how adultery is punished under Islamic law, sharia, in Nigeria. Even more troubling, however, is a recent trial in Sudan, where the ruling National Islamic Front is engaged in a longstanding attempt to impose a harsh version of sharia on Muslims and non-Muslims alike. Abok Alfa Akok, an 18-year-old Dinka tribeswoman of Christian faith, was sentenced in Nyala (southern Darfur Province) to be stoned to death for adultery.

title: From History to Stage to TV, Huey P. Newton's Story
description: HUEY P. NEWTON spent much of his life trying to escape the constricting labels of ''hero'' and ''criminal'' affixed to him by both political friends and political enemies. So it's no surprise that ''A Huey P. Newton Story,'' which will be broadcast by PBS on Wednesday at 9 p.m. to commemorate the 60th anniversary of his birth (on Feb. 17), is a work that defies categorization.

title: To Sell Itself, Fashion Turns to an Uneasy 'Realism'
description: YOU might think ''but is it art?'' is as outdated a question as ''is the bride a virgin?,'' but don't be too sure. The Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston puts an up-to-the-minute slant on the first question in ''Chic Clicks: Creativity and Commerce in Contemporary Fashion Photography,'' on view through May 5.

title: Political Briefing; New Tucson District Drawing a Crowd
description: Speaking of Latinos in politics, when Arizona, another state with a large Latino population, was awarded two new House seats last year because of population growth in the 1990's, the lines for one district, the Seventh on the southwest side of Tucson, were drawn to give Latino candidates a leg up in elections.

title: Helping Hands That Heal Hearts
description: ''MY daughter has a new life now, and she never has to go to the hospital again,'' said Gantuya Boldbaatar, who was speaking of her 2-year-old toddler, Bujinlkham.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BACKER, BERNARD
description: BACKER-Bernard. Born July 18, 1918. Died on February 7, 2002. Former Senior Vice President, The Segal Company. Former President, the Workmen's Circle. Lifelong social democrat and fighter for social justice. Cherished husband of Henrietta. Father of Louise Uphoff, Jo Laird & Richard Backer. Eight grandchildren, one great-grandchild. In lieu of flowers, donations to: DSA, 180 Varick St., NY, NY 10014, or NJ Geriatric Center of the Workmen's Circle, 225 W. Jersey St., Elizabeth, NJ 07207.

title: Two Parties, Poles Apart
description: NEVER mind a melting pot. Last Tuesday it was so cold that New York was a Slurpee machine. Or maybe it was a tossed salad, given the disparate events that drew highly specific young people to big parties on the Upper East and Lower East Sides.

title: 6 Girls Charged in Beating Of Counselor at Their School
description: A counselor at a Westchester school for troubled students was in critical condition yesterday after being beaten and burned by as many as eight girls, who also poured bleach on her face, the police said. Six of the girls have been arrested and charged with attempted murder.

title: Where the Dogs Are: The Favorite ZIP Codes
description: The census gathers lots of information, but it has no check box for dogs. So their owners have marked their turf with homespun theories about where the most dogs reside.

title: Czech Composer, American Hero
description: IN 1991, the New York City Council was petitioned by Beth Israel Hospital to permit the demolition of a small row house at 327 East 17th Street, once the home of Antonin Dvorak. The hospital wanted to create an AIDS hospice with financing from a foundation established by the photographer Robert Mapplethorpe.

title: L.I. @ WORK
description: Nastech to Develop Spray For Sexual Dysfunction

title: Lay to invoke Fifth Amendment at Senate Hearing
description: WASHINGTON (AP) -- Former Enron chairman Kenneth Lay, scheduled to testify under subpoena before Congress on Tuesday, will assert his right against self-incrimination and refuse to answer questions, his spokeswoman said Sunday night.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some regional copies last Sunday about the creation of luxury housing in Chicago referred incorrectly to a consultant who discussed the strength of the city's downtown market. The consultant, Tracy Cross, is a man.

title: His Loss, The State's Gain
description: SITTING at his desk and looking out onto Military Park and the surrounding buildings, Richard D. Pompelio sees crime victims who need help.

title: The (Very) Opposite Sex
description: Male Lawyer Seeks Female Lawyer

title: No Strangers to Sweat
description: For many executive women, the climb up the corporate ladder began with a well-worn pair of sneakers.

title: Barnaby, the Enforcer, Appears in a New Role
description: In parts of two seasons with Tampa Bay, Matthew Barnaby was used solely as an enforcer. Barnaby, who had enjoyed some offensive success in Buffalo and in Pittsburgh, felt he was miscast with the Lightning.

title: Stacy Johnson, Peter Viles
description: Stacy Janine Johnson, a clothing designer, and Peter Campbell Viles, a cable news reporter, were married on Wednesday in Honolulu. The Rev. Wendell P. K. Silva, a nondenominational minister, officiated at Diamond Head Plantation.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KROUWER, HENRI
description: KROUWER-Henri. Missing and loving you always. Nadia

title: In Bombay, Public Indignity Is Poverty's Partner
description: To be poor and female on the streets of India's largest city is to exact a punishing daily self-discipline: to relieve yourself only before sunrise and after sunset.

title: Those Uncertain Air Connections
description: ONE benefit of the decline in air travel since Sept. 11 has been an improvement in the airlines' on-time performance. The most recent report issued by the Department of Transportation showed the 11 largest United States carriers had an 84.7 percent on-time arrival rate last November, compared with 72.8 percent a year earlier. But all it takes is one bad experience to reveal that customer service problems still exist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, JOSEPH
description: GOLDBERG-Joseph. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun mourns the passing of the beloved father of our devoted member Steven Goldberg. We extend our condolences to the entire bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Rabbi Joshua Lookstein Chaim Edelstein, President

title: Count Them: Children With Chores; A Task Gives Siblings Time to Spend Together
description: To the Editor:

title: Western Culture and The Arab World
description: To the Editor:

title: How Will Washington Read the Signs?; Greater Authority for the S.E.C.
description: The S.E.C. will be the locus of many changes, starting with the choice of four new commissioners to join the chairman, Mr. Pitt. The new political climate has significantly widened their agenda.

title: Personal Business; Blowing the Whistle: Not for the Fainthearted
description: THE became an overnight icon of workplace integrity, celebrated as a corporate insider who had the courage to confront her boss about possible wrongdoing in high places. For warning Enron's chief executive last summer that the energy company could ''implode in a wave of accounting scandals,'' Sherron S. Watkins has been called a fearless upholder of business ethics.

title: The Nation: Second Opinion; The Painful Fact of Medical Uncertainty
description: OVER the past century medicine has wrought so many miracles that progress has come to seem inexorable. A discovery is made, a cure is found. Next, please.

title: Chechen Civilians Are Casualties of Random Acts of War
description: The shell that shattered the lives of the Yedelov family was anonymous. It could have been fired by the Russian military or it might have come from the Chechen rebels.

title: Young Protesters Think Globally and Act Locally to Save a Garden
description: Saving the Cabo Rojo community garden hardly seems a global issue. But that did not stop dreadlocked young protesters, in town for the World Economic Forum, from sleeping in the garden's makeshift shack for the last few weeks, listening to Haitian music, roasting garlic and cooking vegan meals.

title: For Feud Over a Superintendent, 2 Years and Counting
description: One of the longest-running feuds in the city school system is taking place in western Queens, where a battle between the chancellor and the board has been raging for more than two years. At the heart of the feud is Joseph Quinn, the district superintendent, who was appointed to the job in 1990.

title: NO STIMULUS
description: Unable to break a partisan standoff, the Senate abandoned its effort to do something for the economy. Republicans said the Democratic emphasis on helping the unemployed would do nothing to create jobs, and Democrats said Republican plans for more tax cuts were too expensive and would help those who need it least. They managed to pass one provision, a 13-week extension of unemployment benefits beyond the 26-week limit. Richard W. Stevenson

title: A Pair of Pinot Blancs With Verve
description: Lieb Family Cellars has just released two pinot blancs: a sparkling and a still wine. They present consumers with a win-win opportunity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEILER, ABE
description: WEILER-Abe. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Abe Weiler, associated with The Times from 1927 until retiring in 1979.

title: Driving The Company Car
description: Andy Houston would rather have been racing. The gigantic traveling circus that is Nascar had rolled into Lowe's Motor Speedway, 167,000 seats set around a mile-and-a-half track just outside Charlotte, N.C. Under a blue sky, crews were pushing the cars onto pit row and drivers were taking them out on the track, the dozens of revving engines creating a frightening din. But Houston, a 31-year-old driver who has been racing stock cars since he was a teenager, wasn't behind the wheel that afternoon. While the other drivers took their practice laps, he was stuck in an elegantly outfitted 18-wheeler parked on the speedway's infield. There, in a small, windowless sitting room, Houston was getting an education in analgesics.

title: Planning a Place to Raise a Glass To the 6 Train as It Roars By
description: If passengers riding the No. 6 train uptown on Tuesday afternoon had peered out the window between Union Square and 23rd Street, they might have glimpsed what looked like two marooned sailors from ''The Odyssey,'' stranded in a nether world between the brightly lighted stations that punctuate the subway's known domain.

title: UConn Is Game, but St. John's Prevails at Its Playground
description: The tangled thicket of arms and elbows around the rim after every missed shot, the arguments after nearly every official's call, the missed foul shots. They should have played this one at the storied fenced-in court on West Fourth Street. Instead, a sold-out crowd at Madison Square Garden witnessed a spirited playground game otherwise known as St. John's versus Connecticut.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, JEANNE CRAIG
description: DAVIS-Jeanne Craig, 68. Of Salt Point, New York formerly of Brookville, Long Island. Died Friday, February 8, 2002 at St. Francis Hospital in Poughkeepsie, New York. Mrs. Davis was born January 21, 1933 in New York City. She was known for breeding horses. Mrs. Davis is survived by her husband Lawrence L. Davis at home, 2 daughters; Lessley Davis Burke, and Adrienne Lindsley Davis both of Ridgefield, CT. and a granddaughter Lindsley Alice Burke also of Ridgefield, CT. A memorial service will be held 11 AM Tuesday at St. Johns Episcopal Church, Cold Spring Harbor, New York.

title: Corrections
description: The L.I.@Work column last Sunday, about a company that has contracted to sell the rights to Russian-made vaccines, misspelled the surname of a lawyer who cautioned about the regulatory obstacles to the use of such vaccines in the United States. He is Raymond S. Fersko, not Firko.

title: Davis Cup Player Credits Ashe's Influence
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 9 — As a former Harvard student and the only African-American in the top 100 on the men's pro tour, James Blake pulls double duty as a standout.

title: Reverse Commuters Face a Long, Hard Ride
description: MOST weekday mornings, Piers McMahon takes the Long Island Rail Road's 7:39 train from Pennsylvania Station, laptop and bicycle by his side, to his job as a product manager at Computer Associates in Islandia.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: February 10, 2002
description: Weeks

title: A Real City Bird: Cathedral's Peacock Is Treated for Malaise
description: For the past 18 years, a pair of unnamed peacocks have strolled the 13-acre grounds of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, near Columbia University. Each spring, the ornamental birds strut and fan their blue-green tail feathers, wooing pigeons and crowds of onlookers. Each autumn, their feathers fall out. Children at the cathedral school collect the feathers, and church legend says the black circle on each feather tip symbolizes the ever-watchful eye of God.

title: In Pakistan, New Talk Of Indian Role In Kidnapping
description: As authorities here search for a British-born Pakistani militant suspected of kidnapping an American journalist, Pakistani officials -- including President Pervez Musharraf himself -- are raising the possibility that he acted with the help of Indian intelligence agencies.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Seeking to Reclaim the Land of Former Duck Farms
description: NOT long ago on the menus of the nation's upscale restaurants, ''Long Island'' and ''duckling'' had the same sort of heft as ''Dover'' and ''sole.'' Sprawling farms in eastern Suffolk were devoted to raising Pekin ducks, and a store in the form of the bird -- the Big Duck -- became a well-loved landmark.

title: Traa's Gold Is No Shock, But Bahrke's Silver Is
description: In her fourth try at the Olympic Winter Games, Norway's Kari Traa finally won the gold medal in women's moguls, jumping higher, twisting in the air more nimbly and skiing with more precision in a performance that dominated today's field. For her next trick, minutes after accepting a congratulatory bouquet of flowers, Traa had the Norwegian team's press attach, 6-foot-3 Lars Otto Bjoernland, hop on her back so she could carry him down the mountain in a dash to the lodge.

title: A Risky Message To Iran
description: Iran's recent promotion from a rogue state to a member of the ''axis of evil'' appears to be a belated rhetorical response to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's portrayal of the United States as the Great Satan. Demonizing Iran may play well with the American audience, but it has already caused discomfort among America's European allies. Actual military action against Iran would be disastrous. But after the United States' success in Afghanistan, there may well be willingness in certain quarters within the Bush administration to entertain that idea, given its statements that Iran supports terrorism and wants to develop weapons of mass destruction.

title: Corrections
description: A review of ''John Maynard Keynes. Volume Three: Fighting for Freedom, 1937-1946'' on Jan. 20 dated the Bretton Woods conference on international finance incorrectly. It was in 1944, not 1946, and Keynes's death in 1946 followed by four months the ratification of the conference's agreements, not the conference itself.

title: Anza-Borrego: Visitor Information
description: The spring wildflower bloom usually peaks between late February and April, with cactuses and some trees and shrubs flowering into early summer. Information: (760) 767-4684.

title: Vigilante Vengeance, Hollywood's Response To Primal Fantasies
description: THE Arnold Schwarzenegger revenge picture ''Collateral Damage,'' which opened on Friday, had its original release date in November postponed when Warner Brothers executives speculated that the sight of the hero's wife and young son being blown up by terrorists would be in poor taste.

title: At the Bodega, Antibiotics With No Prescription Needed
description: Sitting in her West 135th Street apartment, Marina Aguilera held a cup of hot tea in one hand and a small blue and red packet of tablets in the other. She calls the tablets ''la combinacin,'' and she takes them for just about everything.

title: Editorial Observer; Still a Mystery: Nazi Germany's Atomic Bomb Failure
description: A small trove of documents released last week throws cold water on the notion that high-minded German scientists tried to slow work on an atomic bomb for the Nazi regime during World War II. But the documents provide no definitive answer to the question of why German physicists, who were among the best in the world, made so little progress on an atomic weapon compared with their counterparts in the United States.

title: Terrier Seen as Westminster Favorite
description: Of the 2,568 dogs in the storied Westminster Kennel Club show tomorrow and Tuesday in Madison Square Garden, the favorite to win best-in-show is a 5 1/2-year-old Kerry Blue terrier named Ch. Torum's Scarf Michael and known as Mick.

title: A Sound-Alike
description: To the Editor:

title: How Will Washington Read the Signs?; Revived Debate on Stock Options
description: Five years ago, Senators Carl Levin and John McCain offered a bill that would have forced companies to count stock options as an expense against profits. Business lobbyists fought the idea vigorously, and it died quickly. Last week, the senators said they would introduce nearly the same bill.

title: Sculpture With African Influences
description: THE Tomasulo Gallery at Union County College is showing ''Down to the Bone: Sculpture by Bisa Washington,'' a tantalizing exhibition of the work of Ms. Washington, a sculptor who lives in Morristown and works with unorthodox materials.

title: COMING UP
description: The trial of the former Yugoslavian president, Slobodan Milosevic, begins before the international war crimes tribunal on Tuesday. Gen. Pervez Musharaff, the Pakistani president, arrives in Washington on Tuesday. President Bush leaves for Asia on Saturday. Enron hearings continue, with testimony by Kenneth L. Lay expected. Academy Award nominations will be announced on Tuesday.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Jan. 20 with an article about the rise of Hispanic politicians to positions of influence misstated the birthplace of Representative Robert Menendez. He was born in New York City; his parents were born in Cuba and immigrated.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief report in the Private Sector column last Sunday about EchoStar Communications' proposed takeover of Hughes Electronics referred incompletely to the opinion of Gene Kimmelman, co-director of Consumers Union. Mr. Kimmelman, a high school classmate of EchoStar's chief executive, said he would support the deal if antitrust problems were addressed; he did not say he would support it as currently proposed.

title: Enron Fall Creates Race to Regulate
description: For more than 20 years, the federal government has given companies increasingly free rein. Enron's downfall may well halt that trend. As Congressional hearings unfolded last week, policy makers were lining up to fix American business. New safeguards for 401(k)'s, new oversight for accountants, greater authority for securities regulators and new restrictions on stock analysts are all under consideration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LISS, SALLY
description: LISS-Sally, 88. Of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., formerly of Long Beach, N.Y. Died February 6. Loving wife of the late Harry Liss, beloved mother of Arthur, Michael and his wife Karin. Adored grandmother of Meredith, Andrea and her husband Chris. Graveside service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUCHS, STELLA (WEINREB)
description: FUCHS-Stella (Weinreb), 80. Died on February 5th, 2002 at Sarasota Memorial Hospital. Formerly of Miami Beach, FL and Forest Hills, New York. Beloved wife of the late Eugene Fuchs. Mother of Vivian (Vicki) Fuchs of Centerville, MA, & Monica Kramer & her husband Barry of Sarasota, FL. Loving grandmother of Michael and Ariel Caplan of Sarasota, FL. Sister of Gertrude Herz of Alberquerque, NM. Aunt of Cary Herz of Alberquerque, N.M. Funeral was held on Friday, February 8th at Mount Hebron Cemetery. Expressions of sympathy for Stella may be made to Jewish Family Services. She will be missed.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Monsey; Low Inventory, Lots of Kugel, Some Deer
description: IT has been just four weeks since Chana Rabinowitz; her husband, Arie, an investment banker at L. H. Financial in Manhattan; and their three children moved from Flatbush, Brooklyn, to the hilly Rockland County hamlet of Monsey and already they feel quite comfortable here.

title: How Will Washington Read the Signs?; Regulation of Derivatives
description: After Long-Term Capital Management imploded in 1998, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission quickly called for the regulation of over-the-counter derivatives markets. In the end, Congress decided to take only minimal action. Did that help limit the damage from Enron's fall, or did it make it worse?

title: WHAT $750 MILLION?
description: In terms of total losses, Enron is going to be hard to beat. But on a per capita basis, a currency trader for a Maryland regional bank has done well. John M. Rusnak, right, lost $750 million trading at Allfirst Financial, which he concealed until just a few weeks ago from Allfirst and its parent, Allied Irish Banks of Dublin. It was a catastrophic breakdown of internal controls, even if the banks claim Mr. Rusnak fooled them with fictitious trades. Loopholes for such cheating were supposed to be closed after Nicholas W. Leeson brought down Barings, the British investment bank, in 1995 with $1 billion in losses on unauthorized derivatives trades. Jonathan Fuerbringer

title: Janice Lieberman and Steve Gerber
description: YEARS before Steve Gerber met Janice Lieberman, his father had already picked her out as a fitting prospect for his very exacting son.

title: Corrections
description: A profile on Jan. 27 about the singer Alicia Keys, who is nominated for six Grammy Awards including best new artist, misstated the given name of her mother. She is Terri Augello, not Nikki.

title: Habitats/Chelsea; Living White and White
description: WALKING into Judi Longo's apartment in Chelsea is like sinking into a cloud, all soft and white and light. Candles line the window sills and sit on the kitchen counter. Every piece of furniture is white; even the roses in the living room are white. It hasn't been delivered yet, but soon a white sofa will take its place in the living room.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENSPIRE, ISIDORE (IZZY)
description: ROSENSPIRE-Isidore (Izzy). Born April 30, 1922, died February 8, 2002, after a long illness. Beloved son of the late Harry and Frieda Rosenspire. Adored husband of Eda (Fanrove) for 54 years. Father of Allen, Richard and Wendy. Grandfather of Joshua, David, Matthew and Haley. Special father-in-law to Karen and Helen. Brother of Pearl and Jack Commike and uncle, great-uncle and great-great-uncle of the Commike clan. Special friend of Joe and Joan Belilos, the poker group, the old Bronx house bunch and all those who knew him. Life member of Local No. 3 I.B.E.W., served in the U.S. Navy 1942-46, Chief Petty Officer in Ship Repair Unit, San Diego, CA. Memorial service will be announced. Good night, good night.

title: Long-Stem Moments: He's Seen Them All
description: MY father and uncles were all florists. When I was 21, my dad bought a florist shop on the East Side of Manhattan and told me: ''Here's a store. Go run it.''

title: The Nation; Where the Minorities Rule
description: FOR more than two decades, a mural on the wall of a public housing project in East Los Angeles has been exhorting the neighborhood's mostly Mexican-American residents to stop thinking of themselves as members of a minority group. ''We are NOT a minority!'' the image of a finger-wagging revolutionary declares.

title: More Departures From Fidelity
description: Fidelity Investments, the nation's biggest mutual fund company, has lost six fund managers so far this year.

title: 'Oldish' and Vital, Bea Arthur Returns To Live Theater
description: BEA ARTHUR looked a little tired as she opened the door of her Manhattan hotel suite. She was barefoot, wearing black sweats and no makeup, coughing a little from a cold she was getting over. It was the end of the day, she had just returned from rehearsal, and the trip had not gone smoothly. Although she was born in New York and has lived in the city as an adult, she had forgotten how hard it can be to get a taxi right after the 4 p.m. shift change.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUTSKY, MAX
description: RUTSKY-Max. Beloved husband of Rhoda. Devoted father of Gerald (Monica) and Alan. Cherished grandfather of Justin and Elijah. Dear brother of Hyman. Funeral services today 12:15 at ''Sinai Chapels'', 16205 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLASS, WILLIAM
description: KLASS-William. On February 6, 2002. Beloved husband of the late Anne. Cherished father of Rochelle, Sheila and Philip. Devoted father-in-law of Earl and Patricia. Loving grandfather of Shoshie, Tamar, Micah, Aaron and Ben. You will always be in our hearts. Services Sunday, 1 PM at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to The Jewish National Fund.

title: Batteries Included
description: REID GOLDSMITH, a 47-year-old court reporter who lives in Syosset and works in Queens, used to start his day by watching commuters off the night shift wade bleary-eyed from the Hicksville train station platform to their parked cars. Before long, Mr. Goldsmith learned to identify the cars so he could position his station car, a gas-guzzling former police cruiser he bought at auction, to swoop into one of their spots and begin his train ride to Jamaica.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEARER, HARTLEY PARKER
description: SHEARER-Hartley Parker. On February 7, 2002, at age 57 in Williamstown, MA. Born in New York City and a longtime resident there, he leaves his loving wife of 35 years, Linda and his devoted son, Ivor. Earning his living as a landlord he dedicated his life to art and public service, and changed the lives of countless students, friends and strangers in unexpected ways. He attended Middlebury College and earned a BFA from NYU in 1968. He had been a part-time lecturer in art at Williams College since 1991 and was pursuing a MSW at SUNY-Albany when he suffered a stroke in 1999. The last three years were filled with challenges and struggles which even he could not overcome. He will be greatly missed by his family and many friends. A memorial gathering will take place on Saturday, February 16. Please call 413597-2318 for time and location. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Berkshire Farm Center and Services for Youth in Canaan, NY.

title: How Will Washington Read the Signs?
description: Let the reforms begin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, JERRY LEE
description: MARCUS-Jerry Lee. On February 7, 2002. Beloved husband of Wendy. Loving son of Dorothy. Devoted father of Judith, Susan Halperin, Leslie and Jeff. Dear brother of Irene Salzberg and Ira. Brother-in-law of Regina. Cherished grandfather of Lindsey and Chelsea Halperin, Jesse Marcus. Services private.

title: Grinding Down a Gruenfeld In a Long-Awaited Victory
description: Yevgeny Bareyev, 35, a Russian grandmaster, said: ''It's huge. The best result of my career,'' when asked about his winning the Corus International Tournament in Wijk-aan-Zee, the Netherlands, Jan. 11 to 27. For reasons that are not clear, Bareyev has missed out on invitations to the best tourneys for more than a decade, but now he showed what he can do.

title: For Teams, It's Survival of the Fittest. For Fans, Check Your Scorecards.
description: Twelve years ago yesterday, Bud Selig stood at a microphone at a hotel in a Chicago suburb and proclaimed, ''On Feb. 16, if there is no agreement, camps won't be opened.''

title: High Up in Nevis
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''A Resort Where Service Is Serious'' (Dec. 23), by Anita Gates: We stay at the historic and comfortable Golden Rock Estate, which, like some other Nevis hotels that were once sugar plantations, is sensibly built high in the cool, mosquito-free hills.

title: How Will Washington Read the Signs?; Review of Bankruptcy Changes
description: There is at least one piece of legislation that Enron's move into bankruptcy protection will stall, not accelerate: the bankruptcy reform bill that passed both houses of Congress last March.

title: A Security Agency With More Muscle
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Scrutiny of Somalia as the Old Anarchy Reigns
description: Aghanistan may have been a failed state, but it was a state that Somalis could gaze upon with envy.

title: Center Helps Patients With Water Therapy
description: THE slender young woman, her head supported by a white flotation collar around her neck, lay on her back in the pool, her long hair streaming behind her as she was pulled by her legs. She moved her arms slowly down to her side at the instructor's command. The movement did not come easily.

title: On Her Radar
description: THE CLOUDS ABOVE

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE NAME JAR

title: Faraway Places
description: LIMBO, AND OTHER PLACES

title: Danger: Romantic Love
description: Why is it so hard to commit to someone or to get someone to commit to you or, for that matter, to stay in a committed relationship? Advice to the lovelorn may seem like a frivolous subject for this book review, but consider all the brow-furrowing books that ponder these questions. Public policy analysts fret about declining marriage rates. Evolutionary psychologists posit genetic motives for philandering. Biologists, historians, economists and anthropologists -- they all have their big theses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELIN, LAZARE
description: GELIN-Lazare. February 7, 2002. Born 1903, in Lithuania. Survived by his wife Irene Slosbergs. His first wife Dorothy Bresler predeceased him. Also survived by his children Jacques B. and Margaret (Littwitz), of Rockville, MD, and Lia G. and William J. Poorvu, of Cambridge, MA; seven grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. Services private.

title: How Should U.S. Answer Hate?

title: ENRON'S MANY STRANDS: The Company Unravels; Enron Buffed Image to a Shine Even as It Rotted From Within

Before him, bright light from the ballroom's chandeliers spilled across scores of round tables where executives from the Enron Corporation waited to hear the words of Mr. Lay, their longtime chairman and chief executive.

title: A Media Event
description: More than 200 newspaper front pages, photographs, letters, reward posters and other items generated by John Wilkes Booth's crime, the trial of his eight accomplices, and their subsequent hangings are reproduced in LINCOLN'S ASSASSINS: THEIR TRIAL AND EXECUTION (Arena Editions, $45). Readers unfamiliar with the conspirators (celebrities of their day who long ago entered obscurity) will have to look elsewhere for background information. This fascinating book evokes the cultural climate -- the feverish idiom of the editorialists, the scramble among the fashionable for courtroom tickets -- that defined what the editors, James L. Swanson and Daniel R. Weinberg, suggest was a thoroughly commercialized and media-driven series of events. As Swanson and Weinberg make clear, it was all quintessentially American. People purchased the trial transcripts rushed into print by ambitious publishers, ordered commemorative trinkets by mail, hung paper flags and collected cards memorializing the slain president. Most notably, ''Lincoln's Assassins'' reproduces Alexander Gardner's striking photographs of the incarcerated defendants, which convey a sense of almost surreal immediacy. In the roll of a young conspirator's soiled lapel, or in his matted hair and perturbed brow, we see hints of how the assassination and its aftermath were lived by its participants, behind the screen of sensationalism. For a reader looking at the tense, shackled bodies of those who had trapped themselves at the core of a pivotal event, there's a sense of mundane moments that add up to history. Andrey Slivka

This carnival look began with the first Easter Sunday be-in, in 1967 in the Sheep Meadow. title: 'A Life of Sir Francis Galton'
description: Francis Galton invented pedigree analysis to measure the heritability of human "talent and character." This technique caught the imagination of eugenicists in the early twentieth century and is a fundamental tool of modern human genetics. One reason Galton set such store by this method was his own sterling pedigree (Table 1-1). His ancestors, the scientific and medically inclined Darwins, and the Galtons, a family of wealthy Quaker merchants, both hailed from the environs of Birmingham. Galton's cousin Charles Darwin inspired his investigations in human heredity while his father, Samuel Tertius Galton, endowed him with a substantial inheritance. This permitted him to roam without financial constraint through his various scientific pursuits. His father may also have sparked his lifelong interest in numbers and quantification. Francis Galton indeed had an enviable pedigree, so to understand the man one must know something of his family and especially his maternal grandfather Dr. Erasmus Darwin, the common familial link between Galton and Charles Darwin (Fig. 1-1).

title: UNRAVELING ENRON

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, EMIL
description: COHEN-Emil. Died February 12, 2000 at age 88. With apologies to those who were unaware of his death two years ago in Lake Worth, Florida, we honor his memory and the way he celebrated life bringing mirth and good will to countless friends and audiences. As an entertainer in a golden era of Catskill Mountain performers he developed a special blend of home-spun stories topped off with the punch line in Yiddish. It helped, but you didn't have to be Jewish to get it. As the laughter was at its crest he would follow up with an English translation, but such was his delivery that even the occasional gentile couple from the farm belt could swear they got it the first time around. Because he appeared before hundreds of thousands of people in a career that spanned half a century, he was billed as America's Foremost American Jewish Humorist. Born in Elizabeth, New Jersey in 1911 the son of Julius and Ida (Magidoff), he was raised in Wilmington, Delaware in a family that included his sister Rose (who survives) and his brothers Hym and Phil. After serving in the United States Air Force during World War II, he joined the staff at the Grossinger Pancoast Hotel in Florida where he honed his skills as a professional comedian. There, Paul Grossinger introduced him to Lillian Rothman. Elaine Grossinger Etess recalls that after what seemed (to Paul) an appropriate length of time, he asked Emil, ''And what are your intentions with Lillian?'' ''Honorable.'' They were married in 1950, and, as Emil was fond of saying, they soon produced two sons: ''One a doctor, the other a lawyer. The doctor is 6 and the lawyer is 3.'' This proved prescient. The older son, Jay, did become a doctor and the younger, David, a lawyer. His relationship with the Grossinger Hotel was felicitous. He and his family would stay at the resort, where he entertained at poolside. The guests were in Catskill heaven. Mornings with Lou Goldstein at Simon Sez, afternoons at the pool with Emil Cohen, evenings at the playhouse to see the likes of Milton Berle, Eddie Fisher, Zero Mostel, Joey Bishop, Alan King, Buddy Hackett. What could be better? The borscht was plentiful as Emil and the guests enjoyed a society of mutual admiration. He would criss-cross the country, with club dates from Seattle to Miami, from Portland to LA. But in summer, he would always come back to Grossingers' poolside, as if to recharge his batteries with love from his adoring family-not to mention the gefiltefish and nova and the brisket done just right. He lived to make people laugh. When he was not performing live, he made recordings, one of which (T'synagogues and T'centers) revealed where he spent a good deal of his time. He was, perhaps, best known for his hilarious translation of Lincoln's Gettysburg Address into Yiddish, and his accounts of his Southern Bubbie who could speak no English. With his sweet tenor voice (for which he would credit his father, a cantor), Emil would move audiences with nostalgic renditions of traditional Yiddish tunes. Over the course of his career he raised tens of millions of dollars for UJA and Israel Bonds. Emil worked until about a year before his death. Even at 87, he made the rounds. But instead of flying to Montreal for a club date, he'd enliven a group of senior citizens at a nearby center. Never crude or the least bit off-color, his humor was gentle. As he grew older, he spent a great deal of time with his grandchildren (Jay's children Samantha, Zachary, and Joelle; David's children Alexandra, Danielle, and Scott). He taught them kindness and generosity, not by preaching it but by example. They loved him for it. He spoke ill of no one and never uttered an unkind thought. Perhaps because he never harbored one. Messages may be sent to David Cohen, C/O Iridian Asset Mgt., 276 Post Road West, Westport, CT 06880.

title: HEISENBERG BOMBSHELL

The case remains open: some suggest Bohr misunderstood Heisenberg's mission. James Glanz

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAWRENCE, RICHARD W., JR.
description: LAWRENCE-Richard W., Jr. Elizabethtown, NY. 93, died on Wednesday, February 6, at the Elizabethtown Community Hospital. He was born January 16, 1909, in the Bronx, son of Richard W. Lawrence and Ruth Earle. He was a graduate of the Riverdale School, Princeton University and Columbia Law School. In 1933, he married Marjorie Fitch. She predeceased him in 1945. He served in the Army Air Corps from 1942-45 and retired from the Air Force Reserve as Lt. Col. in 1969. He practiced law in New York City and was the former Chairman of Printers Ink Publishing and Bankers Commercial Corp. In 1947, he moved with his second wife, Elizabeth Hand Wadhams, to the Adirondacks. His interest in education led him to serve on the Elizabethtown-Lewis School Board, as Chairman of the College Council of SUNY Plattsburgh, as founder of the Council of Councils of NY State Universities and as past Chairman of North Country Community College. He served as President of the Crary Foundation in Elizabethtown from 1973 until his retirement in 2000. This organization, which he helped found, provides scholarships for Adirondack students to pursue higher education. He served as a Trustee of the Elizbethtown Library and was founder of the State's first multicounty library association, the Clinton-Essex-Franklin system. He was founder of the Essex County Historical Society and served for many years as a Trustee of the New York State Historical Association. His interest in the environment and conservation led to his appointment by Governor Rockefeller, in 1971, as first Chairman of the Adirondack Park Agency. He stepped down from the position in 1975, but continued for many years to serve on the Boards of the Association for the Protection of the Adirondacks, the Adirondack Council, the New York Parks and Conservation Association and the Adirondack Nature Conservancy. He received an award from the NY-Vermont Interstate Commission on Lake Champlain, the Velma Moore Award from the NY State Library Assocation, a North Country citation from St. Lawrence University, a conservation award from the Garden Club of America, a distinguished service award from Potsdam College and the Founder's Award from the Adirondack Museum at Blue Mountain Lake. He was a member of the Princeton Club, the Union League Club, the Explorers Club and the AMR/Ausable Club. In addition to his wife Marjorie, he was predeceased by his sister Ruth L. Wittmer in 1965, his wife Elizabeth Hand Wadhams in 1987 and his daughter Ruth L. Wilson in 1991. He is survived by his daughters Alida L. Currey of Grand Junction, CO, and Elizabeth W. Lawrence of Elizabethtown, NY; granddaughters Lynn Chernushin and her children Cole and Marina of Arvada, CO, and Anne L. Wilson, her husband Peter Q. Lawson and their son Bates of Moab, UT. He was a man of humor and intellect who had a visionary and stubborn dedication to the creation of educational opportunities and the protection of the environment. A memorial service will be held on Friday, February 15, at 10:30 AM at the United Church of Christ in Elizabethtown. His family requests that memorial donations be made to the Essex County Historical Society, Elizabethtown; the Resident's Committee to Protect the Adirondacks, North Creek; or the Boquet River Association, Elizabethtown.

title: IMMIGRATION HIGH

They make up 20 percent of the population -- less than the 1910 peak of 35 percent. Janny Scott

title: A Courtyard at the Heart of the Story

The story was always spatial, however. In its antique origins, the story was about the land. With the Greeks, architecture narrates the history of the sacred site it occupies. With the Romans, the building becomes the sacred site. It is autobiographical, self-reflexive, postmodern. It narrates itself.

title: Keeping Watch
description: On Sept. 11 and the days after, crowds were drawn to the view of the altered Manhattan skyline from the Eagle Rock Reservation in West Orange. Now a memorial statue is to be erected at the overlook. Joseph DiVincenzo, the Essex County freeholder president, initiated the idea and he has commissioned a sculptor, Patrick Morelli of Cedar Grove, who designed a memorial to Martin Luther King Jr. in Atlanta, to design and build the monument that will be dedicated on Sept. 11 of this year. The memorial will depict a girl clutching a teddy bear staring at an open book inscribed with the names of the New Jersey residents who died in the attacks. Behind the book will be a bald eagle with an eight-foot wingspan perched atop a tree. A teenage boy holding a lantern and facing New York will be stationed next to the book. The estimated $250,000 cost will be covered by corporate donations and individual contributions. John Holl

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOMOTO, KANEJI (KAN)
description: DOMOTO-Kaneji (Kan). Architect and landscape architect of New Rochelle, NY died Jan. 27, 2002. Born in Oakland, California on November 5, 1912, he attended Stanford University, UC Berkeley, and studied with Frank Lloyd Wright. Domoto was interned with his wife Sally Fujii at Amache, Colorado during World War II after which they moved to New York and raised four children. Kan's career in architecture and landscape design spanned over 50 years, and included both residential and commercial projects. He received many awards for his JapaneseAmerican gardens including the Frederick Law Olmsted Award for his Jackson Park design. His first wife died in 1978, and in 1992 he married Sylvia Schur, who survives him. In addition to his 4 children, he leaves 3 stepchildren, six grandchildren, one great granddaughter, two sisters, and numerous nieces and nephews. A memorial service was held on January 29th. Donations in his memory may be made to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation.

title: CHAOS IN LAGOS
description: Ethnic clashes resulting in more than 100 deaths widened the chaos in Lagos, where more than 1,000 civilians were believed to have been killed after an explosion at an ammunitions depot a week earlier. President Olusegun Obasanjo deployed soldiers to try to control the fighting between the Yoruba and Hausa in two neighborhoods in the city. The riots followed months of spreading anarchy in Nigeria, Africa's most populous nation, and Mr. Obasanjo warned that the country's three-year-old democracy was at risk. Elections are scheduled to take place next year, but many Nigerians have expressed disillusionment with what is widely regarded as an ineffective government and are calling for a return to military rule. Norimitsu Onishi

title: TEENAGE BIRTH RATES
description: New Jersey ranked third lowest in the nation in the rate of births to teenage mothers in 1999, according to a survey released last week. The Kids Count survey, released by the Annie E. title: George Divoky's Planet
description: What I find even more disturbing than George Divoky's unequivocal evidence of catastrophic global warming (Darcy Frey, Jan. 6) is the overwhelmingly misdirected sentiment voiced by readers in the letters columns of Jan. 20 and 27. Given the scope of what Divoky's field research is proving, it is nothing short of a trivialization of this evidence to dwell, almost exclusively, on his personal sacrifice and commitment. It should go without saying that his contribution is extraordinary and that his dogged pursuit of knowledge is heroic. However, I seriously doubt that this is what Divoky envisions as the legacy of his work: a human interest story suitable for a TV talk show. We're in serious trouble. The ramifications of his evidence are unfathomable. What we must do is act, and act now, to reduce the environmental impact we are having on this planet, not to mold Divoky and his message into a story ready-made for a Hollywood treatment.

title: Private Sector; Learning to Time the Market And Then, Who Knows?
description: Ringing the opening bell at the New York Stock Exchange has become one of those larger-than-life events, a moment of media attention akin to christening a ship. And the list of those eligible to perform the honor no longer includes just the usual titans of finance or founders of newly listed companies. These days, it includes heads of state, Hollywood celebrities, fashion models -- even a chimpanzee, when E*Trade was listed last year. But the bell ringers have always shared one trait: they were, well, alive. So history will be made again this Thursday when Asimo, the humanoid robot from Honda, whirs onto the balcony overlooking the trading floor, puts a mechanical finger on the bell switch and signals the start of another day.

title: QUICK BITE/Kearny; The Young and the Deep-Fried
description: I don't like being shown up by a 3-year-old. But I must admit that my friend's son Donovan had the upper hand during our recent lunch at the Argyle Restaurant in Kearny. According to the Argyle's place mat, Kearny is the ''Scottish capital of the United States.'' Could Donovan tell you that? No, he can't read. So I will have to tell you that the walls of the cozy dining room are covered with Scottish artwork: bagpiper portraits, Edinburgh photos, maps and a scenic loch or two. And if for a moment you doubted the Argyle's authenticity: a fellow diner was wearing a kilt. The house specialty is fish and chips ($10.25 in the dining room, $8.22 for takeout). This is where Donovan truly upstaged me: His child's portion was nearly as large, included a small beverage and dessert, and cost a mere $4.50. What a treat that fish was, served piping hot in a crispy, flaky crust. The chips were decent French fries, though I expect chips to be thicker and wrapped in grease-stained newspaper, like in the 1981 Scottish film ''Gregory's Girl.'' Donovan, whose knowledge of cinema goes as far back as ''Toy Story 2,'' couldn't have cared less about the meal. He busied himself with Bob the Builder stickers. After the meal, we exited through the adjoining Piper's Cove Scottish gift shop. I said hello to the clerk, but she was preoccupied with Donovan's antics. ''He's a Power Ranger!'' she said with admiration. Yes, he is. And apparently, I'm the Invisible Man. Jack Silbert

title: The High-Gravity Games
description: There is something so ornate, so ceremonial and institutional, about the staging of the Olympic Games, summer or winter, that it's easy to forget how elemental they really are. Nearly every event is a contest not only against other athletes but also, in some sense, against the physical restraints of life on earth. That fact is most visible in the Summer Olympics, when, as you watch, you can almost feel in your own body the wind resistance, the weight of gravity that afflicts each runner in a field of sprinters. You realize that every athlete is the solution to an equation involving the fundamental physical forces of our planetary existence.

description: BRIMBERG-Harold. Died Feb. 2, 2002 at the age of 98. Beloved husband of the late Frances. Father of Barbara and Toby. Grandfather of Jenifer and Daniel.

title: Hot Tubs Among The Blooms
description: WITH a vision of magenta and golden desert flowers in full bloom, I picked up the phone in frozen mid-February to make late March reservations for a family romp in the warm, dry air of Anza-Borrego Desert State Park. Encompassing diverse desert landscapes, with almost two-thirds of it wilderness, the park stretches south from Riverside County for more than 60 miles to just short of the Mexican border. In the northern half of the park, a two-and-a-half-hour drive northeast of San Diego, where we plucked our son Ben from his drafting table, the unprepossessing town of Borrego Springs offers the only amenities in the area. None of the recommended inns I called could accommodate five of us for a week -- they were already almost solidly booked -- so we split our time among three. And for different reasons, we would happily revisit each.

title: Redfish Survive Their Promotion
description: If fish were philosophers, they would no doubt spend a lot of time pondering what makes a trash fish, or an eating fish, or a game fish. Then, if they were smart, they would do everything within their power to become a trash fish.

title: So Proudly They Hailed, Weeping as They Sang
description: THE late-night talk turned sober at Richter's on Third Avenue near 90th Street, as it tended to do ever since word came that the place was going to be torn down to make room for a luxury high-rise. The whole block of tenements was coming down.

title: Worried About Portfolios But Reluctant to Sell

description: With its bright yellow console and flashing screen, it may look to passers-by like a castoff prop from a science fiction movie.

description: Mrs. Bennet was counting the days until the gala opening of Asprey & Garrard on Main Street, Hampton-by-the-Sea. It wasn't that she herself, however, hungered for fine jewelry. Mrs. Bennet was content with her single strand of classic Tiffany pearls. But she had five daughters with five vacancies for a Harry Winston emerald on their crucial ring fingers.

description: Best Bet

title: Britain's 'Satanic Mills' Now a Valued Heritage
description: WHEN Britons look back on the Industrial Revolution that spread their influence and their empire, they reserve a special place for the textile mill -- the clattering red brick institution that, along with railways and smokestacks, became the emblem of the nation's new and global economic power in the 19th century.

description: After Fordham lost to St. Joseph's by 84-77 yesterday, Fordham Coach Bob Hill borrowed a reporter's pen and did some quick math on scratch paper. By his count, the numbers read 165-69, as in 165 free throws for St. Joseph's to 69 for Fordham in their past four games against each other.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUTLER, MICHAEL
description: CUTLER-Michael. Age 82, died in Sarasota, FL, Saturday, February 9, 2002. Beloved husband for 57 years of Barbara Levine. Adored father of Michael and Andrea, Thomas and Catherine and Jon. Loving grandfather of Eli, David and Nathan. A highly decorated Major in the U.S. Cavalry, President of Frank A. Hall & Sons, Ltd. Services to be announced. Memorial contributions can be made to the charity of your choice or to Planned Parenthood of Southwest, FL, 1958 Prospect St, Sarasota, FL 34239.

title: How Will Washington Read the Signs?; Watching Deregulation
description: Enron's collapse has reignited the debate about how closely Congress and regulators should watch the nation's recently deregulated electricity markets. Though regulators say the markets generally responded well after the collapse, Enron's downfall has prompted calls from many officials, including some staunch deregulation advocates, for more oversight and transparency.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a commission's recommendation that Amtrak be broken up misstated the amount of the subsidy that the railroad intends to request from Congress this year. It is $1.2 billion, not $2.1 billion.

title: How Much for That Thing in the Attic?
description: EVERYONE, even those who do not watch ''Antiques Roadshow'' on Channel 13, probably has an object or artifact that is a family treasure, and along with it the dream that if were ever offered for sale it might be a bonanza. The item could be a Civil War flag, a dining room table or a portrait of an ancestor, something passed down through generations or bought at a yard sale.

title: Russians Lead In the Pairs; Canadians Slip Into Second
description: The Canadians Jamie Sal and David Pelletier were maneuvering beautifully around each potential trapdoor in their short program tonight without a single sweaty palm, only to come undone on a move most prom dates can master.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: THE BEAUTY OF THE HUSBAND: A Fictional Essay in 29 Tangos, by Anne Carson. (Vintage Contemporaries, $12.) This Canadian poet, whose unclassifiable work is steeped in a deep knowledge of Hellenic literature as well as philosophy, fiction and other fields, brings her elusive, free-associative style to bear on the story of a marital breakup and ''the dilemma of desire.'' Last year our reviewer, Daphne Merkin, was struck by Carson's ''refusal to edit out the personal, even at its most pathetically lovelorn,'' and said, ''I don't think there has been a book since Robert Lowell's 'Life Studies' that has advanced the art of poetry quite as radically.''

title: In Skating, Perfection Is in Judge's Eye
description: For about 20 minutes, Michelle Kwan had the ice to herself in an arena empty of fans. She went to work.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the current film ''Scotland, PA.,'' misidentified its source of financing and misstated the affiliation of an executive producer, Karen Lauder. The film was financed by Abandon Pictures; Lot 47 was the distributor. Ms. Lauder is chairman of Abandon Pictures; she is not affiliated with Lot 47.

title: Canada by Train
description: Via Rail, the Canadian national train network, offers full-time students 12 or older fare discounts year-round. Holders of an International Student Identity Card ($16; show a current university ID card or a registrar's letter at any VIA station to apply) receive 35 percent off economy-class fares. Student cardholders get 10 percent off sleeper-class fares and VIA 1 (first class) tickets. The identity card also earns discounts at hotels, restaurants and museums. Information: (888) 842-7245 or www.viarail.ca .

title: Who Stands To Benefit As Military Expands
description: PRESIDENT BUSH'S 2003 budget calls for a $48 billion, or 14 percent, jump in military spending, the biggest increase in two decades. While a sizable chunk is for pay raises, health care and the impact of inflation on programs, weapons procurement would rise 12 percent, reversing a general decline through most of the 1990's.

title: Rafalski's Last Surge of Energy Powers Devils
description: Brian Rafalski checked his internal meter and figured he had just enough energy for one final charge down the ice. Rafalski had missed four Devils games because of a knee injury before Thursday, and two overtime games in less than 48 hours had just about wiped him out.

title: Uncertain Toll in the Fog of War: Civilian Deaths in Afghanistan
description: In an age of eavesdropping warplanes and satellite-guided bombs, the Pentagon finds itself accused of sometimes relying on faulty intelligence in Afghanistan, leading to an unnecessary toll of civilian deaths.

title: Dressing for Success: Try a Beat-Up Pair of High-Tops
description: In the entertainment world these days, the answer to a boy's dreams (not to mention a producer's) would seem to be a little magic. But in Showtime's new film ''The Red Sneakers,'' it doesn't come in the form of a gleaming sorcerer's stone but in that of a beat-up old pair of high-tops. And instead of being delivered by a thunderous Anglo-Saxon fellow with flowing beard, it has sources that are more hip-hop than Hogwarts: a soft-spoken black man who presides over a junk shop in Brooklyn.

title: Even the Front Row Has Its Bad Days
description: TO be honest, I had a bad feeling about the jeans. I kept asking my husband to pull over so I could get a pair of black flat-front Helmut Lang wool pants out of my bag and change.

Visitation Sunday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. at Connell Funeral Home, 934 New York Ave, Huntington. Mass Monday 10 A.M. St. Philip Neri Church, Northport. title: Women at a Royal Court In a Tumultuous Time
description: THE word ''restoration'' implies a return to a previous condition, but when the monarchy in England was restored after the failure of the commonwealth, the country went through important changes, including the flourishing of the arts. For example, for the first time in over 20 years, the theaters were reopened, with women appearing on the stage.

title: Eve Ensler Wants to Save the World
description: The feminist playwright Eve Ensler likes to say that she's a product of the 60's, but as she works the room during a Washington gala benefit for her antiviolence project, she seems much more like a creature of the 90's boom, a high-powered networker. There's something downright Clintonian about her ability to communicate energy and empathy in the time span of a handshake -- as well as her gift for enlisting business and entertainment celebrities to her cause. In fact, the evening's earlier, more exclusive fund-raiser had been held at the home of Beth Dozoretz, an F.O.B. and minor player in Pardongate. In between the two events, Ensler had appeared in a benefit performance of the play that made her famous, ''The Vagina Monologues,'' and now reverent fans are squeezing their way toward her in hopes of a brief audience: a crew-cut young man who says he has seen the light, an activist who's pitching a new shelter for drug-addicted women, a female executive who bonded with her daughter at the show. Ensler listens closely, if briefly, to each one, usually grasping a hand to reinforce the connection.

title: Michael Tilson Thomas: Maverick in a City of Same
description: THIS endlessly charming city, you may recall, did not even register on Saul Steinberg's classic New Yorker cover of 1976, ''A View of the World From Ninth Avenue.'' If blinkered New York music lovers do cast an occasional glance this far west, it is probably directed at the San Francisco Opera, which has attained prominence largely through its presentations of Wagner's ''Ring'' cycle. But oh, yes, isn't there also an orchestra here that plays in a bad hall?

It pours down the mountains and into the sandy washes and canyons. The gorges of these California badlands are flooded with a silence so thick that standing in the midst of it feels like a tactile experience.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Priest Dies During Mass
description: A Roman Catholic priest collapsed, apparently from a heart attack, while saying Mass yesterday at St. Agnes Church and later died, the authorities said. The priest, Anthony Dalla Villa, 62, collapsed on the altar around 12:55 p.m., about a half-hour into the service at the church, at 143 East 43rd Street, the police said. Parishioners called paramedics, and several tried to revive Monsignor Dalla Villa, who was unconscious, they said. The priest, who carried the honorary title of monsignor, was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center and pronounced dead at 1:39 p.m., the police said. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

description: The Labor Department announced yesterday that it was seeking to oust the trustees of Enron's 401(k) plan because it was unhappy with the job the trustees did protecting plan participants as Enron's stock plunged.

title: All Fashion All the Time: It's a Global Show Now
description: In the old days, it would seem, the fashion world functioned like a small village. Everyone knew everyone. People visited one another's houses; traded advice, business news, style tips, lovers, beards; and gossiped about who was headed for Chapter 11, who was pulling another rehab stint at Silver Hill, who was ripping off whose designs.

title: As Fans Show No Love, Bryant Shows No Mercy

Michael Jordan laughed while attempting to show up the young stars who grew up revering him. And the great heavyweight champions Muhammad Ali and Joe Frazier, adversaries in an ugly, deeply personal feud for the past 30 years, sat next to each other in the front row, locking arms as they stood for the pregame singing of ''America the Beautiful.''

title: N.H.L. and Its Teams Send Players to Bench
description: Slovakia and Latvia, whose game would have been dramatic enough in simple terms of athleticism and patriotism, played tonight for the right to compete in the main draw of the men's hockey tournament in the Winter Olympics. But their star players were battling much more powerful opponents: their bosses in the National Hockey League. For them, it is a difficult choice: your country or your employer.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Unlicensed Social Club Shuttered
description: Twenty-one people were arrested yesterday when investigators shut down an unlicensed social club and found drugs and two handguns, the police said. Among those arrested was an off-duty city correction officer, identified as Janette Carter, 40, of West Hempstead, N.Y., the police said. Investigators executed a search warrant at 4 a.m. at the establishment, the Brick House Social Club, in the basement at 198-19 Hollis Avenue in Hollis, and arrested all those inside, the police said. All 21 people have been charged with criminal possession of a weapon and possession of marijuana, they said.

title: Zigzagging Emotions And a Technical Glitch
description: Jacqulyn Buglisi and Donlin Foreman, the artistic directors of Buglisi/Foreman Dance, take care to make the stage look good. Their dancers are polished. The lighting devised for them by Clifton Taylor enhances the choreographic moods. A. Christina Giannini's costumes can range from the simple to the ornate. Yet they are always beautifully designed.

title: Advice to a Superpower
description: ''Methinks I see in my mind a noble and puissant nation rousing herself like a strong man after sleep, and shaking her invincible locks.'' Milton's words perfectly describe America today. After the horror of Sept. 11 the world has seen America gather its strength, summon its allies and proceed to wage war halfway across the globe against its enemy -- and ours.

description: Such a good gimmick. ''The Boom Boom Room in the Go-Go Room,'' they're calling it. Too bad the play that's involved is so unappetizing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOSEE, WILMOT H.
description: LOSEE-Wilmot H. On February 9, 2002, at the age of 89, in Englewood, FL. Devoted father of Wilmot Hurst Losee Jr. and Steven Thomas Losee and father-in-law of Jean Gilpatrick Losee. Adoring grandfather of Elizabeth Losee McGurl, Geoffrey Andrew Losee, James Alden Losee, Stephanie Losee, Sandy Losee-Woods and Sharon Rodriguez. Also survived by nine great-grandchildren. He was predeceased by his wife of 51 years, Virginia See Losee. Born in Brooklyn, NY, on July 14, 1912, he was a proud U.S. Navy veteran of World War II and retired president of Major Market Radio. Burial will be private.

description: Kenneth L. Lay, Enron's former chairman, exercising his right to avoid incriminating himself, has decided not to testify before Congress on Tuesday about the company's collapse, a spokeswoman said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOLZ, HILDA (WEBER)
description: VOLZ-Hilda (Weber). On February 4 at the age of 95. Born in Mannheim, Germany, she immigrated to the U.S. in 1928, becoming a U.S. citizen in 1934. She was the widow of Hermann Volz, who reopened Chase's branches in Germany after the Second World War. Mr. Volz died in 1976. She was a community volunteer throughout her life. After moving from New York to Frankfurt, Germany with her husband in 1948, she became active in fostering German American relations. Later she became a member of the committee that awarded Fulbright scholarships to German graduate students and a Board member of the Steuben Schurz Gesellschaft. Returning to New York in the 1960s, she raised scholarship funds for the exchange of American and German graduate students. She is survived by her daughters, Anita Wien of New York, NY, and Janet Kirwan of Greenwich, CT; two grandchildren, Deborah Wild and Peter Kirwan, Jr., and two great grandchildren. Donations in her memory may be made to the Institute of International Education, Attention Quadrille Fund, Development Office, 809 UN Plaza, New York, NY 10017.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINRIB, NORMA
description: WEINRIB-Norma. On February 9, 2002. Beloved wife of Jerry (Jay), devoted mother of Paulette Mae Cole, Madeline Beth Weinrib and the late Steven Lloyd Weinrib. Cherished grandmother of Lena Pearl and the late Kyle and Jeremy Cole. Mother-in-law of Evan Cole. Loving sister of Gloria and Dan Pilot. Dear aunt of Kenny Pilot. Services Tuesday, 10:30 AM, at Beth El Synagogue of New Rochelle, North Avenue and Northfield Road, New Rochelle, NY.

title: Austrians Assert Downhill Dominance
description: At the world championships a year ago in St. Anton, Austria, the American Daron Rahlves silenced a mountainside of clanging cowbells and cheering hometown fans with a stunning victory over the famed Austrian skiers in the super-G competition. Neither Hermann Maier nor his noted Austrian teammates, Stephan Eberharter and Fritz Strobl, could outrace the risk-taking Rahlves, who for the next 12 months was promoted as the logical American candidate to halt years of Austrian dominance at the Winter Olympics.

description: AS the old French maxim goes, the more Michael Jordan changes, the more he stays the same. More or less.

description: SALT LAKE CITY:  A year ago, at the World Ski Championships in Austria, an American named Daron Rahlves upstaged his hosts to win the opening men's race. On Sunday, in the first race of Ralves's home Olympics, the Austrians returned the favor.

The day sometimes ends in the small hours as well, like 2 a.m., the hour on Saturday that the White House press plane arrived in Idaho Falls after Mr. Bush opened the Winter Olympics on Friday night in Salt Lake City.

title: Robert J. Lamphere, 83, Spy Chaser for the F.B.I., Dies
description: Robert J. Lamphere, an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who supervised the investigations of some of the biggest espionage cases of the cold war, including those of the Rosenbergs, Klaus Fuchs and Kim Philby, died on Jan. 7 in a Tucson hospital. He was 83.

title: In Ohio School Hearing, a New Theory Will Seek a Place Alongside Evolution
description: The latest challenge to evolution's primacy in the nation's classrooms -- the theory of intelligent design, not the old foe creationism -- will get a full-scale hearing next month before Ohio Board of Education members, who are in a heated debate over whether established science censors other views about the origins of life.

description: The tenor Ben Heppner has canceled his recital at Carnegie Hall tonight for medical reasons. He has laryngitis, Carnegie announced, and on the recommendation of his doctors and vocal coach has canceled all dates on his current tour.

title: Fashion Week: Combs Leaves Streets Behind
description: Sean Combs has been known to offer wildly ostentatious animal pelts on his runways, although they were strictly for show; in stores, he traffics in jeans, denim work jackets and other components of urban regalia. Or at least that's what Mr. Combs used to do. At his show on Saturday night, Mr. Combs immersed himself in another world. The models wore three-piece suits, cashmere car coats and military greatcoats. The clothes were smart and martini-ready.

But five miles away as the crow flies, residents of Greenpoint, Brooklyn, are all too familiar with the insect, its appetite and the havoc it can create.

The ski flew, his leg splayed, but his line somehow held, all the way across the finish line.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Proposal For Waterfront
description: New York City's efforts to reclaim and revive its 500 miles of waterfront, a priority under Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, should begin with city-owned land, the chairman of the City Council's new committee on waterfronts said yesterday. The chairman, David Yassky, a Brooklyn Democrat, released a list of city-owned ''waterfront wastes.'' They include a towing pound in Red Hook, Brooklyn, giant mounds of road salt piled along the banks of the Harlem River and parking lots and empty lots on the Hudson. He said that the city should move the facilities inland, freeing up the properties for development. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: The Fatal Flaws
description: In the spring of 2000 a team of lawyers and criminologists at Columbia University released the first phase of the most far-reaching study of the death penalty in the United States. It showed that the system of capital punishment was riddled with unfairness and incompetence, with serious errors erupting with alarming frequency at every stage of the process.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEARER, HARTLEY PARKER
description: SHEARER-Hartley Parker. On February 7, 2002, at age 57 in Williamstown, MA. Born in New York City and a longtime resident there, he leaves his loving wife of 35 years, Linda and his devoted son, Ivor. Earning his living as a landlord he dedicated his life to art and public service, and changed the lives of countless students, friends and strangers in unexpected ways. He attended Middlebury College and earned a BFA from NYU in 1968. He had been a part-time lecturer in art at Williams College since 1991 and was pursuing a MSW at SUNY-Albany when he suffered a stroke in 1999. The last three years were filled with challenges and struggles which even he could not overcome. He will be greatly missed by his family and many friends. A memorial gathering will take place on Saturday, February 16. Please call 413597-2318 for time and location. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Berkshire Farm Center and Services for Youth in Canaan, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLACH, ARLEEN GAIL
description: WALLACH-Arleen Gail. On February 9, 2002. Beloved and adored wife of Henry. Devoted mother of Louis and Ty. Dear mother-in-law of Allison. Loving sister of Dr. Joel Wilentz and sister-in-law of Linda. Cherished grandmother of Charlie. A unique and wonderful woman who made us feel good about ourselves and who made us laugh, she will be missed by everyone who knew her. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANNADAY, RICHARD LEE
description: CANNADAY-Richard Lee. 77, died on February 8, 2002, at his home in Manhattan. Mr. Cannaday was a patent attorney in private practice in Elizabeth, NJ, prior to his retirement in 1995. Before entering private practice he worked in Esso Research and Engineering's Patent Department and with the New York City patent law firm of Kenyon and Kenyon. He was a member of the New York Bar and of the Bars of the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office, New York and Washington, DC. He was also a licensed professional engineer. Mr. Cannaday attended St. Paul's in Manhattan and graduated from St. Bernard's in Manhattan and Deerfield Academy in Massachusetts. He received Bachelor's and Master's Degrees in Naval Engineering from MIT in 1945, and was commissioned in the US Naval Reserve shortly after graduation. Mr. Cannaday is also a 1954 graduate of St. John's University Law School. After an active duty tour with the US Navy at the end of WWII, Mr. Cannaday worked at Los Alamos New Mexico Scientific Laboratory in the field of cryogenics. Mr. Cannaday was recalled to active duty during the Korean War and was involved with designs that replaced oxygen with liquified nitrogen in areas surrounding aviation fuel tanks on aircraft carriers. Mr. Cannaday retired from the Navy with the rank of Lt. Commander. Mr. Cannaday was a member and lifetime communicant of Central Presbyterian Church and Holland Lodge No. 8 F&AM. He was also a member of St. Anthony's fraternity at MIT. He leaves an aunt, Lee McKeithen of Old Greenwich, CT, and six first cousins. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St., Monday, February 11, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral services at Central Presbyterian Church, 595 Park Avenue at 64th St., Tuesday, February 12, 12 noon. Interment will be at Fairview Memorial Park, Albemarle, NC, Wednesday, February 13.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUMAN, FREDERICK JAMES
description: BAUMAN-Frederick James. Of Atlantic Highlands, NJ, and formerly of NYC, entered eternal life on February 6, 2002. Beloved husband of Frances Saganich Bauman. Devoted father of Paul of NYC, and of David and daughterin-law Laura of Roseland, NJ. Loving grandfather of Nicholas, also of Roseland, NJ, and former husband of Haruko Nomura Bauman of NYC. Mr. Bauman was a true New Yorker, as he was born in Manhattan at Doctor's Hospital and his father and grandfather owned and operated Bauman's Apothecary in Yorkville. He attended Cardinal Hayes High School in NYC and St. John's Prep School in Danvers, MA, and graduated from Sophia University, Tokyo, Japan, and did post-graduate work at Columbia University, NYC. He was also a veteran of the Korean War, serving in the US Navy as Chief Hospital Corpsman attached to FMFPAC 3rd Marine Division. He worked for 25 years in the pharmaceutical industry as a representative for pharmaceutical companies and later in medical publishing, including the American Medical Associaiton and McGrawHill, and for the past 17 years has been the popular owner and proprietor of the Highlands Hardware Store in Highlands, NJ. Mr. Bauman had an all-encompassing love of the sea and delighted in his boats and fishing. The family will be receiving relatives and friends for a Memorial Gathering on Wednesday, February 13, 2002, from 24 and 7-9 PM, at Posten's Funeral Home, 59 E. Lincoln Ave. at Central Ave., Atlantic Highlands, NJ. A Memorial Mass will be offered on Thursday at 10 AM from St. Agnes R.C. Church, Atlantic Highlands, NJ. Memorial donatons in his name may be made to Salvation Army or Radio Station WBGO in Newark, NJ. Interment services are private.

title: Sly Wit for a Modernist, Clarity for Impressionists
description: There were both institutional and personal crises hovering over the concert by the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra on Friday night at Carnegie Hall, as well as one small story of triumph. Like many arts institutions, this respected orchestra has been struggling financially in the wake of the recession and the war on terrorism. For a while it looked as if it might go under. Since Sept. 11, W. Randolph Adams, the orchestra's determined new president and executive director, has raised some $29 million. By curtailing the season and other belt-tightening measures, and with a major challenge grant now lined up, the orchestra has been forging on.

title: The Trial of Slobodan Milosevic
description: The most important war crimes trial in Europe since Nuremberg opens tomorrow in The Hague. Slobodan Milosevic, once Yugoslavia's dictator, stands indicted for war crimes and crimes against humanity in Bosnia, Croatia and Kosovo, and genocide committed in Bosnia. It is not only his victims who should rejoice that Mr. Milosevic is facing justice. His trial is a triumph for the civilized world, which has created a court capable of condemning the most heinous crimes with appropriate gravity and fairness.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Liaison Named for Victims' Families
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he had appointed a special liaison to work with the relatives of those killed in the Sept. 11 terror attack. The liaison will be Christy Ferer, a television correspondent whose husband, Neil D. Levin, the executive director of the Port Authority, died in the attack. Ms. Ferer and Mr. Bloomberg met with family members at a private viewing site for relatives on the southwest corner of the World Trade Center site. The platform was opened Oct. 1 by the Port Authority. Unlike the public viewing platform on the other side of the site, no tickets are required and there is no time limit on viewing.
