title: Technology Briefing | Finance: Venture Capitalists Raise Less
description: The amount raised by venture capitalists dropped sharply in the fourth quarter, falling to levels last seen in 1993, according to the National Venture Capital Association and Venture Economics. Venture capitalists raised $4.6 billion in the fourth quarter, compared with $23.4 billion for the period a year earlier. For all of 2001, venture capitalists raised $40.6 billion, down from $104.6 billion in 2000, but still the third-highest year on record. One reason for the slowdown, the group found, was that venture capitalists already had money in reserve. The group found that venture capitalists invested $36.5 billion in 2001, down from $99.6 billion. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Auditor Suspended
description: PricewaterhouseCoopers, which audits a quarter of Italy's traded companies, was ordered by the market regulator to suspend one of its auditors after Banca Popolare di Novara failed to report a $50 million loss. Luca Redaelli, the auditor responsible for Popolare Novara and one of 70 partners among the 1,200 employees at the Italian unit of PricewaterhouseCoopers, was barred from working as an auditor for two years. The ban was related to the loss that Popolare Novara found in its 1999 first-half earnings, Consob, the regulator, said. PricewaterhouseCoopers said it had acted in good faith, and the Italian branch said it was considering a court challenge to the regulator's decision.

description: BALSAM-Sidney. 86, died peacefully on February 11, 2002. Loving husband of the late Esther Luttan Balsam. Devoted father of Wendy, Peter and Robert. Someone apparently broke into the home of the professor, Carla E. Grayson; her partner, Adrian Neff; and their infant son at 3 a.m., doused the floor with gasoline and set it afire, the police chief, Bob Reid, said. Jim Robbins (NYT)

title: Storm in Mexico Devastates Monarch Butterfly Colonies

Between 220 and 270 million frozen butterflies had rained down from roosts where they normally festooned towering trees, researchers estimated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIPS, WALTER F. JR.
description: GIPS-Walter F. Jr. Died February 10, 2002 at home in Princeton, NJ. Graduate of Yale College and Harvard Business School '43, Captain US Army Quartermaster's Corps, WWII, then faculty Harvard Business School. His successful business career culminated as CEO and Chairman of the Board of Gulton Industries, Inc. He believed strongly in community service. He was a member of the Board of Governors and Treasurer of the American Jewish Committee and National Treasurer of the Coro Foundation. He also served as a Board member of many nonprofits, including the Princeton Area Community Foundation, Medical Center at Princeton Foundation, and Stony Brook Millstone Watershed Association. He was a wonderful husband, father, grandfather and friend and is deeply loved by all who knew him. He is survived by his wife, the former Ann; son Walter F. Gips III (Terry) of Minneapolis; son Rob Gips and Karen Harris, Sara, Allie and Rachel of Cape Elizabeth, Maine; son Don Gips and Liz Berry, Sam, Pete and Ben of Boulder, Colorado; daughter Ellen and Peter Nee, PJ and Jamie of Ballyconneely, Ireland; sister Kay and Arthur Ross of Hamden, CT; and sister Mary Jane and Robert Pelz of Purchase, NY. The funeral will be at 2 PM, Wednesday, February 13 at Temple Micah, which meets in the Lawrenceville Presbyterian Church, 2688 Main Street, Lawrenceville, NJ. Following the ceremony, friends and family will gather to celebrate his life at The Nassau Club, 6 Mercer Street, Princeton. Donations may be made to the Princeton Area Community Foundation, 188 Tamarack Circle, Skillman, NJ 08558.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALLA VILLA, MONSIGNOR ANTHONY J.
description: DALLA VILLA-Monsignor Anthony J. Called to the Lord on February 10, 2002. Monsignor Dalla Villa was born in New York City on April 2, 1938, to Frank and Elizabeth (nee Nicolini) Dalla Villa. He studied at St. Agnes High School, Cathedral Preparation School and Cathedral College before entering St. Joseph's Seminary. He was ordained in 1964. He later received a Master's degree in pastoral counseling from Iona College. Monsignor Dalla Villa was assigned as a parochial vicar in 1980, became administrator in 1987 and was named rector in 1988. Before being assigned to the Cathedral, he was a parochial vicar at Our Lady Queen of Peace parish in Staten Island and spent his first ten years of pastoral services at St. Dominic's Church in the Bronx. His sister Barbara Srinivas will receive friends on Tuesday from 2-4 and 7-9 PM at F. Ruggiero & Sons, Inc., 726 Morris Park Ave, Bronx. Monsignor Dalla Villa will then lie in state at his parish, St. Agnes Church, 143 East 43rd St (between 3rd and Lexington Aves) on Wednesday from 11 AM-4 PM. A Mass of Commemoration will be celebrated at St. Agnes Church, Wednesday evening at 6:30 PM. The Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Thursday, 10 AM at St. Patrick's Cathedral. His interment will follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Valhalla, NY. For further information, you may call the funeral home at 1-888-828-1800.

title: MOODY'S WILL BUY KMV FOR $210 MILLION
description: The Moody's Corporation, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy KMV, a closely held firm that analyzes risks of bonds, loans, and credit derivatives, for $210 million, to add risk-management customers. Moody's, which is based in New York, said it would close the purchase early in the second quarter and merge KMV with its Moody's Risk Management Services unit. KMV, which is based in San Francisco and has about 135 employees, is expected to generate about $60 million of sales this year, compared with $40 million for Moody's Risk Management. Among KMV's 150 clients are some of the world's largest banks, some of which Moody's does not have as risk-management clients, a spokeswoman, Fran Laserson, said.

description: Joe Torre will meet with his coaches at Legends Field here Tuesday, and for the first time since he became the Yankees' manager in 1996, Torre will plan for a season without Tino Martinez and Paul O'Neill. For the first time in five springs, Torre will not be concerned with Scott Brosius and Chuck Knoblauch either.

description: ORIGIN -- The International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia was established by the United Nations Security Council in 1993 and opened in The Hague in 1994. It is the first international criminal court since the military tribunals that judged Nazi and Japanese leaders after World War II.

title: Luxury Steamliner Tours
description: The American Orient Express, a luxury streamliner, offers $1,000 a person in discounts on two itineraries. The Antebellum South tour, an eight-day trip from Washington to New Orleans or reverse, features a New Orleans jazz trio, a one-night hotel stay, most meals (dinners with wine) and guided tours in Richmond, Charleston, Savannah and Vicksburg. Prices start at $1,890 a person based on two to a compartment, on five departures in March and April. The 11-day Great Transcontinental Rail Journey, from Washington to Los Angeles, departs Feb. 19; stops include Grand Canyon National Park. From $3,290 a person, double. Information: (800) 320-4206, www.americanorientexpress.com .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEBORER, DR. MIRIAM
description: SEBORER-Dr. Miriam. On February 7th, Dr. Miriam Seborer, Navy veteran, WWII, neurologist, teacher of English, translator, U.N. medical officer, Medical Director for insurance company, Treasurer, NY County Medical Society, mother and housewife, died after a long illness.

description: In the beginning, just liniment could speed recovery for an athlete with a nagging muscle pull. That and, of course, rest.

title: World Briefing | World: United Nations: U.S. Nominee
description: The secretary general of the United Nations nominated James T. Morris, left, president of the Indiana University Board of Trustees, as executive director of the World Food Program, heading off a confrontation with the Bush administration, senior United Nations officials said. Mr. Morris was at first rejected for the post, and the United Nations had appeared poised to name an Australian official. But American officials complained, saying the United States was already underrepresented in the leadership. Catherine Bertini, an American, will step down next month after 10 years in the post. Elizabeth Becker (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fireworks Ban To Remain
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he would not lift the ban on professional fireworks displays for the celebration of the Asian New Year, which begins today. For several years, the city has cracked down on illegal firecracker sales, but after the Sept. 11 terrorist attack, officials banned even professional displays. Many Chinese-American leaders have asked for the ban to be lifted for this week's celebrations of the new year, 4700, which is the Year of the Horse, because in Chinese folklore fireworks and firecrackers are said to ward off evil spirits. Mr. Bloomberg said he hoped the ban would be lifted by the summer. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: How Endangered a Species?
description: A steel autopsy table in a red-tiled room is the last resting place for nearly every manatee that dies in Florida. And it is rarely unoccupied these days.

title: Investors Feel Some Ripples At J. P. Morgan
description: After a string of losses and bad publicity, J. P. Morgan Chase finds itself on the defensive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANUR, RACHEL D.
description: TANUR-Rachel D. Born March 15, 1958, of New York, NY, passed away on February 10, 2002. Rachel was a devoted granddaughter of Edith Tanur, cherished daughter of Michael and Judy Tanur, sister and true friend of Marcia Tanur and her partner Vicky Gurfolino, loving and proud aunt of Emma and Max, beloved niece of Reuben and Arlene Mark, and the heart and soul of an extended family of Tanur, Mark, and Gringauz cousins. Rachel also stood at the center of a wide circle of lucky friends and colleagues. Rachel's courage, indomitable spirit, and great pleasure in life enriched all who are blessed enough to have known her. She will be deeply missed by many. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, February 13, 2002, at 11:30 AM at Frank Campbell Funeral Home, located at 1076 Madison Ave. at East 81st St., NY, NY. A fund for donations will be created shortly.

title: Terror Suspect Granted Bail in Britain
description: LONDON, Feb. 12  With his arms wrapped tightly around his wife and his mother, an Algerian pilot once identified by American investigators as the "lead trainer" of the Sept. 11 hijackers, walked free on $14,200 bail from a high security courtroom today after the United States abandoned an effort to extradite him on terrorism charges.

title: Olympic First: Father and Son Go Luge to Luge
description: Werner Hoeger, 48, and his 17-year-old son, Christopher, became the first father-son combination to compete head to head in the same event at the Olympics. Christopher finished 31st today in the men's singles luge with a time of 3 minutes 4.313 seconds, while Werner finished 40th in 3:08.278.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Reward For Return Of Girl
description: More than a week after 7-year-old Danielle van Dam vanished from her bedroom, her parents offered a $25,000 reward for information that would lead to her return. ''Somebody out there knows something they're not talking about,'' said Brenda van Dam, who last saw her daughter on the night of Feb. 1 in their home in the Sabre Springs section of northeastern San Diego. Investigators have received at least 250 tips from the public, the police said, but there have been no arrests in the case. Investigators said they believed Danielle had been abducted. Nick Madigan (NYT)

title: Making Toys For Children Too Mature For Most Toys
description: In a world where Barbies have become oh, so first grade, toymakers are struggling to deliver items that appeal to rapidly maturing 8-year-old girls.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Another Problem For Paypal
description: The online payment provider PayPal, which is on the brink of an initial offering, has been cautioned that its service may violate banking regulations in several states, including New York, the company said yesterday in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. One state, Louisiana, confirmed that it had asked PayPal to stop operating in the state. A lawyer in the state's Office of Financial Institutions said Louisiana was investigating whether PayPal was engaged in the ''business of banking,'' a designation that would require it to obtain a bank charter. PayPal said it had taken steps to address the concerns and to obtain the required licenses. PayPal postponed a planned offering last week after it was sued for patent infringement.

title: White House Is Backing Foes Of Finance Bill
description: The White House is working through the Republican Party to scuttle campaign finance legislation before the House this week while protecting President Bush from any political fallout, advisers to Mr. Bush said today.

description: NBC and the Warner Brothers television studio concluded the biggest deal ever for a half-hour television program last night, a one-year renewal for the comedy ''Friends'' that will exceed the per half-hour price the network paid for ''E.R.'' in 1998.

title: Asians take a closer look at Islamic schools

The raid, on Jan. 3, led to the closure of the Islamic school, or madrasa, which Malaysian authorities say was linked to a group of Muslim extremists.

title: Pakistan Arrests Top Suspect in Abduction of U.S. Reporter
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Feb. 12 — The Pakistani authorities today arrested an Islamic militant who had been the main suspect in the kidnapping of the American journalist Daniel Pearl, and said he told them that Mr. Pearl was still alive.

description: Conventional wisdom has it that anyone who really wants to become fit can do so. Just walk or ride a bicycle, swim or run. Speed and endurance will improve and what was once hard will become easy. Lift weights, work with a trainer in a gym, and muscles will grow larger and stronger.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Air Traffic Recovering
description: BAA, which runs Heathrow in London and six other British airports, said the decline in airline passengers seemed to be slowing, suggesting that travelers were beginning to recover from the impact of the Sept. 11 attacks. BAA said eight million passengers used its airports in January, a fall of 3.9 percent compared with the level a year earlier. The decline in December was 6.4 percent. The slide in passenger numbers was more marked on trans-Atlantic routes, down 10 percent in January compared with 13 percent a month earlier. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Crown Point: State Trooper Killed
description: A state trooper who only recently graduated from the police academy was shot to death in a small town yesterday, the authorities said. The trooper, Lawrence P. Gleason, 28, was speaking to Amanda Olcott, 36, at her house in Crown Point, 100 miles north of Albany, when James Scharpf, 36, Ms. Olcott's estranged boyfriend, arrived with a rifle, the police said. Mr. Scharpf shot Trooper Gleason, then Ms. Olcott, then himself, said Sgt. Glenn Miner, a spokesman. All three died. Trooper Gleason had graduated from the State Police Academy in May. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Iran and the 'Axis of Evil'
description: Millions of Iranians marched with unusual vigor and anti-American defiance yesterday to mark the 23rd anniversary of their Islamic revolution. Staged rallies on official anniversaries are not an accurate measure of the mood of a country, but in this case the turnout partly reflects a genuine popular backlash against President Bush's description of Iran as a member of the ''axis of evil.'' His comment has clearly strengthened the hand of the hard-liners and forced reformers to prove their patriotism by denouncing the United States.

title: FEDERATED SAYS IT HAS RECEIVED A BID FOR FINGERHUT UNIT
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. is reviewing a formal offer for the Fingerhut catalog and Internet business, a month after saying it expected to close the unit. Federated, which owns the Macy's and Bloomingdale's chains, said on Jan. 16 that it was unlikely to find a buyer for Fingerhut and sent notices to the unit's 6,000 workers saying they might be laid off if none appeared. A Federated spokeswoman, Carol Sanger, would not disclose details of the offer. Federated is reducing its Web operations and has hired Credit Suisse First Boston to sell businesses.

title: A Delight in Sheer Sound to Break Down Boundaries
description: The colored spotlights at Alice Tully Hall cast slivers of brightness across the array of drum sets and keyboards onstage. Right away, it made you prick up your ears, whether in appreciation or suspicion. Gone were the staid ranks of chairs, the ritually empty stage, the formal sobriety associated with classical music. The setup made a statement about the classical concertgoing experience before anyone had played a note.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYO, SMITH, MARGARET
description: MAYO-SMITH-Margaret. Writer, painter, and conservationist, of Bedford, NY died on February 8, 2002. On graduation from Smith College, she worked as a writer for Vogue Magazine in New York, Paris and London. Subsequently, she was a writer and editor at the Institute of International Education in New York. Her paintings have been exhibited at the Salmagundi Club in New York, Gallery East in Easthampton, the Silvermine Guild, and the Katonah Gallery, among others. Conservation activities have included the National Board of the Girl Scouts, on which she worked to expand the outdoors program, the Rails-to-Trails Conservancy, in which she worked as an advocate for Westchester's Acquisition of the North County Trailway, the Sierra Club, the Westchester Land Trust, the John Jay Homestead and the Bedford Conservation Board. She is married to Worthington Mayo-Smith and has three children, Sabina of Topanga, CA, Bill of Weston, MA, and John of Rye, NY and seven grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at St. Matthew's Church, Bedford, NY on Friday, February 15 at 2 PM. Donations in her memory may be sent to the Oncology Nurses Education Fund, Northern Westchester Hospital, Mt. Kisco, NY 10549.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Chemical Bankruptcy
description: Gazprom, the giant gas monopoly, will move to enforce a $932 million debt owed to it by a rogue subsidiary, the petrochemical maker Sibur, by asking a Siberian court to place Sibur in bankruptcy, Gazprom's deputy chief executive told news services today. Prosecutors are investigating accusations that senior Sibur managers siphoned off assets for their own benefit, and several of the executives, including the former chief executive, Yakov Goldovsky, are in custody. Mr. Goldovsky's lawyer has demanded his release on the ground that there are no witnesses who can prove he has stolen from Sibur.

title: For Trillin, Parking Is an End, Not a Means
description: For Calvin Trillin, finding a parking space on New York City streets is not just a subject of immediate urgency, it is, he said, ''the only thing that matters.'' In an attempt to prove his point, he has written a novel, ''Tepper Isn't Going Out,'' which chronicles the life and parking times of a New Yorker named Murray Tepper. Were it not for the apparently arcane subject and the book's brevity (213 pages, a length that is, however, Tolstoyan in Mr. Trillin's ouevre of 21 slim volumes), a reader might be tempted to call it his magnum opus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, ELISABETH LUCE
description: MOORE-Elisabeth Luce. On February 9, 2002, age 98, in New York City. She was the wife of the late Maurice T. Moore, the mother of Michael Moore and the late M. Thompson Moore, Jr. and the sister of the late Henry R. Luce. Born in Teng Chou, Shandong, China of missionary parents. She attended Abbott Academy and Wellesley College, of which she was a trustee. Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller appointed her chairman of the State University of New York. She was a trustee of China Institute in America, the Asia Foundation and the National Board of the Y.W.C.A. She was president of the United Board for Christian Education in Asia and chairman of the Institute of International Education. For sixty-three years she was a director of the Henry Luce Foundation, Inc. A memorial service will be held on a date to be announced. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Brick Presbyterian Church, 8 East 91 St., New York, NY will be welcomed.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Guatemala: Job Bias Report
description: Labor laws have failed to protect women working in clothing factories who encounter ''persistent'' discrimination and abuse, including forced overtime and pregnancy tests, according to a report by Human Rights Watch. It says that the factories, some subcontractors for major American retailers, discriminate by refusing to hire those who are pregnant, or by denying health care to those who become pregnant. Although most major American retailers spell out worker rights, the report says some factories continue to flout them. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: Poisoning Shays-Meehan
description: When campaign finance reform finally comes before the House on Wednesday, the lawmakers trying to kill the bill will come in many disguises. Rather than voting against the whole measure, they will proclaim their love for reform -- a love so deep that it can best be expressed in a series of amendments to ''improve'' the bill. Today we say: Beware of such talk. The aim of almost all such ''improvements'' is to destroy the fragile coalition backing reform, or to pass a version that cannot immediately win approval in the Senate, thereby forcing the legislation into a House-Senate conference -- and certain oblivion.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Eurotunnel's Loss Widens
description: Thousands of people seeking asylum who try to board trains or flee on foot to Britain through the Channel Tunnel caused disruptions that contributed to widening losses in 2001, Eurotunnel, the operator of the tunnel rail link, said. Losses grew to 132 million ($187 million) from 124 million in 2000, Eurotunnel said, blaming disruptions caused by the asylum seekers for 20 million ($28 million) in lost revenue. Eurotunnel also said that reduced demand for telecommunications cable laid in the tunnel contributed to the losses. Eurotunnel is fighting in French courts to force the closing of a camp for people who are seeking asylum that is near the tunnel's French terminal. Kurdish, Afghan and other people at the camp routinely storm the Eurotunnel terminal to try to make their way to Britain to seek asylum. Alan Cowell (NYT)

description: RUSSELL-Rosemary. description: A body-piercing bill that is soon to become state law can be traced to Kate Dalrymple's lower lip.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Growth Outlook Brightens
description: Glimmers of economic recovery in the United States are brightening the outlook for export-dependent Singapore. In his Lunar New Year message to the country, Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong said the government now predicts Singapore's economy will grow from 1 to 3 percent this year. Officials had forecast that the economy would post 2 percent growth to 2 percent contraction, but economists said evidence of growth in Singapore's electronics industry foreshadowed the end of a recession that has left thousands jobless. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, KALMAN
description: KLEIN-Kalman. Of New York City and Westhampton Beach. In his 96th year. Beloved father of Dr. Stephan Marc Klein, Peter D. Klein, Joan Gandy and the late Richard Springer. Father-in-law of Andrea B. Klein and the late Judy Graf Klein. Grandfather of Adina and Oleanna Klein. Grandfather of Steven Gandy, David Gandy, Susan Smith, Terry Gandy, Mark Springer and Jonna Hutchingson. Great-grandfather of Monique and Amy. Brother-in-law of Hazel Phillips Stanley. Uncle of Gilda Love and Jesse Greenberg. Dear friend of Leo and Shirley Margolin. Kalman Klein was a prominent Long Island home builder and developer. For 65 years he was a principal of Klein and Teicholz Builders. He was Past President of the Long Island Builder's Institute. He was a loving, caring and generous man. We deeply mourn his passing. The funeral will take place on Wednesday at 1:30PM at the Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

title: Foreign students on rise : Enduring allure of a U.S. diploma
description: WASHINGTON  Marga van der Werff had the typical priorities in mind when she went looking for a graduate program in businessaffordability and a challenging curriculum. But for the 28-year-old Dutch woman, the most important factor was location.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Charter Reports Wider Loss
description: A leading cable television provider, Charter Communications, has reported a wider fourth-quarter loss on higher costs as it upgraded systems for digital TV. The company also said subscribers would decline by 125,000 this quarter. The loss widened to $305.7 million, or $1.04 a share, after the payment of preferred dividends, from $241.1 million, or $1.03. Sales were $1.1 billion, Charter said, up 23 percent from a year earlier. Shares rose 10 cents, to $11.35. The company was expected to have a fourth-quarter loss of $1.08 a share and sales of $1.08 billion.

title: Focus of Latest Terrorist Alert Includes Al Qaeda Members
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12  Suspected members of Osama bin Laden's Al Qaeda network were among the 17 men identified in the latest terror alert issued by the F.B.I., government officials said today.

title: White House Seeks to Ease Rules Put on I.R.S. Workers
description: The Bush administration wants to ease some of the 10 rules that require the dismissal of Internal Revenue Service employees for acts like filing their personal tax returns late -- even if a refund is due. The rules were enacted in 1998 after Senate hearings on accusations that I.R.S. employees had abused taxpayers.

title: Bush Featured In G.O.P. Ads Criticizing 5 Senators
description: After months of largely avoiding head-on partisan attacks on individual Democrats, President Bush has taken a starring role in a new, decidedly critical advertisement that is running in the states of five Democratic senators who voted against his economic stimulus package.

title: The Unforgiving Edge of Sports
description: ''Forgiving'' is not a word that comes to mind when you think of the Olympic Games being played at Salt Lake City. The clock is, as always, ruthless. The terrain can be brutal. The judges, in the competitions where judges determine the scores, often seem heartless, even cruel. And, it's worth adding, the TV cameras are painfully acute, translating exhaustion or despair into a searing image that can be replayed over and over again.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Thermometer in Nanotube

title: District Rescinds Busing Plan For 700 Young Pupils in Bronx
description: A school district in the northwest Bronx has rescinded a plan that would have bused about 700 black and Hispanic kindergartners and first graders from their neighborhoods to unfamiliar schools as part of a complicated plan to preserve the racial balance at a school in Riverdale, school officials said yesterday.

title: G.O.P. Studies New Rules On Companies
description: House Republicans are circulating proposals for post-Enron legislation that they say will strengthen federal standards for auditor independence and corporate financial disclosure.

title: Suits Against Andersen May Test Partners' Risks
description: Lawsuits against Arthur Andersen and its partners may provide the first test of whether a widely adopted form of partnership will shield the property of partners who were not at fault, lawyers say.

title: Pakistan Holds 2 Ex-Agents in Kidnapping
description: The authorities in Pakistan have detained two former members of the country's intelligence service in the hope that they can provide information about the kidnapping of the American journalist Daniel Pearl, Pakistani officials said today.

title: Business Versus Biznes
description: Memo to critics of the media's liberal bias: the pinkos you really should be going after are those business reporters.

title: American Women Rout Germany
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 12  No one needed to see the scoreboard late in the second period today to figure out how things were evolving in the women's hockey game between the United States and Germany. In the American end, the playing surface was mostly smooth, with few skate marks. It reflected the bright lights overhead.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Now I can go home and all my friends will make fun of me for being in the Olympics. It'll be sick.''

title: NBC's Olympic Coverage Is Shown 'Live' on Tape
description: It was, in a way, a flashback to NBC's broadcast of the 2000 Summer Olympics from Sydney, Australia, when nothing but the men's basketball final was carried live.

title: At 21, a Grasp Of Women's Clout
description: ''It's about the power of different kinds of women,'' the designer Zac Posen said, explaining the theme of his show, which takes place tonight at the Angel Orensanz Foundation on the Lower East Side and is among the more eagerly anticipated of Fashion Week.

title: Objections may scuttle NBC's plan to accept hard liquor commercials.
description: TWO months ago, NBC became the first broadcast network to accept commercials for hard liquor like vodka, rum or whiskey. But an outcry from members of Congress and advocacy organizations opposed to expanding ads for distilled spirits may scuttle the effort.

title: Congress Sets Inquiry on U.S. Flaws in Attack
description: The House and Senate intelligence committees are set to begin a joint investigation into United States intelligence gaps in the Sept. 11 attacks, the chairman of the House panel said tonight.

title: A Global Vision For a Global Show; Documenta Curator Sees Art As Expression of Social Change
description: When Okwui Enwezor arrived in the United States from Nigeria 20 years ago, he was a political science major at Jersey City State College who wrote poetry on the side. Now, at 38, he has become an internationally known curator who will cap his career in June as artistic director of Documenta 11, an international exhibition that is to contemporary art what the Olympics are to sports.

title: Corrections
description: An event listing in the Long Island section on Sunday for a screening of ''Sleep in a Nest of Flames,'' a documentary film about the poet Charles Henri Ford, misstated the day of the showing. It is at 3:30 p.m. on Friday, not Saturday, in the student activity center of the State University at Stony Brook.

title: Closing the Gap on Heart Risk for Women
description: ''Women Are Not Small Men,'' by Dr. Nieca Goldberg, Ballantine Books, $24.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Lincoln's Birthday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Terror Inquiry Is Set
description: The House and Senate intelligence committees are set to launch a joint investigation into United States intelligence gaps in the wake of the Sept. 11 attacks, the chairman of the House panel said. Representative Porter J. Goss of Florida said details of the investigation would be announced on Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAGNER, NATHAN
description: CAGNER-Nathan. To our adored Grandpa. We will always remember the smiles and happiness that Grandpa brought to us at every occasion. From sharing a great breakfast with him at Mom's Kitchen to learning how to hit a golf ball with perfect ease, his ways were both comforting and lasting. His journey through life has touched many people, places, and certainly years-but it is our hearts, the hearts of his grandchildren most of all, that he has touched the most. We will always love you. Love, Adam, Lana, Evan, Michele, Dana, Rachel, and Eric

title: For Outsiders in Saudi Arabia, Worship Comes With a Risk
description: At a secret location every Sunday evening, a young Catholic priest does a dangerous thing. He says Mass.

title: The Indoor Game Mounts a Comeback
description: The Major Indoor Soccer League may be forgotten, but it is not gone.

title: U.S. Backing For Guidelines On Fighting Cybercrime
description: The first guidelines for responding to attacks on computer systems to be endorsed by both the F.B.I. and the Secret Service, the main Federal agencies fighting such crimes, were published yesterday.

title: Rescuing the Buildings Beyond Ground Zero
description: Five months after the World Trade Center attack, the focus of the recovery effort is moving outward from ground zero to another trauma zone: a ring of battered skyscrapers and other buildings that once held 10 million square feet of floor space, slightly more than the twin towers.

title: High Winds Postpone The Women's Downhill
description: Even Olympians can go too fast on a downhill course, and today, with 20-mile-an-hour mountaintop winds gusting at the backs of skiers, race officials postponed the women's downhill until Tuesday.

title: Hartford Lawmakers Consider 2 Bills on Gay Couples' Legal Status
description: More than 200 people packed a public hearing today as Connecticut lawmakers considered two bills, one to legalize gay marriages and the other to recognize civil unions between same-sex partners.

title: Scolding Socialists, Chirac Opens His Re-election Effort
description: President Jacques Chirac began his re-election campaign today, defending himself against accusations of corruption and lashing out at the Socialist government, accusing it of squandering the benefits of France's recent economic growth.

title: Interpublic Board To Add Outsiders
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies in New York said yesterday that it would substantially remake its board to give greater weight to outside directors by having four inside directors leave.

title: Halfpipe Dreams: A U.S. Sweep
description: There is a mountain in southern Vermont where the legend of a certain 23-year-old snowboarder is as large as the snowdrifts. Riders and instructors there talk about how Ross Powers learned to ride on the icy slopes of Stratton Mountain on a scholarship, how his mother supported the family by working in the cafeteria of a nearby resort, how he competed in the United States Open within a few years of getting his first snowboard at age 7.

title: Pounding Feet and Hearts Pay Tribute to a Victim
description: They were dancing to the silence between heartbeats, at least that's how the choreographer, Jacques d'Amboise, put it. One hundred schoolchildren between 9 and 15 years old, members of the National Dance Institute, were up on stage last night at La Guardia High School on the Upper West Side, paying tribute to Valerie Ellis, who died in the attack on the World Trade Center. She was the wife of the institute's beloved production manager, Sam Ellis.

title: Foreign Aid in Our Own Defense
description: The events of Sept. 11 made it painfully clear that the political, social and economic problems of other countries have a direct impact on American national security. Our country was attacked by a terror organization that had turned a weakened Afghanistan into its training ground and that searches for recruits in nations that offer young men little political voice and limited economic opportunity. To crush this threat, we need a program of tightly focused foreign aid to address the economic, political and social conditions that will otherwise continue breeding new terrorists.

title: ImClone Board Said to Be Discussing Bristol's Request
description: The board of the biotechnology company ImClone Systems met yesterday to consider a demand from Bristol-Myers Squibb that it drastically alter the terms of their $2 billion partnership to develop and market a cancer drug. ImClone did not announce its decision last night.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  AGAPITO, KARIN HEIDER

title: How Cells Know Where to Exit the Bloodstream to Go to Work
description: Suppose you are a cell with an urgent errand, swimming through the plumber's nightmare that is the human blood circulation system. How do you know when you have arrived where you want to go? Why aren't there helpful station signs saying, ''Kidney,'' ''Hold tight, heart ahead,'' or, ''Hush, neurons thinking''?

title: Campuses Across America Are Adding 'Sept. 11 101' to Curriculums
description: Five months after the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, the events of Sept. 11 and their aftermath have become a central theme in college courses across America.

description: DIAMONDSTEIN - Murry. Of Boynton Beach, FL. Formerly of Westbury, NY. Beloved husband of Helen. Loving father of Heather and Elliott Friedman, and Diane Diamondstein and David Garelik. Cherished grandfather of Michael and Laura Friedman. Died peacefully at home on February 11, 2002. He was a devoted friend to many who will long remember his thoughtfulness, caring, wisdom and compassion. Contributions may be made to the Hearing and Learning Center at Beth Israel Medical Center, c/o Jane Madell, 10 Union Square East, New York, NY 10003. Inquiries I.J. Morris Funeral Directors, 800-332-8484.

title: Is It Gibberish or Slang Or Anglo-American Jive?
description: It's not unusual for a singer to ask his audience to ''give it up now for the D.J.'' But when Craig David made that request last Wednesday night at Roseland, something didn't quite add up. He had brought three backup singers and five musicians with him, but there wasn't a turntable in sight.

title: An Upstart Surpasses a Spanish-Language Daily
description: It looked like a big gamble when Louis Sito persuaded executives at Newsday to start a Spanish-language daily newspaper three years ago. Many internal critics balked at the notion, saying that others had tried and failed to dislodge El Diario/La Prensa, New York City's older Spanish-language daily.

title: U.S. Seizes Bank Business Of Web Credit Card Issuer
description: The government last week seized the banking operations of NextCard, a company that issued credit cards over the Internet, saying that it had grown too fast and with scant attention to lending quality and had endangered the safety of its $525 million in government-insured deposits.

title: Philippine Army Awaits New U.S. Gear
description: Capt. Harold Cabunoc, 29, the commanding officer of the Philippine Scout Ranger camp in the heart of Abu Sayyaf guerrilla territory, showed off some of his weaponry: a 22-year-old American M-16 rifle and magazines of 25-year-old bullets stamped, ''Made in the United States.''

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Thursday about 2000 census figures that show a record number of foreign-born residents in the United States misstated the number. It is 28.4 million; 56 million is the number of people who are foreign-born or who are native-born to at least one foreign-born parent.

title: ATTACK POSSIBLE IN U.S. OR YEMEN, THE F.B.I. WARNS
description: Based on information law enforcement officials said was obtained from detainees being held at Guantnamo Bay, the F.B.I. tonight issued a new security threat alert, more specific than any one before, warning of the possibility of an attack as early as Tuesday in the United States or Yemen.

title: Big Gains In Research Are Aimed At Military
description: At first glance, President Bush's proposed budget for the 2003 fiscal year includes a healthy increase for scientific research and development: $8.6 billion, or 8.3 percent, to a record $111.8 billion.

title: Taming Tyranny in Zimbabwe
description: Last week Secretary of State Colin Powell told the House International Relations Committee that the Bush administration would restrict travel to the United States by President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe and his inner circle. This welcome step does not go far enough. Now, in the run-up to national elections on March 9 and 10, is the time for Washington to take the lead in insisting that Mr. Mugabe relinquish power. He poses enormous danger to his country and the region; yet he is also quite vulnerable, and his recent actions, like imposing a repressive new media law, suggest desperation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORBES, JAMES
description: FORBES-James. Of North Merrick on February 7, 2002. Professor Emeritus Fordham University. Beloved husband of Matilda Forbes. Devoted father of James Forbes and father-in-law of Julianne Larsen-Forbes. Funeral was private. A Memorial Service for James Forbes will be held Friday, February 15, at 11 AM at the Community Presbyterian Church, 2101 William Place, Merrick, NY.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Woman In Paramedic Mix-Up Dies
description: An unconscious woman mistakenly declared dead by two emergency medical technicians, then taken in critical condition to a hospital, died yesterday, officials said. The woman, Frances Foster, 77, was found in her apartment on Saturday and was believed to be dead until a coroner who attempted to put her into a body bag discovered she was still alive. She was taken to New York Methodist Hospital, where she died yesterday morning. The two technicians who mistakenly declared her dead have been suspended without pay, according to the New York Fire Department. Nichole M. Christian (NYT)

Cherished sister of Mary Reddy. Adored godmother of Allison Reddy. Dear niece and cousin. Devoted friend to many. Proud New York City Police Officer. She will be greatly missed. Friends may call at the Bay Ridge Manor, 476 76th St., Brooklyn, NY, on Wednesday, February 13, 2002, 5-10 PM. description: The Twin Towers Fund, which has raised more than $105 million for the families of firefighters and police officers killed in the Sept. 11 attack, has decided to extend survivor benefits to the families of 28 people who died assisting the rescue effort but were not uniformed service members.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Verdict In 1999 Killings
description: A former employee was convicted by a King County jury of killing two men and wounding two more in a Nov. 3, 1999, shooting at a Seattle shipyard. The gunman, Kevin Cruz, 32, faces the death penalty or life imprisonment without parole for the shooting at the Northlake Shipyard that killed Peter Giles, 27, and Russell Brisendine, 43. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Romney's Future After Salt Lake A Guessing Game
description: In 1994, running against the post-Palm Beach Ted Kennedy for a seat in the United States Senate, Mitt Romney stood in front of the Massachusetts Republican convention and roused the crowd by declaring, ''I will not embarrass you.''

title: Review/Fashion; From Alice Roi, The Importance Of Being Impudent
description: I don't know if people read ''The Group'' by Mary McCarthy anymore, about some high-strung girls at Vassar, and they certainly don't read Mademoiselle magazine, since it's gone out of existence. But to look at the Alice Roi show on Sunday, with its off-the-shoulder down jacket and organza-cuffed polo shirts, was to imagine what Lakey and her sisters would do if they got hold of the September college issue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, IDA PHILLIPS
description: COHEN-Ida Phillips, born April 5, 1906 in Paterson, New Jersey, died in Pompano Beach, Florida on Sunday, February 10, 2002. She was the devoted wife of the late Samuel Cohen and the loving mother of Beryl (Murray) Zankel and Alan (Carol) Cohen. She was the grandmother of six and the great-grandmother of six. She is also survived by a brother, Harry M. Phillips of Paterson. Services are planned for 10 AM Wednesday, February 13th at the Jewish Memorial Chapel, 841 Allwood Road, Clifton, New Jersey.

title: Avalanche Rolls Past The Bruins
description: Joe Sakic, Rob Blake and the rookie Radim Vrbata each had a goal and an assist to lead the Colorado Avalanche past the visiting Boston Bruins, 5-2, last night.

description: A wave of Israeli F-16 warplanes struck a Palestinian security compound in Gaza City today after a Palestinian rocket attack on Sunday that Israeli officials called an escalation in the conflict.

title: Milosevic, 'The Biggest Fish,' on Eve of War Crimes Trial
description: Lawyers, human rights workers and victims of the Yugoslav wars arrived here today on the eve of Slobodan Milosevic's trial, hailing a new era of accountability for war crimes despite anger about other suspects who are still free.

title: U.S. Defends Missile Strike, Saying Attack Was Justified
description: Senior military officials today defended a missile attack by a Central Intelligence Agency drone over eastern Afghanistan last week, calling the strike ''appropriate'' and sharply questioning assertions by Afghans that the missile killed as many as three peasants who were merely scrounging for scrap metal.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Nurses End Strike
description: Nurses at Oregon Health and Sciences University returned to work after voting 736 to 118 on Sunday to end a 56-day strike. The 1,500 members of the Oregon Nurses Association agreed to a minimum 20.5 percent raise over the next three years and increases in their health care coverage. The strike began after the union rejected an offer from the hospital for a 14 percent raise over 27 months. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ground Zero Air Quality
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton called for several measures yesterday to help improve air quality near the World Trade Center site, including requirements for reducing emissions from heavy-duty construction vehicles there. Senator Clinton, who conducted a hearing yesterday at the United States Customs House, near the site, also called for the federal government to track the health of people who have worked or lived at or near ground zero. She also urged the city to expand testing of indoor air quality in Lower Manhattan.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Norway: Profit Falls At Energy Concern
description: The Norwegian industrial group Norsk Hydro said its profit fell 76 percent in the fourth quarter, to 1.1 billion kroner ($127 million), reflecting losses at the company's aluminum unit and declining crude oil prices. Sales fell to 35 billion kroner from 41 billion kroner. For the year, Norsk Hydro's profit fell 44 percent, to 7.89 billion kroner ($885 million). The results met analysts' expectations.

title: Catholics Upgrade Presence in Russia, Annoying Orthodox
description: The Roman Catholic Church said today that it had upgraded its presence in Russia by carving the nation into four new dioceses, drawing a quick and bitter rebuke from the Russian Orthodox Church just as the two faiths seemed to be edging toward a long-sought reconciliation.

description: Sally Silvers and Dancers

title: Lure of the Exotic Stirs Trouble in the Animal Kingdom
description: On Jan. 16, police officers entered the apartment of Ronald J. Huff, 42, of Newark, Del., and found seven Nile monitor lizards feeding on his corpse. An autopsy proved inconclusive as to whether the monitors, ranging up to six feet long, had killed their owner. But the grisly scene provided a glimpse into the growing international trade in exotic pets.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Airline Expands In Macao
description: The China National Aviation Company, controlled by China's aviation regulator, plans to buy aviation assets in Macao from its parent company for 665 million Hong Kong dollars ($85 million), hoping to gain from increased tourism after Macao granted three licenses for casinos. China National Aviation will buy 51 percent of the Air Macau Company, 26 percent of a Macao airport handling company and 20 percent of an aircraft maintenance provider.

title: A Howl of Total Anguish With a Punch in the Head
description: Never let it be said that Linkin Park isn't genre neutral. While most rap-rock acts feel obliged to choose a side, Linkin Park strives for impartiality. When this band came to the Nassau Coliseum tonight, it brought along DJ Z-Trip, who appeared on a platform in the middle of the audience. He played well-known songs from both sides of the rap-rock divide: at one point he spliced together Jay-Z and Jane's Addiction. ''How many people like a little bit of hip-hop?'' he asked, and a loud cheer went up. ''How many people like a little bit of rock 'n' roll?'' he asked, and there was another cheer, equally loud.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Youth Driving Restrictions
description: A state lawmaker has again proposed legislation that would phase in driving privileges to teenagers. The bills, submitted by Representative David Scribner, a Republican from Brookfield, would limit the number of minors allowed in a car for a teenage driver's first six months behind the wheel to one. The legislation would also increase driver training to 12 hours from 8, require night driving training, and ban most driving between 11 p.m. and 5 a.m. for 16- and 17-year-olds.

description: ASIA

title: Karachi's Dark Past Lingers Over Efforts For a Brighter Future
description: For most of the last two decades, this giant port city has been notorious for its ethnic and religious combat, fought with drive-by shootings, the burning of homes and vehicles, street bombings and assassinations. Criminal gangs made fortunes kidnapping the rich, while carjackings became too common to track.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Handspring Shares Rise
description: Shares in Handspring, a maker of Palm OS-based hand-held computers, jumped 34 percent yesterday after the company announced that its Treo hand-held communicator was available in the United States. The device, which integrates a mobile phone and a personal organizer, costs $399 if it is bought with wireless service from Cingular or Voicestream. The unit can be bought without a bundled service for $549. While several products combine a hand-held computer with a mobile phone, many reviewers have said the Treo is the first to integrate both functions in such a small package. Handspring shares rose $1.49, or 33.8 percent, to close at $5.90. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Google Enters Corporate World
description: Google, the search engine company, has started to sell the Google Search Appliance, a device that permits companies to locate documents within their databases. The Google.com Web site has become a popular search service for consumers, but the company has been less active in the corporate search business. Google says the device -- available in two versions, one for $20,000 and the other for $250,000 -- is a plug-and-play solution that takes minutes to install. Google, based in Mountain View, Calif., enters a market with several rivals, including Verity, Ask Jeeves and AltaVista. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: A German Legend Loses to an Italian, Then Loses His Composure
description: Georg Hackl, the 35-year-old German luge legend, spent most of his postrace news conference today smiling about his silver medal and breezily dismissing his place in luge history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSNER, VICTOR
description: POSNER-Victor. Industrialist and financier, died on February 11, 2002 at the Miami Heart Institute. Born on September 18, 1918 in Baltimore, MD, Mr. Posner was one of nine children of Morris and Mary Posner, who both emigrated from Russia. He left school as a teenager to work in the grocery store owned by his parents and subsequently built his first fortune in Baltimore real estate, amassing $1 million by the age of 21. In 1948 he started buying and developing land and constructing houses. By 1952 he was the largest home builder in Maryland, building more than 1,100 houses a year. In 1954 he moved to Miami Beach and began investing in real estate and public companies. At various points in his career he served as Chairman, President and CEO of DWG Corp., NVF Company, Sharon Steel Corp., Pennsylvania Engineering Corp., Salem Corporation, APL Corp., Graniteville, Inc. and Southeastern Public Service Company. An active philanthropist in both Florida and Maryland, Mr. Posner was a generous supporter of causes related to children, the homeless, the arts and health care. He was a Platinum Angel of the Jackson Memorial Foundation, a founder of the Mount Sinai Medical Center, and a generous supporter of the Miami Heart Institute, the United Way, Miami Children's Hospital, The National Foundation for Advancement in the Arts, The Vizcayan Foundation, The St. Jude Children's Research Institute and the Knights of Malta. The Victor Posner Center for Communicative Disorders at the University of Miami Ear Institute and Posner Hall at Barry University are both named in his honor. He also holds an Honorary Doctor of Laws Degree from the University of Miami. Mr. Posner is survived by four children: Steven Posner, Gail Posner, Tracy Posner Ward and Lance T. Posner, seven grandchildren, five godchildren, one brother, Morton Posner, and one sister, Beatrice Cohen. Funeral services are private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Miami Heart Institute or the Victor Posner Center for Communicative Disorders at the University of Miami Ear Institute.

The performance of Beethoven's ''Eroica'' Symphony at the end was a lot happier and a lot more musical than the account of his ''Fidelio'' Overture at the start, even though the essential sound -- full, bass strong but transparent with inner parts well projected -- was much the same.

title: SCHERING-PLOUGH'S ALLERGY DRUG GETS WIDER APPROVAL

The expanded uses may attract patients now taking the medicine's predecessor, Claritin, before it loses its patent protection. Claritin, which had $3.2 billion in sales in 2001, may face generic competition by the end of the year. The medication has Food and Drug Administration approval only for treating chronic hives and outdoor allergies. Clarinex, cleared in December for outdoor allergies, now has the broadest range of approved uses among nonsedating antihistamines, the company and analysts said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALLA VILLA, RT. REV MSGR ANTHONY
description: DALLA VILLA-Rt. Rev Msgr Anthony. In life and now in death, Monsignor Anthony Dalla Villa was quintessentially a priest. Totally dedicated to his calling, he served God and the Church devotedly and without reservation throughout his life. A deeply spiritual man, he was a treasured friend and confidant to Florence D'Urso and her family. He was always there for us in times of need as a most compassionate priest; and his guidance and spiritual strength were invaluable. We shall miss him terribly; and we offer our heartfelt condolences and love to his sister Angela, and her family. We take comfort, however, in knowing that his final call could not have come at a time or place more perfectly fitting for a man whose greatest joy in life was in being a priest. I pray that Our Lady of Guadalupe and St. Therese of Lisieux, to whom Monsignor had such great devotion, gave him a special welcome. I pray too, that Our Lord greeted him saying, ''Well done, my good and faithful servant''.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Princeton: Anti-Deer-Hunt Lawsuits
description: Princeton Township officials said yesterday that they had spent $47,000 defeating lawsuits brought by animal-rights advocates seeking to block this year's deer cull. ''We have won all of our cases,' Mayor Phyllis L. Marchand said, ''but the cost is distressing.'' She also said that 300 deer, instead of 400 or more, would probably be killed by professional hunters. A warm winter and ample food means that deer have been less likely to visit bait sites where hunters have been waiting. Iver Peterson (NYT)

The organization, Permanent Offense, is being reorganized, the spokesman, Monte Benham, said. Mr. Eyman said this month that he had diverted $200,000 from the organization to a company for his own salary and had lied about it. Mr. Benham said Mr. Eyman would play a less prominent role and ''no longer controls the money.'' Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: KRISPY KREME WILL ALTER ITS ACCOUNTING FOR PLANT

Krispy Kreme, based in Winston-Salem, N.C., was accounting for the plant's financing by classifying lease payments as current expenses like salaries, rather than as a long-term obligation like other debt. The company changed the reporting because of investor concern that its financial statements were not clear enough.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEBHAR, DR. NEIL F.
description: LEBHAR-Dr. Neil F., 88. Of Vicar's Landing, Ponte Vedra Beach, Florida died February 11, 2002. Beloved husband of B. Eleanor Lebhar for almost 52 years, father of the Rev. Neil G. Lebhar of Jacksonville, Brett H. Lebhar of Cincinnati, Clay G. Lebhar of Fort Lee, NJ, stepfather of Richard H. Finnegan of New York City. Devoted grandfather of seven and great grandfather of three. A native of New York City, Dr. Lebhar was a retired pediatrician who had practiced for over 40 years in Westport, CT. Dr. Lebhar was a graduate of Blair Academy, Princeton University '35, Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons '39, He served for four years as a physician in the Army Air Corps. He had been for many years an associate professor of Pediatrics for NYU, teaching at Bellevue Hospital. The pediatric library was donated in his honor to Norwalk Hospital (CT) by his former patients, their parents and friends. The funeral and interment will be held at noon, Friday February 22 at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer, 7500 Southside Boulevard, Jacksonville, FL. For information Hardage - Giddens Funeral Home, Jacksonville Beach, FL. 904-249-2374.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANDELSMAN, RICHARD
description: HANDELSMAN-Richard, 63. Died unexpectedly Friday, February 8 in his Woodstock, Ill. home. Services were held February 11 at Congregation B'nai Torah in Highland Park, Ill. Mr. Handelsman graduated from Cornell University in 1960 with a degree in Engineering Physics. He earned his Master's and Ph.D from the Courant Institute of Mathematics. Richard worked on the communication satellite Telstar at Bell Labs and taught applied math at Brown University before becoming a full Professor of Advanced Mathematics at the University of Illinois. He co-authored the graduate level textbook ''Asymptotic Expansions of Integrals'' and published more than 50 research papers on various subjects of applied mathematics and physics. Richard was an original member of the Chicago Board Options Exchange. As member of the Board of Directors, pit trader and clearing firm owner, Mr. Handelsman was an integral force shaping the ultimate structure of the Exchange. He was a renowned expert in option trading and theory, and regarded as the originator of the ''butterfly spread.'' Richard Handelsman was a top level bridge player and earned extra money during college competing with several future Bermuda Bowl winners. Very proud and nostalgic of his Brooklyn roots, still Richard took to life in the country. He designed and built a park from a cornfield. The park became a sculpture garden of Shona stone art from Zimbabwe. Richard is survived by his wife Susan, his son Gary Handelsman, daughter Robin (Eric) Gould, sister Arlene (Jay) Gold, and his beloved dog, Dodger. He worked very hard, he was extraordinarily loyal, and he is unforgettable.

description: PRAGER-Edward. Beloved husband of Joan. Devoted father of Jacqueline and Frank Rea, and Elizabeth Prager. Loving son of Aline. Cherished brother of Judith and Sheldon Dumaine. Fond grandfather of Jason Rea. Special friend to Ellisa, Karaline and their parents Cynthia and Allan Rosen, and beloved friend of Stuart and Sandra Juskowitz. Services 11 AM Wednesday, at ''Plaza Jewish Community Chapel,'' 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Case Tying Algerian To Sept. 11 Attacks Collapses in Britain
description: An American effort to extradite an Algerian pilot on charges of direct links to the Sept. 11 hijackers collapsed today, and the pilot, once identified by American investigators as the ''lead trainer'' of the attackers, walked free on $14,200 bail.

title: House G.O.P. Leaders Push Rival Campaign Finance Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12  In a final scramble to defeat a broad overhaul of the campaign finance law, House Republican leaders struggled today to shape a rival bill and a strategy to fracture the coalition of Democrats and Republicans who want to ban unlimited contributions to the political parties.

title: News Corporation Reports a Loss
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 12 (Bloomberg News)  The News Corporation ( news/quote ), the global media company controlled by Rupert Murdoch, reported a loss of $606 million in the fiscal second quarter because of a write-down of $809 million in sports broadcast contracts and investments.

description: Ruggerio  la Mexico

title: Corrections
description: A table in Business Day on Jan. 25 listing mutual funds and companies that had invested in notes issued by Osprey, a trust created by the Enron Corporation in 1997 to finance several partnerships, misstated the amount of debt held by First American and Firstar, mutual fund families owned by U.S. Bancorp. Firstar was merged with First American in September. Combined, they held $7.8 million in debt, not $11.8 million. Firstar did not hold $3.75 million separately.

title: Congress in Search of Its Soul
description: With campaign finance reform facing its moment of decision today in the House, lawmakers must look beyond the threats, promises and distortions surrounding the Shays-Meehan bill and vote for what they know is the right thing to do. It will not be easy. After a discreet silence, President Bush is allowing his operatives to work with an ungainly alliance of unions, special-interest groups and big business to scuttle a bill that would curb the buying of influence in politics. Mr. Bush, the White House says, is not willing to join directly in the wrecking effort. Lawmakers should ask why they are being recruited to take the heat and kill reform while the president remains comfortably out of sight.

title: Uneasy Truce For Bristol And ImClone
description: ImClone Systems yesterday rejected demands by Bristol-Myers Squibb to rework their $2 billion agreement to develop and market a cancer drug. But Bristol-Myers did not immediately carry through with a threat to terminate the relationship, saying it would continue to work with ImClone at least until the companies meet with the Food and Drug Administration later this month to discuss the drug's status.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDE, ANITA
description: LANDE-Anita. On February 11, 2002. Beloved wife of Robert, loving mother of Laura Graumann and her husband Fred, Barbara Lande and John Lande. Devoted grandmother of Carol and Billy. Dear sister of David Mersten. Memorial service Thursday 3PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Lesser Lights in G.O.P. Are Lining Up to Take On Torricelli
description: What is revealing about the race for the Republican nomination to oppose Senator Robert G. Torricelli in November is not who is running but who is not.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Birthrate At Replacement Level
description: Enough babies were born in 2000 to replace their parents' generation, a milestone reached for the first time in three decades, a federal report showed. More than four million children were born in 2000, the report by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said.

title: Back to Whatever Normal Is
description: Sister Parish, the late decorator, once characterized her privileged and carefree youth by saying, ''There was no tomorrow except for what to wear tomorrow.'' It is no exaggeration to say that this dizzy (some would say heedless) attitude still has a certain currency in the fashion world today.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Economy Falls 4 Percent
description: New York City's economy slid steeply in the last quarter of 2001, even as the national economy edged upward, according to new data from the New York City comptroller's office. The comptroller calculates a measure of all the goods and services produced in the city, which it calls the gross city product, much like the gross domestic product for the nation. In the quarter that ended in December, the gross city product, figured over a full year, dropped by 4.4 percent, while the nation's economy rose by 0.2 percent. The last time that the city's economy contracted so sharply was in the second quarter of 1991, when it shrank by 6.9 percent. Personal income tax revenues, a proxy for incomes in the city, dropped a similarly steep 4.8 percent in the period, while the comparable national measure rose 2.9 percent. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

title: Plushenko Takes Tumble, Short-Circuiting Showdown
description: The helium leaked out of Yevgeny Plushenko's levitation act as he crashed in his chrome-colored costume on his opening quadruple jump, then finished his short program with the wobble of a runaway hubcap.

title: CARNIVAL ASKS SUITOR TO MEET OVER ANTITRUST ISSUES
description: The Carnival Corporation said yesterday that it had asked P&O Princess Cruises for a meeting to discuss antitrust issues related to its proposal to buy the cruise line. Carnival, which is based in Miami, said it was ''prepared to consider making such nonmaterial disposals as the regulators may require in order to obtain regulatory clearance.'' P&O Princess has said that while Carnival's takeover bid of $6.8 billion was ''realistic,'' Carnival had not addressed regulatory hurdles that could prevent a deal. P&O Princess, which is based in London, favors a merger with Royal Caribbean Cruises.

title: Bloomberg Plan Would Trim 1,600 Police Jobs via Attrition
description: In a striking signal of New York City's financial distress, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is expected to announce today that he will cut the size of the police force by trimming the jobs of 1,600 officers through attrition, according to officials who have been briefed on the mayor's budget.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Murder Suspect An Apparent Suicide
description: A suspect in the December bludgeoning death of a Bronx woman and her son has been found dead in an abandoned Newark building, the police said. The suspect, Kil Nam Kang, 43, apparently committed suicide by hanging himself with a leather dog leash, said Deputy Chief Joseph J. Reznick, commander of the Bronx detectives. New York investigators say they believe Mr. Kang beat his estranged girlfriend, Young Ja Kim, 46, and her son, Tatsuhiro Oki, 15, with the wooden leg from a kitchen table in her Bronx apartment. Mr. Kang's body was discovered during a search of the building just before its planned demolition. He may have been dead for two weeks, Chief Reznick said. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Life Outside the Barricades
description: One of the eternal questions at world sports tournaments is whether they mess up the city for the people who live there. My memory of the Summer Games in Los Angeles in 1984 is that half the citizenry went to Hawaii and therefore the freeways flowed better than usual. And Rome emptied out so much during the World Cup of soccer in 1990 that shopkeepers were moaning to my wife, "Signora, tell your husband these soccer fans dont spend any money."

title: Stocks Rise on Retail Sales Data
description: Encouraged by a better-than-expected report on retail sales, investors pushed stocks higher today on the hopes that the economy could be turning around.

title: Del Ponte's Words: 'An Almost Medieval Savagery'
description: Following are excerpts from the opening statements of Carla Del Ponte, chief prosecutor, and Geoffrey Nice, lead prosecutor, in the trial of Slobodan Milosevic at The Hague. Mrs. Del Ponte's full statement, as provided by the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia, is available on the Web at nytimes .com/world. The tribunal did not provide a transcript of Mr. Nice's remarks, which were transcribed by The New York Times from a tape recording of the proceedings.

title: SALT LAKE 2002
description: 4TH WITH FLAIR -- Jonny Moseley hit his Dinner Roll but didn't win a medal. PAGE D2

title: The Struggle to Find Enough Teaching Mentors
description: After teaching mathematics in the Bronx for two decades, Milagros Betharte had become a therapist of sorts for new teachers at her school, doling out instructional advice and much-needed emotional support. So when her school district started a formal mentoring program to help first-year teachers, Ms. Betharte was a natural for the job.

title: Decision Day for a Score of Undecided Republicans
description: Most of the two dozen or so House Republicans who profess to be undecided about how to vote on the campaign finance legislation on Wednesday were not talking today, at least not publicly.

title: Waylon Jennings, Country Singer, Dies at 64
description: NASHVILLE, Tenn. -- Waylon Jennings, who defined the outlaw movement in country music, died Wednesday after a long battle with diabetes-related health problems. He was 64.

title: MILACRON, EQUIPMENT MAKER, PLANS TO CLOSE 14 PLANTS
description: Milacron Inc., a maker of equipment used to mold plastics, said it would eliminate about 1,150 jobs, or 11 percent of its work force, and close 14 plants because of falling demand. The company, based in Cincinnati, expects to complete most of the cuts by midyear. Milacron has about 10,000 employees, a spokesman, Al Beaupre, said. The restructuring, which is expected to have a pretax cost of about $8 million, is projected to save $40 million a year. Milacron said that its fourth-quarter loss narrowed to $21.9 million, from $22 million a year earlier. Sales fell 21 percent, to $305.5 million from $388.8 million.

title: Founder of Barnes & Noble to Step Down as Chief Executive
description: Leonard Riggio, founder, chairman and chief executive of the Barnes & Noble ( news/quote ), is stepping down as chief executive and naming his brother, Stephen Riggio, to succeed him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITLER, ERNEST ALBERT
description: MITLER-Ernest Albert. Died peacefully on February 12, 2002. Graduate of Yale, Columbia Law School, Oxford University. Former District Attorney, NY, Professor of Law, Westminister College, Missouri. Survived by loving family, devoted friend Harriet Garber, and many loyal students. Memorial to be announced.

title: Turkey Will Not 'Tolerate' Unilateral U.S. Action Against Iraq
description: ANKARA, Feb 13 (AFP) - Turkey warned its top ally the United States on Wednesday that it would not agree to any unilateral military action against neighboring Iraq, which Washington has described as part of an "axis of evil".

title: Swiss Rail Discounts
description: Rail Europe's Swiss Youthpass, a new rail pass for travelers under 26, starts at $120 in second class and $184 in first for four consecutive days of unlimited travel (the regular pass costs $160 in second class and $245 in first). Another new pass from the Swiss is good for groups of two to five people traveling together: from $136 a person in second class for four days and from $208 a person for four days in first class. New this year for Swiss rail-pass holders are discounts on ski and bike rentals, rooms at participating hotels and guided city tours, among other things. There have been price increases on some Swiss passes. Ask for the free Swiss Family Card when buying any Rail Europe Swiss pass; it allows children under 16 to ride the trains free with an adult. These passes must be bought in the United States. Information: (888) 382-7245 or on the Web at www.raileurope.com .

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Central Bank Still Downbeat
description: The Bank of Japan left its basic view of the economy unchanged in its monthly report, saying that overall conditions continue to deteriorate. Looking ahead, the central bank said it saw signs that the current recession would not deepen further, although only a mild recovery is expected. Exports, the bank said, might begin rising over the next six months, offsetting some of the tough conditions at home, which include further declines in corporate capital spending. The central bank left monetary policy unchanged at its two-day meeting last week. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Sweet Sugar and Trouble: The Lowdown on Lovin'
description: They're singing the blues at the John Houseman Theater. That statement is not a report of a complaint but a description of the little show that occupies the house on Saturday and Sunday afternoons at 3 and Monday nights at 8.

description: A subheading yesterday with a Books of The Times review of ''The Eyre Affair'' by Jasper Fforde misstated the given name of the heroine. She is Thursday Next, as the review said, not Tuesday.

title: Special Legal Team Formed To Handle Detainee Suits
description: The Justice Department has created a special team of lawyers headed by Solicitor General Theodore B. Olson to oversee all court challenges to the government's policy of detaining terrorism suspects indefinitely on an American military base in Cuba, administration officials said today.

title: Levy's Communications Director Is Resigning
description: KAREN FINNEY, director of communications for Chancellor Harold O. Levy, will resign on Friday after less than a year on the job. Ms. Finney, who was the press secretary for Hillary Rodham Clinton's Senate campaign before joining Mr. Levy's staff, is moving to Scholastic Inc., where she will be director of business development. She previously worked for Scholastic as chief of staff to the company's chairman. Although Mr. Levy's contract expires in June and the Board of Education has not yet moved to extend it, Ms. Finney said her departure was based on personal reasons and was not a sign that Mr. Levy was on his way out. Mr. Levy has named CATIE MARSHALL, Ms. Finney's deputy, as acting communications director.

description: NORTHWEST

title: Single, Perverse Prig, 68, Seeks Comely Young Lass
description: While 20 blocks uptown chorus girls and puppet beasts are turning stages into dazzling spectacles, at the Irish Repertory Theater two experienced actors are proving that a simple idea well executed can capture the attention just as effectively.

title: The Phases of Love in an 18th-Century Setting
description: No one seems to know what globilization really means, but a helpful description on Saturday night was the sight of French Baroque opera rising out of the soft, flat farmland of northern Ohio. And not only opera, virtually unknown opera: ''Le Pouvoir de l'Amour'' by Pancrace Royer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIIG, ROY
description: WIIG-Roy. Of White Plains, NY, on February 11th, 2002, age 78. Born on Staten Island, New York. A veteran of WW II, graduate of City College, completed graduate studies at Harvard, employed by I.B.M. for 33 years. Survived by Elaine Wiig, David Wiig, Caroline Margagliano, John Wiig, Elsa Wiig Denno, and five grandchildren. Predeceased by Helen Wiig Loery. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions to WNYC Radio. Private services will be held by his family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBERG, FANNY
description: GINSBERG-Fanny. On February 11, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Lawrence. Devoted mother of Robert. Loving grandmother of Nan Foster and Dr. Robert Foster. Great grandmother of Matthew and Dylan. Graveside services on Friday, at 11 A.M. at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Seat Belt Use Urged
description: Federal transportation safety officials gathered in the Bronx yesterday to urge Hispanic parents to use seat belts and other restraints for their children. Officials cited recent data reporting that automobile accidents are the leading cause of death for Hispanics as young as 1 year old. Dr. Jeffrey W. Runge, of the National Highway Safety Administration, noted that this differed from non-Hispanic whites, for whom car accidents are the leading cause of death for children 4 and older. The report suggested, he said, that Hispanic parents needed to be more vigilant about using child safety seats. Randy Kennedy (NYT)

title: A Unique Pig, and Its Rare Cousins
description: WHEN the 5:24 p.m. from Grand Central pulls into Mount Kisco at 6:16, not every commuter heads straight to a waiting car. Some go inside the train station to buy dinner.

title: Review/Fashion; From Marc Jacobs, A Ball of Confusion
description: Among the hundreds in fashion's militia who filed into the Marc Jacobs show on Monday night were those who vividly recalled the eeriness surrounding the designer's last presentation. Mr. Jacobs offered his spring 2002 collection on the night of Sept. 10. For some in the fashion pack, the show that had Monica Lewinsky in the front row, and the crowded party that followed it, became the most immediate symbol of the excess and self-interest that characterized habits before the attacks. At least one woman who made the tiring exit from Mr. Jacobs's event at the Hudson River piers that night would lose her husband in the morning.

title: Excerpts From the Senate Committee Hearing on the Collapse of Enron
description: Following are excerpts from a hearing yesterday of the Senate Commerce, Science and Transportation Committee into the collapse of the Enron Corporation at which Enron's former chief executive, Kenneth L. Lay, invoked his right against self-incrimination, as recorded by Federal News Service Inc. Among the senators making statements were John McCain, Republican of Arizona; Peter G. Fitzgerald, Republican of Illinois; John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts; John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana; Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon; Olympia J. Snowe, Republican of Maine; Barbara Boxer, Democrat of California; Jean Carnahan, Democrat of Missouri; George F. Allen, Republican of Virginia; and Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: E.U. Ministers Set VAT Plan
description: European finance ministers agreed yesterday on a plan for collecting value-added tax on online sales to consumers of digital products like computer software and services like pay television. Under the proposed system, companies based outside of the European Union, which currently pay no VAT on sales to customers there, would pay the VAT rate in the country where their customers are. Companies within the union will continue to pay VAT at their local rates. The rules, which are due to become law throughout the union by summer of next year, have drawn criticism from the United States office of the trade representative, which contends that the rules discriminate against companies based outside the European Union. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Obscure Olympic Event Energizes a Utah City
description: This is a working-class town, gritty and proud, less a bedroom community for Salt Lake City, 35 miles south, than its own master, with an economic base of heavy industry, small businesses and government jobs.
