description: The husband and wife who founded the Body Shop International chain of health and beauty stores resigned today as co-chairmen after failing to find a buyer for the company.

They were asked by Cliff Stearns, Republican of Florida, not James C. Greenwood, Republican of Pennsylvania.

title: Kurt Gutenbrunner
description: POPPY seeds can add lots of character to a dish, especially if you use a good quantity of them, not just a sprinkling like you find on a bagel. I love mixing them with buttered noodles and a plain cheese like fromage blanc. They give texture, a bit of dark contrast and a smart element of nutty flavor.

description: You did not need to see the scoreboard late in the second period today to figure out how things were evolving in the women's hockey game between the United States and Germany.

title: Safety Agency Rejects Request To Investigate Ford Explorer
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration today denied a request by Bridgestone/Firestone to investigate safety defects in the Ford Explorer, saying crash data indicated that the Explorer was not markedly different from comparable sport utility vehicles.

description: Campaign Money Battle

title: Minaya, Robinson, Tavares Will Now Run the Expos
description: The Montreal Expos moved to South Florida yesterday, lock, stock and baseball operations people. When the smoke had cleared from the sale of the Marlins to the owner of the doomed Montreal Expos and the sale of the Expos to Major League Baseball, the new Montreal officials had a roster of players but only a handful of front-office employees to call their own.

title: A Prosciutto Bonus With the Vino Rosso
description: There's often an extra treat in store for those who stop at Italian Wine Merchants, 108 East 16th Street (owned by Mario Batali, Joseph Bastianich and Sergio Esposito), for an informal Saturday afternoon tasting. To complement a sprightly Orvieto or a lusty Amarone, there may be rosy slices of salami, satiny prosciutto, peppery coppa and other pork products cured, Italian style, by Dan Latham in the kitchen behind the shop. Mr. Batali, whose father, Armandino, is a salami maker in Seattle, oversees the production. The meats, made from the pork of free-range Vermont pigs, include a delicious rolled pancetta with cured fillet of pork in the center, and a sweetly tangy sopressa salami. The meats are not sold, but they are served during the weekly wine classes given by Mr. Esposito.

title: Man Held After College Hostage Standoff
description: A recent graduate of Fairfield University in Connecticut who claimed he was carrying a bomb took a classroom full of students there hostage yesterday afternoon, the police said. He released them gradually during the evening, with the last one leaving the building around 10:10 p.m.

title: Russian Supreme Court Strikes Down Military Secrecy Order
description: Russia's Supreme Court handed civil-liberties advocates here a potentially crucial victory tonight, striking down a 1996 military secrecy order used to convict the journalist Grigory Pasko and other state gadflies of espionage and treason.

title: Settlement Reached In Overbilling Case
description: The White House Office of National Drug Control Policy and Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide in New York, part of the WPP Group, have reached a $1.8 million settlement with the civil division of the Justice Department on charges that Ogilvy overbilled the drug office for work on its account.

title: Enron's Ex-Chief Harshly Criticized by Senate Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12  After being subjected to a bipartisan oral barrage from 21 senators, Kenneth L. Lay, the former chairman of Enron , asserted his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination today and pleaded with members of the Senate Commerce Committee not to rush to judgment about his responsibility for the largest corporate bankruptcy case in American history.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; In 30 months, two top executives at Tyco made hundreds of millions of dollars selling the stock.
description: SINCE July 1999, Tyco International's two top executives have made more than $500 million in profits by selling Tyco shares, while saying publicly that they rarely, if ever, reduce their holdings.

title: A Taste of the Town, Bittersweet; Why Twist Arms?
description: To the Editor:

title: Once a Luxury, Diamond Rings Now Overflow Bargain Tables
description: Americans shopping for Valentine's Day this year are being swamped with offers of diamonds at prices low enough to compete with a bouquet of long-stemmed roses.

title: United Mechanics Reject Contract Proposal
description: Mechanics at United Airlines voted overwhelmingly last night to reject a contract settlement proposed by a White House-appointed panel, raising the possibility of new labor turmoil at the carrier.

title: Will the Real Shakespeare Please Stand Up? Sorry. Dead, You Know.
description: Michael Rubbo's eccentric's-eye-view of the Shakespeare-Wasn'tShakespeare faction is the subject of his Betacam documentary ''Much Ado About Something,'' a likable dissection of single-mindness that begins a run today at Film Forum. Mr. Rubbo, who wrote the film as well as directed it, finds these obsessives attractive. With their societies and detailed explanations why William Shakespeare actually didn't write Shapespeare's plays, these investigators are certainly great subjects for filmmakers.

title: A Duo Deprived
description: At the Salt Lake City Winter Olympics, there is an array of technologies devoted to portraying the hidden dimensions of athletic performance in ways never quite seen before. But when all is said and done, success or failure rests, in one sport at least, on the most fleeting of impressions. That sport is figure skating, and the impressions that count are those flashing through the judges' minds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECKER, MARVIN
description: HECKER-Marvin. The Board of Governors and members of Montammy Golf Club express their deepest sorrow at the passing of their beloved member and extend their heartfelt sympathy to Iris and the entire family. Kenneth R. Orr, President

title: American Miller Makes Remarkable Comeback
description: HUNTSVILLE, Utah, Feb. 13  It was not over for Bode Miller. No race this year is ever over so long as Miller has at least one more shot at the leaders.

title: German Joins Europe's Cry That the U.S. Won't Consult
description: The German foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, warned the Bush administration today not to treat American allies like satellite states in some new empire or to move unilaterally against countries like Iraq. His remarks added a prominent voice to a new wave of anxious Continental criticism of Washington's post-Afghanistan foreign policy.

title: Making the Most of an Hour For an Afternoon of Songs
description: You can do a lot in an hour. Whole television dramas fit into less. On Sunday afternoon, the young baritone Keith Phares demonstrated that an hour is a good length for a recital. In the elegant salon of the Kosciuszko Foundation, he offered a nice program, borne ''on wings of song'' by the Marilyn Horne Foundation (which so titles its series) and, more concretely, by a solid performance by his accompanist, Michael Baitzer.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Snow Relief Sought For Buffalo
description: Gov. George E. Pataki asked President Bush yesterday to declare Erie County a major disaster area. The designation would make the towns hit hard by late December snowstorms eligible for federal disaster assistance. In a separate appeal, the governor also asked the federal Small Business Association to issue a physical-damage declaration for the county, which would make low-interest loans available to renters as well as home and business owners hurt by the storms. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: The Axis Of No Access
description: Back in the 60's, my brother would occasionally pretend to be a spy to impress girls.

description: WEISS-Bernard. Remembering you today and every day with love. Sash

title: AT&T Is Moving 70 Jobs From Lower Manhattan
description: The AT&T Corporation is moving about 70 technical jobs from Lower Manhattan to White Plains, and union leaders and several City Council members are protesting the move as a betrayal of Manhattan.

title: Devils Go Into Break With a Tie
description: There was a sweet reward awaiting the Devils once last night's 2-2 tie was over, a two-week break, courtesy of the Winter Olympics, until their next game Feb. 26 against the Rangers.

title: Crazier Than Thou
description: Reading Europe's press, it is really reassuring to see how warmly Europeans have embraced President Bush's formulation that an ''axis of evil'' threatens world peace. There's only one small problem. President Bush thinks the axis of evil is Iran, Iraq and North Korea, and the Europeans think it's Donald Rumsfeld, Dick Cheney and Condi Rice.

title: Making a Mountain Out of a Dinner Roll
description: Jonny Moseley had them all 14,237 who came to see America's counterculture ski bum toy with gravity, maybe life and certainly limb. He catapulted from a moguls jump, spun two revolutions with his body nearly inverted and landed flawlessly.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Khmer Rouge Trial, Even Without U.N.
description: The government's negotiator said Cambodia would set up a genocide tribunal -- with or without the United Nations -- to try former leaders of the Khmer Rouge, who are blamed for the deaths of more than a million people. The negotiator, Sok An, said Cambodia was open to new talks with the United Nations, which pulled out last week, saying the planned tribunal could not guarantee impartiality. Prime Minister Hun Sen also urged the United Nations to reconsider its decision, but said his government might procede on its own. Cambodia and the United Nations had agreed on a framework for holding trials in Cambodia with local and foreign judges, but critics said the plan relied too heavily on Cambodia's politicized judiciary. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, AUSTIN J.
description: BROWN-Austin J. Of Emerson, New Jersey, former employee of The American Lung Association, former Country Director of The United States Peace Corp (Uganda and Gambia) Africa Service Institute, the African American Institute and the Institute of International Education. Died Saturday, February 9, 2002. He is survived by his wife, Sonia, of Bergen Community College, and his son, Peter. Family will receive friends on Friday, February 15, from 3-5 and 7-9 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Funeral Mass Saturday, 10 AM, at the Assumption Church, 29 Jefferson Ave., Emerson, NJ. Entombment to follow at the Garden of Memories, Paramus, New Jersey. There will be an opportunity for further viewing at 9:30 AM prior to the mass at the church.

title: A New President at DeVry Institute Campus
description: DIANE ENGELHARDT, the former president of the Katharine Gibbs School in Melville, N.Y., has become president of the DeVry Institute of Technology campus in Long Island City. Previously, Ms. Engelhardt, 46, founded and led International Technology Development, a company specializing in business and aerospace electronics education. Established in late 1998, the Long Island City campus now has more than 2,000 students studying accounting, business administration, computer technology and other technical fields. ROGER C. ANDERSEN, the former president, left last spring and is now senior vice president and chief operating officer at Heald College in San Francisco. Karen W. Arenson

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hand-Held Market Avoids PC Slump
description: Makers of hand-held computers last year avoided the slump that hit the personal computer market, as the number of personal digital assistants rose 18 percent in 2001, according to a report scheduled for release today. Dataquest, a division of Gartner Inc., said 13.1 million hand-held computers were sold last year, up from 11.1 million the previous year. The annual gain came despite lower fourth-quarter sales, which declined 2 percent from a year earlier but were better than expected because of price cuts as manufacturers tried to clear out old models. Palm held the top spot, with 39 percent of the global market -- three times the share of Handspring, ranked second -- but its share fell from 50 percent in 2000. Compaq, in third place, and Hewlett-Packard in fourth, which make more expensive hand-held computers for corporate customers, gained the most ground and ''are the only vendors making decent profits in this market today,'' Dataquest said. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEFF, MARY ALICE
description: NEFF-Mary Alice. Age 88. Died February 4, 2002 in Manhattan, where she had resided since 1939, after a long illness. Survived by her husband, Richard B. Neff, and son, Richard B. title: Dealer Is Guilty of Selling Stolen Egyptian Art
description: A prominent New York antiquities dealer was convicted yesterday in federal court on a charge of conspiring to sell ancient artifacts that had been illegally taken out of Egypt.

title: Beyond the Split: The Bakeable Banana
description: A BANANA may have the slouch of a rock star and a cool leather jacket, but it is treated like an average Joe. Tossed into a briefcase or lunchbox, slid across the seat of a car and eaten on the fly, the banana is so neat, so tidy, so portable, it barely registers. Yet when baked, this out-of-the-starting-gate snack achieves an eloquence that is persuasive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARHAM, JAMES W.
description: PARHAM-James W. Port Authority Police Officer, a fallen hero, at the World Trade Center, September 11, 2001. Funeral service, 10AM Thursday, February 14, at Conway Funeral Home, 82-19 Northern Blvd., Jackson Heights. Interment Calverton National Cemetery.

title: October Strike on Taliban Hit Civilians, Survivors Say
description: When a bomb landed just outside his home, blowing out windows and demolishing a wall, Qudratullah decided that his family should flee. Theirs was a panicked attempt to leave the area of Tirin Kot, a Taliban stronghold in southern Afghanistan that was being bombed that October night.

title: COMFORT SYSTEMS SELLS 19 UNITS TO EMCOR
description: Comfort Systems USA Inc., which installs and services heating, ventilation and air-conditioning systems, plans to sell 19 business units to the Emcor Group for about $186.3 million. Comfort Systems, based in Houston, also said its president, Gary E. Hess, 54, would retire on April 1. The units being acquired by Emcor, a provider of mechanical and electrical construction services in Norwalk, Conn., had sales of about $650 million last year, Comfort Systems said. They are mostly in the Midwest and the New York City area. About $160 million of the proceeds will go to reducing debt, Comfort Systems said.

title: Texas Casino Shut Down As Hope for Reprieve Dies
description: By midnight on Monday the jingle of 1,500 slot machines had been stilled, felt-covered tables had been cleared of chips and poker hands, and overflowing trash buckets were stacked where bingo players had earlier pored over ''Krazy Kash'' jackpot cards, hoping for a blackout.

title: Lord of the Oscars: Fantasy Is Big Nominee; 'Beautiful Mind' and 'In the Bedroom' Also on List
description: A three-hour epic about elves, dwarfs, wizards and small, hairy-footed hobbits that is just the first chapter in a trilogy of films dominated the 74th annual Academy Award nominations this morning, coming away with 13.

title: Spain Decides to Fine Deloitte Over Audit of Failed Concern
description: Spanish authorities have decided to fine the accounting firm Deloitte & Touche 540,000 euros ($473,000) in connection with the collapse last summer of one of its audit clients, Gescartera S.A., a Madrid brokerage firm. In proportion to Deloitte's total revenue in the country, it is the most severe fine Spain has ever imposed on a Big Five auditing firm, analysts said.

title: Deal for British Auto Seller
description: The United Auto Group, the third-biggest auto retailer in the nation, said today that it had offered to buy a British luxury-car retailer, the Sytner Group. United Auto offered $135 million in cash and the assumption of about $20 million of Sytner's debt. It added that it expected the transaction to close at the end of this quarter. Sytner will have sales of about $850 million in the fiscal year ending this month, United Auto said.

title: Yankee Success Evolves Into Security for Torre
description: Joe Torre began his seventh spring training as the Yankees' manager today, and he was startled by the realization. It seemed like yesterday, Torre said, that he was just beginning his Yankees career, having failed to win a pennant as the manager of three other teams.

title: New Evidence of Cancer Risk In Hormone Therapy Study
description: A new study adds to the increasing evidence that women who take hormone therapy for five years or more after menopause have an increased risk of breast cancer, especially a type known as lobular tumors, which account for 5 percent to 10 percent of all breast cancers.

Lay, the former chairman of Enron, asserted his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination today and pleaded with members of the Senate Commerce Committee not to rush to judgment about his responsibility for the largest corporate bankruptcy case in American history.

description: Silence grew eloquent when the New York City Ballet presented Jerome Robbins's ''Moves'' on Thursday night at the New York State Theater.

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Japanese Newsman Repatriated
description: Apparently in a good-will gesture, North Korea has returned to Japan a former newspaper reporter, Takashi Sugishima, who was detained more than two years ago on spying charges. Mr. Sugishima, now 62, had just retired from Japan's leading business newspaper, Nihon Kezai Shimbun, when he was seized in December 1999 after a tape recorder and a camera were found in his possession. North Korea and Japan do not have diplomatic ties, and relations were strained recently when Japan sank a suspected North Korean spy boat and arrested ethnic Korean officers of a Japanese bank linked to North Korea. James Brooke (NYT)

title: Swiss Jumper Wins Second Gold
description: PARK CITY, Utah, Feb. 13  Simon Ammann discovered flight while in his teens. It happened near the home village of the renowned ski jumper Walter Steiner, a Swiss woodcarver who won a silver medal in the 1972 Winter Games in Japan. The reclusive Steiner had long since moved to Sweden, but his practice hill was still there in his native country, its glistening slopes still fertile ground for another airborne prodigy.

title: Free Speech and Enron Play In Debate Over Soft Money
description: House Republicans opened a furious attack on landmark campaign finance legislation today, calling it a sham that would not really ban the unlimited contributions known as soft money and instead would just restrict free speech.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Fujitsu And Accenture Link Up
description: The technology consultant Accenture Ltd. and one of Japan's largest computer makers, Fujitsu Ltd., will work together to build and manage computer systems. The two companies have no plans to form a joint venture, but the Nihon Keizai Shimbun said Fujitsu expected its work with Accenture to bring in an additional 200 billion yen ($1.5 billion) in revenue over the next three years. Fujitsu and rivals like the NEC Corporation are trying to increase their offerings of services and software to decrease their reliance on sales of hardware. Ken Belson (NYT)

description: ONLY a fool or a columnist -- the two are often interchangeable -- would choose sides in a dispute over New York real estate.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Equipment Maker Has A Loss
description: Applied Materials, the world's largest supplier of chip-making equipment, reported a narrow first-quarter loss yesterday as sales declined 58 percent from the year-earlier period. The company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., lost $45 million, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter ended Jan. 27, in contrast to a $157 million profit the year before. Excluding one-time items, Applied Materials earned 2 cents a share, beating Wall Street's expectation of a break-even quarter. For the first time in a year, new orders rose slightly over the previous quarter, and the company said it expected them to rise again this quarter. James C. Morgan, the chairman and chief executive, said he saw signs of a recovery, but not for at least several more quarters. ''It's still challenging out there,'' he said in an interview. ''We're scratching for every order.'' Job cuts and factory closings helped offset the decline in sales, which fell to $1 billion, from $2.36 billion a year earlier. Chris Gaither (NYT)

description: Carol Boggess says she was ''eager and willing to serve'' on the jury in the 1986 capital murder trial of Thomas Miller-El in Dallas. When questioned by prosecutors, Ms. Boggess, an occupational therapist, said she strongly supported capital punishment and ''had no doubt at all'' that she could sentence a person to death.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: F.T.C. Cites 'Spam' Scheme
description: The Federal Trade Commission said it had settled charges against seven people for operating illegal e-mail schemes that promised quick and easy money. The defendants sent chain letters with slight variations of the same message: $46,000 or more within 90 days. The messages, which claimed to be legal, drew in more than 2,000 people from nearly 60 countries, the agency said. Some of the letters even urged recipients to check their legitimacy with the F.T.C., which has begun a broad effort to stop unsolicited and deceptive e-mail messages, often called spam, officials said. ''Almost everyone with an e-mail account gets spam,'' said Timothy J. Muris, above, chairman of the agency. ''It's intrusive, unwelcome, and annoying. Deceptive junk e-mail is also illegal.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, ELISABETH LUCE
description: MOORE-Elisabeth Luce. On February 9, 2002, age 98, in New York City. She was the wife of the late Maurice T. Moore, the mother of Michael Moore and the late M. Thompson Moore, Jr. and the sister of the late Henry R. Luce. Born in Teng Chou, Shandong, China of missionary parents. She attended Abbott Academy and Wellesley College, of which she was a trustee. Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller appointed her chairman of the State University of New York. She was a trustee of China Institute in America, the Asia Foundation and the National Board of the Y.W.C.A. She was president of the United Board for Christian Education in Asia and chairman of the Institute of International Education. For sixty-three years she was a director of the Henry Luce Foundation, Inc. A memorial service will be held on a date to be announced. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Brick Presbyterian Church, 8 East 91 St., New York, NY will be welcomed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIPS, WALTER F. JR.
description: GIPS-Walter F. Jr. The American Jewish Committee mourns with deepest regret and sadness the death of Walter Gips, an Honorary Vice President, beloved member of our Board of Governors, and Past Treasurer. Since 1951, Walter served AJC in numerous national leadership capacities. He was also active in AJC's Central New Jersey Chapter and was honored in 1991 with its Philip Forman Human Relations Award. Walter was a thoughtful, beneficent man of great warmth and wisdom, who sought to use his gifts for the betterment of Jews the world over, and all people of goodwill. We will sorely miss his contagious love of life, and his friendship. We send our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Ann, his children, Terry, Rob, Don, and Ellen, his grandchildren, and the rest of the grieving family. Harold Tanner, President David A. Harris, Executive Director

title: Taking a Lover's Sweet Tooth to Heart
description: I had to be convinced. But a few sips of ChocolaTea, made by Serendipitea of Long Island City, Queens, overcame my initial skepticism about chocolate-flavored tea. The company, which supplies teas to some high-end New York restaurants, makes three kinds. The chocolate in the black tea intensified the tea without overwhelming it. Another variety, Cocoa Loco, is a mixture of rooibos, a fruity South African herbal tea, with chocolate and vanilla bits. It had rich, spicy nuances. A third variety adds some mint to the rooibos. Interesting, but not, quite literally, my cup of tea. I was surprised Serendipitea does not make a green tea with chocolate, because to my palate strong green tea has almost chocolate overtones. ChocolaTea might be just the right Valentine's Day gift for the chocolate and tea lovers on your list. The rooibos blends are $10 for four ounces, and the black tea is $10 for three ounces, plus shipping, from (888) 832-5433 and www.serendipitea.com. The teas are also sold at Zabar's.

title: Love Story, With Arms Outstretched
description: ''Israel Non-Stop'' was what the Jewish Community Center in Manhattan called its program on Sunday at the John Jay College Theater. The festivities began at 2 p.m. and were to last six hours, with spectators coming and going as they pleased. The event was subtitled ''A Marathon of Music, Theater and Dance.''

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Beating Case Shakes Up Police
description: Eight white police officers in Montgomery have resigned and three others have been placed on administrative leave as officials investigate a black 17-year-old's report that officers beat him. The officers involved in the case worked the midnight shift. The youth, Billy Holloway, said he was handcuffed and beaten after approaching officers who had stopped his guardian. Information on the case has been turned over the F.B.I., the Alabama Bureau of Investigation and the county prosecutor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, IDA

She leaves behind children, grandchildren and great grandchildren who loved her and will always remember her. Love, Vicky and Gordon

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Aid For Battery Park City
description: Households in Battery Park City, hard hit by the Sept. 11 terror attack, will each receive nearly $2,000 in disaster relief as early as June, officials said. The money, about $15.6 million in all, will come from the Battery Park City Authority, the state agency that collects rent and payments from landlords in the downtown development. Each household will receive about $1,845, said James F. Gill, the authority's chairman. The authority also said it was pursuing $13 million withheld by more than 2,000 condominium owners who want their ground leases renegotiated and taxes lowered. The withheld payments are a combination of taxes, ground rents and civic facilities fees. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Moody's Is Cool To Ratings Change
description: Moody's Investors Service is backing away from a proposal to raise and lower credit assessments more often, bowing to pressure from investors who said the plan would make bond prices too volatile.

title: Nortel Says Orders Are Slow and Key Product Is Delayed
description: Nortel Networks said today that demand for its telecommunications equipment had been softer than expected and that delivery of a crucial new switching product had been delayed.

title: Biomedical Engineering Department at CUNY
description: The City University of New York has approved the creation of a department of biomedical engineering at City College, CUNY's first new engineering department since the computer science department was added in 1968. The biomedical program will accept 25 freshmen in the fall and expects to offer 20 scholarships, which will include free tuition for four years as well as $17,000 in stipends and expense money for research in the junior and senior years, said SHELDON WEINBAUM, a CUNY distinguished professor in mechanical engineering and one of the program's architects. title: Levy's Communications Director Is Resigning
description: KAREN FINNEY, director of communications for Chancellor Harold O. Levy, will resign on Friday after less than a year on the job. Ms. Finney, who was the press secretary for Hillary Rodham Clinton's Senate campaign before joining Mr. Levy's staff, is moving to Scholastic Inc., where she will be director of business development. She previously worked for Scholastic as chief of staff to the company's chairman. Although Mr. Levy's contract expires in June and the Board of Education has not yet moved to extend it, Ms. Finney said her departure was based on personal reasons and was not a sign that Mr. Levy was on his way out. Mr. Levy has named CATIE MARSHALL, Ms. Finney's deputy, as acting communications director. Abby Goodnough

title: The Soup That Ate Manhattan

It comes in a tall bowl completely covered by a crunchy sheet of melted cheese, and topped with a mound of crme frache, black truffles and celery leaves. Your first few spoonfuls are spent trying to figure out how to get through the fripperies and into the soup.

title: Briefly Noted
description: DISCUSSING SURRENDER More than 15 top Taliban leaders, most of them ex-cabinet members, are in contact with Afghan authorities in Kandahar over their possible surrender, according to Khalid Pashtun, a senior aide to Gov. Gul Agha Shirzai. Asked whether the Taliban's supreme leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, was among them, he said: "No. He knows the consequences if he surrenders." But security officials said they hoped that the Taliban leaders could provide information to track down Mullah Omar, and even help locate Osama bin Laden. (Reuters)

title: A Straight Man Who Won't Dwell on the Bad Stuff
description: BIFF HENDERSON crosses himself before eating, and it's a good thing, since what he's having for breakfast could kill him: an egg and sausage sandwich. It's a rare 55-year-old man in New York City who will consent to being in the same room with that much cholesterol, but there is Mr. Henderson, sometime straight man on ''Late Show With David Letterman,'' dispatching it with gusto in the green room.

title: Upgrading of Jewish Educators Is Sought
description: Dr. ISMAR SCHORSCH, the chancellor of the Jewish Theological Seminary in Manhattan, says the climate is right to attract an improved generation of Jewish educators: Young, unemployed people are considering further schooling and, in the aftermath of Sept. 11, many are on a quest for spirituality. To help solve a shortage of good teachers, the seminary has designated $1.5 million in fellowships that will let students attend its two-year masters in Jewish education program tuition free and has created a $3 million rabbinical school fellowship fund to cover four years of tuition for about 10 students beginning in September. Dr. Schorsch attributes the current lack of strong quality among Jewish educators to postgraduate debt that, coupled with entry-level salaries, makes careers in Jewish education unattractive.

description: Liberty Media ( news/quote ) has begun to scout for new acquisition targets in Europe as John Malone's media group has all but given up on hopes of receiving regulatory clearance for its proposed E5.5bn ($4.8bn) acquisition of German cable assets.

title: Technically Speaking, It Was Canada
description: The two top teams from Monday night's pairs free skate were both beautiful to watch, according to Ron Ludington, a United States coach of many Olympic pairs, but the Canadian team outshone the Russians in the technical difficulty and execution of the moves they tried. The judges saw this, as six of the nine judges awarded the Canadian pair higher technical marks. In a controversial decision, five judges ultimately put the Russian team on top on the basis of the presentation mark, a grade of the pair's unison and style. Here is how Ludington broke down the two performances. ARCHIE TSE

title: Prospects Improve for a Bronx Charter School
description: Prospects are looking brighter for a grass-roots group of educators -- friends from their days at Ivy League schools and working as teachers -- who have been trying to start the Bronx Charter School for the Arts in a former factory building in Hunts Point. The group's application was rebuffed in November by the State Education Department, which said that while the academic plan was sound, the group needed a guarantee of $500,000 in startup money. XANTHE JORY, the Stanford graduate and Teach for America alumna leading the effort, began losing hope. Now Ms. Jory has resubmitted the plan, including approval for a $500,000 bank loan, a promise by the landlord to spread out the cost of renovations and an increase in student enrollment that will bring in more operating aid. Some state Regents, who must give final approval to the application, appear to be coming around. Anemona Hartocollis

title: AIDS Fund Falls Short of Goal And U.S. Is Given Some Blame
description: Nine months after Secretary General Kofi Annan called on wealthy nations to contribute at least $7 billion a year to a global fund to fight AIDS, donations have fallen far short of that goal. Advocates and some lawmakers blame the White House, saying its pledge of $200 million this year sets a poor example for other countries.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Eastman Chemical's decision to abandon a plan to break into two companies misstated the company's revenue for 2001. It was $5.4 billion, not $4.5 billion.

description: MAYO - SMITH - Margaret. The Board of Trustees of the Friends of John Jay Homestead mourns the loss of our friend and colleague, Margaret. Her vision and leadership inspired us all.

description: The European Union backed down today from sending Germany a politically embarrassing official warning about the size of its budget deficit, instead accepting new commitments from Germany, its largest member, to put its budget in order.

description: You won't find a sterling-silver chocolate set for sale at 401 Fifth Avenue in Manhattan like the one given to F. Scott and Zelda Fitzgerald as a wedding gift, nor a 16.25-carat heart-shaped diamond and platinum ring like the one Reginald Claypoole Vanderbilt bought there for his fiance, Gloria Morgan.

description: President Bush is very likely to meet with Hu Jintao, the man expected to take over as China's supreme leader, during the president's trip to Asia next week, an administration official said today.

description: HIGGINS-Margaret, nee Canny, February 12, 2002, at her home in Bronxville, NY. Wife of Edward M. Higgins (d. 1997). title: Power Drove Milosevic to Crime, Prosecutors Say as Trial Opens
description: The chief prosecutor of the United Nations war crimes tribunal today accused the ousted Yugoslav leader Slobodan Milosevic of committing genocide and other crimes against humanity out of a pure lust for power that eventually wrecked his country and killed more than 200,000 people.

title: Victor Posner, 83, Master of Hostile Takeover
description: Victor Posner, a corporate raider whose exploits over three decades earned him a place in the rogue's gallery of American business, died on Monday at the Miami Heart Institute. He was 83 and lived in Miami Beach.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIMPFHEIMER, RUTH
description: WIMPFHEIMER-Ruth. The officers, Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Ruth Wimpfheimer, a cherished friend, who expressed her commitment to Jewish and other humanitarian causes through her generosity on behalf of our Women's Campaign. Mrs. Wimpfheimer's husband, Kurt, is also deeply devoted to the Jewish community. He has been a longtime leader in the UJA-Federation community of caring. We extend our deepest sympathies to Kurt; to Mrs. Wimpfheimer's son, Steven, and his wife, Ruth; to her daughter, Judith Bodie, and her husband, Zvi; to her five grandchildren; and to the entire Wimpfheimer family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO Joan Ginsburg, Women's Campaign Chair

title: Qwest Is Planning Account Consolidation
description: Qwest Communications ( news/quote ) is planning to consolidate its account and is beginning a review to seek one agency to handle the assignment, said advertising executives who were told of the decision. Billings were estimated at $100 million.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about politicians who are sending donations they received from employees of the Enron Corporation to charitable funds for former Enron employees referred incorrectly to the intentions of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. While she plans to return donations from individual employees, she did not receive money from Enron's political action committee. She did not indicate that she would keep contributions from the committee.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Thursday about the release of 27 prisoners captured in a raid last month north of Kandahar, Afghanistan, referred imprecisely to the findings of a Pentagon investigation into the attack. That inquiry found that the 27 detainees were not members of the Taliban or Al Qaeda network. The Pentagon has not yet determined if at least 15 people who died in the raid were linked to those groups.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNREUTHER, FREDERICK
description: KUNREUTHER-Frederick, (85). Died February 11. Survived by his wife Emily and children Richard, Katharine, Robbie, Frances and Elizabeth. Predeceased by son John. Contributions in his memory can be made to Marlboro College, Marlboro, VT. 05344.

title: Briefly Noted; TERROR LINK
description: Faisal Michael al Salmi, charged with lying to the F.B.I. about his contacts with a Sept. 11 hijacker, repeatedly changed his story during 10 hours of questioning, a prosecutor said in a statement opening Mr. Al Salmi's trial in Phoenix. ''This is not about Sept. 11,'' said the prosecutor, Peter Sexton. ''This case is about lying about knowing the terrorist who flew a plane into the Pentagon.'' The terrorist in question was Hani Hanjour, who came in contact with the defendant at a flight club in Phoenix. Mr. Sexton said Mr. Salmi first denied knowing Mr. Hanjour, then said they had met on 10 occasions and later said they had met only twice, at a mosque. Mr. Al Salmi's court-appointed lawyer, Gerald Williams, described the interrogation as a ''wrestling match'' of miscommunication.

title: Prudential's Loss Grew in Quarter
description: NEWARK, Feb. 12 (Bloomberg News)  Prudential Financial said today that its losses widened in the fourth quarter from a year earlier because of investment losses and costs related to its conversion to a public company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINDEBAND, SEYMOUR J.
description: SINDEBAND-Seymour J. On February 1, 2002. Age 85. Of Pound Ridge, N.Y. Husband of the late Elizabeth Bennett. Survived by son Markham L., daughter-in-law Jacqueline, daughter Caroline Ricker, brother Allan L., eight grandchildren and two great grandchildren. Veteran U.S. Navy, 6 years of active service, W.W. II. An engineer, inventor and entrepreneur. He was a distinguished Engineering graduate of Columbia University and winner of the Egelston Medal for Distinguished Engineering Achievements and the Columbia University John Jay Award for Distinguished Professional Achievement. His family and friends hearts are filled with pride, and all whose paths have crossed with his feel privileged to have known him. Service will be held at the Pound Ridge Community Church, 3 Pound Ridge Road, Pound Ridge, N.Y. 2 PM, Saturday, February 16th. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society in his name.

title: With Help in Short Supply, Peca Lifts Isles
description: Michael Peca never saw the puck roll into the net. He had fallen after taking the last shot of the game and was simply trying to gather his stick and scramble up to make another play.

title: Many More Children Calling New York City Shelters Home
description: The number of homeless children sleeping in New York City shelters rose by 29 percent last year, to a record 13,088 each night, according to city figures released yesterday by the Coalition for the Homeless, an advocacy group that monitors the shelters under a longstanding court decree.

title: A Search for Justice in The Hague
description: To the Editor:

title: METLIFE REPORTS LOSS OF $296 MILLION FOR QUARTER
description: The life insurer MetLife Inc. reported a fourth-quarter loss yesterday, reflecting slow sales and losses on investments in Argentina and the Enron Corporation. Metlife had expenses of $489 million as it laid off employees and set aside money for lawsuits. MetLife, based in New York, said it lost $296 million, or 41 cents a share, in contrast to net income of $591 million, or 74 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue was little changed at $8.4 billion. MetLife reported $172 million in investment losses and also absorbed costs for the settlement of a lawsuit and layoffs. Excluding these items and one related to annuity contracts, profit rose 9 percent. MetLife put aside $159 million to settle litigation involving claims of race-based pricing on policies.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Two Cabinet Officers Named
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey announced his choices yesterday to oversee the Department of Transportation and the Department of Human Services. The nominee for transportation commissioner is James P. Fox, former state director for United States Senator Frank R. Lautenberg. The nominee for human services commissioner is Gwendolyn Long Harris, who held a similar position in Trenton's city government. Both nominations are subject to State Senate approval. A spokesman for Mr. McGreevey said the new corrections commissioner, the only remaining cabinet position, will probably be filled within two weeks. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Drama Assists Fine Start By NBC
description: With ratings up 25 percent at the Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City, NBC could not have manufactured the fortuitous place it is now in. Nearly perfect weather. Early medals by American athletes. A production that is inviting, not overlong.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Jay Bertram was named president at the Toronto office of TBWA/Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group, succeeding David Fong, who left. Mr. Bertram had been senior vice president for corporate development at the Toronto office of the Cossette Communication Group.

title: Democrats Criticizing Bush Budget On Education
description: Congressional Democrats complained today that President Bush's budget provided far less money than Mr. Bush promised when he signed a landmark education bill just five weeks ago.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: U.N. Official Visits
description: The United Nations representative for human rights arrived to assess the situation, his third visit. The official, Paulo Sergio Pinheiro, said he would meet the opposition leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, who has been having talks with the military government. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: States Oppose Microsoft Witness List
description: State antitrust enforcers asked a federal judge yesterday to bar Microsoft from calling Bill Gates and 17 other possible witnesses. They were among 23 people whosenames were added by Microsoft last week to its list of potential witnesses for the hearings, which are scheduled to start March 11. Microsoft, the leading maker of software, said in its own court filing yesterday that the additions to the list were a response to the ''sweeping and draconian'' remedy that had been proposed by the states. The exchange was the latest in a series of volleys between the sides as they prepare for a courtroom showdown next month in a long-running battle over the company's business practices.

title: Criticism Is Often The Rule
description: Ola Sundequist of Sweden, a snowboarding judge at the 19th Winter Games, understands the complaints, the catcalls and even the cries for investigations in other events.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: School Board Challenges Test
description: The Montgomery County school board decided unanimously to ask the State Education Department to stop administering a test meant to measure schools' performance. The board, in suburban Washington, called for an overhaul of the Maryland School Performance Assessment Program test, noting that results for 2001, released last month, showed substantial declines for Montgomery County and 19 others. The Montgomery board questioned the reliability of those scores. The test is to be given to third, fifth and eighth graders in the spring. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: Chinatown Yearns for a Lucky New Year
description: Carmine Bau, a shy 10-year-old, clutched a bright red paper packet as other children lining Mott Street waved at the passing dancing lion. Yesterday was the beginning of the Chinese New Year, and Carmine's parents, following Chinese tradition, had given her the packet, containing cash, to wish her good luck.

title: Seton Hall Falters Late And Falls to Georgetown
description: Seton Hall played well only in spurts last night when a 40-minute effort was required. After overcoming a 16-point first-half deficit to take a 10-point lead with 10 minutes 2 seconds left in the game, the Pirates wilted down the stretch and dropped an 84-77 decision to Georgetown at Continental Arena.

title: Lindh Pleads Not Guilty to Conspiring to Kill Americans
description: John Walker Lindh, the American who fought with the Taliban in Afghanistan, pleaded not guilty today to a 10-count indictment that includes charges he conspired to kill Americans abroad and aided Osama bin Laden's terrorist network.

title: Clintons Accused of a Failure To Disclose Gifts' True Value
description: The Clintons underestimated the value of dozens of gifts they received while in the White House and failed to disclose others, according to documents released today by Republican Congressional investigators.

title: Showtime in Midtown
description: February brings a strange and fabulous confluence to New York, as Fashion Week and the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show captivate, just a few blocks apart. At Bryant Park and Madison Square Garden, wondrous creatures, so perfectly evolved as to be almost caricatures of their kind, are put on display. Backstage, they are groomed, blow-dried and combed out. Their fans often wear their devotion not on their sleeves, but on their backs.

title: For Value, the Languedoc
description: YOU would be hard-pressed to find better red wine values than those from the Languedoc region in southern France. Not only will $15 buy some fascinating bottles, it will also give you a rare opportunity to step away from widely held perceptions about the world's better-known grapes and wine regions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPPE, JEANETTE
description: LIPPE-Jeanette, 94. Died peacefully February 4, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Philip. Adored mother of Lawrence and motherin-law of Lenore. Cherished grandma of Kenneth, Linda and Robert. Honored grandma-in-law of Robert, Susan and Renee and loving great grandma of Barry, Allison, Eric, Alexis and Andrew. You can finally hear us again.

title: KELLOGG AND DISNEY ANNOUNCE CEREAL DEAL
description: The Walt Disney Company and the Kellogg Company announced a partnership yesterday that would put the animated superstars of one company on the cereals, waffles and cookies of the other. Buzz Lightyear from the movie ''Toy Story,'' Mickey Mouse and Winnie the Pooh will make their debuts as cereals, and other more Disney characters will eventually appear on Pop-Tarts, Eggo Waffles and Keebler cookies. Disney, hurt by lower attendance at its theme parks and falling ratings at its television network, ABC, suggested the partnership to expand its licensing agreements. For Kellogg, the deal is an effort to jump-start sluggish sales. Greg Winter (NYT)

title: From Icy Waters, A Wild Pleasure: Maine's Briny Belon
description: ON a freezing February day, the deep blue waters along this shredded coastline have a deceiving stillness. While life seems suspended until spring, beneath the surface is a thriving shellfish garden with scallops, crabs, sea urchins and lobsters.

title: Home Depot Board Grows
description: Home Depot Inc., the home improvement chain, named Richard Grasso, the chairman and chief executive of the New York Stock Exchange, to its board, effective immediately.

title: DVD RENTALS HELP BLOCKBUSTER REDUCE LOSS
description: Blockbuster Inc., the video store chain, said its fourth-quarter loss narrowed on increased rentals of DVD's and lower costs. The loss narrowed to $4.5 million, or 3 cents a share, from $24.6 million, or 14 cents, a year earlier. Sales rose 1.3 percent, to $1.36 billion, said the company, which is 82 percent owned by Viacom Inc. Excluding good will amortization and costs related to reducing inventory, Blockbuster said its fourth-quarter profit would have been $63.2 million, or 35 cents a share, better than the 28 cents forecast by analysts.

title: A Grandfather of Jerk, Still Going Strong
description: WHEN Allan Vernon opened Vernon's Jerk Paradise 20 years ago on a lonely corner in the northeast Bronx, he said it was not only the first restaurant in New York City to serve the Jamaican delicacy known as jerk, but the first in the entire country.

title: School Hires Security Firm After Attack By Students
description: The Westchester school for troubled children where a counselor was tortured by several students last week said today that it had hired a leading international security firm to study the school ''from top to bottom'' and make recommendations.

title: Driver Hits 18 People in Manhattan Havoc
description: A hit-and-run driver barreled through the center of Manhattan yesterday afternoon for more than 20 crowded blocks, striking 18 people before abandoning his battered Buick and fleeing on foot, the police said.

title: Jets May Tag Fabini As Transition Player
description: The Jets may put the transition player tag on left tackle Jason Fabini next week, all but assuring that he would return next season, according to his agent Anthony Agnone.

title: The Other Side of Choice: After Top Students Leave
description: A NEW federal law allows students in low-scoring schools to transfer out. I have little doubt that students who are motivated to switch will benefit, partly because in their new public schools they will befriend youths whose ambitions and enthusiasm for learning are strong.

title: Short-Track Racing Begins
description: Apolo Anton Ohno of the United States begins his quest for four short-track speedskating gold medals with men's preliminaries in the 1,000 meters and the 5,000-meter team relay semifinals at the Salt Lake Ice Center on Wednesday.

title: Gore, Championing Bush, Calls For a 'Final Reckoning' With Iraq
description: Al Gore said last night that the time had come for a ''final reckoning'' with Iraq, describing the country as a ''virulent threat in a class by itself'' and suggesting that the United States should consider ways to oust President Saddam Hussein.

title: A Magnet for Lovers, And Chefs, Too
description: THE River Caf has not had a run as long as that of the ''The Fantasticks.'' It only seems that way. But 24 years is a very long time, the equivalent of a century or more in restaurant years. The astonishing thing is not how long the River Caf has been in business but how good it has been for most of those two-and-half decades, and how many star chefs it has produced. It has been the jumping-off point for David Burke, Larry Forgione, Charlie Palmer and most recently, Rick Laakkonen, who left the River Caf to make a big splash at Ilo last year. That is an impressive list of alumni, even more so for a restaurant catering to tourists and couples seeking a romantic evening. A view and a setting like the River Caf's should be death to serious food. But it isn't.

title: The Gold Starts With the Nomination
description: Whether at the box office, the video rental store or through sales of DVD's, a best picture nomination can add up to Oscar gold even before the engraved statuettes arrive.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about the plans of W. Randall Jones, chief executive of Worth Media, to buy out his partners referred incorrectly to a woman who attended parties at Mr. Jones's duplex on Sutton Place, where he cultivated his flamboyant image. The woman, Candy Spelling, is the wife of the television producer Aaron Spelling, not his daughter.

title: $4.9 Million Of Cantor Net To Be Shared By Survivors
description: Cantor Fitzgerald, which lost 658 people in the Sept. 11 attacks , reported unexpectedly strong fourth-quarter earnings yesterday for eSpeed, its publicly traded electronic trading unit, and announced that it would share $4.9 million of its own fourth-quarter profits with the families of the employees killed in the attacks.

title: Afghanistan's Civilian Casualties
description: Americans can be thankful that military operations against the Taliban and Al Qaeda have produced few American fatalities. Innocent Afghan civilians have paid a higher price, including those killed in mistaken American attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, KALMAN
description: KLEIN-Kalman. Of New York City and Westhampton Beach. In his 96th year. Beloved father of Dr. Stephan Marc Klein, Peter D. Klein, Joan Gandy and the late Richard Springer. Father-in-law of Andrea B. Klein and the late Judy Graf Klein. Grandfather of Adina and Oleanna Klein. Grandfather of Steven Gandy, David Gandy, Susan Smith, Terry Gandy, Mark Springer and Jonna Hutchingson. Great-grandfather of Monique and Amy. Brother-in-law of Hazel Phillips Stanley. For 65 years he was a principal of Klein and Teicholz Builders. He was Past President of the Long Island Builder's Institute. He was a loving, caring and generous man. We deeply mourn his passing. The funeral will take place on Wednesday at 1:30PM at the Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

title: Seeking California Poets Who Want Laurels to Rest On
description: Many wax poetic about California. But that is not helping the search for a California state poet laureate.

title: Army Denies Mistreatment Of Agfhans
description: The chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff today rejected accusations that American forces beat or kicked captives following a raid north of Kandahar last month and said medical examinations of the men in detention found no evidence of abuse.

Age 76 of Weston, CT., on February 11, 2002, loving husband of Lois Alcosser, devoted father of Melinda Susan Alcosser of Guilford, CT., Andrew Isaac Alcosser of Fairfield, CT., cherished brother of Stella Prafder of Woodmere, New York, adoring grandfather of Rebecca, Lucy, Jody & Sam. Services Wednesday 11:00 AM at Temple Israel, 14 Coleytown Road, Westport, CT. Memorial contributions to the Children's International P.O. Box 219055, Kansas City, MO. 64121

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURT, MAGGIE Z. HORN
description: BURT-Maggie Z. Horn, 105. Died on February 5th in Alexandria, VA. Born Shelbyville in East Texas in 1896, living there and Fort Worth with siblings and parents Dr. John Henry Horn and Ada Sullivan Horn. Taught piano in Fort Worth, and after 1930, in New York City. Husband, Henry Radcliffe Burt, died in 1937. She moved to the Washington area in 1976. Survivors include son Henry R. Burt of Fairfax, VA., and two grandsons, Henry and Radcliffe of Richmond.

title: Principal at Martin Luther King Is Removed After Students' Arrest
description: The Board of Education has removed the principal of the troubled Martin Luther King Jr. High School after a spate of violence involving weapons at the school. Most recently, on Friday, a student sneaked a knife into the bustling five-story building and threatened another student.

title: Inquiry Is Started on Judging Of Olympics' Figure Skating
description: Responding to disenchantment over the decision to award the Olympic gold medal to a Russian pair instead of a Canadian one on Monday night, the International Skating Union said today it was investigating whether the judges had followed its rules and procedures.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Alaska: A Plan To Revive The Income Tax
description: Gov. Tony Knowles asked legislators to consider an assortment of new taxes, including a state income tax, to raise an additional $400 million annually to cover projected revenue shortfalls. Mr. Knowles, a Democrat, proposed imposing an income tax equal to 20 percent of Alaskans' federal tax liability, an increase from a proposal last month for 18 percent. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Furor Over Death Sentences Of 5 in China Church Group
description: An international campaign has begun on behalf of five leaders of a defiant evangelical Christian group who were given death sentences in December under China's 1999 anti-cult law.

title: U.S. Goal Seems Clear, And the Team Complete
description: In the weeks following the defeat of the Taliban and the scattering of Al Qaeda in Afghanistan, the Bush administration was consumed with internal debate about where to take the war on terrorism next. Now, by all indications, the debate is largely over: toppling Saddam Hussein is the next major goal, and the administration is putting in place the diplomatic and military means to accomplish it.

title: Microsoft Is Putting Its Muscle Behind Web Programming Tools
description: After spending three and a half years, five million hours of labor and $2 billion, Microsoft begins a huge campaign today to woo millions of computer programmers to use its new generation of Internet software tools.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Inflation Climbs
description: British inflation surged in January to its highest level in five months, exceeding economists' expectations and raising speculation that the Bank of England might raise interest rates from their current 36-year lows later in the year. The Office of National Statistics said inflation rose by an annualized 0.7 percent, to 2.6 percent, from December to January, above the bank's target of 2.5 percent. Higher oil prices and a consumer boom that enabled stores to reduce seasonal discounts were blamed for the increase. The news strengthened the pound against the dollar while bonds fell in anticipation of higher interest rates. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: FitzRandolph Makes Good on His Vow to Be Like Heiden
description: Minutes after Casey FitzRandolph became the first American speedskater to win an Olympic gold medal in the men's 500 meters since Eric Heiden in 1980, he walked over to his inspiration.

title: JETBLUE FILES PLANS FOR $125 MILLION OFFERING
description: The JetBlue Airways Corporation filed for an initial stock sale to raise as much as $125 million to buy planes as the low-fare carrier also prepared to add cities. JetBlue, which is based at Kennedy Airport, added to its pre-Sept. 11 expansion plans while rivals scaled back, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. The carrier plans to begin service to San Juan, P.R., on May 1 and expects to add at least two other American cities this year, a JetBlue spokesman, Gareth Edmondson-Jones, said. JetBlue intends to add 61 aircraft by the end of 2007. The company has not disclosed how many shares it will offer the public or an estimated share price.

title: Wine Solves A Mystery
description: FOR years, I was haunted by a dark pasta sauce served all around Tuscany. It's made with duck, rabbit or some other stewed, shredded meat. And it clearly has a tomato base. But it has a character that I could not duplicate at home; I tried over and over but could never get the right depth of color and flavor. With each failure, I convinced myself that it was one of those illusions of travel -- things always taste better abroad -- or maybe it was the quality of the meat, or some special mushroom I couldn't get my hands on. I would give up. But then I would go back to Italy, eat it again and start all over: this was a dish I needed in my repertory.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Thursday about the release of 27 prisoners captured in a raid last month north of Kandahar, Afghanistan, referred imprecisely to the findings of a Pentagon investigation into the attack. That inquiry found that the 27 detainees were not members of the Taliban or Al Qaeda network. The Pentagon has not yet determined if at least 15 people who died in the raid were linked to those groups.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: California: U.S. Raid Sets Off Protests
description: Federal agents raided three medical marijuana clubs, in San Francisco, Oakland and Petaluma, arresting four people and adding fuel to a dispute between local and federal officials. The administrator of the Drug Enforcement Administration, Asa Hutchinson, met a hostile audience later in the day at the Commonwealth Club in San Francisco as he explained the Bush Administration's stepped up drug war. The San Francisco district attorney, Terence Hallinan, said that city officials had not been informed of the raid and that it and Mr. Hutchinson's simultaneous visit were the latest insults in an ongoing battle between local and federal officials. ''The city's chief law officials do not agree with the federal government's actions,'' Mr. Hallinan said. Mr. Hutchinson said the raid was apolitical and reflected the drug agency's responsibility to uphold federal law.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Profit Falls At BP
description: BP reported a 62 percent drop in fourth-quarter profit, as energy prices plunged. Net income fell to $1.06 billion, or 5 cents a share, compared with $2.8 billion, or 12 cents a share, in the period last year. BP said it increased oil and gas production for all of 2001 by 5.5 percent, in line with the company's own estimates and at a faster rate than its rivals Royal Dutch/ Shell and the Exxon Mobil Corporation. In response to lower oil prices, which have fallen as the world economy slows and the terror attacks in the United States have crimped demand, BP said it would eliminate 15 percent of the jobs in its chemicals unit and an unspecified number elsewhere. The chief executive, John Browne, said he expected supply and demand to be in balance this year. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: An Idiosyncratic Overview From a Japanese Master
description: As part of its annual festival of traditional and contemporary compositions, Music from Japan presented an evening of works by Akira Nishimura at Merkin Concert Hall on Saturday evening. The program included only three works, yet for anyone unfamiliar with this inventive 48-year-old composer, the evening offered a fairly comprehensive overview.

description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

Investigation Into Rogue Trades Finds Red Flags but Few Details
description: The currency trader who lost $750 million at a regional Maryland bank was so successful in counterfeiting proof of bogus trades that his bank was frantically trying to verify six-month-old trades the day before the suspected fraud was made public, foreign exchange traders said yesterday.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALLA VILLA, MSGR. ANTHONY J.
description: DALLA VILLA-Msgr. Anthony J. Central Synagogue mourns the loss of a wonderful colleague, a dedicated spiritual leader and a beloved friend. Our condolences to his family, to the people of St. Agnes Church and to the Archdiocese of New York. Peter J. Rubinstein, Rabbi Samuel Wasserman, President

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the appeal of a death row inmate, Thomas Miller-El, misidentified the law school at the University of California at Berkeley, where the director of the death penalty clinic wrote a supporting brief. It is Boalt Hall; Hastings is another law school in the California system, at San Francisco.

title: Graduate Is Held in Bail In Campus Hostage Case
description: The man accused of taking 27 people hostage at Fairfield University in Connecticut before releasing them unharmed was arraigned yesterday and ordered jailed with bail set at $1 million, as the Roman Catholic campus tried to return to normal.

title: Idol Available. Teens Please Apply.; In Connecticut, Chasing Pop Stardom With Voice Lessons and Arm Curls
description: As long as there are little girls, goes the recording industry wisdom, there will always be pop music -- no matter how many adults hate it. And as long as there is pop music, there will always be young men like William Surett, who plans to become a teen idol.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Each side in the Hewlett battle says a strong profit report supports its stand.
description: THE pace of hostilities accelerated yesterday in the Hewlett-Packard proxy fight on a day when the company reported solid quarterly financial results in the midst of the slump in corporate spending on computers.

title: Charges Filed After Incident Near Pentagon
description: A man who told the authorities he was from Jordan was charged today with document fraud and making false statements after he and a companion drove a tow truck into an off-limits security zone near the Pentagon, law enforcement officials said.

title: Mayor Calls Budget Too Tight for New Stadiums and Other Construction
description: With evident exasperation, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg declared yesterday that the city's capital budget, already straining under the weight of its commitments, was far too strapped to entertain his predecessor's notion of building new stadiums for the Yankees and the Mets right now.

title: A Portable Sleeping Place Wins a Top Prize in Design
description: A New York artist, Michael Rakowitz, took home the $10,000 grand prize last week in a competition for young artists and designers organized by Unesco and the Felissimo Design House. The contest's theme was connection. Mr. Rakowitz's design, an inflatable shelter for the homeless, was one of 736 entries from 81 countries. Mr. Rakowitz made the prototype, left, for about $5, out of polyethylene, the material used to make trash bags. It was tested on the street and was inflated and heated after being hooked up to a duct on the side of a building. The winner's circle also included a polypropylene chair called Origami, designed by James Dieter, and a mirror called OBS by Rodrigo Leo. These and other prizewinning designs are on display through May 4 at Felissimo, the store at 10 West 56th Street.

title: Hunting Hotel Bargains
description: To the Editor:

title: Annan Asks U.S. for More Money for AIDS Fund
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan of the United Nations met privately today with President Bush and members of the Senate to prod them gently to give more for a new global fund to combat the AIDS epidemic.

title: From Serb, One More Protest About His Trial
description: Following are excerpts from an exchange yesterday between Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav leader, and Richard May, presiding judge at the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia, as recorded by The New York Times. Mr. Milosevic's remarks, in Serbian, were translated by a court interpreter; Mr. May spoke in English.

title: Review/Fashion; Closing In on Fall, With Energy to Spare
description: Five months ago, the hierophants of fashion could scarcely have predicted what women would want to wear in the aftermath of Sept. 11. The frivolous, the highfalutin, were clearly out. On the other hand, did anyone in the industry really expect to drum up excitement for the chaste, the earnest and the cutely cozy?

title: Long-Distance Market
description: To the Editor:

title: Uproar Over a Sliced, and Revered, Meteorite
description: When the American Museum of Natural History opened its gleaming new planetarium two years ago, it gave its highest place of honor to the Willamette meteorite, the pitted, 15 1/2-ton boulder that fell to Earth more than 10 millennia ago.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15, 18

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: State Treasurer Runs For Governor
description: State Treasurer Carol Springer has announced that she will seek the Republican nomination for governor. Ms. Springer has promised to deal with a budget shortfall by cutting back on spending. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Peres Offers New Peace Plan to Arafat and Sharon
description: After months of quiet consultations with a top Palestinian leader, Shimon Peres, Israel's relentless foreign minister, has drawn up a new peace plan. It calls for a cease-fire, immediate recognition of an initial Palestinian state on limited turf and a yearlong negotiation over what the final state would look like.

title: Weakness, Strength And Sept. 11
description: To the Editor:

title: A Magazine Gives Readers A Piece of Its Decorating Mind
description: Readers of Nest magazine will find a promotional freebie in the next issue: a folded swatch of wallpaper designed by Paul Noble, an artist, and by Joseph Holtzman, Nest's founder and editor. ''We would really like to see good, forward-thinking design available directly to our reader at a good price,'' said Mr. Holtzman, who plans a line of Nest products. From across a room, the wallpaper looks like benign vignettes. Close up, it is reminiscent of an R. Crumb comic but with little color save for red X's stamped at the seams. The paper is sold in sheets of 10 (the equivalent of one roll) for $72.50 at the Tim Gleason Gallery, 174 Elizabeth Street (Prince Street) and soon at www.nestmagazine.com.

title: HUB GROUP FINDS ACCOUNTING IRREGULARITIES IN A UNIT
description: Hub Group Inc., a freight transportation management company, said it had found accounting problems at a partly owned unit and would restate earnings by about $3 million to $4 million. The unit, Hub Group Distribution Services, was formed in 1990 to perform specialized logistics and distribution operations, Hub Group's general counsel, David Zeilstra, said. It is 65 percent owned by Hub Group and 35 percent owned by the unit's former president. Hub Group said that it was still trying to determine the periods in which the accounting irregularities occurred and that its 1999 to 2001 financial results were affected.

title: Enron Official Says She Warned Lay About Financial Irregularities
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14  An executive of the Enron Corporation ( news/quote ) told a House committee today that she became "highly alarmed" last summer about the company's financial situation and believed that Kenneth L. Lay, who was then Enron's chairman, was being deceived by several high-level subordinates.

title: Rangers Fall Short in Third Period
description: Mike Modano and Mike Richter will be teammates on the United States team at the Salt Lake Olympic Games starting Thursday. For the Rangers, that is one day too late.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Rape Charge At Hospital
description: A male nurse's aide at the Brooklyn Hospital Center was charged yesterday with raping a female patient, the police said. Investigators said the patient, who is 37, was undergoing chemotherapy treatment for throat cancer and could not call out because she had a tube down her throat. After the attack, which the authorities said occurred between 10 p.m. Thursday and 8 a.m. Friday, she wrote notes to her relatives, who notified the hospital staff. The patient, who has been hospitalized since last month, was listed in stable condition yesterday. The police charged Waseem Rehman, 27, of Brooklyn, with rape and other charges, including endangering the welfare of a disabled person.

title: Davis, Who Survived a Protest, Leaves the American Team
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 13  Shani Davis became the first black speedskater to make a United States Olympic team, but after weathering allegations that he was the beneficiary of race-fixing, he learned he would not skate in the Olympics after all.

title: Hunt for U.S. Reporter Leading to Dead Ends
description: The arrest and interrogation of the chief suspect in the kidnapping of the American journalist Daniel Pearl have produced no solid evidence on the whereabouts of Mr. Pearl, or whether he is still alive, the police in Pakistan said today.

title: 6 Into 5 Doesn't Fit for Hernndez
description: The ball came at El Duque from a couple of feet away, and he swatted it with his glove, deflecting it off the chest of El Duquecito, who flipped it to Bobby Estalella. Around and around it went, the ball bounding off shins and shoes like a Hacky Sack, the laughter rising from the three Yankees in shallow right field.

title: Viacom Has Loss but Sees Hope
description: Viacom Inc., the owner of the CBS television network and the Infinity radio group, said yesterday that it had a fourth-quarter loss as advertising sales fell. But the company said there were signs that ad spending might be recovering.

title: Traudl Junge, 82, Hitler's Private Secretary
description: Traudl Junge, a private secretary to Hitler who was the last surviving witness to the Nazi leader's final moments in his Berlin bunker, died in Munich on Sunday night. She was 82.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: East Rutherford: Sports Chief Nominated
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey, left, has named a former state official to be executive director of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority. The new director, George Zoffinger, is a former state commerce commissioner and a former economic adviser to Mr. McGreevey. If the State Senate approves the nomination, Mr. Zoffinger will succeed James DiEleuterio, who resigned yesterday effective March 15. Mr. Zoffinger said his first priority would be to eliminate the annual state subsidies of $48 million for debt and $11 million for operations. He said he would consider layoffs among the agency's 3,000 workers, curbs on bonuses, and slot machines at horse-race tracks. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Metro Matters; How Strange To Encounter Budget Reality
description: THERE were more than a few bewildered souls in and around the old marble corridors of City Hall yesterday -- City Council members, lobbyists and fiscal experts all trying to figure out what it means to have a mayor mix his budget numbers with a rare modicum of candor.

title: Squeezing Ever More From the Cellphone Spectrum
description: ALTHOUGH talking on a wireless phone the size your palm may seem the image of cutting-edge technology, a cellphone is really nothing more than a radio. And like the FM stereo in your car, a cellphone can suffer from the same limitations: blocked signals and interference.

title: Retail Sales Numbers Help Push Major Indexes Higher
description: Encouraged by an upbeat report on retail sales, investors pushed stocks higher yesterday on the hope that the economy could be turning around.

title: A Qaeda Leader Is Reported To Plan New Raids on U.S.
description: An elusive 30-year-old Palestinian who travels the world using false passports and multiple aliases has emerged as the new chief of operations for Al Qaeda and is now believed to be organizing remnants of the terrorist network to carry out new attacks against the United States, American officials said.

title: Excerpts From Milosevic's Statement
description: THE HAGUE, Feb 14 (AFP) - Yugoslavia's former president Slobodan Milosevic on Thursday sought to put NATO in the dock for its 1999 air war against Yugoslavia during his defense against charges of war crimes and genocide in the Balkans war.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: Soldiers On Patrol As Tensions Rise
description: Soldiers patrolled Jos, the central city where a fire gutted the main market early this week and where merchants of different ethnic groups have been blaming one another for the blaze. More than 500 people were killed in Jos in clashes between Muslims and Christians about five months ago in one of the many religious and ethnic uprisings in recent months. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: Young Cellist Puts Powers Of Invention To the Test
description: Li-wei Qin, a 23-year-old cellist who was born in Shanghai, grew up in Australia and now lives in London, was the winner of the Naumburg Competition last year, and as part of his prize he played a recital at Alice Tully Hall on Monday evening.

title: Wrinkle-Free Stepford Wives
description: Hollywood directors like Martin Scorsese and Baz Luhrmann have complained that Botox is so popular among actors that it is playing havoc with facial expression. In a variation on "The Stepford Wives," it is now rare in certain social enclaves to see a woman over the age of 35 with the ability to look angry.

title: With Tremulous Emotion, Bush Reads Your E-Mail
description: Getting your first PlayMail message can be a shock. A realistic animation of, say, Britney Spears appears on your computer screen. She arches her eyebrows, nods and smiles. Then her mouth moves exactly in synchronization with a robotic voice reading the text of the incoming message.

title: South Koreans Criticize Bush's Methods, if Not His Message
description: Ask a South Korean on the streets of this city what he or she thinks about President Bush's recent statements including North Korea in a so-called axis of evil and many will say they are shocked and even insulted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ETTINGER, JANIS
description: ETTINGER-Janis. We mourn the untimely passing of our former colleague and dear friend. Throughout her career and her illness Janis was an inspiration to us all. We shall miss her. The Partners and Associates of Stroock

title: Hailing Kiss And Trying To Turn Into Kiss
description: Maybe there was always an arena-rock band lurking within Weezer, which played the Continental Airlines Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., on Monday night. On albums Weezer's trim, tuneful pop love songs are produced to sound loud, with distortion and feedback at the fringes. Onstage, songs that are rooted in the Beach Boys, the Beatles, the Raspberries and the Ramones got cranked up further, leaning on heavy metal power chords and sullen grunge crescendos. Rivers Cuomo, the band's lead singer, made his lead-guitar solos wriggle and screech.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YAKER, GERTRUDE
description: YAKER-Gertrude, died peacefully at 88 on February 12. Predeceased by loving husband Philip. Her life was rich with family, and she will be missed by her children, brother, grandchildren and greatgrandchildren. Funeral today at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue (West 91st Street) at 12 noon.
