title: A Shifting Of Leadership At Bookseller; Barnes & Noble Chief Steps Aside for Brother
description: Leonard Riggio, founder, chairman and chief executive of the bookstore chain Barnes & Noble, is stepping down from his role as chief executive and naming his younger brother, Stephen Riggio, to succeed him.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Accused of Faking Death
description: A man awaiting trial for passport fraud was charged yesterday with attempting to avoid prosecution by faking his death in the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. The man, Steven Chin Leung, 27, of Hong Kong, now faces charges of jumping bail and obstructing justice. In a complaint filed by the United States attorney's office in Manhattan, prosecutors charged that Mr. Leung called his lawyer and the New York City Department of Law after Sept. 11, claiming to be his brother, and saying that Steven Chin Leung had been working for a company in the World Trade Center and was among the missing. Jane Fritsch (NYT)

title: Bush Hails Musharraf, and Warns Iraq
description: President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan, whom the United States treated as an outcast after he seized power in a coup two years ago, was welcomed to the White House by President Bush today as a ''leader of great courage and vision'' who would continue to receive economic and military aid for his help in the war against terrorism.

title: A Computer Shutdown Plays Havoc at Interior
description: After a 10-week court-ordered shutdown of nearly all its computer communications, the Interior Department said yesterday that it had restored some of them, bringing e-mail back to government scientists, Web service to national parks -- and payments to nearly 40,000 American Indians.

For a Poet, Centennial Appreciation
description: In one of his most famous poems, Langston Hughes asks what happens to a dream deferred. One of his own dreams was to establish himself for posterity as a major figure in 20th-century American literature, and last weekend he seemed to take a giant step in that direction.

description: It is an idea that no one, including Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, likes. And it is something the city has not tried, at least to this degree, since the days of the fiscal crisis of the 1970's. But a plan is now on the table to sell $1.5 billion in long-term debt to balance the city's new budget.

Devoted grandfather of Lia, Kevin, Drew, Sara, Rachael, Jaclyn, Ellen, & Matthew. Brother of Donald Farber and the late Homer Farber. Son of the late Charles Farber and the late Sarah Farber. description: ''I have been through many, many medal ceremonies. These are much, much better run, to tell you the truth.''

description: People with home wireless networks using the 802.11b or Wi-Fi standard usually hook up computers and printers. Now D-Link hopes that they will add digital cameras that might even provide some security for everything else in the house.

description: The Nets spoke today of facing up to adversity. Maybe it is a sign of just how well things have gone this season that they consider their next game a test.

title: Renewing a Latin Trade Pact
description: The Bush White House held its first state dinner last September, in honor of President Vicente Fox of Mexico. A week later, Secretary of State Colin Powell was sitting down to breakfast in Lima with Peru's president, Alejandro Toledo, when he heard about the terrorist attacks on New York and Washington. Ever since then, the administration's pledge to make relations with Latin America a top priority has been tested, understandably enough, by the need to focus on the war on terrorism.

title: Corrections
description: The Personal Shopper column last Thursday, about chandeliers, misspelled part of the name of the street in Paris where a chandelier made of aluminum wire is produced. It is the Rue Vieille du Temple, not Vielle.

title: Some Plans That Offer More Than Minutes
description: CHOOSING a cellphone used to be easy. You simply had to calculate which was the better value: the $40 national plan with 500 anytime minutes, 3,000 weekend minutes and roaming at 65 cents per minute, or the $35 regional plan with 400 national anytime minutes, 5,000 weekend minutes and roaming at 60 cents per minute.

title: Trump Drops Plans to Develop 2 Golf Courses North of the City
description: For several years now, Donald J. Trump has been pursuing ambitious plans to build four golf courses in the suburbs north of New York City. But he confirmed today that he had dropped two of those projects.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOLTTER, RICHARD
description: VOLTTER-Richard, 98, passed away on February 10, 2002. Beloved father of Jacqueline Brettler. Cherished grandfather of Douglas and Martha, Michael and Danielle. Devoted great-grandfather of Andrea and Carolina. Former President of Shapiro, Bernstein & Co. Inc. for 40 years.

title: West Side's Little Liberty Is Relocating to Brooklyn
description: She will lift her lamp beside the Eastern Parkway.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Phone Scheme Reported
description: Hundreds of women in the United States and Canada fell prey to a work-at-home scheme, believing they were getting paid for talking to lonely European men when they were actually speaking to other chat room operators, the New York State Consumer Protection Board reported yesterday. The women were told the calls would cost them $1 a minute but that they would be paid $1.48 a minute. Instead, they were left with large phone bills, some totaling thousands of dollars. Their nominal employer, North Star Communications, said to have headquarters in Winnipeg, went out of business and its managers disappeared, the consumer board said. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Wall Street Found Others Willing to Copy Enron's Deals
description: Investment bankers at some big Wall Street firms helped create and find investors for complex partnerships that the Enron Corporation used to mask its true financial condition. Then they started helping other companies in the same way.

title: One Man With Four Lives, Three Connected by a Game
description: Few men can claim to have had four distinct lives in four different countries. David Berah, who died two weeks ago in Manhattan at age 81, was one of this rare breed. From a childhood in Serbia he went to England and joined the Royal Air Force, serving as a navigator-bombardier in North Africa in World War II. He then spent 30 years as a successful businessman in Venezuela and 25 more retired in Manhattan.

title: Gather Round, Singers, as in the Olde Days
description: Edward Wickham, the director of the Clerks' Group, made an unusual point in his program notes for ''The Original Josquin,'' the program that his ensemble performed as part of the Music Before 1800 series at Corpus Christi Church on Sunday afternoon. Mainly, it was that our notion of Josquin Desprez as the singularly towering figure of Renaissance polyphony owes a great deal to the dawn of music publishing at the turn of the 16th century, the height of Josquin's career.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, AUSTIN J.
description: BROWN-Austin J. Of Emerson, New Jersey, former employee of The American Lung Association, former Country Director of The United States Peace Corp (Uganda and Gambia) Africa Service Institute, the African American Institute and the Institute of International Education. Died Saturday, February 9, 2002. He is survived by his wife, Sonia, of Bergen Community College, and his son, Peter. Family will receive friends on Friday, February 15, from 3-5 and 7-9 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Funeral Mass Saturday, 10 AM, at the Assumption Church, 29 Jefferson Ave., Emerson, NJ. Entombment to follow at the Garden of Memories, Paramus, New Jersey. There will be an opportunity for further viewing at 9:30 AM prior to the mass at the church.

title: Smithsonian Cutting Jobs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13  The Smithsonian Institution said today that it had laid off 45 employees and cut its budget by $9 million to cope with dwindling tourism since Sept. 11. The institution said the number of visitors to its 16 museums in recent months fell by as much as 45 percent.

title: 'This Chip Will Explode in 5 Seconds': Imagining the Uses
description: FREDERIC V. MIKULEC, a postdoctoral chemistry student at the University of California at San Diego, was scribing a silicon chip with a diamond cutter one day when something extraordinary happened: it exploded.

title: Donations in State Judicial Campaign Show Sharp Increase
description: As Congress debates limiting political donations for federal office, a new study shows that donations to state judicial races, a little-regulated and little-noticed arena, have risen substantially in recent years.

title: World Briefing | Africa: More Aid Sought For Malaria Drugs
description: Doctors Without Borders called for donor countries to help Africa pay for more effective, and expensive, antimalarial drugs. Mosquitos have grown resistant to many remedies and the aid group is worried that without help African governments will choose cheaper replacement drugs that are less effective. Malaria is the leading cause of death of children under 5 in Africa. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Palestinians Confirm a Rift in Arafat's Circle
description: Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, has angrily rebuked a top lieutenant over the release of militants from a Palestinian prison this week, Palestinian officials said today.

title: ABB Seeks Return of Some Severance Benefits
description: ABB, the Swiss-Swedish power and technology group plunged into red ink by huge charges for restructuring costs and asbestos liability exposure, said today that it wanted two former chief executives to give back some of their combined $138 million in severance and pension benefits.

description: BASEBALL

title: Design's Mood Swings, From Bliss to Rage
description: ''MOOD RIVER,'' the beguiling new design show at the Wexner Center for the Arts in Columbus, Ohio, goes to your head like a sip of sparkling burgundy brew. But it won't take away your hunger for meat and potatoes. Subjectivity, atmosphere, the idea that ambience can be more powerful than blocks of solid matter: these are among the defining motifs in contemporary architecture and design. There is a need for an exhibition that explores these themes with analytic precision. ''Mood River'' doesn't satisfy that need. Rather, it is an extravagant demonstration in installation techniques, a window display of waves in search of depth.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Shelley Eudene Lanman, executive vice president and executive creative director at the New York office of Draft Worldwide, was promoted to senior executive vice president and chief creative officer. She succeeds Emily Soell, vice chairwoman and chief creative officer, who will serve as a consultant to Draft. Also at Draft New York, Liz Deutch, executive vice president and group account director, was promoted to the new post of senior executive vice president and director for account services. Draft is part of Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRISCH, ROBERT E.
description: FRISCH-Robert E. Born August 18, 1925, died on February 5, 2002. He was a graduate of Harvard College and Harvard Law and a partner at Rogers and Wells. He is survived by his wife, Dolly Hemphill and children, Katharine, Robert, Peter, and ten grandchildren. Memorial service will be held at Christ Church, Rye, New York, on March 9 at 11 AM.

title: Fish Wars
description: The collapse of the once-great salmon runs of the Pacific Northwest ranks high among the ecological blunders committed in the name of progress. Lately there has been more bad news for these threatened fish. A National Academy of Sciences panel declared that efforts to protect fish species in Oregon's Klamath Basin by diverting irrigation water had been based on insufficient scientific evidence. And Western property rights groups have accelerated what has the makings of a river-by-river assault on endangered species protections for two dozen salmon populations in Northern California and the Pacific Northwest.

title: A Growing Girl in Search of a Religion
description: Little Cathy Bronson is confused when her parents instruct her not to mention Jesus in front of her grandmother. When Cathy asks why, her mother says, ''Because Gram doesn't like Jesus.'' Cathy gives this answer a lot of thought. ''Finally I figured it out,'' she says. ''Gram had met Jesus somewhere and didn't like him.''

title: Kenya Cracking Down on 'Beach Boys,' Gigolos Serving Tourists
description: As long as the 60-year-old hairdresser from Cologne kept visiting, Harry Abdalla Ali found it easy to pay for his tribal rituals -- the goat that had to be sacrificed to ensure a successful fishing season, the livestock needed for funeral ceremonies, the dowry of 12 goats, 40 liters of palm wine and 200 German marks he had to give his bride's parents.

title: It's a First: A Creator of Cars Floors Them at Harvard
description: Automobile designers, long overlooked as the design profession's gasoline-fueled stepsiblings, are taking a seat alongside leading fashion, product and theater designers. At least that is the view of the Harvard Design School, which will for the first time honor an automotive designer, J Mays, with an award for excellence in design next Wednesday. Mr. Mays, 48, is in charge of design at the Ford Motor Company and an effusive design champion, in contrast to Detroit's usually low-profile designers. Cars like the red-hot 2002 Thunderbird, above, reflect his desire to put ''a spin on automotive design that is less pragmatic and more fantasy-based,'' he said. He does not conceal his disapproval of brands that lack what he calls the ''emotional connection.'' Two evocative concept cars, as well as models, renderings and historical documents, are included in ''Autoemotive,'' an exhibition of Mr. Mays's work, which is on view through April 7 at Harvard's Gund Hall Gallery in Cambridge, Mass. CHEE PEARLMAN

title: Practice Pays Off for Croatian
description: HUNTSVILLE, Utah, Feb. 14  For others, a training session might be four hours, for Janica Kostelic it would be twice as long. While others would practice by skiing through 400 gates a day, Kostelic would ski through 1,200. While war in the former Yugoslavia stopped most of her Croatian teammates from training or skiing at all, Kostelic and her family fled their native, urban Zagreb and found a place to train in the distant snow of the mountains.

title: Parents Who Lose a Son Try to Find Themselves
description: When the Century Center presents Ibsen's ''When We Dead Awaken'' in November, it will have completed a cycle of his 12 major works in four years. Anyone who has seen some of the plays in this series must marvel at the number of people drawn to it, almost all of them cheerfully curious about what existential knot Ibsen will wrap them in next. A tough breed, these New Yorkers.

title: Road Named for Jefferson Davis Stirs Spirited Debate
description: When State Representative Hans Dunshee recently proposed changing the name of the Jefferson Davis Highway here, he did not think he would be stirring up a major political controversy.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Klan Defendant Has A Stroke
description: A man accused in a 1966 Ku Klux Klan killing, Ernest Avants, has suffered a stroke and may not recover to stand trial. Mr. Avants, 70, was one of three men charged in 1966 with the murder of Ben Chester White. He was acquitted in state court, but federal charges were filed after it was discovered that the killing occurred on government land. Mr. Avants' lawyer, Tom Royals, said his client underwent surgery last week to increase blood flow through a carotid artery.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Tuesday with a rock review of Linkin Park at the Nassau Coliseum misidentified the singer. He was Chester Bennington; Mike Shinoda is the group's rapper.

title: A Big Win for Reform
description: The long battle for campaign finance reform took a major step forward early today when the House removed the last impediments to passage of the Shays-Meehan bill. In a harrowing day and night of fending off amendments advanced by the Republican leadership in conjunction with the White House, the National Rifle Association, various special-interest groups and some unions, lawmakers struggled their way through the complexities and cast vote after vote to clean up the system. Even after what was expected to be a final vote approving the bill in the early morning hours today, the cause should not be considered completely won. The Senate has to vote once again, and get 60 votes to overcome a likely filibuster. And President Bush has to sign the bill.

title: Bach Passion Scaled Small, With Emotions Writ Large
description: The New York Collegium clearly made the right decision in appointing Andrew Parrott its music director: Friday's performance of Bach's ''St. John Passion'' at the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer on Lexington Avenue was consistently fluent, finely beautiful and movingly expressive.

title: Canada to Appeal on Skating; Judge Pressured, French Say
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 13  The head of the French Olympic team said tonight that the figure skating judge from his country was pressured to "act in a certain way" before she voted to award the gold medal to the Russian pairs team.

title: More From a Talkative Body Part
description: Two years ago, one particular performance of ''The Vagina Monologues'' seemed to be a very specific political act. Donna Hanover agreed to perform in the show, a decision that seemed part star turn, part poke at her estranged husband, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Mr. Giuliani's circle of hero worship was smaller then, when he was putting the force of his personality to matters like pornography and jay-walking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLARE, CHARLES
description: KLARE-Charles. On Feb. 12, 2002. Trade union organizer, a lifetime of commitment to the rights of working people and to peace. Beloved husband of the late Mildred. Loving father of Michael, Karl and Jane. Father-in-law of Andrea, Hallie and Arthur. Cherished grandfather of David, Jessica and Alexander. Services on Sunday, 11:15AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Sports of The Times; Duplicate the Medals and Banish Cheaters Forever
description: Figure skating is in terrible, terrible trouble. The admission by a French Olympic official that a French judge had been swayed in her voting constitutes one of the great scandals in Olympic history.

title: Farmers in Peru Are Turning Again to Coca Crop
description: His farm filled with money-losing crops, Francisco Torres had begun to despair that he could ever make ends meet in this green river valley in northern Peru. Then tens of thousands of acres of coca were eradicated in neighboring Colombia in a vast American-backed campaign of aerial fumigation.

title: CALENDER
description: A Study in Scarlet

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of yesterday, 3,062 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11, not including 19 hijackers.

title: Profit Up at Jack in the Box
description: Jack in the Box, operator of the fast-food hamburger chain, said profit rose 4.3 percent in its most recent quarter, beating estimates.

title: Antismoking Group Sues to Preserve an Ad Campaign's Tone
description: The American Legacy Foundation, an antismoking group created with more than $1 billion from a huge 1998 tobacco settlement, sued the Lorillard Tobacco Company yesterday in an effort to preserve an advertising campaign that has piqued the interest of teenagers and the ire of the tobacco companies.

title: Alanis Morissette Reveals Her Trials as a Teenage Star
description: After some 15 years in the music business, the singer Alanis Morissette worked for the first time without a producer or co-writers on her new album, ''Under Rug Swept.'' It is appropriate, then, that on the first single from this artistically liberated album, ''Hands Clean'' (currently in the Billboard top 40), Ms. Morissette looks back on a relationship with one of her early musical collaborators, who remains unnamed in the song.

title: Glass, Metal and Plastic May Become Plain Trash
description: The task of getting rid of New York City's waste has always generated headaches. And since 1993, when a mandatory citywide residential recycling law took effect, it has also essentially required two separate systems -- one for the ordinary domestic detritus of coffee grounds and spoiled take-out, and one for recyclables.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the Chinese New Year celebration in Manhattan misidentified a man on the street. He was unidentified; he was not John Liu, a New York City councilman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCHL, BARBARA
description: HIRSCHL-Barbara. On February 12, 2002. Cherished wife of Norman Hirschl. Devoted mother of Elaine and John Ellis and the late Roger Hirschl. Beloved grandmother of Jennifer and Andrew, Samantha and John, Peter and Heidi, Kate & Mike. Loving great-grandmother of Emma, Jonathan, Nina, Sarah, Kobe, and Caroline. Funeral on February 15th at 1:00 P.M. at Temple Anshe Amunim, Pittsfield, MA. Information 413-445-5988

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Inside Art column of Weekend on Friday about three paintings to be sold at Sotheby's on May 8 from the collection of Grace Sandblom and her late husband, Dr. Philip Sandblom, referred to her incorrectly. She is 94 and lives in Switzerland; she did not die in 1994.

title: New Executive Is Appointed At The AP
description: In a move that signals the beginning of the end of Louis D. Boccardi's 17-year tenure as the top executive of The Associated Press news agency, Jonathan Wolman, the executive editor, has been appointed as its senior vice president.

title: Milosevic Begins His Defense, Blasting NATO for '99 Bombing
description: THE HAGUE, Feb. 14  A driven and engaged Slobodan Milosevic today laid blame for the carnage in the Balkans on everyone but himself, waving away charges that he was responsible for war crimes in four words: "It is all lies."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOFFE, RUTH
description: JOFFE-Ruth. Beloved mother and grandmother to the Gerson family, James, Barbara, Fred and Simon. Services at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st and Amsterdam, Friday, at 11 AM.

title: Who's Hu in Beijing
description: President Bush's trip to the Far East next week will culminate in a summit in China with a lame Peking duck.

title: Waylon Jennings, Singer, Songwriter and Outlaw of Country Music, Dies at 64
description: Waylon Jennings, the leather-voiced singer and songwriter who was at the center of ''outlaw'' country music, died yesterday at his home in Chandler, Ariz. He was 64.

title: A Fund Plea From Volcker Aroused Hopes at Enron
description: When Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the parent organization of the International Accounting Standards Board, sent letters to major corporations seeking financing for the board, Enron appears to have concluded that there was a chance to gain some influence.

title: Behavior Forced Rockefeller U. Head to Resign, Trustees Say
description: After James D. Watson and Francis Crick determined the structure of DNA, microbiology exploded, drawing in many passionate and inventive young scientists. One was Arnold J. Levine, a talented student from Brooklyn who went on to become a leading researcher in the field and the president of Rockefeller University.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  URRY, MRS. CHARLES F.
description: URRY-Mrs. Charles F. Known as Kathe, passed away on February 10th in Locust Valley, NY at the age of 83. She was born in Prague, educated in Switzerland and London and was a graduate of the Sorbonne. She is survived by Valerie Urry, James & daughterin-law, Lieta Urry and three grandchildren, Nathalie, Katherine, Charles and a brother, Eric W. Weinmann. A funeral Service will be held at 10 A.M. on February 14th at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, at 73rd Street and Madison Avenue, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GROSSMAN, LOUIS
description: GROSSMAN-Louis. Your face beams in our dreams. Everything seems to bring memories of you. Your Loving Family

title: Buys in Custom Furniture: Just Say Banana Sent You
description: Curranonline is offering 30 percent off on custom upholstered furniture and made-to-order hardwood pieces this month. But to get the discount on upholstered pieces, you must buy three (and this doesn't mean three ottomans). A sofa, usually $3,275, is now $2,292.50. A club chair that was $1,925 is $1,347.50. Hardwood pieces similar to those of the well-known Thomas Moser line can be ordered singly; a 78-inch-long cherry table that was $2,100 is now $1,470. Delivery is free; tax is charged only in Washington State. Information: www.curranonline.com (the password for the Web site is ''banana'') or (800) 555-6653. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: A Bid to Change, an Uncertain Future
description: Both the financing and the tone of American politics could change profoundly if the campaign finance bill nearing House passage tonight becomes law.

title: The Bloomberg Budget
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg originally planned to release his first city budget today, but he wanted to avoid the inevitable tabloid headlines about a St. Valentine's Day Massacre. From the numbers Mr. Bloomberg offered up yesterday, it's clear why he was worried. The mayor, in his efforts to close a huge, $4.8 billion budget gap, is spreading the pain to every corner of the city.

title: 3 Large Ad Accounts Are Set for Changes
description: Three large advertisers are making account changes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKERMAN, GEORGE
description: BECKERMAN-George. Passed away peacefully on February 13, 2002. Beloved husband of Sylvia of 65 years, dearest father of Sheila and Sonia (Bruce). The best grandfather to Scott, Ronni, and Kenneth. Services at I.J. Morris, Lakeworth, Florida, Friday, February 15, 12:00 PM.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 31 about the Frank Lloyd Wright School of Architecture in Scottsdale, Ariz., referred incorrectly to the background of Arthur Dyson, the dean. Mr. Dyson, who was appointed in 1999, did not help Wright's third wife, Olgivanna, start the process that led to the school's accreditation. She began it in 1984 with help from a number of other administrators.

title: Instead of Disrespect, Athletes Get Embrace
description: They had no idea how they would be received in the United States, but one thing the members of the Iranian Olympic delegation decided in advance: If American immigration officials singled them out for fingerprinting as a team from the ''axis of evil,'' the 11-man group from Iran would turn around and fly back home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPPE, JEANETTE
description: LIPPE-Jeanette, 94, died peacefully February 4, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Philip. Adored mother of Lawrence and mother-in-law of Lenore. Cherished grandma of Kenneth, Linda and Robert. Honored grandma-in-law of Robert, Susan and Renee and loving great grandma of Barry, Allison, Eric, Lauren, Alexis and Andrew. You can finally hear us again.

title: Texans Preparing For Expansion Draft
description: A year ago, the Houston Texans, who will begin play in the N.F.L. this year, conducted a mock expansion draft and realized that even in a make-believe world it was hard to find cornerbacks, offensive linemen (especially tackles), defensive linemen and quarterbacks.

title: At Last, a Gold Medal for Canada
description: KEARNS, Feb. 14  Bitter tears, face-first falls, outrage and investigation. For the Canadians, their Olympic moments in Salt Lake City have not exactly been warm and fuzzy pictures of glory.

title: Pas de Deux, or Travesty on Ice?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, MATTHEW F.
description: PARKER-Matthew F. Our love, prayers, and thoughts are with you. Have a safe trip home. As always, love, Ellen and Rose

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Food Merger Delayed
description: The Snow Brand Milk Products Company said it was delaying a merger of its frozen-foods business with that of the Itochu Corporation, Japan's third-largest trading company, because a beef-mislabeling scandal at Snow Brand hurt consumer trust. The companies need time to assess how much the mislabeling incident will affect Snow Brand's earnings, a Snow Brand spokesman said.

title: Arty, Saw-Toothed Rhythms In a Night of Beefheartiana
description: Rock has its own grass-roots repertory institutions: cover bands, the kind you can hear at Bleecker Street bars playing the music of the Beatles or Bruce Springsteen. But some rock bands aren't going to have their own cover bands any time soon.

title: Skating Official Is in Spotlight
description: Ottavio Cinquanta reached the International Skating Union presidency after a modest athletic career of track and field, ice hockey and speed skating, but not figure skating.

title: INSIDE
description: Meeting at Lindh Hearing

title: Wanderer in Need of a Tissue
description: Kasey Chambers writes an awful lot of songs about crying. The young Australian country singer mentions crying in 9 of the 13 original songs on her new album, ''Barricades & Brickwalls'' (Warner Brothers), and when she performed at the Bottom Line on Monday night she seemed obsessed with her lachrymal glands. In one song, she asked, ''Do I cry too much?'' In another, she threatened to ''cry a river of tears.'' And in a third, she advised a lover to ''take these tears, wash your skin.''

title: U.N. Details Vicious Acts Charged Against Milosevic
description: Slobodan Milosevic could not quite hold himself back today, saying first that he would wait until morning to speak in his own defense, but then unleashing another blistering attack on the United Nations tribunal that has charged him with the gravest of atrocities in three Balkan wars.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, ADELE
description: ROSENTHAL-Adele. Born June 8, 1913 died at her home on Monday, February 11, 2002. An active, funloving mother, grandmother and great-grandmother, she enjoyed a fifty-five year marriage to the late Abner Rosenthal, M.D. She was a long time resident of Queens, an ardent supporter of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies and the United Jewish Appeal, an avid golfer and a member of the Glen Oaks Country Club, where she headed the women's division for many years. She is survived by: her sister Dorothy Barnett; her son Mitchell S. Rosenthal, M.D., president of Phoenix House; her daughter Jane Rosenthal, chief executive officer of Menorah Home and Hospital; her daughterin-law Sarah Simms and son-inlaw Jack Braunstein; her grandchildren, Claudia Plepler, Alexis Proceller, and David Rosenthal; & six great-grandchildren. Services will be held Thursday, February 14 at 11:45AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Ave at 76 St. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made, in her name, to Phoenix House, 164 West 74 St, N.Y., N.Y., 10023 or to Menorah Home and Hospital, 871 Bushwick Avenue, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11221.

title: French Olympic Official Denies Comments About Judge
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 14  The head of the French Olympic team said on Wednesday night that the figure skating judge from his country was pressured to "act in a certain way" before she voted to award the gold medal to the Russian pairs team. Today, however, the team official denied having implicated the judge and said he had been misinterpreted.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Shake-Up At Bank
description: The longtime Spanish banker Emilio Botn, president of the country's largest bank, Santander Central Hispano, has moved to consolidate his authority by naming Alfredo Saenz, a trusted lieutenant, as chief executive and appointing his daughter Ana Patricia Botn, left, to replace Mr. Saenz as head of the group's Banesto bank unit. The departure of Angel Corcostegui, a Central Hispano executive who took over as chief executive after the 11 billion euro ($9.6 billion) merger with Santander, underlines the long-running power struggle between the uneasy partners, with Mr. Botn holding the upper hand. Emma Daly (NYT)

title: In Court, a Not-Guilty Plea. Outside, the Real Drama.
description: Two fathers crossed paths at a federal courthouse here today, one whose son was the first American killed by the enemy in Afghanistan and one whose son is the only American who stands accused of joining that enemy.

title: U.S. Takes Play to Italy, But Can't Produce Goal
description: The United States national team put together a solid effort last night but ultimately lost, 1-0, to Italy at the Stadio Cibalia in the Sicilian hamlet of Catania.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Mission To Russia
description: Prime Minister Jean Chrtien led a delegation of political leaders from Canada's provinces and 300 business figures to Russia to try to increase trade and Canadian investments in Russian oil fields. Canadian officials said Mr. Chrtien would also like to secure more Russian help in international anti-terrorism efforts and support for his views on increasing world assistance to Africa. Mr. Chrtien said that relations between Canada and Russia were ''developing very intensively at the present time.'' Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: Antiterror Steps Aggressive but Balanced, U.S. Official Says
description: A top Justice Department official offered a spirited defense of the Bush administration's antiterrorism measures yesterday, saying they were ''aggressive but, at the end of the day, fair and balanced.''

title: Putin's Pursuit of the National Idea
description: Despite the international obsession with sports during the Winter Olympics, more than a few eyebrows remain raised over Vladimir Putin's speech to Russian Olympians last month invoking sports as a kind of panacea for economic and social ills. For Russia, this presidential pronouncement may not be as far-fetched as it sounds.

title: Remembering the Big Talk After You've Fallen Asleep
description: The ubiquitous white boards of conference rooms have a few shortcomings. They don't fit in a briefcase or on a photocopier.

title: Where Ice Water Is an Insult, and Tap Is a Disgrace
description: DID you know that there are eighteen hundred waters in the world?'' Filip Wretman earnestly inquired. Fair question, since young Mr. Wretman is the water sommelier at the brand new Ritz-Carlton at Battery Park, and is, the hotel says, the only water sommelier in America and possibly the entire universe.

title: Critic's Notebook; A Dark Brother Singing to America
description: When poets become public figures our connection to them calcifies. Then we have to go back and find a way to re-establish private relations. Which is why I will tell you that my first memory of Langston Hughes is a shameful one.

title: In London, Giuliani Is Honorary Knight but Bona Fide Hero
description: They wanted to hear about his crime-slashing techniques. They wanted to know if they could still call him Mr. Mayor (sure, he said). As Rudolph W. Giuliani swept through here today like an Olympic medalist on a prolonged victory lap, the people he met seemed simply to want to bask in the heady glow of his undeniable celebrity.

title: Deciphering the Marks In a Web Page Address
description: Q. What do the tildes, question marks and equal signs in Web addresses mean?

title: Footlights
description: In Memoriam

title: Pas de Deux, or Travesty on Ice?
description: To the Editor:

title: In New Offensive, Israeli Tanks Enter Towns in Gaza, Killing 5
description: Israeli troops in armored vehicles and tanks raided three towns in the Gaza Strip today, killing five people in clashes that represent the broadest offensive into Palestinian-controlled territory here in more than 16 months.

title: Congressman's Trial Begins With Testimony of Kickbacks
description: A former staff lawyer testified today that Representative James A. Traficant Jr. demanded a continuing kickback of half his $60,000 salary as a condition of employment.

title: In Shift, British Airways Looks to Coach
description: After years of pinning its fortunes to the deep pockets of business travelers, British Airways announced a strategic flip-flop today, saying that it would try to compete with Europe's booming budget airlines by offering cheaper travel over the Internet to passengers in coach.

title: Alzheimer's May Be Linked To Normal Diet Byproduct
description: People with high blood levels of a normal diet byproduct, homocysteine, have twice the average risk of developing Alzheimer's disease, a study being published today finds.

title: Thorny Rights Disputes Await Bush in China
description: Just this week, a Chinese-born businessman from Connecticut who has been detained without explanation for almost a year in Inner Mongolia managed to let his wife know that he had been beaten unconscious after his arrest, resulting in a severe brain injury.

title: Cambodia Won't Easily Find Justice on Its Own
description: In 1977, my oldest sister, who had two little daughters, was accused of stealing rice from the collective kitchen. Despite her repeated denials, the Khmer Rouge cadre refused to believe her, and to prove his allegation, he took a knife and cut open her stomach. My sister's stomach was empty, and she died.

title: The Future of Cellphones Is Here. Sort Of.
description: FOR the last few years, ever since a cellphone became nearly as commonplace as a wallet, the telecommunications industry has promoted the potential of wireless Internet access.

title: Bjoerndalen Wins 10K, His 3rd Gold in Biathlon
description: MIDWAY, Utah, Feb. 13 (AP)  Calmly hitting all 10 of his targets, Norway's Ole Einar Bjoerndalen won the gold medal in the 10-kilometer sprint today, winning his second gold medal of the Games and becoming the first biathlete to win three gold medals in a career.

title: Jazzing Up Planet Indoors for Children
description: IN dreary February, a child with cabin fever can get a cheerful lift from something as simple as a miniature wing chair, a translucent Saturn-shaped light or a pair of glow-in-the-dark curtain-rod finials. Some children can even get their own room within a room. Crawling into a private cabin with soft sides and a secret back door can be a welcome respite from long days at home, when winter blahs hit hard.

title: Carnegie Grants Aid in an Emergency
description: The Carnegie Corporation has announced that it is awarding $10 million in grants to 137 arts organizations in New York City that are struggling after Sept. 11.

title: Downtown Design District Grows by Yet Another Showroom
description: The BDDW furniture showroom, which opened this week near the intersection of Crosby and Howard Streets, is the latest addition to an area that is fast becoming a downtown design center. Occupying 4,000 square feet in a one-story 1863 cast-iron building (originally a factory), the showroom has 18-foot ceilings, an enormous skylight, above, and large arched doors made with end-grain walnut tiles. After eight years without a showroom, said Tyler Hays, one of BDDW's founders, ''we finally have the right space to show both high-end limited edition pieces and a less expensive line, which will cover some of our most popular pieces.'' Mr. Hays was the designer of the Mills bed, left. Shown in Claro walnut, the bed can be ordered in several woods for $2,500 to $10,000. In creating simple, well-made pieces using unusual American woods, the designers take inspiration from American and Japanese precursors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALZMAN, GLADYS
description: SALZMAN-Gladys. On February 2, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Herbert Salzman, loving daughter of Marcy Major (Lawrence), and cherished grandmother of Daniel and Hayley. For information, contact Schwartz Brothers Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 718-263-7600.

title: Bush Plan Expected To Slow, Not Halt, Gas Emission Rise
description: President Bush is set to announce a plan today calling for voluntary measures to slow but not halt the growth in emissions of heat-trapping gases linked to global warming, White House officials said last night.

title: Republicans Pick Up 2 Seats in the Assembly
description: A series of special elections throughout the state on Tuesday did little to shift the balance of power between Democrats and Republicans in Albany. The Republican Party picked up two Assembly seats that had been held by Democrats while the Democrats picked up a State Senate seat that had been in Republican hands for more than 30 years.

title: An Inversion of Doubt Over Skating
description: SportsofThe Times SALT LAKE CITY, Feb 13 — Figure skating is in terrible, terrible trouble. The admission by a French Olympic official that a French judge had been swayed in her voting constitutes one of the great scandals in Olympic history.

title: Pakistani Suspect Tells Court Abducted U.S. Reporter Is Dead
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Feb. 14  A British-born militant being held in the kidnapping of the American journalist Daniel Pearl said today that the reporter was dead, and he acknowledged carrying out the abduction three weeks ago. But the Pakistani authorities and Mr. Pearl's employer said they believed he was still alive, while his wife issued a new plea to his captors to release him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCLOVE, LOUISE HERZOG
description: SCLOVE-Louise Herzog. Died in Amherst at 92. Formerly of NYC and Westport CT. Died February 8 in the Center for Extended Care in Amherst, MA. Born February 3, 1910 in New Rochelle, NY, she was the daughter of the late Joseph L. and Eleanor (Guiterman) Herzog. Louise Sclove graduated from Wellesley College, class of 1931, where she formed lifelong friendships, and earned a graduate teaching certificate from Bank Street College of Education in New York City. During her varied professional life, Mrs. Sclove worked as a nursery school teacher, designer of retail displays for children's toys, public opinion poll administrator, mutual fund salesperson, publisher of a professional psychology journal, publicist, public education advocate, Jewish oral historian, and enthusiastic community and social activist. She enjoyed outdoor activities ranging from downhill skiing, for which she was an East Coast Pioneer, to tennis, golf, sailing, ice skating, hiking and camping, as well as international travel, chess and bridge. She read continuously. She continued cross-country skiing, swimming, skating (and unfortunately driving) into her eighties. She was fascinated by children, the younger the better. Her cute sense of humor stayed with her to the end. Her husband, Abraham Bernard Sclove, died in 1954. She is survived by her sons Richard E. Sclove of Amherst and Edward M. Dreyfus of Mar del Plata, Argentina and by four grandchildren. A private memorial service will be held in Amherst for family, friends, and her devoted following of younger people whom she counseled, supported and loved.

title: Global Crossing Woes Delay Military Contract
description: The bankruptcy proceedings for Global Crossing have delayed the awarding of a prestigious $450 million contract to provide the Defense Department with fast Internet services connecting laboratories and other research locations around the country.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: County Workers Dismissed
description: In a move intended to save Nassau County about $1 million, 33 probationary county employees were dismissed yesterday, County Executive Thomas R. Suozzi said. Mr. Suozzi, left, said the employees, who worked at the county's Department of Public Works, were let go based on performance evaluations. More dismissals are likely because of the budget shortfall, he said. But the president of the Nassau Civil Service Employees Association, Anthony P. Giustino, said it was ''highly suspect'' that all the dismissals were related to poor performance. He said he would fight those that were not. Mr. Suozzi is ''trying to get people off the payroll, and he's going to do it any way he can, and that's not appropriate,'' Mr. Giustino said. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Rule Makers Take On Loopholes That Enron Used in Hiding Debt
description: Responding to the collapse of the Enron Corporation, regulators, legislators and the chief accounting rule maker proposed changes yesterday in the way companies do business and report their finances, including closing the loophole that Enron used to hide hundreds of millions of dollars of debt and inflate its profits.

title: The 'Evil' Missiles
description: President Bush's tough stance toward North Korea has yet to stem its sales of ballistic missiles to nations like Iran, Syria or Libya. But his description of North Korea as part of an ''axis of evil'' has already distressed a long-time ally: South Korea.

title: Pas de Deux, or Travesty on Ice?
description: To the Editor:

title: After Surviving Rutgers's Storms, President Falls to Trenton Politics
description: He had survived an ugly scandal involving charges of racism that spurred a wave of student demonstrations. He had weathered growing discontent and flagging morale in his faculty and the emergence of a campus organization that lobbied for his removal from office.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Columbia Union Vote
description: The regional director of the National Labor Relations Board has ruled that the more than 1,000 graduate teaching and research assistants at Columbia University can vote on whether to join a union. Columbia University did not immediately say whether it would appeal. The director, Celeste J. Mattina, rejected Columbia's argument that the graduate students were not employees. Her ruling followed a decision involving New York University, which last month became the first private university to sign a contract with its graduate assistants. George Rupp, Columbia's president, criticized the decision, saying, ''There are many significant differences between graduate education at Columbia and N.Y.U.''

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Hearing Dropped In Patent Fight
description: The International Trade Commission has decided to eliminate closing arguments in a closely watched patent dispute over Gemstar-TV Guide International's interactive program guides. Closing arguments were scheduled for next Wednesday, and a ruling was expected by March 21. The Gemstar dispute, which has lasted a year, involves a number of leading players in the emerging interactive television industry. Gemstar-TV Guide, a company known for its aggressive litigation tactics, brought lawsuits against EchoStar Communications, Scientific-Atlanta, SCI Systems and Pioneer for importing cable and satellite television set-top boxes with interactive program guides. Gemstar says the guides violate its patent portfolio. The I.T.C. hearings, which have been closed because of the secrecy of patents involved, have ignited a great deal of speculation over the financial fate of the companies involved. ''We're very satisfied with the judge's decision,'' a Gemstar spokeswoman said, adding that the company was confident that papers already submitted adequately presented its position.

title: EMMIS COMMUNICATIONS TO SELL 2 DENVER RADIO STATIONS
description: The Emmis Communications Corporation, a radio and television broadcaster, agreed to sell two Denver FM radio stations for $135.5 million to repay debt. The company, which is based in Indianapolis, is selling KALC 105.9 to the Entercom Communications Corporation for $88 million and KXPK 96.5 to the Entravision Communications Corporation for $47.5 million. Emmis, which had paid $134.8 million for the two Denver stations, has about $1.49 billion in debt, the chief financial officer, Walter Berger, said.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Phone Concern's Shares Fall
description: Shares of AT&T Canada, which is 31 percent owned by the AT&T Corporation, have fallen on uncertainty over a commitment by the American company to buy the rest of the Toronto-based unit's equity in 2003 at a predetermined price. AT&T Canada stock, which trades on Nasdaq, has fallen more than 25 percent this year. AT&T Canada has accumulated substantial losses and debt in a battle to break into the domestic telecommunications market. It is currently awaiting an important regulatory ruling on charges for access to networks operated by established telephone companies. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Pauline Trigre, Exemplar of American Style, Dies at 93
description: Pauline Trigre, the Paris-born designer who was not only her own best model but also an elegant and chic symbol of the American fashion industry for more than half a century, died at her home on the East Side of Manhattan last night, said her daughter-in-law Melanie Radley. She was 93.

description: One needs audacity and imagination and a passion for books quite remarkable to become a small, independent book publisher these days, because the communal territory is jammed with large houses capable of gobbling up every manuscript there is with their economic and editorial muscle. For the small publisher, no matter how eclectic, it's rather like being an elegant lightweight boxer doing speedy zigging and zagging in a ring with a heavyweight.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Homestore To Restate Results
description: The online real estate company Homestore.com said yesterday that it would restate its 2000 financial results by mid-March after it ends an internal accounting inquiry. The restatements involve historical accounting issues that will be corrected, and do not relate to continuing operations, the company said in a statement. Homestore.com had already said it would restate financial results for the first, second and third quarters of 2001. The company said it expected cash from operations to be positive for 2002.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Stay Home, Pope's Envoy Is Told
description: The Russian Orthodox Church canceled a long-scheduled visit to Moscow from an envoy of Pope John Paul II, more evidence that church officials are steaming over the Vatican's decision on Monday to create four dioceses in Russia, where none existed before. The Orthodox Church is deeply suspicious of the Catholic Church and many other religions that it says have swept into post-Soviet Russia to poach its flock of believers. The Vatican says Catholics have been in Russia for centuries and that the creation of the dioceses merely formalized the church's presence there. The papal envoy, Cardinal Walter Kasper, was to come to Moscow later this month on a mission to repair relations between the churches. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, MEYEROWITZ THERESA
description: BERNSTEIN - MEYEROWITZ Theresa. Painter and writer of New York City and Gloucester, MA, died peacefully on February 12, 2002, at Mt. Sinai Hospital. Date of birth reported to be March 1, 1890. She graduated from Philadelphia's School of Design for Women (now the Moore College of Art) in 1911, and moved to NYC in 1912. She married fellow painter and etcher William Meyerowitz (d. 1981) in 1919. Along with her husband and John Sloan, she helped establish The Society of Independant Artists. She also became an integral part of the Gloucester art community from 1916 until 1998, and was a founding member of The North Shore Arts Association in 1922. She was also a member of several art associations both in New York and in Massachusetts. Also known as one of the very few women to work in the Ashcan Mode, she had several very well received and successful shows in museums and galleries beginning in 1914. Noteworthy were her shows at the Museum of the City of New York in 1991, and several at Joan Whalen Fine Art, New York City, from 1998 to 2001. She is well represented in several private collections in the U.S. and in Israel. She will be greatly missed by her loving and devoted aides, Violet Sternlicht, Meggon Wilcox and Ingrid Fishman; by her devoted friends & family; Suzanne Laurier, Diane Dawson, Sylvia Selfridge, The Newman Family of Long Island, Gerry Jackson, Marilyn Clark, Walter Mannenen, David Hall, Kenneth and Keith Carlson & their families. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, February 17, 2002, 11:30 AM at Crestwood Memorial Chapel, 33 Spring St, NYC (212-431-6712). Her interment will follow at the New Montefiore Cemetery, Wellwood Avenue, Pine Lawn, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Visiting Doctors, Mt. Sinai Medical Center, 1470 Madison Ave, NY, NY 10029, and/or Global Children, 300 Central Park West, Apt 10B, NY, NY 10024. For further information on services and burial only, call: 212-787-4355.

Her love, humor and how she affected each of us will live in our memories. In January, Congregation Anshei Shalom designated her as its first Aishes Chayil (a woman of valor) award recipient. She was grateful to be able to see everyone at that ceremony and surprised and humbled to be so honored. He who weds a good woman, it is as if he had fulfilled all the precepts of the Torah. Survived by her husband, Harold, who has lost his best friend in the whole world; daughters Lisa & Lori and dearest sons-in-law Sheldon and Paul and six grandchildren; brother Maurice and wife Phyllis, sister Rosalyn, brother-in-law Harry, sister-in-law Alice, nephews, nieces & cousins; a lifetime of dear friends and neighbors. title: Technology Briefing | Software: States Seek Windows Code
description: Nine states that oppose the proposed Microsoft antitrust settlement have asked a judge to let them examine the so-called source code of the company's Windows operating system. California, Iowa and the seven other states want to force the software maker to sell a version of Windows without the Internet Explorer browser. Microsoft argues that removing the Web search program from Windows would destroy the system. The states that refused to sign the settlement negotiated by the Bush administration said that they needed access to the Windows code to rebut Microsoft's argument that their proposal was not technically feasible. Microsoft has refused to give the states access to the Windows code, the states said in a court filing made public yesterday.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Panel Supports Patriotism In Schools
description: The State Senate Education Committee has voted to recommend teaching patriotism in each grade. The bill's Republican sponsor, Senator John Andrews, was disappointed with the outcome because his original bill would have mandated teaching patriotism, rather than encourage it. Mr. Andrews said the measure was needed to keep the country patriotic long after Sept. 11. The bill moves on to the full Senate. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Ex-Professor Sentenced
description: A former Yale professor was sentenced yesterday in federal court to 15 years in prison for possession of child pornography. The former professor, Antonio Lasaga, 52, a geochemist, pleaded guilty to downloading from the Internet what prosecutors said were 150,000 pornographic images of children. Mr. Lasaga had faced a maximum sentence of 20 years and $250,000 in fines, but a federal judge said that testimony by Mr. Lasaga's wife and son helped reduce the sentence. On Friday, on separate state charges, Mr. Lasaga will face sentencing for the sexual assault and videotaping of a 6-year-old. Mr. Lasaga, who pleaded no contest, faces a maximum possible penalty of 110 years.

title: CAMPBELL SOUP PROFIT FALLS ON HIGHER SPENDING
description: The Campbell Soup Company said its profit fell 25 percent in its most recent quarter as higher marketing spending failed to increase sales in the United States, where warm weather curbed demand. Net income fell to $203 million, or 49 cents a share, from $271 million, or 65 cents, a year earlier. Sales in the period, which ended Jan. 27 and was the second quarter of Campbell's fiscal year, rose 3.1 percent, to $1.81 billion from $1.76 billion, the company said. Campbell, which is based in Camden, N.J., spent 17 percent more on marketing as part of its plan to revive soup sales.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Profit At Drink Maker
description: The British drinks and confectionary group Cadbury Schweppes posted a 12 percent increase in full-year profit, helped by a strong performance from its noncarbonated drinks. Cadbury posted a pretax profit before restructuring costs, good will and amortization of $1.27 billion, above analysts' expectations of $1.23 billion to $1.25 billion and higher than the $1.13 billion a year earlier. Total sales rose to $7.8 billion from $6.45 billion last year. The company attributed the increase in profits to a strong performance from its North American drinks operations led by its Mott's juice brand, which rose 12 percent, and its European drinks business.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Accused Justice Seeks Salary
description: Justice Victor I. Barron, who was suspended after his indictment on bribery charges, is seeking continued payment of his salary. His lawyer has asked the State Court of Appeals to allow the justice to receive his usual pay while the case continues, according to court documents released yesterday. Depriving him of his $136,700 annual salary, wrote the lawyer, Barry Kamins, would cause the justice ''irreparable harm for an alleged criminal act of which he is presumed innocent.'' Court TV said it would televise the trial of Justice Barron, who is accused of receiving a kickback from a lawyer. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: A NATION CHALLENGED: Briefly Noted; U.S. PLANE CRASHES
description: An Air Force MC-130 transport plane crashed in Afghanistan on Tuesday but all eight of its crew survived, a spokesman for the Central Command said. Officials said the crash apparently was not caused by enemy fire. Pentagon officials said the plane was on a mission at the time but declined to give details. The MC-130 typically flies night missions and is used to transport Special Operations troops, for search and rescue and to refuel helicopters. Thom Shanker (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Intuit Posts Sharp Profit Gain
description: Intuit Inc. said it posted a big gain in profit for its fiscal second quarter as sales of its tax preparation software increased and it made money on investments. Net income was $119.9 million, or 55 cents a share, in the period ended Jan. 31, compared with $26.6 million, or 12 cents, in the year-earlier period. Sales rose 20 percent, to $547.2 million from $457.6 million. The latest quarter is typically Intuit's most profitable because of sales of tax software, which it markets to consumers under the TurboTax brand name and also provides to professional tax consultants. Intuit, which also makes Quicken personal finance software and QuickBooks for small-business accounting, had a gain on investments of $1.63 million, in contrast to a loss of $71.9 million in the period a year earlier.

title: A NATION CHALLENGED: Briefly Noted; PROTEST IN NEW JERSEY
description: About half the nearly 100 people jailed in Middlesex County, N.J., on immigration charges are refusing to eat some meals. Among their complaints are the length of their detentions and inadequate medical treatment, several detainees said. Kerry Gill, Immigration and Naturalization Service spokesman in Newark, said it was hard to say how many detainees were involved. The warden, Michael T. Abode, said that rather than go hungry, some detainees had bought food at the commissary, which sells candy and instant soup. Immigration and jail officials denied there were serious problems at the jail but said they would look into the complaints. Christopher Drew (NYT)

title: MARRIOTT POSTS QUARTERLY LOSS AS TRAVEL DECLINES
description: Marriott International Inc. posted a loss in its fourth quarter as business and leisure travel fell and the company wrote down the value of property and loans. The loss of $116 million, or 48 cents a share, is in contrast to net income of $149 million, or 59 cents a share, a year earlier. Marriott, which is based in Bethesda, Md., said its revenue fell 10 percent, to $2.87 billion. Marriott took $85 million in write-downs of off-balance-sheet loans it guaranteed or made to developers. Arne Sorenson, the chief financial officer, said that no more write-downs were expected. The company had $1.15 billion in off-balance-sheet items representing loans and guarantees to hotel developers as of the end of the year. The company's revenue per available room, a measure of average occupancy and room rate, fell 25 percent in the quarter from a year earlier, compared with the company's estimate of a decline of as much as 35 percent.

title: A Compact-Size Music Player In the Subcompact Class
description: How much smaller can MP3 players get? The new MPIO-DMK player from Digital Global Network is so tiny that most of its 88-millimeter length is taken up by the single AAA battery that powers it for 10 hours. About the size of a lipstick case, the DMK comes in 32-, 64- and 128-megabyte versions, transfers music files through a standard U.S.B. connection and is compatible with both the Mac and PC. Its backlighted L.C.D. screen can display song information in several languages.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Chip Maker Ends Merger Talks

An Infineon spokeswoman, Katja Schlendorf, said the talks, which were at an early stage, had ended. The announcement comes as Hynix's chief executive, Park Chong Sup, said he was close to an agreement to sell his company's memory chip business to Micron Technology Inc. for about $4 billion, according to Yonhap News. The combination of Micron, the No. 2 producer of dynamic random access memory chips, with Hynix would create the largest DRAM producer, surpassing the Samsung Electronics Company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKINNEY, ROBERT S.
description: McKINNEY-Robert S. Age 60. Of Manhattan, died February 11, 2002. Raised in Bayside, Queens, the son of a New York City Police Detective, he had a long, impressive career in computer systems, rising to Chief Information Officer of top financial services institutions. After graduating the U.S. Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, N.Y., he circumnavigated the globe at a young age before earning a Master's degree from Columbia University & embarking on his meteoric career. Far more impressive, however, was his passionate commitment to those he loved. He is survived by his wife Janet Robilotti, whose marriage to him was an epic and perpetual honeymoon, his sons Robert, Richard, James and Glenn, his daughter Meredith and his stepson James Robilotti, as well as daughters-in-law Gina, Cindy, Karissa and Kim, and six grandchildren: Alexandra, Isabella, Julia, Scott, Ryan and Jack, who were enchanted by his guitar playing and his totally uninhibited affection for them. Bob McKinney's children saw their father drop all other commitments to be there in times of need, and heard his encouragement and love in times of peace. He was the loving, courageous father all children deserve but not enought get to have. An expert sailor and private pilot, he and his wife loved soaring in his plane and being on the water. They adventured in Honduras and Central America and cherished their jogs throught Manhattan together. He leaves behind an unfathomable void, but no regrets, as he always told those close to him how much he loved them and delighted in hearing it back. A memorial service will be held Saturday, February 23rd, 2PM at Church of Saint Luke in the Field, 487 Hudson St, N.Y.C. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the New York City Rescue Mission, 299 Broadway, Room 1318, New York, N.Y. 10007, Attention: G. McKinney.

Thompson Moore, Jr. and the sister of the late Henry R. Luce. Born in Teng Chou, Shandong, China of missionary parents. She attended Abbott Academy and Wellesley College, of which she was a trustee. Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller appointed her chairman of the State University of New York. She was a trustee of China Institute in America, the Asia Foundation and the National Board of the Y.W.C.A. She was president of the United Board for Christian Education in Asia and chairman of the Institute of International Education. For sixty-three years she was a director of the Henry Luce Foundation, Inc. A memorial service will be held on a date to be announced. In its quiet expression of formal sorrow, it is a ''Dark Elegies'' for the 21st century.

title: Mammograms and Personal Choice
description: Conflicting judgments about the value of routine mammography have left women in a quandary. Some experts say the evidence that mammography reduces breast cancer death rates by detecting cancer early is substantial, while others believe that routine mammograms provide very little, if any, benefit. As a fiftysomething woman and an epidemiologist tracking the data, I believe that for now women 50 to 69 should stay the course and continue to have regular mammograms. But we ought not to dismiss concerns about flaws in the existing data, and women should know why experts are not speaking with a single voice.

title: A Good Night's Work
description: Very early yesterday it became clear that the Shays-Meehan campaign finance reform bill would pass in the House. Hours later the day dawned as the measure headed toward the Senate, where the majority leader, Tom Daschle, vowed to schedule a quick vote. He was right to take maximum advantage of the momentum. Campaign reform passed the Senate last year with 59 votes. Yesterday, Senator Ernest Hollings of South Carolina, previously a ''no,'' announced he would switch his position and provide the 60th vote needed for the bill and to overcome a likely filibuster. Foes of reform should recognize they have lost, and let the bill pass right away.

title: Editorial Observer; Manhattan's Silk Stocking District Becomes Gold-Plated
description: The price of a State Senate seat on the East Side of Manhattan soared this week into the range normally reserved for the area's tony real estate. The total price tag for this single job in Albany is not public yet, and with New York State's disgrace of a campaign finance law, the truth may never be fully known. But some estimates have the Democratic candidate, Liz Krueger, raising and spending almost $1 million to win the special election for a seat that opened when the departing senator, Roy Goodman, joined Mayor Michael Bloomberg's staff. Her opponent, Assemblyman John Ravitz, and his Republican Party leaders may have spent more than double that in defeat.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bombardier Disputes Price Of Adtranz
description: Bombardier Inc. demanded 1 billion euros ($870 million) from DaimlerChrysler, contending the carmaker overstated the value of the Adtranz train unit sold to the Canadian company last year. The carmaker did not disclose 850 million euros in costs from contractual obligations to third parties, said Dominique Dionne, a spokeswoman for Bombardier, which paid $752 million for the unit in cash and assumed debt. The contention is ''baseless,'' a DaimlerChrysler board member, Manfred Bischoff, said. The companies said the dispute would go to arbitration rather than court.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: An Effort To Make Smokers Think Twice
description: The Health Ministry has ordered tobacco companies to display on cigarette packs photographs showing the effects of smoking. Of the five pictures, one shows premature babies breathing through tubes and another shows a depressed couple in bed after an unsuccessful attempt at sex. Brazil has tightened regulations on the tobacco industry since 1995, banning cigarette advertisements at sporting and cultural events and on television until 11 p.m., and forbidding smoking in enclosed areas.

title: An Attach's Job Ill Prepares Him for the Stalag
description: ''Hart's War'' appears to be another of the Greatest Generation action dramas, coming on the heels of last year's botched ''Pearl Harbor.'' But ''War'' wants to be much more than pitched battles and casualties rendered with up-to-the-minute technology depicting violence. There are, of course, a few obligatory episodes of big-budget brutality wedged into this unwieldy crunch of social melodrama and P.O.W. action movie. But rather than creating dramatic tension or irony, the contrasts combine to result in the oddest thing -- a movie that wants to be everything and adds up to nothing. ''War'' is a film that tries to excel on several levels and falls flat on all of them.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Judge Bars Police Checkpoint

The page casts a softer, reflected light back onto her face, sharpening the profile.

It is among the first major construction plans to be approved for the area since Sept. 11, said Jake Lynn, a Council spokesman. The plan, which would need the approval of the full Council, calls for a 45-story residential building with retail space on the ground floor and an outdoor plaza at 10 Liberty Street. The development, which would contain more than 485 apartments and a public parking garage, would have entrances on Liberty, William and Cedar Streets and is set for a vote by the full Council on Feb. 27.
