description: A newly released study of advanced-placement mathematics and science courses, which have become an important ingredient for admission to elite colleges, is highly critical of the curriculums that most of those courses cover and the way they are taught.

title: Commissioner Calls Smoking Public Health Enemy No. 1 and Asks Drug Firms for Ammunition
description: A day after Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said he would seek a significant increase in the cigarette tax but dismantle the City Health Department's smoking cessation program, Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, the health commissioner, said yesterday that his main priority would be to combat smoking in the city, perhaps using money from companies that make products to help smokers quit.

title: Another Snag For Comcast As Its E-Mail Goes Awry
description: Hitting yet another snag in its nascent Internet service, the Comcast Corporation said yesterday that it was scrambling to repair an e-mail failure that had left as many as 300,000 customers unable to receive messages.

title: Holiday on Monday: Washington's Birthday
description: NEW YORK

title: Silver and Bronze for U.S. in Doubles Luge
description: PARK CITY, Utah, Feb. 15  The United States solidified its status as a new world powerhouse in the obscure sport of doubles luge this morning, when its two teams won silver and bronze.

title: Dell Reports Strong Earnings for Quarter
description: Dell Computer said yesterday that it had reaped the benefits of unexpectedly good holiday sales to record strong earnings for the fourth quarter of its fiscal year, but it predicted no immediate end to the weak demand for computers.

title: Glaring at Two-Thirds of an 'Axis'
description: To the Editor:

title: More Homeowners, More Luxury, More Moving
description: AS the economy struggled, there was speculation about the health of the housing market. Would it follow the technology sector in a downward spiral? The answer, said David Lereah, the chief economist at the National Association of Realtors, is no.

title: Italians Hope Blair Visit Helps Berlusconi's European Image
description: Many Italians are hopeful that a visit here on Friday by Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain will mark not just the beginning of a new closeness between the two nations, but also an end to Italy's keenly felt isolation in Europe.

title: William Dwyer Dies at 72; A Judge of Vast Influence
description: William L. Dwyer, a federal district judge whose imprint on the Pacific Northwest stretched from 500-year-old forests saved from logging by his court rulings to the major league baseball team created as a result of his work as a trial lawyer, died on Tuesday at his home in Seattle. He was 72.

title: Mine Wrecks Tank; 3 Israeli Soldiers Die
description: For the first time, Palestinians destroyed an Israeli tank, planting a mine that punched through its belly and killed at least three soldiers.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Loss At Telecom Concern
description: Telecom Italia posted its first loss in two decades after writing down 3.8 billion euros ($3.3 billion) in assets, as the chairman, Marco Tronchetti Provera, moves to improve the finances of the telephone company. Mr. Tronchetti Provera, who led a group that bought control of the company in July, inherited a number of businesses that have plunged in value since they were purchased by his predecessor, and the company is taking steps to account for the lost value and to sell the assets. While the write-down left Telecom Italia with a loss for 2001, operating earnings increased. Telecom Italia's sales last year rose 13 percent, to 30.8 billion euros ($26.7 billion), and operating profit increased 4.7 percent, to 6.7 billion euros ($5.8 billion).

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Ryanair Increases Flights
description: The low-budget Irish airline Ryanair added more than 30 daily flights on 10 international routes from its hub in Hahn, Germany, outside Frankfurt, where it expects to serve 1.5 million passengers over the next year. On Tuesday, a German court lifted an injunction that had been granted to Lufthansa to prevent Ryanair from comparing prices on its advertisements. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Before You Leap, Hire an Expert to Look
description: CONNECTICUT has an abundance of old houses, and J. Reilly is familiar with many of them, including the grand and not-so-grand.

title: Enron Official Says Many Knew About Shaky Company Finances
description: An Enron executive who warned of dire financial problems months before Enron collapsed appeared before lawmakers today and placed much of the blame for the company's demise on its former chief executive, Jeffrey K. Skilling.

title: From the BBC, A Watery World
description: Across the water is the leviathan called the BBC: a gargantuan producer of all kinds of programming, with five channels and a 24-hour-a-day public. In the water, a blue whale, 100 feet long and with arteries big enough for a man to swim through, cruises azure seas as part of ''The Blue Planet,'' an eight-hour, four-part BBC production about life in the oceans.

title: Realism in Cutting Emissions
description: The climate policy President Bush announced yesterday sets out a better and far more workable approach for measuring progress against global warming than the one in the Kyoto framework he rejected last spring. The president set the goal of an 18 percent reduction over the next 10 years in greenhouse gas intensity -- the ratio of emissions to economic activity -- rather than an arbitrary goal for curbs on total emissions. And he announced steps to get there.

title: New Mantra for Revelers: Eat, Drink and Be Comfy
description: VICTORIAN velvet couches and cozy armchairs were arranged in clusters around coffee tables. Colorful floor pillows were strewn about. Bunches of red tulips bowed gracefully from simple vases, adding a rosy glow, and the carpet had just been meticulously vacuumed, one last time.

title: Europeans Give Bush Plan on Climate Change a Tepid Reception
description: Saying that any action taken to reduce emissions of heat-trapping gases was at least a step in the right direction, the European Union gave a tepid welcome today to President Bush's new proposals to tackle climate change.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a television review on Feb. 4 about ''Bertie and Elizabeth,'' a ''Masterpiece Theater'' presentation on the life of Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother, misstated the policy of the Church of England on divorce, a factor in the abdication of her brother-in-law King Edward VIII, who became the Duke of Windsor. An obituary of her daughter Princess Margaret on Sunday also included the error. The church does not forbid divorce. It revokes the right to marry in a parish church while a former spouse is living. But even then, depending on circumstances, a priest can allow a church wedding.

title: Verizon Wireless Will Lay Off 1,000
description: Verizon Wireless, the largest wireless carrier in the United States, is planning to lay off 1,000 employees in a reorganization in the next few weeks, a company spokesman said last night.

title: Seeing Squalid Despair In Stark Black and White
description: Be grateful that the photographs in Roger Ballen's first big gallery show in New York, at the Gagosian Gallery on Madison Avenue, are not in color. His images of the impoverished, often filthy, sometimes deranged-looking inhabitants of the areas around Johannesburg and Pretoria in South Africa make the walls bristle. They don't need to be any more immediate, visually complex or emotionally disorienting than they already are.

title: They Have Equity. Now What Do They Do With It?
description: Repeat buyers usually slide through the mortgage process quickly because they have accumulated equity in their previous homes, which can be put down on their next purchase. Repeat buyers must decide, however, how much of their equity they want to invest in the next house, which is essentially an illiquid asset.

title: Union Talks Set to Resume Between City And Teachers
description: Contract talks will resume today between New York City and the union representing 80,000 public school teachers, with the union continuing its push for a double-digit pay increase despite the city's budgetary woes. Formal negotiations broke off 11 months ago.

title: Janet Sobel
description: Gary Snyder Fine Art

title: Objects of Affection: A Rug, a Pot, a Cat, a Cross
description: It may be an abstract masterpiece by an impossibly hip artist, a daughter's nursery-school finger painting, a quilt made by Grandma or an overstuffed chair picked up at a fire sale. Whatever the special item is, it connotes warmth and comfort and well-being  and says "home." In that spirit, these people were asked about that certain something.

title: Dow Closes Above 10,000 for First Time in a Month
description: Stock prices were narrowly mixed in directionless trading yesterday, but the Dow Jones industrial average closed above the 10,000 level for the first time in more than a month.

title: Teresa Hubbard And Alexander Birchler
description: Tanya Bonakdar Gallery

title: The Thrill of Cheap China, and Other Deals
description: EVERYONE knows there is nothing wrong with buying inexpensive home furnishings, and nowadays you can find plenty of slickly designed items that look expensive but are mass-produced and priced to please. Designers and architects love to divulge the thrill of finding jaw-droppingly cheap items at Ikea or at Home Depot that can pass any design snob's once-over.

title: S.& P. CUTS GAP'S CREDIT RATINGS TO JUNK LEVEL
description: The credit ratings of Gap Inc. were cut to junk yesterday by Standard & Poor's, which said that increased competition, merchandising blunders and a glut of stores had led to a string of profit and sales declines. Gap, owner of Gap, Banana Republic and Old Navy stores, ''faces significant challenges in turning around the performance of each of its brands,'' S.& P. said. Ratings cuts make it more expensive to borrow money. The company's same-store sales have dropped for 21 consecutive months and on Feb. 27, Gap is expected to report its first back-to-back quarterly loss in 25 years. Earlier yesterday, Gap said it received commitments for a $1.3 billion credit line from banks.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Feb. 5 about Henry Kloss, an inventor of innovative audio and video components, misspelled the surname of a partner with whom he developed the AR-1, the first speaker small enough to fit on a bookshelf while able to produce rich, deep bass tones. The partner was Edgar M. Villchur, not Vilchur. The obituary also misstated the year they developed the AR-1. It was 1954, not 1952.

title: Scottish and Newcastle to Buy Finnish Brewer in $1.7 Billion Deal
description: Moving to gain access to the fast-growing Eastern European beer market, Scottish and Newcastle, Britain's largest brewer, said today that it would buy Hartwall of Finland for $1.7 billion in stock.

title: Heisenberg and History
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a link between Alzheimer's disease and high blood levels of a substance called homocysteine referred incorrectly to the foods that provide certain B vitamins, all of them able to lower homocysteine levels. Fruits and leafy vegetables provide the B vitamin called folic acid, but not vitamins B6 or B12. Vitamin B6 is found in dried yeast, liver, organ meats, whole-grain cereals, fish and legumes; vitamin B12 occurs in liver, organ meat and other meat, eggs and dairy products.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Driver Who Mowed Down 19 Returned to Hit 7, Police Say
description: A man suspected of shooting a woman last weekend and of deliberately running down 19 people in a hit-and-run spree in Midtown Manhattan on Tuesday was seized at his New Jersey home yesterday after he hijacked a car at gunpoint in Secaucus, returned to Manhattan and, the police said, did it again -- plowing into more Midtown pedestrians.

title: Evoking Several Famous Names at 18
description: Watching Peter Cincotti, the wiry, fresh-faced, 18-year-old singer and pianist hunched over a piano, a lock of hair brushing one eyebrow, conjures images of a very young Mel Gibson or Hugh Grant portraying the youthful Hoagy Carmichael in an imaginary film biography. Hugely talented, Mr. Cincotti, who is appearing at the Oak Room at the Algonquin Hotel, has the sound to match his look. On top of his sophisticated jazz piano, he sings in a boyish, Sinatra-style baritone with a distinctively rapid vibrato.

title: INSIDE
description: China Arrests Westerners

title: Sh! They're Making Mini-Masterpieces
description: TO feel at home. It's an emotional connection, an intangible tug of the heart. To some, it happens in a cabin in the wilderness; to others, a quiet corner beside the kitchen window. The home is the most intimate of landmarks, the place where newborns explore the boundless frontiers of carpeting, and memories are like doors opening into every room.

title: Energy Department Recommends Yucca Mountain for Nuclear Waste Burial
description: The Energy Department recommended this evening that President Bush designate Yucca Mountain, a volcanic ridge in the desert about 100 miles northwest of Las Vegas, as the main burial spot for radioactive wastes from the nation's nuclear power reactors and bomb production.

title: Seeking Comfort in a Market That's Still Warm
description: EVERY economic cycle produces a proverb on how best to achieve the American dream. During the inflation-frenzied 1970's and early 80's, it was ''Buy as much house as you can afford and finance it for as long as the lender will allow.'' With interest rates, house prices and incomes racing upward, leverage was considered a good thing. A hefty mortgage payment would soon turn to chump change while the house's value doubled or tripled. A house was an investment.

title: Handmaiden to an Egotist: The Years With Ezra Pound
description: OLGA RUDGE AND EZRA POUND -- 'What Thou Lovest Well . . .'

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Rudolph W. Giuliani's free trip to London on the Concorde for a knighthood ceremony misstated the current fare for the flight in some copies. It is $12,775 round trip, not one way.

title: Ice Dancers Struggle To Prove Legitimacy
description: Long battered by critics who say that corrupt judging has stripped it of credibility as a sport, ice dancing begins three nights of competition on Friday under harsh scrutiny.

title: Answering Accusations With a Gallic Shrug
description: It's not as if France were one of the world's superpowers on ice. And it's not as if a judge bending to political pressure is unheard of here.

title: Arabs Deploy New Explosive Against Tank; 3 Israelis Die
description: For the first time, Palestinian militants destroyed an Israeli tank tonight, planting a mine that punched through the tank's belly, killing at least three soldiers and lightly wounding a fourth.

title: Pushkin's Countess Turns Enemy of the People
description: The main thing about writers like Marcel Proust and James Joyce is not that they did not tell a story straight but that they told a story. The main thing about ''The Queen of Spades,'' a new Canadian ballet production with spectacular mixed-media effects, is that it has trouble telling a story, much less the one it promises.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Bargaining For State Workers
description: The Washington House passed a bill that would give state employees collective bargaining power. If the Senate approves the measure and it is signed into law, workers will negotiate for their wages with the governor, and the legislature will be allowed only to approve or reject the outcome. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Disney's Chief Seems Cool on a Hot Seat
description: When Michael D. Eisner, the longtime chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, takes the stage at the company's annual shareholder meeting in Hartford, Conn., on Tuesday, he is going to have a lot of explaining to do.

title: Canadian Figure Skating Pair Awarded a Shared Gold Medal
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 15  The International Olympic Committee, seeking to end a controversy in the pairs figure skating competition, announced today that a gold medal would also be awarded to the Canadian team. The Russian pair will keep the gold medal awarded to them on Monday, officials said, but a French judge at the center of the controversy has been suspended for misconduct.

title: From Garbage Time to a Prime-Time Role
description: Andre Stanley, who made the St. John's basketball team as a walk-on this fall, called his mother from the Queens campus after a recent practice. His mother, Stephanie, who last year had a leg amputated because of complications from diabetes, answered the phone in the eighth-floor apartment where they live on York Street in the Farragut housing projects in Fort Greene, Brooklyn.

title: Jidda Journal; Where the Prophet Trod, He Begs, Tread Lightly
description: Sami Angawi built his house around the wind.

title: If Arguing Won't Move Insurers, Maybe a Gun Will
description: This country's sad state of health care for the poor and disenfranchised is a great movie subject. Until that film comes along, we'll have to endure ''John Q.,'' which will leave most audiences in dire need of medical attention, though it would be hard to say if that need will come from the painful collection of plot clichs or Aaron Zigman's assaultive soundtrack. ''John Q.'' is a remarkable document, so ham-fisted that it sabotages its own worthwhile arguments.

title: O.K., Pesky but Perky, Too (and That Cute Bushy Tail Is a Plus)
description: When it comes to squirrels I'm reminded of the old union song ''Which Side Are You on?,'' written in the 1930's about the mining wars in Harlan County, Ky.

title: Vernon A. Walters, 85, Former Envoy to U.N.
description: Vernon A. Walters, a former ambassador to the United Nations and deputy director of central intelligence, died Sunday in West Palm Beach, Florida. He was 85.

title: Suspect, Changing Story, Says American Reporter Is Dead
description: The chief suspect in the kidnapping of the American journalist Daniel Pearl said today that the reporter was dead, and that he had carried out the abduction three weeks ago ''under my own free will.''

title: 62 Million Viewers on Thursday
description: With a 17.6 Nielsen rating for Thursday night's Salt Lake Winter Olympics broadcast, NBC's seven-day rating is now a 19.2, up 14 percent from CBS's during the Winter Games from Nagano in 1998.

title: Objects of Affection: A Rug, a Pot, a Cat, a Cross

description: BASEBALL

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: 2nd Satellite Radio Service Begins
description: Sirius Satellite Radio introduced its satellite-delivered radio service in four cities yesterday, hoping to catch up with a competitor, XM Satellite Radio, whose service began operating last September and expanded nationwide in November. Sirius began offering 60 commercial-free music channels and 40 news, sports and entertainment channels to subscribers in Denver, Houston, Phoenix and Jackson, Miss. The service costs $12.95 a month and requires customers to buy an antenna and receiver for $249. It is currently available only in vehicles. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: Objects of Affection: A Rug, a Pot, a Cat, a Cross
description: It may be an abstract masterpiece by an impossibly hip artist, a daughter's nursery-school finger painting, a quilt made by Grandma or an overstuffed chair picked up at a fire sale. Whatever the special item is, it connotes warmth and comfort and well-being -- and says ''home.'' In that spirit, these people were asked about that certain something. KIMBERLY STEVENS

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The real crime was the killing of Yugoslavia and crucifying me here.''

title: Halliburton Says Judge Halts Asbestos Suits
description: Halliburton said today that a federal bankruptcy judge had temporarily halted more than 200,000 asbestos claims against its Dresser Industries unit. Dresser used to own a business facing the health lawsuits.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review on Feb. 5 about Athol Fugard's ''Sorrows and Rejoicings'' at the Second Stage Theater referred incorrectly to the setting, Karoo. It is a southern region of South Africa, also called Great Karoo, not a village.

title: Will Malone Scuttle German Cable Deal? Or Play the Patient Vulture?
description: The American cable magnate John C. Malone appears set to walk away from a $5 billion deal to buy the majority of Germany's cable television systems, but Europe has hardly seen the last of him.

title: Co-Presidents Of State Senate Devise Plan To Share Power
description: Ending the impasse that had paralyzed New Jersey's Legislature for the past five weeks, two top legislators announced today that they had agreed on a plan to share power in the evenly divided State Senate.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Woman Gets Grisly Gift
description: A woman at an East Village hair salon found the tip of a human finger yesterday when she opened a jewelry box that had been delivered to her as an apparent Valentine's Day gift, investigators said. The name of the woman, a 27-year-old hairdresser, was not released. The police later traced a phone call that came into the salon on East Eighth Street to a former boyfriend of the woman and took him into custody when they noticed that he had a bandaged left hand. The man was scheduled to be taken last night to Bellevue Hospital Center for a psychiatric evaluation, the police said. Kevin Flynn (NYT)

title: County Asks State for Pills To Block Radioactivity Effect
description: Westchester County officials said today that they would ask the state for more than 500,000 potassium iodide tablets for people living near the Indian Point nuclear plants, and perhaps beyond, in an effort to thwart radiation-induced thyroid cancer in an emergency.

title: Middle-Class Parents Say Schools Have Been Cut to the Bone
description: Since the first days of school last September, parents at Public School 87, the quintessential middle-class school on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, have brought reams of paper so teachers can photocopy homework assignments.

title: Canadian Figure Skating Pair Awarded a Shared Gold Medal
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 15  The International Olympic Committee, seeking to end a controversy in the pairs figure skating competition, announced today that a gold medal would also be awarded to the Canadian team. The Russian pair will keep the gold medal awarded to them on Monday, officials said, but a French judge at the center of the controversy has been suspended for misconduct.

title: The Accused: Expressing 'the Will of the People'
description: Following are excerpts from testimony given Thursday by Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav leader, at the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia, as recorded by The New York Times. Mr. Milosevic's remarks, in Serbian, were translated by a court interpreter.

title: Williams Chief Says One Issue Is Delaying Profit Report
description: The chief executive of the Williams Companies told investors yesterday why his company was not like its one-time competitor, Enron. But first he had to deal with the complications of having copied some of Enron's financing methods.

title: Initial Unemployment Claims Continued to Slide Last Week
description: The number of workers filing initial applications for jobless benefits fell for the fifth week in the last six, the Labor Department said today, a sign that layoffs are slowing.

title: New Video Releases
description: Hearts in Atlantis

title: Snowboarders Leading Charge on U.S. Ski Team
description: HUNTSVILLE, Utah, Feb. 15 - Bill Marolt, the president of the United States Ski and Snowboard Association, brazenly predicted long before the 2002 Salt Lake City Olympics that his team would win 10 medals. It was a bold statement considering the American skiers and snowboarders won six medals four years ago at the Nagano Olympics - and that was a record haul.

title: From the BBC, a Watery World
description: Across the water is the leviathan called the BBC: a gargantuan producer of all kinds of programming, with five channels and a 24-hour-a-day public. In the water, a blue whale, 100 feet long and with arteries big enough for a man to swim through, cruises azure seas as part of "The Blue Planet," an eight-hour, four-part BBC production about life in the oceans.

title: The Living Room? Just Drop It Over There, Please
description: THE Taylors needed a ''dream house'' -- fast. When Nicholas Taylor, a sales manager of construction equipment, was transferred last summer to Roanoke, Va., from Staffordshire, England, he and his wife, Julie, had a week to find a home. They had four requirements: the house had to be near a good high school for their two teenagers, be close to Nicholas's job, be big enough to accommodate visiting relatives and have a view.

title: Late August Trial Date for Lindh Set
description: Afederal judge in Virginia said today that trial would begin in late August for John Walker Lindh, the 21-year-old Californian who fought against America with the Taliban and Al Qaeda in Afghanistan.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a court-ordered shutdown of Interior Department computers to safeguard an accounting system that manages money for Indians misspelled the surname of a woman who initiated the lawsuit that resulted in the order. She is Elouise Cobell, not Cabell.

title: 'The Last Man'
description: Directed by Harry Ralston

title: Remembering Skip, the Midwestern Colossus in My Kitchen
description: TO me and many others, I suspect, contractors are scary people. They are usually bigger than we are. They speak a different language, filled with names of strange gadgets and processes. They're good with their hands, which always frightens those of us who aren't. With most of them, you're forever on tenterhooks (a term that they, unlike me, can probably define). Sometimes it gets much worse, and you end up at loggerheads (ditto). Or even worse, in court (this, alas, is something I know about). Even when things are going well, you can't help but feel they're laughing at you and your boundless ignorance of how the world fits together.

title: First Croatian Medalist Wins the Gold for Her Family
description: HUNTSVILLE, Utah, Feb. 14 -- For others, a training session might be four hours. For Janica Kostelic, it would be twice as long. While others would practice by skiing through 400 gates a day, Kostelic would ski through 1,200. While war in the former Yugoslavia stopped many of her Croatian teammates from training or from skiing at all, Kostelic and her family fled their native Zagreb and found a place to train in the distant snow of the mountains.

title: Kidd's Misses Add Up as Nets Lose Again
description: First the Nets lost Kenyon Martin (bruised right forearm) for the entire second half. Then Jason Kidd lost his shooting touch. Eventually, the Nets lost another game, an 85-80 decision to the Detroit Pistons tonight at Continental Arena that gave New Jersey (32-17) three consecutive losses for the first time this season.

title: Jets and Jones Talk Contract
description: The Jets have spoken to the agent for middle linebacker Marvin Jones about a contract extension before free agency begins March 1.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. The ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on

title: Reviews/Fashion; Lauren: Edwardian But Cut For Curves
description: If Ralph Lauren were as rich in irony as he is in romance, he would commission a contemporary artist to copy the large Victorian mural that served as a backdrop yesterday for his splendid fall collection, held amid the dark paneling and Persian carpets of his headquarters on Madison Avenue. Except that Mr. Lauren should substitute his own likeness for the faces of the high-hatted English gentlemen milling around in the scene, so Waldo-like is his immersion into that supercivilized world.

title: INSIDE ART
description: Frank Stella Makes a Gift

title: Editors' Note; SPECIAL TODAY -- Nesting
description: One of the 43 million Americans who spent last year looking for a home recounts an experience that was time-consuming, frustrating and emotional, but in the end deeply satisfying. With articles on buying, building, fixing up and furnishing.

title: 53 Expelled in Falun Gong Protests in Beijing
description: BEIJING, Feb. 15  The Beijing police said they had detained a total of 59 foreign members of the Falun Gong spiritual movement involved in protests here on Thursday and had expelled all but six of them by this evening. Those expelled included 33 Americans, according to the American Embassy, which said it had received the information from Chinese authorities but had no further details about the protesters or where they had been sent.

title: Alpine Skill Gives Europeans an Edge in Giant Slalom
description: There is no end now to all the talk of snowboarding as America's sport. The American sweep of the men's halfpipe event on Monday and Kelly Clark's gold medal in women's halfpipe the day before made an entire nation take notice of what has been in its backyard (or back country) for two decades.

title: No Knee-Whacking, but It's a Ratings Spike
description: As an Olympic scandal, the figure skating judging furor is great fodder for NBC's ratings, but it is not the pure gold of Tonya Harding's entourage whacking the leg of Nancy Kerrigan, just in time for CBS to maximize it and generate astounding ratings for the 1994 Winter Olympics.

title: House Adopts New Tax Cuts; Senate Votes For Benefits
description: The House today passed a Republican-sponsored package of tax cuts and other measures intended to help the economy, rebuffing an effort by the Democratic-controlled Senate to put further tax reductions aside for now and move quickly just to extend unemployment benefits.

title: Executives Nominated To Lead Ad Group
description: The American Association of Advertising Agencies in New York has nominated executives to serve as officers for the 2002-2003 year.

description: It may be an abstract masterpiece by an impossibly hip artist, a daughter's nursery-school finger painting, a quilt made by Grandma or an overstuffed chair picked up at a fire sale. Whatever the special item is, it connotes warmth and comfort and well-being -- and says ''home.'' In that spirit, these people were asked about that certain something. KIMBERLY STEVENS

title: Personal Touches to Highlight Bush's Asian Visit Next Week
description: President Bush will speak to American troops in the demilitarized zone between North and South Korea next week during a three-nation, six-day trip to Asia and will appear live on television in China during a question-and-answer session with students at Tsinghua University in Beijing.

title: G.O.P. Bloc Stayed Solid To Guarantee Bill's Passage
description: The campaign finance bill was approved early today not because of any new ground swell of support for restricting political donations but because most Republicans who had voted for similar measures in the past did not change their position.

title: Man in Need of a Bookcase Takes On an Empty Wall
description: HERE was the problem: My wife and I have a little Victorian house on eastern Long Island, with small rooms and almost no storage space, and I am a book critic who needs an almost infinite amount of bookshelves.

title: Cheney Says America's Allies Would Support Action in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15  Vice President Dick Cheney said today that he believes America's reluctant allies would support the United States "if aggressive action is required" in Iraq, and said the United States is prepared to use "all the means at its disposal" to stop Saddam Hussein from developing weapons of mass destruction.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: U.S. Trade Official Cites New Approach
description: Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, said during a visit to Kenya that the African Growth and Opportunity Act, a law approved by Congress in 2000 that gives 35 African countries duty-free access to American markets, represents the United States' new approach to helping Africa. ''The age of dependency is over,'' he told reporters at the start of a trip that will also take him to South Africa and Botswana.

title: Pauline Trigre, 93, Exemplar of American Style, Dies
description: Pauline Trigre, the Paris-born designer who was not only her own best model but also an elegant and chic symbol of the American fashion industry for more than half a century, died at her home on the East Side of Manhattan on Wednesday night, said her daughter-in-law Melanie Radley. She was 93.

title: CUMMINS AND BRUNSWICK FORM VENTURE IN BOAT INDUSTRY
description: Cummins Inc. and the Brunswick Corporation are forming a venture to supply diesel engines and parts for commercial and recreational boats. The companies said they would each own half of the venture, Cummins MerCruiser Diesel Marine. Cummins Marine's general manager, Scott Patrohay, was named president of Cummins MerCruiser, which will be based in Charleston, S.C. Cummins, based in Columbus, Ind., is expanding beyond making diesel engines for heavy-duty trucks to include marine and power generators. Brunswick, based in Lake Forest, Ill., shed its camping, fishing, bicycle and cooler businesses last year to focus on marine engines, pleasure boats, fitness equipment, bowling and billiards.

title: Grabbing Viewers 'Tween 8 and 14
description: TWO years ago, Terri Minsky's agent sent the Disney Channel the script of a pilot episode she'd written for a comedy series about a 15-year-old girl. The Disney executives asked her if she could shave a few years from her heroine's age. Twelve would be perfect.

title: A Tender Ta-Ta For a Pub Mate
description: The challenge faced by Fred Schepisi in bringing Graham Swift's Booker Prize-winning novel ''Last Orders'' to the screen can hardly be underestimated. Like James Joyce in ''Dubliners,'' Mr. Swift refracts history, place and social class through the smoky filters of dialect, consciousness and memory.

title: Qwest Moves To Shore Up Its Finances
description: Qwest Communications International said yesterday that it would draw on a $4 billion line of bank credit to cover its short-term cash needs after being rebuffed by its customary short-term lenders.

title: Six Named in Terror Warning Had Already Been Imprisoned
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has dropped the search for 6 of the 17 men named in a public alert about a possible terrorist attack in the United States after learning that they were already in custody in Yemen, federal law enforcement officials said today.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FOSTER WHEELER, Hamilton, Bermuda, an engineering and construction company, said it won contracts worth $70 million to build three power plants in Germany.

title: It's a Bird! It's a Plane! Gee Whiz, It's Wendy's Daughter!
description: ''Return to Never Land,'' the breezy, confident sequel to Disney's 1953 animated classic, ''Peter Pan,'' comes outfitted with a perky tag line: ''Faith, trust and pixie dust.'' Those are the three requirements for anyone who dreams of flying without wings to become airborne.

title: Cocaine and Intensity of H.I.V. Are Related in a Study of Mice
description: Research in mice may help explain something that doctors have noticed in people who are infected with H.I.V.: cocaine use seems to make the disease progress faster and lead to more of the opportunistic infections that are the hallmark of AIDS.

title: The Philippine Wars
description: The main public hospital here serves 300,000 people and has next to nothing. No running water. No medicines. No ambulance. No anesthetic.

title: A Pragmatic Approach To a Bad-News Budget
description: As Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has made the rounds this week trying to sell his austere budget plan, one thing has been notably absent: sweeping, ideological pronouncements about how his budget will shape city policy or transform its delivery of services to reflect his political beliefs.

title: R Is for Reading (D Is for Dispute)
description: To the Editor:

title: Facing Down the Adjustable, Fixed and 3-Point Mortgage
description: Borrowers can find it difficult to wade through the roughly 10,000 mortgage lenders and more than 100 permutations of the mortgage loan. But information on how to navigate the industry, which is laden with jargon and fine print, is a mouse click away. There are more than 100,000 Web sites related to real estate.

title: A Matter of Pride For a Nation of Skaters
description: On most wintry days, the winding Rideau Canal is an oasis of tranquillity in this bustling capital, where government employees and high-tech workers ice skate on their lunch hours and commute to work with an eye on the giant ice sculptures on either shore.

title: LIPA Chairman Seeking to Extend Temporary 5.8 Percent Surcharge
description: With a 5.8 percent temporary surcharge on Long Islanders' electric bills set to expire next month, the chairman of the Long Island Power Authority proposed today that the charge be extended for a year.

title: Objects of Affection: A Rug, a Pot, a Cat, a Cross
description: It may be an abstract masterpiece by an impossibly hip artist, a daughter's nursery-school finger painting, a quilt made by Grandma or an overstuffed chair picked up at a fire sale. Whatever the special item is, it connotes warmth and comfort and well-being -- and says ''home.'' In that spirit, these people were asked about that certain something. KIMBERLY STEVENS

title: 9/11 Charities Set Cutoff Date For Applicants
description: Having already doled out hundreds of millions of dollars to residents and businesses in Lower Manhattan, three of the charitable funds that have given the most to victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attack will soon stop taking applications for emergency cash grants for anyone who has lost a job, a business or income because of the attack.

title: Officers' Relatives Hire Lawyer To Look Into Twin Towers Fund
description: A group of relatives of police officers killed at the World Trade Center has retained a lawyer to raise concerns over Rudolph W. Giuliani's handling of the Twin Towers Fund, the charity that so far has raised more than $150 million for the families of rescue workers.

title: SMITH & NEPHEW AGREES TO BUY ORATEC FOR $310 MILLION
description: Smith & Nephew, Europe's largest maker of hospital supplies, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Oratec Interventions, which develops medical devices to treat spine and joint disorders, for $310 million. Smith & Nephew offered $12.50 a share, 40 percent more than Wednesday's closing price for Oratec, based in Menlo Park, Calif. Smith & Nephew, based in London, has been selling consumer brands like Lil-lets tampons and focusing on medical devices like replacement knees and hips, which have higher profit margins. Oratec makes devices that use heat to cut and shrink damaged tissue.

title: A 14-Year-Old With an Idea That Nobody Believes Is His
description: Big Fat Liar

title: People
description: * Romain Hatchuel was named to the new post of director for global new business at Euro RSCG Worldwide, part of Havas Advertising. He had most recently been chief executive at the Cannes International Advertising Festival, London.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Ruling Favors Police Disclosure
description: A state commission has voted unanimously to require the New Haven Police Department to release more than 4,500 pages of police documents from the investigation into a Yale student's murder in 1998. But because of a likely appeal from the city's attorney, who is representing the Police Department, the documents may remain sealed for months, perhaps years, while the case of Suzanne Jovin's murder proceeds through the justice system. The state's Freedom of Information Commission ruled Wednesday that the Police Department had not proved that the documents about Ms. Jovin would damage its investigation or outweighed the public's right to view them. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

title: Offbeat Shelter Magazines That Glow Amid the Glossies
description: AS a combination of architecture, interior design, food and gardening, shelter magazines offer readers a chance to gawk at someone's home without having to bring over a Bundt cake. These are not do-it-yourself publications, but fantasy reads that promise a life in which flowers are always on the table and cashmere throws are draped just so.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: The Memorabilia of Music
description: One blustery afternoon a few months ago, I set out to find a former home of Sergei Rachmaninoff. The great pianist and composer once lived at 33 Riverside Drive, but when I arrived I discovered that his townhouse had been razed to make room for a stately apartment building at the same address. A plaque affixed to the facade tells the passer-by nothing about the old Russian master but proudly notes that George and Ira Gershwin lived there years later. I was intrigued by this coincidence. Like the vertical strata of an archaeological site, New York's musical history seemed to be stacked on top of itself.

title: Remarks by Vice President Dick Chaney Before the Council on Foreign Relations
description: Following is the full text of remarks today by Vice President Dick Chaney before the Council on Foreign Relations in Washington, as distributed by the Federal News Service:

title: I.O.C., Seat of Influence Now Finds Itself Powerless
description: For all its political muscle and worldwide prowess, the International Olympic Committee is finding itself powerless against two mighty forces: it cannot dictate to international sports federations how to conduct their Olympic tournaments, and it cannot change public opinion.

title: From the BBC, a Watery World
description: Across the water is the leviathan called the BBC: a gargantuan producer of all kinds of programming, with five channels and a 24-hour-a-day public. In the water, a blue whale, 100 feet long and with arteries big enough for a man to swim through, cruises azure seas as part of "The Blue Planet," an eight-hour, four-part BBC production about life in the oceans.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a television review on Feb. 4 about "Bertie and Elizabeth," a "Masterpiece Theater" presentation on the life of Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother, misstated the policy of the Church of England on divorce, a factor in the abdication of her brother-in-law King Edward VIII, who became the Duke of Windsor. An obituary of her daughter Princess Margaret on Sunday also included the error. The church does not forbid divorce. It revokes the right to marry in a parish church while a former spouse is living. But even then, depending on circumstances, a priest can allow a church wedding.

title: 'Surrealist Collage'
description: Zabriskie

title: What Is Warm and Fuzzy Forever? With Cloning, Kitty
description: Scientists in Texas have cloned a cat, opening the door to what some experts say will be the first large-scale commercial use of cloning -- to reproduce beloved pets.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: AOL Moviefone, New York, part of AOL Time Warner, to Gotham, New York, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies, to handle the creative and media duties for brand advertising. Billings were estimated at $10 million. The agency for AOL Moviefone, the online listings guide and ticketing service for movies, had been Mad Dogs and Englishmen, New York.

title: Their Roles Are Sometimes Wooden but Always Solid
description: Movie characters are like everybody else. They just want a home of their own -- to enjoy the good life, to show off, to retreat to or to find peace of mind in. Characters buy, build, renovate -- whether they can afford it or not -- and inherit. In the movies, as in life, sometimes it works out and sometimes it doesn't. ANITA GATES

title: Chinese Police Detain Westerners in Falun Gong Protest
description: In the largest protest yet by foreign supporters of the outlawed Falun Gong spiritual movement, more than 40 Westerners were detained this afternoon as they staged raucous demonstrations in Tiananmen Square, Chinese authorities said.

title: Florida Tests Diversity at 2 Law Schools
description: At a time when campuses nationwide are struggling with issues of diversity, Florida has created two new law schools at universities with high minority enrollment in an effort to bring more blacks and Hispanics into legal careers without using affirmative action.

title: With Candor, Powell Charms Global MTV Audience
description: Daniella Satori, who described herself as a ''young Catholic woman,'' had a question from Milan: What about her church's ban on condoms in an age of AIDS? Secretary of State Colin L. Powell pursed his lips as if to stifle the rueful smile of trepidation he knew was coming, then he let loose.

title: Both Sides Pressured Judge, French Skating Official Says
description: The head of the French Olympic team said tonight that the figure skating judge Marie Reine Le Gougne of France had been approached by trainers and other judges during a practice before the pairs competition on Monday but that she had not succumbed to pressures to ensure that the Russians won the gold medal.

title: PALL AGREES TO BUY VIVENDI FILTRATION BUSINESS
description: The Pall Corporation, a maker of filtration and purification systems, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the rival filtration and separations business of Vivendi Environnement of France for $360 million. Pall, based in East Hills, N.Y., also said it would reduce its quarterly dividend to 9 cents from 17 cents. The Vivendi business has $270 million in annual sales and will add 2,037 employees to Pall's work force, an increase of about 22 percent. The purchase will allow Pall to offer more products and services, the company said.

title: Rust Rejoins the Giants' Staff
description: The Giants brought the veteran coach Rod Rust back to their staff yesterday and shifted Dave Brazil to a new position in moves made to surround their new defensive coordinator, Johnnie Lynn, with experienced assistants.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: A Fall At The Opera:
description: A performer fell off the stage at the Metropolitan Opera's opening night performance of Prokofiev's ''War and Peace'' last night, stopping the immense and elaborate production for about four minutes. During the second act, about six minutes from the end of the opera, the performer, an extra playing a French grenadier retreating from Moscow, lost his footing and landed in the orchestra pit from the special dome-shaped stage built for the production. His fall was broken by a net not visible to the audience. The music stopped and the players froze, until one of the stage managers gave a signal for the conductor, Valery Gergiev, to continue. At the end of the performance, the opera's general manager, Joseph Volpe, came on stage with the actor, who was later identified by a spokesman for the opera as Simon Deonarian, and said, ''A retreating French grenadier lost his way in the snowstorm and fell off the stage. He is in good condition now.'' They took a bow, and the audience applauded. William H. Honan (NYT)

title: Tales of a Book Tour
description: To the Editor:

title: Fire Kills Mother and Injures 5 More in a Brooklyn Family
description: A 16-year-old woman was killed and three children, including her infant son, were critically injured yesterday when a votive candle left unattended started a fire in a three-story Brooklyn house, fire officials said. The woman's mother and grandmother were also injured.

title: DNA Testing In Rape Cases Frees Prisoner After 15 Years
description: Exonerated by DNA testing after 15 years in prison, Bruce Godschalk walked out of the Montgomery County Jail at 4:45 p.m. today, with less than $10 in his pocket, wearing a pair of old jeans, a T-shirt and no winter coat.

title: A Food Supply Without Antibiotics
description: To the Editor:

title: IN FILING, BERKSHIRE SAYS IT HOLDS NO CITIGROUP SHARES
description: Berkshire Hathaway reported in a regulatory filing yesterday that it no longer held shares of Citigroup, ending an investment of almost 15 years in Citigroup and its predecessors. The stake of 7.4 million shares was valued at more than $350 million if sold at Citigroup's average price in the fourth quarter. A Citigroup spokeswoman, Christina Pretto, declined to comment. Berkshire Hathaway's chief financial officer, Marc D. Hamburg, did not return repeated calls. Berkshire reported holding 7.4 million shares of Citigroup on Sept. 30.

title: NBC's Ratings Increase
description: The sixth night of the Salt Lake Olympics, during which the American skier Bode Miller won a silver medal in the Alpine combined, generated a 17.5 rating for NBC, up 14 percent from CBS's rating on the comparable day during the 1998 Olympics.

title: Early Concerns Fade Away As Competition Takes Over
description: Richard M. Wirick, a civic booster who owns a shoe store in this city's downtown, feared the worst when he got a call at home this week from a state law enforcement officer assigned to the 2002 Olympic Winter Games.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Slant-Drilling Ban Passes
description: The State Senate passed a bill to ban new drilling from Michigan shores for oil and gas under the Great Lakes. The bill, which passed 28 to 5, would abolish slant drilling from onshore sites. Seven existing wells would not be affected. The House, which passed a similar bill, is expected to review the Senate's changes and send the bill to Gov. John Engler. Mr. Engler, who has opposed the bill, said he would not veto it. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Ratcheting Up Tony Tensions

title: FAST SENATE ACTION SOUGHT
description: The House early today approved a broad overhaul of the way campaigns are financed, and Senator Tom Daschle, the majority leader, swiftly promised to do all he could to speed the bill to the president, putting the nation's political system at the brink of sweeping change.

title: Britain's Revived Labor Movement Is Spoiling for a Fight
description: A resurgent labor movement is confronting the government of Tony Blair with the biggest threat of widespread industrial action in the two decades since Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher broke trade union power over the British economy.

description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Offers Plan for Voluntary Measures to Limit Gas Emissions
description: President Bush announced his long-awaited plans today for slowing the buildup of gases linked to climate change and for cutting power plant pollution.

title: Paul Kooiker -- 'Hunting and Fishing'
description: James Cohan Gallery

title: When a Sink Could Be Art Fit for a King
description: The French are famous for their love of luxury and objets de luxe. Consider Louis XIV, the Sun King, who established royal factories to supply his palaces with fine furniture, tapestries and porcelain. For the Bourbons, one artisan's skill was as important as the next; the aim was to glorify the crown. Napoleon carried on the royal tradition with great enthusiasm; as emperor, he, too, lent state support to fabricators of all the decorative arts.

title: JUDGE OVERTURNS GUIDANT VERDICT, SAYING WITNESS LIED
description: The Guidant Corporation cannot collect a $140 million jury award in a patent case, and may owe millions of dollars in penalties, because its central witness lied in the dispute with a rival cardiac-device maker, St. Jude Medical, a judge said. The judge, David F. Hamilton of United States District Court in Indianapolis, overturned the judgment in the dispute over patents for implantable defibrillators, which are used to restore normal heart rhythm. Guidant's chief expert witness, a Purdue University biomedical engineer, Joe D. Bourland, ''deceived the jury, deceived the court and deceived St. Jude,'' Judge Hamilton said. Judge Hamilton ruled that two Guidant patents were invalid and said the $140 million in damages was ''grossly excessive.'' A Guidant spokesman, Steven Tragash, said the company was reviewing the ruling and its options. St. Jude said it expected Guidant to appeal.

title: TESTSTSTT
description: EUROPE

title: Walter Bolden, 76, a Jazz Drummer
description: Walter Bolden, a jazz drummer who came through the Hartford jazz scene, moved to New York in the early 1950's and played with many of the top names in the field, died on Feb. 7 at a Manhattan hospital. He was 76.

title: Scrutiny Has Judges Feeling Unsettled
description: When Dr. Yang Jiasheng of China withdrew from judging the men's short program after scoring the pairs competition at the Salt Lake City Olympics, his absence was described vaguely as ''due to illness.''

title: Ersatz Climate Policy
description: Alert shoppers know that an extra word in a product's description can make a big difference, and rarely for the better. Apologies to connoisseurs of Velveeta, but most of us don't regard ''cheese food'' as a good substitute for plain ordinary cheese.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: TiVo Sells Stock At Discount
description: TiVo Inc., a maker of digital video recorders, said it had agreed to sell up to $19 million of stock to a mutual fund company at a discount to the stock's market price. According to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, TiVo gave Acqua Wellington North American Equities Fund Ltd. the right to buy TiVo stock at 3 percent to 5.4 percent below the market price during the next 14 months. The amount and timing of each sale of common stock will be at TiVo's discretion, the filing said.

description: RUSSIAN SKATER WINS GOLD -- Aleksei Yagudin captured the men's singles. PAGE D1

description: INTERNET

title: Thumbs Up Or Down?
description: Squirrels confuse us. On the one hand, they are cute. Some of them are even incredibly appealing, like the frisky gray squirrel scampering along an upstate New York tree limb at the left.

title: Rutgers Somehow Survives the Loss of 2 Key Players
description: As soon as he reached in, a 6-foot-6-inch mountain trying in vain to swipe the ball from a guard 30 feet from the basket, Rashod Kent knew -- as did every Rutgers fan whose heart dropped -- that he had blundered.

title: Art in Review
description: Janet Sobel

title: From Busby Berkeley To 60's Berkeley
description: Hussain Kadir is a taxi driver, and on Wednesday night this writer, en route to the Anna Sui show in Bryant Park, was treated to his unsolicited oration on figure skating and clothes. Mr. Kadir, like most of the Western world, was outraged that the Canadian skaters Jamie Sal and David Pelletier were denied a gold medal this week. But he had one issue with the vanquished Olympians. ''Their costumes were too casual,'' he announced. ''When you go to a wedding, you put on a tuxedo.''

title: Bobsledder Can't Avoid Her Ousted Teammate
description: And after everything, Jean Racine had a 102-degree fever this morning.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Qualcomm Names A President
description: Qualcomm Inc., which licenses patents for mobile phones used by 103 million people, named its chief operating officer, Anthony Thornley, president, possibly placing him to succeed the chief executive, Irwin Jacobs. Qualcomm also made William Keitel chief financial officer, succeeding Mr. Thornley, above, in the job he had held since joining the San Diego-based company in 1994. Mr. Thornley added the operating chief's title last July when the president and chief operating officer, Richard Sulpizio, resigned.

title: New Team, Old Look for Saloon; P. J. Clarke's Changes Owners, Who Plan to Retain Atmosphere
description: P. J. Clarke's -- that aged-in-wood, beveled-glass embodiment of a New York that disappeared along with the Third Avenue el outside its double doors -- will close next week as it changes hands for only the second time in 98 years.

title: Undaunted and Planning the Next Great Skyline
description: NEW YORK CITY's familiar skyline -- the old one -- lives on in his incandescent gold cuff links. The Trump-size theme baubles come into their own as Larry A. Silverstein, the chatty septuagenarian who runs Silverstein Properties Inc., shrugs off his suit jacket and sinks, with a discreet groan, into a bottomless blue sofa in his Fifth Avenue office.

description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: In Your Biggest Room, Think Before Planting
description: AMERICANS are determined do-it-yourselfers. But today, the high aspirations of home construction keep most people from wielding anything more dangerous than a credit card. The landscape seems the last outlet for the urge of self-expression. And it is unfortunately true that you can dig a hole in the ground, stick a plant in it and get something to grow an unreasonably high percentage of the time. The plantings you see around you on your new property -- all those dreadful shrubs you are dying to get rid of -- are undoubtedly a result of the former owner's proudest moments. Let that be a lesson to you.

description: He is the nation's most senior Roman Catholic leader, closely connected to the pope, and a man who has gained a reputation as powerful and politically astute.

description: It is safe to say that Dave Marcis is a throwback to another era of stock-car racing, when drivers did not grumble much about rule changes while they rustled up their own sponsors.

description: There were definitely rooms at the inn last month.

description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Inquiry Into Tapes
description: Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn district attorney, is conducting an investigation of video and audio recordings delivered anonymously to his office that assert that a Brooklyn judge has been bribed to fix a case, his spokesman, Jerry Schmetterer, said yesterday. The recordings, which do not name any judge, are said to be of a meeting conducted in Yiddish and are accompanied by a partial English transcript. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: McGreevey Forces Out Head of N.J. Transit
description: The executive director of New Jersey Transit, who had two years remaining on his contract, was forced out of his job today by Gov. James E. McGreevey.

title: LeMay Doan Gives Canada a Long-Awaited Gold Medal
description: Bitter tears, face-first falls, outrage and investigation. For the Canadians, their Olympic moments in Salt Lake City have not exactly been warm and fuzzy pictures of glory.

title: The Last Dynasty, Trying to Fit In Through a Burst of Creativity
description: The Qing dynasty was China's last dynasty. It came at the end of a very long history and had a longish history of its own. This began with a bang in 1644, when the Ming dynasty collapsed and its emperor hanged himself, and ended with an inglorious whimper in 1911, when China became a republic.

title: Mayor Looks At Tolls For Bridges On East River
description: The Bloomberg administration said yesterday that it was exploring placing tolls on city-controlled bridges on the East River and perhaps others. An idea that has been proposed by mayors several times before, it seems to be gaining momentum as a way to help cure the city's ailing finances.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the arts pages on Wednesday about the Berlin Film Festival misidentified the film Tom Tykwer directed before ''Heaven,'' which was shown there. It was ''The Princess and the Warrior''; ''Run Lola Run'' was the previous one.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Circuits yesterday with the State of the Art column, comparing offerings from six cellphone carriers, omitted several features available from AT&T Wireless and from VoiceStream. Both offer plans providing downloadable ringer tones, instant messaging from America Online or Yahoo, news alerts, short text messages and the ability to check e-mail and calendars stored on a PC. AT&T Wireless also plans to offer the ability to play games against other customers, as VoiceStream and other providers already do. A corrected chart is available at nytimes.com/circuits.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Netherlands: Rwandan To Be Turned Over
description: A court in The Hague ruled that it would allow a Rwandan Hutu songwriter, Simon Bikindi, who is wanted on genocide charges, to be handed over to the United Nations war crimes tribunal in Arusha, Tanzania, which wants to try him. Mr. Bikindi, a well-known singer, has been indicted for inciting Hutu to kill Tutsi in his poems and songs. He was also charged with taking part in killings as a member of a Hutu militia during the 1994 Rwandan genocide. He was arrested in July in the Netherlands, where he had been living as a refugee. Since then he has fought his transfer to Tanzania, which is now believed to be imminent. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Monday with an article about a digital image sensor that rivals the abilities of 35-millimeter film mislabeled the order of the three color-sensing elements in the device, made by Foveon. As light hits the sensor, it passes through a blue layer, a green one and then a red one (not red, blue and green). Because of an editing error, the article misstated the definition of V.L.S.I., the abbreviation for a process that makes it possible to imprint tens of thousands of transistors on a single silicon chip. It stands for very large scale integration, not very large system integration.

title: Knicks Haven't Learned How to Hold a Big Lead
description: The Knicks' lack of size and their lack of health are two of the biggest factors in their predicament. But there is another significant reason for the Knicks being on the verge of missing the playoffs, the players are walking around in fright, worried about being traded.

title: Before the Walls Come Tumbling Down
description: DOING your homework will help you avoid the most common renovation pitfalls, and some experts suggest that you start planning what you want and how to finance it a year or more before you hire a contractor.

title: Listen Up, the Contractor Has Something to Say
description: WE have all heard the horror stories. Renovations started but never finished. Kitchens $100,000 over budget. Cabinets with no pulls, light fixtures that go AWOL and big muddy men in every nook and cranny.

title: As U. S. Assumes Screening, Little Will Appear Changed
description: When the federal government takes over responsibility for security at the airports on Sunday, passengers will probably not notice any immediate changes, Transportation Department officials said today.

title: Objects of Affection: A Rug, a Pot, a Cat, a Cross
description: It may be an abstract masterpiece by an impossibly hip artist, a daughter's nursery-school finger painting, a quilt made by Grandma or an overstuffed chair picked up at a fire sale. Whatever the special item is, it connotes warmth and comfort and well-being -- and says ''home.'' In that spirit, these people were asked about that certain something. KIMBERLY STEVENS

title: Report Shows a Rise in Television Clutter
description: Clutter on television  the time devoted to nonprogramming content like commercials and promotions  increased last year in most instances, an annual report showed.

title: At War With an Invisible Army
description: IF termites have started eating your house, chances are it will be years before you notice. Experts at chewing from the inside out, termites can carve their tunnels within a paper's width of the outside of a piece of wood, remaining out of sight. Even when they accidentally break through, they quickly patch the hole with ''termite mud'' -- a mixture of dirt, excrement and chewed wood. A little pile of dirt on the floor or a mud stain on a wall are often the earliest signs that termites have moved in. By the time termites make themselves visible -- a swarm of ''winged reproductives'' seeking to establish new colonies -- they have been munching for several years.

title: Steamed Over Family Matters
description: Eddie and May are back, hammering each other and the walls, slamming doors and yanking in vain at the mental chains holding them together in a physical embrace that seems to drive them to screaming rages. The 29th Street Rep's revival of ''Fool for Love'' is as threatening as the original version directed 19 years ago by the playwright, Sam Shepard, at the Circle Repertory Company's old converted garage next to Sheridan Square.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Deal On Offshore Drilling
description: New drilling for oil and natural gas off the coast of central California would be banned under a bill in Congress intended to settle a dispute between California and the Bush administration, which wants to open 40 offshore tracts. The deal, proposed by Senator Barbara Boxer, a Democrat, would offer companies with leases on the tracts incentives worth up to $2.8 billion to bid on tracts in the Gulf of Mexico already scheduled for drilling. The California tracts, most off Santa Barbara, would become an ecological preserve. Nick Madigan (NYT)

title: Last-Minute Ski Trips
description: If the Olympic Winter Games have you thinking about a late-season ski trip, Resort Reservations Network, an Internet reservations company (www.rezrez.com), has some last-minute offers. Five nights at the Coast Whistler Hotel in Whistler, British Columbia, with four nights' skiing is $98 a night per person, based on double occupancy. It's good through March 10. Call (888) 403-4727 or go to www.whistlerblackcomb.com. Through March 23, a week's lodging and five days' skiing at Dillon Valley East/West in Brekenridge, Colo., starts at $101 a person per night, based on double occupancy. Information: (888) 256-8957 or breckenridge.rezrez.com .

title: Threats, Dead Undertakers and Plenty of Questions in Wisconsin
description: When an undertaker and his young apprentice were found shot dead in a funeral home here on a sunny afternoon last week, this town became intrigued over the inevitable question of who was responsible for the killings, the first in Hudson in 24 years.
