description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Not Quite a Whistle-Blower
description: Sherron Watkins took a bow in Washington yesterday. The Enron executive who famously warned Kenneth Lay last August that accounting misdeeds threatened to destroy the company was greeted as a hero by the same House members who excoriated Jeffrey Skilling and Andrew Fastow last week. Billy Tauzin, the chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee, even wished her a happy Valentine's Day. The welcome was largely deserved, though Ms. Watkins's role was not quite as heroic as some have described.

title: A Charismatic Congressman and the Trail He Blazed
description: There is no such thing as an objective biography, and that is certainly demonstrated by ''Keep the Faith, Baby,'' a film about Adam Clayton Powell Jr. that has its premiere Sunday on Showtime. Yet being a bit worshipful, as this treatment of the Harlem congressman is, doesn't preclude its being interesting or even valuable, and ''Keep the Faith, Baby'' is often both.

title: A Score Overwhelms Many Years of Effort
description: In figure skating, in which judging controversies become larger than life, Marie Reine Le Gougne seemed to have slipped through unscathed until this week. But her controversial scoring Monday night, which gave the Russian pair rather than the Canadian pair the Olympic gold medal, has thrust the Frenchwoman and her sport into an awkward position.

title: Cablevision Reports 4th-Quarter Loss
description: The Cablevision Systems Corporation, the biggest cable television operator in metropolitan New York and the owner of Madison Square Garden, had a fourth-quarter loss on higher costs and falling ticket sales, the company said today.

title: What Goes Around Can Come Around
description: David Wells ambled into the Legends Field clubhouse today, his untucked shirt hanging loosely on his body. He wore shorts, and his legs looked lean. General Manager Brian Cashman noticed that Wells was carrying a jug of nutritional powder. ''That's my breakfast,'' Wells said. This is the new Boomer, Cashman thought.

title: Album of the Week
description: OMAR SOSA: ''Sentir'' (Ot). The Cuban pianist Omar Sosa moved to the San Francisco Bay Area in 1995 and in short order made seven albums. They're all over the map: solo piano, duets with percussion, large-band orchestrations and now this, a kaleidoscopic record variously using Afro-Cuban percussion, Yoruban incantation vocals, Moroccan drums and string instruments, a rapper, even an oud and a didgeridoo.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Heading for Womanhood
description: Britney Spears, above, as Lucy is entertained by Ben (Anson Mount) in her debut film, ''Crossroads.''

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: UBS Profit Down 36% on Merger Costs
description: Switzerland's biggest bank, UBS, said its net profit fell 36 percent in 2001, with private equity investment losses and the merger costs from its PaineWebber acquisition accounting for most of the decline.

title: Violence Is a Symptom of Youth Centers' Struggles
description: The crime was horrendous a 32-year-old counselor beaten with a phone, dragged down two flights of stairs and set on fire by a gang of girls at the Pleasantville Cottage School in Westchester County.

title: Celebrating the Other Matisse: Dealer, Patron and Son
description: The painter Henri Matisse turned out some of the masterpieces of the 20th century, not the least of them his son Pierre. More interested in selling art than in making it, Pierre (1900- 1989) set out to be a painter himself, but wound up as one of the century's most influential dealers in modern European works. Migrating to New York as a young man, he became a persuasive agent in guiding American museums and collectors toward acceptance and appreciation of this art.

title: Much Ado About Gold, But Some Wonder Why
description: In recent months, Russians have accepted the inevitability of an expanded NATO, the collapse of a nuclear arms treaty and the stationing of American forces on their southern border with what some here call Prozac-like equanimity.

title: Officials Banding Together Over Judge
description: The Maginot line was drawn today at State and West Temple Streets downtown. There stood the respectable gray building housing the French Club. There flew the French and American flags, side by side, hanging from poles above the entrance.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: L'Actuel, the Midtown brasserie, has traded in its name, and its identity, for an even more mysterious name, and a warmer, slightly more formal persona. The tables have white tablecloths now. The shiny surfaces have been muted with thick curtains, and large pyramid-shaped lights now cast a soft glow over the dining room. The hamburger, choucroute and snazzy Frenchified tapas dishes have been shown the door. The name, which meant ''up to the minute,'' never rolled easily on American tongues, so now it's Olica, a splicing of Olivia and Camille, the owners' daughters.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Five Buddies From Britain

title: For Executives Of Enron Unit, The Skill Was in Leaving
description: Thomas E. White served 23 years in the Army, rising to the rank of brigadier general. But it was his second career -- a decade spent as a top executive of the Enron Corporation -- that won him inclusion in the circle of businessmen whom President Bush appointed last year to run the armed services.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bank Raises Bad Debt Provision
description: Barclays Bank said it increased its provisions for bad debts, reflecting concern among banks about loans to troubled companies, including the Enron Corporation in the United States and the phone equipment maker Marconi in Britain. Barclays said bad-debt provisions for 2001 rose 35 percent, to $1.64 billion, slightly higher than analysts had expected. Barclays also increased its estimate of the risk of bad debts in 2002 by 13 percent, pushing its shares down by almost 2 percent despite a 3 percent rise in pretax 2001 profit, to $5.17 billion. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: As It Beat Profit Forecast, I.B.M. Said Little About Sale of a Unit
description: When I.B.M. announced in mid-January that it had beat Wall Street's profit forecasts in the fourth quarter, it did not disclose that the sale of a business had generated $300 million that the company used to lower its operating costs.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: They're Always Happy Campers

title: A Britney Spears Vehicle That Bypasses the Bumps
description: It should come as no surprise that Britney Spears emerges unscathed (though not artistically ennobled) from her debut movie, ''Crossroads.''

title: City Agrees to Private Control Of Giuliani's Mayoral Papers
description: The Bloomberg administration has signed an agreement that permits a private nonprofit group to retain control of Rudolph W. Giuliani's mayoral papers, brushing aside the concerns of some historians, archival groups and civil libertarians who had urged the city to physically return the documents to the Municipal Archives.

title: 'Lone Voice': Excerpts From Testimony of Executive Who Challenged Enron
description: Following are excerpts from the testimony of Sherron S. Watkins, an Enron vice president, before a hearing of a House Energy and Commerce subcommittee yesterday, as recorded by the Federal News Service. Ms. Watkins was questioned by Representatives James C. Greenwood, Republican of Pennsylvania; John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan; Cliff Stearns, Republican of Florida; and Greg Ganske, Republican of Iowa. A full transcript is available online: nytimes.com/business.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Ex-Nazi To Face Charges
description: Prosecutors in Hamburg said they were preparing to charge a former SS officer, Friedrich Engel, 93, in connection with the killing of at least 246 Italians in 1944 and 1945. An Italian court convicted him of the killings in absentia in 1999 and sentenced him to life in prison. The case against Mr. Engel, who denies having killed anyone or having ordered any killings, came to national attention last year when German television reported that he was living in Hamburg. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Restarting Afghan Cycle Of Agriculture
description: While American troops search Afghanistan for terrorists, relief agencies feed its refugees and a nascent government seeks to restore order, something experts call essential for reviving the shattered country is quietly taking place in a few fields.

title: Yemen Fears Being Singed by a Home-Grown Firebrand
description: Not many people see Abdel Meguid al-Zindani these days. Since the rout of the Taliban in Afghanistan, when many Yemenis worried that they might be the next target for Western forces, the fiery Muslim cleric, a prominent and long-tolerated political force in Yemen, has stayed uncharacteristically out of the limelight.

title: Sports of The Times; These Games Deserve Better From N.H.L.
description: IN other blemished sports at the Winter Games, players from the Big Six nations arrived here yesterday like an airdrop of human hockey packets, changing from professionals to Olympians like lines on the fly.

title: 'Pictures'
description: Greene Naftali

title: Man Misses Wife
description: Michael Weiss and I have something in common. He looked so forlorn last night after finishing seventh in the figure skating. He was happy with his jumps but sad because his wife had been forced to watch from the stands.

title: 'The Artist's Hand' -- Willem de Kooning Drawings, 1937 to 1954
description: Mitchell-Innes & Nash

title: DEFIANT, MILOSEVIC BEGINS HIS DEFENSE BY ASSAILING NATO
description: A driven and indignant Slobodan Milosevic today laid blame for a decade of carnage in the Balkans on everyone but himself, waving away charges that he was responsible for war crimes in four words: ''It is all lies.''

title: GQ steps out of its pages and opens a lounge, trying to put advertisers and consumers together.
description: THERE is a new lounge for the chic and trendy in Hollywood. Why is this news for an advertising column rather than a gossip column? A big publisher is creating the lounge to promote a magazine to consumers, celebrities and advertisers.

title: R Is for Reading (D Is for Dispute)
description: To the Editor:

title: In Albany, a Redistricting Plan to Help the Majority Party
description: The Assembly Democrats and Senate Republicans unveiled a plan for new district lines today calculated to preserve their majorities in both houses and play mischief with the districts of members of minority parties.

title: Glaring at Two-Thirds of an 'Axis'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Big City; Rethinking The Rites Of Recycling
description: ENVIRONMENTALISTS may not like Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's proposal to suspend the recycling of cans and bottles. But it could be their best chance to save their reputations and do some good for the environment.

title: Memo to Assemble-It-Yourselfers: Rome Was Not Built in a Day
description: HAVE you ever found yourself wondering, gripping an Allen wrench and murder in your heart, just who the designers of ready-to-assemble furniture had in mind when they wrote the instructions for putting such furniture together?

title: Klug Brings Home Bronze
description: PARK CITY, Utah, Feb. 15 - A buckle on his rear boot snapped off. That's what it came down to for Chris Klug - liver transplant survivor, World Cup contender - during his giant slalom race today for a bronze medal against Nicolas Huet of France. He could feel the loosening of the red plastic boot, the slight loss of control.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a television review on Feb. 4 about ''Bertie and Elizabeth,'' a ''Masterpiece Theater'' presentation on the life of Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother, misstated the policy of the Church of England on divorce, a factor in the abdication of her brother-in-law King Edward VIII, who became the Duke of Windsor. An obituary of her daughter Princess Margaret on Sunday also included the error. The church does not forbid divorce. It revokes the right to marry in a parish church while a former spouse is living. But even then, depending on circumstances, a priest can allow a church wedding.

title: Booklet Makes Name as Derby Contender
description: Monarchos won the Kentucky Derby for John Ward last year. Now Ward is optimistic about making it two victories in a row with Booklet, a bay colt who, unlike Monarchos, likes to run near or in the lead.

title: Sports of The Times; The Russians Are Still The Royalty of Skating
description: While waiting for resolution in the figure-skating mess, the best thing to do is focus on the superb athletes who, oddly enough, are still performing in the Winter Games.

title: A Nimble Agent Wants to Know, What Recession?
description: THE middle-aged teacher is all business as she walks into the sales office of the Clifton, an upscale condominium complex being built near Emory University, in the leafy northeast section of the city.

title: My Olympics, Your Olympics
description: It seems silly now, but four years ago I got up in the middle of the night to catch the last minutes of the Olympic gold medal men's hockey game on television from Nagano, Japan. I needed to see if a local hero, the Buffalo Sabres goalie Dominic Hasek, could lead his Czech Republic team to the championship. He did, and I went happily back to sleep.

title: G.M. Plans To Lay Off 3,000 People
description: General Motors said today that it planned to lay off nearly 3,000 workers at two plants, including 1,100 at a truck plant in Linden, N.J.

title: Residential Real Estate; Return of a Lure: A Month's Free Rent
description: With the sagging economy and the aftereffects of Sept. 11, developers of apartment buildings are incorporating a factor into their rents that all but disappeared from the real estate vocabulary in the mid-1990's: the concession.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of yesterday, 3,062 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11, not including 19 hijackers.

title: Greenwich Sets Charges For Outsiders To Use Beach
description: Forced by a State Supreme Court decision to end Greenwich's residents-only beach policy, the Board of Selectmen approved a new fee structure today that will cost a nonresident as much as $408 for a seasonal beach pass. Daily passes will not be available.

title: 2 Dead in Shootings at Manhattan Beauty Salon
description: A man fatally shot his 17-year-old former girlfriend in a crowded beauty salon on the Upper East Side last night, and then killed himself, the police said. The shootings took place around 6:30 p.m. at La Dolce Vita salon, at 117 East 60th Street.

title: N.A.S.D. Prepares a Glossary for Investors
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers Inc. has prepared a guide and glossary to help investors understand stock recommendations of equity analysts.

title: Argentines Are Missed At Resorts
description: At the height of the Southern Hemisphere summer, the Carnival holidays just before Lent are peak periods for the coastal resorts of Uruguay and southern Brazil. Any other year at this time, the Moby Dick, a bar across from the yacht club in this seaside town, would be packed with middle-class Argentines spending their American dollars.

title: Can Investors Believe Cash Flow Numbers?
description: ''YOU can't fake cash flow.''

title: World Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Ex-Communists Convicted
description: Five Communist-era security officials were convicted for their part in a campaign to force dissidents and intellectuals to flee Czechoslovakia. Two former department heads from the Interior Ministry and the former chief of the Prague secret police were given three-year suspended sentences, with the judge citing their age as the reason for the suspension. Two lower-ranking secret police officers were given three-year jail terms for beating dissidents under the same plan. The trial of former Interior Minister Jaromir Obzina, who was among the organizers of the plan, has been delayed while a court considers his claim that since he was a member of the Communist legislature he has parliamentary immunity. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: There's No Argument Over Yagudin's Gold
description: The showdown with his Russian peer never materialized. The challenge from the American fell short, too. By the time Aleksei Yagudin had taken the ice tonight, neither his countryman, Yevgeny Plushenko, nor the crowd favorite, Timothy Goebel, could approach his splendor and near perfection.

title: Glaring at Two-Thirds of an 'Axis'
description: To the Editor:

title: In Seoul, a Micron-Hynix Deal in the Making
description: Micron Technology and Hynix Semiconductor have agreed on a basic price for seven Hynix chip plants and are near to reaching an understanding that would make Micron the world's largest manufacturer of memory chips, Hynix officials said today.

title: R Is for Reading (D Is for Dispute)
description: To the Editor:

title: Andersen Labors to Recover Enron-Related Documents
description: It may be months before Arthur Andersen can collect and sort all the documents that its employees generated in the course of working for the Enron Corporation, a court filing by the accounting firm suggests.

Slide Show: Men's Figure Skating
Executive Decisions

Paid Notice: Deaths  SHELOV, FAITH NEE RISSER
description: SHELOV-Faith nee Risser. Of Voorhees, NJ, formerly of New York, NY, on February 15th, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Sidney. Devoted mother of Steven Shelov, Karin S. Beth and Tamar Shelov. Dear sister of Pete Risser. Loving grandmother of 8, great-grandmother of 1. Funeral services are private. McGuinness Funeral Home of Woodbury. Donations may be made to Alumni Association, Mt. Sinai Hospital School of Nursing, 1425 Madison Ave., MC Level, NY, NY 10029. Expressions of sympathy may be e-mailed to: tributes@McGfuneral.com

title: 'War and Peace' Opens; Mishap Raises Concerns
description: The Metropolitan Opera's ambitious and long-awaited premier production of Prokofiev's epic ''War and Peace,'' based on the Tolstoy novel, arrived on Thursday night, conducted by Valery Gergiev, who had spearheaded the project from the start. The stirring performance that Mr. Gergiev elicited from the Met orchestra, chorus and huge cast (68 roles sung by 52 singers) was an artistic milestone for the company.

title: Oh, This Shark Has Missing Teeth, Dear
description: IN the back of a dim two-table pool hall behind the bus station, a funny-looking man with no front teeth is practicing trick shots with his cronies. The yellow one-ball flies through the air and bounces along the concrete floor: a miss. ''Wow!'' the man cries, and he throws back his head and laughs.

title: Global Economy Taking Toll on Small Towns
description: All along the nation's back roads, hundreds of towns like this one are teetering in the recession, and some worry that they may never recover. Uranium mining has stopped in Falls City, Tex. In Loving County, Tex., oil exploration has stalled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLZMAN, CARYLL H.
description: HOLZMAN-Caryll H. Beloved wife of the late Lewis, dearest sister of the late Marjorie Steinhardt, devoted mother of Ralph, Sharon and Sallie, cherished grandmother of Benjamin and Nathaniel.

title: Nature Calls, But New York Is Out of Order
description: But despite the state the world is in,

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLZMAN, CARYLL
description: HOLZMAN-Caryll. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York expresses to the family of our devoted member Caryll Holzman our deepest hope and prayer that beautiful memories will linger as a legacy to her life. May all who loved her be comforted. Robert A. Bernhard, President Herbert C. Bernard, Secretary

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: A Redistricting Battle
description: Federal Justice Department officials say they are hesitant to approve a new Congressional redistricting plan drawn up by Democrats and adopted by a state court judge in December, because the plan may be appealed in state courts. Their concerns, expressed in a letter to state officials, may increase the chances of races this year being run under a map created by a federal three-judge panel that was considered a victory for Republicans.

title: Ratings Climbing for NBC
description: With a 17.6 Nielsen rating for Thursday night's Salt Lake Winter Olympics broadcast, NBC's seven-day rating is now a 19.2, up 14 percent from CBS's during the Winter Games from Nagano in 1998.

title: Corrections
description: Anews analysis article on Thursday about campaign finance legislation in the House of Representatives misstated the amount of hard money  limited and closely regulated donations  raised last year by Republican national party organizations. It was $132.3 million, not $122.3 million.

title: The Two-Enron System
description: If you're having trouble keeping up with the Olympian scandals in Washington, just think of the Republicans and the Democrats as the French and the Russians and all the rest of us as Canadians. But at least those Canadians got their gold back.

title: Banking offshore : Even for a middle roller, it can make sense
description: Having an offshore bank account may sound exotic and racy and not quite on the upand-up, but it can be a useful  and legitimate  financial planning tool for expatriates, providing tax savings and convenience.

title: Letters Show Bush and Lay Shared Much
description: In more than two dozen letters written from Kenneth L. Lay to then-Gov. George W. Bush, the former Enron chairman lobbied repeatedly for his company's pet issue, electric deregulation, sought the governor's presence at Enron-related functions and sent magazine articles and personal notes.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: McDonald's Profit Falls
description: McDonald's of Japan said second-half profit fell 67 percent as customers shunned beef products because of Japan's first cases of mad cow disease. Net income was 2.59 billion yen ($19.5 million), or 17.92 yen a share, down from 7.87 billion yen, or 65.38 yen a share, a year earlier. Sales fell 5 percent to 177.8 billion yen, even though the company added 142 stores in the period.

title: Rice Dominates Bishop Loughlin
description: In his final high school regular-season game, Christian Brown scored a career-high 26 points last night, leading four Rice players in double figures, as the Raiders capped a 23-2 season with an 88-60 victory over Bishop Loughlin of Brooklyn at the Gauchos Gym in the Bronx.

title: Rosemary Woodruff, 66, Wife And Fellow Fugitive of Leary
description: Rosemary Woodruff, who was married to the psychedelic guru Timothy Leary, designed their flamboyant wardrobe and spent much of her life living underground after helping him escape from prison, died on Feb. 7 at her home in Aptos, Calif., near San Jose. She was 66.

title: Head of Camp In Arizona Is Arrested In Boy's Death
description: Seven months after a 14-year-old boy died from exposure at an unregulated boot camp for troubled youth near Phoenix, the head of the camp, Charles F. Long II, was arrested yesterday and charged with second-degree murder.

title: New Hampshire Diocese Names 14 Priests Accused of Abuse
description: In a reflection of the rising concern over pedophile priests in the Roman Catholic Church, the bishop of the diocese of Manchester, N.H., today announced the names of 14 priests who had been accused of sexually abusing children in the past and turned those names over to prosecutors.

title: Fertility Society Opposes Choosing Embryos Just for Sex Selection
description: The ethics committee of the nation's fertility society has revised a controversial opinion on sex selection that some of its members offered in September. In its new, more restrictive, opinion, the committee says that couples should be discouraged from creating embryos, selecting some and discarding others, solely because they have a child of one sex and want one of another.

title: A Watershed in American Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Vatican to Hold Off Opening Pope Pius XII Wartime Archives
description: The Vatican announced today that it would partly open its prewar archives next year, but would not make available documents on Pius XII's controversial World War II pontificate for at least three more years.

title: Morgan Stanley Made Big Cut In 2001 Pay Of Its Chief
description: In the midst of a prolonged drought in Wall Street's most lucrative businesses, the financial pain is shooting all the way to the boardroom.

title: Olympic Recount
description: Credit Jacques Rogge, the new president of the International Olympic Committee, with intervening to prevent the pairs figure skating imbroglio from disfiguring the Winter Games in Salt Lake City. He leaned hard on the International Skating Union to remedy the judging distortions that marred the pairs competition, and in so doing protected the integrity of the Games. His openness and decisiveness are a welcome break from past Olympic traditions.

title: Signs of Hope in the Bronx Neighborhood Where Diallo Died
description: It has been three years since Amadou Diallo was killed by the police in an extraordinary standoff in an ordinary doorway in the Soundview section of the Bronx.

title: Asylum Seekers Set Fires at Detention Center in Britain
description: Fires and riots tore through Britain's showcase holding center for asylum seekers overnight in what the police said appeared to be an attempted mass escape by some of its 380 inmates. The violence highlighted a growing collision between governments and migrants from the developing world desperate for sanctuary in wealthy Western Europe.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Thursday about a prayer service at Fairfield University attended by people who had been held hostage by a former student carried an erroneous credit. The photographer was Janet Durrans, for The New York Times.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLIOT, WANDA
description: ELLIOT-Wanda. On February 14, 2002. Wife of the late Mike Elliot. Loving mother of Mootsy, Robert, Peter and Max. Cherished grandmother of David, Hattie and Michael. Dear sister of Mary Sohl. Devoted companion of Oliver Lundquist. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St., Saturday, February 16th, 4-8 PM. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to Columbia University Pancreatic Cancer Research Fund, attention Dr. John Chabot, 161 Fort Washington Avenue, New York, New York 10032.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEMAN, MARYANN
description: FREEMAN-Maryann. Died at home in the early morning on Valentine's Day after a long and heroic battle with cancer. Mary, we will love and miss you always. Barbara, Sandy and Robert

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of yesterday, 3,062 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11, not including 19 hijackers.

title: Linden G.M. Workers Take Wait-and-See Approach as They Face Layoffs
description: The last time there were layoffs at the General Motors Corporation plant here, Guy Messina, shop chairman of the union local, had to go onto the plant floor to answer questions about them. He was roundly booed by the members.

title: Russians Are Angered By the I.O.C. Decision
description: If the Canadians were jubilant, the Russians were angry.

title: Bulls Are What Nets Need To Break a Losing Streak
description: The Nets beat the Chicago Bulls, or what's left of them, tonight to halt a three-game losing streak, their longest of the season. All five of the Bulls' regular starters were out with injuries.

title: Milosevic Vows a Parade of Witnesses, Including Clinton
description: Sweeping away his last sliver of indifference to his war crimes trial, Slobodan Milosevic announced today that he would call present and past world leaders, including former President Bill Clinton, to the stand.

title: With Aryans Gone, Town Seeks New Life
description: As the proprietor of Everett's on the Lake, a restaurant that looks out on the clear waters of Hayden Lake and the snowy pine forests beyond, Everett Fees knows he has a beautiful spot for dining and an appealing menu, which he describes as Northwestern eclectic. But he is still bothered by the response he got when he described it all one day to a woman from Spokane, Wash.

title: INSIDE
description: Cheney Defends Iraq Stance

title: In Cheney's Words: 'Our Role Is Clear'
description: Following are excerpts from Vice President Dick Cheney's speech yesterday to the Council on Foreign Relations, as transcribed by Federal News Service Inc. The full text is available on the Web at nytimes.com/world.

title: HERCULES'S PROFITS WIPED OUT BY COURT DECISION
description: The chemical company Hercules Inc. said an appellate court decision upholding a judgment against it wiped out its $6 million fourth-quarter net income. Hercules said it broke even for the quarter after a $9 million pretax expense resulting from the decision. The company said its 2001 loss was $58 million, or 54 cents a share, wider than the $52 million loss, or 48 cents, it reported Feb. 5. The Appellate Division of the New York Supreme Court upheld a $10.9 million judgment against Hercules in a case related to the 1996 acquisition of Hercules's former composite-products business by the Hexcel Corporation. The case involved ''alleged 'post closing' adjustments'' to the price Hexcel paid for the unit, Hercules said in a statement. Hercules may appeal, the company said.

title: Lincoln Online: New Treasures
description: Honest Abe? Not according to Charles Hanks, Abraham Lincoln's cousin, who said Lincoln was famous for ''rowdying,'' the 19th-century version of wilding. Charles wanted to set the record straight after reading a letter supporting Lincoln's presidential bid by Charles's own brother, John Hanks.

title: Secrets Confided to the Clergy Are Getting Harder to Keep
description: It was while in jail awaiting trial on double murder charges that O. J. Simpson had his famous heart-to-heart chat with the pro-football-player-turned-minister Roosevelt Grier. For weeks afterward, the press was rife with rumors that Mr. Simpson had confessed to the crimes. Questioned on the stand about what he'd heard that day, however, Mr. Grier declined to say, testifying that the conversation ''was part of a religious discussion.''

title: Latest Issue for Blair to 'Spin' Is That He Spins
description: After a teacup storm over spin doctors that turned into a political typhoon, two media advisers to Britain's Labor government quit tonight in a dispute over the practice of hiding bad news behind yet worse tidings of others.

title: 3 Olivier Awards for 'My Fair Lady'
description: Trevor Nunn's revival of ''My Fair Lady'' was a three-time winner yesterday when the 26th annual Laurence Olivier Awards for distinguished achievement in London theater were announced in a ceremony at the Victoria Palace Theater in London.

title: National Briefing | Plains: Nebraska: A Hat In The Ring
description: An Omaha businessman, Stormy Dean, announced he would seek the Democratic nomination for governor. He is expected to win the nomination and could face Gov. Mike Johanns, a Republican who is running for a second term. Mr. Dean, 44, is the chief financial officer for InfoUSA, a company that sells information products, and the president of the Ralston Board of Education. He said he was asked to enter the race by the former Democratic governor Ben Nelson. Mr. Dean faces Luis Calvillo, a store clerk, in the primary. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: Heisenberg and Bohr
description: To the Editor:

title: LAY SOLD SHARES FOR $100 MILLION
description: Kenneth L. Lay sold $100 million in Enron stock last year, the company disclosed yesterday, with a large part of that coming from selling shares back to the company after he was warned by Sherron S. Watkins that the company might collapse ''in a wave of accounting scandals.''

title: Police Dept. In Wallkill Has Improved, Monitor Says
description: In his first report on the troubled Police Department in Wallkill, N.Y., a federal monitor has said that no new complaints have been made against the force, which was accused last year of harassing women and intimidating its critics.

title: National Briefing | Plains: South Dakota: Going Smokeless
description: Smoking in most restaurants and workplaces would be banned under a bill passed by the House. The bill, approved 40 to 28, already passed in the Senate. A ban on smoking exists in many public places, including health care facilities, schools, child care centers, museums and theaters. The measure would expand the ban to most enclosed public places, workplaces and private homes used for day care. It would not ban smoking in casinos, bars or restaurants that serve alcohol. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: Reviews/Fashion; From Beene and Karan, Designs That Live Past the Catwalk
description: If you had stumbled on the throngs of 19-year-olds waiting outside Cooper Union for the As Four show on Thursday night, you might have wondered whether Clairol really has a future in shampoo. As Four is a design collective of two men and two women -- Adi, Kai, Gabi and Ange -- none of whom use last names. Their shows attract Japanese teenagers in woven leather scarves that look like Slinkys and hang to the feet. At 10, an hour after the show was set to begin, one fantasized about what a trenchant comment As Four could make by holding an audience captive for, say, an hour, getting everyone worked up and then announcing that nothing at all would be shown because fashion is consumed so quickly, why bother?

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Spare Times column of Weekend yesterday for the Pathmark Gospel Choir Competition misstated the day. The event is today from 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. at Grand Central Terminal and at 8 p.m. in Aaron Davis Hall at City College in Harlem. It was not held yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 29 about a news conference at which President Bush spoke in Crawford, Tex., added a word erroneously to his reply on his watching of a broadcast videotape of Osama bin Laden. Mr. Bush said, ''I didn't watch it all''; he did not say ''at all.'' The error was pointed out in a letter dated Dec. 29 from a reader who noticed a discrepancy with the published excerpts; the letter was misrouted at The Times.

title: HALLIBURTON SHARES RISE AFTER ASBESTOS RULING
description: Shares of the Halliburton Company rose 11 percent after a judge halted more than 200,000 asbestos claims against a construction subsidiary, Dresser Industries. The shares rose $1.61, to $16.27. Halliburton is down 60 percent from a year ago after three asbestos verdicts totaling $152 million caused concern that such liabilities would lead to bankruptcy, as they had for other companies. Judge Judith Fitzgerald of United States Bankruptcy Court issued a restraining order after a Chapter 11 filing Thursday by the Harbison-Walker Refractories Company, formerly owned by Dresser and now a unit of RHI. The judge's order delays asbestos claims for at least two weeks and signals that Halliburton's liabilities may be limited, analysts said.

title: Rulings Tarnished Games For Some
description: The International Olympic Committee did something rare yesterday: it declared the outcome of a competition wrong and righted it.

title: Religion Journal; Colleges Are Scrambling For Muslim Chaplains
description: Shamshad Sheikh was taken aback when she was asked to become the Muslim spiritual adviser to students at Mount Holyoke College. She did not feel qualified.

title: Some Affected by 9/11 Are Hard to Reach
description: A day after three major charities announced a last-minute extension for victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attack to apply for emergency cash grants, charitable organizations and social service agencies scrambled yesterday to get the word out to a group that has probably received the least, and most contradictory, information to date: non-English-speaking immigrants.

title: A Refusal To Take Nuclear Waste
description: Yesterday, Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham finally forwarded to the White House his plan for high-level nuclear waste disposal: Put it all in Yucca Mountain, a volcanic ridge 100 miles northwest of Las Vegas. President Bush took just a few hours to send the plan on to Congress with his blessing. But like Sisyphus pushing his rock up the mountain only to have it crash back down, time and again, the Department of Energy can send its Yucca Mountain plan wherever it likes -- and the plan will crash again. Why am I so sure? The Energy Department tends not to complete its more grandiose projects, even when they were based on sound science and common sense. This project is based on neither.

title: Trying to Divide New York Arts Aid More Evenly
description: In her first public remarks since being named the city's commissioner of cultural affairs, Kate D. Levin said yesterday that she hoped to restructure her agency's budget to allow more flexibility in its giving, including the ability to shift more money to some of the city's less-well-known cultural organizations.

title: Holiday on Monday: Washington's Birthday
description: The holiday, actually Feb. 22, is legally observed Monday.

description: AMERICAS

title: Judge Rejects Long Prison Term For Arab Caught in Terror Sweep
description: In one of the more puzzling cases to emerge from the Sept. 11 investigation, a federal judge in Brooklyn imposed a six-month jail sentence yesterday on an Egyptian man who entered the country with a fake pilot's uniform in his luggage.

description: In percent

title: Fusing Cheerfulness With Cynicism and Quirks
description: A fan yelled ''We missed you!'' to the Breeders at the Bowery Ballroom last Saturday night. The Breeders, led by the twin sisters Kim and Kelley Deal, had dissolved after releasing their million-selling 1993 album, ''Last Splash,'' and both sisters formed bands of their own.

title: French Need No Help To Take an Early Lead
description: Under normal circumstances, the performance of the ice dancers Marina Anissina and Gwendal Peizerat of France this evening would have raised few eyebrows. The skaters, among the favorites to win the gold medal, were in sync, technically sound and worthy of their first-place finish after the two compulsory dances.

title: U.S. Troops Reinforcing Safety of Base In Kandahar
description: American troops in Afghanistan are working to strengthen the perimeter of their base at Kandahar airport after two security breaches by hostile forces this week, military officials said today.

title: Elisabeth Mann Borgese, 83, Writer and Defender of the Oceans
description: Elisabeth Mann Borgese, a multifaceted writer, defender of marine resources and founder of the International Oceans Institute based in Malta, died on Feb. 8 while on vacation in St. Moritz, Switzerland. She was 83 and lived in Halifax, Nova Scotia.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Executive Payback
description: ABB Ltd., Europe's largest electric engineering company, said two former chief executives might return part of their severance pay, as investors demand more accountability and transparency after the collapse of the Enron Corporation and the Swissair Group last year. The executives, Percy Barnevik, above, and Goran Lindahl both signaled a willingness to settle, an ABB spokesman said. The company has demanded that they pay back an unspecified part of the $137 million they received.

title: Beware the Asian Longhorned Beetle
description: If ever the urge to step on a bug were justifiable, the Asian longhorned beetle is the bug that justifies it. We are so used to the thought of scourges that come in microbial sizes, like foot-and-mouth disease, that it is almost shocking to grasp the size of this particular scourge. An adult Asian longhorned beetle can be up to an inch and a half long, and is black-bodied with white spots and long mottled black antennae. The beetles entered New York in 1996 in solid wood packing material from China, where they are uncontrolled, and they immediately began devastating trees in Greenpoint. Since then they have turned up in Bayside and Amityville, and in sections of Chicago. Now the beetles have been found in two maples in Central Park.

title: For Margaret, Cremation, As She Wished
description: Princess Margaret, a rebellious royal who broke with tradition to the last by insisting on cremation rather than burial, was mourned today at a funeral service at Windsor Castle outside London.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: A Clergy Ill Prepared to Deal With Scandal
description: On Ash Wednesday, Catholics in Boston went to Mass to receive our cross of ashes. On our foreheads, and on the forehead of Cardinal Bernard Law, the archbishop of Boston, was this symbol of sin and suffering, of death and hope. Yet this spiritual unity belies the huge gap between the cardinal and the region's Catholics.

title: Elderly Say Budget Plan Will Cut a Needed Meal
description: Politicians don't usually take on the elderly, who tend to be more politically active -- and vocal -- than other constituents.

title: Texans Ready to Pick Glenn
description: Jets cornerback Aaron Glenn will be at the Houston Texans' headquarters for the expansion draft on Monday, the most obvious indication that the Texans will pluck Glenn from the pool. Glenn will almost certainly be joined on the Houston roster by two other Jets on the expansion list, cornerback Marcus Coleman and offensive tackle Ryan Young.

title: Mayoral Race Grown Bitter Ends Today In Dallas
description: In a city where elections for mayor have usually been low key and as predictable as the summer heat, the campaign for the mayoral runoff on Saturday, between an outspoken former journalist and a mild-mannered insurance executive, has instead been a bitter monthlong fracas marked by accusations of endorsement-buying and mail-in-ballot irregularities.

title: SPRINT PCS TO CUT 3,000 JOBS, OR 9% OF ITS WORK FORCE
description: The Sprint PCS Group said yesterday that it would cut 3,000 jobs, or 9 percent of its staff, and shut five customer service centers to cut its annual costs by $60 million. The announcement deepened investor concern that the Sprint Corporation, the No. 3 long-distance phone company and the parent of Sprint PCS, a mobile-phone unit, would struggle to reduce debt. Sprint PCS will have a first-quarter expense of $25 million for the job cuts, which affect offices in Atlanta; Tallahassee and Jacksonville, Fla.; Lawrence, Kan.; and Irvine, Calif. On Feb. 4, Sprint PCS reported a fourth-quarter loss of $328 million. The Sprint Corporation has already announced plans to cut 7,500 positions as it loses long-distance customers to new competitors and prices fall.

title: Enron to Provide 17 Years of Tax Records to Senate Panel
description: Lawmakers said today that the Enron Corporation had agreed to waive tax-privacy protections and provide tax records for the last 17 years to the Senate Finance Committee, which has begun an investigation into whether the company improperly avoided paying taxes or exploited tax law loopholes.

description: KLUG'S COMEBACK -- Chris Klug, a liver-transplant survivor, won a snowboarding bronze. PAGE D1

title: Holder of Trade Center Lease Settles With Two Insurers
description: The holder of the lease to the World Trade Center complex, Larry A. Silverstein, announced yesterday that he had settled a dispute with two of the companies insuring the complex.

title: Bury the Nation's Nuclear Waste in Nevada, Bush Says
description: President Bush said today that a 57-year accumulation of nuclear waste from power plants and weapons should be buried in the Nevada desert at Yucca Mountain, declaring that an end to the 40-year search for a place to isolate radioactive waste was necessary to ''protect public safety, health and the nation's security.''

title: Doubles Luge Earns U.S. Some Respect
description: In doubles luge, one competitor lies snugly atop of another, creating a mass of nearly 500 pounds as the sled streaks down the course with the look of a bloated walrus.

title: Corrections
description: Anews analysis article on Thursday about campaign finance legislation in the House of Representatives misstated the amount of hard money  limited and closely regulated donations  raised last year by Republican national party organizations. It was $132.3 million, not $122.3 million.

title: In Real Elections, There Ought to Be Competition
description: To no one's surprise, the Republicans in Albany's Senate majority have just gerrymandered themselves once again into districts designed to last for life, while the Democrats controlling the Assembly have done the same. The next, inevitable step is legal challenge by legislators or groups on the losing end of the fight -- with taxpayers picking up much of the tab.

title: In Rural China, Mental Hospitals Await Some Who Rock the Boat
description: No one would dispute that Huang Shurong is stubborn and outspoken. She is also smart, confident and articulate, attributes that would seem to leave her poised for success. But not in rural China.

title: Jeter A Good Bet To Lead Off For Yanks
description: On the days Derek Jeter bats third, he might kid with Manager Joe Torre. ''Oh, you finally learned,'' Jeter might say. But that is the most Jeter will let on about where he prefers to hit in the Yankees' lineup. ''He may want to hit in a certain place,'' Torre said. ''But he never has ever hinted to me.''

title: Cheney Rejects Criticism By Allies Over Stand on Iraq
description: Vice President Dick Cheney offered a strong rebuttal today to allied officials who have criticized the Bush administration's aggressive stance toward Iraq, saying the United States was prepared to use all available means to stop Saddam Hussein from continuing his development of weapons of mass destruction and that he expected allied support if ''aggressive action is required.''

title: New Tune in Queens School District: Harmony; Children of Every Race (and 22 Schools) Find a Band Brings Them Together
description: At snack time one recent Saturday morning, the young musicians munched casually on Pizza-Licious Pringles and sipped coolly from cartons of mango Hi-C, as if nothing historic were unfolding there in the basement of Public School 99 in Kew Gardens, Queens.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We're happy that justice was done.''

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Jobless Rate Rises
description: The state's unemployment rate increased for the 13th consecutive month in January, to 8 percent, the nation's highest and the state's worst in almost a decade. State economists said the rise was unexpected because fluctuations usually followed the national trends; the nation's unemployment rate dropped 0.2 percent, to 5.6 percent, last month. About 161,300 Oregon residents were without work in January, compared with 104,800 in January 2001. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Pet Food Deal Cleared
description: Mars Inc., the family-owned maker of Pedigree pet food, won European antitrust approval to buy Royal Canin S.A. of France for $1.3 billion after offering to give up some brands to offset competition concerns. Mars must sell five pet food brands and two factories, the European Commission said. After that, the combined company will have less market share in France than Royal Canin does now. Sales of Royal Canin's specialty nutritional dry food are growing about five times the rate of sales of canned food.

title: Two Economic Reports Indicate Recovery Could Be a Slow One
description: Consumer confidence fell this month, and industrial production declined in January, evidence that the economy may be slow in gaining strength.

title: Lawyer Known for Class Actions Will Lead the Enron Plaintiffs
description: William Lerach, a flamboyant class-action lawyer, was named yesterday to lead the tangle of securities fraud cases against Arthur Andersen and former executives and directors of the Enron Corporation.

title: Attack at Youth Center Jolts Staff and Students
description: Like a lot of students at the Pleasantville Cottage School, Rafaelina, a soft-spoken 17-year-old with long, wavy hair, was shaken by the vicious attack on a counselor here.

title: Gun Owned By Ex-Athlete Killed Driver Of Limousine
description: Investigators believe that the shooting death of a limousine driver at the estate of the former New Jersey Nets star Jayson Williams was accidental and occurred in Mr. Williams's bedroom, authorities said yesterday.

title: Global Crossing's Asia Unit Delays Release of Earnings
description: Adding to the uncertainty over Global Crossing, its Asian subsidiary announced today that it would delay reporting its fourth-quarter earnings by a week.

title: Police Link Suspect In Hit-and-Run Case To Second Shooting
description: Ronald J. Popadich may have been arrested, but his tally kept growing yesterday, the authorities said.

title: A Celebration of the Birthday And Works of Gubaidulina
description: Celebrating Sofia Gubaidulina's recent 70th birthday on Tuesday evening at Miller Theater, the ensemble Continuum pretty much repeated a program it gave in 1989, focused on her ''Perception'' for soprano and baritone soloists with string septet. During the last 13 years a lot has changed. Ms. Gubaidulina has taken her place as one of the most admired composers now working. But ''Perception'' remains one of her most powerful pieces.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHARP, SAMUEL RICHARD
description: SHARP-Samuel Richard. Feb. 15, 2002. For our very dear, beloved son, brother, uncle and devoted father, Samuel Richard Sharp, Esq., 1959-2002, 42 years old, who died unexpectedly. Your life has enriched & helped so many others to realize their true potential. You truly were gifted with a love for life and with the ability to show your love in great acts of kindness and generosity of spirit. You were such a giving, selfless person, only caring for the happiness of others. You were an optimist always, no matter how big the obstacles. You were such a hard worker, a perfectionist and success in everything you set out to do. In sports & your practice you were brilliant and tenacious, yet everyone you touched could not help but love you dearly as a friend. In your short life and tragic unexpected death, you left very precious memories for all who loved you and knew your love. Most of all your great sense of humor, brilliant mind and empathy for others will be sorely missed by family and friends who were so close to you. We will find it difficult to recover from such a loss & your profound influence upon us. We will truly feel your loving presence each day for the rest of our lives. All our love always, a brokenhearted mother and father Rachel and Martin Sharp, his son Thomas Sharp, who had such a very special, loving bond with his father, his devoted brothers and sistersin-law Robert and Ramy Sharp and Michael and Denise Sharp, and nephews and nieces Kyle, Dylan, Emily, Olivia, Jason and Sydney. Funeral service Sunday, February 17, 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, New York City.

title: Trial for Lindh Is Set for a Date Near Sept. 11
description: The trial of John Walker Lindh, the American accused of fighting alongside the Taliban, was scheduled today for late August, although his lawyers objected that it could mean that they present their defense around the first-year anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: A moving experience : Coping in a strange, new world
description: You think, "I'm living in Paris. How can I be miserable?" Yet it happens, even in the most romantic and historic settings. You get the dream assignment in Paris or London, or Florence, settle in  and the bottom falls out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWAID, ROBERT (BOB)
description: SCHWAID-Robert (Bob). Longtime music industry manager. Brother of Sandy and Al. Father of Cindy Leesha and Matthew Schwaid. Loving grandfather of Samantha and Joshua. Beloved life partner of Cynthia Lane. On February 15, after complications from esophageal cancer. Memorial service Sunday, February 17, 12:30 PM, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street. Donations to the American Cancer Society in lieu of flowers.

title: A Battle Over Redistricting Builds in the Legislature's Deeply Divided Houses
description: The legal and partisan battle lines began forming today as more details emerged about newly proposed legislative districts and as the Senate Republicans said they had released inaccurate maps and demographic information on Thursday.

description: The last time Herb Brooks coached the United States hockey team against Finland, it was the last game of the 1980 Olympics and the Americans clinched the gold medal.

title: P&O Princess Holders Defer Action on Rival Bids
description: Deferring a decision on two competing bids until antitrust regulators have ruled on both, shareholders of P&O Princess Cruises voted today to adjourn a meeting scheduled to approve one of the deals -- with Royal Caribbean Cruises.

title: Internet Offering Soars, Just Like Old Times
description: An Internet start-up goes public. It is not profitable -- in fact, it has lost hundreds of millions of dollars to date -- and faces competition from old-economy stalwarts. Yet on the first day of trading, investors go wild, pushing the company's stock up 60 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIDSON, ALFRED E.
description: DAVIDSON-Alfred E. Born in New York City on November 11, 1911, died in Arlington, VA on February 15, 2002. He is survived by two sons, Thomas and Kenneth, four grandchildren, Douglas, Anne, Alice and Claire, and one brother, Frank. At his request there will be no services. Contributions may be made to UNICEF.

title: AFGHANS' LEADER BLAMES OFFICIALS IN KILLING OF AIDE
description: Afghanistan's volatile post-Taliban politics took a grim turn today when Hamid Karzai, chairman of the interim government, said the killing Thursday of one of his ministers was carried out by other senior government officials, including the intelligence chief.

title: Youthful Skiers Exceed Predictions
description: Long before the Salt Lake Olympics convened, Bill Marolt, the president of the United States Ski and Snowboard Association, brazenly predicted that his team would win 10 medals. Considering that American skiers and snowboarders won a record six medals four years ago at the Nagano Games, it was a bold statement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LLOYD, JAMES W.
description: LLOYD-James W. Age 61 of Darien, CT, on February 12, 2002 after a long illness. Born in Syracuse, NY, he graduated from Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Columbia Law School, and served as a Lieutenant in the U.S. Navy. He was Senior Counsel at the law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell, where he was a partner for 26 years. He was a Director of The Charles A. and Anne Morrow Lindbergh Foundation. His loving wife, Maureen B. Lloyd, survives him. Funeral services will be private. A memorial service will be held on a date to be announced. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Whittingham Cancer Center at Norwalk Hospital, 24 Stevens St., Norwalk, CT. 06856.

title: Responding to Hate
description: To the Editor:

title: Backward on Global Warming
description: The obvious conclusion to be drawn from President Bush's latest global warming strategy, unveiled this week, is that he does not regard warming as a problem. There seems no other way to interpret a policy that would actually increase the gases responsible for heating the earth's atmosphere. That the policy demands little from the American people, while insulting allies who have agreed to take tough steps to deal with the problem, only adds to one's sense of dismay.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Segregation Suit Settled
description: Twenty-seven years after Jake Ayers sued Mississippi on behalf of his son and other black citizens for maintaining the remnants of a segregated public university system, the state has settled the case. Judge Neal B. Biggers Jr. of Federal District Court approved a long-range $503 million plan to upgrade historically black campuses after state legislators here endorsed it. Judge Biggers had expressed doubts about whether the settlement would result in more integrated campuses and about the future burden to taxpayers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEARER, HARTLEY
description: SHEARER-Hartley. The Trustees and staff of the American Federation of Arts are deeply saddened by the death of Hartley Shearer, husband of our beloved Trustee, Linda Shearer. We send our heartfelt condolences to Linda and their son, Ivor. Jan Mayer, Chairman, Gilbert H. Kinney, President, Julia Brown, Director

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Government Investigates Police
description: The government is investigating accusations of misconduct by police officers in County Donegal, which borders Northern Ireland, including charges that officers hid bomb-making equipment in the countryside that they then recovered to claim credit for infiltrating republican terrorist groups. Other accusations relate to harassment of suspects in a 1996 killing that has already been the subject of six investigations. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Uruguay: Trade Pact Sought
description: Hoping to open new markets to agricultural and beef products, President Jorge Batlle of Uruguay met with President Bush to push for a free-trade agreement between the two nations. Exports fell 22 percent last month in Uruguay, which is highly dependent on struggling economies in Argentina and Brazil. Standard & Poor's downgraded Uruguayan sovereign bonds to junk status on Thursday, citing decreasing revenue and increasing debt-service costs as a result of pressure on the Uruguayan peso. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: Family Hopes Bush Trip To China Frees Relative
description: The New Year's decorations are still over the mantel. The Christmas presents, crisply wrapped but gathering dust, are neatly piled on the living room floor. They are forlorn reminders of the hope that Sylvia Fong still holds out for her husband, Fuming Fong, an electrical engineer who went to China on a business trip two years ago and never came home.

title: Classrooms Did Not Gain In Bounty For Schools
description: The Board of Education released figures yesterday showing that the amount of money going directly into classrooms remained flat last year, while spending for central administration and middle management -- like principals and assistant principals -- increased sharply.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bank Layoffs
description: The British banking group Lloyds TSB said it would shed 3,000 jobs, 4 percent of its work force, after full-year net income fell 7.7 percent, to 2.5 billion ($3.5 billion). Lloyds, Britain's fifth-largest retail bank, attributed the decline to a 38 percent increase in provision for bad debts in 2001 and falling revenue from its Scottish Widows investment unit. Lloyds shares fell as much as 5.2 percent on concern that increased costs had outpaced reduced revenue. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Washington: Los Alamos Defamation Suit
description: A federal judge in Virginia has dismissed a defamation suit by a former Energy Department intelligence officer against Wen Ho Lee, the former nuclear scientist at the Los Alamos National Laboratory who was at the center of a spying case, on the grounds that a trial would disclose state secrets. The suit said that Dr. Lee and two government officials claimed that the plaintiff, Notra Trulock, had based an accusation of espionage against Dr. Lee on his Chinese ethnicity. Larry Klayman, a lawyer for Mr. Trulock, said he would appeal. James Sterngold (NYT)

title: Brooklyn Teacher Arrested
description: A public high school teacher was arrested early yesterday morning in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn on charges of drug possession and trespassing, the police said.

title: Elephant's 'E' Irks G.O.P.
description: It comes as no surprise that the Republican Party of Texas does not find the World Wide Web site www.EnronOwnsTheGOP.com as amusing as the Texas Democrats who run it.
