title: House G.O.P. Leader Urges New Push on Social Security
description: The House majority leader, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, urged his fellow Republicans today not to shrink from a fight with Democrats this year over how to shore up Social Security.

title: In a word : Was that yes, no, or maybe?What the dictionary forgot to tell you
description: PARIS  There was the time in Egypt when it took a few days to figure out that "five minutes" meant "in an hour" or maybe "tomorrow" or "one of these days, if the wind is blowing from the right direction."

title: Denver Zoo Is Investigated for Bear Fights, Including a Fatal One
description: Federal officials are investigating why the Denver Zoo did not separate two Asiatic black bears who fought repeatedly over their 14 years in captivity together until the male killed the female in October.

title: Bush Has Much to Finesse In Trip to Japan and Korea
description: Barely a month ago, the first two stops on President Bush's Far East tour -- Tokyo and Seoul -- had all the markings of a makeup class, routine stopovers in a trip that was hastily cut in the wake of the Sept. 11 terror attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEHRMAN, DARRYL
description: BEHRMAN - Darryl. Age 51, passed away suddenly February 12, 2002. He is survived by his heartbroken, adoring and devoted wife Janine, son Greg, daughter Amanda, her fiance Zac Zeitlin, mother Fay Behrman, brother & sister-in-law Grant and Shelley Behrman, mother-in-law Gloria Stern, brother-in-law and sisterin-law Colin and Felicia Stern, niece and nephews Kim and Doug Behrman and Craig and Gary Stern. A co-founder of Behrman Capital, Darryl graduated from the University of Witwatersrand, Johannesburg, South Africa and Stanford Business School. A remarkably warm and compassionate man, he led an extraordinary life full of vigor, adventure and love. He was an accomplished outdoorsman with a deep passion for nature and particularly for the Africa of his birth. Above all, he cherished his beloved family. His family and friends will carry his legacy with adoration and pride. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, February 17, 2002, at 11:00 A.M. at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, New York.

title: Responding to Hate
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Washington: The Wheat Wars
description: Responding to complaints from North Dakota farmers, the United States trade representative accused Canada of undercutting American wheat producers through monopoly practices by the Canadian Wheat Board, a government trading group. The comments by the trade representative, Robert B. Zoellick, came after a 16-month investigation. Mr. Zoellick said he was considering bringing the case before the World Trade Organization as well as filing antidumping petitions with the Department of Commerce. Imports of Canadian hard red spring wheat increased by 300,000 metric tons in the last two years. Elizabeth Becker (NYT)

title: Canadians Refuse to Back Down
description: Jamie Sal smiled at her partner, David Pelletier, who entertained the news media with his affable humor. In a news conference held this morning after it had been announced that they had been awarded a gold medal, Pelletier and Sal, the Canadian pairs skaters, celebrated the end of a whirlwind week with sweet vindication.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BILLINGSLEY, FRANCES LONG WORTH
description: BILLINGSLEY - Frances Long worth. Age 89, died peacefully on February 14, 2002 in Somers, NY. Resident of Somers for 57 years, founder of Frances Billingsley Realty, a founder and president of the Somers Historical Society, trustee of the Westchester Historical Society, delegate to UNICEF executive board for 20 years. Executive director of the American Indian Hall of Fame, Anadarko, OK, which was founded by her husband, Logan. Loving mother to Jerome, Robert and Francis and generous grandmother of Katherine, Hillary, Jennifer and Alyssa. Visiting Saturday, 2-5 PM and Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, NY. Funeral Mass, Monday 1 PM, St. Mary's Church, Katonah. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Somers Historical Society, Attn: The Frances Fund, Town Hall, Somers, NY 10589.

title: Concerns About Accounting Cause Losses Once Again
description: Stocks fell yesterday, led by the International Business Machines Corporation, after a published report said the company did not fully disclose a gain from the sale of a unit.

title: GLOBALSTAR FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION
description: Globalstar filed yesterday for bankruptcy protection after spending more than $4 billion to build a satellite-telephone network that failed to attract enough customers and left Globalstar struggling to pay creditors. Globalstar, mostly owned by Globalstar Telecommunications and Loral Space & Communications, listed $573.4 million in assets and $3.34 billion in debts in Chapter 11 papers filed in United States Bankruptcy Court in Delaware. Qualcomm also owns a stake in the partnership. The bankruptcy plan would cancel the partnership stakes, and bondholders and unsecured creditors would assume ownership of the company's assets, Globalstar said. The company, which is based in San Jose, Calif., said the filing would not interrupt the company's worldwide phone service.

title: Corrections
description: The Classical Music and Dance Guide in Weekend yesterday included an outdated reference to a 651 Black Dance program at the Harvey Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music and rendered the name of the performing group inaccurately. ''Tradition and Transformation'' by the Rennie Harris PureMovement troupe (not Pure/Movement) was canceled; there was no performance last night, and there will be none tonight.

title: F.B.I. Agents Say Student Freely Gave Cooperation
description: Several F.B.I. agents testified yesterday that a Jordanian student freely cooperated with them and voluntarily accompanied them to their office for questioning before he was held as a material witness in the Sept. 11 investigation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOLKMAN, JEROME
description: VOLKMAN-Jerome. Beloved husband of Helen. Devoted father of Robert and Gwen, Carol and Richard Hanfling. Adored brother of Alvin. Cherished grandfather of Jaclyn, Evan, Lee, Jamie and Brett. Services Sunday 10AM at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Boulevard at 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: College President Is Accused of Impersonating a Police Officer
description: A state university president was arrested today and charged with impersonating a police officer because, the authorities say, he pulled over a speeding driver here last month.

title: Execution Is Stayed in a Case With Race Issues
description: The Supreme Court gave a Texas death row inmate a stay of execution today and agreed to use his case to decide an important question of how a defendant can prove that the jury selection process was unconstitutionally tainted by racial discrimination.

title: Two Words for Volunteers
description: Rexene Boyd's voice is just about gone. I had to lean over to hear her.

title: Seeing Common Facets In Modern and Romantic
description: Since Michael Tilson Thomas took over the San Francisco Symphony in 1995, it has become the envy of East Coasters. Along with Esa-Pekka Salonen and the Los Angeles Philharmonic, it has become a model of how an orchestra can renovate its repertory and not only keep its audience but attract younger listeners as well.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHTULL, JACOB, RABBI
description: SHTULL-Jacob, Rabbi. We record with sorrow the passing of our revered colleague and friend, Rabbi Emeritus of Congregation Shaarey Tikvah, Beachwood, OH, whose community he served for 35 years. Our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Rita, to their family and to all who were blessed by his rabbinate. Rabbi Reuven Hammer, Pres. Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Exec. VP The Rabbinical Assembly

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: State Pageants at War With Miss America Organization
description: To pull the struggling Miss America pageant into the 21st century, Robert M. Renneisen Jr., its chief executive, has proposed some unconventional ideas, like moving the pageant from Atlantic City -- perhaps to an Indian casino in Connecticut -- and licensing a Miss America slot machine.

title: Algerian Pilot Says Detention Has Made Him a Sept. 11 Victim
description: Lotfi Raissi, an Algerian pilot freed on bail after the United States abandoned an effort to extradite him on terrorism charges, urged Washington today to drop further charges against him, saying his five months of detention without trial had been a ''living nightmare.''

title: Icahn Seeking U.S. Approval For Big Stake In ImClone
description: The financier Carl C. Icahn is seeking antitrust approval to acquire a stake of as much as 40 percent in ImClone Systems, the troubled cancer drug developer. ImClone, which announced Mr. Icahn's action yesterday, said it had adopted a takeover defense.

title: Valentine Punctuates the Question Marks
description: Bobby Valentine was nearing the end of his first full day at spring training with the Mets, a day that began with a 7 a.m. television interview and continued through several hours of team meetings. But Valentine, the Mets' manager, remained intense because he was discussing his team. His new team.

title: Swedish Offense Easily Dismantles Talented Canadian Team
description: Even after his team beat Canada by 5-2 in its Olympic opener tonight, Sweden Coach Hardy Nilsson was talking of how honored his players were to face such great opposition.

title: National Briefing
description: NORTHWEST

title: Theresa Bernstein, an Ash Can School Artist, Dies at 111
description: Theresa Bernstein, who as a member of the Ash Can School of realistic painting was both hailed and flailed for ''painting like a man'' in the 1910's and then continued to generate vibrant canvases for eight more decades, died in Manhattan on Tuesday. She was generally believed to be 111 and lived in Manhattan and Gloucester, Mass.

title: A Classicist's Starting Point: Putting Aside Interpretations
description: Confessions of ignorance are not usually in a critic's best interest. But in this case, perhaps, an exception can be made. Ignorance, after all, is now common when confronting Greek literature. Beginning with ignorance is also an approach recommended by many of these demanding essays by Seth Benardete, a classicist at New York University, who died to relatively little notice in November. Because of his difficult and idiosyncratic interpretations, that notice is not likely to expand beyond a small group of philosophers, political scientists and classicists.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Violence In Kashmir
description: At least a dozen members of militant groups were killed by Indian forces in Kashmir in the last two days, the authorities said. Most had been trying to cross the line that separates the Pakistani- and Indian-controlled parts of the territory. The Indian government has said that all guerrilla infiltration must cease before it reduces its heavy deployment in the region. Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: NBC Trying Its Best To Be Cool
description: Using terms like gnarly and dude, Matt Lauer archly nudged the Olympic snowboarding medalists on NBC's ''Today'' show Wednesday to admit that they had celebrated in a ''party-hearty'' fashion. He looked a little like an English anthropologist poking at Tarzan.

title: Defying the Odds Again, Klug Grabs the Bronze
description: A buckle on his rear boot snapped off. That was what it came down to for Chris Klug -- liver-transplant survivor, World Cup snowboarding contender -- during his parallel giant slalom race today for a bronze medal against Nicolas Huet of France. Klug could feel the loosening of the red plastic boot, the slight loss of control.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the On Stage and Off column of Weekend on Feb. 8 about a revival of the musical ''Gypsy,'' set for Broadway next year, omitted a reference to two of its creators. Arthur Laurents wrote the book and Jule Styne the music; Stephen Sondheim wrote only the lyrics.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Giuliani Shows Milder Side To Star-Struck Londoners
description: The unseen cellphone began ringing at the worst possible moment, just as Rudolph W. Giuliani started his speech.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BARTH, EDITH
description: BARTH-Edith. February 16, 1997. Forever mourned, missed, loved and always in our thoughts. Your Famil

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Lay Sold $100 Million In Enron Stock Last Year

title: Bunny Allen, 95, Hunter; Found Fame in East Africa
description: Bunny Allen, the last of a generation of professional hunters in East Africa who prided themselves on having as sharp an eye for their clients' wives as for their four-legged quarry, died at his home on the Indian Ocean island of Lamu last month, his family said.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the folk singer Dave Van Ronk on Tuesday misstated the name and release date of a Folkways album. It was ''Dave Van Ronk Sings Ballads, Blues and a Spiritual,'' not ''and Spirituals.'' It was released in 1959, not 1960. The article also misstated the date of a second album and thus reversed the release order for the two. ''Dave Van Ronk Sings Earthy Ballads and Blues'' was issued in 1961, not 1959.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Norway: Whalers Allowed A Bigger Catch
description: After tentatively approving a resumption of international trade in whale products, officials increased the quota of minke whales for the 2002 hunt by 23 percent, to 674. Norway resumed whaling in 1993, defying a ban by the International Whaling Commission. Japan is weighing whether to allow imports of Norwegian products despite concerns about possible PCB contamination, and the value of each whale could rise sharply. Walter Gibbs (NYT)

title: Canadian Skaters Awarded Share of Olympic Gold; French Judge Suspended, Her Scoring Thrown Out
description: Four days after they were awarded silver medals behind a Russian team in the Olympic pairs figure skating competition, the Canadians David Pelletier and Jamie Sal were awarded duplicate gold medals today.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article on Thursday about campaign finance legislation in the House of Representatives misstated the amount of hard money -- limited and closely regulated donations -- raised last year by Republican national party organizations. It was $132.3 million, not $122.3 million.

title: Cloning the Cat Gives Us Pause
description: To the Editor:

title: WORLDCOM TO FIRE WORKERS IN COMMISSIONS CASE
description: WorldCom said yesterday that an internal audit had found that a dozen sales representatives improperly claimed commissions for sales made by other employees. At least three workers in WorldCom's office in Arlington, Va., will be fired or forced to quit, said Brad Burns, a spokesman. The salaries of other employees under scrutiny have been frozen, and those workers may also be fired, he said. The actions by the sales representatives cost WorldCom, which is based in Clinton, Miss., as much as $4 million, Mr. Burns said. He said that the company expected to recover the money and that the matter would not affect financial results.

title: Corrections
description: A report by Bloomberg News in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about the sale of Berkshire Hathaway's holding in Citigroup misstated the number and value of shares that Berkshire reported holding on Sept. 30. It was 2.4 million shares, valued at $114 million -- not 7.4 million shares, valued at $350 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANDLERS, ANNE
description: HANDLERS - Anne. Beloved mother of Lynne Handlers and Sherry Parise. Beloved mother-inlaw to James Parise and beloved sister to Renee Mackler and Elise Shill. Services will be held Friday, February 15th at 11AM at Kehila Chapels, 60 Brighton 11th Street, Brooklyn, New York.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Stake Sale Canceled
description: The lender BHW Holding A.G. and a shareholder canceled a $1.3 billion stock sale because of insufficient demand, the third European equity offering to fail this year. Plans to sell may be renewed, a spokesman said. BHW aimed to sell a 5 percent stake in itself, and the holding company BTA was trying to sell 27.5 percent.

title: Amid Confusion, Expos May Not Be Able to Wait Till Next Year
description: Javier Vazquez spent four or five nights a week during the off-season futilely searching for information about his baseball future on the Internet. No one could definitively tell Vazquez if the Montreal Expos would even exist in the 2002 season, so he scoured various Web sites trying to collect slivers of news.

title: Suspicious Signals?
description: One big question in the investigation of the currency trader whose employer says he tried to hide $750 million in losses last year is going to be how aware the company was of his trades and whether other currency traders should have been suspicious.

title: An Insecure Afghanistan
description: The world got a chilling demonstration Thursday of why Afghanistan urgently needs an expanded international peacekeeping force. The country's aviation minister, Abdul Rahman, was beaten to death at the Kabul airport, allegedly by rivals within the government. Yesterday rioting erupted outside Kabul's main soccer stadium when disappointed fans could not get into a good-will match between peacekeepers and a local team.

title: Cablevision Is Holding Off on Carrying YES
description: AOL Time Warner and Comcast are expected to announce next week that they will carry the fledgling YES network -- which will feature 130 Yankee games -- as a basic service on its cable systems. Cablevision remains a holdout because it views YES as too expensive.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Privatization Fails
description: Plans to privatize the Czech electricity company CEZ were thrown into disarray when the lead bidder, lectricit de France, pulled out, saying the government's minimum price of 200 billion koruny ($5.5 billion) for a 67.6 percent stake was too high. This was the third time in three months that low bids postponed the CEZ sale. Analysts say CEZ may not be sold in the foreseeable future. ''This is no disaster for CEZ,'' said Libor Vinklat at Erste Bank in Prague. ''CEZ is a utility that doesn't need a majority owner. The management is O.K., and CEZ is highly profitable and financially healthy.'' Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: Former Yale Professor Gets 20 Years for Molesting Boy He Mentored
description: A former Yale University professor was sentenced today to 20 years in prison for sexually assaulting and making pornographic videotapes of a New Haven public school boy he once had mentored.

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Splitting Counties For Voting
description: A state judge ruled that the legislative districts drawn by the General Assembly are unconstitutional because they split counties. The judge, Knox Jenkins of Superior Court, said the redistricting plan violated a provision of the State Constitution that requires counties to be kept intact when State House and Senate districts are redrawn. Lawyers for the state maintain that the federal Voting Rights Act trumps the requirement to keep counties intact.

title: Cloning the Cat Gives Us Pause
description: To the Editor:

title: Nascar's Rule Tweaking Pleases Few Competitors
description: Scrambling like a pit crew to re-establish competitive balance before the Daytona 500 on Sunday, Nascar announced today that it had tweaked its aerodynamic rules for the second time in five days.

title: Sports of The Times; Silver Monday, Golden Friday
description: Ladies, gentlemen and judges of all nations, we have a decision. The winners in the pairs skating on a technical knockout of an intolerable controversy are the Russians, the Canadians and the rest of the Olympians, who may now be rediscovered, at least until the next figure skating row breaks out.

title: Show of Leadership on Shaky Japan Banks
description: Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi asked financial regulators today to step up inspections of the country's shaky banks, the latest effort in his campaign to head off a financial crisis.

title: Steps to Mend Frayed Image
description: Pressing for the decision to award two gold medals in the Olympic figure skating pairs competition yesterday, the International Olympic Committee signaled a fresh willingness to intervene speedily in an attempt to restore credibility to a tarnished competition and salvage its own sullied reputation.

title: Israeli Killed as His Commandos Demolish West Bank HOuse
description: The leader of an elite Israeli commando unit was killed today by a falling wall as his troops demolished a Palestinian militant's home in the West Bank. The accident was the second blow in 12 hours for the Israeli Army, which lost three soldiers and their tank in a Palestinian attack near here on Thursday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, MARCEL
description: STEIN-Marcel, member NSPE, AHES, ASME, passed away in his 101st year. Born in Hungary, was Chief Engineer of textile plants, worked for the City of New York for 15 years and taught at Pace College for 12 years. He had pattents for textile processes, steam and lighting equipment. He is mourned by his son, daughter, grandson and their families, as well as many friends. Donations requested to Isabella Home, NY.

title: A Watershed in American Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGELSON, LILLIAN
description: ENGELSON-Lillian. Beloved wife of the late Larry. Devoted mother of Hal and Louise, and David and Leslie. Cherished grandmother of Todd & Claudia, Nancy & Andrew, Drew and Gilian, & Trevor. Loving great-grandmother of Benjamin and Francisco. Services at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont Road, Elmont, LI, Sunday, 10:30AM.

title: Bush Is Giving Peace Corps An Aid Mission In Afghanistan
description: President Bush said today that a Peace Corps team would leave within three weeks for Afghanistan to assess how the program could help reconstruct the country. The mission would be the first time the agency has been in Afghanistan since the Soviet Union invaded in 1979.

title: Play or Defend? Keep an Eye On Your Entries, Declarer
description: Study the diagramed deal and decide whether you would like to play or defend a six-club contract, with best play and defense. It occurred a week ago in the Betty Kaplan Teams in Manhattan, an event that is perhaps unique in North America. Players are required to rotate partnerships, facing each teammate on one-third of the boards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, DOROTHEA H.
description: KRAMER-Dorothea H., L.H.S. On February 13, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Walter F. Kramer. Mother of Allan F., II and the late Walter F. Jr. Daughter of the late M. Frank and Clara Russell Hurley. Sister of the late Gertrude Russell Hurley. Grandmother of Walter F., III, Elizabeth Brown, Dorothea Adams, Marguerite Kircher and Thomas J. Bennetter. Also survived by nine great grandchildren. Funeral Saturday, 10 A.M. from Duffy Funeral Home, 255 Ninth St, Bklyn. Mass of Christian Burial 10:15AM Saint Saviour Church. Funeral private. Visiting Friday, 2-5 and 79PM. In lieu of flowers, donations to Catholic Charities, Dioceses of Brooklyn, appreciated.

title: Mayor Says Police Officers Should Obey Smoking Rule
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg sternly pledged yesterday to stop city employees from smoking in public buildings -- even if those employees happen to be police officers.

title: China Expels 53 Foreign Falun Gong Followers
description: China expelled 33 Americans and 20 other foreigners today, a day after they were arrested in the largest demonstration yet by foreign members of the banned Falun Gong spiritual movement, the Beijing police said.

title: Narcotics Gang Dismantled in Bronx, Police Say
description: Authorities said yesterday that they had dismantled a narcotics-peddling gang that they accused of distributing large amounts of heroin in the Bronx, some of which ended up being resold throughout New England.

title: Disney Names a Chairman for Its Live-Action Movie Studio
description: Richard W. Cook, who has worked for the Walt Disney Company his entire career, beginning as a monorail operator at Disneyland, was named chairman of the company's live-action movie studio today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7, 10

title: LIBERTY MEDIA TURNS DOWN GERMAN REGULATORS
description: The Liberty Media Corporation, which has agreed to buy six German cable television companies from Deutsche Telekom, said it refused to offer concessions to German regulators who might block the sale. Germany's cartel office sent Liberty a second warning yesterday that the $4.8 billion purchase might not be approved. Regulators said Jan. 31 that the company, which is based in Englewood, Colo., must commit itself to upgrading the regional cable TV systems so they can provide high-speed Internet access and telephone services to compete with Deutsche Telekom.

title: In a Big Switch, Barrick to Sell Some Gold on Spot Market
description: The Barrick Gold Corporation said today that it planned to sell half of its 2002 gold production on the spot market -- the first time in 14 years that it has not hedged, or locked in prices in advance, on all its output.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Feb. 7 about Dr. Robert Hanbury Brown, an engineer who helped develop a telescopic device that allowed the measurement of stars, misstated its reach. The device measured stars in this galaxy, not in distant ones. The obituary also referred erroneously to a connection between the device and Dr. Hanbury Brown's earlier work on radar. The technologies were not related.

title: The Knicks Squander Another Chance
description: Scott Layden, the Knicks' president and general manager, said before last night's game against the Detroit Pistons that he would not be pressured into making a trade simply to alter the team's look or to create the illusion of change. But every time the Knicks take the floor, they look more and more like a club in need of a shake-up, if only because it might change their mentality.

title: DRUG BOAT INVESTIGATED
description: Intelligence officials are investigating possible Al Qaeda or Taliban links to a drug shipment intercepted off the coast of Pakistan on Wednesday. Canadian naval officers discovered two metric tons of what was believed to be hashish or opium when they stopped a wooden boat. Two men jumped from the boat into a speedboat and escaped. Christopher Marquis (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: Government Apologizes For Bombing
description: The government apologized for bombing a food distribution site in the south last Saturday hours after the World Food Program handed out food to 18,000 people. Abdoulaye Balde, operations manager for the agency in southern Sudan, where the government is fighting rebels, called the incident ''totally unacceptable.'' Two children were killed in the bombing, which the government attributed to ''an unintended technical fault.'' Marc Lacey (NYT)

Dear grandmother of Peter and his wife Lynda Wollmeringer of Winchester, MA., and Robert D. & his wife Elizabeth Wollmeringer of Marlborough, MA. Great-grandmother of Britney and Joseph. She is also survived by many nieces, nephews and friends. Services on Tuesday, February 19 at 1:00 P.M. at the Park West-Riverside Chapel, 333 Amsterdam Avenue, New York City. Donations in her memory may be made to the charity of your choice.

Argentine Tourism Pins Hopes on Devalued Peso
description: UNTIL early January, Argentina was perhaps the most expensive country in Latin America for tourists. But it has become dramatically cheaper as a result of an almost 50 percent devaluation of the peso, which for more than a decade had been fixed at one to one with the American dollar.

title: Arab Experts Fault Saudi's Idea Based on Land-for-Peace Trade
description: A tentative proposal from Crown Prince Abdullah of Saudi Arabia for ending Middle East violence, based on a longstanding land-for-peace formula, would serve only to convince Israel that inflexibility toward ending its occupation works, Arab experts said yesterday.

title: No Requests for 'Disco Inferno,' Please
description: Quebec City, home to North America's only ice hotel, now boasts another frozen first: the Icecothque, a discothque on the terrace of the popular Maurice Night Club, through March, weather permitting. Its sculptured walls are made from 50,000 pounds of ice blocks.

title: 10 Years After
description: IN the early morning of Feb. 15, 1992, just hours before Foxwoods Resort Casino was scheduled to open, Richard (Skip) Hayward, the chairman of the Mashantucket Pequots at the time, sat at a bar with the head of the tribal gaming commission and the casino's chief executive officer.

description: If you were president of the United States, and someone asked you to describe -- in one word -- what kind of state the Union was in, what adjective would you select?

description: Thirteen percent of investors polled recently said that they would have to delay retirement because of stock losses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOCKRY, JOHN JAMES
description: DOCKRY-John James. Passed away January 6. Memorial service to be held Saturday, February 23rd, 2002 at 11 A.M.. at Blessed Sacrament Church, 152 West 71st Street, New York.

title: The Trouble With Self-Esteem
description: My thanks to Lauren Slater (Feb. 3) for putting a pin to the bubble of self-esteem. When my 8-year-old daughter makes me proud, I tell her ''good job,'' never ''good girl.'' When she disappoints, I focus on what was wrong with what she did, never implying something wrong with her. In this way, I try to guide her without helping to build a self-image of any kind.

title: The Nation; Taking Enron Scraps to Auction
description: MOST office workers are familiar with them -- the spongy squeezeballs and coffee mugs, the calculators and desk calendars bearing the logo of whatever conglomerated amalgamation happens to sign the checks. A new-hire orientation, for instance, might yield a tote bag. A job well done might earn a glass paperweight with the company's logo suspended in the center. And while all this boosterish debris rarely transforms wage slaves into loyal corporate argonauts, who doesn't like a new yo-yo?

title: Following the Path Of Gertrude Stein
description: THE story of modernism coming from Europe to America in the first decades of the 20th century is one that never gets tedious. At the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art in Hartford, the new exhibition, ''Impressionism to Surrealism From the Baltimore Museum of Art: Selections From the Collections of Claribel and Etta Cone, Saidie Adler May and Blanche Adler,'' is a rich addition to the saga.

title: INVESTING WITH/Sandor Cseh; Dreyfus International Value Fund
description: MEETING with a company's management can be more informative than the company intends, says the multilingual Sandor Cseh, who runs the $300 million Dreyfus International Value fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE GRAZIA, LUCIA HEFFELFINGER
description: de GRAZIA-Lucia Heffelfinger. Age 75, on February 10, in Princeton, NJ. Born in Minneapolis, MN to influential Republican parents, Elizabeth and Peavey Heffelfinger. Her mother was treasurer of the National Women's Republican Organization and her father was a wealthy grain dealer. She moved to Princeton in 1948 with her first husband, John W. Ballantine. She had been active in the New Jersey juvenile justice system in the 1960's and 1970's, serving on the civilian parole board of the Clinton Home for Girls and on the board for the Jamesburg State Home for Boys. She also helped found the Center for Women in Politics. Lucia was described as a caring person, flamboyant, funny, generous, remarkable, distinguished and fascinating. She was also praised for always wanting to help the less fortunate. She was predeceased by her second husband, the Pulitzer Prize winning author Sebastian de Grazia with whom she spent much time at their home in Capri, Italy. She is survived by her two children, John W. Ballantine, Jr. and Lucia P. Ballantine, two granddaughters, Elizabeth and Anna Walden and five step-children of Sebastian de Grazia. A memorial service will be held at noon Tuesday, February 19, at Trinity Church, 33 Mercer St, Princeton, NJ. A reception will follow at the Nassau Club, 6 Mercer Street, Princeton, New Jersey.

title: The Legislature Settles Its Custody Battle
description: What was proving to be a cantankerous custody battle has been solved. The Democratic Senate leader, Richard Codey, and the Republican Senate leader, John Bennett (foreground), had been squabbling for weeks about how to share their joint custody of a Senate that is split 20-20 between the two parties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSSMAN, ILENE
description: SUSSMAN-Ilene. January 19, 2002. Beloved wife of Brian, loving Mommy of Rhy, cherished sister of Janet & dear daughter of Arthur and the late Rosalie, stepdaughter of Sydell, best friend to countless many, & accomplished attorney and law partner. She was adored by all those she touched as she enriched all our lives with her incomparable warmth, humanity, wit and intellect. Thank you, Lenie, for your brief stay on earth was a treasured gift to us all. We will miss and love you always.

title: Political Briefing; Kerry Is Running; Opponents Are Scarce
description: Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts is running for re-election this year. But hardly so you'd know it.

title: Broad Help Arrives For Pension Savings
description: WHEN President Bush signed the tax-overhaul bill last year, the ground shifted under almost everyone saving for retirement. Most of the law's changes are favorable to taxpayers, allowing them, beginning this year, to put away more in tax-deferred plans.

description: It looks as though the lights may be turned back on at Crossroads Theater, now that it plans to name an interim artistic director.

description: THERE are few things more forlorn looking than a seaside place in the dead of winter. That thought crossed my mind on entering Harbor Lights, which faces Norwalk Harbor in East Norwalk.

description: Richard Wesley Lawrence Jr., the founding chairman of the Adirondack Park Agency, died on Feb. 6 in Elizabethtown, N.Y., the Essex County village where he lived. He was 93.

title: Police Shut Down Several Auto Parts Shops
description: Investigators closed a string of shops in Queens on Friday for trading in stolen auto parts, the authorities said yesterday. Several of the shops were owned by Carmine Agnello, the imprisoned mobster and son-in-law of John J. Gotti, the jailed Gambino family boss, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies last Sunday about the discovery of Asian longhorned beetles in two maple trees in Central Park included a parks official's erroneous reference to the removal of the trees. They were cut down this past Thursday, not earlier.

title: Austin
description: Austin is the capital of Texas, but musicians, filmmakers and artists are as much a part of its identity as politicians, bureaucrats and high-tech moguls like Michael Dell, who started his namesake computer company out of his University of Texas dorm room.

title: Signed, Sealed and Then What?
description: DELIVERIES are the lifeblood of the suburbs. All day long the trucks rumble through the subdivisions, enlivening the empty days of those of us who are at home waiting for a delivery. Is it our turn at last? What decadent luxuries have the neighbors ordered from the Bed Barn, Seniors 'R' Us or Hot Tub Heaven? The boxes reveal nothing. They could hold a pool table or a gazebo. Often the item was ordered so long ago that it comes as a surprise to the recipients themselves.

title: One Town's Mayor Is Now Overseer of 567
description: THE view from Susan Bass Levin's window is much different these days. Her new office as head of the Department of Community Affairs overlooks a stunning panorama, with the Delaware River in the distance and the golden dome of the State House a bit closer and off to the right.

title: All Things Japanese At Honolulu Festival
description: Nearly 5,000 Japanese performers and artisans will bring their crafts and festival traditions to Hawaii for the Honolulu Festival from March 8 to 10. The event, which builds on the close cultural and historical ties between Japan and Hawaii, showcases the main attractions of about 20 religious or cultural festivals held around Japan.

title: Awe and Unease as South Africa Stretches Out
description: The strangers from the south set up shop in this port city of rusting shacks and neglected buildings two years ago and soon thousands of sleek cellphones were chirping in one of the world's poorest countries.

title: A Sky-High Work in Progress
description: IN 1882 Maj. A. B. Rogers, an American engineer and former soldier working for the Canadian Pacific Railway, pitched camp with his survey crew in a deep valley between the soaring Rocky and Purcell Mountains. Rogers's supply cache was soon renamed Golden City, in hopes of outglittering a Silver City nearby. Seldom since then has Golden, a fraying timber town in southeastern British Columbia, entertained such dreams of grandeur.

title: When Neo-Realism Collided With Reality
description: WHEN Vittorio De Sica's relentless dissection of postwar Italian society, ''Umberto D.,'' appeared in 1952, he was accused by the government's minister of entertainment of ''washing Italy's dirty linen in public.'' The open letter, published in a newspaper, hinted strongly that Italian filmmakers should henceforth be more upbeat -- especially if they wanted to continue receiving government subsidies.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Front Lines column last Sunday referred incorrectly to a man sought in the kidnapping of Daniel Pearl, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal. The man, Ahmed Omar Sheikh, was identified as the chief suspect by Pakistani authorities; he was not arrested until Tuesday.

title: Pataki Works Out Deal With Indians For Upstate Land
description: Gov. George E. But on the ground or in the trees, they are a smelly, noisy nuisance, frightening to children, with a penchant for scattering compost heaps and fouling car roofs. They're turkey vultures. They arrived in the small Lake Truesdale community in South Salem in early December, and only recently have they shown any signs of leaving.

title: QUICK BITE/New Brunswick; Franks for the Memories
description: Who says a hot dog isn't breakfast food? At 7 o'clock on Tuesday mornings, hungry patrons can be found lined up in front of New Johnny's restaurant on Route 27 in New Brunswick, across from the Coach Bus terminal, on the Somerset border. Tuesdays are ''dollar days'' when the establishment's biggest seller -- a hot dog with chili sauce and fried onions -- goes for a buck. In fact, a breakfast special of steak and egg and cheese is just $2.99, a pretty good bargain any day. The menu also includes breakfast sandwiches, lunch sandwiches and hamburgers, buffalo wings, Philly-style steaks, fish and chips and mozzarella sticks for $1.50 to $3.50. The little restaurant has been serving up to 20 customers at a time for breakfast and lunch for 45 years, said Katherine Kourti, who with her husband, Dmitrios Gavalos, manages the place for his uncle, Lucas Barbatsis. Mr. Barbatsis and his wife, Theodora, have owned the place for about four years (adding the ''New'') and also run a Stewart's in Franklin Park. On any given day, according to Mrs. Barbatsis, New Johnny's fills 200 to 300 orders for patrons who include lawyers from New Brunswick and businesspeople from down the street, people like Phil Seagull, who works for a tire outlet and has been eating there for 20 years. ''Good food, clean and not expensive,'' he explained. Those franks, $1.65 when not on sale, are coveted by former customers. Mrs. Barbatsis said some visiting expatriates buy 20 or 30 or them, freeze them and take them back home. Norm Oshrin

title: Private Sector; A Highflying Offering That Started as a Sleepover
description: What does it take to win a big underwriting deal these days? It may just be giving up some room on your living-room sofa. Morgan Stanley was named the lead underwriter last week for the initial stock offering of JetBlue Airways of New York -- an offering that will surely be one of the more high-profile deals of the year. But Morgan Stanley had the inside track years ago. In the late 1990's, when David Neeleman, JetBlue's founder and chief executive, was visiting Manhattan from his home in Salt Lake City to try to sell his business plan for a no-frills airline based at Kennedy Airport, Kevin Murphy, Morgan Stanley's airline analyst, offered to put him up in his East Side apartment. The frugal Mr. Neeleman ended up staying over several times before JetBlue got off the ground in early 2000. Mr. Murphy has also invested nearly $125,000 in the fledgling airline. The two men first met when Mr. Neeleman was president of Morris Air, a low-fare airline based in Salt Lake City. Morgan Stanley was supposed to take Morris Air public, but it was sold to Southwest Airlines in 1993. Now, if all goes according to plan, Morgan Stanley will finally gets its fee from Mr. Neeleman. Laurence Zuckerman

title: A 'Baroque' Approach to Strauss Opera
description: IN the year and a half before he died last April, the Italian conductor Giuseppe Sinopoli committed to disc what were to become the last two operas in his (unfinished) Richard Strauss cycle. ''Ariadne auf Naxos'' is one of Strauss's most popular works; ''Friedenstag,'' such an oddity that the recording, from 1999, will not even be released in the United States until May. Still, as the last recordings of a conductor who was known for his Strauss, these disparate pieces have both taken on a stamp of authority, all the more so since both feature Deborah Voigt, said to be Sinopoli's favorite soprano and arguably the leading Strauss soprano on the scene today. Both, moreover, were made with the Dresden Staatskapelle, which Sinopoli led for a decade and which has its own Strauss tradition, since it played the world premieres of 9 of the composer's 15 operas.

The prosecution says his speech will have no bearing on the trial. This week, they will begin calling witnesses they claim will prove that troops under his command carried out mass deportations and executions of civilians against ethnic Albanians in Kosovo in 1999.

The mid-January storm brought between 220 million and 270 million dead butterflies raining down from their roosts in the towering trees. The Mexican butterflies form the entire breeding stock for the eastern United States and Canada, where the monarchs will begin returning this spring and summer. Scientists will be watching to see if they start recovering during their breeding season, when they start their northern migration. Carol Kaesuk Yoon

title: 'The Lessons of Terror'
description: Long before the deliberate military targeting of civilians as a method of affecting the political behavior of nations and leaders came to be called terrorism, the tactic had a host of other names. From the time of the Roman republic to the late eighteenth century, for example, the phrase that was most often used was destructive war. The Romans themselves often used the phrase punitive war, although strictly speaking punitive expeditions and raids were only a part of destructive war. For while many Roman military campaigns were indeed undertaken as punishment for treachery or rebellion, other destructive actions sprang out of the simple desire to impress newly conquered peoples with the fearsome might of Rome, and thereby (or so it was hoped) undercut any support for indigenous leaders. In addition, there was a pressing need to allow the famous Roman legions, who were infamously underpaid, to plunder and rape as a reward for their almost inhuman steadiness in the heat of battle. The example of Rome incorporates nearly every possible permutation of warfare against civilians. In this as in so many things, antiquity’s greatest state provided a remarkably complete set of precedents for many later Western republics and empires.

title: The Ottoman of Workout Gear

Gymphiles have fallen upon a new, futuristic-looking exercise accessory: the Bosu Balance Trainer ($129.95 from www.bosu.com), a rubber dome resembling a big medicine ball cut in half. Beginners can place it flat side down and balance on it for lunges, squats and push-ups. The idea is that staying steady on the squishy dome develops stability and strength. Advanced athletes (like the United States Olympic ski and snowboard teams) place it rounded side down and clench their core muscles even tighter to stay on top. Crunch Fitness introduced the country's first Bosu boot-camp classes at its 38th Street gym last month, and members of the buff and belly-ring set have been fighting for spots ($24 for a guest pass). title: Taking the Gold For Heady Style
description: The last time -- an American president was caught on camera with a young woman in a beret, it was a scandal. This time, it's a fashion trend. The hottest souvenir at the Winter Games is the official United States Olympic team berets, made by Roots, a Toronto-based outfitter to Canadian preppies. The berets, navy blue and red trimmed, started flying out of Roots stores after the opening ceremonies, when President Bush was surrounded by beret-topped members of the team. The company reports that the hats sold out, at $19.95, by the end of the next day, and daily shipments have been selling out within the hour, not only at the two stores in Salt Lake City, but also at the Roots in SoHo and Beverly Hills. Outside Olympic events, bidders have offered to buy the berets off lucky wearers' heads for $60 each. Roots executives say they are selling about 10,000 a day, and wearers include not only Olympic athletes and spectators, but also Rosie O'Donnell, who donned one on her show last week. American Olympic officials contacted Roots after the Games in Nagano, Japan, four years ago, when the Canadian team scored style points with its red Roots poor-boy caps. ''I think its 9/11, the mood of the country, the way the team looked opening night,'' said Michael Budman, one of two American expatriates who started Roots in 1973. ''Something happened for the 72 million people that watched. Everyone wanted to be a part of it.'' KATE ZERNIKE

description: An 11-year-old boy who had been stabbed repeatedly was found on the the roof of a Brooklyn apartment building last night, the police said. His attacker had already fled the scene and remained at large early today.

title: Buying In to the Company School
description: An elementary school on a block of boarded-up houses here offers a glimpse of how Edison Schools Inc. would remake many of America's classrooms. Its experience is perhaps of most immediate interest to parents and teachers in Philadelphia, which is expected soon to surrender dozens of its worst schools as part of the nation's largest experiment in educational privatization.

title: Celebrity, Then Oblivion: History Is Fickle
description: EVEN the most talented artists tend to vanish from history when their temperaments don't match the mood of the times. History, which prefers linear narratives, has a difficult time with artists who zigged while others zagged. Take the case of Cosm Tura (1433-95), who was the star performer at the cosmopolitan court of the ruling Este family of Ferrara, Italy, in his day. By 1550, when Giorgio Vasari published ''Lives of the Artists,'' a famous Who's Who of Italian art, Tura had already sunk into obscurity, meriting only a few dismissive lines.

title: When the People Took Back the Schools
description: ANNA RIVERA couldn't make it to the recent book party at Judson Memorial Church in Greenwich Village, a party celebrating the story of the East Harlem Block Schools. But her heart was there. Like the dozens of former teachers, administrators and students who did attend, Ms. Rivera praised what happened in 1965, when a group of poor parents in East Harlem started schools in which the parents controlled hiring, firing and lesson plans.

title: Boating in the Netherlands
description: Families with a sense of adventure and good boating skills can save from 10 to 15 percent on self-skippered cabin cruisers in the Netherlands, a country with lots of canals and other inland waterways. Crown Blue Line will take 15 percent off their rates on its five-passenger Princess Shebas and 10 percent off all other craft for reservations made by March 3; discounts are valid all year. And another 5 percent will be taken off if a trip begins on a Monday. With the discounts, renting the five-passenger boat could cost as little as $875 a week, depending on the season. Information: (888) 355-9491 or www.crownblueline.com .

description: Fordham Prep of the Bronx, led by Conrad Dalton, won the boys' team title in the 74th annual Catholic High Schools Athletic Association indoor championship yesterday for the first time in its more than 100-year history. Sacred Heart of Hempstead, N.Y., won the girls' crown for the first time.

description: SINCE it was commissioned by President George Washington in 1796, the business end of the Montauk Lighthouse has repeatedly been adapted to technological improvements. From the original whale oil lamps to kerosene to the electric lanterns first installed in 1938, it beamed brighter and farther with each change.

description: SUFFERING insult on top of injury, millions of investors are facing hefty tax bills for the second consecutive year on mutual fund holdings that have slumped in value. Few funds, no matter how poor their performance, failed to distribute capital gains, which are taxable to shareholders even if automatically reinvested.

description: AFRICA, whatever it is, is everywhere. It's far more than just a continent. It's a global diaspora, an international culture and a metaphor with fantastical associations for the West: gold, savages, ''darkest,'' ''deepest,'' liberation, devastation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHUTE, YURA SOPHIE
description: CHUTE-Yura Sophie. Wife of the late A. Lionel Chute and daughter of the late Ignas & Laura Slapelis, died in her home in Washington, New Hampshire on February 13, 2002. She was born in Kaunas, Lithuania in 1927, and emigrated to the United States following Lithuania's extended occupation by the Soviet Union. Yura was an accomplished classical pianist who had performed for large audiences in Lithuania, Austria, Germany, Italy and the United States. Her instructors included the celebrated pianists Rudolph Ganz and Claudio Arrau. After living in New York City for more than 25 years, Yura moved to New Hampshire in 1981, where she enjoyed gardening, reading, writing & teaching piano. She is survived by four children: Laura, Celeste, Lionel Jr. and Yvette. Yura will be sorely missed by all who knew her.

title: CRIME
description: Despite its sluggish start and bloated length, John Katzenbach's psychological thriller THE ANALYST (Ballantine, $25) redeems itself through the sheer sadism of its premise. On his 53rd birthday, a stodgy Manhattan psychoanalyst named Frederick Starks is given a life-or-death challenge by a cunning psychopath calling himself Rumplestiltskin. Starks has 15 days to identify his tormentor and the source of his grievance, or else commit suicide -- unless he is willing to have some blameless relative die in his stead. Being a sporting kind of guy, Mr. R. offers his victim the dubious assistance of encoded clues and two untrustworthy guides, one of whom calls herself Virgil and presents herself in the buff. But the shrink is no match for his persecutor, and he is soon stripped of his assets and professionally discredited.

title: TRANSACTIONS

title: February 10-16: SPORTS; SILVER TO GOLD
description: It has never happened before: to resolve the scandal overwhelming the 19th Winter Olympics, a second gold medal was awarded. The scandal, of course, was the 5-4 judges' vote that initially gave the gold to the Russian pairs skating team of Anton Sikharulidze and Yelena Berezhnaya, even though the Canadian duo of David Pelletier and Jamie Sal appeared to have outperformed them. Second-guessing engulfed the Games until the International Skating Union, in a late-night emergency meeting, upgraded the Canadians' medal -- and suspended a French judge for not coming forward to report that she had been pressured to vote for the Russians.

An eminent scholar, with numerous publications in Russian, French and English, he was buried at the Holy Trinity Monastery, Jordanville, N.Y. Survived by his wife of 60 years, his son Michael and his family, Professor Obolensky will be sorely missed. May he rest in peace. Helene, Michael, Dimitri, Nicholas, Natasha

title: A Blueprint for a New Beginning in the Mideast

Such efforts are not likely to succeed, and even if it were possible to manage the violence for a time, the world needs something more. The United States has a responsibility to aim higher.

description: ONE of the upsides in the Enron collapse is that investors have been awakened from their perilous dream state, brought on by the beautiful stock market bubble of the late 1990's. Before Enron, investors believed every utterance from corporate executives, Wall Street analysts and prestigious accounting firms. Now all of these players are viewed, justifiably, with more of a gimlet eye.

title: Commercial Property/Manhattan Retail Space; Banks From Outside the City Are Opening Branches
description: LED by a group of feisty banks, the retail sector of the real estate market in Manhattan is beginning to stir once again, after a period of near-paralysis after Sept. 11, brokers specializing in this sector of the market report. The bankruptcy of several store chains and cutbacks by others are also returning retail space to the market and providing opportunities for companies seeking to enter or expand in New York.

description: FOR better or worse, a bipartisan consensus has emerged in the Bush administration and Congress alike that the United States can no longer tolerate an Iraqi regime led by Saddam Hussein. Former Vice President Al Gore, for example, told the Council on Foreign Relations last week, ''Failure cannot be an option, which means that we must be prepared to go the limit.''

title: F.Y.I.
description: It Happened on Ice

title: The Nation; On Television, Funny Is Money
description: THE record-breaking deal that NBC signed last week to keep its biggest hit show is proof: ''Funny is money.''

title: Ship of Dreams
description: IN order to begin to look for the fortune in lost Revolutionary War gold that is said to lie at the bottom of the East River, one must first get to the river. On the back streets of Hunts Point in the Bronx, the water is almost a fiction, a gray and ghostly shimmer barely visible past the hulking warehouses and factories that have colonized the waterfront: a New York Post printing plant, a Con Ed plant, and, as announced by a putrescent gust, a waste transfer station.

description: HOMER AVILA and EDISSA WEEKS  "Advantage Danceworks" with a debut performance of a ballet by Alonzo King. Cunningham Studio, 55 Bethune St. (212-924-0077) Thur., Fri., 8; Sat., next Sun., 8.

title: Suffolk Home Buyers May Get Tax Relief
description: First-time buyers of new homes would be exempt from a portion of county property taxes for five years under a bill approved last week by the Suffolk County Legislature.

title: Broadway Baby
description: O.K., so they no longer send telegrams on opening night, but the theater is still the most glamorous act in town. Rachel Weisz got a taste of it firsthand when she starred in Neil LaBute's play 'The Shape of Things,' soon to be a glamorous motion picture. Here, she plays the part of Leading Lady.

title: For One Day, Disney Is Coming to Hartford
description: COULD it really be true that when you wish upon a star, or in the case of Hartford simply label yourself New England's rising star, dreams come true?

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Real Estate page last Sunday about expansion plans of the Maryland Institute College of Art in Baltimore misidentified the architect for the conversion of a former hospital into student housing. The architect is DRBrasher Inc., not Crozier Associates.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Fieldston; A Leafy Enclave in the Hills of the Bronx
description: ENTERING Fieldston, a woodsy enclave in the northwest Bronx, is like following Alice down her rabbit hole. In this world, streets defy the city grid, following the natural contours of rock outcroppings and hillside. Tudor mansions, Dutch colonials and Mediterranean bungalows cozy into the landscape, sometimes squarely facing the street and occasionally tucked in sideways. Trees here are treated like treasures, kept alive at almost any cost and, in one case, even allowed to grow through a slate-roofed cottage.

title: Hi, Old Friend. Help Me Get a Job Like Yours.
description: THE class was called New Communication Technologies, and it was a requirement for me and other students in the radio-television department at Ithaca College about 10 years ago. The assignment was to write a paper on brand-new technologies. Since the eight-track tape was no longer a big deal and the CD-ROM was not yet mainstream, I chose the colorization of film, which was somewhat controversial at the time.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to sales agreement.

title: Greenburgh Set to Acquire Former Unification Property
description: As part of a continuing effort to maintain green space within the town's borders, the Greenburgh's Town Board has unanimously approved a $3 million expenditure toward the purchase of 199 acres that are currently part of the Unification Church property in Tarrytown.

title: His Eye on the Yankees, Piazza Assesses the New Mets
description: Mike Piazza had been in spring training with the Mets for about an hour today when he playfully griped that he might have to pay $2 more a month on his cable television bill to watch Yankee games. Piazza, who makes $13 million a year to play in his own televised games, was obviously not worried about the extra charge. But he moaned anyway.

title: Italian Food in Informal Tarrytown Setting
description: ALTHOUGH neoned pizza places and spaghetti joints now dot Tarrytown's business streets, Lago di Como since 1986 has been just about the only place in town for diners craving Italian cuisine in gentle, polished, yet informal surroundings.

title: A Summer of Fun At Nearby Camps
description: ALTHOUGH most overnight camps are up north in Maine or New Hampshire, Connecticut boasts some interesting day camps and programs. Want to join the circus? Learn to care for animals abandoned in the wild? Or, just play in mud up to your ankles? You can, and the action is close to home.

title: When Push Comes to Shove, Only Some Tax Cuts Add Up
description: A month ago, Gov. James E. McGreevey tried to shake off doubts about whether he could carry off his campaign promise not to raise taxes. What he meant, in a ''clarification'' that sounded artful but still in the realm of the possible, was that he would leave sales and income taxes alone.

title: The Palestinian Conversation
description: I was shocked to see a Hamas leader referred to as ''the Mr. Rogers of Hamas.'' (''Won't you be my neighbor?'') And as a New Yorker, I was offended by the ''sitcom'' scene with the Gaza City family, some of whose members were ''snickering'' about the World Trade Center bombings.

title: February 10-16: NATIONAL; WHO'S WHO
description: There seem to be two New York City mayors, and one is having all the fun. As Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, facing a $4.7 billion budget gap, was proposing to cut nearly every city agency, suspend some recycling and charge tolls on the East River bridges, former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was in London being knighted for his handling of the Sept. 11 aftermath. Jennifer Steinhauer

title: JERSEY FOOTLIGHTS
description: Transformed by Prehistory

title: Booklet Continues Run for Respect and Toward Kentucky
description: Booklet passed another challenge today in his unlikely bid for serious recognition as a top 3-year-old.

title: Pipeline May Skirt Pine Barrens' Core
description: UNDER pressure from state and local government officials and environmentalists, the Islander East Pipeline Company agreed last week to consider alternates for the route of its proposed natural gas pipeline to avoid destroying core areas of the 100,000-acre pine barrens state preserve in Suffolk County.

title: Once Upon a Mattress
description: A queen-size bed may sound roomy, but when it is shared by a couple married for 40 years, the fit can be tight. Such a bed becomes a place where thoughts -- on love, negotiating a long partnership, motherhood, staying faithful -- and memories flow powerfully. Mimi Schwartz, a professor at Richard Stockton College and a Princeton resident, has written down those bed thoughts in 34 essays that make up ''Thoughts From a Queen-Sized Bed'' ($22) a book just published by the University of Nebraska Press. Subjects range from Ms. Schwartz's cooking for her husband (he is a professor at Princeton) before she leaves for a conference, to dealing with a mastectomy. This being New Jersey, there are stories about driving, most notably one describing a long drive to Cape Cod, replete with arguments over who forgot the map, and other tension. As couples surely know, a car is roughly the same size as a queen-sized bed.

title: No Pay, Long Hours but, Now, Glory
description: GROWING up, Henry J. Pinto Jr. wanted to be just like the volunteer firefighters on his East Meadow block. Armed with garden hoses, he and his neighborhood playmates formed bucket brigades and practiced dousing imaginary blazes.

title: Vanishing Acts
description: I've seen ghosts. Really, I have. Just this week, staring back at me from my new Powerbook titanium laptop. They came to me in a bundle of seven. Seven little e-mail messages, sent from an address I didn't know, the sender a person I'd never met. Each addressed with a single word subject: ''Weisz.'' The attachments were stunning, little cocktails of frozen black and white or color. There was Sir Ian McKellen at Sardi's, staring off into space with only the hint of a whimsical smile. A gaggle of chorus members from ''42nd Street'' surround Rachel Weisz in another, and in still others, she is a solitary figure, an impossibly glamorous creature. And then the ghosts begin to appear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOLIDGE, MARTHA (MUFFY) HENDERSON
description: COOLIDGE-Martha (Muffy) Henderson. Of Cambridge, Massachusetts, 77. Died on February 11, after a long illness. The widow of Harold Jefferson Coolidge, she is survived by her sister-in-law, Maia Henderson, her cousin, Theodore Conant, many Coolidge relatives and dear friends. A memorial service will be held on March 23, at noon in Harvard's Memorial Church. Donations may be made to The Squam Lake Natural Science Center, P.O. Box 173, Holderness, N.H. 03145.

title: The Trouble With Self-Esteem
description: Lauren Slater accurately predicts that the psychotherapy industry ''would take a huge hit were self-esteem to be re-examined'' and perhaps replaced by an emphasis on self-control. But would only psychotherapists suffer in such a new world?

title: R. M. Hare, British Philosopher, Dies at 82; Looked for Logic in Morals
description: R.M. Hare, a moral philosopher who wrestled ethical questions out of the murky realm of emotion and into the hard-edged arena of logic, died on Jan. 29 in his home in Ewelme, England. He was 82.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, CHARLES MYER
description: MILLER-Charles Myer. Born April 25, 1919 in Springfield, Massachusetts. Mr. Miller, a decorated Navy veteran in World War II and recent resident of Charlottesville, Virginia, died in Charlottesville on Friday, February 8, following heart surgery and a stroke. He was 82. Mr. Miller grew up in Springfield, Massachusetts. He attended Wesleyan University and received a Bachelor of Arts degree in 1947. His education at Wesleyan was interrupted by military service during World War II. He served in the United States Navy as executive officer (second in command) of the USS LCI 366. After graduating from Wesleyan, Mr. Miller received an MBA degree from Harvard Business School in 1949. He then began a long, successful career in the manufacturing industry, which eventually led him to southern California. He worked for Standard Products Company; United Carr Fastener Company; & the Monadnock Division of TRW, Inc. In 1979, Mr. Miller purchased Monadnock from TRW and created The Monadnock Company, where he served as president until his retirement in 1988. Mr. Miller was married for 35 years to Thalia Lucy Carter, formerly of Cleveland, Ohio, and mother of Meredith and Laurie. He was an avid golfer and served as president of Yorba Linda Country Club and Hacienda Golf Club in southern California. At Hacienda, he served as general chairman of the Scotty McGregor Guest Tournament for nine years. For many years, Mr. Miller enjoyed yearly gatherings with his Harvard classmates at The Greenbrier Resort in West Virginia. In 2000, he moved to Charlottesville, Virginia to be closer to his two daughters on the east coast. In Charlottesville, he pursued his interest in bridge and played several times a week. He was a member of the American Contract Bridge League and held 35 points. He also pursued his interest in architecture (he held an Associate of Arts degree) by serving as chairman of the Architectural Review Board of the Forest Lakes Community Association. Mr. Miller is survived by his two daughters, Meredith Miller of New York City, & Laurie Miller and her husband William Gregory Grymes of Barboursville, Virginia; his former wife Thalia C. Miller of La Quinta, California; and his two brothers, Norman and David L. Miller of New York City. A private memorial service will be held in New York City in April. The family suggests that memorial contributions be made to an educational institution.

The news on the radio throughout the fall and early winter was of Taliban retreats and food-relief plans and celebrations in cities released from oppression. Dr. Inamori, 70, who founded and ran the Kyocera Corporation and the DDI Corporation, retired five years ago to become a Buddhist monk. He said the deals and accounting issues that brought down Enron ''show how much we have lost moral standards,'' adding that ''we need to reawaken business leaders to the importance to do the right thing, even in the pursuit of profit.''

title: 'The Future of Life'
description: The totality of life, known as the biosphere to scientists and creation to theologians, is a membrane of organisms wrapped around Earth so thin it cannot be seen edgewise from a space shuttle, yet so internally complex that most species composing it remain undiscovered. The membrane is seamless. From Everest's peak to the floor of the Mariana Trench, creatures of one kind or another inhabit virtually every square inch of the planetary surface. They obey the fundamental principle of biological geography, that wherever there is liquid water, organic molecules, and an energy source, there is life. Given the near-universality of organic materials and energy of some kind or other, water is the deciding element on planet Earth. It may be no more than a transient film on grains of sand, it may never see sunlight, it may be boiling hot or supercooled, but there will be some kind of organism living in or upon it. Even if nothing alive is visible to the naked eye, single cells of microorganisms will be growing and reproducing there, or at least dormant and awaiting the arrival of liquid water to kick them back into activity.

title: A Specter Stalks the Victorian Novel
description: Jasper Fforde's first novel, THE EYRE AFFAIR (Viking, $23.95), is a spirited sendup of genre fiction -- it's part hard-boiled mystery, part time-machine caper -- that features a sassy, well-read ''Special Operative in literary detection'' named Thursday Next, who will put you more in mind of Bridget Jones than Miss Marple. This may sound like Douglas Adams territory, and indeed it is; Fforde has written a pop science fiction novel with brains and sass. ''The Eyre Affair'' is ostensibly set in 1985, but we're thrust into a world where revisionists have proved history to be malleable: the Crimean War rages on into its 131st year, Wales is a Soviet Republic, and England is beholden to Goliath, a multimedia corporation. Most important, literature is nearly the stuff of religion, and a savage extortionist named Acheron Hades is Britain's No. 1 heretic, reviled for wreaking havoc with the great novels of the Victorian era. Most recently, he's kidnapped and murdered Mr. Quaverley, an inconsequential character he extracts from Dickens's original manuscript of ''Martin Chuzzlewit.'' Enter Thursday, a book cop of sorts with a rogue time-warp-cop for a father, a novelist ex-boyfriend and an Uncle Mycroft, the inventor of something called the ''Prose Portal.'' When Hades uses Mycroft's literary time machine to abduct Jane Eyre, Thursday embarks on a rescue mission that puts her at risk of being trapped forever inside the world of Bront's masterpiece. Fforde delivers almost every sentence with a sly wink, and he's got an easy way with wordplay, trivia and inside jokes. ''The Eyre Affair'' can be too clever by half, and fiction like this is certainly an acquired taste, but Fforde's verve is rarely less than infectious. Kera Bolonik

With a quick shift of her left hip, Schreckenbach sent Dunn thumping into the boards and sprawling onto the ice of the E Center earlier this week.
