description: A CONVENIENT SPY

title: Do Stock Options Buy Silence?
description: A QUESTION lingers as the Enron debacle unfolds: Why did so few of the company's 20,000 or so employees come forward to report that something was amiss? Granted, not everyone would have had access to information about lapses in accounting judgment or would know if decisions were made to mislead rank-and-file employees about the financial health of the company. But it's a safe bet that hundreds, perhaps thousands, of employees saw some red flags or had an inkling that something was awry. What went wrong?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STOKVIS, JOSEPH WILLIAM
description: STOKVIS-Joseph William. March 15, 1915 to February 15, 1999. Father, father-in-law and grandfather. Three years and we miss you and love you more than ever. All our love always, Irene, Paul & Jonathan Land

title: Feathers Are Flying, Literally, Over Poultry Slaughterhouses
description: It could be a scene from a madcap 1920's comedy: Renegade chickens escaping into people's apartments, feathers flying through the air. But Carroll Gardens residents are not amused by what they describe as an unbearable situation that falls through the cracks of the city agencies they have appealed to for help.

title: Business; Hounds and Foxes Match Wits in Pursuit of Hidden Assets
description: MOTOROLA and Nokia lent $3 billion to the Uzan family of Turkey over several years to create a wireless telecommunications system for that country. The companies say the Uzan family and its telecom company, Telsim, did spend some of the money building a system -- but then refused to repay the loan.

title: NON-FIRING OFFENSE
description: The state Supreme Court ruled unanimously last week that public employees guilty of petty offenses should not be forced to forfeit their jobs. The decision came from the case of James Flagg, 62, a 29-year Newark sanitation employee fired after being convicted of illegally dumping constructing debris, something his supervisor instructed him to do. David Beckerman, Mr. Flaggs's lawyer, said the decision should allow his client to reclaim his job and pension and would help public employees in similar situations.

title: Deanna Leslie, Peter Kelly
description: Deanna Lynn Leslie, a daughter of Mary Lou and Douglas D. Leslie of Madison, Wis., was married yesterday to Peter George Kelly, the son of Catherine Maura Kelly and Ralph L. Kelly of Jacksonville, Fla. The Rev. Bartholomew Daly performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Peace Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan.

title: Fury Aside, Russian Skaters See Upside
description: In the hours after the International Olympic Committee and the International Skating Union announced that the Canadian team would be sharing the gold medal with the Russian pairs team in figure skating, there was outrage in Russia, as commentators and officials condemned the decision as a shameful display. But here, at a mansion dubbed Russia House, there was a more pragmatic attitude Friday night.

title: Valid Approaches
description: To the Editor:

title: The Trends That Just Blew In
description: PEOPLE like me who love fashion are meteorologists at heart -- poor paradoxical creatures always trying to get a fix on the flux, besotted with the dynamics of change. We watch trends building, breaking and dissipating like weather fronts. We see thunderclaps in a hat, or lightning in a shoe. One of the great secrets of the fashion business is that most of the interesting weather doesn't come from the runway. It comes from ''out there'' somewhere in the ether.

title: A Teacher, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Bracing, Nutty And Italian
description: Fish dishes are enhanced by Cima's 2000 Candia dei Colli Apuani, an aromatic, salty white with bracing lemony acidity made from vermentino grapes in northwest Tuscany, near the Ligurian Sea. To appreciate its lightness and nuttiness, open it young, chill it moderately and swish it 30 seconds on your palate. It's $18.13 at Italian Wine Merchants, 108 East 16th Street (Union Square). HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: Footlights
description: Cushions Are the Chairs

title: The Future of the C.I.A.
description: Washington can be a funny town. As the House and Senate are gearing up to hold joint hearings on the intelligence community's response to terrorism in recent years, including the failure to detect or prevent the terror attacks of Sept. 11, lawmakers are showering the Central Intelligence Agency and other spy organizations with money. Indeed, these are boom times for the C.I.A. The agency's overseas operations are expanding, its budget is growing, and its director, George Tenet, is spending more time with the president at the White House and Camp David than any spy chief since the C.I.A. was created more than a half-century ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOFFE, RUTH
description: JOFFE-Ruth. Beloved mother and grandmother to the Gerson family, James, Barbara, Fred and Simon. Mother of the late Raymond E. Gerson and cherished aunt, sister and sister-in-law to the Greilsheimer, Stein and Sambol families.

title: Those Stock Options Are Still Flowing
description: To the Editor:

title: Sam Who?
description: The men's fedora, worn at a rakish angle, the snap and roll of the brim full of swagger, has been discovered by a new generation that recognizes its power of expression. It's all in how you wear it, as evidenced by many of the guests attending last week's fall fashion shows in New York. With the high cost of clothing and the conformity of style, the spotlight has been on accessories -- hats, handbags and shoes. The revived fedora and other styles with the same jaunty spirit are seen on both men and women. Some changed their hats each day during the shows.

title: Enron Had More Than One Way To Disguise Rapid Rise in Debt
description: Along with the debt it spirited away in partnerships, Enron hid billions in loans in plain sight.

title: The Palestinian Conversation
description: 'A Palestinian Conversation''? You mean a ''Palestinian Love Song.''

title: Rise in Mergers Anticipated
description: Last year was slow for mergers and acquisitions. But 60 percent of senior executives at large multinational companies anticipate an increase in activity in the next 12 months, and 90 percent predict a resurgence in the next two years, according to a recent survey of 171 executives by PricewaterhouseCoopers.

title: Uneasy Times: A Buddhist Lens
description: To the Editor:

title: Inspired by Dance, A Circus Is Writing The Poetry of Flight
description: EVERY soul is a circus,'' Martha Graham, earth mother of modern dance, declared in the title of one of her pieces. The high-flying Nijinsky, having crashed into the hell of madness, proclaimed himself the clown of God. Why marvel, then, when actual circuses aspire to higher spheres?

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-15

title: Investing; A Foul-Weather Bet Has a Following
description: COAL-MINING stocks are paying a price for their emergence from obscurity a year ago. They became an unlikely glamour sector during the harsh winter of 2001 and California's energy crisis, only to plummet when the weather improved and fears of imminent power shortages subsided.

title: Chekhovian Angst Amid Real Trees
description: ONE of the things Michael Cacoyannis missed most in stage productions of ''The Cherry Orchard'' was the cherry orchard. Its fate is at the heartrending core of Chekhov's masterpiece. But an indoor set usually does little more than provide the barest representation of the trees that fall under the ax of the bourgeois speculator who buys the estate out from under the deluded, land-poor heroine, Madame Ranevskaya.

title: The Young and the Dangerous
description: THE recent events at the Pleasantville Cottage School, in which seven teenage girls were arrested for attacking a counselor, reminded me of just how dangerous and violent this kind of work can be. I have worked with at-risk youth for the past 21 years. When you do this type of work for any length of time, it is almost impossible not to experience violence or the immediate threat of it.

title: Executive Life; An Evolution in a Best-Supporting Role
description: DAVID PEASBACK remembers the day when Amy Bragg, his executive assistant for more than five years, left the company to marry and start a family.

title: February 10-16: NATIONAL; WHAT LAY KNEW, AND WHEN
description: Kenneth L. Lay, the former chairman and chief executive of Enron, sold $100 million in Enron stock last year, including $70 million he got from sales to the company that were only just disclosed. A Lay spokeswoman said the ''vast majority'' of the money went to repay debts. Of the sales, $26 million came after Mr. Lay received a letter from Sherron S. Watkins, an Enron executive, presciently warning that the company might be destroyed by an accounting scandal. In Congressional testimony, Ms. Watkins said she thought Mr. Lay took so little action after her alert because he had been duped by other Enron executives and ''did not understand the gravity of the situation the company was in.'' Floyd Norris

title: Witt's Vote
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: LIPA's Tree Cutting Stirs Suffolk Protest
description: AN AGGRESSIVE pruning program in January by the Long Island Power Authority left a scenic stretch of the Montauk Highway in Water Mill and Bridgehampton partly denuded. Now, a task force of local officials and residents has been set up, and last week the work began on a restoration plan for 1.8 miles of right of way.

title: Bush on Way to Asia, After Repeating Demand on North Korea
description: President Bush stopped off here today to visit American troops and raise money for the state's Republican Party, after the White House released an interview in which Mr. Bush strongly repeated a demand that North Koreans pull back their conventional arms from their border with South Korea.

title: 'Shouting Fire'
description: To the Editor:

title: Gene Therapy Gives Heart Patients Hope
description: ''I WANTED anything that would make me feel better and that would avoid surgery or complications like a stroke,'' said Dr. Jacqueline Rose Hott, a Great Neck resident and a former dean of Adelphi University's School of Nursing.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BEISERMAN, HERMAN
description: BEISERMAN-Herman. Funeral February 19th, 2002, at 12:15 at Boulevard Riverside Chapels, 1895 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn, between Avenues K & L.

title: The Trouble With Self-Esteem
description: 'Maybe thinking highly of yourself is the real problem,'' Lauren Slater says. I think perhaps the real problem has to do not so much with how we see ourselves but with how we see others. Our worth, our dignity, comes not from setting ourselves apart as ''special'' but in recognizing that it is only when we are in relationships with others that our lives have real significance.

title: Deregulation By Landlords Is Increasing, Study Says
description: When, after a bitter battle, the New York Legislature extended the state's rent regulation laws in 1997, it was largely regarded as a victory for tenants.

title: February 10-16: NATIONAL; HARD VOTE ON SOFT MONEY
description: The House voted to ban ''soft money,'' the large unregulated contributions from corporations, unions and the rich, and to prohibit so-called issue ads if they mention a candidate's name close to election day. Late in the 17-hour debate, one weary Republican opponent slipped and said, ''All we want is a level paying field.'' But 41 Republicans deserted their leaders and the bill passed, 240 to 191. The Senate, which passed a similar bill last March, is likely but not certain to approve this version. Adam Clymer

title: A Little Deli Goes the Way Of So Many In the City
description: Awni Samba always felt he belonged on the northwest corner of West 106th Street and Broadway, where for 13 years he has kept a modest store called Samba's Deli and Grocery. He sells milk and potato chips and makes 200 deliveries a week to nearby apartments. Schoolchildren cluster outside his door most afternoons.

title: At Troubled Bargemusic, Discord Amid the Sonatas
description: Bargemusic, the floating chamber music spot at Fulton Ferry Landing, has for two decades been an idyllic spot where you could listen to intimate sonatas resonate off the cherrywood interior while waves lapped against the outer walls of the docked boat.

title: February 10-16; COMING UP
description: President Bush, on his tour of Asia, will spend Monday in Japan, Tuesday in South Korea and Wednesday in China. He returns to Washington on Friday. Congress is in recess for the Presidents' Day holiday.

title: 'The Jazz Bird'
description: Already, the telephone in the study was ringing. They had just come in the front door from a glorious month at the family cottage at Murray Bay, Quebec: the clear frigid water with its walleye and bass and muskie, the autumn trees, the brisk air, the children. Ten years they'd been married, Charlie and Eleanor Taft, but instead of a second honeymoon they'd chosen to take the children along, and it had so been the right thing.

title: Reader, I Dumped Him
description: ME TIMES THREE

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Friday, 3,062 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11, not including 19 hijackers.

title: Warm Colors That Ward Off Winter's Chill
description: AT this time of year, the only thing standing between me and lunacy is the mandevilla. Deprived of its steady supply of bright red blossoms, I might resort to sowing poppy seeds in the cracks of my floorboards or some other desperate scheme to relieve winter's doldrums with a dose of floral color.

title: Promise Fulfilled, Karsay Is Back in New York
description: Steve Karsay was ready for his final start of 1993. At 21 years old, he had skipped Class AAA and made it to the majors, pitching effectively over 49 innings. The problem was that one more inning would disqualify him for rookie of the year consideration the next season. Tony La Russa, his manager with the Oakland Athletics, told Karsay to shut it down.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUTTMAN, BLANCHE
description: GUTTMAN-Blanche. On February 14. She would have been 101 on February 17. Beloved wife of the late Paul Guttman. Loving mother of LeRoy and Joan, Joyce and Al. Cherished grandmother of Howard and Grace, Beth and Gary, Alan and Michelle, Steven and Phil, Richard and Erica, Lori and Vett. Adoring great-grandmother of Maverick and Montana; Zachary, Satchel, Noah and Jacob; Jared and Zach; and Jennifer and Amy; and loving nieces and nephews. She touched so many lives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TELCHIN, JOSEPH G.
description: TELCHIN-Joseph G. On February 5, 2002, age 92. Retired attorney in NY, Washington DC and Sarasota, FL. Also a founder and general counsel of Countrywide and Statewide Insurance Companies. He is survived by his daughter, Esther Baker Fassler of Sarasota, his granddaughter, Andrea Glantz Kas, and great-granddaughter, Griffin Elizabeth Kas of Michigan. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Hospice of SW Florida.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STUBBLEFIELD, ROBERT LEE
description: STUBBLEFIELD-Robert Lee. Silver Hill Hospital mourns the death of Dr. Robert Lee Stubblefield, a former Medical Director, who died January 18 in Houston, Texas at age 82. Richard J. Frances, M.D., President & CEO, and the Silver Hill Board of Directors

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 3 about the film ''Scotland, PA.,'' misstated the year and type of release for ''Oxygen,'' directed by a producer of ''Scotland, PA.'' And a correction in this space last week misstated the producer's given name. ''Oxygen'' was released in 1999, not 1991, and was made as a theatrical movie, not for television; the producer is Richard Shepard, not Roger.

title: February 10-16: SCIENCE; KITTY, KITTY
description: Scientists in Texas have cloned a cat, opening the door to the commercial replication of cherished pets. Supported by a company, Genetic Savings and Clone, they began by trying to clone dogs but added cats to the list after market research showed that cat owners were just as affluent and passionate. Success came after 87 cloning attempts, so as the scientists work to streamline the process, the company says it will accept cloning applications only from selected cat owners who agree to bear part of the undisclosed, but undoubtedly hefty, research costs. The first clone, a calico, was named cc, for carbon copy -- but in a demonstration of the limits of cloning it looks a little different than the genetically identical original. Gina Kolata

title: Minaya Has Big Job In Restocking Expos
description: Four men who were not general managers when last season ended are general managers today. A fifth is the general manager of a different team than he was a year ago. Two other general managers were not general managers at this time last year. One who is a general manager today may not be by the end of spring training, if the incoming owners decide to make a change.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOLL, LAWRENCE
description: TOLL-Lawrence, 42. Son of Olga and the late Wilbur. Died peacefully at his home in Houston, TX. Lawrence leaves two brothers, Stanley and David. He was a graduate of the Scarsdale School System and attended American University.

title: Venture Capitalists Dust Off Their Checkbooks
description: JAMES CATACOSINOS remembers the days in the late 90's when an exuberantly self-confident 20-something entrepreneur armed with little more than a business plan could pick and choose from an field of deep-pocketed potential investors, returning phone calls -- or not -- from people ready to sink millions into what was often little more than an unproven idea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCLOVE, LOUISE HERZOG
description: SCLOVE-Louise Herzog. Died in Amherst at 92. Formerly of NYC and Westport CT. Died February 8 in the Center for Extended Care in Amherst, MA. Born February 3, 1910 in New Rochelle, NY, she was the daughter of the late Joseph L. and Eleanor (Guiterman) Herzog. Louise Sclove graduated from Wellesley College, class of 1931, where she formed lifelong friendships, and earned a graduate teaching certificate from Bank Street College of Education in New York City. During her varied professional life, Mrs. Sclove worked as a nursery school teacher, designer of retail displays for children's toys, public opinion poll administrator, mutual fund salesperson, publisher of a professional psychology journal, publicist, public education advocate, Jewish oral historian, and enthusiastic community and social activist. She enjoyed outdoor activities ranging from downhill skiing, for which she was an East Coast Pioneer, to tennis, golf, sailing, ice skating, hiking and camping, as well as international travel, chess and bridge. She read continuously. She continued cross-country skiing, swimming, skating (and unfortunately driving) into her eighties. She was fascinated by children, the younger the better. Her cute sense of humor stayed with her to the end. Her husband, Abraham Bernard Sclove, died in 1954. She is survived by her sons Richard E. Sclove of Amherst and Edward M. Dreyfus of Mar del Plata, Argentina and by four grandchildren. A private memorial service will be held in Amherst for family, friends, and her devoted following of younger people whom she counseled, supported and loved.

title: Superintendent for a Day
description: RARELY a month goes by that Dr. Maryann Peifly does not get a telephone call or two asking if she is available to work as an interim superintendent.

title: A Show That Dares To Span a Continent
description: ''THE Short Century: Independence and Liberation Movements in Africa, 1944-1994'' at the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center in Long Island City, Queens, is one of those rare occasions when the usually hyperbolic term ''landmark exhibition'' is not an overstatement.

title: The World; A Question for Afghanistan: Who's the Proxy Here?
description: IN the wake of the swift collapse of Afghanistan's Taliban regime, there was considerable triumphant talk in Washington that a new form of warfare had been developed: massive bombing guided by small cadres of Special Operations troops on the ground and, best of all, the use of what were called proxy forces to do the actual fighting.

title: Defining the Enemy
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Jan. 27 with an article about snowboarders misidentified the one with the U.S.S.A. logo on his jacket. He was Rahm Klampert; Ross Powers was at his left.

title: For 'Startup.com' Partners, Life Becomes Reconciliation.com
description: The sequel could be ''shutdown.com'' or, in the parlance of financial analysts, ''wind-down.com.''

title: As National Oil Giant Struggles, Mexico Agonizes Over Opening It to Foreign Ventures
description: Mexico's state-run energy company, Pemex, certainly looks like a world-class operation. Its rigs pump billions of dollars of crude from the Gulf of Mexico, spewing flame and smoke into the sky, as helicopters shuttle skilled engineers from this port to some of the world's richest oil fields.

title: Some Olympic Flames Burn Brighter
description: MY husband is at the Olympics, enjoying the most glamorous part of his job as a radio correspondent. He has also been to Sydney, Nagano and Atlanta. Glamorous, yes. But his first day in Salt Lake City, they fitted him for a gas mask.

title: Where Wild Dogs Roam, Worry Stalks the Streets
description: One of four wild dogs that sneaked into the Staten Island Zoo on Christmas Eve and killed 10 animals has been caught. But the three other dogs are still on the loose, spreading fear through the neighborhood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASHINSKY, SHELDON
description: BASHINSKY-Sheldon. Future Tire Company mourns the loss of Sheldon Bashinsky, a conscientious coworker and good friend, his sweet smile and uplifting spirit will remain in our hearts.

title: Maps Gain in Clarity But Lose a Bit of Art
description: EVERY major city has its essential map. Locals and tourists in Paris rely on the little red Paris par Arrondissement. In Los Angeles, no one leaves the garage without a Thomas Guide in the glove compartment. New York City is now served by a whole shelf of way-finding tools. But for 60 years, for better or for worse, the city's map of record has been the Five Borough Atlas produced by the Hagstrom Map Company of Maspeth, Queens.

title: Pitfalls in Picking Chimney Crews
description: WHEN an 82-year-old woman got a phone call in September promoting a chimney cleaning for $49, she accepted the offer. But what seemed like a good deal went sour when the three-man crew from Unique Chimney Company based in Patchogue, cautioned that she needed to replace her chimney liner immediately. Although that additional work was priced at $3,000, she gave them the go-ahead to install the liner that day. Her neighbors, seeing that the crew left after only about an hour on a job that typically takes five hours, advised her to stop payment on the check and to file a complaint with the Westchester County Department of Consumer Protection. Unique, which did not return a reporter's phone calls, initially threatened to contact the police if the woman did not pay. But after Consumer Protection investigated and held an informal hearing, Unique agreed to stop seeking payment.

title: Anne Bancroft Finds Her Own Way Back
description: IN the early 1960's, Anne Bancroft, Bronx born and raised, decided she simply had to play the part of the depressed English wife of a philandering screenwriter in a movie that was about to be made from a script by Harold Pinter. But the film's director, Jack Clayton, had serious objections. Even if she had just won an Oscar, portraying a passionate teacher of the blind in ''The Miracle Worker,'' Clayton did not think she projected the smoldering quality he was looking for.

title: Nothing Personal
description: Can anybody get into Harvard? If you're one of the thousands of students who have just completed the grueling college admissions process and are awaiting the results from selective universities, the answer is no, of course. But if you have been to the movies in the past few months, you might think anyone could. In ''Legally Blonde,'' Reese Witherspoon plays a ditzy sorority girl who lands at Harvard Law School thanks to a video rsum with generous footage of her in a bikini; in ''How High,'' Method Man and Redman play two small-time pot dealers who light up Cambridge; and in ''Orange County,'' a West Coast variation on the theme, a Stanford reject shows up on campus to plead his case.

title: Uneasy Times: A Buddhist Lens
description: To the Editor:

title: When French Fries Go Over the Rainbow
description: Perhaps the best way to create brand loyalty among customers is to start young. Few companies may understand that better than H. J. Heinz, which has a growing line of products geared toward young taste buds.

title: Kidd Not Touching Possible McDyess Deal
description: Jason Kidd had been given warnings about tampering from the National Basketball Association and a lecture on the same subject from Nets General Manager Rod Thorn. Although he spoke cautiously today, it was clear who would be on his mind Sunday when the Denver Nuggets arrived at the Meadowlands to play the Nets.

title: Some Quiet Political Voices in Enron's Backyard
description: They have been accused of robbing the bank. Of taking the lifeboats and leaving the women and children to drown. Of squandering the savings of mothers-in-law.

title: Ideas & Trends; Is Planned Obsolescence Obsolete?
description: THERE was a time not so long ago when planned obsolescence was a troubling ghost in the machine. In his 1959 book ''The Waste Makers,'' Vance Packard described engineers at General Electric who intentionally shortened the life of light bulbs, and automotive engineers who proposed limiting the lifespan of cars. Consumer advocates denounced what they saw as ethical lapses in business executives and engineers.

title: Uneasy Times: A Buddhist Lens
description: To the Editor:

title: Las Vegas Journal; Endless Vows on Valentine's Weekend
description: Michael Goolsby and Evelyn Muhammad of Fresno, Calif., pulled their silver Dodge Stratus up to a drive-through window and exchanged some words with Shawn Jewell. Not 10 minutes later, the couple's lives were irrevocably altered.

title: Correspondence/Urban Glory; New York and Bombay, Two Great Cities, Keep Faith With What Matters
description: NEW YORK, the place I came from six weeks ago, recently rediscovered, at terrible cost, some of the reasons cities are great. They are, as New York has showed, humanity's great reservoirs of kindness, civility and resilience. Only cities can turn ruin and death into a kind of collective grandeur.

title: An Irreverent Powerhouse From Harlem
description: AS he was filming the story of Adam Clayton Powell Jr., the flamboyant preacher-politician from Harlem, the director Dou McHenry asked himself this question: ''What was Powell's essential quality as he looked in the mirror?''

title: INSIDE
description: Daytona, a Year Later

title: The Might of the Mitfords
description: THE SISTERS

title: In America, Where Business Is King
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the lasting effects of Congressional investigations referred incorrectly to the House testimony of Jeffrey B. Skilling, a former chief executive of Enron. He said he had not known that partnerships with the company were improperly used to hide losses. He did not say he knew nothing about the partnerships.

title: Susan Fragnoli and David Sands
description: FOR Susan Fragnoli and David Sands, the timing of their introduction was as startling as tulips popping up in mid-January.

title: Christina Canellas, Steven D'Onofrio
description: Christina Daphne Canellas, a pastry chef, and Steven Jude D'Onofrio, an instructor of pastry chefs, were married yesterday at the Greek Orthodox Church of Our Saviour in Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Elias G. Villis performed the ceremony.

title: Ideas & Trends; Comets, Asteroids and Other Invaders From Outer Space
description: AT this moment, an asteroid two-thirds the length of the Titanic with the utilitarian name 2002 AT4 is barreling toward Earth. Fortunately, AT4, traveling at 14,000 miles an hour, will miss the planet by nearly six million miles. That's a close shave in astronomical terms, but still 25 times the distance between Earth and the Moon.

title: Latin Lovers
description: TARZAN'S TONSILLITIS

title: Rising Star Lands Near Leaders After Hot Start
description: Tiger Woods did not make an appearance this week, skipping the Nissan Open at the fabled Riviera Country Club for the first time since he became a professional in the summer of 1996. But Charles Howell III, the 22-year-old many have anointed as Woods's most formidable rival for the future, is here and in contention.

title: A Dream Team: Ice Cream and Sports
description: A HOCKEY game was on the television and the crowd at Last Licks here was hoisting a few -- ice cream sodas, that is. Described by its owners, Jon Deutsch and Brandon Steiner, as a ''sports bar for kids,'' this ice cream-cum-sports memorabilia shop in the Golden Horseshoe Shopping Center here has become a favorite destination for the under-18 crowd and their parents. Children from toddlers to teenagers gather around its tables (which are autographed by the likes of the New York Yankees manager Joe Torre and the shortstop Derek Jeter), eat ice cream, frozen yogurt and candy, visit -- everyone seems to know one another -- and watch the two television sets affixed to the walls, which are perpetually tuned to sports events and news.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALLANTINE, PERCY HARPER
description: BALLANTINE-Percy Harper. Age 87, of Oxford, MD (formerly of Andover, NJ), died of natural causes on February 11, 2002. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, Anne Brackenridge VanBlarcom, his children, Dr. Percy Ballantine II of Hanover, NH, Anne Piccone of Lakewood, CO, Andrew Ballantine of Bedminster, NJ, Karl Milbauer of Scottsdale, AZ, Sara Ryan of Easton, MD, Katherine Badman of Greenwich, CT, Elizabeth Overholser of Hong Kong, PRC, Grier Flinn of Wilmington, DE, and Mark Ballantine of Easton, MD, seventeen grandchildren and one great grandchild. He attended The Fessenden School (class of 1930), Hotchkiss School (class of 1933), Asheville School (class of 1933), and Cornell University (class of 1937). He was a Senior Vice President of Midlantic National Bank, a Mayor of Andover Township, a Director of The Sussex & Merchants National Bank and The New Jersey Herald, a Trustee of the Newton Memorial Hospital, and a Member of the Adirondack League Club, the Society of Colonial Wars and the Mayflower Society. He was the last surviving great grandchild of Peter Ballantine founder of P. Ballantine & Sons brewery, Newark, NJ. A private service will be held Saturday, February 16, 2002. Memorial gifts may be made to the Easton Memorial Hospital, Easton, MD, or the Newark Museum, Newark, NJ.

title: NBC: Low Marks
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Flair and Imagination in Rockville Centre
description: THERE'LL be stars in your eyes at Veritage. Bold New Age ones are painted on the walls and clusters of shimmering, five-pointed paper lanterns hang from the high ceiling. Candied star fruit, star anise ice cream and free star-shaped cookies adorn elaborate presentations. There's an assertive gold star at the top of the changing menu and squeeze-bottle star squiggles decorate plates. But the three biggest stars are Frank and Claudia Purita, the husband and wife chefs who own this inventive spot at 160 North Village Avenue (516-678-9868) in Rockville Centre, and their creative executive chef, Michael Meehan.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 5 of Arts & Leisure today, and a theater listing on Page 44 of the section, about Anne Bancroft's return to the stage in ''Occupant'' at the Signature Theater, include outdated references to its opening. After the section had gone to press, the producers delayed the opening, scheduled for next Sunday, because Ms. Bancroft had bronchitis. She was replaced by her understudy, Kathleen Butler, for preview performances through last night and perhaps longer. A new date has not been announced.

title: Private Sector; General's New Fleet of Six-Seaters
description: Gen. Charles A. Horner, the retired commander of the allied air forces in the Persian Gulf war, knows a thing or two about airplanes. Now he's applying that expertise to a flying taxi service.

title: Paints With Wolves
description: LA TOUR DREAMS

title: Enrollment Is Up Sharply At CUNY, To 197,089
description: A weaker economy, higher enrollment standards and even the attack on the World Trade Center have helped drive total enrollment at the City University of New York up 3.5 percent this semester over the same semester last year, officials said. The increase is partly a result of a 23 percent jump in the number of freshmen at the university's senior colleges.

title: The Center of Their Universe
description: There are times when being a journalist is just an amazing occupation. You get taken places that other people just cannot go. I think we would all admit this. The job is the ultimate backstage pass.

title: Elizabeth Berberian, Joseph Oliveri

title: Correction
description: Areview on Jan. 27 about ''Kiss and Make-Up,'' by Gene Simmons, misstated the rankings of the Beatles and the band Kiss among those who have achieved gold records, which are awarded to records that sell 500,000 copies. Though the Beatles have more gold records than any other group, according to the figures of the Recording Industry Association of America, they rank behind at least one individual performer -- Elvis Presley. Kiss ranks behind several individuals and one other group -- the Rolling Stones; it is not second only to the Beatles.

title: Hull's Late Goal Gives United States a Tie With Russia
description: It might be time for hockey fans to stop talking about the past history of the United States-Russia hockey rivalry and start thinking about the near future. The two nations played tonight in their first Olympics meeting on United States ice since the Americans beat the Soviet Union and went on to win the gold medal in the ''Miracle on Ice'' in 1980.

title: Wanted: Poster With a Bit of Goat
description: 'The poster is a play's coming-attraction trailer -- but you don't want imagery that tells you what happens in the play,'' says Drew Hodges, the creative director of the Manhattan-based graphic-design and advertising company SpotCo. Hodges and his company usually design posters in-house, but for Edward Albee's new play, ''The Goat or Who Is Sylvia?'' -- which just began previews and opens March 10 -- they also enlisted outside artists and then passed along ideas to the three lead producers. The play, about an architect with a secret that threatens to wreck his life, was difficult to capture in one image. Here's what some of those involved had to say about the making of the poster.

title: The Palestinian Conversation
description: Your article offers a new term, ''sufferness,'' to describe the capacity to endure in the face of hardship. But this sufferness is simply another manifestation of the Palestinians' embrace of victimhood. It substitutes for accepting responsibility for the damage that their misguided leadership has done to them. The word for the Palestinian situation has to be ''needlessness.''

title: BackTalk; Peek Behind Curtain At Skaters' Routines
description: Judges at the figure skating events have the best seats in the house. They clearly see, or choose not to see, as was witnessed in the pairs event, the most blatant and the most minute technical details of an athletic performance. What they do not witness, however, is the intense preparation that nearly all skaters routinely execute behind the curtain, in the corridors and empty spaces of the arena. This is an event in itself. And it will be repeated on Tuesday when the women begin the short program.

title: Dessert Equivalent Of a Fashion Classic
description: To sweeten the temperaments -- of those jaded tent-hoppers at New York's Fashion Week in Bryant Park, restaurants around New York are introducing the latest in confectionary fashion: the little black dessert. Using ingredients like black sesame paste, licorice and poppy seeds, these new desserts are equally about flavor and style. At Citarella on the Avenue of the Americas at 49th Street, a black sesame pudding (left, $8) is served in a clear glass bowl on a square white plate that is bathed in black sesame seeds: the effect is pure Calvin Klein in an enticing architectural way. District, at the Muse Hotel on West 46th Street, makes a black sesame seed pineapple upside-down cake ($7), while Tan Da on Park Avenue South (24th Street) has a black sticky-rice confection. And at Clove, the restaurant on 80th Street near Madison Avenue, deep-fried black squid-ink ravioli are stuffed with bananas and cinnamon and served with ice cream. ''Black is the universal color of fashion,'' said William Yosses, the pastry chef at Citarella. ''It has intrinsic allure in terms of mystery, seduction and romance. Black desserts are unique in that they must be both gastronomically and stylistically appealing -- because of this, they attract the attention of the chic yet adventurous diner.'' ELLEN TIEN

The winter season has been high-energy, and the troupe continues on a creative jag with resident choreographers and new talent emerging from company-sponsored workshops. Above all, the dancing looks recharged, especially from dancers who have overcome major injuries -- Alexandra Ansanelli, Darci Kistler and Nikolaj Hbbe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LLOYD, JAMES W.
description: LLOYD-James W. Age 61 of Darien, CT, on February 12, 2002 after a long illness. Born in Syracuse, NY, he graduated from Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Columbia Law School, and served as a Lieutenant in the U.S. Navy. He was Senior Counsel at the law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell, where he was a partner for 26 years. He was a Director of The Charles A. and Anne Morrow Lindbergh Foundation. His loving wife, Maureen B. Lloyd, survives him. Funeral services will be private. A memorial service will be held on a date to be announced. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Whittingham Cancer Center at Norwalk Hospital, 24 Stevens St., Norwalk, CT. 06856.

title: Solace Is the Order of Business At the Borough's Chaplain's Office
description: The man was bereft. After Sept. 11, he lost his job as a chef near ground zero. That, in turn, meant he could not pay his rent or send money back to his family in Mexico. So he sought out a clergyman, the Rev. Raymond Rivera, who counseled him, helped him find a new job and got him some relief money.

title: Guidebooks Deal With Sept. 11
description: THE consequences of Sept. 11, felt throughout the travel industry, extend to publishing as well. The creators of the Michelin Green Guide and the Mobil Travel Guide series, along with other publishers, had to quickly revamp their 2002 editions on New York to reflect a city whose social, financial and geographic landscape was violently altered. And with tight deadlines, the most extensive revisions will not be coming until next year; for example, neither guide mentions the observation platform for ground zero.

title: Judging Bush's $1.35 Trillion Bet
description: LAST year, President Bush won the political battle over taxes, signing into law a 10-year, $1.35 trillion tax cut that gradually reduces individual income tax rates, doubles the credit for children, expands retirement and education savings programs and repeals the estate tax in the year 2010.

description: BUDGETING for spring-break travel or that mid-winter holiday? Here's one option. A family of four from Southern California can enjoy a seven-night stay at the spiffy Portofino Bay Resort Hotel in the Universal Studios theme park near Orlando, Fla. The price: $3,072.37, including air fare and a mid-sized car.

title: Into Thin Air
description: On the evening of Sept. 10, negotiators for the C.E.O. of United Airlines, James Goodwin, huddled in Washington with union officials representing United's 30,000 baggage handlers, customer-service representatives and reservation agents. They were putting the finishing touches on an agreement for a hefty double-digit wage increase, and Goodwin, a tall, likable West Virginian who had been with the company 34 years, was waiting for a call to give his O.K. It didn't matter that United, which had lost $605 million in the first half of 2001, was in a financial tailspin: when airline unions are due for a raise, they get one. If you don't understand why, then you don't understand the airline business.

title: Habitats/New Jersey; From Hudson River View To a Hudson River View
description: ON Sept. 11, Nicole and Marcus Morton had to move out of their apartment on Chambers Street overlooking the Hudson River. Although they were able to move back three weeks later, they no longer wanted to live in the neighborhood. Mrs. Morton worried about the quality of the air; she was also concerned that she would never stop thinking about what she had seen that day as she stood by the river watching the towers burn and then fall.

description: Abortion in Africa remains steeped in taboo and against the law throughout most of the continent. But it is widely practiced outside of the confines of modern medicine.

description: HAVE you ever stopped at a red light at an intersection where there is hardly ever any traffic and wondered why on earth there is a signal there at all? title: Disclosing Co-op Election Results

The vote was conducted by the managing agent and the counting was overseen by inspectors appointed by the board. The four winners were all incumbent board members, and the board refused to give the number of votes that each received on the ground that the feelings of losers might be hurt. Does this violate the New York State Business Corporation Law? . . . S. Halwyn Beale, Bronxville, N.Y.

He was 86 and lived on the Upper East Side, where he also had his practice.

title: Snowy Profits
description: In our ski town in northern Vermont, many of us carry chains in our four-by-four pickups in the winter. If a local runs his car off the road, we pull him out free, but if a tourist gets stuck in the snow, we charge $20. (We can always tell the difference.) Our rationale: Tourists have more money than locals, and a tow-truck operator charges even more than us. Agreed? Michael Roche, Morrisville, Vt.

title: CABINET POSITIONS
description: Governor McGreevey completed his cabinet appointments last week by naming James P. Fox as transportation commissioner and Gwendolyn L. Harris as human services commissioner. Mr. Fox was chief of staff to Senator Robert Torricelli and Ms. Harris is chief of staff for Mayor Douglas H. Palmer of Trenton. She will oversee the the largest department in state government with about 18,000 employees. Both nominations must be approved by the Senate. Jo Piazza

Kazimierz Kord will conduct Chopin's Piano Concerto No. 1 with Ingrid Fliter as soloist, Tchaikovsky's Symphony No. 6 and Wojciech Kilar's ''Orawa'' -- not Chopin's Piano Concerto No. 2 and Tchaikovsky's Symphony No. 5.

title: TRANTINO RELEASED
description: Thomas Trantino, who was New Jersey's longest-serving inmate, was released on parole last week. Originally sentenced to death for the 1963 killing of two police officers in Lodi, Mr. Trantino had his sentence was changed to life in prison after New Jersey abolished the death penalty in 1972. Released on his 64th birthday, Mr. Trantino had spent more than 38 years in prison, the last year in a halfway house. Although he has applied to live in Staten Island, he is living in a transitional house in Collingwood, based on an order from the state parole board that he live in Camden County. Jill P. Capuzzo

title: Both His Hobby and His Job Can Be Filed Under 'M'
description: TED LEE, owner of Lee's Funeral Home on Fisher Avenue here, calls himself the mortician magician, and the name says it all. He began practicing magic 30 years ago when he was looking for a hobby to distract him from the rigors of his profession.

title: The Composer
description: To the Editor:

title: Whose Hand Holds the Laser?
description: A MANHATTAN woman of 29, who regularly visited a SoHo spa for chemical peels to keep her face acne-free, was used to mild flaking afterward. The treatment, using glycolic and salicylic acids, strips off a layer of skin. But a peel three months ago, the woman said, left her face so raw that it oozed blood for six days. Weeks later, she still looked as if she had windburn from skiing.

title: The Neediest Cases; Total for Neediest Fund Is a Record $9.8 Million
description: The most successful campaign for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has come to its official end. The annual appeal ended on Feb. 1, the books were closed Wednesday and all the money has been counted. The fund received $9,785,570 this season, nearly 22 percent more than was donated during the 2000-01 appeal, which raised $8,033,582, the previous record.

title: Ochowicz Follows Her Parents' Lead
description: KEARNS, Utah, Feb. 16 (AP)  Elli Ochowicz was born to be an Olympic speedskater. Or perhaps a top cyclist. Maybe she could be both. It's certainly in her genes.

description: DEBRA WINGER and her husband, Arliss Howard, are accustomed to questions about why Ms. Winger left the movie business six years ago. And they have a good answer as to how Mr. Howard, the star and director of Ms. Winger's new comeback film, ''Big Bad Love,'' lured his wife back into acting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BILLINGSLEY, FRANCES LONG WORTH
description: BILLINGSLEY - Frances Long worth. Age 89, died peacefully on February 14, 2002 in Somers, NY. Resident of Somers for 57 years, founder of Frances Billingsley Realty, a founder and president of the Somers Historical Society, trustee of the Westchester Historical Society, delegate to UNICEF executive board for 20 years. Executive director of the American Indian Hall of Fame, Anadarko, OK, which was founded by her husband, Logan. Loving mother to Jerome, Robert and Francis and generous grandmother of Katherine, Hillary, Jennifer and Alyssa. Visiting Saturday, 2-5 PM and Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, NY. Funeral Mass, Monday 1 PM, St. Mary's Church, Katonah. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Somers Historical Society, Attn: The Frances Fund, Town Hall, Somers, NY 10589.

title: Where Minimal and Maximal Meet
description: MORTON FELDMAN once described his Second String Quartet as a nightmare. That has certainly seemed to be true from the standpoint of the groups that have played it. In a splendid new recording by the Ives Ensemble on Hat Art, the piece is five hours long: 293 minutes, to be exact. If you lift your right arm into the position to hold a violin bow and imagine keeping it there for five hours, you will see the problem.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies last Sunday about the discovery of Asian longhorned beetles in two maple trees in Central Park included a parks official's erroneous reference to the removal of the trees. They were cut down this past Thursday, not earlier.

title: February 10-16; FRONT LINES
description: AFGHANISTAN -- Episodes of violence and chaos erupted in Kabul. In the most telling, the interim government's aviation and tourism minister was killed. Early accounts said he had been pulled from a plane at the airport and bludgeoned by hundreds of Muslim pilgrims enraged by a two-day delay in their departure for Mecca. But then Hamid Karzai, the government's leader, said the killing had been engineered by a group of senior officials, including his new intelligence chief: clear evidence that old ethnic and tribal enmities could remain powerful enough to destroy the fragile government.

title: A Pop Idol's Survival: Now She's Taking On America
description: WHEN Kylie Minogue was 11, she started acting on Australian television. By the time she was 18, she had a leading role in ''Neighbours,'' a soap opera whose success quickly made her a star in Britain and the most popular actress on Australian television.

title: Explanations From One Former Enron Official, Silence From Another
description: One talks, the other doesn't: The long-awaited testimony by Sherron S. Watkins provided the dramatic high point for the week in Enron news, while a hearing in which lawmakers pilloried a silent Kenneth L. Lay, the former chairman of the once-grand energy and trading giant, provided another. Meanwhile, ripples from the Enron mess washed through Washington.

title: A Faded City Brightens In Nicaragua
description: WHEN I lived in Nicaragua during the war years of the 1980's, I often lamented Granada's fate. Once the country's stately capital, it had fallen on hard times. Many of its aristocratic families had fled, and their grand colonial-style mansions were crumbling. Walking through the shabby streets and along the shore of nearby Lake Nicaragua, I thought that with a little money and ambition, this city could be returned to its glory.

title: A Cat's-Eye View Of Couture
description: ''Zat Cat!'' -- (Scholastic Press, $16.95), Chesley McLaren's new children's book, proves you're never too young to plunge into the world of haute couture. Rife with French phrases and places, the story follows a Parisian kitty who literally tears through the spring collections with unexpected results. Fashionettes will enjoy the fictional antics, while parents can search the illustrated pages for real-life arbiters of style like Anna Wintour, Andr Leon Talley and Karl Lagerfeld. Introduced in time for Fashion Week, ''Zat Cat!'' is being sold at Saks Fifth Avenue in a bright paper pocketbook. Apparently, reading is not only fundamental -- but it's also an excellent accessory. ELLEN TIEN

title: Donald Trump Gives Up On Two Golf Courses
description: This week, Donald J. Trump announced that he would cancel his plans to build two golf courses planned for the Westchester area. He dropped a proposed 155-acre golf course in Yorktown, and plans for a course on a 300-acre plot in Putnam Valley. Mr. Trump said that his other two golf course projects -- the Trump National Golf Club in Briarcliff Manor, and another planned for a 213-acre estate in Bedford -- would move forward.

title: Unplanned Legacy
description: There is no good way to start this story. A friend of mine killed himself on New Year's Eve, and the question on everybody's lips, the one right after ''How was your New Year's?'' is ''My God, what happened?'' Sometimes I just tell people that a friend passed away. The delicate treatment doesn't work, though, because everyone wants to know the details, or they assume it was a car crash in some far-off state or that I, at 28, have been hanging out with an aged friend who just happened to pass on, ever so gently, perhaps in a slumber lullabyed by me.

title: Camby Needs Time as Knicks Need Help
description: Marcus Camby showed up at the Knicks' practice today, offering all he could at this point: a smile and encouraging words. Camby looked much better than he did two weeks ago, when he tore a muscle in his right hip in Indiana. He can now dress himself, tie his shoelaces and even drive. But he is nowhere near being able to play.

title: Corrections
description: A review on Jan. 27 about ''Kiss and Make-Up,'' by Gene Simmons, misstated the rankings of the Beatles and the band Kiss among those who have achieved gold records, which are awarded to records that sell 500,000 copies. Though the Beatles have more gold records than any other group, according to the figures of the Recording Industry Association of America, they rank behind at least one individual performer -- Elvis Presley. Kiss ranks behind several individuals and one other group -- the Rolling Stones; it is not second only to the Beatles.

title: Local Hero
description: Before my family left for Rome, I did the math. Over 11 days, with a lunch and a light dinner, each of us could taste approximately 55 dishes. We could compare carciofi alla romana among restaurants, squeeze in a few visits to Giolitti, the famous gelateria, and stop in for pizza bianca at the Antico Forno in Campo dei Fiori. It was my grandmother's first trip to Italy, and she loves to eat. I wanted her palate to be enlightened.

description: CARS have taken the names of all sorts of places and things, but the Mazda MP3 is probably the first model to be named after a feature of its sound system.

title: The Medals Plaza Is the Hottest Place to Celebrate on a Cold Night

An octogenarian couple from Montana, married 48 years, laughed at the adolescents and their glazed looks, but then the couple began to bump and grind, their moves captured on the overhead video screen.

title: Political Briefing; Shadowy Coverage Of Pennsylvania Race
description: In Pennsylvania, the guy with the video camera who was constantly shadowing former Mayor Edward G. Rendell of Philadelphia had the look of a newsman. Nothing unusual there, considering that Mr. Rendell is in a tight battle with Auditor General Robert P. Casey Jr. for the Democratic nomination for governor. But which station?

title: Aamodt Makes a Precision Turn, Then Makes History
description: The last and most pivotal portion of today's men's Olympic super-G course was a snowy cliff called the Buffalo Jump. It is so named, the locals say, because the earliest hunters in this part of Utah would try to stampede buffalo over the precipice, knowing the terrain below the crag was so steep the buffalo would tumble several hundred yards, leaving the hunters a helpless bounty at the bottom.

title: The Trouble With Self-Esteem
description: Excessive self-esteem is a sort of drunkenness of the self. Self-control is our inner designated driver. When we silence it with an unrealistic high opinion of ourselves, somebody gets hurt. We ought to remember this when we are tempted to see in self-esteem a panacea for mental and social ills. Self-esteem, like self-expression, can be a very good thing. But it can also turn into self-indulgence and a delusional and dangerous sense of superior worth.

title: DataBank; Blue Chips Climb as Technology Slides
description: Blue-chip stocks advanced last week on a wave of optimism that the economy could be turning around, but technology stocks lost some ground.

title: Remembrance Of Flings Past
description: Just beyond the curtained and half-shuttered window of Edith Templeton's small flat, in the Italian Riviera town of Bordighera, lush flowers and palm trees flourish in an atmosphere of sunny off-season indolence. But inside her sitting room, conversation takes place at an intense emotional pitch. At 85, Templeton is tiny-boned and barely five feet tall, but there's nothing else delicate about her, beginning with the head-on stare she trains on me as I sit on her ancient moss-colored sofa. Her slightly bulging dark green eyes appear never to blink. Occasionally she'll adjust her hair or touch the small pearls at her throat, but she never shifts her gaze until she has finished what she intends to finish, leaning in so far that her head at times seems to hover several inches in front of her body. This comes across as a result less of age or of myopia than of a willful, avid nature, and while it adds to the impression she gives of intellectual vigor, it also increases your feeling of being pinned, helplessly, as you sit and chat with her.

You stagger a bit and then you see it, the 60-foot Ferris wheel that sweeps through all four levels of the store, a winking, blinking circus ride bolted into Manhattan bedrock and open all day long.

description: It's nice to know that if your political career gets unexpectedly interrupted by, say, an investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, there is another life to be had in rustic upstate New York.

I am not referring to airline tickets -- it will be a while before we can spring for such a luxury again -- but what may be the next best thing: several beige-and-brown boxes of the unique soap we had in our hotel room when we visited that French Polynesian island last year. Redolent of coconut and the tiare, a petite but potent Tahitian gardenia, it smells like nothing else on earth.

All were waiting to get into a free concert of 12-tone music, the last of six programs in the Focus Festival. Every year at Juilliard, the conductor Joel Sachs, an intrepid champion of contemporary music, presents a weeklong examination of some aspect of the field. The situation could have implications for Lee as well, because, as he understood it, the other scientist was caught doing something Lee himself had been busy at, providing unclassified documents to the government of Taiwan.

Johnson's Great Society, died Saturday at his home on the campus of Stanford University in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 89.

title: The Senate's Useful Farm Bill
description: Last year, for the first time in recent memory, there were serious efforts in Congress to make basic changes in the government's outdated, wasteful and discriminatory farm subsidy programs. These efforts fell short of meaningful reform. The House and the Senate have now passed differing farm bills that preserve many of the worst features of the old subsidies. Yet for a host of reasons the Senate bill is far superior. Since the country is going to get a farm bill anyway, we urge the Senate to stand firm in what are sure to be difficult negotiations aimed at reconciling the two versions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLE, DAVID AMBROSE
description: COLE-David Ambrose. Age 49. Died February 15 from complications of melanoma in Key Biscayne, FL. A graduate of the Delbarton School in Morristown, NJ, and Bowdoin College, he obtained a D. Phil. from Oxford University. A Senior Vice President with Foote Cone & Belding Latin America, David had enjoyed a long and successful career in advertising in Argentina, Venezuela, Mexico, and the US. He was a poet and a scholar, and participated as an actor and director in English language theater in Latin America. He loved good food, wine and cigars. He was the beloved husband of Moira Tamayo-Cole, and father of David Ashley (Dash) and Adrian Augustine. He is deeply mourned by his mother Nancy McManus Cole of Eliot, Maine (formerly of Mendham, NJ); his brothers Ashley Trimble Cole of Brooklyn, Christopher Cole of Portsmouth, NH; his sisters Wendy Donohue of Irvine, Cal., Nancy King of Farmingdale, NJ, and Alison Westfall of Washington, DC, as well as many nieces, nephews, and friends. His father, Ashley Cole, died in 1971, and a younger brother, Robert, died in 1962. A memorial Mass will be celebrated at St. Agnes Catholic Church, Key Biscayne, FL, on February 18, 2002. At David's request, donations in his memory may be made to: CATCO (Contemporary American Theater Company), 77 S. High St., 2d fl., Columbus, OH 43215, or to the American Civil Liberties Union

title: Reviving Korean Diplomacy

Yet as President Bush prepares to meet with President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea in Seoul this week, the two countries have developed sharply different strategies for dealing with Pyongyang. Mr. Kim has dedicated his presidency to building diplomatic links with the North. Mr. Bush has taken a decidedly harsher line and last month lumped North Korea with Iraq and Iran as part of an ''axis of evil'' against whose advanced weapons Washington might one day feel compelled to use pre-emptive military force.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARKHAM, MARGOT
description: BARKHAM-Margot. Died on February 12 in Sarasota. Survived by her sister Pauline Forbath of Philadelphia, her brother Physil Buirski of Hallandale and her brother Abe Buirski of London and her children Jennifer and Graham and her grandchildren Scott, Phoebe, Elliott and David. She was born on the Cape Flats in South Africa in 1909. Following her husband John Barkham, in 1946 she emigrated from South Africa to New York with two young children and her mother. Although fiercely proud of her American citizenship since 1951, she remained connected to her motherland all her adult life through a business in Pretoria which she operated with her brother and her concern for South Africa's political future as a democratic state. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARRAND, VERA N., NEE POPOV
description: FARRAND-Vera N., nee Popov, 95, Of Pondfield Rd. in Bronxville, NY, beloved wife of the late Clair L. Farrand, died at home February 13th. Born in Riga, Latvia, to Russian parents, she and her family fled German occupation during World War I and settled in Tallinn, Estonia. She attended a Germanlanguage secondary school and entered the University of Tartu at 16. She married Mihkel Nommik, in the mid 1920's. She survived both the Soviet and Nazi occupations of Estonia during World War II, and fled the advancing Red Army with Nommik to Sweden in 1944. She was widowed shortly thereafter. She met Clair Farrand, an American traveling on business, in Stockholm in 1964. They married, a second, very romantic marriage for both, and settled in Bronxville, NY and Palm Springs, CA. Mrs. Farrand was an international tennis champion, winning singles, doubles, and mixed doubles national titles in Estonia in 1930 and holding top ten ranking in Sweden until she was over 50. Among her doubles partners were Lennart Bergelin, Bjorn Borg's coach, and Vytas Gerulaitis, Sr., father of the American tennis star. She continued to play tennis regularly into her 80's. She is survived by her stepson, John L. Farrand, SJ, of New York, NY; nine grandchildren, & 15 great-grandchildren. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at St. Joseph's Church, 15 Cedar Street, Bronxville, NY, 10:00 AM Saturday, February 23rd. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to Tolstoy Farm Foundation, 104 Lake Road, Valley Cottage, New York 10989.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOBDELL, FRANCIS
description: LOBDELL-Francis. Of Shelburne, Vermont, 80, Died on Feb. 16, 2002, of renal failure. He is survived by his wife, Adair, by his 3 children, Peter Tillotson Lobdell, of Amherst, MA., Katherine Lobdell Norris of Southborough, MA., and Michael Childs Lobdell of New Canaan, CT, his sister, Brenda Rudner of Dorset, VT., and his brother, Leighton Lobdell of Ponte Vedra, FL. Also surviving members of the family include five stepchildren, nine grandchildren and two great grandchildren. For 32 years, Francis worked at John Wiley and Sons, New York, NY, a leading college textbook publisher where he was Vice President, Chief Financial Officer and Director. He retired in 1978. He was President of the Board of Trustees of Rumson Country Day School, Rumson, NJ from 1962 to 1968. Board member of the Rumson Country Club, President and Trustee of Ekwanok Country Club, in Manchester, VT. US Seniors' Golf Assoc, Emeritus, Member of the New York Yacht Club. He was born in New York, NY on Aug. 24, 1921, the son of Ruth and Edward Dean Adams, a descendant of John Adams, second President of the United States. He was a member of the founding class of Rumson Country Day School, Rumson, NJ. He attended St. Mark's School in Southborough, MA., and he graduated from Yale University in 1944. Francis received an advanced management degree from Harvard University in 1956. He married Jane Childs (deceased) on August 8, 1944 of Monmouth County, NJ. He remarried Adair Gould Gans on Feb. 24, 1979. Francis served as second lieutenant in the US Armed Forces Air Corps flying a P-47 in World War II. Francis was a member of Trinity Church of Shelburne, and Landgrove Church, Landgrove, VT. Memorial Service will be held at 11:00 o'clock at the Trinity Church in Shelburne, VT. on Friday, Feb. 22, 2002. An additional service will be held during the summer in Landgrove, VT. In lieu of flowers, donations to Circle of Care, PO Box 477, Hincsburg, VT. 05461 or Hospice at Visiting Nurse Assoc, 1110 Prim Road, Colchester, VT. 05446 will be deeply appreciated.

description: PUGH-F.C. Richmond, 82. Died Saturday, February 16, 2002. He was born in Salt Lake City, Utah, on March 27, 1919, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Walter N. Pugh. He attended Wasatch Elementary School, East High School, and the University of Utah where he received a B.A. Degree. Following college, he enlisted in the Army in order to serve in WWII achieving the rank of Captain by the time he was discharged. After the war, he earned his M.B.A. at Harvard University. He was employed by Mobile Oil Corporation for 27 years in their Marketing Department, first in Los Angeles and later in New York City. He retired in 1974 and moved to Chatham Township, NJ. An avid fly fisherman, he was a member of The Flat Rock Club of Mack's Inn, Idaho, where he fished annually for over 50 years. His devotion to fishing encompassed a reverence for the outdoors and the beauty of the wild. Rich was a jokester of the first order, and a gamesman of no small skill. He will finally be remembered for his quick wit and love of chess, handcarved wooden jigsaw puzzles and The New York Times crossword puzzles. Rich was also no stranger to the good life, enjoying a fine meal, a good beer, his ubiquitous cigar and a clever story. He is survived by his sister and her husband, Muriel and George Baker, also of Chatham Township, NJ, and two nieces, Melody G. Baker of Basking Ridge, NJ, and Melissa B. Connelly of Salt Lake City, Utah, as well as five grandnieces and nephews. No services are planned as this is what Rich wanted. Those who wish may make a donation in his memory to the Chatham Public Library, 214 Main Street, Chatham, N.J., 07928.

title: Tougher Policies on Refugees
description: Today 35 million people worldwide are fleeing war or persecution. The last time the number was this high, World War II was raging. Yet many countries are hardening their refugee policies. The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees must cut its services -- which already fall far short of the need -- by 10 percent because contributions from the European Union have dropped. Even as wealthy countries cut back their financing for food, health and education in refugee camps, they are also taking in fewer people. Nations like the United States, Denmark and Australia, historically open to the persecuted, are now closing the doors.

title: Review/Fashion; For Fall, Chaste Dresses and Uniforms of No Known Land
description: The space alien aspect of fashion goes well beyond galactic shoulders and small heads. It embodies the sensation that fashion is spinning not out of control -- the economy cooled that -- but without any gravitational pull. To sit at the Jeremy Scott show on Friday night, the last of the fall 2002 collections, was to sense this vacuum. Here was inventiveness run amok: party dresses conceived as Manhattan skyscrapers, with windows and cornices picked out in sequins. One laughed. One grinned. But when the music stopped and the audience gathered up its goodies bags (yum, makeup), you knew that these clothes would change nothing.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Call for End To Car Restriction
description: The chairman of the City Council's Finance Committee called yesterday for lifting the ban on single-occupancy vehicles on many city bridges and tunnels weekday mornings. The chairman, David Weprin, who represents Hollis, Queens, cited a study commissioned by business and labor leaders that says the ban hurts the economy. The ban is from 6 to 10 a.m. weekdays on the Brooklyn, Manhattan and Queensboro Bridges, along with the Holland, Lincoln and Queens-Midtown Tunnels. The Transportation Department says the ban, put in place after Sept. 11, is needed to improve traffic. Mass-transit advocates praised the ban, citing another study that found that gridlock hurts business.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Fugitive Priest Arraigned
description: A Roman Catholic priest sought in California as a fugitive from justice on child molestation charges was arraigned in Superior Court in Hartford yesterday after being arrested on Saturday at a Hartford behavioral treatment center. The 35-year-old priest, whose name is reported as Oskar Pelaez by the Hartford police and as Oscar Alberto Pelaez by the police in California, served at Sacred Heart Church in Turlock, Calif. He was charged with being a fugitive from justice and held in $500,000 bail. He agreed to be extradited to California. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: Sylvia Rivera, 50, Figure in Birth of the Gay Liberation Movement
description: Sylvia Rivera, who helped lead the charge -- in makeup and full voice -- at the birth of the modern gay liberation movement, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Manhattan Hospital. She was 50 and lived in Brooklyn.

title: A Cheese Maker Taps A Vein of Blue In the Rockies
description: An indication of just how far American cheese makers have come in making blue-veined varieties can be found at the Bingham Hill Cheese Company in Fort Collins, Colo.

description: THERE is a spot in the lower jaw where the back of the front teeth and the gum merge. Only by tucking the tip of my tongue into that spot can I achieve the proper inflection to pronounce Tuk Tuk, the name of an appealing new Thai restaurant on Smith Street in Brooklyn.

title: 9% of Staff Is Laid Off at Kirshenbaum Bond
description: The Kirshenbaum Bond Creative Network in New York is laying off 21 employees, or 9 percent of its staff of 223. Erin Johnson, a spokeswoman for Kirshenbaum Bond, confirmed a report of the cutbacks in the online edition of Advertising Age. Most of the layoffs are coming at the New York advertising agency, Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners, she said, after the loss of the Revlon ( news/quote ) account.

title: A Matter of Church and State
description: The Supreme Court hears arguments today in Zelman v. Simmons-Harris, one of the most important church-state cases in the last decade. At issue is Cleveland's school voucher program, which subsidizes students' tuition at religious schools. The Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals rightly found that the program violated the First Amendment. If its defenders succeed in overturning that decision, it would mark a serious retreat from this nation's historic commitment to maintaining a wall between government and religion.

title: APPLIED DIGITAL SAYS BROAD RESTRUCTURING IS COMPLETE
description: Applied Digital Solutions Inc., the largest maker of implantable devices to track livestock and pets, said yesterday that it had reduced its work force by about 73 percent and sold seven units to repay debt and become profitable this year. The company, which had 1,374 employees in August, expects to have fewer than 200 workers when it completes an acquisition of Medical Advisory Systems by March 18. Its chief executive, Richard Sullivan, said the company was also within 10 days of completing an agreement to restructure its $53.4 million revolving credit line. The company is based in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Apples, Oranges And Eighth Graders
description: REPORTS on school performance usually compare test scores of the same grade from one year to the next. For example, most states ask schools to report whether this year's eighth grade did better than last year's. A new federal law says that every state must track progress by comparing the same grades year after year.

title: Use of Film By Milosevic Draws Protest
description: An American filmmaker has protested the unauthorized use of film from his documentary, ''Yugoslavia: The Avoidable War,'' which was presented on Monday by Slobodan Milosevic, Yugoslavia's former president, as evidence in his defense at The Hague.

description: Just because Wayne Gretzky says Europeans hate Canadian hockey, that does not mean it is so, said the man in charge of the Olympic hockey tournament.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAEBECK, WILLIAM JR., D.D.S.
description: RAEBECK-William Jr., D.D.S., Age 78, of Naples, FL, died Friday, February 15, 2002. Formerly of Bronxville, NY, he has been a permanent resident of Naples for six years. He was a member of Reformed Church of Bronxville. Dr. Raebeck was a graduate of Brooklyn Friends School, Brooklyn, NY, in 1941, Colgate University in 1945 and Columbia University Dental School in 1947. He was named Associate Clinical Professor of Dentistry at Columbia in 1947 and was Editor of the dental school newspaper, Dental Columbian, in 1947. He married Doris Oetjen of New York, NY, on June 10, 1949. He served in the U.S. Army Dental Corp. from 1951-53, stationed in Germany. After service with the U.S. Army, he joined a dental practice in Bronxville, NY, and later bought the dental practice, which became known as William Raebeck, Jr. & Asociates. He was a member of Phi Gamma Delta fraternity, Psi Omega Dental Fraternity, the William Jarvie Society for Dental Research and the American Dental Society. Dr. Raebeck was Past Chairman of the Bronxville Adult School, Bronxville, NY, and Past Governor and member of the Bronxville Field Club, Bronxville, NY, Siwanoy Country Club and was active in the Colgate University Alumni Association. He was an avid squash and tennis player, competing in the United States Senior Men's Squash Championships. He was also an avid amateur photographer. Dr. Raebeck was a pioneer and active in researching the effects of, and a remedy for, osteoporosis in women. He published several articles on this subject in dental publications, as well as The New York Times and other newspapers. He is survived by his wife, Doris Raebeck; two children, Elizabeth (Alan) Raebeck Hall of Nashville, TN, and Malcolm (Martha) Mallery, D.D.S. of Danville, VA; three grandchildren, Justin, Anna and Cooper Hall, and a sister, Arleen Wahn of Wellesley, MA. He was preceded in death by his son, William Raebeck III. A Memorial Service will be held in Bronxville at a later date. Contributions in his memory are suggested to the Reformed Church of Bronxville, P.O. Box 397, Bronxville, NY 10708 or to Adoption and Children's Services of Family Service of Westchester Co., One Summit Ave., White Plains, NY 10606. For information, call Fuller Funeral Home, Naples, FL, 941-592-1611.

title: Biathlon Relay Victory Gives Norwegian Fourth Gold
description: SOLDIER HOLLOW, Utah, Feb. 20  Ole Einar Bjoerndalen, the Norwegian biathlete, won his fourth gold medal of the 2002 Winter Olympics today, proving that skis, a gun and a vacuum cleaner make for a great champion.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Nissan Expects Record Profits
description: The Nissan Motor Company, Japan's third-largest carmaker, will post record profits for the second straight year, according to its president, Carlos Ghosn. The company, which was near bankruptcy in 1999 before Renault took a one-third stake, said last May that it expected to earn 330 billion yen ($2.5 billion) in the fiscal year ending this March, just below the record profit produced in fiscal year 2000. Mr. Ghosn, however, said he expected to beat that mark this year. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRIGERE, PAULINE
description: TRIGERE-Pauline. Always ready with a ''bon mot'', ready to party, inpeccably chic, Pauline Trigere was incomparable-bigger than life. We mourn her passing with her sons Jean-Pierre and Philippe, her daughter-in-law Melanie and granddaughter Karen. Jacky and Jeff Clyman, Karen and Cooke Rand

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHARP, SAMUEL RICHARD
description: SHARP-Samuel Richard. Feb. 15, 2002. For our very dear, beloved son, brother, uncle and devoted father, Samuel Richard Sharp, Esq., 1959-2002, 42 years old, who died unexpectedly. Your life has enriched & helped so many others to realize their true potential. You truly were gifted with a love for life and with the ability to show your love in great acts of kindness and generosity of spirit. You were such a giving, selfless person, only caring for the happiness of others. You were an optimist always, no matter how big the obstacles. You were such a hard worker, a perfectionist and success in everything you set out to do. In sports & your practice you were brilliant and tenacious, yet everyone you touched could not help but love you dearly as a friend. In your short life and tragic unexpected death, you left very precious memories for all who loved you and knew your love. Most of all your great sense of humor, brilliant mind and empathy for others will be sorely missed by family and friends who were so close to you. We will find it difficult to recover from such a loss & your profound influence upon us. We will truly feel your loving presence each day for the rest of our lives. All our love always, a brokenhearted mother and father Rachel and Martin Sharp, his son Thomas Sharp, who had such a very special, loving bond with his father, his devoted brothers and sistersin-law Robert and Ramy Sharp and Michael and Denise Sharp, and nephews and nieces Kyle, Dylan, Emily, Olivia, Jason and Sydney. Funeral service Sunday, February 17, 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, New York City.

description: In a plan approved by President Bush, a temporary wartime effort to shape information and coordinate messages will be expanded into a permanent office of global diplomacy, intended to spread a positive image of the United States.

description: In an audacious attack on a West Bank outpost on Tuesday night, Palestinian gunmen killed six Israeli soldiers and then escaped, stunning an army that had already been reeling from the deaths of seven soldiers since Thursday.

description: Stocks fell yesterday, led by a broad-based decline in technology issues as worries about corporate accounting practices continued to roil the market.

description: The United States Supreme Court heard arguments today in what could be a landmark case about whether the government should grant school vouchers for education at religious schools.

title: Justices to Review Copyright Extension
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the 1998 law that extended the duration of existing copyrights by 20 years was constitutional. The court's action took the world of copyright holders and users by surprise and held the potential of producing the most important copyright case in decades.

title: Curacao Resort
description: Improving your surroundings is one major motivation for taking a vacation, and a resort in Curacao is helping guests do so even after they arrive. The all-inclusive Sunset Waters Beach Resort is offering a free room upgrade through Dec. 19. By confirming a standard garden-view room, guests will be put up in a superior ocean-view room. The standard-view rooms are $125 a night through April 15, and $110 a person a night April 16 to Dec. 19. That includes all meals, unlimited drinks, nonmotorized water sports and nightly entertainment. Children under 12 stay free when sharing a room with their parents (four people to a room). Information: (305) 477-8636 or www.sunsetwaters.com .

description: A rebellion of the bored is being waged on the streets and highways of Saudi Arabia.
