description: Conservatives in the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) defeated an effort yesterday by four New York City churches to allow the ordination of gay men and lesbians nationwide.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: Denied A Last Wish
description: A convicted killer who asked to die in the electric chair to make a statement about capital punishment was executed by lethal injection. John W. Byrd Jr., 38, who was sentenced to death for the 1983 murder of a store clerk, was the third person to be put to death by the state since 1963. The state last year banned the use of the electric chair. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Moody's Warns About Brokerage Houses
description: Moody's Investors Service lowered the credit ratings of Japan's second- and third-largest brokers, Daiwa Securities and Nikko Cordial Securities, citing falling stock-trading volumes and growing costs brought on by the weak economy and deregulation. Daiwa's long-term debt ratings fell one notch, to Baa3, while Nikko's was lowered to Baa2. The outlook for Nomura Holdings, which includes the country's largest brokerage house, was lowered to negative. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: War's Deadly Reminders
Goldman Sachs Moves to Tighten Stock Analysts' Independence
description: Moving to address concerns about the independence of stock analysts, the Goldman Sachs Group said yesterday that it would break its research department out of its investment-banking operation and place it under two newly appointed managing directors.

description: The District of Columbia Boxing and Wrestling Commission voted today to grant Mike Tyson a boxing license, possibly setting the stage for a fight between him and another powerful but aging heavyweight, Lennox Lewis, here in June.

The returning cast members are Keith Nobbs (June), Armando Riesco (Dexter) and Isiah Whitlock Jr. (Joe). title: People
description: * Douglas B. Leeds, chairman and chief executive at the Thomson-Leeds Company, New York, an agency specializing in point-of-purchase advertising, is relinquishing his chief executive post to Vince Esposito, president. Mr. Leeds will serve as chairman through the end of this year. Michael Parkes, executive vice president, will succeed Mr. Esposito as president. Thomson-Leeds is owned by the Array Marketing Group.

title: PNC FINANCIAL REDUCES ITS 2001 EARNINGS BY $35 MILLION
description: The PNC Financial Services Group said yesterday that it reduced 2001 earnings by $35 million more after discovering it incorrectly accounted for the sale of its mortgage banking business last year. The Pittsburgh bank, which in January was forced by the Federal Reserve to cut 2001 net income by $155 million, said one entry of its $605 million residential mortgage business sale to Washington Mutual Inc. was accounted for as retained earnings rather than discontinued operations. PNC said the reduction would not hurt shareholders' equity. The company still expects 2002 profit to be about $4.60 a share. PNC's accountants, Deloitte & Touche, will review PNC's internal controls involving accounting and reporting processes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLANK, ADELE S.
description: BLANK-Adele S. On February 18, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Robert. Loving mother of Cecile Jordan, Judith and Robert Block, and Stephen and Marsha Blank. Devoted grandmother and great grandmother. Dear sister of Pearl Rosenthal and sister-in-law of Selma Schechner.

title: Drought on East Coast Raises Worries of Water Rationing
description: Through the dry, cold nights and almost balmy winter days, across snowless mountains and under desert-blue skies, a record-setting drought has settled over the New York region and much of the East Coast, raising fears of a spring and summer of water rationing, dying plants and mud flats where water and life once ran.

title: U.S. Woman Jailed in Peru Won't Get a Presidential Pardon
description: Lori Berenson, the New York woman whose conviction on charges of collaborating with Marxist rebels was upheld by Peru's highest court on Monday, will not be granted a presidential pardon, the justice minister said today.

title: Nets Snap Out of Trance Caused by Their Big Lead
description: What looked like an easy victory for the Nets tonight almost turned into a nightmare.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Invensys Will Sell Units
description: The engineering group Invensys, which cut 11,000 jobs last year to bring its work force down to 76,000, said that it would sell businesses worth $2.1 billion and restructure other divisions to reduce debt of over $4.2 billion. The announcement ended speculation that the company, formed from the merger three years ago of Siebe and BTR, might issue new shares to raise money. The units to be sold, which make valves and sensors, generate almost one-third of the company's sales. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about genetic differences among anthrax samples misstated the name of a laboratory that decoded part of the anthrax DNA. It is the Los Alamos National Laboratory, not Nuclear.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mount Pleasant: Inquiry Into Youth Homes
description: After a spate of violent incidents, including the torture of a counselor by youths at the Pleasantville Cottage School, State Senator Nicholas A. Spano announced yesterday that he would begin an investigation next month of all of the state's 50 residential treatment programs for troubled youths. Mr. Spano, a Yonkers Republican and chairman of the Investigations, Taxation and Government Operations Committee, will hold public hearings on security problems and abuse at the programs. The hearings will be held in Westchester and Albany and on Long Island. Separately, the State Office of Children and Family Services is investigating the Cottage School. Randal C. Archibold (NYT)

title: Playing for the Maestro In a Show of Affection
description: Friday night's Philharmonic concert at Avery Fisher Hall was a buoyant occasion, a feast of orchestration provided by masters from Schubert (''Unfinished'' Symphony) to Henri Dutilleux (''The Shadows of Time''). It was also a feast of full-blooded orchestral playing, given by an orchestra whose affection for Kurt Masur is coming right to the surface in these closing months of his tenure as music director.

title: A Nation Worries And Waits for Gold
description: The fans came in beaten-up cars and rented R.V.'s one with a goal cage strapped to the back. They came with their flags flying behind them, driving as many as 24 hours straight. They came by the hundreds, armed with body paint and hungry for victory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARDOZO, SIDNEY B.
description: CARDOZO-Sidney B. Died February 17th, 2002, after a long and courageous battle with Parkinson's Disease. Survived by brothers Benjamin M. Cardozo & Richard Cardozo. Also survived by many nieces and nephews and close friends. Funeral private. In lieu of flowers donations in his memory to Dartmouth College Class of 1938, or Parkinson's Disease.

Served with the Army Air Force 1942-1945. Decorated with the Air Medal and the Croix de Guerre. Retired as Senior Vice President and Director of College Department of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. title: Indictment in Dartmouth Case Outlines Robbery-Killing Plan
description: Two teenagers accused of killing two Dartmouth professors last year had tried in vain over several months to talk their way into other people's homes, where they intended to kill them after stealing their A.T.M. cards and passwords, according to an indictment unsealed today.

title: Virginia Hamilton, Writer For Children, Is Dead at 65
description: Virginia Hamilton, an internationally recognized writer for children whose work celebrated the African-American experience as an essential component of American life, died yesterday in Dayton, Ohio. She was 65 and lived in Yellow Springs, Ohio.

title: A MAKER OF COMMUNICATIONS EQUIPMENT ACQUIRES CELIANT
description: The Andrew Corporation announced yesterday that it plans to acquire the Celiant Corporation, which Lucent Technologies Inc. spun off last year, for about $470 million. Payment consists of $203.1 million in cash and 16.3 million in shares valued at $266.6 million based on Andrew's closing price Friday of $16.38. Andrew, a communications equipment, systems and services provider, said the deal would enable it to become one of the largest independent suppliers of power amplifiers and of products that support traditional wireless standards and emerging technologies. Celiant provides radio frequency subsystems and power amplifiers.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Gene DeWitt, chief executive at Optimedia USA, New York, part of the Zenith Optimedia Group, was named president at the Syndicated Network Television Association, New York, succeeding Allison Bodenmann, who left last year to join the Court TV cable network. Also at Optimedia USA, Steve Soldano, president, resigned to pursue other interests, the agency said. A decision about their successors is expected soon. Zenith Optimedia is owned by the Cordiant Communications Group and the Publicis Groupe.

title: Padres Add Winfield To Front Office
description: Dave Winfield's reunion with the San Diego Padres, his first team in baseball, continued yesterday as the Padres named him a vice president and senior adviser. Winfield, who played outfield, was already a member of the team's board of directors and wore a Padres cap for his induction into the Hall of Fame.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Agree to Review Case On Issuing Megan's Law Lists
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether laws that inform the public of the whereabouts of convicted sex offenders after the offenders' release from prison impose extra punishment in violation of the Constitution's ban on ex post facto legislation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEKOFSKY, MORRIS
description: LEKOFSKY-Morris, 86. Passed away on February 17, 2002, after a short illness. Born in Newark, NJ, he graduated from Brooklyn College. He served with the Combat Engineers in W.W. II. After the war, he worked for the New York Housing Authority for thirty years. After retirement, he prepared tax returns for the Civil Service Retired Employees Association. He is survived by his sister Anna of New York City.

title: Parra Turns Tables and Zips to Gold in 1,500
description: Her face shimmered in the crowd today like the gold wedding band around his finger.

title: LVMH gives up major stake in auction house
description: LONDON  The French luxury products group LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton has sold its controlling stake in the art auction house Phillips, de Pury & Luxembourg, the group's chairman, Bernard Arnault, said in a telephone interview Tuesday.

title: In Control Group, Most Welfare Recipients Left the Rolls Even Without Reform
description: They may be the last people in America to have experienced welfare as we used to know it -- 2,400 Connecticut families randomly assigned in 1996 to get public aid under old welfare rules, as a control group for one of the nation's most ambitious welfare reform experiments.

title: Bloomberg May Seek to Continue Ban on One-Occupant Cars Entering Manhattan
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg hinted yesterday that he would favor keeping in place the morning ban on single-occupant cars crossing into parts of Manhattan if a municipal traffic study being conducted shows that the ban is beneficial to the city.

title: John Gardner, Public Citizen
description: It is the rare politician these days who does not promise to unleash the energy of private citizens to do public good. Yet nobody in public life believed more deeply in the concept of citizen activism, or did more to make it a reality, than John Gardner. Mr. Gardner, who died last Saturday at the age of 89, served with distinction as an adviser to presidents and as Lyndon Johnson's secretary of health, education and welfare. In a rich and active career that spanned more than half a century, he was also a teacher, foundation executive and author. But he will best be remembered as an eloquent voice for citizen participation in public life, and as a man whose own career was powerful testimony to what a caring individual can accomplish.

title: A Place to Pick a Peck of Pickled Anything
description: Pickles, it seems, are a global thing. Scores of countries pickle, and judging from the jars lining the shelves at Just Pickles, 569 Ninth Avenue (41st Street), just about every fruit and vegetable can be pickled. Fatih Saat, above, the owner of this new venture, is from Turkey, and his native country is represented with stuffed pickled baby eggplants tied with chives. Asian pickled galangal and gooseberries, Mexican cactus, Korean kimchi and Polish pickled mushrooms are among the choices. There are barrels full of 13 kinds of cucumber pickles, olives and pickled vegetables, including some that have the bite of hot peppers. Bulk pickles are $3 a pint and $5 a quart; prices vary for the ones in jars.

description: Adapted from Lia Gomes

description: Verizon, New York's local phone carrier, presented a plan to increase rates for local telephone service to the State Public Service Commission yesterday.

title: CNN Names a Rising Star to Head Its U.S. Network
description: CNN, locked in a war for ratings with the Fox News Channel, announced yesterday that it had reshuffled its executive lineup.

title: Pakistan to Cut Islamists' Links To Spy Agency
description: In a significant signal of its change in course, Pakistan has begun to disband two major units of its powerful intelligence service that had close links to Islamic militants in Afghanistan and Kashmir, senior Pakistani military and intelligence officials said today.

title: Police Seize Cache of Thousands Of Counterfeit CD's and Videos
description: Police investigators seized 17,000 counterfeit compact discs and 2,000 counterfeit videos of current movies yesterday after executing a search warrant at two Harlem apartments, officials said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 4 Convicted Of Drug Conspiracy
description: A jury has convicted four men of running a transcontinental drug ring that trucked thousands of pounds of marijuana monthly to New York from California. The men -- Carl Coleman, Winston Hilton, Barrington Irving and Solemn Joseph -- used an Oklahoma trucking company, where Mr. Coleman worked, to transport the drugs, then stored them in a Bronx house. They also sold drugs in Harlem, the Bronx, and Utica, N.Y. Convicted on Friday of narcotics conspiracy, they face a mandatory minimum sentence of 10 years' imprisonment and a maximum of life in prison. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: Cisco Is Said to Win a Huge I.B.M. Order
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Feb. 19 (Bloomberg News)  Cisco Systems , the largest maker of computer-networking equipment, won an order worth $300 million to $500 million to upgrade I.B.M.'s internal network, an analyst said today.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GENERAL MOTORS CORP., Detroit, said that one of its units, Residential Funding Mortgage Securities I Inc., had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for permission to register $10 billion worth of securities in the form of mortgage pass-through certificates and sell them when financing needs arise.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  Senior Pentagon and Bush administration officials responded to criticism of a new Pentagon information office today, saying government officials would not be allowed to tell lies to promote American views overseas.

title: The next spokesman to put a human face on Ford comes with a pedigree.
description: WILLIAM CLAY FORD JR. does not seem eager to join the ranks of Frank Perdue, Dave Thomas, Lee Iacocca and other top executives who have embodied their companies through advertising.

description: WHERE do New York City's nearly 12,000 Brazilians usually eat? Not, it seems, in the handful of Brazilian restaurants in the city.

title: Union in South Korea Promises To Bar Any Micron-Hynix Deal
description: The labor union that represents 10,000 employees of Hynix Semiconductor promised today to take ''aggressive action'' to block any deal for Micron Technology to buy the company.

title: For Those Who Like Pepper, But Not All Those Little Specks
description: White Penja peppercorns from Cameroon deserve their pretty little tin, maybe even their own pepper mill. White peppercorns, which come from the same plant as black peppercorns, are ripe berries that have been soaked and dried to remove the outer skin. Black peppercorns are picked before maturity and darken during fermentation. The processing of white peppercorns makes them more expensive and leaves them with a more muted taste and a color that will not mar the look of a delicate sauce. Penja white peppercorns are $7.99 for 2.82 ounces at Fairway markets.

description: GOODMAN-Bernard. The Solomon Schechter School of Westchester notes with sorrow the death of Bernard Goodman, father of our esteemed Trustee, Maida Silver. We extend our condolences to Maida, Howard, Daniel and Rafi. May the memory of Bernard Goodman be a blessing. M. MacSchwebel, Chairman, Board of Trustees James M. Dubin, Vice Chairman Dr. Elliot Spiegel, Head Master

title: Panel Created in New Jersey To Aid Poor School Districts
description: Promising to reinvigorate New Jersey's fitful attempts to improve its poorest school districts, Gov. James E. McGreevey today appointed a fierce critic of the state education system to a new commission on urban education.

title: Bush Plays Ball With Japanese Premier
description: In one appearance after another during President Bush's 72-hour stay in Japan, his praise for Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi was so hearty that many Japanese were left with the impression of one long bearhug.

description: El Paso Energy Partners L.P. plans to acquire certain Texas midstream assets from its parent company, the El Paso Corporation, for $750 million.

title: Milosevic Cross-Examines Victim in Court
description: THE HAGUE, Feb. 20  When Slobodan Milosevic faced his first victim of the war in Kosovo today in court, he paused for a moment before asking questions. He blew out a little breath. He frowned. He rustled his papers, then put his hand on his chin.

title: Belarus Stuns Sweden
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 20  Shortly after the fluke goal came the final buzzer, and the celebration began for the hockey players of Belarus. By stunning Sweden, 4-3, this former Soviet republic bolted into the quarterfinals of the Olympic tournament today and shoved aside a previously undefeated favorite.

title: Idec Wins Approval Of New Cancer Drug
description: The Idec Pharmaceuticals Corporation won approval today for Zevalin, its treatment for non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, the first of a new class of drug that zeroes in on cancer cells and zaps them with a deadly dose of radiation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, BETH
description: LEVINE-Beth. Beloved and respected founding faculty member, she fought her disease with courage, dignity and determination. She was an inspiration to all of us. Her many contributions to the School and to all our students who benefited from her wisdow and caring will always be remembered. All of us in the Heschel community extend our heartfelt condolences to her husband Avi, her children Raya, Eli and Dalia, and the entire family. Shira Nadich Levin, President, Board of Trustees Roanna Shorofsky, Director Abraham Joshua Heschel School

title: From the Young, Nothing Less Than Full Commitment
description: Kurt Masur has long felt that part of his responsibilities as music director of the New York Philharmonic should include working with young musicians in the area. During his 11-year tenure he has given of his time to the Juilliard School, his Lincoln Center neighbor, in particular, doing regular open readings with the orchestra, concerts at Alice Tully Hall and occasionally high-profile concerts at Avery Fisher Hall, including Monday night's.

title: Our Towns; Finding Hope As an Enemy Ties a Noose
description: THE blinds are closed in Ricci Reyes Adan's high-rise apartment here, keeping out both the sun and the shadows it casts, making it difficult to mark the passing of time. But then, time has stood still for so long.

title: Tracing Complex Emotions, On a String
description: Randy James's ''View from the Hudson'' is best seen without the knowledge that it was inspired by the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11. The new dance is intriguingly close to abstraction, despite its gradual building from quiet walks to urgent runs and lunges juxtaposed with sad crawls and huddles. That delicate balance was introduced by the two pieces that preceded ''View from the Hudson,'' in a program of three new and recent works presented by Randy James Dance Works on Friday at the John Jay College Theater.

title: Judge Rejects European Suit On Cigarettes
description: A federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday dismissed an unusual lawsuit by European countries against American tobacco companies that had asserted that the companies used fraud and money laundering to smuggle American cigarettes into their countries.

title: Knicks Dial for Marbury, And It's Just Talk So Far
description: One question made Latrell Sprewell's eyes as big as the basketball he was shooting today: ''Have you heard the rumor that you're being traded to Phoenix for Stephon Marbury?''

title: Giambi Leads Newcomers Into Camp
description: If the story unfolds the way it usually does, Jason Giambi will have many more days like this. If he fulfills his mandate and becomes a Yankee hero, Giambi will return to Legends Field every spring. He should have a lifetime supply of pinstripes.

description: In percent

title: GENERAL MILLS WILL CLOSE TWO PLANTS AND LAY OFF 372
description: General Mills, the maker of Cheerios cereal and Old El Paso Mexican food, plans to close two plants and eliminate 372 jobs as the company integrates its purchase of Pillsbury. General Mills will shut a Mexican ingredients and sauces plant in Anthony, Tex., in March. A plant in Geneva, Ill., that makes frozen breakfast products will close Friday. Closing the two Pillsbury plants will save General Mills about $28 million this year, the chief executive, Stephen Sanger, said at a conference in Scottsdale, Ariz. Beginning in its next fiscal year, the company may save more from the $10.4 billion Pillsbury acquisition than its earlier $250 million forecast, Mr. Sanger said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERS, A. GERARD, M.D.

Memorial donations may be made to: Passaic Valley Hospice, 783 Riverview Drive, PO Box 1007, Totowa, New Jersey 07511-1007.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Rebel May Boycott Talks
description: Jean-Pierre Bemba, leader of Uganda-backed rebels who control about a third of Congo, said he would boycott peace talks next week in South Africa. At a news conference in Paris, he said he objected to the selection of political foes who will take part. The so-called Inter-Congolese Dialogue is supposed to bring together representatives from the government and the political and armed opposition, and other leaders. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: American Wins Skeleton Gold
description: PARK CITY, Utah, Feb. 20  The laminated photograph of his dead grandfather pressed against his head as he plummeted face-first down the mountain.

title: Combative Milosevic Displays A Flair for Courtroom Tactics
description: Slobodan Milosevic made clear today, as he did during his three-day opening statement, that he will fight every moment of what may be a two-year trial. He may not acknowledge the authority of the tribunal at The Hague to try him for war crimes, but he showed that he could quickly adapt to its interrogatory style.

title: Can't Find The Mayor? Well, What's It to You?
description: Deputy Mayor Marc V. Shaw was in charge of New York City last weekend.

title: Pinched Pennies and the Stranded User
description: In my column in Circuits this week, I ran out of room to make fun of the fact that ArialPhone, the company that makes the voice-dialing headset I reviewed, doesn't put its own help-line phone number in the package. If I had had the space, I would have really enjoyed deliberately publishing that number as punishment. (It's 888-201-9757, by the way.)

description: We were sitting around our office in the press center on Tuesday night watching Michelle Kwan warm up on the tube. The door opened tentatively and a young woman took one small step into our space.

description: A prospective juror allowed that he had heard of the defendant.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Passaic: Suspect Surrenders To Mayor
description: A man sought in the shootings of three people in Passaic has surrendered to the town's mayor after eluding the authorities for three days. The fugitive, Ramon Santana, 22, was arrested in the office of Mayor Samuel Rivera, above, about 9:30 a.m. Monday and charged with three counts of attempted murder and other offenses. Mr. Santana had been sought in the shootings Friday of Jerome Sturdivant, 21, his girlfriend, Deshawn Thorpe, 30, and her 16-year-old daughter. They remained hospitalized yesterday. The mayor, a childhood friend of Mr. Santana's family, appealed to Mr. Santana's mother, Zenaida Rosa, to ask her son to turn himself in. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

description: Minutes after President Bush's plane touched down in Seoul today, North Korea's news agency sought to upstage him with an amazing report that two halos had just appeared in the sky above the legendary mountain birthplace of Kim Jong Il.

description: Was it the fog of ''War and Peace''? An inspired bit of emoting gone awry? Or the unfamiliar bulge of the stage, curved to evoke the earth?

title: Astronaut to Speak at Brearley
description: BONNIE DUNBAR, an astronaut who took part in five space missions, will talk to the students of the Brearley School today about future human space travel. Brearley, a selective girls' private school on the Upper East Side, hopes that the presence of Dr. Dunbar, a member of the first United States shuttle crew to dock with the Russian space station, Mir, will encourage its students toward careers in science. Brearley has recently renovated its science labs, and a senior of the school, ARIANE ISABELLE TSCHUMI, is a semifinalist in this year's Intel Science Talent Search.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Leader Faces Special Protest
description: Chancellor Gerhard Schrder faces very personal criticism for his new legislation ending tax breaks for single parents. His half-sister Ilse Brcke, 47, and a hundred other single parents filed a complaint with a court in Karlsruhe seeking to restore the tax relief, which the government abolished on Jan. 1. Victor Homola (NYT)

description: Either Marjorie Knoller and Robert Noel delighted in having two huge dogs terrorize their San Francisco neighbors or they had no indication that the dogs were capable of a lethal attack.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Opposition To Sun Life Deal
description: Jarislowsky Fraser, a prominent Canadian fund manager, said yesterday that it would vote against Sun Life Financial Services' bid of 6.9 billion Canadian dollars ($4.3 billion) for Clarica Life Insurance because of what it called an excessively high breakup fee that would be paid to Sun Life if its bid failed to go through. Jarislowsky, which owns about 3 percent of Clarica's stock, said the proposed fee -- 310 million Canadian dollars, equal to 4.5 percent of Clarica's current value -- was out of line with Sun Life's expenses and the estimated cost savings of the deal. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Copyright Review
description: The Supreme Court agreed to decide whether the 1998 law that extended the duration of existing copyrights by 20 years was constitutional. The court's action holds the potential of producing the most important copyright case in decades.

description: WEINBERG-Isabella. Of Tenafly, NJ. Beloved wife of Louis. Devoted mother of Amy, Mark and Paul. Loving grandmother. Graduate of McGill University and MIT with a Masters in Physics. Services ''Wien & Wien'', Hackensack, 1-800-378-1892.

title: Vaughn Will Be One of the Mets' Leaders
description: Mo Vaughn earns millions of dollars to hit baseballs a long, long distance. But Vaughn does more than bash baseballs over fences and more than catch them when he lumbers near first base. He preaches, he persuades and he pilots. He does these things to himself, his teammates and anyone who listens. He is a natural leader.

title: Report Notes Swift Course Of Inhalational Anthrax
description: Detailed descriptions of the swift and relentless course of inhalational anthrax, and of doctors' futile efforts to save two women whose symptoms were not diagnosed early enough, are being published today for the first time in The Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: Brazil to End Rationing Of Electricity
description: After eight months of learning to line-dry their clothes and eat by candlelight, Brazilians were told today that they no longer needed to reduce their electric power use sharply.

title: Virtual Coaching at the Winter Games
description: Simon Ammann has twice strapped a pair of Elan skis to his feet and soared to gold -- once in the K90 ski jump and again in the K120. As impressive as that is, until several months ago he jumped with a different brand of skis.

title: Snowmobilers Gain Against Plan for Park Ban
description: The Bush administration took another formal step today toward overturning the Clinton-proposed ban on snowmobiles in Yellowstone and Grand Teton National Parks and along the 82-mile parkway that links them.

title: 'Wintel' takes aim at cell phones
description: PARIS  Hoping to repeat what they have done in the personal computer industry, Microsoft and Intel unveiled an alliance Tuesday that could extend the dominance of their "Wintel" platform to the multibillion dollar cell-phone industry, an area where the two companies have had little success so far.

title: Walter Winterbottom, 89, English Soccer Coach
description: Sir Walter Winterbottom, the first coach of the English national team and the man who presided over the two most shocking defeats in English soccer history, died on Saturday in Guildford, England. He was 89.

title: SALT LAKE 2002
description: KWAN LEADS -- Michelle Kwan, below, flaunting her trademark grace, was in first place after the women's figure skating short program, followed by Irina Slutskaya of Russia and Kwan's fellow Americans, Sasha Cohen and Sarah Hughes.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Passengers Barred From Flight
description: More than two dozen passengers were temporarily prevented from boarding a flight from New York to Yemen via London last night after British Airways employees raised concerns about their travel documents, officials said. The passengers, who were checking in for British Airways Flight 116 at Kennedy International Airport about 9 p.m., were interviewed by the F.B.I., and some were later allowed to take the flight, said Diana Fung, an airline spokeswoman. Port Authority police were called to the terminal, as were officers of the Joint Terrorist Task Force and the New York City police. Dan Bledsoe, a spokesman for the Port Authority, said that 31 male passengers had been stopped because none of them had visas and they had paid for their one-way tickets in cash through the same travel agent. But Ms. Fung said the passengers had a variety of problems with their documentation. ''It's not that there was any criminal wrongdoing, it was just the matter of the circumstances surrounding their intention to board,'' Mr. Bledsoe said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Across the Great Divide
description: When I went to Chicago for a wedding a few years ago, I decided to spare myself the agonies of air travel and take the train. I booked a first-class sleeping compartment on the Empire Builder, one of Amtrak's most historic trains, which travels more than 2,000 miles over the Cascades and across the Great Plains. Since then, I've taken the Empire Builder half a dozen times, and the stops along the way -- places like Havre, Mont., Minot, N.D., and Red Wing, Minn. -- have become for me more than abstractions on a map.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAWCH, WALTER S. JR. ''SKIP''

description: Thomas Trantino, who spent 38 years incarcerated for killing two police officers, has abandoned plans to move to his father's Staten Island apartment because the building's landlord threatened eviction, Mr. Trantino's laywer and family members said.

title: Israeli Court Stops Demolition of Homes
description: In a rare intervention, the Israeli Supreme Court issued a temporary order today halting the army's demolition of Palestinian homes in the Gaza Strip after an attack that killed a settler and two soldiers there on Monday.

title: Sports of The Times; An Inner Balance Helps the Leader
description: No one fully understands why Michelle Kwan fired her coach of 10 years, Frank Carroll, in October, having already waited almost four years for another go at the Olympic women's figure skating gold, beginning with tonight's short program.

description: The United States Treasury Department said yesterday that it had caught someone violating the bidding rules in recent Treasury auctions and had referred the case to federal law enforcement officials.

He leaves two daughters, Toni Sonet, and Barbara Lubow, a son, Peter Susman; five grandchildren, Karen, Jenny, Vikki, Leah and Mark; and eight greatgrandchildren. Memorial contributions may be made to the Jewish Federation of Palm Beach County, 4601 Community Drive, West Palm Beach, FL, 33417, The Ted and Mutt Susman Fund.

title: An Extra Twist Does the Trick in an Aerials Upset
description: The Olympics can frame a moment, give it weight and import, even in something as outlandishly eccentric as the freestyle aerials. This is a twisted group of athletes, but until this afternoon, none of them had ever performed five twists in the air during one jump at the Winter Games.

title: Honeywell Hires TRW Chairman as Chief
description: Honeywell International, after a search of several months, said yesterday that it had hired David M. Cote, 49, chairman of the TRW Corporation, as its chief executive, effective immediately. Lawrence A. Bossidy, 66, Honeywell's current chief, will remain chairman until June 30. Then Mr. Cote, who signed a five-year contract, will get that title, too.

description: AS spring approaches, the seed companies begin clamoring to provide new and fascinating things. Like fashion designers, they send their latest creations down the catalog runways. And like the annual parades of haute couture, these new fruits and vegetables are designed to stir excitement and desire in the hearts of consumers.

title: CMGI, STRUGGLING INTERNET COMPANY, TO GET NEW CHIEF
description: CMGI Inc., the Internet company that bought more than two dozen Web businesses in four years and had a $5.49 billion loss in its last fiscal year, said yesterday that David Wetherell would step down as its chief executive. Mr. Wetherell, 47, will continue as chairman and will be replaced by the chief financial officer, George McMillan, 54. The change is effective March 1, the company said in a statement. Mr. Wetherell is stepping down after CMGI stock tumbled 70 percent in the last year, leaving it with a market value of about $537 million compared with $26.5 billion in December 1999.

title: TriBeCa Building Wins Control of Ground-Floor Retail Space
description: Alawsuit over structural and decorative defects in a TriBeCa condominium has been settled, with the board of the building, known as the Ice House, gaining possession of the commercial space on the ground floor.

title: A Ruptured Vocal Cord Brings a Harmony of Its Own
description: It's set on a blistering hot day in New York, but Kurt Weill's ''Street Scene,'' which opened at the Dicapo Opera on Friday night, is a lukewarm piece. It has all the ingredients of melodrama -- love, death, adversity, and an overabundance of local color -- but these ingredients are combined with a clinical hand, which gives the piece a formulaic feel. Here's the big love duet; here comes the dramatic soliloquy; here's the comic relief, the ice cream septet, which has no dramatic purpose but to be cute and flesh out some cameos as the denizens of a tenement sing an ornate tribute to vanilla.

title: Ruling Favors Auto Insurers, Citing Fraud In Claims
description: A New York State judge yesterday upheld stricter no-fault auto insurance regulations that the Pataki administration had been trying to put into effect for two years in an effort to curb soaring auto insurance fraud in the state.

title: A Schmear of Pt, to Help Stanch the Appetite for Art
description: At gallery openings visitors are usually offered a glass of wine, but at a Taste of Art, Laurence Asseraf's new gallery at 147 Duane Street (West Broadway), art lovers have a selection of drinks and snacks that they can buy at any time. Wine, espresso, cappuccino and cocktails like the gallery's own blue martini, made with Curaao, lime juice and elder flower essence, are sold at the bar. There are also elegant nibbles like caviar, smoked salmon and pts from Petrossian, and desserts. Currently, watercolors by Izak are on view.

title: Bush Will Keep the Wartime Operation Promoting America
description: President Bush has decided to transform the administration's temporary wartime communications effort into a permanent office of global diplomacy to spread a positive image of the United States around the world and combat anti-Americanism, senior administration officials said today.

title: Forgotten Team Gives U.S. Gold In the Bobsled

After failing to qualify at the trials in Sacramento, she found a flier, posted on her hotel entrance: ''Wanted,'' it read, ''Versatile Athletes Interested in the Bobsled.'' Her husband, Johnny, handed it to her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARGOLIS, BERTRAM
description: MARGOLIS-Bertram, 84. Educator and owner of Camp Greylock for Boys, died on February 19 of complications from strokes. He is survived by his wife, Barbara Richland; one sister, Elaine Wickens; four daughters, Margaret Schwedler, Elizabeth Schwartz, Catherine Lalk, Victoria Brown; nine grandchildren and two stepchildren Jody and Arthur Rosengarten. Born in Montgomery, WV in 1917 he graduated from Johns Hopkins University, received an MBA from the New School and taught and studied for a doctorate at Columbia University. He was perhaps best known for the integrity and sportsmanship that he inspired in so many children during his 50 year directorship of Camp Greylock. Memorial service to be announced. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to Camp Greylock Alumni Scholarship Fund, 200 W. 57 St, NY, NY 10019.

title: Viewers See Double, But It Isn't Their Eyes
description: First there was instant replay, the initial revolution in sports television technology. Once perfected, it was simple and informative.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Plan for Distributing Seized Domains
description: The consortium responsible for Internet addresses ending in .info, Afilias, plans to re-release more than 10,000 .info names that were falsely registered last summer during a period intended for trademark owners. The names, which Afilias repossessed after registrants failed to provide proof of valid trademarks, will be available for the public to register this spring through accredited registrars. To distribute the addresses, Afilias said it would randomize each batch of requests submitted by registrars later this spring, and then select them for consideration in random order. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: $6 Million for Middle School
description: The Little Red School House and Elisabeth Irwin High School, a private school in Manhattan known for its progressive traditions, has raised $6 million to enhance school programs and buildings, according to ANDREW McLAREN, the director. The money will be used for the construction of a new middle school with a two-level library and technology center, a media arts center with digital editing equipment for aspiring high school filmmakers and faculty computer and technology workshops. Stephanie Rosenbloom

title: Miscellany
description: * The Publicis Groupe, Paris, acquired a majority stake in Johnston & Associates, Washington, a government relations agency led by J. Bennett Johnston, a former senator.

description: AS I opened the worn-shiny leatherette menu at Aux Fins Gourmets here, it felt as if A. J. Liebling should be sitting right down the banquette.

title: Wines of the Week
description: Everyone loves a deal and these California chardonnays deliver. Two of them taste like they cost double their $10 price tag, while the other two are actually worth their $20 cost.

title: Court Ruling May Change Landscape For Media
description: Investment bankers, start your engines.

title: A Voice That Bursts With Glory
description: Things are not what they seem at the Mormon Tabernacle. The oaken pews are actually painted pine boards. The marble columns are painted pine. The mahogany organ is painted pine. The gold piping is painted pine. And Wes Matheson seems happy.

title: Judge Dismisses Cigarette Suit
description: A federal judge in Brooklyn dismissed a lawsuit yesterday in which the European Commission accused the Philip Morris Companies and the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company of smuggling contraband cigarettes into Europe to evade paying billions in taxes.

title: PetroChina May Try to Acquire Husky Energy
description: CALGARY, Alberta, Feb. 19 (Bloomberg News)  Husky Energy ( news/quote ), a Canadian oil company controlled by the Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing, said today that it was in talks with the PetroChina Company ( news/quote ) about a possible takeover that would give the Asian company access to consumers in the United States, the biggest energy market.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Little Progress In Arms Talks
description: Foreign Minister Igor Ivanov said Moscow had not yet agreed with the United States over how to reduce the two countries' stores of warheads. He made the statement after two days of talks with Undersecretary of State John Bolton in preparation for a meeting in May. Mr. Bolton said that there were a number of issues requiring more discussion, but added that he did not see any insuperable obstacles. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: AES Says It Will Sell Assets And Cut Capital Spending
description: The AES Corporation, the electricity producer whose stock has been battered as investors worry about how it intends to finance itself in a sour economy, said yesterday that it hoped to raise as much as $1.5 billion by selling assets and would cut capital spending by 38 percent this year.

title: WAL-MART'S PROFIT CLIMBS 9% IN FOURTH QUARTER
description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. said yesterday that its fiscal fourth-quarter profit rose 9.2 percent as it sold more groceries and attracted customers from Kmart. Net income rose to $2.19 billion, or 49 cents a share, compared with $2 billion, or 45 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Wal-Mart offered more discounts last quarter to fend off Kmart, which cut prices on thousands of goods in an unsuccessful attempt to win shoppers before seeking bankruptcy protection. The move helped to lift sales, which rose 13.5 percent, to $64.21 billion.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a front-page picture in some late editions yesterday, showing President Bush in Japan, carried an erroneous caption and credit. The photograph, by The Associated Press, showed Emperor Akihito and Empress Michiko escorting the president and his wife, Laura, into the Imperial Palace. (A picture in earlier editions showed the president at a news conference with Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi.)

title: $1.5 Million for CUNY Program
description: The Herman Muehlstein Foundation has given CUNY a $1.5 million grant to support the City College honors program. The honors program seeks to attract top students into science, engineering and architecture, and the grant will help pay for high school recruiting programs, math and science programs for entering freshmen during the summer and more faculty members.

title: Inquiry Into Computer Associates Started by Federal Prosecutors
description: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn have opened a preliminary inquiry into whether Computer Associates deliberately overstated its profits to inflate its stock price and enrich its senior executives, two people close to the investigation said.

title: Warmer-Up From Japan
description: THE beef stew here will be unfamiliar to most cooks, though it has much in common with the classic American dish. It is Japanese in origin and loaded with the warmth of soy, ginger, sweetness (best provided by mirin, the sweet Japanese cooking wine, but sugar or honey will do, too), winter squash and the peel and juice of a lemon. These simple and delicious counterpoints make a great stew.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Domain Name Grace Period Proposed
description: The group responsible for the Internet's address system, the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, has proposed giving domain name holders a 30-day grace period to re-register addresses that have expired. The proposal, on which Icann is seeking feedback via e-mail messages sent to redeem-comment@icann.org, is intended to prevent unintentional deletions of domain registrations. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: BUSH SAYS THE U.S. PLANS NO ATTACK ON NORTH KOREA
description: President Bush said today in Seoul that the United States had no intentions of invading or attacking North Korea and that his goal in the Korean peninsula was peace.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Netherlands: Lawyer-Accountant Link Barred
description: The European Court of Justice yesterday upheld a ruling by the Bar Association in the Netherlands forbidding two Dutch lawyers from forming partnerships with the local offices of the accountants PricewaterhouseCoopers and Arthur Andersen. There may be a degree of incompatibility between the advisory activities carried out by a lawyer and the supervisory activities carried out by an accountant, the court said in a statement. The lawyers had argued that by preventing them from allying with the accountants, the bar group was violating European Union competition law. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEHRMAN, DARRYL G.
description: BEHRMAN-Darryl G. The investment and administrative professionals of Behrman Capital were shocked and deeply saddened by the untimely passing of our beloved co-founder and managing partner, Darryl G. Berhman, who died unexpectedly of a heart attack at age 51 on Tuesday, February 12, 2002, while vacationing in Anguilla. He was a strong and effective leader, who will be greatly missed. We will draw on Darryl's strength and vision as we honor his legacy through the continued success of the firm that he worked so hard to build. We are committed to carrying on the firm's objectives with an undaunted will to achieve-the will heightened by the remembrance of Darryl's example. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Janine, his son Greg, his daughter Amanda, his mother Fay, and his brother Grant, co-founder and managing partner of our firm, as well as the other members of Darryl's extended family and his many friends and colleagues. They are in our hearts and prayers.

Hewlett, with a shareholder vote in a month, issued a report yesterday that sketched out an alternative plan for Hewlett-Packard -- a strategy, he argued, that could leave stockholders better off by $14 to $17 a share than if the company proceeds with its proposal to buy Compaq Computer.

Mr. Tobias will help researchers devise and analyze projects to determine what works in the classroom for urban-school children, and how to make teaching and curriculum better.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANG, JENSEN, HELEN JEAN NOLAN
description: BANG-JENSEN-Helen Jean Nolan, 87. On January 21, 2002. She was the widow of Povl BangJensen, a Danish diplomat and UN official. Active in the Chappaqua community, Mrs. Bang-Jensen served as a local newspaper correspondent and founding member of the New Castle Historical Society. A Port Jervis native, she graduated from Elmira College, Phi Beta Kappa, in 1936. In Washington, DC, prior to WWII, she was employed by the Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies and was elected president of the International Student House, a de facto center for students and young professionals supporting the allies. She received a commendation from the King of Denmark for her work during WWII. She was an editor of The InterAmerican, a political affairs journal. In 1991 the President of Hungary honored Mrs. Bang-Jensen for her husband's efforts to protect Hungarians testifying before the UN about the 1956 Revolution, which lead to his firing from the UN and death in 1959. In 1989, Hungary erected a memorial to her husband next to the gravesites of Imre Nagy and other leaders of the Revolution and, in 1999, a bust of her husband was added to the busts of three early Foreign Ministers in the lobby of the Foreign Ministry. She is survived by her children: Karen Zumwalt, of Chappaqua; Per of Warrenton, VA; Lise of Albany; Lars of Burlington, VT; and Nina of Chevy Chase, MD; and five grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 11 AM, March 23, at Union Church, Pocantico Hills, where Mrs. Bang-Jensen worked for Historic Hudson Valley until 1999 as a guide for the Chagall and Matisse stained glass windows. Donations may be made to International Student House, 1825 R St., NW, Washington, DC 20009; New Castle Historical Society, 100 King St., Chappaqua 10514; or UNICEF, 333 East 38th St., NYC 10016.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Switch In Contests
description: The Democratic leader of the State Senate, Stan Matsunaka, has quit the race for governor this year to run for Congress. Mr. Matsunaka, 48, a lawyer from Loveland, said he was urged by the House minority leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, to seek the Fourth District seat. Gov. Bill Owens, a Republican, said on Monday that he was seeking re-election. Mindy Sink (NYT)

description: The Omnicom Group, an advertising company, said yesterday that it had a 15 percent increase in fourth-quarter profit after it won more business from new customers.

title: NBC's Ratings Are Still Rising
description: NBC's 11th night of the Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City on Monday generated a 17.1 Nielsen rating, 15 percent better than CBS's rating on the comparable night four years ago in Nagano, Japan. Each network showed the finals in ice dancing. Through 11 days, NBC's 18.2 average rating is 11 percent ahead of CBS's after the same period of time. Each rating point equals 1.06 million television households.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: Bid For Workers' Sacrifice

The governor, a Republican, said employees must turn in their cellphones and lower thermostats in state offices. A memorandum suggested that workers wear sweaters. title: A Place to Pick a Peck of Pickled Anything
description: Pickles, it seems, are a global thing. Scores of countries pickle, and judging from the jars lining the shelves at Just Pickles, 569 Ninth Avenue (41st Street), just about every fruit and vegetable can be pickled. Fatih Saat, above, the owner of this new venture, is from Turkey, and his native country is represented with stuffed pickled baby eggplants tied with chives. Asian pickled galangal and gooseberries, Mexican cactus, Korean kimchi and Polish pickled mushrooms are among the choices. There are barrels full of 13 kinds of cucumber pickles, olives and pickled vegetables, including some that have the bite of hot peppers. Bulk pickles are $3 a pint and $5 a quart; prices vary for the ones in jars.

Contributions in her memory may be made to The 92nd Street Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARDNER, JOHN W.
description: GARDNER-John W. John Gardner's mark on Carnegie Corporation of New York, where he served as president from 1955 to 1965, is indelible. He arrived at the foundation after his service in WWII, imbued with the optimistic American spirit that this country's values could help transform a world wracked by war. He believed in the power of ideas and in the determination of man to change. Gardner shared our founder Andrew Carnegie's unwavering passion for the mission he established for our institution, that ''the advancement and the fusion of knowledge and understanding'' could ''do real and permanent good'' in the world. Like Carnegie, Gardner believed the greatest evil of all is ignorance. The board of trustees of the Corporation, its staff, both present and past, are thankful for John Gardner's service, leadership and legacy. Vartan Gregorian, President, Carnegie Corporation of New York

description: LIZ KRUEGER, the state senator-elect from Manhattan's East Side, has one of those ''Yeah, right'' styles of irony, and if you want to see for yourself, step into the kitchen of her Upper East Side house.

title: Editorial Observer; The Pursuit of Mental Perfection at the Salt Lake Olympics
description: There isn't a lot of time in an Olympic ski run -- men's, women's, downhill or slalom -- to think about ontology, the philosophy of the nature of being. Yet every athlete these days knows the importance of ''being in the moment.'' The ancient Greeks gave us the Olympic Games and the foundations of a Western philosophy of being. What they might have called sports ontology we call sports psychology, which is the discipline of helping athletes find their true potential in the moments when it counts most. No matter how much an athlete trains, it's rarely possible to train in a way that completely reproduces the circumstances of Olympic competition, the years of waiting, the screaming fans, the sense of national and team pride. The moment can't be examined until you're actually in it. All those years of thinking about those few seconds of competition boil down to the few seconds of actually living them.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Earthlink Expands Wireless Offerings
description: EarthLink will begin sales of wireless modems and service plans today to provide Internet connections for hand-held computers that run the Palm and Pocket PC operating systems. The services are EarthLink's first that use technology acquired from its purchase of OmniSky last month. EarthLink, the No. 3 Internet service provider in the United States, will offer monthly service plans ranging in price from about $40 to $60. EarthLink acquired the privately held OmniSky and its 32,000 subscribers for an undisclosed price. The company also offers wireless access to the Internet and e-mail through pagers from Motorola and Research in Motion. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: It's a Rare Scene: Movie Executive With 9 Lives; From Warner Brothers to Columbia, and, Now, Paired With Ovitz
description: Mark Canton, in his fourth day on the job as chief executive of Artists Production Group, the moviemaking offshoot of Michael Ovitz's Artists Management Group, sat at one end of the coffee table. Joel Gotler, head of A.M.G./Renaissance, the company's literary division, sat at the other. ''O.K.,'' Mr. Canton said, ''Pitch me. I've only got a few minutes.''

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Venture On a Small Scale
description: Molecular Electronics Inc., a start-up company based in Houston that is one of the first efforts to commercialize a new technology based on molecular-scale electronic circuits, has signed a confidential product development agreement with the Amphenol Corporation. The participation of Amphenol, a leading maker of connectors and interconnection systems, suggests that molecular electronics researchers may be within striking distance of commercial success in developing ultrafine wires that are no wider than several molecules in diameter. A number of large and small companies are pursuing the possibility of making storage systems and computers on a scale far smaller than the current generation of microelectronic components. John Markoff (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Afternoon Trading Resumes
description: The Philippine Stock Exchange will resume afternoon trading tomorrow for the first time in more than two decades. Taking advantage of a spurt of interest from foreign investors that has sent the benchmark stock index up 25 percent so far this year, the exchange will follow its usual morning session, which runs two and a half hours, with an hour and a half of trading after lunch.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Adoption Web Site Started
description: New York City is taking its search for adoptive parents online. To help find families for the hundreds of children waiting on city adoption lists, the city has started a Web site, www.nyc.gov/adopt, with pictures and biographies of some of the children. The site can be searched by age, gender, race, special needs and number of siblings. William C. Bell, the commissioner of the Administration for Children's Services, said the city wanted to complete 3,000 adoptions a year. He said the site would not report the children's last names, but would explain how to begin the adoption process. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Split Proceeds At Hyundai
description: Hyundai Heavy Industries, the world's largest shipbuilder, is completing its separation from the Hyundai group in March by renouncing ownership of a significant portion of its shares in Hyundai Asan, which operates tours to North Korea. Hyundai Heavy Industries, which now owns 24.84 percent of Hyundai Asan, will reduce its equity stake to 14.95 percent by returning the rest to the company. Hyundai Heavy decided not to charge for the shares after finding no buyers. Hyundai Heavy has already given up most of its equity in other Hyundai companies and is suing two of them, Hynix Semiconductor and Hyundai Securities, for more than $200 million that it lent to them when they all were under the same umbrella. title: WELLS FARGO SETTLES CASE ON SUPERVISION OF BROKER
description: The brokerage unit of Wells Fargo & Company agreed to pay $150,000 to settle accusations by securities regulators that it had inadequately supervised a broker who improperly switched customers among mutual funds. The Securities and Exchange Commission said that the broker had switched mutual funds to generate commissions for himself and the firm. Wells Fargo Brokerage Services, known at the time as Norwest Investment Services, had no system to enforce its fund switching policies in 1999, the S.E.C.'s order said. The company said it was adopting new procedures for switching funds but neither admitted nor denied wrongdoing. The former broker at the Aurora, Colo., office, Russell Turek, switched mutual funds in at least seven customer accounts from February to August 1999, the S.E.C. said. He agreed to pay a $10,000 fine and surrender $1,412 in improper commissions.

''What's the Worst That Could Happen,'' a 2001 release starring Danny DeVito and Martin Lawrence, will be available for $3.99 or $4.99 depending on the viewer's geographic region. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Tuition Policy At Cuny
description: The City University of New York said yesterday that its new policy of charging illegal immigrants its higher, nonresident tuition did not appear to have discouraged them from enrolling. Nonresident tuition is $3,400 a semester, or more than double the $1,600 for state residents. About 20 percent of the illegal immigrants at the senior colleges in the fall did not re-enroll for the spring semester, compared with 19 percent for all students. The policy took effect this semester. CUNY officials said they were complying with federal law, and the policy was recently upheld by a state court. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

title: HERSHEY FOODS TO INTRODUCE MORE CHOCOLATE PRODUCTS
description: The Hershey Foods Corporation, the maker of chocolate candy, plans to introduce more products this year in an effort to bolster nonholiday sales, its chief executive said yesterday. Hershey is planning to sell limited-edition Hershey's Kisses, with red, silver and blue wrappers, in the second quarter. Also planned are limited-edition Kit Kats and Jolly Rancher-filled lollipops, among others, the chief executive, Richard H. Lenny, said in an interview. Sales for the Valentine's Day holiday were ''reasonably good,'' Mr. Lenny said. He did not provide exact figures. Hershey has completed a two-year program to stop selling some less-profitable candies and candy-package sizes, Mr. Lenny said. The initiative cut the number of products Hershey offers by 20 percent and will help the company focus on bigger items.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOOKMAN, JANET S.
description: BOOKMAN-Janet S. Passed away February 19, 2002, age 84 at her home in Lakeville, Connecticut. Born in Brooklyn and raised in the Bronx, she went to Washington, DC in The New Deal Days, worked for several U.S. Government agencies, including the Library of Congress intelligence group in the early days of W.W. II and then became a reporter for The United Press (later UPI). She covered The War Production Board and The Interior Department when Harold Ickes was Secretary. Married in 1944, she later edited books and scientific papers for the NY Botanical Garden & several publishing firms. She is deeply mourned by her husband George, daughter Jean of Winchendon, MA, and Charles of Seattle, Wash., also grandchildren Aaron and his wife Wrenna of Oakland, CA, Alanna of New York City, Tyras of Venice, CA and Zachary of College Park, MD. She also leaves two adored great-grandchildren, Vivien and Jasper of Oakland and cherished family members Betsy of San Francisco, Richard of Winchendon and Andrea of Seattle. The F.T.C. said that it granted Mr. Icahn early termination of the waiting period required under federal antitrust law. Mr. Icahn earlier made a filing with the trade commission and the Justice Department seeking clearance to buy up to $500 million of stock in ImClone, which has run into regulatory problems with a cancer drug it is trying to develop in partnership with Bristol-Myers Squibb. ImClone said on Friday that it had adopted a shareholder rights plan as a defense against a hostile takeover.

description: William Davis Taylor, the publisher of The Boston Globe for 22 years, until 1978, died on Tuesday at his home in Brookline, Mass. He was 93.

title: City Opera's Fall Season To Open With 'Il Trittico'
description: Just as the spring half of the New York City Opera's current season is about to begin, the company yesterday announced its plans for the 2002-3 season, which will open on Sept. 10 with a new production by James Robinson of ''Il Trittico,'' conducted by George Manahan, City Opera's music director. This Puccini triple bill has not been staged at City Opera since 1969.

description: Gun sales across the country were hampered this week after the federal authorities failed to provide gun dealers with new forms to run background checks, officials said today.

title: Games and Museums
description: Ineeded to get away from the milling crowds of parka people downtown, so I picked the most peaceful place in the city  the University of Utah. The school has been on break this month during the Winter Games, leaving a ghost town of open parking spaces, empty walkways and barren classrooms.

title: From Japan and Guaranteed to Be Logo-Free
description: Muji, a Japanese company, offers utilitarian wares in cardboard, plastic and aluminum -- without logos. (Indeed, Muji is short for mujirushi ryohin, which means ''no brand goods.'') And while Martha Stewart is now selling her goods in a Muji store in Tokyo, this month Muji arrives in America, as a shop within a shop at the Museum of Modern Art. Paola Antonelli, a design curator at the Modern, said the no-name plainness is Muji's appeal. Cognoscenti carry Muji's aluminum business-card case, she said, as ''a reaction to logos.'' The card case is $7.50, photo albums are $4 to $6.50, and a cardboard tube of colored pencils is $20. MoMA Design Store, 44 West 53rd Street or 81 Spring Street (Crosby Street). MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: A Peace Impulse Worth Pursuing
description: The violent cycle of Palestinian attack and Israeli reprisal grows deadlier by the day. With Palestinian militants increasing the frequency and effectiveness of their assaults on Israeli soldiers, Israel hit back yesterday with intensified air, sea and ground fire.

title: Non-Orthodox Gain Support From Ruling In Israeli Court
description: The Israeli Supreme Court took an important step today toward deciding the question of ''who is a Jew'' by ruling that Israelis converted by the Conservative or Reform movements should be listed as Jews in the official population registry.

description: The search for a new president of Lincoln Center has narrowed to two leading candidates, Lincoln Center executives say.

description: PARIS:  David Burgess, 57, an editor and writer for the International Herald Tribune, died of cancer Tuesday in the Paris suburb of Suresnes.

title: Car Rental Agency Is Ordered to Stop Charging Speeders Fines
description: A New Haven car rental company that uses satellite technology to track and fine drivers $150 each time they exceed a certain speed was ordered by the state today to cease the practice and pay back about $12,000 in fines it had collected since October 2000.

title: On to the Senate
description: After an impressive victory in the House, campaign finance reform is headed to a new showdown in the Senate. The McCain-Feingold soft-money bill, nearly identical to the Shays-Meehan legislation passed last week in the House, was approved by the Senate last year with 59 affirmative votes. The Senate now needs to pass the House bill intact in order to avoid a House-Senate conference that could kill the bill. But Senate opponents led by Mitch McConnell of Kentucky are mulling the possibility of blocking the Shays-Meehan bill with a filibuster that would require 60 votes to break. With the Enron scandal tainting lawmakers in both parties, this is no time for senators to choose obstruction over reform.

title: TYCO'S FINANCE UNIT RAISES $1.2 BILLION IN DEBT SALE
description: Tyco International said yesterday that its CIT Group finance unit raised $1.2 billion through the sale of securities backed by customer bills to repay maturing debt. J. P. Morgan Chase, Citigroup and Credit Suisse First Boston arranged the transaction, CIT said. Financial terms were not disclosed, and a spokeswoman for Tyco did not have further details. Tyco used $14.4 billion in bank loans earlier this month to repay short-term corporate debts as it prepared to split into four companies and sell a plastics unit. It also said it would raise $3 billion by borrowing and pledging assets to secure the loans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAHAM, HELENE
description: ABRAHAM-Helene. On February 19, 2002, in Palm Beach, Florida. Beloved wife of Sandy, devoted mother of Nancy and Jimmy, and mother-in-law of Andrea Abraham and Arnold Moss. Loving grandmother of Lauren, Antonia & Karen Abraham. Helene wished that there be no formal funeral service, but hoped that her family and friends would remember her for all the joy she brought to the living of her life. Contributions in her memory may be made to The 92nd Street Y.

title: Judge Rejects New Charge Filed After Man's Acquittal
description: A federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday dismissed a new charge against a man who had just been acquitted last month in a related case, criticizing federal prosecutors for what he said was an attempt to make up for their defeat in court.

title: Hundreds Die as Fire Engulfs an Egyptian Train
description: A blazing train crammed with holiday travelers sped through the darkness early today with flames engulfing car after car. More than 370 passengers were killed, some of whom leapt to their deaths on the tracks in an effort to escape the flames.

title: Panel Discounts Some Fears Over Vaccinations for Babies
description: Amid growing fears that vaccines may harm babies' immune systems, an independent panel of experts said today that childhood shots did not increase the risk of juvenile diabetes, a disease associated with immune system dysfunction, or certain serious infections like meningitis.

title: HEAD OF RETAIL INVESTING AT CHARLES SCHWAB RESIGNS
description: Steven Scheid, who led the individual investor business at the discount brokerage firm Charles Schwab, has resigned, leaving the co-chief executive, David Pottruck, to operate the firm's largest division temporarily. Mr. Scheid, who joined Schwab in June 1996, said he wanted to run a large financial services organization where he could make more decisions. Mr. Pottruck said a successor would be chosen within the company in the next 30 days.

title: Economist Finds Value And Fixed Books in Online World
description: Tracking phantom subsidiaries is one thing. For a real accounting challenge, try balancing the books for an entire virtual world.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Denmark: Brewer Demotes Executive
description: The Danish brewer Carlsberg replaced its chief financial officer after earnings information was disclosed to analysts before it was released to the public, violating stock market regulations forbidding selective disclosure. Jesper Baernholdt, who had been chief financial officer for about a year, will be replaced by Per Broendum Andersen, previously chief financial officer of a joint venture of Carlsberg and Coca-Cola. Mr. Baernholdt will be assigned to ''other tasks,'' the company said.

title: Miller Gets First American Medal in Giant Slalom
description: PARK CITY, Utah, Feb. 21  Stephan Eberharter, who had been the greatest skier of these Winter Olympics without a gold medal, could finally wave to the finish line grandstand today and know the Austrian flags in the crowd were waving back at him. Long in the shadow of his countryman Hermann Maier, Eberharter would be granted his turn on the highest step of an Olympic podium. And when he stood there, he would also be the first Austrian skier awarded four Olympic medals.

title: 'Israel Is Not Collapsing,' Sharon Says in Address
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 21 - Ariel Sharon, the prime minister of Israel, said tonight that Israel would create buffer zones to achieve ``security separation'' from the Palestinians, as he urgently appealed for national unity in the face of sharpening criticism that he lacks a plan to end 16 months of grinding conflict.

title: Gooden Faces Charges Of Drunken Driving
description: Hours after George Steinbrenner cited his behavior as an example of a successful reclamation project, Dwight Gooden was arrested here Tuesday night on a drunken-driving charge. He posted $500 bond and was released from the Hillsborough County Jail this morning.

title: S.E.C. Widens Investigation Into PNC
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has widened its investigation of the accounting of the PNC Financial Services Group, sending subpoenas to the company's auditor, Ernst & Young, and the American International Group, a company partner.

title: Bone-Shaking Slide to Gold By 3rd-Generation Olympian
description: He plunged face-first down the icy chute with a laminated photograph of his grandfather inside his white helmet, a bittersweet reminder of the legacy he was racing for.

title: Dialing, Without Fingers
description: AS millions of Americans can tell you, working from home has its perks: no cubicles, a commute of about 25 feet, and an unbelievably liberal dress code. Of course, you give up certain things, too, like color laser printers, sports betting pools and the illicit thrill of free office supplies.

title: Save Your Own Life: Backing Up a PC
description: BACKING up a computer ranks somewhere between cleaning the oven and checking the batteries in the smoke detector on most people's long-avoided to-do lists. They are all good ideas but, for some reason, you never follow through on any of them.

title: Third Medal in Hand, Kostelic Focuses on Fourth
description: Last week, Janica Kostelic of Croatia entered an event for which she had little time to train, the women's combined, and won. She then raced in the super-G, a difficult, risky discipline for someone who has had three knee operations in the past year. She won the silver medal.

title: National Briefing | Labor: A.F.L.-C.I.O. To Vote On Political Spending
description: Union officials said they expected the executive council of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. to vote next week on whether the labor federation's 66 unions should make a contribution of $1 per member to raise $13 million for a political fund. The federation plans to spend $35 million on political and legislative matters in 2001 and 2002. Union leaders said the proposal is likely to be for a voluntary contribution, not through a mandatory assessment. The federation, which represents 13 million union members, holds its winter executive council meeting in New Orleans on Tuesday and Wednesday. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

description: Jim and Judy Jacques concede that life in this middle-class suburb of Sacramento has been good, maybe too good.

description: Having waded well into Puerto Rican politics, Gov. George E. Pataki today found the waters uncomfortably choppy, as businessmen and reporters challenged him for refusing to take a position on the commonwealth's overarching issue, its status within the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDERSON, DAVID E.
description: ANDERSON-David E. David, who combined moral substance with matchless style, died Friday February 15, 2002 after a long illness. David brought creativity to diverse senior management positions in fields including recording and marketing where, as in his interaction with friends, he had a solution for any problem. His many admirers will remember him as an incomparably loving, giving friend. His generosity set an example we cannot hope to equal, but we will be the better for trying. David is survived by his sister Mary, his brothers Mike, Joe and Tom and nine nieces & nephews. title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Oil Policy Meeting
description: Executives of major Russian oil companies met yesterday with the country's prime minister and energy minister, but they did not discuss whether Russia would continue to limit exports to prop world oil prices. A promise to OPEC to hold down shipments expires on March 31, and there was little sign that it would be extended. The energy minister, Igor Yusufov, told the Russian news agency Interfax that the country should step up exports of refined products to compensate oil companies for the limits on exports of crude. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Lucent Sticking To Sales Forecast
description: Lucent Technologies, the big telephone equipment maker, still expects sales to rise 10 percent to 15 percent this quarter from the preceding period, its chief executive, Patricia Russo, said in an interview after the company's annual shareholder meeting in Wilmington, Del. Last month, Lucent Technologies said it expected sales to rise in the fiscal second quarter ending March 30 from $3.58 billion the first quarter. During the meeting, Lucent's chairman, Henry B. Schacht, said the company had stopped using its auditor, PricewaterhouseCoopers, for consulting.

title: AVANT SHARES FALL AFTER EXPERIMENTAL DRUG FAILS TRIAL
description: Shares of Avant Immunotherapeutics Inc. tumbled 65 percent yesterday after the company reported that its experimental heart drug failed in a clinical trial. The company said a total of 564 patients were tested in the midstage, or Phase 2, trial of the drug, TP10. The trial showed no clinically important differences between the drug and a placebo in reducing deaths, heart attacks or complications after heart surgery, the company said. ''We are evaluating the future of the TP10 program but we no longer plan to advance TP10 in clinical development on our own nor do we intend to put any more Avant resources into this program,'' said Una S. Ryan, the chief executive of Avant. Shares of Avant fell $1.94, to $1.06.

title: From Long Jump to a Leap of Faith
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 20  The day after she helped make history in the first Olympic women's bobsled competition, Vonetta Flowers, America's sweetheart du jour, had everybody asking the same questions today: How did a 28-year-old African- American woman go from Summer Games rejection to Winter Games royalty in less than 20 months? And how did a warm, candid woman from Alabama get mixed up in this frozen pool of sharks?

title: Hawaiian Vacation Packages
description: United Vacations has taken up to $200 a person off its Hawaiian packages that include air fare on the airline, five nights' accommodations and (in some cases) a rental car. For Wednesday and Thursday departures June 5 to Aug. 22, for example, Oahu vacations start at $539 a person, double, from San Francisco and Los Angeles, $704 from Denver, $814 from Chicago and $864 from New York and Washington. Rental cars are included on trips to Maui, Kauai and the Big Island. Availability is limited, and various airport fees apply. Information: (800) 328-6877.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Argentina: U.S. To Require Visas
description: Washington is again insisting that Argentines obtain visas for travel to the United States, generating huge lines outside the American Embassy in Buenos Aires and confusion at airports. The exemption, in place for six years, was ended in part because of an increase in the number of Argentines remaining in the United States illegally. That trend coincides with a worsening of Argentina's crippling economic crisis. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: A Fitting Memorial to Turner by the Sea He Loved to Paint
description: Snohetta, an architectural firm based in Oslo, along with Spence Associates of London, has won the competition to build the Turner Center (drawing, above), a museum to honor the painter J. M. W. Turner, in Margate, England, east of Canterbury. The plans call for a 12-story building for galleries, a nautical fin made of reinforced concrete and clad in English oak, set on the side of a jetty facing the sea. An arc of skylights will provide natural illumination to the top gallery, a space 52 feet high, whose interior walls are a continuous curve. A smaller glass-faced building on the quay houses offices and a restaurant, with views also of the inner harbor.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Child Hit By Stray Bullet
description: A 5-year-old Bronx girl was critically injured yesterday when she was struck in the neck by a stray bullet, said Detective Valerie St. Rose, a police spokeswoman. No arrests have been made. The girl, Angelica Vasquez, was walking with her mother in the 1100 block of Evergreen Avenue in the Soundview section about 4:45 p.m. when she was shot. She was taken to Jacobi Medical Center, where she was listed in critical but stable condition last night, said Nina L. Johnson, a hospital spokeswoman. Though the bullet remains lodged in her neck, the girl is expected to recover, Ms. Johnson said. Al Baker (NYT)
