The history being rewritten now at Columbia University, in a series of concerts, is that of Mary I of England, long remembered by some as a Catholic hiccup in the inevitable arrival of Anglicanism and good sense. No, says George Steel, the organizer of these programs. And no, agrees Alexander Blachly, who on Saturday led his group Pomerium in a superb concert of English sacred polyphony at St. Paul's Chapel on the Columbia campus.

description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 20  The future flashed prematurely on the E Center ice Tuesday afternoon. And Daniele Sauvageau, the Canadian women's ice hockey coach, was more than a little anxious to see it.

description: A group of states suing Microsoft, citing recent testimony from a company executive, have told a federal court that Microsoft has used the Bush administration's antitrust settlement as ''a sword to extract valuable concessions'' from personal computer makers.

description: American Express Financial Advisors has reached a settlement with plaintiffs in a sex discrimination lawsuit brought earlier this year, according to documents filed with a federal court in Washington.

description: The New Jersey attorney general's office has quietly proposed a regulation that would allow the troubled state police to shield a wide array of police documents from the public -- including the disciplinary records of troopers and videotapes of their traffic stops.

title: Officers' Widows Oppose Control Of Twin Towers Fund by Giuliani
description: The widows of 15 police officers killed at the World Trade Center threatened yesterday to take legal action to try to stop the Bloomberg administration from transferring control of the $160-million Twin Towers Fund to a private charity of the same name run by Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Google Adds Ad Option
description: The search engine Google introduced a service in which advertisers that bid for ad position on the results page will get better placement if their ads draw more user responses, or clicks. While advertisers could previously pay only by the number of ads displayed, Google's new service calculates the placement of the paid ads on the basis of both the bid and the click rate. That means an ad with a lower bid that draws more responses can be placed above a more expensive but less compelling link, said Sergey Brin, co-founder of Google. Shares of Overture Services, a Google rival, fell $2.80, or 9.6 percent, yesterday as investors assessed the new Google service. But Safa Rashtchy, a research analyst at Piper Jaffray, played down the threat to Overture. ''It's inconceivable to us that any one of the portals would want to make this deal with Google, because they see Google increasingly as a competitor,'' Mr. Rashtchy said. Glenn Fleishman (NYT)

title: Plan to Cut Construction Spending Would Delay Willis Avenue and Brooklyn Bridge Projects
description: A plan to replace the 101-year-old Willis Avenue Bridge, which connects the Bronx and Manhattan, is being delayed as part of the Bloomberg administration's plan to cut spending on capital construction projects by 25 percent, officials said yesterday.

title: The Math: How It All Added Up to a Hughes Gold
description: To get the final ranking in the figure skating competition, the placement from the short program is multiplied by one half. That number is then added to the placement from the long program. The skater with the smallest resulting number wins the competition. If there is a tie, the skater who received the higher ranking in the long program is the winner. Here is how it worked for last night's final: Sarah Hughes was fourth in the short program and first in the long program. The result of those two placements is 3. Irina Slutskaya was second in the short program and second in the long program, also resulting in a 3. Hughes won the long program, so she wins the tie breaker. Michele Kwan was first in the short program and third in the long program. Those placements result in a 3.5.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Camden: 6 Killings May Be Linked
description: Six homicides discovered over three days this month appear to be related, the Camden County prosecutor said yesterday. The victims' bodies were found in three locations in Lindenwold and Winslow Township from Feb. 5 to Feb. 7. The victims -- Kasim Dale, 24, Chris Ferguson III, 37, Una Bethune, 30, Corlis Williams, 43, Donald Mays, 42, and Absalom Giddings, 30 -- all appeared to have been shot to death with a similar weapon, said Lee A. Solomon, the prosecutor. The reward for information about the crimes has been increased to $25,000 from $10,000, the prosecutor said. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANSEN, RUTH CATHERINE UNGER
description: HANSEN-Ruth Catherine Unger. A native of New York, wife of the late Nelson Hansen, died in Cabrini Medical Center, February 18, 2002. Born November 2, 1911, daughter of the late George and Margaret Mulligan Unger. A member of the administrative staff of Bellevue Hospital for more than 40 years. After she retired, she enrolled at the College of New Rochelle and received her Bachelor of Arts degree at age 70. She is survived by her cousin, Kathleen M. Ross of Westin, CT. A mass of Christian burial will be held on Friday, February 22nd at 11 AM in Church of the Epiphany, Manhattan. Interment Calvary Cemetery, Long Island City, New York.

title: Finding New Ways To Duck and Cover
description: A cold-water immersion suit and a camouflage evening gown are part of ''Comfort Zone,'' an exhibition in Philadelphia, with Ellen Lupton as curator. The show's theme is refuge or, as Ms. Lupton puts it, the need ''to insulate against enemies from within and without.'' The SLAK jacket by Jurgen Bey inflates into a portable shelter. (''Slak'' is also Dutch for snail.) A coat called Mobile Dreaming (below) by Hella Jongerius turns into a blanket with houndstooth sleeves. Most exhibits guard against chills, snipers or germs. Polaris International designed a tent to protect postal workers from anthrax. Emily Keown took on noise, knitting sound-muffling cozies for an egg timer, a hammer and a popcorn maker. Through April 20, except Sundays, at the Fabric Workshop and Museum, 1315 Cherry Street, Philadelphia; (215) 568-1111. Free. JULIE LASKY

title: New Jersey Education Chief Allowed to Scale Back Exams
description: In a decision that may pave the way for a major overhaul of New Jersey's standardized testing, the state attorney general has determined that the new education commissioner can unilaterally cut several components from next month's exams.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAINES, G. ROGER
description: HAINES-G. Roger, 91. Of Greenwich, CT, died on February 19, a native of London, he spent his insurance career with Phoenix Assurance Co. and later Continental Insurance Co. He retired in 1976 as Vice President of Continental and President and director of Phoenix London Group. During his career he was based in London, Peru, San Francisco, Chicago, New York and spent time in more than 40 countries. He continued with extensive arbitration, consulting, and volunteer work following his retirement. He received the 1995 Greenwich Time Community Leader Award. A Memorial service will be held February 23, at 11 A.M. at First Presbyterian Church of Greenwich. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Call-ARide or TechnoServe.

title: 2 Parents Not Always Best For Children, Study Finds
description: Two-partner households may not necessarily be better for poor children than single-parent households, researchers from Johns Hopkins have found.

title: Hidden Currency Losses Go Back 5 Years, Irish Bank Says
description: The losses that a currency trader at a regional Maryland bank is accused of trying to hide with fictitious transactions had been mounting since 1997, rather than just over the last year, bank executives said today.

title: Top Court Hears Argument On Execution of Retarded
description: Thirteen years ago, the Supreme Court refused to declare that the Constitution categorically barred the execution of retarded people, ruling that ''there is insufficient evidence of a national consensus'' from which to conclude that such executions violated the country's ''evolving standards of decency.''

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Online Sales Rise 13% In Quarter
description: Retail sales over the Internet in the fourth quarter of 2001 were up 13 percent, compared with the October-December period a year earlier, the Commerce Department said. The statistics were not adjusted to account for holiday sales or other seasonal factors. Total sales on the Web were about $10 billion in the fourth quarter, up from roughly $7.5 billion in the third quarter of 2001 and up from $8.8 billion in the fourth quarter of 2000. Total retail sales on the Web in 2001, based on a survey of 11,000 businesses and excluding some popular online transactions like airline tickets and brokerage services, surged to more than $32 billion, up 19 percent from the preceding year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN ALEN, CANDACE A.
description: VAN ALEN-Candace A. One of the tireless supporters of the Soldiers', Sailors', Marines' and Airmen's Club, Candy Van Alen left us peacefully on the morning ofTuesday, 19 February, 2002. Without her indefatigable efforts and generosity, SSMAC would have been hard put to survive the many years of public disinterest in things Military that followed World War II. She and her late husband, Jimmy, who was President of the Club during three successive terms, were ever prime movers in a cause that addresed the dire need of Servicemen and Servicewomen for a safe and affordable home away from home as they transited our great city on their way to new tours of duty elsewhere. She set a high standard for our wholly volunteer Board of Directors and Advisors, one that, thanks to her, will endure despite the uncertanties confronting us in the Twenty-First Century. Candy Van Alen was one of a kind, and we at SSMAC are eternally grateful for her many, many kindnesses throughout the years. R.I.P. Ivan Obolensky, Chairman Joseph Koletar, President

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   RAFSKY, ROBERT ALAN
description: RAFSKY-Robert Alan July 22, 1945-February 21, 1993 Lovingly remembered today and every day.

title: Metro Matters; For Red Cross, A New Round Of Complaints
description: THE American Red Cross just cannot seem to catch a sustained break. The first time it got in trouble, for its plan to reserve some Sept. 11 donations for future needs, it made a comeback by pleading guilty, toppling its president and reversing policy.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: 3 Accused Of Moving Fraud
description: Three men were accused yesterday of operating moving companies that set artificially low prices and then essentially held customers' furniture hostage until they paid inflated bills, federal prosecutors in Brooklyn said. The men were identified as Avinoam Damti, Barry Minsky and Ofer Yosef. They were arrested after investigators said their companies, including On-Time Van Lines and Starving Students Moving and Storage, fraudulently advertised on the Internet and elsewhere to get customers. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: Live Klezmer Punctuates This Modernist Megillah
description: The story of Queen Esther, who saved her fellow Jews from death in the Persian Empire, is retold annually in the Jewish festival of Purim. On Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater, the same tale was retold in somewhat abstract form in ''Purim, the Casting of Fate,'' a two-act dance piece presented by the Gyor National Ballet Theater from Hungary.

title: EL PASO SAYS FIRST-QUARTER RESULTS WILL MISS FORECAST
description: The El Paso Corporation, an energy company, reiterated its 2002 earnings forecast but said earnings in the first quarter would be below the expectations of analysts because of low natural gas prices. It also announced yesterday that it was assuming an additional $2 billion of debt from its two off-balance-sheet financing ventures. It projected annual earnings of $3.30 to $3.45 a share. A Thomson Financial/First Call survey of 19 analysts produced a 2002 earnings estimate of $3.38 a share. The energy company said it expected first-quarter earnings of 85 cents to 89 cents a share, compared with analysts' projections of 93 cents a share. The stock, was off 7 cents, to $36.24, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Amid the Byways, Sure of His Direction
description: The Young Concert Artists Series is happily and proudly maintaining its 42-year record of creating win-win situations. Musicians just starting their careers get a helping hand, and New York audiences get some memorable nights, like Tuesday evening, when the Russian cellist Alexandre Bouzlov gave a recital with the pianist Noreen Cassidy-Polera at the 92nd Street Y.

title: Making a Point in an Old Debate, but Not Settling the Issue
description: An old argument, never likely to be resolved, concerns the opening lead from three low cards. A majority of modern tournament players favor the lowest card, which fits into the tendency to lead third and fifth rather than fourth best. But there are two splinter groups. Traditionalists favor ''top of nothing,'' and some heretics believe in MUD, which means leading the Middle card followed by Up and Down.

title: Kwan and Cohen Entering Finale With Momentum
description: In front of staid international figure skating judges unfamiliar with her style, Sasha Cohen was impervious to the pressure of making an Olympic first impression, living by the teenage mantra ''yeah, whatever.''

title: John Gardner's Vision
description: To the Editor:

title: Fourth Gold Medal For a Positive Thinker
description: Ole Einar Bjoerndalen, a Norwegian biathlete, won his fourth gold medal of the 2002 Winter Olympics today, proving that skis, a gun, a guru and a vacuum cleaner make for a great champion.

title: Snapshots of a Company, Its Past and Its Present
description: Monte/Brown Dance presented one of the oldest and three of the newest works in its repertory on Friday night at the Joyce Theater.

title: Forget Technical Merit If Earrings Miss Mark
description: For the home version of Olympic judging, we had no fur coats, no pressure from the French federation, no champagne in the waiting room, no payment for our work and no pretense at objectivity.

title: Kidnappers Killed Reporter, Journal and U.S. Officials Say
description: Daniel Pearl, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal who was abducted a month ago in Pakistan, was killed by his captors, the State Department and executives of his newspaper said today.

title: INTIMATE BRANDS TO REVIEW OFFER FROM THE LIMITED
description: Intimate Brands Inc., the owner of the Victoria's Secret lingerie stores, said yesterday that, pending a review, it was unable to decide on the unsolicited offer of the Limited Inc. to buy back the 16 percent stake of Intimate Brands it does not already own. Intimate Brands said it had formed a three-member committee of independent directors to consider the $1.49 billion offer, scheduled to expire on March 11. The company asked shareholders not to tender their stock until the panel took a position. A decision in favor of the offer by the Limited would combine Intimate Brands with its parent, which sold the 16 percent stake to the public in 1995 for $680 million, or $17 a share.

title: The Math: How It All Added Up to a Hughes Gold
description: To get the final ranking in the figure skating competition, the placement from the short program is multiplied by one half. That number is then added to the placement from the long program. The skater with the smallest resulting number wins the competition. If there is a tie, the skater who received the higher ranking in the long program is the winner.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: C.I.A. SEES THREAT AFGHAN FACTIONS MAY BRING CHAOS
description: The Central Intelligence Agency has warned in a classified report that Afghanistan could once again fall into violent chaos if steps are not taken to restrain the competition for power among rival warlords and to control ethnic tensions, senior American officials said today.

title: This Is a Job For Supercleaner
description: Red wine on the tablecloth -- reach for salt or club soda? Jerry Pozniak of Cameo Cleaners says that salt can bleach colored fabrics and that club soda is the same as plain water. His advice is to blot with a clean dry cloth and then get a professional cleaning. Mr. Pozniak, who was trained at both the New York School of Dry Cleaning and at the French Culinary Institute in Manhattan, is a specialist in food-related stains. He says he has a 95 percent success rate, if a stain has not been left too long. The cost is $30 to $75 to clean a tablecloth, $5 to $15 each for napkins. House calls in Manhattan to spot-clean furniture or rugs are $100 for the first hour, $65 for each additional hour. Cameo Cleaners is at 284 Third Avenue (22nd Street); (212) 677-3949. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Colombian Rebels Hijack a Plane and Kidnap a Senator
description: Colombian guerrillas hijacked a domestic flight today, forcing it down on a remote highway in the south in order to kidnap a senior senator who had been on board. Hours later, President Andrs Pastrana broke off peace talks with Colombia's largest rebel group.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Governor Proposes Cuts
description: Gov. George Ryan proposed a $52.8 billion budget for the next fiscal year that would cut 3,800 jobs from the state work force and reduce the amount spent on medical services for the poor by about $530 million. Governor Ryan, a Republican who is not seeking a second term, proposed closing two prisons and a mental health center to deal with lower than expected tax revenue. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: Group Seeks Tax on Big Incomes To Solve Nassau's Fiscal Crisis
description: Grass-roots campaigns for new taxes are seldom seen in politics, but a coalition started pushing today for a local tax on high incomes to solve Nassau County's fiscal crisis.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Another Warning From Cable And Wireless
description: Cable and Wireless, the world's biggest manager of corporate Web sites, delivered its third warning in the last year that sales and profits would be lower than forecast. The news sent the company's shares to their lowest level in 10 years. Cable and Wireless said sales at its global division, its biggest unit, would be down 10 percent in the year through March 31, compared with an earlier forecast of a 5 percent fall. The company blamed difficult market conditions. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Learning to Navigate Where the Invisible Clues Have Changed
description: Past the turnstiles at 42nd Street, just when everyone else wants to hit top speed, Eddie Montanez throttles himself down a notch. Still moving, yes, but slower, more deliberately. Rushing is for people with eyes that still work, and for those who do not have to cut new paths across the city because their old routes were ripped asunder on Sept. 11.

title: INSIDE
description: Call for One Korea

title: Market Place; Disclosure Is Now Name Of the Game For More Banks
description: Executives at many companies are telling analysts and investors to expect more detailed disclosures in their year-end filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Amtrak Workers Charged In Phone Scheme
description: Eighteen Amtrak workers have been charged with using credit and telephone calling cards lost or forgotten by Amtrak passengers to place $100,000 worth of calls from telephones on the trains. The Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, said yesterday that some employees face up to 15 years in prison. From 1997 to 2000, the employees placed 47,000 minutes of long-distance and international calls, the authorities said. The employees, accused of criminal possession of stolen property and other charges, repaired and cleaned trains at Amtrak's train yard in Sunnyside, Queens. Sarah Kershaw (NYT)

title: 5 Umpires Are Said to Be Near Reinstatement
description: Five umpires who lost their jobs because of a disastrous labor strategy a season and a half ago are on their way back to work.

title: As Children Adopt Pets, A Game Adopts Them
description: FOR domesticated critters, Allyn Morse's house pets are curiously high-maintenance. In addition to the daily feeding and the occasional grooming, 10-year-old Allyn reads aloud to her three pets so their brains can stay razor-sharp. To thrive, her pets must also endure an ever changing series of games and grueling competitions with other pets. If they don't taste the thrill of victory with some regularity, they can perish.

title: Inspired by Museum-Class Costumes
description: ''It was ribbons, embroidery and buttons that inspired us,'' said Mark Pollack, the design director of Pollack, a Manhattan textile maker with 18 new fabrics based on costumes in the Rhode Island School of Design Museum. From left, Peek-a-Boo ($85 a yard in a silk-linen blend) from a 1920's French dress, Trs Chic (embroidered silk-polyester, $185 a yard) from an 1880's French jacket and Oh My! (viscose-nylon, $75 a yard) from lace on a 1912 American gown. To the trade only, 979 Third Avenue (58th Street); (212) 421-8755. ELAINE LOUIE

title: Friesinger (First) and Rodriguez (Third) Are the Toast of Their Towns
description: Cut to City Hall in Inzell, Germany, where Anni Friesinger knew that the Bavarian beer was flowing in her hometown in honor of her gold medal.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRIEDHOFF, ARNOLD J., M.D.
description: FRIEDHOFF-Arnold J., M.D. February 21, 2001. In loving memory of a dear husband, father and grandfather. Sorely missed today and every day.

title: Israel Steps Up Counterstrikes; 22 Arabs Slain
description: Israeli tanks rolled into Gaza City and missiles were fired for a second day at Yasir Arafat's compound in Ramallah as the Israeli Army kept up a fierce offensive today in retaliation for the killing of six Israeli soldiers in the West Bank on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDSTEIN, ANNA (NEE LANDAU)
description: FELDSTEIN-Anna (nee Landau). Died peacefully February 19, 2002 at the age of 92. She is survived by her sons Arthur and Fred, daughter-in-law Joan and granddaughter Lori. Service 11:30AM today, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 St and Amsterdam Av. Burial to follow Mount Ararat Cemetery.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: Accused Nazi's Citizenship Revoked Again
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21  In a case that has alternately haunted and humiliated the Justice Department for more than two decades, a federal judge today revoked the United States citizenship of John Demjanjuk, an 81-year old retired Cleveland auto worker, who prosecutors charged was a Nazi death camp guard during World War II.

title: Ikea Names Crispin To Handle Account
description: Ikea, the home furnishings retailer based in Plymouth Meeting, Pa., owned by Ikea Svenska, said yesterday that it had named Crispin, Porter & Bogusky in Miami to handle its account. Billings were estimated at $40 million to $50 million.

title: Families Try to Trace Thousands of Missing Taliban, Many Forced to Fight
description: They sat on chairs or crouched on the floor in their turbans and shawls, faces turned in hope toward the young clerk at the computer. But one after another, the men silently moved away from the desk, the shock and pain only discernible in the fixed stare of their eyes.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Treasury Chief Accuses World Bank of Harming Poor Countries
description: Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill said today that the World Bank had driven poor countries ''into a ditch'' by lending instead of donating funds to fight poverty, and he sharply criticized allies for failing to back a plan to revamp aid policies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NABATOFF, DR. ROBERT A.
description: NABATOFF-Dr. Robert A. Beloved husband of Joan. Dear father of Diane, Ross and Richard. Loving grandfather of Alison, Andrew and Nathan. Devoted brother of Gene Norman, Sylvia Mandelbaum and the late Ruth Lichtenstein. Services on Friday. February 22, 12 noon at Temple Emanu-El Fifth Avenue at 65th St. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Mount Sinai Hospital in his honor, where he spent fifty years of service.

description: To the Editor:

title: Twins Up for Sale; Will Likely Survive
description: A target of the owners' contraction plan for three months this winter, the Minnesota Twins were formally placed on sale yesterday. The decision virtually guarantees that the Twins will not be eliminated after the coming season in the next contraction attempt.

title: An Investor Traveling An Unusual Career Path
description: The business relationship of Gary Winnick and Steven J. Green traces to the 1980's, when Mr. Winnick was a lieutenant of the junk bond king Michael R. Milken at Drexel Burnham Lambert.

title: Losing Pseudonym, Gaining Notoriety
description: From childhood, Mohamed Moulessehoul dreamed of being a writer. Yet by the time his fiction was recognized, no one knew he was the author.

description: A few observations after two weeks writing about and contemplating the world's best skiers:

title: 4 Arrested in Plot Against U.S. Embassy in Rome
description: The Italian police arrested four Moroccan nationals today, who they found with nine pounds of a cyanide compound and a map pinpointing the location of the water pipes that lead to the American Embassy here.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Mother Arrested In School Truancy
description: A Queens mother has been charged with preventing her daughter from attending school so that the girl, who is now 17, could baby-sit for two step-brothers and do housework, the police said. The woman, Sita Singh, 41, of Ozone Park, was arrested on Tuesday and charged with endangering the welfare of a child, the police said. The daughter, Kavita Raghoo, missed 23 days of school in 1998, then 69 days in 1999, according to court papers. On June 11, 1999, Ms. Singh withdrew her daughter from school, telling the authorities that her daughter would live in Guyana. But the girl later told the police that she returned after a two-week visit. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Panel's Ruling on Royalties Is Setback for Web Radio Services
description: The fledgling Internet radio industry was handed a setback yesterday as a government arbitration panel said online radio stations should pay recording companies nearly 10 times what the Webcasters had proposed for the songs they play.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEITZER, MILDRED
description: SCHNEITZER-Mildred. Died February 20, 2002. Beloved wife of 50 years to Herbert, who predeceased her. Dear mother of Leila Schneitzer Wilner. Mother-in-law of Gregg Wilner. Cherished grandma of Jordan and Harris Wilner. Services Friday 10 AM at I.J. Morris, 1895 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn. Interment to follow, New Montefiore Cemetery. Donations in her memory to the Poverty Fund, UJA Federation, 130 East 59 St., New York, NY 10022. May she rest in peace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, HENRY
description: COOPER-Henry age 96. Born September 6, 1906, Bar, Ukraine. Died February 16, 2002, Baltimore, Maryland. Cantor Emeritus, Har Sinai Congregation, Baltimore, and portrait painter: Roberta Peters (Metropolitan Opera House) Golda Meier (Hadassah Hospital, Jerusalem), 27 portraits in The National Jockeys Hall of Fame Pimlico. Graduate: Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts and Gratz College. Survived by wife Ruth Wilen Cooper, daughters Gail CooperHecht (Stanley Saplin) New York, Deborah Sidlin (Murray Sidlin), Portland, Oregon, grandchildren Allison Hecht, New York, Nicholas Sidlin and three step-children and six step-grandchildren in Baltimore. For more information please call Sol Levinson & Bros, Baltimore, Maryland. 1 - 800 338-1701.

title: Bush Says U.S. and China Want to See Koreas Unified
description: President Bush and President Jiang Zemin of China said today that they would work together on reunification of North and South Korea, and that peace in the region was crucial to both them and the world.

title: Foundation Announces 2 New Grant Programs
description: The Howard Gilman Foundation has announced the creation of two grant programs that will award about $9 million over three years to nonprofit performing arts organizations in New York City. The grants, announced Tuesday, will be for artistic and organizational development and technical assistance for dance and for the training of young dance and theater performers.

title: Can You Hear The Chorus Of the Chairs?
description: A new line of furniture by the Manhattan architects Craig Nealy and Joan Dineen recalls the many moods of modernism. The dining chair, with a charm all its own, brings to mind Mies van der Rohe's dining chair of 1920, Jean-Michel Frank's chairs from 1938 and Gio Ponti's famed Superleggera chair of 1957. Which, after all, was the point. ''It's not made to a be a diva piece -- it's not Beverly Sills,'' Mr. Nealy said. ''It's like one of the backup singers.'' Backup singers cost money, too. The chair, made of ebonized rock maple, is $1,200 through the Dineen Nealy showroom, 49 West 38th Street, (917) 342-0060. DAVID COLMAN

title: LIN TV BUYS 6 STATIONS AND FILES FOR STOCK OFFERING
description: Lin TV said yesterday that it would buy six television stations in Texas, Ohio, Rhode Island and Michigan from Sunrise Television. Financial terms were not disclosed. Lin TV, based in Providence, R.I., and controlled by the investment firm Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, separately filed for a $300 million initial stock sale with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Lin's subsidiary, Lin Television, owns 26 network- affiliated and independent stations nationwide, and provides sales and management services for four additional stations.

title: Alomar Will Give the Mets A Player Who Does It All
description: Robbie Alomar, a 12-time All-Star and 10-time Gold Glove winner, looked sheepish today as he twirled his personalized black bat. In his first day in a Mets uniform, he was hoping no one would notice that the bat manufacturer had spelled his last name wrong: Alomr. But he laughed off the embarrassment. He was feeling too good.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: Anti-Terrorism Hearing
description: The City Council has scheduled a public hearing to hear a status report on the New York Police Department's antiterrorism task force. Committee Room, City Hall, Manhattan, 10 a.m. Information: (718) 274-4500.

title: Corrections
description: The E-Commerce Report column in Business Day on Monday about the business challenges of Internet radio broadcasting misstated the origin of a 300 percent premium paid to actors in radio commercials that are also played on the Web. The fee was set by advertisers, advertising agencies and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists. It was not required by the United States Copyright Office.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Adobe Introducing Image Campaign
description: Adobe Systems in San Jose, Calif., is introducing a brand image advertising campaign carrying the theme ''Tools for the new work,'' which is meant to sell the company's products like page-layout software to design and creative professionals. The campaign will appear first in metropolitan New York, with signs and billboards placed at or near advertising agencies and design companies. The humorous campaign, with a budget of $3.25 million, is the first for Adobe from the agency it hired in November, Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco, a division of the Omnicom Group. One ad promises that using Abode products ''means you can work faster. Or, if you prefer, slack more.'' Stuart Elliott (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WATTLES, ELIZABETH
description: WATTLES-Elizabeth. Died on February 19, 2002. Loving sister of Gurdon W. Wattles of Bedminster, NJ. A graveside service will be held on February 27, 2002 at 11:00 AM at the New Vernon Cemetery. There will be no visitation hours. For information Gallaway & Crane Funeral Home, 101 South Finley Ave., Basking Ridge, NJ.

title: Searchers Say Rare Woodpecker Was Possibly Heard, if Not Seen
description: A team that spent 30 days in a swampy Louisiana forest looking for a woodpecker long thought to be extinct reported yesterday that members may have heard the bird, but they did not see it.

description: And What About Samantha?

title: A Higher Power, but No Power Tools
description: WHEN Iwao Nakajima was testing a piece of red cedar last fall at the Home Depot near his home in Hauppauge, N.Y., he stroked it to check its density, sniffed it and even licked it to see if it was sweet.

title: Jospin Jumps Into the Race For President Of France
description: Surprising no one except with his timing, Prime Minister Lionel Jospin declared today that he will run for president of France.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SETTEL, IRVING
description: SETTEL-Irving, 85. Died February 19th, 2002. Beloved husband of Trudy, loving father of Ken and Joanne, cherished grandfather of Jennifer, Daniel, Ethan, Willie and Maya, dear father-in-law of Linda and Barry. Teacher, mentor and devoted friend. Funeral services February 21st, 10 AM at Temple Ohabei Shalom, Brookline, MA.

title: Tanqueray and Stolichnaya start intense efforts to gain in the ''white goods'' liquor market.
description: TWO major imported brands of distilled spirits are emerging with campaigns from new agencies intended to help them keep up in the highly competitive ''white goods'' category of the American liquor market.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about spending by the New York City Board of Education last year referred imprecisely to spending for classroom instruction. The share of spending devoted to the classroom, not the amount of the money spent, remained flat.

title: Grant Program Meant to Keep A Population Downtown
description: The group overseeing the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan is expected to approve today a $200 million program of grants to downtown residents or those who move downtown and commit to staying there for two years, city and state officials said yesterday.

title: Stirring Souls With Sound and Vision
description: ''The devil is so mad that we're up in this place tonight,'' said the Rev. Hezekiah Walker, authoritative and serene in his white leather suit from the stage of Radio City Music Hall. This was far from the Love Fellowship Tabernacle, Mr. Walker's church on Liberty Avenue in East New York, Brooklyn. But at Saturday night's concert, recorded for Mr. Walker's next album, the audience drove him on, tabernacle style.

title: Chewing Up a Fragile Land
description: For many Americans, the Bush administration energy plan, developed by Vice President Dick Cheney with the help of a task force whose deliberations he will not reveal, is an abstraction at best, and at worst a secret. Here in the redrock desert of southern Utah, it is literally an earth-shaking reality.

title: Enlisting Ice as an Ally of Skiers and Aircraft
description: When Olympic skiers plunge down Utah's slopes at speeds approaching 100 miles an hour, the result may be a medal. But for weekend skiers trying to emulate them, extremely high speeds are more likely lead to a dangerous loss of control.

title: SHARES OF COMPUTER ASSOCIATES DECLINE 17%
description: Shares of Computer Associates International slid 17 percent yesterday after published reports that the F.B.I. had opened an inquiry into how the company recorded sales of software and maintenance fees. The shares of Computer Associates, the fifth-largest software maker, declined $4.40, to $20.91. The company is unaware of an inquiry and has not been contacted by the authorities, Computer Associates said in a statement. Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn have opened a preliminary inquiry into whether Computer Associates deliberately overstated its profits to inflate its stock price and enrich its senior executives, two people close to the investigation said.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Jim Firestone was named account planning director at Oasis, New York, succeeding Sally Spriggs, who is relocating to Australia, her native country, the agency said. Mr. Firestone had been vice president and senior account planner at Deutsch, part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Oasis is part of the Dentsu Business Development Group, a unit of Dentsu.

title: An Artist Who's Grateful For Elephants
description: For a decade Mya, Layang Layang and Dilberta have been the unheralded contributors to Chris Ofili's rise to fame. The three Asian elephants, visited nearly every month by Mr. Ofili, the British-born painter, replenish the supply of dung that he uses in nearly all his paintings, including the one of a black Virgin Mary that enraged former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani when it appeared in the ''Sensation'' exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum of Art in 1999.

title: Inquiry Into a Link Between Global Crossing and a Dot-Com
description: Global Crossing said late yesterday that it would ask its audit committee and its outside law firm to review its association and deals with Withit.com, a Chicago Internet company run by the son of Joseph Perrone, Global's executive vice president for finance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEVENSON, JOHN

description: It has been here for at least a decade, quietly chewing its way through the city's beloved maples and elms, leaving barren neighborhoods and parks in its wake. First discovered in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, it appeared in Queens, Long Island and Manhattan, before finally, disappointingly, wreaking its telltale damage within the stone walls of Central Park, uncovered at the end of last month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARGOLIS, BERT
description: MARGOLIS-Bert. The Camp Greylock Directors, Staff, Alumni, and Community mourn the passing of one of its most beloved and longest serving Directors who passed away February 19, 2002 at his home in New York City. Born May 12, 1917 in Montgomery, WV, Bert attended Greylock as a camper and a counselor. He served as an officer in the Army Air Corps before joining the Greylock Directorate in 1949, retiring as Director Emeritus in 1995. Bert was a pioneer in children's summer camping, where his model of teaching balanced excellence in instruction with insistence on kindness, and fair play. His intolerance for bullies was years ahead of its time. Through his vision and compassion, Bert inspired many. He is survived by his wife, Barbara, his sister Elaine, his daughters: Margaret, Katherine, Elizabeth, and Victoria, and nine grandchildren. He will be missed.

description: President Bush's decision this month to reverse himself and apply the Geneva Conventions to the Afghan war came after the Pentagon and State Department lined up against the administration's top lawyers, senior administration officials now say.

title: SPIEGEL TO SELL CREDIT BUSINESS AND CLOSE 40 STORES
description: Spiegel, the owner of Spiegel and Newport News catalogs, plans to sell its credit card business and close 40 Eddie Bauer stores. The company disclosed the news while reporting its fourth-quarter results yesterday. It said it lost $378.1 million, or $2.86 a share, in contrast to net income of $65.4 million, or 50 cents, a year earlier. Sales fell 13 percent, to $1.01 billion. The company said it had enough liquidity and cash flow to finance day-to-day operations. Spiegel, based in Downers Grove, Ill., said it had put a plan in place to sell its credit card business, including its First Consumers National Bank subsidiary.

description: In an extraordinary expression of frustration over questionable judging, leaders of the Russian Olympic delegation threatened today to pull their team out of the Salt Lake Games and future Olympics over the treatment of their athletes in three sports here.

title: Corrections

title: A Tale of 2 Neighbors, Both Pains in the Neck
description: Michael Kalesniko's acerbic comedy, ''How to Kill Your Neighbor's Dog,'' is a Hollywood rarity, a movie about an icy grown-up heart-warmed by a child that doesn't wield emotional pliers to try to squeeze out tears. That frosty heart belongs to Peter McGowan (Kenneth Branagh), a whiny, cynical British-American playwright, nicknamed America's Favorite Bastard, who lives comfortably in a Los Angeles suburb with his wife, Melanie (Robin Wright Penn).

title: View of the Other Matisse: Dealer, Patron and Son
description: Henri Matisse turned out some of the masterpieces of the 20th century, not the least of them his son Pierre. More interested in selling art than in making it, Pierre (1900-1989) set out to be a painter himself, but wound up as one of the century's most influential dealers in modern European works. Migrating to New York as a young man, he became a persuasive agent in guiding American museums and collectors toward acceptance and appreciation of this art.

Loving husband of Elaine, devoted father of Leonard (Michelle) Tucker, Daniel (Renee) Tucker, Gary (Beth) Tucker, Stefanie (Chad) Schreibman, Janet (Paul) Lesniak & David (Colleen Kelley) Perlmutter. Loving son of Mary Tucker, dear brother of Bruce (Peggy) Tucker & Jill (Steven) Hurtig. Papa Jerry is also survived by grandchildren Shayna, Hannah, Montana, Cameron, Jesse, Quinn, Kyle, Felicia, Cori, Jenna & Jacob. In lieu of flowers, donations to the American Heart Association and/ or The National Kidney Foundation would be greatly appreciated. Services Sunday, February 24, 2002 at 1:30 P.M., at RiversideMenorah Chapel, 6701 West Commercial Blvd., Tamarac, Florida (954) 721-1877. title: U.S. Reaches Gold Medal Game

They will meet on a big indoor sheet of ice in the western highlands of their vast continent in the championship game of the Olympic hockey tournament on Sunday afternoon. Although no one will say so officially, it is the game the National Hockey League most desired when it committed to Olympic participation two Winter Games ago.

title: WATCHING MOVIES WITH/Nicole Kidman; A Perfectionist's Pupil With a Major in Creepy
description: THE first time Nicole Kidman saw ''The Shining,'' she was 14 and spent most of the movie paying more attention to her 16-year-old boyfriend than to what was happening on the screen. ''I was meant to be going roller-skating at this rink in Sydney,'' she said. ''But we decided to ditch that and go see a movie. I really wasn't supposed to be in there. I was too young, as I recall, but he got me in. I looked older. And I kind of watched a bit of the movie, but really, I made out through most of it.''

title: A World Tournament For Words and Action
description: THE global gathering of hockey tribes for the Olympic tournament, and the terrific games that have been played, gives this sport the group therapy it needs. Conflicts of philosophy and culture are debated along with rules. The word ''hate'' was used seriously by the most famous name in the game. Other power brokers sat side by side and disagreed about Olympic participation. These discussions are as refreshing as the fast, energetic and artistic shows put on by the elite players on the larger international ice.

This is a bona fide tale of passion, tears and the kind of ecstasy that comes from endorphins flooding the nervous system. Yes, ''Elaine Stritch at Liberty'' has opened at the Neil Simon Theater.

description: ROBERTS-Myron, M.D. The Boards, Faculty, and Staff of NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital and Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons deeply mourn the passing of our distinguished colleague Dr. Myron Roberts. For 41 years until his retirement in 1997, he was an invaluable member of the Department of Urology-an excellent surgeon and diagnostician, a knowledgeable consultant, and, above all, an outstanding teacher, who trained generations of the country's leading urologists. He was a winner of Columbia Presbyterian's Distinguished Practitioner Award. We extend our deepest and heartfelt condolences to his family. Herbert Pardes, M.D. President & CEO NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital Gerald Fischbach, M.D. Executive Vice President for Health & Biomedical Sciences Dean of the Faculty of Medicine Columbia University

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Coal Acquisition
description: A Swiss commodities company, Xstrata, plans to buy the Australian and South African coal business of Glencore International, and list on the London Stock Exchange. Xstrata, which is based in Zug, Switzerland, will pay $2.5 billion for the mines owned by Glencore, a closely held commodities trading company started by the fugitive billionaire trader Marc Rich, who sold out in 1993. Glencore holds a stake of about 40 percent in Xstrata. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

This was the same game her ancestors had invented hundreds of years ago on the frozen ponds of Scotland, the same calling that had sent her around the world in pursuit of the highest accolades in the sport.

The most reasonable judgment at this point is that the outside air in Lower Manhattan is safe to breathe and that indoor spaces that have been properly cleaned are fine as well. The main concern is a few hot spots outdoors and whether some apartments or offices need a better cleaning than they have previously received.

title: The Armory Show, Grown Up and in Love With Color
description: The Armory Show has survived its growth spurt. Last year it shot up to 170 dealers from fewer than 100, moved into two big piers on the Hudson River and experienced some moments of adolescent awkwardness. There were problems moving art in, getting it on the walls and finding a decent snack. Many dealers grumbled, but they seem to have been heard. The New York dealers who founded the fair, back at the Gramercy Hotel in 1994, have handed over its administration to full-time professionals, and much has been ironed out.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: State Of Emergency Extended
description: Parliament voted overwhelmingly to extend for three months a state of emergency imposed in November to battle a Maoist rebellion that has spread to much of the nation. Over the weekend rebels staged the deadliest attack of their six-year revolt, killing more than 130 people -- mostly police officers and soldiers -- in Achham and Doti districts, 375 miles northwest of Katmandu. The army counterattacked on Wednesday, killing 48 rebels, the Defense Ministry said. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

Governor Ventura has not said whether he will veto it.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Nazi Loses Court Appeal

Malloth, 90, was one of the most feared guards at the concentration camp at Theresienstadt, now Terezin, in Nazi-occupied Czechoslovakia. He evaded justice for nearly 50 years before being arrested in 2000 in a home for the elderly in Bavaria. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: PG&E REVIEWS CLASSIFICATION OF POWER PLANT LEASES
description: The PG&E Corporation, whose California utility filed for bankruptcy protection last year, delayed reporting fourth-quarter earnings yesterday as it reviewed whether to reclassify power plant leases as debt on financial statements dating back to 1999. The company may add $1 billion to total assets and liabilities, a move that would not affect net income, a spokesman, Greg Pruett, said. PG&E executives and auditors from Deloitte & Touche discovered the possible overpayments Wednesday night, Mr. Pruett said. The review related to so-called synthetic leases, which were used for two power plants. PG&E set up partnerships to finance the $1.15 billion cost of building the plants. Outside investors held 3 percent of the trusts. PG&E is now investigating whether the deal met the qualifications for synthetic leases, which are allowed under generally accepted accounting principles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOULKOS, PETER
description: VOULKOS-Peter. Friends of Contemporary Ceramics are deeply saddened by the death of Peter Voulkos, the leading figure in Postwar American ceramics, on February 16. Voulkos, whose exhibition record spans over five decades, had an international impact as the leader of a revolutionary movement in contemporary ceramics. Respected by critics, museum curators, and artists around the world, Voulkos' work is included in over eighty museums. He is the recipient of six honorary doctorates and other honors too numerous to mention. Pete was an extraordinary man, loved and respected by his fellow artists. Like the Pied Piper, where Pete went, artists were sure to follow, be it a workshop, the opening of a Voulkos exhibition or a dinner. Everyone wanted to be around Pete. We will all miss him very much. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife Ann Adair Voulkos, their son Aris, and Pier Voulkos, his daughter from a previous marriage. Linda Leonard Schlenger Founding Chairman Friends of Contemporary Ceramics

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUPFERMANN, IRVING, PH.D.
description: KUPFERMANN-Irving, Ph.D., on Tuesday, February 19, 2002, at home. Neuroscientist and beloved husband of Kirsten, loving father of his children David and Celina Poole, and grandfather to new and cherished Justin Paul Poole, father-in-law to Patty Kupfermann and Jonathan Poole. In addition to his warmth and kindness, Irving was notorious as an inveterate punster. He was known to all as adventurer, jazz connoisseur and avid tenor saxophonist, lover of movies, theater, and modern dance, and one who brought scientific precision to the game of golf. He delighted in photographing fire hydrants in elegant settings worldwide, sometimes featuring friends and colleagues. He was a valued member of the New York scientific community, first at New York University and later at Columbia University and New York State Psychiatric Institute where he was a faculty member for twenty-nine years. Irving was unique, a compassionate and understanding listener to all who sought his advice and counsel. Family, friends and colleagues will gather to celebrate his life on Sunday, March 3, 1-5 PM at the Faculty Club of the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, 630 West 168th Street, New York, NY 10032. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that memorial contributions be sent to Planned Parenthood, Amnesty International, Sierra Club; Hospice Care Network, 900 Merchant's Concourse, Westbury, NY 11590; or, Donations for Prion Research, 44 Montgomery St., Suite 2200; San Francisco, CA 94104-0248 (Check payable to: UC RegentsUniversity of San Francisco).

title: Editorial Observer; All of New York on the Same Page
description: It seems like such a simple, worthwhile idea. Invite all the residents of a city, young and old alike, to read the same book during the same week, then use that common literary ground to strike up a civic conversation about literature, about reading, about each other, about almost anything. The idea has worked in other cities, like Chicago, which read ''To Kill a Mockingbird,'' by Harper Lee, last year. And perhaps it would have worked in New York if New York had done it first, with no one else paying particular attention. The idea of having a New York City-read isn't dead yet. But perhaps it should be.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Military Escort For Jet
description: A passenger jetliner from Miami was escorted safely to Newark International Airport by two F-16 fighters last night after the captain inadvertently sent a message to the Miami tower that the plane had been hijacked, the authorities said. The plane, American Airlines Flight 882, which took off at 7:30 p.m., landed at 10:15 p.m., said Dan Bledsoe, a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. The signal was sent about an hour into the flight, which was scheduled to end at Newark. The tower contacted airline officials, who were able to contact the captain, said John Hotard, a spokesman for American Airlines. The captain was unaware that the signal had been sent. The airline then notified military officials to say the signal had been a false alarm, but the F-16s accompanied the plane to Newark anyway, Mr. Hotard said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENGE, JOHN (JACK)
description: MENGE-John (Jack). Of Lyme, New Hampshire, who was born in Milwaukee, Wisconsin on March 17, 1927, died this week, leaving his ex-wife Geneva, his four children Rich, Karen, Lissa and Susan, eight grandchildren and many friends and colleagues. Jack earned his B.A. from the University of Idaho and his Ph.D. from MIT. He went to Dartmouth in 1956 where he held various positions including Chairman of the Economics Department. He retired in 1999 as the longest serving professor at Dartmouth. At the time of his death, he was serving as an outside director of the Yankee Farm Credit Bank (New Hampshire, Vermont and Northeast New York). In addition to his professional activities, Professor Menge devoted himself to improving education in New Hampshire. He was elected to the State Legislature as the first democrat to be elected from the Lyme-Orford District in 200 years. As a legislator, he was an early proponent of a state income tax. Jack also made maple syrup on his 220 acre farm. His greatest accomplishment though, was his role as a father and grandfather. A service will be held Saturday, February 23rd, 2PM at Lyme Congregational Church. A reception will follow in the Church Hall. Memorial contributions may be made to the Jack Menge Fund, Lyme Foundation, POB 292, Lyme, N.H. 03769. A memorial service will be held at Dartmouth College later this year.

title: A Writer Holds It All In, At Least From His Family
description: Legend has it that Mississippi is home to more writers per capita than any other state in the union. Arliss Howard's ''Big Bad Love,'' based on stories by the Mississippi writer Larry Brown, takes place in a ripely literary corner of Dixie. Leon Barlow, the hero and narrator (played by Mr. Howard) sits at his Royal manual and bangs out lyrical prose and feverish poetry, and the world he inhabits springs from a sensibility not far from his own. In this Mississippi, a land of courtly bohemians and magic-realist oddities, country blues plays on the radio, and barroom conversations turn to the Aeneid and the Iliad -- a book, Leon tells his drinking buddy, that ''you can wear like hip waders.''

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Data Storage Products Makers To Merge
description: Legato Systems Inc., maker of data storage management products based in Mountain View, Calif., said yesterday that it would buy OTG Software Inc. for $403 million, or roughly $11.13 a share, in cash and stock. OTG of Rockville, Md., makes data storage and e-mail management software. The combined company, whose product lines are said to have little overlap, will be able to offer a more complete line of data management and protection products, officials said. Under the terms of the deal, which is expected to close before the end of the second quarter, a share of OTG common stock will be exchanged for $2.50 in cash and 0.6876 share of Legato common stock, the companies said. Richard Kay, chairman, president and chief executive of OTG, will join Legato's board after the merger. Legato's shares fell $2.43, or 19.4 percent, to $10.12. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: The Murder of Daniel Pearl
description: After nearly a month of churning rumors and contradictory reports, American and Pakistani officials announced yesterday that Daniel Pearl, the Wall Street Journal reporter who was kidnapped last month in Karachi, had been murdered by his captors. His killing is a senseless act, shattering for his family and ultimately self-defeating for those responsible. Mr. Pearl's reportorial enterprise and personal courage were admired by his colleagues and competitors alike. The world of journalism mourns his death, though it can only begin to fathom the grief of his family, particularly his wife, Mariane, now nearly seven months pregnant with their first child.

title: JUDGE CERTIFIES CLASS-ACTION STATUS IN SUIT AGAINST RAND
description: A federal judge has certified a 1996 suit brought by women employees at the RAND Corporation, the research group, as a class action. The decision, made earlier this week by Judge Richard W. Roberts of United States District Court in Washington, clears the way for a federal lawsuit. The class consists of about 250 women who worked at RAND as long ago as 1994 and as recently as 1998, said Michael D. Lieder, a partner at Sprenger & Lang in Washington, which is representing plaintiffs. The plaintiffs contend that the company discriminated against them, paying them thousands of dollars less than it paid men, he said. A lawyer for RAND played down the significance of the ruling. ''We view this simply as a step in the process,'' said Karen J. Kubin, whose law firm, Cooley Godward, is representing RAND. ''If the case does get to trial, we're confident that RAND will prevail.'' Jonathan D. Glater (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Airline's Profit Falls

About three-quarters of Qantas's business comes from its international operations, which swung to a net loss of $8 million from a net contribution to earnings of $147.9 million. Domestic operations improved; revenue rose 11 percent, to $2.95 billion. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: U.S. Says 16 Killed in Raids Weren't Taliban or Al Qaeda

title: A Not-So-Timid Woman Who Stayed in Her Seat
description: The way I'd always understood the story, Rosa Parks was a mousy, soft-spoken, middle-aged seamstress who had lived meekly with Alabama racism all her life. And one day in 1955 when a bus driver in Montgomery insisted that she vacate her seat so a white man could have it, she decided, on the spur of the moment, that she was just too fed up and too exhausted after a hard day at work to deal with this. She quietly said no. Her subsequent arrest inspired the city's bus boycott by black passengers, and that action gave the civil rights movement its start.

The company showed a design study for an updated GT40, right, at Detroit's auto show last month. Ford did not disclose details or a price.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Kazakhstan: Energy Merger
description: Kazakhstan's president, Nursultan Nazarbayev, has signed a decree merging the oil and gas company Kazakhoil and the oil and gas transportation company Transneftegaz, the two main state-owned companies. The new company will be called Kazmunaigaz and will be led by Lyazzat Kiinov, 52, the former governor of the Mangistau region in western Kazakhstan. His deputy will be the president's son-in-law, Timur Kulibayev, formerly the head of Transneftegaz. Birgit Brauer (NYT)

title: Marlene McCarty
description: American Fine Arts

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DURDIN, MARGARET (PEGGY)
description: DURDIN-Margaret (Peggy). Age 92, of pneumonia on February 12, 2002, at Silverado Senior Living, Encinitas, California. Beloved wife of the late F. Tillman Durdin, loving sister of Maude Hudson and Lena Albright, both deceased, and of brother Oscar V. Armstrong of Mitchellville, MD, & of informally ''adopted'' son Edward Chen of Hong Kong. Born in China of missionary parents, she spent many years in Asia, accompanying her husband, a New York Times correspondent and writing feature articles for various American publications. She also served as an assistant to the editor of the New York Times Magazine.

title: Corrections
description: The legend of a diagram on Wednesday with an article about the increasing use of thumbprinting for identification in fast-food restaurants and stores misspelled the name of the company that supplies the technology shown. It is Indivos, not Invidos.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Vigneti is an odd restaurant in an odd location. It's tucked into a corner of the new Library Hotel, on a block not far from the New York Public Library that becomes very quiet after the workday ends. Perhaps the unnatural hush made Vigneti's owners want to crank up the volume on the sound system, transforming what seems, from the outside, to be a charming trattoria, with rustic wooden tables and tall-backed chairs, into a throbbing, party-hearty singles bar.

title: Grand but Idle In Old Russia, A State of Denial
description: Chekhov's ''Cherry Orchard'' portrays as stingingly as any work of literature how patterns of family wealth often play out in the modern world. With devastating delicacy, it illustrates the principle of deceleration by which the idle rich allow inherited privilege to trickle through their fingers until they suddenly find themselves the idle dispossessed. In this Darwinian cycle of having and losing, the self-made nouveaux riches are panting to step into their shoes. One contemporary maxim that could be gleaned from the play is the adage to ''stay hungry.''

title: A Florida Quartet Bearing Gifts From Three Centuries
description: On Wednesday night at Alice Tully Hall, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center's guest was the Miami String Quartet, a lively and likeable group that recently completed a two-year association with the society. The ensemble played two works, Haydn's last quartet (the F major, Op. 77 No. 2) and Alberto Ginastera's first, and then was joined by Jaime Laredo and Sharon Robinson in Dvorak's String Sextet.

title: Jets' Fabini Signs 5-Year Deal
description: The Jets, who shed $14 million in Monday's expansion draft, used a chunk of it to sign left tackle Jason Fabini to a five-year deal yesterday.

title: After 5 Days, Oneida Deal Is Unraveling
description: Just five days after Gov. George E. Pataki trumpeted a tentative agreement with the Oneida Indians of New York State to end a 31-year-old dispute over a quarter of a million acres in Central New York, the deal has begun to unravel. The Oneidas of Wisconsin, a separate branch of the tribe that was shut out of the negotiations, filed 20 lawsuits today against individual landowners in Oneida and Madison counties.

title: Corrections
description: The legend of a diagram on Wednesday with an article about the increasing use of thumbprinting for identification in fast-food restaurants and stores misspelled the name of the company that supplies the technology shown. It is Indivos, not Invidos.

title: Charles Lacoste -- 'A Forgotten Nabi'
description: Wildenstein

title: Judge Denies Qaeda Captives A Day in Court
description: A federal judge today dismissed a lawsuit that had been filed by civil rights advocates in an effort to identify Al Qaeda detainees at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, and have them taken before a court to determine their legal status.

title: Hughes Jumps Past 3 Rivals to Take Gold
description: Against all Ouija board predictions and sentimental expectations, Sarah Hughes, a porcelain-faced 16-year-old from Great Neck, N.Y., won the Olympic women's figure skating gold medal tonight.

title: How Mourners Were Betrayed
description: The horrors in Noble, Ga., where hundreds of the dead have been found in various states of putrefaction around the 16-acre site of Tri-State Crematory, are the result of a series of failures.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Ciena Posts Loss As Sales Fall
description: Ciena said yesterday that it had lost $70.6 million, or 22 cents a share, during the three months ended Jan. 31, as revenue tumbled 54 percent, to $162 million from $352 million a year earlier. Ciena, one of the last telecommunications equipment suppliers to be hit by the carriers' sharp slowdown in capital spending last year, also warned that sales in the current quarter would be about $100 million, well below recent projections. Ciena's shares fell $1.60 in heavy trading yesterday, to $7.60, down more than 90 percent from their 52-week high of $84.25 a year ago. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: Mayor Says Higher Taxi Fares Are Needed to Lure Drivers
description: New Yorkers can expect a taxi fare increase because the industry cannot attract enough drivers under the current fee structure, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday.

title: Slide Show: Hughes Wins the Gold
The Winter Olympics Tale
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Dressing the Audience
Slide Show: Day 15
Slide Show: U.S. vs. Russia
Korean Official Defends Seoul's Efforts on Economy
description: South Korea's finance minister, Jin Nyum, said today that the job of imposing financial discipline on the country's deeply indebted companies belonged to lenders, not the government, but that the country's banks were not yet up to the task.

title: New Incentive To Join Army: Direct Sign-Up In Green Berets
description: In an unassuming storefront where signs and a life-size cutout of a Special Forces soldier advertise ''An Army of One,'' Sgt. First Class Jeremy Burton delivers his pitch to prospective recruits.

title: Continental Clash for Gold
description: Now they go for gold, these friendly neighbor nations of North America, the United States against Canada. The most talented players from both sides of the border, born and raised in the National Hockey League's primary places of business, will play on Sunday afternoon before a worldwide audience in the climax of this stimulating tournament and these controversial Olympic Winter Games.

title: Northrop Grumman Bids $5.9 Billion For TRW
description: The Northrop Grumman Corporation announced an unsolicited $5.9 billion stock offer today for the TRW Corporation in the hope of becoming the nation's leading satellite and missile contractor as military spending rises in response to terrorist threats.

title: San Diego Neighbor Charged With Kidnapping Young Girl
description: A neighbor of a 7-year-old San Diego girl who disappeared three weeks ago was charged today with kidnapping her after DNA tests showed that the child's blood was on an article of his clothing and in his motor home, the police said.

title: Killed on Job But Spared 'Hero' Label
description: DANIEL PEARL was doing his job, and it got him killed in Pakistan, senselessly and cruelly. What was striking yesterday was how his family and his colleagues at The Wall Street Journal remembered this 38-year-old foreign correspondent.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Skepticism On Cable Deal
description: The chief executive of Deutsche Telekom, Ron Sommer, sees little chance the sale of six cable TV networks to the Liberty Media Corporation will go ahead and said his company might not sell stock in its mobile unit until 2003. Mr. Sommer had counted on the 5.5 billion euro ($4.8 billion) cable sale to Liberty, controlled by John C. Malone, and the initial share sale of T-Mobile International to help reduce the former German monopoly's 65 billion euros ($56.5 billion) in debt. ''The chances the Liberty sale will go ahead are very slim,'' Mr. Sommer said at a news conference in Berlin. ''But I don't give up hope. It would be a shame if we would lose an investor like Liberty.''

title: Kostelic Smooths Rough Road With 3rd Gold
description: Because she is not ranked among the top competitors worldwide in the giant slalom, Janica Kostelic began her pursuit of Olympic history as the 19th skier from the starting gate today. That meant she skied about a half-hour after the first of the favorites, enough time for the snow on the race course to develop ruts like foxholes.

title: A Cinderella Team Takes Grand Nationals
description: The toughest event in the national calendar is, in the opinion of the cognoscenti, the Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams at the Fall Nationals. In 1983 this was won by the great Oswald Jacoby when he was seriously ill.

title: J. P. MORGAN MUST ALLOW DISCLOSURE VOTE, S.E.C. SAYS
description: J. P. Morgan Chase, the second-largest bank in the country, must allow shareholders to vote on a proposal to force the company to bar analysts from owning stocks they cover, the Securities and Exchange Commission said. J.P. Morgan Chase failed to get S.E.C. permission to block the motion by the A.F.L.-C.I.O., a federation of trade unions sponsoring benefit plans with more than $400 billion in assets. The proposal would also prevent J.P. Morgan's analysts from participating in investment banking. According to documents released by the commission, J.P. Morgan had asked the S.E.C. for permission to exclude the proposal from the proxy statement for its 2002 annual meeting, in part because it related to the bank's ''ordinary business operations.'' The S.E.C. disagreed in a letter dated Jan. 21.

title: Briefly Noted; CRASH VICTIMS
description: The bodies of three American servicemen killed in a helicopter crash off the Philippine coast arrived at Kadena Air Base in Okinawa, Japan, as rescue crews searched for the other seven.

title: Scientists Doubting Discovery Of New Dark Matter in Space
description: Two years ago at a scientific meeting here, a team of physicists based at the University of Rome shook the world of physics by announcing that they had made what would have been one of the greatest discoveries in the history of science: a detection of particles that may flit through space almost unnoticed, in such numbers that they make up most of the mass of the universe.

title: In Failed States, Can Democracy Come Too Soon?
description: From Washington to London to Bonn, it's now an article of faith that building a nation means creating a Western-style democracy. That is certainly the case with Afghanistan. The industrialized nations that recently promised $4.5 billion to help rebuild the country all assume that it will adopt Western political institutions. And the Afghans themselves have agreed on a political blueprint that calls for a transitional government ending in ''free and fair elections'' within 30 months.

title: Napster Wins One Round In Music Case
description: America's major record companies, which successfully sued to shut down the online music-swapping service Napster, suffered a setback today as the judge in the case allowed Napster to seek evidence that the record companies colluded to monopolize the digital music market.

title: PROCTER & GAMBLE SELLING PLANT IN CINCINNATI
description: The Procter & Gamble Company is selling its plant that manufactures olestra, which is used to make low-fat Pringles potato chips, as the company focuses on brand-name foods like Folgers coffee. Terms of the sale were not disclosed. The plant, which is in Cincinnati and employs about 40 people, will continue to produce olestra for Procter & Gamble after its sale to Twin Rivers Technologies L.P. of Quincy, Mass., said Gary Dowdell, a spokesman for Procter & Gamble. The sale of the olestra-producing business is part of Procter & Gamble's effort to concentrate on its larger brands like Folgers, Sunny Delight juice and Pringles, Mr. Dowdell said.

title: Corrections
description: An article by Reuters on Wednesday about a new deployment of the Nepalese Army to deal with raids by Maoist guerrillas trying to overthrow the constitutional monarchy misidentified the king who first sent the troops into action, in November. He was Gyanendra; King Birendra, his brother, was killed with most of the royal family last June by Crown Prince Dipendra, who also died of wounds in a shootout at the palace.

title: Crematory Case Underlines Gaps In Oversight of Funeral Business
description: Four years ago, Ohio passed a law requiring crematories to be licensed and inspected. Today, not a single license has been issued and no crematory has been inspected.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAIZEL, RALPH PHILLIP
description: MAIZEL-Ralph Phillip. Beloved husband of the late Rosalie. Devoted father of Andrew. Services Sunday 9:30am Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 2nd Ave corner of East 10th St.

title: Matthew Culligan Dead at 83; Ex-Curtis Publishing President
description: Matthew J. Culligan, an executive who held high positions in the radio, television, advertising and publishing businesses, including a stint as president of the Curtis Publishing Company, owners of The Saturday Evening Post, died Jan. 31 in New hall, Calif., his companion, Judith Valentine, said. He was 83 and lived in Manhattan.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SATIN, SHELLY
description: SATIN-Shelly. Our sympathies to his wife Joan Throckmorton, family and other friends at the passing of this loving husband, impassioned opera singer and remarkable gardener. He will be sorely missed. Bill Kutik and Julie Packer

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: More Defectors From North
description: The National Intelligence Service has reported 20 more defectors, bringing the total this year to 74. Defections have been steadily increasing, even though most North Koreans have to reach the South by crossing through China or Russia, both of which return them to North Korea if they are caught. A total of 583 Koreans defected last year, and 312 defected in 2000, the agency said. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Opponent Says Newark Mayor Is Using City Funds for Ads
description: The councilman seeking to unseat Mayor Sharpe James asked state election officials today to investigate whether the mayor was improperly using municipal funds to buy campaign advertisements that masquerade as public service announcements.

title: N.Y.U. Gets A Rebuff From FEMA In Aid Quest
description: New York University, which estimates that it has lost more than $25 million in connection with the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center, says that the Federal Emergency Management Agency has advised it that the agency would not reimburse any of the costs.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPEAN UNION

title: First Tower to Fall Was Hit At Higher Speed, Study Finds
description: Researchers trying to explain why the World Trade Center's south tower fell first, though struck second, are focusing on new calculations showing that the passenger jet that hit the south tower had been flying as fast as 586 miles an hour, about 100 miles an hour faster than the other hijacked plane.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURTEN, WILLIAM, M.D.
description: BURTEN-William, M.D. died on February 19th. Psychiatrist with private practice and consultant for Westchester institutions. Loving husband of Katharine and dearest Daddy of Annie and Michael. Graduate of Brown University, NYU, and the University of Miami School of Medicine. A scholar and a doctor's doctor. Memorial at John J. Fox Funeral Home in Larchmont on Sunday at 12:30. Donations to the Larchmont library or the Audubon Society.

description: RECORD GOLD -- Janica Kostelic won the giant slalom to tie the Alpine mark for gold medals (three) and set another for total medals (four) at a Winter Olympics. PAGE D1

description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about changes in the research department of the Goldman Sachs Group referred incorrectly at one point to the department's status. It is being separated from the firm's stock sales and trading division, not the investment banking division.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's welfare policies misspelled the surname of a writer whose Op-Ed column in The New York Post urged city officials to decline a federal waiver of food stamp rules. She is Heather MacDonald, not McDonald. The article also misstated her title at the Manhattan Institute. She is a senior fellow, not an associate.
