title: At Last, The Judges Are Able To Explain
description: The morning after Sarah Hughes's magic carpet ride from fourth place to gold medal Thursday night, the judges who gave her room to fly allowed a peek into the thinking that produced the all-but-unimaginable outcome.

title: Truce Accord In Sri Lanka Could Herald Peace Talks
description: The prime minister of Sri Lanka and the reclusive leader of separatist Tamil rebels signed a formal cease-fire agreement today that is expected to lead to the first peace talks between the warring parties in seven years.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KAYE, ROBERT
description: KAYE-Robert. January 16, 1976, to February 23, 1996. Always missed, always remembered, always loved. Mom, Dad and Andy

title: Suspect Says Reporter Was Slain In January as Part of Wider Plot
description: The chief suspect in the Daniel Pearl case has told investigators that the captive Wall Street Journal reporter was killed in late January as part of a plot that was to have included an attack on the United States Consulate in Karachi, intelligence and law enforcement officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAUVELT, HARRIET
description: BLAUVELT-Harriet. We record with sorrow the death of Harriet Blauvelt, beloved sister of Bea Shorr, Honorary Chairman of the Board. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Martin and Gladys Raskin, brother and sister-in-law, and the entire family. Elias Strum, President American Friends of David Yellin College of Education

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Food Maker To Close
description: The Snow Brand Food Company, which is accused of falsely labeling its meat products to recover government subsidies, said it would close in April. Sales fell as much as 85 percent after the accusations emerged in January. Snow Brand Milk, which owns two-thirds of the food company, tried to sell its operations, but the damage to its brand proved too deep. Snow Brand Milk is trying to repair its own image after being implicated in a tainted-milk outbreak in 2000. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; When What Is Seen Should Be Believed
description: THE grim and disciplined world of professional football seems light-years away from our friendly little playpen of the Olympic Winter Games -- Camp Sportsmanship, I like to call it.

title: Veuve Clicquot's 2nd Female Chief Takes Charge
description: CCILE BONNEFOND is the second woman to run the venerable French Champagne house of Veuve Clicquot. The first was the widow who gave the company its name.

title: Norway Wins Curling Gold
description: After the Canadian women's curling team had failed to capture the gold medal, settling for bronze, it was left to the Canadian men's team to restore some pride in a national obsession second only to hockey.

title: Enron Is Said to Be Negotiating With Andersen
description: Enron is negotiating with its former auditors, Arthur Andersen, about settling any claims that Andersen mishandled the company's accounts, according to a voice-mail message issued today to employees by Enron's interim chief executive, Stephen F. Cooper.

title: Canada Redux
description: Afew days ago I fretted about Canada, what with its sudden proclivity for figure-skating controversy and its early-round troubles in men's hockey. I even came up with a list of admirable things about Canada, in order to console the locals.

title: At a Kabul Cemetery, British Soldiers Honor the Victims of Wars Past
description: In a corner of this ruined city, a group of British soldiers paused from their peacekeeping duties to remember their fallen compatriots who had come to conquer decades ago.

title: Alabama Jury Says Monsanto Polluted Town
description: A jury decided today that the Monsanto Company, which made toxic chemicals in Anniston, Ala., for 40 years, was responsible for polluting the town.

title: The Tragic Story of Daniel Pearl
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUTZ, HERBERT DIETRICH
description: SCHUTZ-Herbert Dietrich. Passed away February 20, 2002. Memorial service Monday, February 25, 2002 at 11 am, at Round Hill Community Church, 395 Round Hill Road, Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Schutz Memorial Fund of the Henry L. Ferguson Museum, Fisher's Island, NY 06390, or the Medica Foundation, c/o Dr. Daniel Macken, Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, 161 Ft. Washington Ave, NY, NY 10032, would be appreciated.

title: Government Releases Little Information on Sept. 11 Crashes
description: Within five months of an accidental crash, the National Transportation Safety Board has typically released thousands of words of technical information. In the case of the four planes involved in the Sept. 11 attacks, the board has said nothing and is not likely to, because it has given jurisdiction over the case to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, which looks at the information as potential evidence in a criminal case.

title: In Argentina, I.M.F. Impasse Heightens Fear On Economy
description: Though Argentina and the International Monetary Fund are once again discussing new loans to help ease the country's economic crisis, a fundamental obstacle has emerged. The Argentine government says it cannot carry out the economic changes that the fund and other creditors are demanding unless it receives fresh money from abroad first, but foreign lenders say they cannot advance the country any new money until after it has shown some results.

title: Warming Up to China, Neglecting Democracy
description: It's the 11th day of the Lunar New Year Festival in China. The money god has been welcomed back to earth with firecrackers, children ride their new bicycles on the roads and back alleyways of Beijing, the Summer Palace is seeing the last of its holiday visitors and all seems right with the world that is China.

title: At the Ice House, Sharing Hughes's Victory and Her Dream
description: This is the house that Sarah Hughes helped build. Turn right at Circle Brake and continue past the tire shop. It is along the railroad tracks next to the bowling alley. The big brownish building with few windows and even fewer available parking spots.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MUFSON, JOANNA
description: MUFSON-Joanna. August 16, 1969 to February 23, 1983. ''Four demeter walked with Persephone over the land of the springing corn. And men rejoiced, they sang believing in Earth from Heaven life receiving, in life that does not die.'' Love, Abby & Mom.

title: Military Contractor In Bid to Buy a Rival
description: The Northrop Grumman Corporation announced an unsolicited $5.9 billion stock offer for the TRW Corporation in the hope of becoming the nation's leading satellite and missile contractor.

title: Swelling Linked to Experimental Drug
description: The Elan Corporation's experimental treatment for Alzheimer's disease has been linked to more cases of inflammation of the central nervous system, a side effect that caused the company to suspend a study last month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARFIELD, FRAN
description: GARFIELD-Fran. National Council of Jewish Women Brooklyn Section Board of Directors extends heartfelt sympathy to Joseph Garfield and family on the passing of Fran Garfield Board member. Services Sunday February 24th, 10am, Sherman Funeral Home, 1283 Coney Island Ave, Brooklyn, NY. Sylvia Ladner, Dolores Measer Co-Presidents

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the announcement that France's prime minister, Lionel Jospin, will run for president misidentified the cabinet minister most likely to manage his campaign. It is Agriculture Minister Jean Glavany, a member of Mr. Jospin's party, the Socialists, not Transportation Minister Jean-Claude Gayssot, a Communist.

title: Old Idea for Downtown Rail Line From Long Island Gains Favor
description: Bringing suburban commuter trains into the financial district, either from Midtown or Brooklyn, has long been a dream of business leaders in Lower Manhattan. But the idea of doing so from downtown Brooklyn -- and using an existing subway tunnel instead of trying to find the money to build a new one -- is gaining fresh support as transit officials begin to draw up plans for rebuilding the transit lines around the World Trade Center site.

title: From Putin on Down, Charges of Bias and Insult
description: It was one of those increasingly frequent moments, usually concealed beneath a thick fur coat of Slavic civility and grace, when the average Russian madly itched to take to the streets and yell ''Yankee go home.'' Except that the Yanks are not here, but in Salt Lake City.

title: A Holdout Polygamist, 88, Defies the Mormons
description: These are the generations of Allred: William, a colonist, begat Isaac, and Isaac lived many years and begat William. William, who walked to the Great Salt Lake alongside Brigham Young, begat a son during the journey and named him Byron. Byron begat Byron Jr. and then lived two and forty years more. Byron Jr. begat many children including one named Owen.

title: Another Twist At Global As Chairman Quits a Board
description: Gary Winnick, the chairman of Global Crossing, the troubled communications company, resigned yesterday from the board of a Singapore investment firm that has links to investors from Singapore and Hong Kong who want to buy the company.

title: Briefly Noted; ANTHRAX EXPOSURE?
description: A building at the Army Reserve Command headquarters in Fort McPherson on the south side of Atlanta was evacuated yesterday after a powder on a mailed package tested positive for anthrax, Army officials said. Six people in the mailroom were decontaminated after they were exposed to the package, a spokesman said. It was taken to the Centers for Disease Control for further tests. David Firestone (NYT)

title: Jonas Savimbi, 67, Rebel Of Charisma and Tenacity
description: Jonas Savimbi, who was killed yesterday by Angolan government soldiers, spent more than 35 years in the African bush battling first for Angolan independence and then for personal power.

title: The Tragic Story of Daniel Pearl
description: To the Editor:

title: Monte M. Williams, 40, Times Reporter
description: Monte M. Williams, a reporter for The New York Times, died yesterday in Forest Hills, Queens. She was 40.

title: Europe Seethes as the U.S. Flies Solo in World Affairs
description: Europe's unconditional solidarity with the Bush administration, declared so quickly in the shock after the Sept. 11 attacks on New York and Washington, has faded almost as suddenly.

title: Small Canadian Apparel Maker Is First in Olympics Exposure
description: In an industry filled with powerhouses like Nike, Reebok and Adidas, how did a little-known Canadian athletic apparel company with a beaver as its trademark win the Winter Olympics?

title: Mexican Puzzle: Is Missing Body A Most-Wanted Drug Kingpin?
description: Mexico's attorney general said today that the government was investigating whether a man shot to death on Feb. 10 in the resort town of Mazatln was Ramn Arellano Flix, one of the world's leading cocaine kingpins.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Bank Profit Rises
description: The Royal Bank of Canada reported its profit rose 9.2 percent in its last quarter, as the bank benefited from the drop of interest rates to 40-year lows and cut costs outside the United States. Net income rose to 722 million Canadian dollars ($454 million) from 661 million Canadian dollars ($416 million) a year earlier, said a spokeswoman, Beja Rodeck. Revenue in the period, which ended Jan. 31, rose 17 percent to 4.09 billion Canadian dollars ($2.6 billion).

title: Russia Questions Officials From North America
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 22 — The referee for tonight's game between the United States and Russia was Bill McCreary, a native of Canada and one of the most experienced officials in the National Hockey League. He has worked several games in this Olympic tournament, which involves the best players in the N.H.L. playing for their national teams. Suddenly, McCreary's nationality was an issue.

title: Briefly Noted
description: ANTHRAX EXPOSURE?

title: Balancing a Little Old, a Little Nouveau
description: The most perilous balancing act in town right now is the one being attempted by Cirque loize with the show it calls ''Cirque Orchestra.''

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Mother's Defense Starts
description: After five days of testimony, the prosecution rested in the capital murder trial of Andrea Pia Yates, who is charged with drowning her five children in the bathtub of their home in June. Mrs. Yates, of Houston, has pleaded not guilty by reason of insanity. The first defense witness, Dr. Melissa R. Ferguson, medical director of psychiatric services at the Harris County Jail, said Mrs. Yates was suffering postpartum depression with psychotic features. Dr. Ferguson said Mrs. Yates had told her that she killed her children to save them from the fires of hell.

title: Judge Refuses To Free Man After Charge Is Dismissed
description: A federal judge refused to set a man free yesterday, even though the man was acquitted last month in a deadly robbery and this week the judge himself dismissed a new, related charge.

title: Briefly Noted; AIRPORT EVACUATION
description: Two terminals of Philadelphia International Airport were evacuated last night after a woman walked through an unstaffed security lane in Terminal C. ''The passenger was apparently afraid she would be late for her flight,'' said Laura Brown, a Department of Transportation spokeswoman. The woman boarded the plane for San Juan, Puerto Rico, but security officials unloaded the plane and evacuated the terminals. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERG, ADELE
description: WEINBERG-Adele. Loving mother of Joan Kasler and Linda Yellin. Dear sister of Lou Kaye. Cherished grandmother of Patti McWherter, Eric Yellin, Julie Yellin and Jennifer Kasler and greatgrandmother. Service Sunday, 2:30PM at ''Riverside'' 21 W. Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZWASKA, JOHN C. (JACK).
description: ZWASKA-John C. (Jack). On February 19, 2002. Beloved husband of Patricia Bessone. Devoted father of Julie and Jessica, and stepfather of Amy and Jonathan Bessone. Loving brother of Jill Zwaska. Executive Director, for 20 years, for the Television Music License Committee. The family will receive friends Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Funeral service Saturday, 10:30AM at Frank E. Campbell.

title: The Fast-Paced Nets Watch the Knicks in Their Rearview Mirror
description: It happens every time they play nowadays. The Nets, for so many years the joke of the New York metropolitan area, if not the N.B.A., turn the Knicks into a scout team, a gang of slow-moving, nonleaping, unexciting foils who do not look as if they belong on the same court.

title: Health Posts: Expertise Meets Politics
description: With the resignation of the head of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Thursday, four of the most important federal health jobs are now vacant. Experts say there is a vacuum in health leadership as the Bush administration is trying to improve the nation's defenses against bioterrorism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, ALAN J.
description: GREEN-Alan J. Adored husband of Lisa Cari, loving father of Adam and Anthony, dear brother of Lynn, devoted son of Edith and Sol and Lorraine and Herb Weitz. Our hearts are broken for the loss of such a kind and gentle soul. Services Sunday, February 24, 1 pm, at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Introspection and Turmoil In a Work of 1934 Germany
description: Ingo Metzmacher, the German conductor who made his New York Philharmonic debut on Thursday evening, began his career in 1981 as the pianist in Ensemble Modern, the new-music group. When he moved on to orchestras in the late 1980's, the 20th-century repertory remained his specialty; it has formed the basis of his discography, which includes a complete traversal of Karl Amadeus Hartmann's symphonies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, BERNARD
description: LEWIS-Bernard, a former newspaperman and publicist born May 15, 1912, died February 11, 2002, worked as a reporter for the Old Brooklyn Daily Eagle and then for the Associated Press. Later he worked as a Publicist for Paramount Pictures, 20th Century-Fox, Italian Films Export, Kingsley International Pictures, The Brooklyn Opera Society and The Arts at St. Ann's. In the 1950s Mr. Lewis was instrumental in publicizing and introducing foreign films to an American audience. He will be profoundly missed. He is survived by his daughter Judy Nash, her husband, Tony Onorato, his son Andy Lewis and his wife Cindy, by six granchildren, two granddaughters-in-law and a great-granddaughter. His wife Florence of 63 years died in April, 2002.

description: A Staten Island woman has been arrested and charged with taking pornographic photographs of two of her children and six other minors, the police said.

description: With a few words at the opening of Sabbath evening services yesterday, the senior rabbi of Temple Emanu-El, Ronald B. Sobel, talked publicly for the first time about the arrest of the synagogue's cantor on charges that he molested his nephew.

title: Man Is Indicted In 1981 Killing
description: An Essex County grand jury indicted a New Jersey man today in a 1981 killing, and accused him and two others of running an illegal lottery, or numbers racket, as associates of the Luchese crime family.

title: Angola Says Soldiers Have Killed Savimbi, Longtime Rebel Leader
description: The guerrilla leader Jonas Savimbi, whose guile and ferocity have fueled one of Africa's longest civil wars, was killed today in a battle in eastern Angola, government officials there said.

title: Boston Gets a Sign Of Levine's Impact
description: The courtship is over, the engagement set. Now to woo the family. The Boston Symphony Orchestra wavered long, perhaps too long, in its search for a music director. Worthy candidates came, waited and went. Meanwhile, players were restive: 29 years under Seiji Ozawa, or any one conductor in these quick and mobile times, made them so. Now the Boston has chosen James Levine, and the successful suitor arrived at Symphony Hall on Thursday night to tell the city what it could expect of him.

title: U.S. and China Stay Positive, but Make Little Progress
description: President Bush left for home today after lecturing the Chinese people on the merits of liberty and religious faith and taking more than one opportunity to remind them that the United States is pledged to aid Taiwan's defense.

title: Colombian Troops Begin Retaking Rebel-Held Territory
description: Elite government troops landed by helicopter today inside a swath of southern jungle that President Andrs Pastrana ceded to Marxist rebels three years ago as a safe haven so peace talks could take place. The soldiers were the first of thousands expected as the army works to retake the zone now that Mr. Pastrana has broken off the talks.

Loving father of Shannon, Elizabeth, Catherine & Margaret, and father-in-law of Kevin O'Donnell and Christian Olivier. Dear Grampi of Quinn. Loving brother of Michael, Cathleen, Eileen, John and Kevin. Cherished friend of Mr. and Mrs. M.C. Marks. A modest & elegant man, well-loved. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Avenue at 12th Street, Garden City, 2-4 and 7-9 PM Friday. Mass of Christian burial, St. Joseph's Church, 11 A.M. Saturday. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to the American Cancer Society, Garden City Unit would be appreciated.

description: BRIGGS-Richard Edward (Jeff), died on February 16. Memorial service Saturday, March 2nd at 12:30PM. Unitarian Church in Westport, CT.

description: NASH-Evelyn. Beloved wife of the late Morris. Devoted mother of Arthur Bachner, Stanley Nash and Michelle Nash Cohen. Also survived by seven grandchildren and one great grandchild. Loving sister of Mildred Kahn. Services Sunday 12 noon at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

description: Time Warner Cable announced yesterday that it would add the new YES Network to its metropolitan-area systems, which serve about three million subscribers.

title: The Sleeping Car Porter Who Won the Last Round
description: A. Philip Randolph's world is unraveling. His efforts to win recognition for his union of black railroad porters have stalled in the face of the Depression and the Pullman Company's racist intransigence. His bank account and his marriage have been taxed to the breaking point. Now his mother has died in Harlem, and he has no money to get home from Chicago for the funeral.

title: Sports of The Times; Loss Only Heightens Russians' Search for Olympic Slights
description: NOTHING happened here today to soothe any wounded Russian feelings. By the end of a furious and tense third period, Russia's men's hockey team looked like the rest of the federation, sick of North America and eager to get back, well, in the case of these National Hockey League professionals, back to playing for pay in North America.

title: Backup Catcher Is Prepared To Get Dirty
description: The Mets' clubhouse attendants have a mundane routine when Mike Piazza, Vance Wilson and other catchers finish their workouts in spring training. They dip into bulky, black duffel bags, empty the catchers' equipment and wipe it clean. Wilson despises this scrubbing process and told the attendants to leave the stains on his mask, shin guards and chest protector.

description: Bitterness in Europe

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERBERICH, DENNIS E.
description: BERBERICH-Dennis E. of Pelham, NY, former President and CEO of Canada Dry Bottling Company and Coors Distributing of NY, died on February 21, 2002. Born in the Bronx on July 3, 1939. Mr. Berberich graduated from Fordham Prep and received his BA degree in Economics from Fordham University. His 37 year career in the beverage industry began with New York 7UP in 1963. In 1980, Dennis was named President of Canada Dry Bottling Company of New York. When Coors Brewing Company entered the New York market, they formed the Coors Distributing Company of New York, of which Dennis was Chief Executive Officer. Dennis was strongly committed to enhancing the quality of health care and to charitable and community service. His most exemplary volunteer leadership was his participation in the Calvary Hospital Fund. He served as a Board of Director of the Fund since 1985, and Chairman since 1991. Dennis received many tributes including the Calvary Hospital Man of the Year Award and the prestigious Calvary Medal. He is survived by his wife Jo-Ann; their son Dennis M.; their daughters Jennifer Murray, Jane and Elizabeth; three grandchildren: Mary, Peter and Bobby Murray. Visiting hours at Pelham Funeral Home, 64 Lincoln Ave., Pelham, NY on Saturday 7-9 pm, and Sunday 2-4 & 7-9 pm. Funeral Mass at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church Pelham Manor on Monday at 10 am. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Valhalla, NY. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made in his memory to the Calvary Hospital Fund, Inc., 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, NY 10461.

description: Larry A. Silverstein has a new proposal for rebuilding his office tower at 7 World Trade Center later this year that he hopes will finally address all the objections from local residents and downtown officials.

title: With Ease, Canada Ends Belarus's Stunning Run
description: Near the conclusion of this dreary game today, a group of young men wearing Canadian hockey jerseys rose to their feet from their seats near the Belarus net and added a little noise to the E Center arena by singing their country's national anthem. They were celebrating Canada's 7-1 victory over Belarus in a men's hockey semifinal and also a berth in the gold medal game on Sunday against the United States.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NIKE INC., Beaverton, Ore., the largest maker of athletic shoes, said it had bought the closely held Hurley International, Costa Mesa, Calif., a maker of clothing for teenagers, to expand beyond its namesake brand. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Another Brooklyn Judge Said to Be Reassigned
description: A Brooklyn State Supreme Court justice has been reassigned following accusations that he failed to tell the authorities after hearing that a fellow judge had solicited a bribe, several people knowledgeable about the move said yesterday.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the second day of Id al-Adha, the Islamic Feast of Sacrifice, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Man Held in Killings Is Described as a Recluse
description: It was no secret in the family that John W. Mabie had begun to fear for his own safety, to think that criminals were coming to get him, his daughter-in-law said today. He painted the windows of his home black, and cut the shading branches of a pitiable birch tree on his lawn down to lifeless stumps. He spent almost all of his time indoors.

description: The Bush administration plans to provide military intelligence to the Colombian government for its campaign against Marxist rebels and is rushing spare parts to the country's armed forces, officials said today.

description: The Kmart Corporation is betting that it still has time to change the perception of its discount stores by starting an ambitious brand-image advertising campaign.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAILOVE, MORRIS
description: BRAILOVE-Morris. Devoted husband of Sylvia. Died peacefully on February 21st at age 96. Cherished father of Michael and Jane Brailove Rutkoff and beloved grandfather of Adam, Rachel, Joshua and Rebekah. A native of Woodbine, NJ and graduate of Temple University Dental School, he practiced in Elizabeth for 50 years before moving to Monroe Township. His life was devoted to caring for family and friends. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Mayor Says City Can't Afford Higher Raises for the Police
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the city would have a ''tough time'' giving police officers raises larger than those proposed by the previous administration, even if a state arbitration panel were to rule that a larger-than-budgeted salary increase was warranted.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of yesterday, 3,062 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11, not including 19 hijackers.

title: AGENCY FILES SUIT FOR CHENEY PAPERS ON ENERGY POLICY
description: The General Accounting Office, an arm of Congress, sued Vice President Dick Cheney today to try to force the White House to reveal the identities of energy industry executives who helped the administration develop a national energy policy last year.

title: Skating Commentators Deserve Lowest Marks
description: As Sarah Hughes skated flawlessly to Winter Olympic gold in Salt Lake City on Thursday night, NBC's analysts turned into emotional, confused fans who failed to explain the scoring that led to her victory.

title: Credibility Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Bank Fires Two Traders
description: Banco Santander Central Hispano fired two traders in Brazil after an internal investigation found ''irregular'' securities transactions worth 3 million reais ($1.2 million) or less. Police are investigating, the bank said. Santander, Spain's biggest bank, dismissed the traders in January, Miguel Jorge, the bank's vice president for corporate affairs, said. The bank turned its evidence over to Brazilian police, a Santander spokeswoman said. Santander, based in Madrid, bought the Brazilian state-owned bank Banespa in November 2000 for $4.9 billion.

title: Troubled Times in Nigeria
description: An abusive military, deadly ethnic and religious violence, police mutinies and aloof presidential leadership are tarnishing the once shining reputation of Nigeria's president, Olusegun Obasanjo. Three years ago his election restored democracy to Africa's most populous nation after more than 15 years of corrupt and brutal military rule. Though he has made positive changes, his inability to control army lawlessness and heal the country's divisions have disappointed many Nigerians. Democracy's roots are shallow in Nigeria. Mr. Obasanjo must provide more effective leadership for the remainder of his term to ensure its survival.

title: Gold for Hughes a Surprise, But Perfection Is a Standard
description: The second she landed her last triple jump Thursday night, the figure skater Sarah Hughes clapped her hands and released a spontaneous little shriek. By the end of her gold-medal performance at the 2002 Salt Lake Games, she carried the crowd in a crescendo as she accelerated into her final, dazzling spin.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I promise you that the terrorists did not defeat my husband no matter what they did to him, nor did they succeed in seizing his dignity or value as a human

title: Historian Says Borrowing Was Wider Than Known
description: The historian Doris Kearns Goodwin, under fire for inappropriately copying several passages in a book she wrote in 1987, yesterday disclosed that her borrowings were far more extensive. In all, she said that in the same book she failed to acknowledge scores of quotations or close paraphrases from other authors.

title: John Thaw Is Dead at 60; Played TV's Inspector Morse
description: John Thaw, the British television actor known to millions as the crusty, music-loving Chief Inspector Morse of Oxford, died at his home in Wiltshire, England, on Thursday. He was 60.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANTOR, EDWARD A.
description: CANTOR-Edward A. Of Chester, NJ and Manalapan, FL, beloved husband of Jane, devoted father of Michael (Debra), cherished grandfather of Brittny. Funeral services private. Should friends desire, contributions may be made to the Saint Barnabas Hemodialysis Center, 94 Old Short Hills Rd., Livingston, NJ 07039. For additional information call Bernheim Apter Kreitzman, Livingston, NJ, 1-800-938-6372.

title: Pataki's Top Aide Is Leaving for Law Firm
description: Gov. George E. Pataki's top aide, Bradford J. Race, is leaving government after seven years, the governor's office announced today, and top Republicans say he will be replaced by John P. Cahill, another Pataki adviser.

title: License Rule for Buildings Chief May Be Waived
description: City Council Speaker Gifford Miller said yesterday that the Council would be willing to waive the requirement that the buildings commissioner be a licensed architect or engineer to make it easier for the Bloomberg administration -- and future mayors -- to hire a candidate.

title: The Death Penalty Re-examined
description: America's death penalty system is badly broken. Just how badly was underscored two years ago when a study of capital appeals by a team at Columbia University unearthed the fact that fully 68 percent of all death sentences reviewed by appellate courts between 1973 and 1995 had been reversed because of serious error.

description: G.A.O. Sues Vice President, Seeking Energy Records

title: Fight at Party Led to Shooting, L.I. Police Say
description: Stunned teenagers gathered today around a makeshift memorial on a roadside here where one of their friends was killed and another was wounded in a drive-by shooting Thursday night.

title: Penetrating the Mind by Metaphor
description: What does a Buddhist monk meditating in a soccer stadium during a game have to do with Coca-Cola? Everything, says Gerald Zaltman, a maverick marketing professor at the Harvard Business School. Just don't expect a Coke drinker to tell you this.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Judge Lets Princess Fly Home
description: A judge let a Saudi princess accused of beating her Indonesian maid in Orlando to fly home to be with her family for a Muslim holiday. The ruling by Judge Richard Conrad of Circuit Court was opposed by the prosecutor, Bill Vose. The princess, Buniah al-Saud, 41, is a niece of King Fahd. She faces a charge of attempted aggravated battery, a third-degree felony. A student at the University of Central Florida, the princess has been free on $5,000 bail since December, after Orange County deputies had arrested her in the beating of the maid, Memet Ismiyati.

title: North Korea and Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Montgomery Is Cut By the Giants
description: As part of the Giants' efforts to better position themselves within the salary cap, the team is releasing running back Joe Montgomery, a second-round draft pick from 1999 who missed all of last season with an Achilles' tendon injury.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Killing 4,500 Deer To Fight Disease
description: To control chronic wasting disease, state wildlife officials have approved a plan to kill 4,500 deer over five years. Over the objections of some mountain homeowners and wildlife advocates, hunters and state biologists will kill the deer in three areas of northeastern Colorado. Chronic wasting disease affects deer and elk brains. It is not known how the disease is spread, and there is no live test to confirm it. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Princeton Easily Handles Upstart Yale
description: This has been a most unusual Ivy League season. A once-hopeless team is in first place, a couple of perennial powers have struggled to keep pace and there is a good chance the league will end up in a three-way tie. But for one night, things looked pretty much the way they have always looked.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAHN, MELVIN J.
description: HAHN-Melvin J. Beloved husband of Janet A. Hahn, ever devoted father of Peggy and Peter and loving grandfather of Kathy. Forever in our hearts. Services private.

description: What would the American Museum of Natural History do for Act II?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARGOLIS, BERT
description: MARGOLIS-Bert. The Camp Greylock Directors, Staff, Alumni, and Community mourn the passing of one of its most beloved and longest serving Directors who passed away February 19, 2002 at his home in New York City. Born May 12, 1917 in Montgomery, WV, Bert attended Greylock as a camper and a counselor. He served as an officer in the Army Air Corps before joining the Greylock Directorate in 1949, retiring as Director Emeritus in 1995. Bert was a pioneer in children's summer camping, where his model of teaching balanced excellence in instruction with insistence on kindness, and fair play. His intolerance for bullies was years ahead of its time. Through his vision and compassion, Bert inspired many. He is survived by his wife, Barbara, his sister Elaine, his daughters: Margaret, Katherine, Elizabeth, and Victoria, and nine grandchildren. He will be missed.

title: Frozen Foods Show Upturn in Taste and Sales
description: For decades, frozen food meant granular fish sticks, cardboard crust pizzas and portion-controlled diet meals. Bland and low budget, frozen food was most often eaten in front of the television -- which provided a welcome distraction from the taste.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bridgestone Profit Slips
description: The Bridgestone Corporation said profit fell 6.9 percent in the last six months of 2001 as losses at its United States subsidiary nearly doubled. Bridgestone/ Firestone Inc., the unit in the United States, lost $201 million in the half-year, almost twice as much as in the period in 2000, as the company grapples with the recall of up to 6.5 million tires. Over all, Bridgestone earned a pretax profit of 42.9 billion yen ($320 million) between July and December last year. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARQUIT, CHESLEA DEE STAPLETON
description: MARQUIT-Cheslea Dee Stapleton. Born November 27, 1916, Parkersburg, West Virginia, the daughter of Joseph Clark Johnson Stapleton and Georgeanne Reese Stapleton. Received a Bachelor of Arts at Ohio University, 1939. Studied at the Cincinnati Conservatory with Alfred Rose, nephew of Gustave Mahler and son of Arnold Rose, founder of the Rose String Quartet. Performed with Eugene Goossens, Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra with Bruno Walter, Eugene Ormandy, Fausto Cleva, Benjamin Britten and Max Rudolph, performed with opera companies in New York, Montreal, Cincinnati, Boston, Washington D.C. and toured with the Columbia Community Concerts Series, performed over 20 roles, including Theodora in Boris Godonov, with Enzio Pinza, Sophie in Der Rosenkavalier, Marcellina in The Marriage of Figaro, followed by a lengthy career as a vocal coach for Nathan Lane, Elizabeth Hubbard, Bettina Covo and numerous other singers, actors and performers over a career extending over 50 years. A 56-year resident of the City who maintained a home in Setauket, Long Island. Owner and shower of championship longhair dachshunds and an accomplished pianist. Predeceased on June 25, 1998 by her husband, Executive Director of the Brooklyn Developmental Center of the Herbert Birch Society and Eponym of the Henry R. Marquit Children's Center, Brooklyn, NY. Survived by her nephew, Larrick Stapleton, a niece, Victoria Martin, and numerous grand and great-grand nieces and nephews.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the announcement that France's prime minister, Lionel Jospin, will run for president misidentified the cabinet minister most likely to manage his campaign. It is Agriculture Minister Jean Glavany, a member of Mr. Jospin's party, the Socialists, not Transportation Minister Jean-Claude Gayssot, a Communist.

title: 3 Premieres for a Juilliard Anniversary
description: The Dance Division of the Juilliard School could hardly have offered a better 50th-anniversary program than the bill of new works by Robert Battle, Lar Lubovitch and Ohad Naharin that it is presenting through tomorrow afternoon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, FLORA
description: GROSSMAN-Flora. On February 21, 2002 at age 98. Loving sister of Herbert Grossman. Beloved aunt and great-aunt. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St, Sunday, 10:00 AM. Interment to follow at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery.

title: Arise, Ye Prisoners Of Starvation
description: One way to measure Russia's slow recovery from the 70-year coma of Communism is to count lobster tanks and sushi bars. Old Russia hands like me, who remember when a banana was more wondrous than a Faberg egg, swoon at the profusion of delicacies available these days in the bright showcase cities of Moscow and St. Petersburg.

title: 3 Women Are Raped in 2 Manhattan Incidents
description: Detectives are investigating three rapes that occurred Thursday, two in Washington Heights and one on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, where a woman was ambushed while going to arrange piano lessons for her son, the police said yesterday.

title: Hughes's Gold Draws Russians' Ire
description: Hours after the gold medal was presented to Sarah Hughes for her performance in the women's figure skating final Thursday night, Russian Olympic officials filed a protest, arguing that ''unobjective judging'' denied first place to their skater Irina Slutskaya.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Amtrak Elects New Chairman
description: In a unanimous vote, the seven-member board of Amtrak elected Mayor John R. Smith of Meridian, Miss., as its chairman. Mr. Smith, a Republican who has been mayor since 1993, has been on the Amtrak board since 1998 and is a member of the Transportation Committee of the United States Conference of Mayors. He takes over at a difficult time for Amtrak, which faces downsizing and eliminating routes, depending on Congressional appropriations. He succeeds Tommy G. Thompson, who became secretary of health and human services in May.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: Willie Thrower, 71, First Black Quarterback
description: Willie Thrower, whose only National Football League game made him the league's first African-American quarterback, died Wednesday at 71. He had a heart attack in his home in New Kensington, Pa., his niece, Shirley Thrower, said.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Economy Slumps
description: Taiwan's economy shrank in the fourth quarter, capping the steepest annual slump on record, as tumbling electronics exports slashed companies' profits and accelerated their flight to China, where costs are lower. Gross domestic product fell 1.9 percent in the fourth quarter from a year earlier, the third consecutive decline, the government said. For all of 2001, Taiwan's economy shrank 1.9 percent, the first full-year decline since records were first kept a half-century ago.

title: The Russians' Search for Slights
description: SALT LAKE CITY

title: Indian Town's Seed Grew Into the Taliban's Code
description: The orthodox Islamic school of thought that came to find its most virulent expression in the Taliban originated in this placid north Indian town where Hindus and Muslims peaceably coexist to the eternal rhythms of sowing and harvesting.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Profit Down At Ceramics Concern
description: Japan's largest maker of industrial ceramics, Kyocera, said it expected to earn 27.5 billion yen ($205 million) in the full year to March, 29 percent below the forecast of November. The company, whose fate is closely linked to demand for semiconductors, was hurt by falling demand for cellphones. Kyocera has already announced 10,000 job cuts at overseas units and plans to move more production to China. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Poking Fun at Social and Sibling Customs
description: Keely Garfield calls her dance company Sinister Slapstick. It is an inspired name, considering her deftly subversive outlook. But the slapstick has diminished considerably in recent years and was almost nonexistent in a program of new dances Ms. Garfield presented on Wednesday night at the Duke on 42nd Street.

title: Challenging the History Of a Slave Conspiracy
description: Among African-Americans, Denmark Vesey's plot to lead a slave rebellion in Charleston, S.C., in 1822 has always been a symbol of black resistance to oppression, proof that slaves did not docilely accept their fate. Along with slave rebellions like the Nat Turner uprising in 1831, the Vesey conspiracy has been held up as proof that the spirits of blacks were not broken by captivity. Had Vesey's plot succeeded, it would have been the largest slave rebellion in American history. But the conspiracy was thwarted by informers -- or so historians have thought. Thirty-four slaves and Vesey, the one free black, were hanged as a result of the charges, making it probably the biggest execution ever in an American civilian judicial proceeding.

title: Russia Questions Officials From North America
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 22 — The referee for tonight's game between the United States and Russia was Bill McCreary, a native of Canada and one of the most experienced officials in the National Hockey League. He has worked several games in this Olympic tournament, which involves the best players in the N.H.L. playing for their national teams. Suddenly, McCreary's nationality is an issue.

title: Daniel Pearl's Essential Work
description: Danny Pearl was the 10th journalist to die covering Sept. 11 and its aftermath. His death was a pointless, wanton murder that deprived a family, a newspaper and a profession of a beloved son, brother, husband, and colleague. His child will be nurtured with the family's stories about him, not by the presence of his father's love.

title: IDENTIX, SECURITY CONCERN, BUYING VISIONICS
description: Identix Inc., a maker of fingerprint-security devices, agreed yesterday to buy the Visionics Corporation for about $285 million in stock and other obligations to increase revenue growth. Identix's chief executive, Robert McCashin, will serve as the new company's chairman and Visionics's chief executive, and Joseph Atick will be the chief executive, a Visionics spokeswoman, Frances Zelazny, said. Identix makes products used by security and law-enforcement agencies to compare fingerprints. Visionics is a maker of face- and fingerprint-recognition systems. Each Visionics share will be exchanged for 1.3436 of newly issued Identix stock, the companies said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOWNE, GEORGE D.
description: BOWNE-George D. In his eightieth year. Passed February 21, 2002 at Plainview New York. Survived by his wife Edna and children George and Debra. Mr. Bowne was a distinguished veteran of WWII and Korea and a charter member of the 1st NY Continental Chapter (NYC) Sons of the American Revolution. It is with deep sorrow that we say farewell to our fellow compatriot. A. John Pappas, President FGG Charles T. Galbraith, FACG Founding President 1st. NY Continental Chapter, S.A.R.

title: Protecting Media Diversity
description: Congress, the Federal Communications Commission and the courts have all taken turns in recent years chiseling away at the intricate web of media ownership rules aimed at preserving competition and a diversity of voices in the nation's information marketplace. This week the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit nullified the F.C.C.'s cross-ownership rule, which prevents one company from owning a cable system and a local broadcast station in the same market. It also held that the agency had offered insufficient justification for the rule preventing any one owner of stations from reaching more than 35 percent of the nation's TV households.

title: Capturing for Generations the Agony of a Single Day
description: Someday, when the toddlers of today are elderly, a teenager may visit a museum, gaze at a dirt-encrusted briefcase found near ground zero and, for the first time, feel chilled by the reality of Sept. 11, 2001.

She opposes the project, arguing that a stable neighborhood should not be unsettled just because of rapid growth in other parts of town.

description: Heinrich Dietrich Schutz, an art dealer and fine art publisher, died on Wednesday at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 79 and lived in Greenwich, Conn.

title: ISRAELIS WEIGHING ARAFAT'S RELEASE
description: The Israeli government is considering releasing Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, from the West Bank city of Ramallah, where it has used troops and tanks to confine him for more than two months, Israeli officials said today.

title: Muslim Group Starts an Effort To Increase Voter Registration
description: The Council on American-Islamic Relations began a nationwide voter drive today, seeking to register more than 100,000 Muslim voters before the November elections.

title: Beliefs; An archdiocese a continent removed from scandal, and psychologically perhaps farther still.
description: At this time of year, when you mention ''the Congress'' to many active Roman Catholics in this area, they don't think you are talking about anything in Washington. To them, ''the Congress'' is the Los Angeles Religious Education Congress, sponsored by the archdiocese.

title: Enron-Linked Company May Be Bought
description: NewPower Holdings, a company formed by Enron to compete with traditional electric and natural gas utilities, said it was in talks to be bought by Centrica of Britain for about $133.4 million.

title: U.S. and Canada Will Clash for Gold
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 22  Now they go for gold, these friendly neighbor nations of North America, the United States against Canada. The most talented players from both sides of the border, born and raised in the National Hockey League's primary places of business, will play on Sunday afternoon before a worldwide audience in the climax of this stimulating tournament and these controversial Olympic Winter Games.

title: Riveting Sport and an Angry Backlash
description: An overview of the last Olympics, the 2002 Winter Games in Salt Lake City.

title: Governors Want Congress to Ease Welfare Work Rule
description: The nation's governors, who helped write the landmark 1996 welfare law and its stringent work requirements, are now urging Congress to let states relax those requirements for some people on welfare.

title: Corrections
description: The Frugal Traveler column on Feb. 10, about Santa Monica and Venice, Calif., misstated the name of the Santa Monica shopping area designed by Frank Gehry. It is Edgemar, not Edgewater.

title: Old Hollywood
description: When the architect John Woolf brought Hollywood Regency into vogue, everyone from Mae West to Ira Gershwin found it impossible to resist. We do, too.

title: Ideas & Trends; Behind the Grammys, Revolt in the Industry
description: SURE, there will be a lot of smiling faces when the 44th annual Grammy Awards are broadcast on Wednesday. There always are, because rules of sportsmanship apply -- even to the music business. Win or lose, you must smile.

title: Despite 'Maniacs,' A Better Report Card For a Troubled Road
description: Celebrity is fleeting, even for roads. About a year ago, a cluster of pedestrian fatalities on Queens Boulevard earned it tabloid fame as the Boulevard of Death.

title: BackTalk; Black-and-White Memoir Dissolves to Gray in Escape From Racial Typing
description: The African-American studies professor, who likes to flash his tough white Brooklyn strut as a transracial greeting, tells this story: 25 years ago, his all-white block association softball team from Park Slope was intimidated to discover that its opponent, a block association team from Prospect Place, was all black. The Park Slopers murmured to each other, ''They'll kill us.''

title: Youngest Nonstop Sailor Recounts Voyage
description: For the record-setting Australian sailor Jesse Martin, setting off to sail around the world, by himself, at the age of 17, was straightforward and proved to be relatively easy. Catching a plane a week ago from New York to Miami was not. And never mind the lost luggage.

title: Special Delivery
description: The second graders at Cornerstone Elementary School in Jersey City counted the $671.42 collected by children from the school during Trick or Treat for Unicef last fall. Then they wrote a letter to Unicef asking that the money be used for winter clothing for the children in Afghanistan. The letter made it farther than the children anticipated. It was delivered to Afghanistan by a Unicef representative, who read it in Kabul to a class of girls who had recently returned to school after being barred from classes for five years by the Taliban. The children in both places and their letter are scheduled to be featured on ''Today'' on NBC between 8 and 9 a.m. on Tuesday. The Unicef money collected by children around the country is used for water, sanitation, health care, nutrition and education. Last fall's all went to Afghanistan, the first time Unicef designated its fund-raising to children in just one country. Karen DeMasters

title: An Art of Realism Amid Recession And Budget Cuts
description: MAURINE D. KNIGHTON, executive director of 651 Arts, wants to make one thing clear: her arts organization is no victim.

title: Enriched by Working Class, Wal-Mart Eyes BMW Crowd
description: Wal-Mart Stores just became the nation's biggest company, the first retailer to have done so. It got there by sounding a single note -- low prices -- that attracted millions of mostly working-class Americans in search of everything from toilet paper to fishing rods.

title: Symbol's Chief Retires After $54 Million Loss
description: On the same day it announced a $54 million loss for 2001, Symbol Technologies (NYSE: SBL) of Holtsville said that Tomo Razmilovic had stepped down as president and chief executive and would take early retirement. Jerome Swartz, the company's chairman and one of its founders, was named chief executive, effective immediately, the company said on Feb. 14.

title: 'Salt'
description: Once I stood on the bank of a rice paddy in rural Sichuan Province, and a lean and aging Chinese peasant, wearing a faded forty-year-old blue jacket issued by the Mao government in the early years of the Revolution, stood knee deep in water and apropos of absolutely nothing shouted defiantly at me, "We Chinese invented many things!"

title: STATE TROOPERS' RECORDS
description: The state attorney general's office has authorized a measure that shields the individual records of State Police officers from the public. Former Attorney General John J. Farmer Jr. approved the plan, which first appeared in last week's New Jersey Register, shortly before he left office last month. The proposal puts many documents off-limits to all but those involved in civil or criminal litigation with the State Police. The plan comes two years after a federal monitor began to oversee the State Police because of concerns about racial profiling. The measure will make many documents exempt from a new state law that makes records more accessible to the public. John Holl

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: John Clute's APPLESEED (Tor/Tom Doherty, $25.95) is virtually criticproof. It may also be readerproof. Clute is a co-author of both The Encyclopedia of Science Fiction and The Encyclopedia of Fantasy, two reference books that dominate their respective fields. There is virtually nothing about the literature of imagination that Clute doesn't know -- which may explain why this estimable novel is so hard to read.

title: February 17-23: INTERNATIONAL; TRAIN FIRE IN EGYPT
description: Fire, apparently caused by a small cooking stove, broke out on a Cairo-to-Luxor train packed with holiday travelers. The only escape from the speeding train was out windows; many of those who jumped died on impact. Some 370 people were killed.

title: Catholic League Plays Hardball
description: A SERIES of errors by the coach of the eighth-grade girls' basketball team from St. Kilian Roman Catholic Church in Farmingdale has led the Catholic Youth Organization of Nassau and Suffolk Counties to forbid the girls from participating in the playoffs and from receiving their division championship medals. The action has raised the question of whether 13-year-old girls should be penalized because of their coach.

title: A Traveler To Saudi Arabia
description: I was riding the elevator the other day in my hotel when a Saudi gentleman got in on the floor below me. He was wearing a traditional Saudi robe and red headdress, and I was in a suit and tie. He looked me up and down for a second, before asking, ''American?'' Yes, I nodded. Then, reaching out his huge hand to me and smiling warmly, he said, ''Saudi.'' It was a kind gesture, meant to say, ''We still like you -- we hope you still like us.''

title: Perez Offers Apology to Mets
description: Outfielder Timo Perez arrived in Mets camp today and apologized to his teammates and the organization for lying about his age. Perez is actually 26, but he gave his age as two years younger when he signed with the Japanese Baseball Academy in 1994. That delayed Perez's arrival from the Dominican Republic because he needed to get his visa information corrected.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HASKELL, FLORENCE
description: HASKELL-Florence, 86, on February 16, 2002. Beloved sister, aunt and friend. Lifelong champion of the disabled, despite her own disability. We celebrate her love, courage, wise counsel and wit. She is survived by sisters Esther, Ruth; brother Leon; nieces Donna, Linda, Hope, Bonnie; nephew Kenneth; grandnieces Julie, Katla; grandnephews Brian, Tryggvi, Jonah, Matthew. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Penn South Program for Seniors or Disabled in Action.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BETHILL, LESTER
description: BETHILL-Lester. Of Tenafly, NJ. Beloved husband of the late Lillian. Devoted father of Charles Bethill. Services were held Friday. For information call ''Wien & Wien'', 1-800-322-0533.

title: (Your Name Here) Park; Peacock Panacea: That Face, That Beak
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLAHAN, JOSEPH DONALD
description: COLAHAN-Joseph Donald on February 21, 2002 of Garden City and Nassau Point, NY. Beloved husband of Jane DuMont Colahan. Loving father of J. Randolph Colahan, Laurie Jane Burke and Peter D. Colahan. Dear grandfather of Kathryn R. Colahan, Elizabeth J. Colahan, Claire E. Colahan, Peter Donald Burke, C. Randolph Burke, Jane T. Burke, Emily S. Colahan, Madeleine D. Colahan and Lily H. Colahan. Loving brother of Anne C. Vaughan and Patricia C. Cunningham. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave at 12th St., Garden City Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 pm. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Garden City Monday 10 AM. Entombment private. In lieu of flowers donations to St. Francis Hospital Development Department, 100 Pt. Washington Blvd., Roslyn, NY 11574 appreciated.

title: New Rules of Political Rhetoric
description: The reviews are in, and they are bad. President Bush's characterization of Iraq, Iran and North Korea as an ''axis of evil'' has been met by our allies' puzzled annoyance and by massive rallies in Iran that only strengthened hard-line elements there. How, one wonders, did the president and his speech writers blunder into this mess?

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 3 about Barry Alterman, general director of the Mark Morris Dance Group, misstated the date of the group's most recent performance in New York. It was last March, not in March 2000. The article also referred incorrectly to the credentials of Nancy Umanoff, the company's executive director, who took mild issue with Mr. Alterman about its financial perils. Her master's degree is in arts administration, not business administration.

title: Winter on the Sound
description: AT the Larchmont Yacht Club in winter a flotilla of forgotten tennis balls, left flat on barren clay courts, lies just beyond the gate. Dry-docked sailboats sit lonely on blocks, and the club's elaborate water park is empty. Sea gulls drop and crack shellfish upon the floating docks.

title: Leiter Changes Signs on Retirement Pitch
description: Al Leiter knows the prospect of retiring after the 2002 season is hovering over him the way it hovers over a 64-year-old who loves his lucrative job and is still one of the company's most productive workers. Everyone watches him for signals about the future and wonders if he is really going to leave a position he has and is handling so skillfully.

title: February 17-23: INTERNATIONAL; EAST MEETS BUSH
description: President Bush made a kind of goodwill tour through Asia. In Japan, he said the country was on the road to reform, though many economists believe it is near disaster. In Korea, he said that the U.S. did not intend to invade the North and that he supported South Korea's economic engagement with it -- even as street protesters argued Mr. Bush was undercutting that outreach. And in China, Mr. Bush won no promises to stop missile proliferation, but he recommended religious freedom and clapped as President Jiang Zemin sang ''O Sole Mio.'' David E. Sanger

title: Great Pretenders
description: When he was talking about one of his favorite subjects -- fame -- Andy Warhol once said, ''Good performers can somehow record complete experiences and people and situations and then pull out these recordings when they need them.'' It's a line that perfectly describes a woman who lived before his time, Countess de Castiglione, but whom Warhol would have no doubt met and probably painted or photographed had their lives coincided. Not only was she one of the great characters of the mid-19th century, but she also was the embodiment of high culture mixed with low, something that was like catnip for Warhol. And the countess would have been great for business, since she seems to have been addicted to having her portrait done and only too willing to do most of the work herself, something else that Warhol would have gone for.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBERSTEIN, WILL
description: DUBERSTEIN-Will. Goodbye, old friend. I'll miss you and the Sunday phone calls. Love and sympathy to Betty and children. Evy Malina

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Long Beach; A City With Ocean Views in Abundance
description: IN Long Beach, a city built on sand on a barrier island off Long Island's South Shore, the sale handled last month by Joyce Coletti, a sales agent at Ryan & Walis Realty, is acknowledged to be a record. A three-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bath penthouse condominium with maid's quarters and an unobstructed ocean view at the Renaissance on West Broadway sold for $1.15 million. That is a jaw-dropping figure in a city that until recently was far from fashionable.

title: Video-Game Lessons
description: To the Editor:

title: Music; A Music Maker Happy to Be Just a Conduit
description: T-BONE BURNETT remembers his first recording studio. It was the mid-1960's, and he had just graduated from high school in Fort Worth, where he grew up, officially, as Joseph Henry Burnett III, but had been, since the age of 5, T-Bone to his friends. ''I have no memory of exactly how the nickname happened, but I can say I came by it honestly,'' he recalled recently. ''It had nothing to do with the blues, though when people meet me, about half the time they say, 'I thought you were black,' and I reply, 'I thought I was, too.' ''

title: One Rule Of Plastic: Recovery Has A Dark Side
description: THE economy appears to be improving, but that hasn't stopped a lot of people from worrying about looming credit difficulties for corporations.

title: Music; More Tenors Where Those Three Came From?
description: QUIETLY and none too soon, the Three Tenors have gone their separate ways. The golden franchise they created -- pops concerts glorifying the operatic tenor voice -- has set a pattern not likely to disappear. Sensing magic in numbers, Three Irish Tenors, Three Mo' Tenors and Three Countertenors have tried their luck, with variable success. But the true sons and heirs seem to be working solo, each in his own way, all over the lot.

title: Spring Theater; Back to the Woods, With Darker Lyrics And a Dancing Cow
description: AT a run-through for ''Into the Woods'' in a New York rehearsal studio, just before the new version of the 1987 Stephen Sondheim musical came here, Vanessa Williams, the star, was startled to find the audience of families and friends weeping. It was the second act of the fairy-tale fantasy, when several characters die brutally at the hands of an evil giant and cast members begin singing the plaintive ballad about shared sacrifice, ''No One Is Alone.''

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: SOUNDS OF THE RIVER

title: It Should Add Up
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Special Education Drags On School Superintendents
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Towns; Yes, in Our Backyard: Accepting a Shelter Can Be a Lucrative Deal
description: THE last time a crowd of people in the Mayfair-Knollwood neighborhood here got together to talk about a homeless shelter in their midst, they were so adamantly against it that they tried to secede from the town. That was in 1989, when the proposal for 108 transitional apartments was only a proposal, before the two-story apartment clusters had been tucked into the woods like a cozy condo complex, although one with a curfew.

title: Brown Adopts Need-Blind Admissions Rule
description: Brown University yesterday became the last of the Ivy League institutions to adopt a so-called need-blind admissions policy, as its trustees endorsed a proposal by the university president to exclude information about applicants' financial means from all decisions on whether to admit them, beginning in 2003.

title: Spring Theater; A Hollywood Maverick, but Also a Broadway Baby
description: IN a rehearsal room eight floors above West 43rd Street, a wiry wisp of a gent is standing so close to the actors that you might mistake him for their dermatologist. When they speak their lines, it is he who registers the biggest reactions: looks of surprise, admiration, worry cross his face in a cascade of emotion.

title: Straight to Rehab
description: MORE, NOW, AGAIN

title: Staying Clean
description: Orenstein is right in asserting that research on treatment efficacy is far from definitive. Addiction is, after all, driven by a complex set of biological, emotional, social and genetic factors. Because of this complexity, many with addictions may enter treatment two or three times before they succeed in getting clean. Repeating treatment does not mean the person or treatment failed.

title: Unemployed Once, Twice . . .
description: LAST September, I joined the swelling ranks of the unemployed. I didn't actually keep a diary of my experiences, but would have had I thought of it. Nevertheless, all of the following is true.

title: Long Island Calendar
description: Art

title: The Mystery of Computers, a Bicycle for Two, and the Tango Lesson
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Elaine Stritch; Solo but Certainly Not Alone
description: THE wardrobe for the bottom half of Elaine Stritch's body pretty much sums her up: Wolford tights (''Mention them, maybe I can get a free pair,'' she rasped) stretched over the thin, coltish legs you might find on a 16-year-old gymnast, and elegant black orthopedic shoes. Like the rest of her, her legs are 77 years old.

title: February 17-23; FRONT LINES
description: THE REPORTER -- A videotape brought a gruesome, brutal end to uncertainty about the fate of Daniel Pearl, the Wall Street Journal reporter who was abducted Jan. 23 in Pakistan. The tape, delivered by a Pakistani journalist to F.B.I. agents in Karachi, shows Mr. Pearl's throat being slit and, later, his dismembered head. The chief suspect in the case, Ahmed Omar Sheikh, has told investigators that Mr. Pearl was killed in late January and that there was a parallel plot to attack the U.S. consulate in Karachi. His earlier claim that Mr. Pearl was still alive was seen as a ruse to give accomplices time to disappear. The calculus, and randomness, of risk, Page 7.

title: Art/Architecture; Fighting With the Monsters That Fill Her Studio
description: BEING big doesn't mean being invulnerable,'' said the sculptor Ursula von Rydingsvard. For nearly 25 years, Ms. von Rydingsvard has made massive abstract sculptures of scored and chiseled wood that are as intimate as they are substantial. Each work is enriched by the interplay between a monolithic scale and the caressing detail of the densely furrowed surfaces.

title: Fund Count Is Growing at a Much Slower Pace
description: Mutual funds aren't starting up the way they used to. The net growth in the number of funds last year, 165, was the lowest since 1981, the Investment Company Institute said last week, and was far below a peak of 792 in 1994 and 365 in 2000.

title: NaCl
description: SALT

title: Music; From a Long Pursuit of Weill, Blurred Lines
description: HEINZ KARL GRUBER, an inventively eclectic composer generally known as H. K. Gruber, has long been drawn to works of Kurt Weill. He has made fine recordings of them both as a singer (for the short-lived Largo label) and as a conductor (one notable outing being a ''Dreigroschenoper'' with the Ensemble Modern for RCA).

title: A Rare White In a Sea of Red
description: In a sea of red Beaujolais, white Beaujolais is rare. The house of Louis Jadot, a merchant whose label denotes the highest-quality white Burgundy, delivers a crisp, refreshing, mineral-like 2000 Beaujolais blanc called Grand Clos de Loyse, Chteau des Jacques. Manley's, 35 Eighth Avenue (Jane Street), Manhattan, charges $15 for this food-friendly chardonnay, made from old vines. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: It's Not a Pleasant Vacation for Betty
description: ''BETTY'S SUMMER VACATION,'' the play by Christopher Durang at Yale Repertory Theater, recalls Betty and Veronica comic books of the 1940's and ''Father Knows Best'' television shows of the 1950's.

title: Truth, Right and the American Way; A Nation Defines Itself By Its Evil Enemies
description: AS President Bush toured Asia last week, some world leaders worried publicly that the war on terrorism was starting to look suspiciously like the last great American campaign -- against Communism.

title: From Canada, With Racquet
description: NEWFOUNDLAND, that far northeastern province of Canada, is hardly a hotbed of sports champions. But for David Yik, that remote corner of the world was just the place to hone his athletic skills.

title: Soldier's Burial As a Non-Jew Adds to the List Of Israel's Pain
description: Staff Sgt. Michael Oxman died with five comrades when Palestinian gunmen attacked an Israeli outpost in the West Bank on Tuesday night.

title: WHITFIELD REVISITS OLYMPIC MOMENTS
description: Mal Whitfield keeps his Olympic medals -- three gold and one silver -- in his home in Los Angeles. Next year, one of them will be on display in the Armory Track and Field Center in upper Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEARL, DANIEL
description: PEARL-Daniel. In memory of Daniel Pearl-we will miss your reporting and your search for the truth. Edelman Public Relations

title: LIPA Faces A Deadline On Buying Generators
description: BARRING a last-minute change of strategy, the Long Island Power Authority will take a major step this week toward buying all KeySpan power plants on Long Island, a move that would give the state agency direct control of over 4,000 megawatts of electric generating capacity and unquestioned supremacy in ordering the region's energy future.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with the Evening Hours column last Sunday about an awards dinner held by the Citizens Committee for New York City on Feb. 11 misidentified the woman shown with Claudia Fleming. She was Megan McLaughlin, executive director of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, not Karen A. Phillips.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the text on Page 65 of The Times Magazine today, with the second puzzle solution, for the ''Pathfinder'' last Sunday, is erroneous. The idea was to fill in the grid in the direction given in the clue. The solutions in the grid are correct. The text that goes with them follows:

title: Music; An American Original Returns
description: ON the cover of his album ''Ragged Old Flag,'' Johnny Cash stands resolute, staring directly at the viewer and pointing to an American flag that is torn and tattered but still flying. His face looks as if it could grace Mount Rushmore. Like the flag behind him, that face is weathered and battle-worn, but nonetheless defiant. ''She's been through the fire before,'' Mr. Cash intones on the album's title track, alluding to the flag and the country it represents, ''and I believe she can take a whole lot more.''

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Friday, 3,062 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11, not including 19 hijackers.

title: February 17-23: NATIONAL; OKAY TO GROW
description: A federal appeals court struck down a rule that restricted cable companies' ownership of television stations and cast into doubt another that limited the number of stations a network may own. It was the latest in a series of actions by the court and regulators over the last year to cast aside rules that for decades limited the growth and expansion of the nation's media giants and cable operators. Stephen Labaton

title: Never Say Goodbye
description: Robert Altman's love letter to 70's Hollywood still influences style. This season's caftans, coverups and boy-bikinis were all part of the Malibu he called home in 'The Long Goodbye.' The cinematographer Lance Acord recreates the moment with James King.

title: The Waiting Game
description: To the Editor:

title: Strike A Pose
description: TALK ABOUT A POSEUR! In her innocent schoolgirl uniform, Oona O'Neill conquered some of the most cultured and elite men of her day. The only older man who wasn't impressed was her playwright father, Eugene, who resented her posing for the paparazzi and soiling his literary surname. This issue looks at some of our favorite ways of posing: art photographers' role playing, tourist snapshots, diva antics, even inhabiting an alternative personality altogether, as does Kate Beckinsale, who conjures up Oona so beautifully on the cover and these pages. As the greatest poseur of all, Madonna, once sang, ''Don't just stand there, let's get to it, strike a pose, there's nothing to it.''

title: Political Briefing; A Bronx Cheer In New Hampshire
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton took his campaign for president to New Hampshire and Iowa last week. Those are the states where it all starts. His message: The other Democratic hopefuls are not liberal enough.

title: E-ZPASS
description: In the wake of still more reports of financial problems for the E-ZPass electronic toll collection system, Governor McGreevey has asked Acting Transportation Commissioner James P. Fox to review the system and report back to him within 120 days. . In addition, the governor has asked the attorney general's office to review the E-ZPass contract to make sure all of its requirements were fulfilled. Karen DeMasters

title: 'More, Now, Again'
description: There are no seasons in Florida. People say that about other places, they say that about southern California, but I've lived through some freezing nights in Los Angeles. I've snuck around people's homes there and turned the thermostat up to eighty degrees because I've been so cold, especially in the canyons. But here in Florida the ground is flat, the terrain is absolute, it is always warm, it is always bright. The Christmas lights strung on the houses along the highway look ridiculous. Today there was a tornado in Miami. They showed the twister in the skyscrapers on the evening news. No one was hurt.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: Spring is approaching, and some may be starting to think about cruises. For them, a few offers to consider.

title: The View From/Kent; Humming a Few Bars Isn't Necessary for This Piano Player
description: ON nights past at the Fife 'n Drum Restaurant in Kent, the great concert pianist Vladimir Horowitz, who lived across the street, played imaginary conductor to the house pianist, waving his arms over his dinner plate while the man played.

title: (Your Name Here) Park; Dodderers, Take Heart: There Is Life After 45
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLAPP, STEEL, MARTICA (HARTLEY) MAIDEN NAME: GLORIA MARTHA ALBERNI ARGILAGOS DE MOLA
description: CLAPP-STEEL-Martica (Hartley) Maiden name: Gloria Martha Alberni Argilagos De Mola. Born Cuba July 4th 1927. Died February 2nd 2002. She was a small but powerful woman; she often referred to her self as a good thing in a small package. Her laurels are too many to mention. She will be missed around the world from USA to China. Family in the USA, Bermuda, Bahamas, Cuba and South America survives Martica. The family is asking for those who wish, to light a candle on the evening of Sunday, February 24, and have a 3-minute silence. Thank you all, that helped her, on the journey of life. Christopher and family

description: To the Editor:

description: English Tours With Stops to Smell the Flowers

title: 40 Years and 4 Minutes Away From History
description: In 1954, Roger Bannister, then an English medical student, ran a mile outdoors in 3 minutes 59.4 seconds, the first sub-four-minute mile. At the time, at the University of North Carolina, Jim Beatty was becoming a 4:06 miler with a future.

title: Washington's Checklist For Business Regulation
description: To the Editor:

title: A Lingering, Sweet Melody
description: LAST year my Dad died. Old age. He was 89. Since then, I've wanted to do something special for him, in tribute, like write a novel or a musical. He was a songwriter, perhaps best known for his songs ''Till Then'' and ''Shoo-Fly Pie and Apple Pan Dowdy.'' He also wrote for the ''Captain Kangaroo'' children's television show.

title: 2002 Games: Riveting Sport and an Angry Backlash
description: The buildup to the 2002 Winter Olympics could be charitably described as bumpy. An embarrassing bidding scandal, sluggish ticket sales and the specter of terrorism fed a sense of foreboding about the Games. The anxiety seemed to mock a handmade sign hanging two weeks ago outside a house 40 miles from here in the tiny town of Mountain Green: ''Welcome Olympics, Feel at Home.''

title: The Nation; The Tao of Enron: Well, It Sounded Good
description: IN the dictionary of philosophical terms at philosophypages.com, the word ''ethics''-- defined as that branch of the discipline concerned with ''the evaluation of human conduct'' -- is tucked snugly between ''e0os'' (a k a ''ethos,'' the Greek word for custom or habit), and ''eternal return,'' a Nietzschean dressing-up of the idea that what goes around, comes around.

title: Nigeria Grows Disenchanted With Democracy
description: A potholed road leads into this village and stops at Clinton Junction, an open space where motorcycle-taxi drivers sit leaning against their handlebars. Not far away, women sell giant yams in Clinton Square, similarly named after the former American president, who delivered a speech on democracy here.

title: Always a Gentleman
description: ''I leave you the truth,'' Marlene Dietrich is said to have told her daughter, Maria Riva, before dying. She also left some 25,000 other things, including every dispatch she ever received from her legendary convoy of lovers. Hundreds of these belongings, along with portraits of Dietrich by her mentor, Josef von Sternberg, and recollections from those who knew her, have been collected in the lavish MARLENE DIETRICH: PHOTOGRAPHS AND MEMORIES (Knopf, $40), compiled by Jean-Jacques Naudet, with captions by Riva with Werner Sudendorf. You can learn a lot about a person by rummaging through her things, and yet even if none of the pieces are missing the story can remain a puzzle. Among Dietrich's feathers, furs and flames can be found a pair of pistols believed to have belonged to Gen. George S. Patton, a playful letter of apology from William Randolph Hearst, a ''highly insured'' Russian sable cloak Dietrich often ''lost'' when she was broke (it was always returned), a musical saw and a battered rotary phone held together with tape. Between an angelic portrait of Dietrich and her daughter and a wartime snapshot of Marlene emerging from the Hollywood Canteen, where she worked kitchen detail, we find an unsigned telegram from her sometime lover Maurice Chevalier. ''I do not even want your friendship,'' it reads. ''Everything is absolutely finished between us. Nonetheless it is the best thing that could happen to me.'' The result of such strange juxtapositions is suggestive, to say the least, especially because Dietrich's own voice is conspicuously absent from the book. There is no indication, for example, of what provoked Chevalier's resentment. But of course, a lady never tells, and, as legend has it, Dietrich once said she was ''always a gentleman at heart.'' Carina Chocano

title: 'America's First Dynasty'
