title: QUICK BITE/Hoboken; Overstuffed Burritos, Not Flavored Margaritas
description: All too often, Mexican restaurants focus not on the food but on flavored margaritas and bottomless bowls of tortilla chips. That's why Mision Burrito in Hoboken is such a find. To call it a restaurant is a stretch. It's really a take-out joint, with stools by the window and dcor consisting of a wooden clock shaped like Mexico and a sombrero on the wall. But who cares about atmosphere when the food, prepared in a spotless open kitchen, is so good? Burritos ($7 to $10.50) are made the overstuffed California way, with rice and red or black beans packed inside a flour tortilla, along with a choice of chili, skirt steak, chicken, or spinach and goat cheese. Some include guacamole and sour cream, and all come with lettuce, pico de gallo and cactus strips (think Mexican pickles) on the side. The bay burrito is especially tasty, with shredded chicken that's been stewed with onions and peppers. The result is a layered flavor combination that puts the competitors' rubber bird to shame. Enchiladas ($8) are another standout, topped with cheese and slathered with a tangy tomatillo sauce, then baked in the oven so they arrive piping hot. If you can't make up your mind, there is a value-packed combination platter ($10), which includes a chicken burrito, a cheese enchilada, a beef taco and rice, beans and salad. Mision Burrito faces Church Square Park, so if the weather is fair, diners can pull up a park bench and watch all of Hoboken parade by. In my book, that beats a kitschy chain Mexican restaurant any day. Gretchen Kurtz

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERG, AUDREY RUTH
description: WEINBERG-Audrey Ruth. 69. Beloved wife, mother and grandmother, died of natural causes after a valant struggle with heart disease. Born in Larchmont, Audrey raised her family in Greenwich, CT, moving to FL in later life, but always returning home to Greenwich where she maintained an apartment. A talented artist, she will be remembered not only for her work of sculpture and clay, bronze and stone, but also for her accomplished stitching. Avid adventurers, Audrey could often be found with her husband boating, cross country by motorcycling, and most recently traveling by motorcoach. She is survived by her husband, Frank Weinberg, of Fort Lauderdale, FL; her son, Chip Weinberg of Greenwich, CT; daughters Joanne Weinberg of Martha's Vineyard and Nancy Hamilton of Wilton, CT; her brothers Ralph Deutsch of Asheboro, NC and Peter Deutsch of Darien, CT; and eight grandchildren. Friends may call at Leo Gallagher & Son Funeral Home in Greenwich, CT, Friday, March 1, between 5-7 PM. A memorial service will be held Saturday, March 2, at 10 AM at Albertson Memorial Church in Old Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the CVICU at Holy Cross Hospital in Fort Lauderdale, FL.

title: Art/Architecture; Ruins of an Old Christian Church on Lao-Tzu's Turf

According to legend, the founder of Taoism, Lao-tzu, wrote his classic work, the Tao Te Ching, during a single night's stay in the nearby hills before disappearing into the west. More than 1,000 years later, in the seventh century A.D., a Tang emperor erected a vast complex of Taoist temples on the site, calling them Lou Guan Tai. And there, more recently, Martin Palmer, a British Sinologist and theologian, claims to have discovered remains of the earliest Christian church in China, dating back to the seventh century.

title: The Satellite Subversives

They had responded to the appeal of Reza Pahlavi, son of the former shah, who lives in Maryland and addressed the Iranian people via a call-in television talk show broadcast from North Hollywood, Calif. In Iran there were enough satellite television dishes and enough people watching what came through them that a man on a telephone call to Los Angeles could hijack a demonstration on the streets of Tehran.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WITENBERG, EARL G., M.D.
description: WITENBERG - Earl G., M.D. Professor Emeritus. The William Alanson White Psychoanalytic Institute notes with sorrow the profound loss of Earl G. Witenberg, M.D., who served as Director from 1963-1992. Dr. Witenberg's service for so many years, while extraordinary, was just one small measure of his singular, indefatigable, and all encompassing dedication to the White Institute. A larger than life personality, Earl's characteristic New England sparseness, straightforwardness, stubbornness and skepticism both intrigued and tantalized his colleagues and his students. Few people who came in contact with Earl left his compelling presence without a spirited story to tell about him. Earl's scholarship was profound and his curiosity boundless. During his early tenure at the White Institute, his research vision encompassed a wide range of areas. He initiated a Visiting Distinguished Lecturer Series and he spearheaded innovative conferences to which he invited scholars from related fields, and of many schools of thought, to enrich the Institute's intellectual foundation. Earl insisted on challenging conventional thinking and in eschewing dogmatism; thereby both contributing to the education and training of creative thinkers who could embrace ambiguity, and shaping the essential and lasting identity of the White Institute. Earl's pragmatism was no where more evident than in his leadership of the Institute. He brought it from financial uncertainty to economic solvency, and purchased a landmark building. He felt that an institute could not sustain itself unless it was constantly responsive to change. He was a decisive leader: tough, persuasive, courageous, canny and occasionally irascible. Dr. Witenberg had a superb reputation as a psychoanalyst. He was concerned with the real and actual nature of the analyst's involvement with the patient, and his deep respect for the ''other'' along with his penetrating views into character made him a widely sought after and much respected analyst and supervisor. Honest to a fault, and curiously but touchingly vulnerable, Earl had little tolerance for inauthenticity. A gallant soul, Earl remained committed to the Interpersonal tradition, and he stood for the best that he, the Institute, and its graduates could offer. His legacy is enduring and more concretely forged by the Earl G. Witenberg Chair. The Chair is among the many honors awarded to him in 1992, and one which will go forward to promote the work in which he always felt privileged to engage. Our deep condolences to his wonderful family whom he loved without limit. Charles C. Harrington, Ph.D. President, Board of Trustees Joerg Bose, M.D. Director, The White Institute

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHENCK, C. NEWTON ''NEWT'', III.
description: SCHENCK-C. Newton ''Newt'', III. Long Wharf Theatre's trustees, staff and patrons mourn the loss of Founding Chairman, Newt Schenck on February 14, 2002. One of New Haven's leading public citizens, Newt championed a range of arts programs in the city. His gentle leadership will be missed. Contributions in his memory may be made to the C. Newton Schenck Memorial Education Fund at Long Wharf Theatre. Barbara Pearce, Chair, Long Wharf Theatre

title: Dressing The Audience
description: A few years ago, it was a rarity to see many African-Americans attending the New York fashion collections. But as more black designers have joined the fashion calendar, their audiences have grown, too, with many devotees dressed in the over-the-top style known in the music world as ghetto fabulous: furs, diamonds and lots of color. It is an expression of taste that will not be found at the London, Milan or Paris shows that end March 15.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: POPE JOHN XXIII

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONACO, DIANA (BERMAN) BENTON
description: MONACO-Diana (Berman) Benton. Of West Palm Beach, formerly of Bronx, NY, passed away February 21, 2002. Cherished wife of the late Joseph Monaco. Devoted mother of Robert (Linda) Benton, Allen Benton and Ida (Herman Green) Benton. Loving grandmother of Suzanne (Harry) Carlson, Claudia, Mark, Robert, David, Amanda and Sara Benton. Six great-grandchildren. Dear sister of Fannie Klein, Tessie Nerenberg, Essie Baum, Estelle (Carl) Kamhi, Shirley (Martin) Nadler, Samuel Berman and Julius ''JuJu'' Berman, nieces, nephews, cousins and friends. Diana was a partner in White Plains Wall Paper until retirement. Her freedom of spirit and love of life will be remembered by all who knew her. Her favorite words were ''Smile'' and ''Be Happy''. Chapel service 11:15 AM, Tuesday, February 26, with interment to follow, The Riverside, 180 West 76th Street, NY, NY.

title: After 3 Murders, a Neighborhood Worries
description: AFTER being jolted awake at 3 a.m. on Feb. 6 by the sound of the police and fire truck sirens and the glare of flashing lights that penetrated the shades of his bedroom window, Robert Fern couldn't believe what he saw out the window of his Jefferson Street home in Milford.

title: February 17-23: INTERNATIONAL; COLOMBIA EXPELLING REBELS
description: Faced with continued rebel abuses that culminated in the hijacking of a domestic airliner and the kidnapping of a senator on board, President Andrs Pastrana broke off talks with the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, ending hopes of a negotiated solution to a 38-year guerrilla conflict. Government planes bombed, and troops began entering, the region Mr. Pastrana had ceded to the rebel group in 1998. Juan Forero

title: Canada Seeks a Reprise Of Its 1952 Gold Medal
description: Just around midnight, as Friday evening blended into Saturday morning, a public television station in the Utah capital showed a quaint old documentary about the 1952 Olympic Winter Games in Norway. The color film was blurry with age and wear. Most of the events were held outdoors. The narrator's voice spoke in the style of old-fashioned newsreels.

title: Scooby-Doo Forever: The Curious Cachet of a Cowardly Dog
description: Though the ubiquitous ''Law and Order'' would seem to be the longest continuously running crime series currently on television, it doesn't even come close. Twenty-four times a week, children can watch cartoon private investigators solve nonviolent but nonetheless serious crimes like real estate scams, antiquities thefts, sheep rustling. The apparent culprits are hosts, mummies, the Miner Forty Niner, (Does the word ''Jinkies!'' sound familiar?) And there is no payment for services rendered (though snacks are accepted).

title: 10 More Cents for Lunch, One Less Place to Gather
description: Bobby Gotlin has walked from her house to her local center for the elderly for so long, she can't remember when she started. A retired waitress, she goes there to meet friends, play canasta and take day trips. ''It's my second home,'' she said.

title: Who's to Judge?
description: Is a poetic, ballet-influenced free-skating routine better than an athletic, entertainment-oriented one, even when the first is marred by a stumble coming out of a double axel and the second is technically perfect? Is this miniature poodle truly a more ideal specimen of its breed than that Kerry blue terrier? Is Russell Crowe's portrayal of the mathematician John Nash in ''A Beautiful Mind'' a ''powerful,'' Oscar-worthy performance or an irritating display of actorly ''mannerism''? There may be a preponderance of opinion on one side or the other of these questions, but each is fundamentally unanswerable -- which may explain why we just can't stop talking about them, especially when the official judgment conflicts with our own.

title: Deer to the Slaughter
description: ALMOST a century ago, Upton Sinclair, the noted muckraker, repaired to a small cottage in Princeton to write ''The Jungle,'' his classic book about the inhumane treatment of both people and animals in the Chicago slaughterhouses of the early 20th century. No doubt Sinclair would be astonished to know that animals are being abused in an equally cruel manner in Princeton in 2002.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARNETT, STELLA GORDON
description: BARNETT-Stella Gordon. Devoted wife of the late Louis Barnett and Jules Gordon. Beloved mother of Barbara Barnett and Dr. Richard Steinfeld and Brenda Barnett and Dr. Charles Solomon. Adored grandmother of Pamela Steinfeld and Richard Dagen and Karen and Jonathon Fishman, Lauren Barnett Steinfeld and Professor Michael Knoll, Dr. Stephen Barnett Solomon, Dr. Lawrence Solomon and Laura Davey Solomon. Adored great-grandmother of Scott Dagen, Austin and Spencer Fishman and Audrey Knoll. Adored aunt of Phyllis and David Lambert. Always in her heart, beloved parents Yetta and David Leibowitz, sister Pauline Leibowitz and brother Samuel Lambert. Services Sunday, Menorah Chapel, 2145 Richmond Ave, S.I., 12 noon. Shiva Sunday, Monday and Wednesday at the Steinfeld home. Shiva Monday and Tuesday at the Solomon home.

title: New Chic: No Sleep
description: Good news for insomniacs: At New York's Fashion Week, dark under-eye circles became a beauty statement, with models for Marc Jacobs, Helmut Lang and Balenciaga wearing fake shadows. At the Marc by Marc Jacobs show, the makeup artist Dick Page, inspired by the naturally dark coloring of the models Erin Wasson and Hannelore Knuts, painted the haggard chic look on the rest of the runway walkers, using mauve-brown shadow. ''Women with white disks of concealer under their eyes look so unnatural,'' Mr. Page said. ''Natural shadows make the eye color look more intense.'' To get the fashionably fatigued effect, Mr. Page suggests applying brown eye shadow, like Bobbi Brown Cream Shadow Stick in Wood (far left) or M.A.C. Cream Colour Base in Root (left), around the rims of the eyes with a dry makeup brush. Those less daring might try using foundation that is a shade or two darker than skin tone. CHRISTINE SHEA

description: THE BUREAU AND

title: February 17-23: INTERNATIONAL; THE GAMES
description: The 19th Winter Olympics drew to a close with Germany and Nordic nations dominating, though U.S. athletes shone in newer and more extreme sports, like snowboarding, skeleton and moguls. Surprises: the winner of the first women's bobsled event was a U.S. team, half of which, Vonetta Flowers, is the first black to leave the Winter Games with gold. Top honors in women's figure skating went to Sarah Hughes, 16, not the favorite, Michelle Kwan, 21. Tensions: The Russians, irked by a skating controversy that was resolved by their pairs team having to share the gold with the Canadian team, said Ms. Hughes should share her gold with the Russian silver medalist. Violence: mercifully absent.

title: New Cigarette Tax? Young Smokers Just Shrug
description: THE SETTING -- The smoky back streets behind the Dalton School, on East 89th Street near Park Avenue. Students huddled in their overcoats last Wednesday, stealing puffs of cigarettes between classes and after school, dutifully respecting the school's no-smoking zone out front.

title: A Restrained Celebration Of Japanese Calligraphy
description: AS part of what the Newark Museum calls its ''yearlong celebration of calligraphy in Asia,'' last summer it reopened its Japanese galleries, which had been closed for 10 years. The exhibition ''Fair Winds and Clear Water: Japanese Poetic Calligraphy,'' set up in those galleries, showcases the museum's widely diverse collection of objects that bear calligraphy.

title: Personal Business; Terror Victims' Survivors Find Tax Help
description: MOUNTAINS of paperwork. That was one of the problems Suzanne Swaine faced in the weeks after Sept. 11. Her husband, John F. Swaine, a vice president at Cantor Fitzgerald, was killed in the terrorist attacks, along with her brother, John A. Reo. She is now left to manage the family finances.

title: February 17-23: NATIONAL; COMING UP
description: President Bush celebrates the 60th anniversary of the Voice of America on Monday and meets with the presidents of Angola, Botswana and Mozambique on Tuesday. A Senate panel hears testimony on Tuesday from several Enron players: Sherron S. Watkins, Jeffrey K. Skilling and Jeffrey MacMahon. Alan Greenspan delivers his semiannual report on the economy to the House on Wednesday. A Senate panel considers the future of NATO on Thursday.

title: Ideas & Trends: Paper Chase; Whose History Is It, Anyway? The Public's or the Officials'?
description: NEWSPAPERS may provide a rough draft of history, but archives are where the raw materials are stored. And so when politicians start messing around with public archives, historians -- and, of course, archivists -- can be counted on to rise up in arms.

description: This

title: SANTIAGO'S TEMPORARY POST
description: The train that was to take Joseph Santiago from his job as Newark police director to Trenton and the post of Superintendent of the New Jersey State Police may not have derailed but it has definitely taken a detour. Last week, amid persistent questions about Mr. Santiago's handling of past tax problems in a side business he operated, Governor McGreevey shunted his nominee into a temporary job as a special assistant to the attorney general charged with studying the state police agency's antiterrorism role. Senate opponents, who have yet to hold hearings on the nomination, contended that Mr. Santiago would be the de facto head of the agency and accused the governor of trying to circumvent their role of advise and consent on appointments.

title: Fantasy Lands' Ailing Turnstiles
description: THEME parks may derive their appeal from fantastic visions seemingly detached from any real sense of time or place, but Sept. 11 brought home the reality of how rooted these destinations can be in the here and now.

title: Your Name, Everywhere
description: The craze for customization has moved beyond bedazzled denim to more prosaic items. This month, L. L. Bean, C. O. Bigelow Chemists and Pookie have come up with ways to attain a bit of bespoke in the everyday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CONHEIM, PHILLIP
description: CONHEIM-Phillip.Feb. 21, 1944. SCHNEIDER-Lorraine. Feb. 17, 1955. In everloving memory, Marilyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMAS, CURTIS
description: THOMAS-Curtis. 96, former 28 year resident of New York City, died February 21, 2002, in Oneida, NY. Mr. Thomas was a published author and formerly a professor of English and creative writing. Survived by daughter Caroline Thomas Benes of New York City. Memorial services will be at a later date. Burial will be Oakhill Cemetery, Newburyport, MA.

title: Film; A Sober Documentary About an Intoxicating Life
description: ''The nature of reality is this: It is hidden, and it is hidden, and it is hidden.''

title: Spring Theater; Pulling Out of the Garage for a Visit to Brooklyn
description: FOR more than 20 years, the Wooster Group, the downtown avant-garde theater troupe, has been presenting its unique theatrical experiments in a drafty former flatware factory in SoHo known as the Performing Garage.

title: Sonoma County
description: Not so long ago, Sonoma County was considered the Napa Valley's country cousin. But with hip new hotels and restaurants sprouting up between the vines, the once-bucolic stretch of wine country, an easy hour's drive north from San Francisco, is now about as unrefined as a $100 bottle of the local cabernet.

title: 'Boys Keep Being Born'
description: The witness to this story was a woman. Not young, not old. Working a job and buying food and vitamins every week, scanning headlines, sometimes sneaking off to a gentle foreign film like When Father Was Away on Business , a plastic orange-juice bottle filled with homemade margarita drink tucked in her purse. She jogged in the park like squadrons of others in her city, an attractive western city near an ocean.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IONESCU, VLAICU
description: IONESCU-Vlaicu. 79, on February 22, 2002 at home. Painter, art expert and critic, and premier modern exegete of Nostradamus's prophetic work. Author of eleven books on Nostradamus, published in France, Japan, Romania, and Italy. Survived by wife Lidia and children Simona, Alexandru and Alina. The family will receive friends at Edward Lynch Funeral Home, 43-07 Queens Blvd. on Sunday, February 24 from 2-5. Funeral at St. Mary's Romanian Orthodox Church, 42-14 74th St., Queens on Sunday, February 24 at 7 PM. Burial at Willowbrook Cemetery, Westport, CT after a service at St. Dimitrie Romanian Orthodox Church, Bridgeport, CT, Monday, February 25, at 12 PM.

title: Political Briefing; In Race for No. 2 Job, A First for the Nation
description: No state has elected a black woman as lieutenant governor. But that almost certainly will change this year.

title: Martha Stewart Tip: Feng Shui With Fur
description: MARTHA STEWART is a busy woman. So to picture her sitting still, with her feet perched upon an antique Chippendale coffee table in her Westport home, doing nothing, may be hard to imagine unless it is for some sort of photo op.

title: Go West, They Said. And So Should the 7 Train.
description: The Manhattan borough president has one. So do an assortment of grass-roots groups. Now, the Department of City Planning is shopping around its own design for developing a swath of Clinton and Chelsea west of Eighth Avenue between West 24th and 42nd Streets.

title: The Struggles Of the Working Class, Courtesy of Fasanella
description: The physical trials and social struggles of working-class New Yorkers are a major theme of ''Ralph Fasanella's America,'' a retrospective of works by the self-taught folk artist and labor activist born to Italian immigrants in 1914 New York (below, ''Family Supper,'' from 1972). Opening Friday at the New-York Historical Society.

title: Sports of The Times; Games Are Speeding To a Merciful Finish
description: WINTER is melting here faster than the schedule of events and the Olympic spirit. With the mountains within view beginning to brown, with the downtown streets sun-drenched and bone-dry, jackets were open yesterday, tourists carting shopping bags out of souvenir shops, already making their emotional disconnect.

description: An art review last Sunday about an exhibition of movie posters at the New Jersey State Museum misidentified the director of ''Little Big Man.'' He was Arthur Penn, not Robert Altman.

description: BASEBALL

title: Our Woman In Tajikistan
description: ''Artem,'' I said to my young interpreter in the Tajik city of Dushanbe on a day of particularly fierce ''Tajik Torture'' -- the catchall phrase we journalists used to describe the botched communications, contaminated food and oppressive bureaucracy we all dealt with. ''I'm going to teach you a new clich: When the going gets tough, the tough go shopping. Take me to the market!''

title: A Little Help Around the House
description: From replacing a floodlight high atop the garage or repairing a few cracked tiles in the bathroom, there are inevitably jobs around the house too big for the homeowner but too small for a traditional contractor.

description: THEODORE J. FORSTMANN, for the first time in years, had to explain himself.

title: Sports of The Times; Helping Professionals Survive the Struggle of Life in Retirement
description: WHEN news reports circulated about the shooting death of a limousine driver at the New Jersey country estate of the former Nets star Jayson Williams, Mike Bantom's first instinct was to wonder if there was something his office could have done.

title: Audits of Big U.S. Airlines By F.A.A. Find Problems
description: The Federal Aviation Administration belatedly released on Friday some results of its audits of major airlines in mid-2000, after a crash of an Alaska Airlines jet raised questions about industry maintenance practices, and said it found problems at America West Airlines and scattered problems elsewhere.

title: Scrambling To Regain Its Cool
description: FOR Gap Inc., 2002 is turning out to be a year for living dangerously.

title: STANDARDIZED TESTS
description: Eighth graders' knowledge of science will continue to be tested as part of an annual standardized test, William Librera, the new state education commissioner, said last week, despite a proposal he made a couple of weeks earlier to eliminate the science test. Tests this spring for 4th, 8th and 11th graders will remain unchanged. However, next year the fourth-grade tests will be eliminated and standardized testing will begin in the third grade. Tests will then be added for another grade level each year until pupils from third through eighth grades are tested annually to conform with federal education requirements. Karen DeMasters

title: Corrections
description: A theater listing on Page 13 of Arts & Leisure today for ''The Elephant Man'' misstates the given name of the playwright. He is Bernard Pom erance, not John.

title: A Crisis Gives Birth to an Inspiration for a Bridge
description: When Dave Lutz, executive director of a nonprofit planning group called the Neighborhood Open Space Coalition, saw how hundreds of New Yorkers walked over bridges to escape danger on Sept. 11, his mind went to one of his pet causes: adding walkways to the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge.

title: Players on 1960 U.S. Gold Medal Team Are Feeling Slighted
description: After today's Olympic hockey final between the United States and Canada, the players will return to their National Hockey League teams and their seven-figure salaries.

title: Music; Words to Express the Extraordinary
description: IN ''Reading Lyrics,'' an anthology published in 2000, Robert Gottlieb and Robert Kimball compiled the texts of their thousand favorite songs written from 1900 to 1975. Essential reading for anyone interested in American popular song, this estimable collection provides fascinating insights. It demonstrates, for example, how in the opening decades of the 20th century the popular song broke away from the traditions of operetta.

title: Television/Radio; The Party Girl on Sitcoms, a Hot Item Getting Hotter
description: IN this week's premiere episode of the NBC sitcom ''Leap of Faith,'' Patty, gal pal of the title character, has just had sex -- ''great, mind-blowing sex'' -- with the guy who pushes the coffee cart around the office.

title: Abortion, Worldwide
description: To the Editor:

title: Fashion Vrit
description: It's one for the books, the coffee table variety: if the worlds of fashion and filmmaking seem such an obvious pairing -- a garish marriage of attitude and glitz -- why is it that when Hollywood tries to replicate the sound and vision, spontaneity and choreography, hilarity and modelicity, decadence and irreverence, spectacle and genius of a big designer show, it more often than not results in mismatched gloves, all thumbs and loose threads?

title: Eve Ensler Wants To Save The World
description: Susan Dominus's article (Feb. 10) describes Eve Ensler sitting in her apartment, holding a cappuccino, talking about how she will help free the oppressed women of Afghanistan. Nonsense. It is the brave young American soldiers, with M-16 rifles in their hands, who, through their sacrifice and bravery, have done more to improve the lot of these women than Ensler and her limousine liberals ever will.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAFFORD, MURIEL K.
description: SAFFORD-Muriel K. Age 74 of Gainesville, GA, passed away February 22, 2002, following a sudden illness in Hall County, GA. Arrangements are complete and no services scheduled. In lieu of flowers family request contributions be made to Barnard College, 3009 Broadway, NY, NY 10027. For more info call Little-Davenport Funeral Home 770-534-5201.

title: Hearing Brings More Debate Over Ground Zero Air Quality
description: The confusion over the air quality inside and outside buildings near ground zero was clearly evident again yesterday at an investigative hearing before the national ombudsman for the federal Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Man Held in Shooting of Girl, 5; More Suspects Are Being Sought
description: A Bronx man has been arrested in connection with the shooting last week of a 5-year-old girl who was wounded by a stray bullet, the police said yesterday. Investigators said they were searching for another man, and possibly two or three, who may have also been involved.

title: Success Is Dividing Line Between Rutgers and Seton Hall
description: They are from the same state and play in the same conference, but the comparisons end there when it comes to Rutgers and Seton Hall.

title: February 17-23: ENVIRONMENT; EAST COAST DROUGHT
description: An unusually severe and extended drought has settled over the Northeast, from Maine to Georgia, raising fears of a spring and summer of water rationing and shriveled plants and crops.

title: How Growers Choose the Plants They Show
description: PEOPLE attend flower shows for all sorts of reasons at this time of year. Some enjoy the heady fragrance of flowers and greens amid winter's doldrums. Others crave the refreshing colors of daffodils and delphiniums. Still others go to learn about new plants and how they can fit into borders and landscapes. Many of the exhibitors at the Philadelphia Flower Show, which opens next Sunday, are in the last category.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUTHBERT, JOHN J.
description: CUTHBERT-John J. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of John J. Cuthbert, associated with The Times from 1959 until retiring in 1996.

title: I've Hit the Jackpot. So Now What?
description: I HATE clichs, and I find it especially distasteful when I act like one. So I was disappointed in myself when I looked inside the envelope that held my wife's inheritance check and my jaw dropped, I did a double take and I gasped for breath.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for JORDAN E. ROHAN; A Court Reshuffles the Television Deck
description: LAST week, a federal appeals court in Washington handed down a set of decisions that could reshape the nation's media landscape.

title: The Door's Open
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, EDNA
description: SCHWARTZ-Edna. On February 23, 2002. The founder of Belvoir Terrace, a Fine and Performing Arts Camp for girls in Lenox, Massachusetts died in her 91st year. Edna, beloved mother of Nancy Goldberg and Eleanor Lupo, enjoyed her four grandchildren, Laura Goldberg, Diane Marcus, Richard Grossman, Rebecca Grossman, and her great-grandchild, Sofia Rose Jain. Edna lived in Boston most of her younger life beginning her career as a ballet dancer and teacher. She spent the last 30 years living in New York City. Edna was active in the Association of Private Camps and pioneer in arts camping. The funeral will be held at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue Monday, February 25 at 12:45 pm. Burial will be in Boston at the Pride of Boston Cemetery on Tuesday, Febraury 26. Donations may be made to the Edna Y. Schwartz Scholarship Fund, c/o Belvoir Terrace, 101 West 79th Street, New York, NY 10024.

title: Desperation Drives a Zimbabwean Exodus South
description: Every night, the emigrants from the Zimbabwe side of the border creep to the rushing river and consider the dangers ahead. There are crocodiles ready to topple stealthy boats. There are twists of barbed wire and miles of electrified fence.

title: The Best Fishing Dreams End With a Big Catch
description: I have recurring dreams about fishing. And I think I know what they mean. Not in a Freudian sense; when it comes to fishing dreams I'm going to take the position that a trout is just a trout.

title: Staying Clean
description: I was pleased to see Orenstein's article. However, as someone who has been 13 years in recovery and who has spent many of those years working with addicts and alcoholics, I was disturbed to read that the healing community still approaches addiction with a brutal self-righteousness that is almost medieval. We live in a culture that still views addiction as a moral failure. This is, as Orenstein suggests, inhumane. We are responsible to one another for our common humanity at all times.

title: In Pursuit of More Room, the Seaport Museum Unearths Buried Treasure
description: In a city, almost everyone has to make accommodations for history, even history museums. So, like Melville's narrator, who was forced to share a bed with Queequeg, the South Street Seaport Museum is making room for items found hiding in its future galleries: a hotel, a small factory, a coffee company and a sailors' boardinghouse.

title: Savings in the Air and on the Sea
description: The Star Clipper, a four-masted 170-passenger vessel that sails out of Barbados, is offering round-trip air fare from New York, Miami and Washington for $298 a person and two-for-one pricing on the cruise. This offer is for May and June out of New York and May only from the other cities. The Star Clipper leaves on one-week trips each Sunday through ports including Martinique, Antigua, St. Lucia, St. Barts, St. Kitts and Grenada, with ports alternating from week to week. Cabins start at $738 a person, with the discount, based on double occupancy. The offer is limited; restrictions apply. Information: (800) 442-0551 or www.starclippers.com .

title: Spring Theater; It's Sondheim's World But They Get a Shot At Reimagining It
description: STEPHEN SONDHEIM'S 72nd birthday may be next month, but the celebratory mood should last longer. In May, the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington opens a Sondheim Celebration that includes new productions of six of his musicals, to be performed in repertory from May 10 through Aug. 25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOOTA, ANNABEL (NEE OPLER)
description: KOOTA-Annabel (nee Opler). Passed away on February 17, 2002. Beloved wife of Jacob Koota. Cherished mother of Jane, Judith and Paul. Loving grandmother of Joan, Andrew, Matthew, Christopher, Jonathan, and Daryl. Honored mother-in-law of Dr. Barry Driscoll. Admired and beloved by family and friends.

title: Teenager Held In the Killings Of Six People
description: In crimes that the authorities described as unimaginable, a 16-year-old boy has been charged with killing six people and wounding a seventh in shootings over two consecutive days this month in Camden County, N.J. Five of the people were apparently killed to cover the assailant's tracks, the authorities said.

title: Girls Just Want to Be Mean
description: Today is Apologies Day in Rosalind Wiseman's class -- so, naturally, when class lets out, the girls are crying. Not all 12 of them, but a good half. They stand around in the corridor, snuffling quietly but persistently, interrogating one another. ''Why didn't you apologize to me?'' one girl demands. ''Are you stressed right now?'' says another. ''I am so stressed.'' Inside the classroom, which is at the National Cathedral School, a private girls' school in Washington, Wiseman is locked in conversation with one of the sixth graders who has stayed behind to discuss why her newly popular best friend is now scorning her.

title: Nets' Collins Makes Mark In Subtle Ways
description: By N.B.A. rookie standards, Jason Collins is a thinking-man's player.

title: Credit and Credibility
description: There was a group of independent analysts that should have been in a position to blow the whistle early about Enron's true condition: Moody's Investors Service, Standard & Poor's and Fitch Ratings. Through their evaluation of a company's creditworthiness, the Big Three rating agencies provide investors with an important assessment of its financial health. In this case, their judgments were too little, too late.

title: The Parrots of the Pantanal
description: THE hyacinth macaw is the biggest parrot in the world. It is all cobalt blue, with yellow trim around its eyes and bill, and there is more than a yard of it.

title: Alain Vanzo, 73, Famed Tenor Who Embodied French Lyricism
description: Alain Vanzo, a leading French lyric tenor of the postwar generation, died on Jan. 27. He was 73 and lived in Gournay-sur-Marne near Paris.

title: The Stephin Merritt Standard
description: It's 6:30 p.m. at a Chelsea bar with black tinted windows. Inside a few regulars are hunched around the bar arguing loudly about Mike Bloomberg. Dance music, heavy on the bass, thumps through the room. The walls are plastered with prints of nude, muscular bodies, and in a corner a thick man in a tight black T-shirt tends to a rack of male sex toys.

title: Belgrade Relishes Life At Peace
description: IN 1990, Belgrade was a bustling worldly city, an oasis of cafes, culture and night life that formed the cultural center of the Balkans. The next year, however, eight years of almost continuous war began, in which the old Yugoslavia broke up along the fault line of religious tensions and nationalism. The conflict culminated in 1999 when NATO bombed Serbia to force the Yugoslav leader Slobodan Milosevic to withdraw his security forces from Kosovo.

title: Pechstein Gets Gold, Record and Wig
description: Her managers wanted her to wear the wig if she won. Claudia Pechstein said fine, but she was not about to bring it to the women's 5,000-meter speedskating race today. It would jinx her. So her managers brought it in a bag. Then they waited.

title: Avoiding Disgrace
description: To the Editor:

title: Angola Shows Rebel's Body On Television
description: Film of the bloodied body of the Angolan rebel leader Jonas Savimbi, surrounded by soldiers and swarms of flies, was shown on state television late today, barely 24 hours after he was killed, the government said, in a commando raid in the far eastern region of the country.

title: JACOBS SETS WORLD RECORD FOR 3 MILES
description: Regina Jacobs, running the final 16 laps of the 24-lap 3-mile run by herself, posted a world indoor best of 14 minutes 44.11 seconds yesterday at the Evian Mayor's Trophy meet at the Armory Track and Field Center in Manhattan. The previous best was 14:53.80 for 3 miles, a distance not run that frequently indoors, set by Christine McMiken of New Zealand in 1985.

title: Mauresmo Wins Dubai Tournament
description: Third-seeded Amlie Mauresmo beat her fellow Frenchwoman Sandrine Testud, 6-4, 7-6 (3), yesterday in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, to win the $585,000 Dubai Open.

title: Hinting at the Hint of a Story
description: They are like so many messages let out of the bottle. Crumbs of paper, accidental graffiti, escaped from purses, notepads and windshield wipers. They swirl in the wind, nip at our heels, curl into dark corners. Harried objects of the moment, printed and in script, evoking the licked tip of a yellow, No. 2 pencil, Bic-stained fingers. They become cryptic scraps, hinting at the hint of a story. Certainly not the opening lines of any tale, but a clause leaked from the middle: the visual equivalent of overheard whispers. And, finally, they feel human, fragile, cultural connective tissue. As the poet Charles Simic says, ''The ephemeral is eternal.''

title: White House Memo; Cheney Takes to the Open Road And Basks in a Warmer Spotlight
description: Vice President Dick Cheney has suffered a hail of criticism for refusing to release records of meetings his energy task force held with executives from the Enron Corporation and other companies. This week, Mr. Cheney found a way to change the subject: skip town.

title: Laurie Nash, Paul Geall
description: Laurie LeNoir Nash, a daughter of Nancy and Paul Nash of Morristown, N.J., was married last evening to Paul Michael Geall, a son of Shirley Geall and Dr. Michael G. Geall of Neenah, Wis. The Rev. David A. Stout performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Higher Yields, Low Threshold
description: Suffering from skimpy returns on certificates of deposit or money market accounts but don't have the $10,000 or more that typifies bond investments?

title: An Unworthy Judicial Nomination
description: A heated debate is shaping up over Judge Charles Pickering, President Bush's choice to fill a vacancy on the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals. Mr. Pickering's critics have implied that he is a racist. His supporters have responded that he has warm relations with blacks in his hometown, Laurel, Miss., and that he is being smeared for ideological reasons. We believe that Mr. Pickering bears no animus toward blacks and that charges of racism have no place in this debate. But based on the serious questions raised about his record as a judge, we urge the Senate Judiciary Committee to vote down his nomination.

title: Take the Money
description: THE SUMMONS

title: Private Sector; From the Ranks, Unassumingly
description: BILL WELDON is the kind of guy who says he never really had his eye on the chairman's job at Johnson & Johnson, the global health care giant, and you almost believe him. But that is the job that will soon be handed to Mr. Weldon, a plain-speaking son of a Broadway stagehand and a seamstress, who has spent virtually his entire working life at the company.

title: America's Rails: Seeking Direction
description: To the Editor:

title: February 17-23: ENVIRONMENT; BIOENGINEERING WARNING
description: A dozen top biologists spent two years studying the federal process for issuing permits for bioengineered plants for the National Academy of Sciences, the nation's pre-eminent scientific advisory group.

title: America's Rails: Seeking Direction
description: To the Editor:

title: Suffolk Is Reviewing Land Acquisition Steps
description: Robert J. Gaffney, the Suffolk County executive, is reviewing recommendations to tighten procedures for county land acquisition programs in the wake of conflict-of-interest charges against the county's former real estate director.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Changes Continuing at Hempstead Shopping Area
description: THE success of the first phase of a major $65 million redevelopment project -- the Hub at Hempstead -- has officials hoping that the village's downtown area is on the way to regaining some of its past glory as ''the hub of Long Island.''

title: Web Site Helped Change Farm Policy
description: Throughout the angry Senate debate about whether to limit subsidies to wealthy farmers, lawmakers kept referring to ''the Web site'' to make their points.

title: Staying Clean
description: Your article describes triggers like certain smells, places or people that can cause an addict to relapse. Readers may be interested to hear of a new, highly controversial form of behavioral therapy called Exposure Response Prevention. It exposes addicts to simulated versions of their drugs of choice and to the equipment to prepare and consume them. Exposure to these catalysts (bongs, rolling papers, coke spoons, etc.) can elicit powerful cravings that addicts are taught to handle without giving in to them.

title: What I Learned at Camp
description: To the Editor:

title: Emily Brisker, Andrew Kotchen
description: Emily Catherine Brisker, a daughter of Melinda and Frank Brisker of Cincinnati, was married last evening to Andrew Douglas Kotchen, a son of Deborah Kotchen of West Hartford, Conn., and William Kotchen of Chester, Conn. Rabbi Rene Feller officiated at Studio Max, a photographer's studio, in New York. The Rev. Robert A. Perless, a minister of the Reformed Church in America, assisted.

title: The Nation: Body and Soul; Why Disposing of the Dead Matters to the Living
description: IN the new film ''Last Orders,'' a clutch of old friends are entrusted to scatter the ashes of a friend. They take turns holding him, or what's left of him, in a brown urn on their long ride to the seaside.

title: ABBOTT DISTRICT COUNCIL
description: Governor James E. McGreevey last week created a council responsible for ensuring the implementation of the State Supreme Court's Abbott decision in 1981 to support the state's poorest urban schools. The decision orders the state to provide urban school districts with educational opportunities equal to their suburban counterparts. There are currently 30 designated Abbott districts in the state including Newark, Camden and Trenton. The Abbott Implementation and Compliance Coordinating Council will consist of seven members, including state education officials and members of The Education Law Center, which represented the poor districts in the Abbott case.

title: Abingdon Square Park: A Triangle in Controversy
description: These days, there seems to be only one thing about the park at Abingdon Square that everyone agrees on: the sliver of open space between Hudson Street and Eighth Avenue is not a square, but a triangle. Beyond that, the city's sixth oldest park is the center of controversy over a proposal to reconfigure the one-fifth-acre space.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARGOLIS, BERT
description: MARGOLIS-Bert. The Camp Greylock Directors, Staff, Alumni, and Community mourn the passing of one of its most beloved and longest serving Directors who passed away February 19, 2002 at his home in New York City. Born May 12, 1917 in Montgomery, WV, Bert attended Greylock as a camper and a counselor. He served as an officer in the Army Air Corps before joining the Greylock Directorate in 1949, retiring as Director Emeritus in 1995. Bert was a pioneer in children's summer camping, where his model of teaching balanced excellence in instruction with insistence on kindness, and fair play. His intolerance for bullies was years ahead of its time. Through his vision and compassion, Bert inspired many. He is survived by his wife, Barbara, his sister Elaine, his daughters: Margaret, Katherine, Elizabeth, and Victoria, and nine grandchildren. He will be missed.

title: Acronymania
description: Who affixes glorious names to acts of Congress -- with words whose initial capital letters spell out a hard-selling acronym?

title: Dillon and Spitzer Clash Over Abortion
description: MIECCIA WEBB is 26 and eight months pregnant with her second child. She lives in Wyandanch and is unemployed and unmarried. When she was pregnant three years ago, she thought about abortion. At the beginning of her second unplanned pregnancy, she thought about abortion again.

title: Tired Enough and Brave Enough to Say No
description: ON Dec. 1, 1955, without warning, a 42-year-old seamstress from Montgomery, Ala., touched off a firestorm. No revolution was ever begun with more quiet dignity.

title: Video-Game Lessons
description: To the Editor:

title: A Modest Solution To a Feeble Foghorn
description: In reading the article about the phonically feeble foghorn now installed at the Montauk lighthouse [''Montauk Light Dimmer Switch Raises Outcry,'' Feb. 17], I can't help but wonder if it's not just a matter of misplaced resources. Harking back to the issue of noisy train whistles, which came with the new L.I.R.R. locomotives on the Montauk branch, perhaps a few could be dropped off at ''The End'' and installed in the lighthouse!

title: Camby to Return Against Lakers, But Only to Watch From Bench
description: The Knicks would rather have him on the court, but having Marcus Camby on the sideline is the next best thing.

title: A Berlin Exhibition Examines the Holocaust
description: Sixty years ago, Nazi officials convened in a villa at the Wannsee in Berlin to discuss ''a final solution to the Jewish question.'' The ensuing Holocaust is the subject of a multimedia presentation through April 9 at the German Historical Museum in Berlin in conjunction with the Topography of Terror Foundation, Wannsee House Memorial and the German-Russian Karlshorst-Berlin Museum and the Sachsenhausen Memorial and Museums.

title: Staying Clean
description: Many times since Sept. 11, I have said that winning the war on drugs is every bit as critical as winning the war on terrorism. Drugs destroy families and communities. They are every bit as insidious as Al Qaeda.

title: The First Car Is Returning To Production
description: BRAND heritage'' is the rage among automakers, which hope to gild their sales by mining their past glories. Mercedes-Benz has taken this concept beyond retro car designs and sepia-tinted advertisements by creating Classic Centers to service and restore vintage Mercedes automobiles.

title: POSTINGS: 15th Annual Co-op and Condo Expo; Free Seminars, Free Advice
description: Avoiding discrimination against prospective buyers and security measures that can be taken to protect buildings are among the subjects of seminars that will be part of the 15th annual Co-op and Condo Expo, to be held tomorrow at the New York Hilton, Avenue of the Americas at 53rd Street. Admission is free.

title: Conservatives Decided Nassau Assembly Race
description: If the special election in the 19th Assembly District [''Nassau Assembly Seat Goes to the Republican,'' Feb. 17] had counted only the Democratic and Republican lines, Steve November, the Democratic candidate, would have beaten David McDonough, the Republican, by 199 votes. McDonough won by 254 votes only because of the Conservative votes cast for him.

title: Tough Guy To Tough Guy
description: LEON LIVINGSTON'S career with the New Jersey Department of Corrections took him through five state prisons and juvenile detention centers. During 25 years on the job he was usually on edge, shepherding inmates through cellblocks, keeping a wary eye on prison gangs and worrying constantly about the safety of the men and women under his command.

title: Madagascar Declares Emergency
description: The government of Madagascar has declared a state of emergency after the main opposition candidate proclaimed himself the country's new leader following a two-month dispute over presidential election results.

title: Iginla Leads the Way to Gold and an Olympic First
description: WEST VALLEY CITY, Utah, Feb. 24  Jarome Iginla came into the Olympics as the top scorer in the National Hockey League, and left it today as the top scorer in a game that brought home the gold to a nation that has waited 50 years to welcome it back.

title: Washington's Checklist For Business Regulation
description: To the Editor:

title: Gwynne Rivers, Robert Cochran
description: Gwynne Vanessa Rivers, a daughter of Clarice Rivers of New York and the painter and sculptor Larry Rivers of Southampton, N.Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Robert Laurence Cochran, a son of Barbara and Robert B. Cochran Jr. of Livingston, N.J. Cantor Daniel Rouse officiated with the Rev. J. Carr Holland III, an Episcopal priest, at the National Arts Club in New York.

title: Letters
description: Peggy Orenstein's cover article "Staying Clean" drew praise from rehab providers and former users confirming that, as reported, there is no quick fix in treating addiction and no guaranteed cure. And Lauren Slater's critique of self-esteem continues to pull in provocative mail.

title: Consumers Have Saved The Day. Well, Maybe.
description: SKEPTICISM about the economy is becoming harder to sustain. The latest statistics are too hopeful. They increasingly suggest that recession is giving way to recovery, although the three most important statistics -- business investment, corporate profits and production capacity -- have yet to go in the right direction. Until they do, the incipient recovery will have no legs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWIN, LILI. NEE SPIELER
description: LOWIN-Lili. Nee Spieler. Age 93. Passed away peacefully on February 19th after a short illness. Lili was a wonderful mother to George and Joan, the best friend of their spouses Erica and James, and a doting grandmother to Rachel and Leanne Davis. Born in Vienna, Austria, Lili fled the Nazis in 1938. She settled in the New York area where she enjoyed a successful career as a designer of children's clothing. No one had a greater passion for opera than Lili -counting among her close friends some of the world's most notable operatic names. She was also known for her love of travel. Lili was a special lady whose loyalty, valor and love of life will be sorely missed. A celebration of Lili's life will be held at a date to be announced. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Lili's memory may be made to the Leonie Rysanek Fund c/o The George London Foundation, P.O. Box 231276, NY, NY 10023.

title: An Alternate Locale for Tyson
description: Mike Tyson's odyssey in search of a fight site seemed to have ended last week when the D.C. Boxing and Wrestling Commission cleared the way for a June bout there. Yet, judging by this note that the owner of a large house in an affluent Washington suburb found under a windshield wiper of his car last night, Tyson's handlers have learned to have a backup plan:

title: How to Reclaim Canadian Taxes
description: AN exchange rate favorable to United States visitors makes Canada an alluring place to vacation and shop. A U.S. dollar is worth $1.60 Canadian, up from $1.35 five years ago. Yet the sales taxes add up quickly. Buy a $100 camera in Toronto and your bill, with taxes, will be $115. Pay $1,400 for a week's accommodation, and the tax bite will be $210. Visitors can often reclaim taxes paid for accommodation and tangible goods, defined as items taken out of the country. There are some fine points to know, however, and recent changes may require a stop at the border.

title: Onward in Armonk
description: THE doughnut machine snarled and hissed, a line stretched out the door and all the Schultz's Cider Mill regulars were there. For a moment, it looked like nothing had changed and nothing ever would.

title: Ensemble Opens School's Baroque Festival
description: WHEN the Hoff-Barthelson Orchestra opens the school's 37th annual Baroque and Beyond Festival next month, it will arrive with high praise -- not to mention a $7,000 grant -- from the New York State Council on the Arts. The council's director, James Jordan, called its programs ''outstanding,'' noting that the judging panel found the ensemble ''ranked among the top community school orchestras in the country.''

title: In Ardsley, a Sushi Bar Rules
description: ONE needn't go hungry in Ardsley, where restaurants seem to outnumber nail shops. Potential diners can park in the center of this busy shopping area and choose among several Japanese restaurants alone, all within walking distance. While each of these restaurants has its own charm, a winner is the snappy, extremely helpful service at bustling Sushi Man, where the sushi counter with its excellent stock of fresh raw fish takes center stage.

title: No Standards
description: To the Editor:

title: Film; Filmmakers Linger to Look at Death's Aftermath
description: MOVIES have given audiences countless previews of death, but they rarely force us to grieve. In film, death is usually an action sequence. Grief is reduced to a pantomime of denials and screams, of tears and silences. But a number of recent films -- several of them nominated for Academy Awards -- have taken a long look at the mourning that usually passes off-screen. And it might be a sign of the times that audiences have seemed drawn to movies about the loss of life.

title: February 17-23: NATIONAL; MAMMOGRAPHY URGED
description: Moving to settle a sudden controversy over mammograms, federal health officials recommended breast cancer screening every one or two years for women age 40 to 69. The guidelines, which expand a previous recommendation calling for mammograms for those over 50, stem from an evaluation by preventive health experts. The experts considered, but rejected, a recent Danish analysis identifying serious flaws in the studies used to justify the tests. Sheryl Gay Stolberg

title: For One Family, A Practical Craft Has Become Art
description: FOR Jack Combs, decoy carving is a way of life, a family tradition passed on through at least five generations, dating from the 1870's. His son Michael is the latest Combs to follow in his family's footsteps. But to him, decoy carving is less of a practical pursuit and more of an expressive art form.

title: Spring Theater; On and Off Broadway, a Season Awash in Starlight
description: THE vernal equinox is the time of year when the summer sky begins to come into view. This year, as the seasons shift, astronomers are not the only ones with something to anticipate in the firmament; indeed, New York theatergoers won't have to look up to see stars. Maybe limited runs are making New York theater productions more attractive to film actors. Maybe it's New York itself, and a show of solidarity after Sept. 11. Or maybe it's just an astrological anomaly.

title: The Devil And Miss McGowan
description: When Rose McGowan is bad, she is very, very bad. Look how comfortably she slips into cinema's naughtiest roles in this season's sexiest get-ups.

title: Fund Count Is Growing At a Much Slower Pace
description: Mutual funds aren't starting up the way they used to. The net growth in the number of funds last year, 165, was the lowest since 1981, the Investment Company Institute said last week, and was far below a peak of 792 in 1994 and 365 in 2000.

title: After Lilco, A Calmer Arena
description: THE former chairman of the Long Island Lighting Company, William J. Catacosinos, is still in the utility game.

title: Monks and Sewer Lines In God's Country
description: IN many disputes each faction believes God is on its side. In a case in Morristown, one party might be said to have a special claim; it is the Benedictine Order of monks, who own St. Mary's Abbey. The monks want to turn their only asset -- their land -- into a revenue-producing engine to support their aging order into perpetuity.

title: At the Ethnic Village, Warm Cultural Traditions Mix With the Frostbite
description: Snowbound mountains hug Salt Lake City. A wintry breeze, not constant but regular, chaps the lips and waters the eyes.

description: Not Branding, but Naming Rights To the Editor:

title: Was It Good for You?
description: Remember the Dirty Young Men? In their company, Philip Roth's Alexander Portnoy, the onanist with the passion for raw liver, and John Updike's Rabbit Angstrom, the sympathetic serial adulterer, stand out for having achieved a place in the modern American canon. But plenty of others made their lustful mark during the so-called 60's, the unwieldy era that began in the 50's and ended in the 70's. There were also, for example, Norman Mailer's Sergius O'Shaugnessy, the Greenwich Village bullfighting instructor who sodomized and insulted a college girl to bring her to her first climax, and Harold Brodkey's gentler but no less persistent Wiley Silenowicz, who went to unparalleled lengths to give his intimidatingly beautiful girlfriend the orgasm she claimed she wasn't interested in having.

title: Far From Crowds, Protester Stands Alone
description: Jeremy Beckham is not an anarchist. He is not a Bolshevik, communist or a pot-smoking hippie. He is a conscientious objector to the flesh-eating world, and if you ask the mayor, Jeremy Beckham is a great citizen.

description: FORTUNE'S FOOL'' is making it to Broadway because Rita Gam knew some people.

description: Rushdie to Lecture

title: When Riding the Rails Meant Something Different
description: All the hot spots for rail-sliding and kick-flipping in Hamilton Township bear signs saying ''No skateboarders allowed.'' But this spring there may be a safe haven for the miniature Tony Hawks of Southern Jersey.

title: Political Briefing; In Any Language, A Big Debate in Texas
description: First it was on. Maybe. Then it was off. For sure. Now it's back on.

title: Film; Watching a Woman's Invention of Herself
description: ESTHER KAHN is a young heroine so stubborn and single-minded that even her creator is a little scared of her. ''She's the kind of girl that all the other girls hate,'' says Arnaud Desplechin, director of ''Esther Kahn,'' which is opening Friday in New York. ''She thinks that there's only one path you can take to becoming a human being like everybody else, with a precise set of directions. It's crazy. But I admire her.''

title: Dinner and a Movie
description: Nasty with unpredictability and generally greeted with both horror and delight, the sardine-packed Stargazy Pie, not unlike Owen Wilson and Wes Anderson's ''Royal Tenenbaums,'' is a spectacular, witty surprise and guarantees to kindle conversation at your next dinner party. Academy voters take note.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Money & Business last Sunday about accounting by Global Crossing, the telecommunications company, for the sale and purchase of fiber optic cable capacity misstated the equivalent practices at Tyco International and WorldCom. Tyco recorded the money received as deferred revenue. WorldCom accounted for it as an asset sale. Neither company used the sales to show increased revenue on its income statements.

title: The Things They Carried
description: In the absence of a procedure for returning items confiscated by airlines inspectors, the constitutional guarantee of security in one's possessions is gone (photographs by Susan E. Evans, Feb. 10). The pictures in your gallery are evidence that the airlines, at the very least, are guilty of overzealous petty larceny. How many of the items have been implicated in an airline incident? An inhaler? Oh, come on!

title: Destiny's Child
description: She was born in Bermuda. Her mother wrote short stories; her father, a chronic alcoholic, was the only American playwright to receive the Nobel Prize in Literature. Barely a toddler when her father ran off with another woman, she and her older brother were raised by their mother. Her formal education ended at Brearley, an exclusive girls' school in New York City. Accepted by Vassar College, she chose instead to seek an acting career, and following a fleeting appearance in summer stock, went to Hollywood and met her future husband. He was 36 years her senior, thrice divorced and a comic genius. When she turned 18, they married. Immediately, her father disowned and disinherited her. The marriage, however, endured; she had eight children, and remained with her husband for 34 years until his death in 1977.

description: Avoiding Disgrace

title: Executive Life; Ideas (and Horseplay) Flourish at 39,000 Feet
description: JUST what do all those corporate chieftains do up in the sky as they crisscross the country in their private jets?

title: Charlie's Angel
description: Charlie Chaplin's better half, Oona O'Neill, was the embodiment of uptown glamour, from her days as a Manhattan deb to her Hollywood exile. The actress Kate Beckinsale was born to play the role.

description: A Setback at the Ritz

description: To the Editor:

title: Hamptons Fisherman Gets Away Again
description: A CRUSTY East Hampton fisherman who believes King James II gave him the right to fish without a state license has turned out to be as slippery as an eel when it comes to proving him wrong in court. But maybe the state Department of Environmental Conservation prefers it that way.

title: Ohno's Move Backfires, Keeping Him Out of Final
description: Many fans who packed into the Salt Lake Ice Center tonight were wearing temporary soul patches -- black, brown or white tape on their chins -- made popular by Apolo Anton Ohno.

title: Commercial Property/The Bronx; Prime Office Space Is Planned in Unlikely Sites
description: THE Bronx is not the first place most people would think of when looking for Class A office space. But two developers think the time may be ripe to entice tenants to the borough's lower rents, central location and good transportation links.

title: Profile In Courrges
description: Everybody, meet Blair. Blair Sabol, from Villanova, Pa., future fashion guerrilla; a girl who would one day be known as the Abbie Hoffman of Seventh Avenue, who would pen a fashion column rife with deliciously bitchy observations no longer possible in these stifling, politically correct times. In this 5-by-6-foot oil canvas, Blair is 18 years old, and barely but gratefully graduated from high school in Lower Merion, Pa. High school would be the worst years of her life.

title: David Cogan, 'A Raisin in the Sun' Producer, Dies at 78
description: David J. Cogan, a theater owner, producer and manager who co-produced Lorraine Hansberry's drama ''A Raisin in the Sun'' on Broadway in 1959, died on Feb. 7 at his home in Bedford, N.Y. He was 78.

title: A Billionaire Leads the Campaign to Keep Switzerland Apart
description: Christoph Blocher, Switzerland's best known politician, makes a point of not appearing larger-than-life. Though he is a billionaire businessman, he likes to come off as a small-town guy fighting the establishment.

title: Correspondence/Dangerous Stories; Doing Your Best to Gauge the Risks Where Reporting Isn't Too Safe
description: IT could have been any of us.

title: Corrections
description: The Streetscapes column last Sunday, about Low Library at Columbia University, misstated the format of the annual Pulitzer Prize award ceremony held there. It is a luncheon, not a dinner.

title: Slammin' Sigurd
description: To the Editor:

title: New Flag Atop L.I. Legal Hill
description: MEYER, SUOZZI, ENGLISH & KLEIN doesn't advertise. It doesn't need to. Since it was established more than 40 years ago, this law firm has relied on the reputations and Rolodexes of its partners to bring in business.

title: After Much To and Fro, an Oak Falls
description: Eight stories and growing, it survived two world wars, outlasted ''The Fantasticks'' and never harbored pestilent beetles. But last week, a century-old oak, rooted in an empty lot on Johnson Avenue, met its maker.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Automobiles section on Feb. 10 about automotive Web sites included an outdated figure for the percentage of revenue that Autobytel, an online service that refers car shoppers to dealerships, receives from banner advertising. In 2001, sources other than dealer fees, including advertising on its four sites, dealer training programs and insurance packages, accounted for 26 percent of revenue; the 40 percent figure was for 2000.

title: Brookhaven Deer Shows High Radiation
description: A deer believed killed by a vehicle on the William Floyd Parkway in January was found to be contaminated with the radioactive isotope cesium-137 at twice the highest levels ever seen at Brookhaven National Laboratory, lab authorities reported last week.

title: 'It Takes a Lot of Courage To Do Something New'
description: SHIRA P. WHITE contends that American companies need to be more creative, yet one company she wrote about, Enron, took creativity to a level that proved its downfall. In an interview, she spoke about striking the right creative balance. WILLIAM J. HOLSTEIN

title: GOING OUT
description: An guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Spring Theater; It Came From New Orleans
description: IT began like a Mickey and Judy musical production, a hey-gang-let's-put-on-a-show fantasy, Creole style.

title: 'Genes, Girls, and Gamow'
description: Although my hair was properly long and my accent toned to suggest almost an English origin, Odile Crick told me I had still far to go before I would look right walking along Cambridge's King's Parade, much less looking purposefully indolent in one of its college gardens. My appearance would not have mattered if I were the same as a month ago—an unkempt slender figure who said what I thought as opposed to what good manners required. But now that Francis Crick and I had given the world the double helix, Cambridge in its own quiet way was bound to ask what we looked like. The time had come to acquire at least one set of clothes that would go well with Francis's Edwardian elegance. I was not trusted to act alone and Odile accompanied me to the men's clothing shop across from the chapel of John's (the College). My ill-fitting American tweed jacket was thrown out and replaced by a blue blazer and associated gray trousers. They would much better express my new status as the co-winner of a very great scientific jackpot.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAIDIN, PHILIP
description: CAIDIN-Philip. Animal activist, passed away early morning Feb. 16, 2002, at Calvary Hospital. He had been suffering from advanced prostate cancer. Friends are invited to attend a meditation on Wednesday, February 27, from 12:00 to 12:30 PM, at Crestwood Memorial Chapel, Inc., 33 Spring Street, Manhattan, 212-431-6712.

title: For Senator Torricelli, Poll News Is Bad News
description: With around eight months to go before the United States Senate election, poll numbers are bound to fluctuate. But a survey released by a Republican pollster last week suggests that Robert G. Torricelli, the Democratic incumbent, may have some work to do to convince voters that he deserves another six years.

title: Alicia Keys Is the Talk Of Her Old Neighborhood
description: Kaldar A. Rodgers hasn't seen Alicia Keys in the last few months. But he has seen her face on record-store posters, and he has heard her rhythm-and-blues smash hit, ''Fallin.' '' He knows that when the Grammys are awarded on Wednesday, Ms. Keys has a chance to win six, including the award for best new artist.

title: Remembrance Of Things Ast
description: Ever one for the attention-grabbing gesture, Halston wanted an extravagant finale for his 1972 Coty Awards runway presentation at Lincoln Center. The designer enlisted the services of his friends Andy Warhol and the fashion illustrator Joe Eula to art-direct performances by the coterie of models and society ladies whom the media had collectively dubbed ''the Halstonettes.'' The bizarre spectacle included the boldface beauties Berry Berenson and Jennifer Lee, who sang to their own guitar accompaniment; the Warhol ''superstar'' Baby Jane Holzer, who tap-danced; and the socialite Lily Auchincloss, who claimed to possess no skills outside the kitchen and fried bacon on the catwalk. But the evening didn't end with pan-fried pyrotechnics. Halston wheeled out an enormous cake, out of which popped the biggest Halston model of them all, Pat Ast.

title: Family Faults Investigation Into Killing At an Estate
description: Relatives of a limousine driver killed 10 days ago at the estate of the former New Jersey Nets star Jayson Williams complained yesterday that investigators had not been forthcoming at times about developments in the case, which appeared to be reaching a critical stage.

title: Three-Decade-Old Echoes, Awakened by Enron
description: SOMETIMES it's hard to care about Enron.

title: In Argentine Crisis, Military Stays in Step
description: After more than a month in office, President Eduardo Duhalde finally got around to meeting with the chiefs of the armed forces here recently. The session lasted little more than an hour, and though it took place at midday, it did not include lunch.

title: FOLLOWING UP
description: Tell-All Book on Trump Won't Be Telling at All

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LLOYD, JAMES W.
description: LLOYD-James W. Age 61 of Darien, CT, on February 12, 2002 after a long illness. Born in Syracuse, NY, he graduated from Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Columbia Law School, and served as a Lieutenant in the U.S. Navy. He was Senior Counsel at the law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell, where he was a partner for 26 years. He was a Director of The Charles A. and Anne Morrow Lindbergh Foundation. His loving wife, Maureen B. Lloyd, survives him. A memorial service will be held on Thursday March 21 at 10:30am at Saint John's R.C. Church, 1986 Post Road, Darien, CT. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Whittingham Cancer Center at Norwalk Hospital, 24 Stevens St., Norwalk, CT. 06856.

title: Spring Theater; Can the Same Old Song and Dance Be New Again?

title: 'Gracefully Insane'
description: Everyone makes the same comment: It doesn't look like a mental hospital. The carefully landscaped grounds, dotted with four- and five-story Tudor mansions and red brick dormitories, could belong to a prosperous New England prep school or perhaps a small, well-endowed college tucked away in the Boston suburbs. There are no fences, no guards, no locked gates. Over time, of course, you see the signs. Iron grilles surround the staircases inside the few remaining locked wards. On some halls, the nurses' stations are enclosed in thick Plexiglas. The washroom mirrors are polished metal, not glass. But on first acquaintance, the only indication that you have entered one of America's oldest and most prestigious mental hospitals is a large sign jutting into Mill Street: McLean Hospital.

title: 'The Summons'
description: It came by mail, regular postage, the old-fashioned way since the Judge was almost eighty and distrusted modern devices. Forget e-mail and even faxes. He didn't use an answering machine and had never been fond of the telephone. He pecked out his letters with both index fingers, one feeble key at a time, hunched over his old Underwood manual on a rolltop desk under the portrait of Nathan Bedford Forrest. The Judge's grandfather had fought with Forrest at Shiloh and throughout the Deep South, and to him no figure in history was more revered. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JABLONSKI, RT. REV.
description: JABLONSKI-Rt. Rev. Monsignor Stanislaus P., a priest of the Archdiocese of New York for over 61 years, died on February 21 in the Bronx, New York. He was 86. Monsignor Jablonski, the former Chaplain of the New York City Fire Department, was born in Manhattan on August 21, 1915, to Francis and Victoria Niestal Jablonski. He graduated from Cathedral Preparatory School and Saint Joseph's Seminary. He was ordained to the priesthood on June 7, 1941. His first Mass was celebrated at Saint Boniface Church, his home parish. Cardinal Spellman appointed Father Jablonski to the faculty of the new Cardinal Hayes High School in the Bronx in 1942. Over the course of more than twenty years that he spent there, he established a reputation that grew throughout the city of New York for his stern and demanding expectations of students as Dean of Discipline, earning him the nickname ''Jabbo'' from a generation of Hayesmen. Elevated to Monsignor by Pope John XXIII in 1961, he was installed as Fire Chaplain in 1962. His career with the Fire Department extended for twenty years. During that time, he distinguished himself in service to New York's bravest. While still Chaplain, he was appointed pastor of Saint Valentine's Church on East 221st Street in the Bronx. He continued to minister to the parish until its closing in 2001. Monsignor Jablonski was predeceased by his brother, Louis. In addition to his sister-in-law, Vincenza H. Jablonski, he is survived by three nieces, Loretta L. Donovan, Irene E. Jablonski and Helen A. McLaughlin, and a nephew, Louis J. Jablonski, Jr., and three grandnieces and five grandnephews. Viewing will be held at the Bennett Funeral Home, Scarsdale, NY, on Saturday, February 23, and Sunday, February 24, from 2:00-4:00 pm and 7:00-9:00 pm. A Mass of Resurrection will be celebrated at Saint Patrick's Cathedral on Monday, February 25, at 10:00 am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Scholarship Fund of Cardinal Hayes High School.

title: Patients' Rights, Jurisdiction and the Fox
description: Note from Ms. Greenhouse: The column received a considerable amount of mail about two recent court developments, the decision on arbitration, Equal Employment Opportunity Commission v. Waffle House, on Jan. 15, and the argument in the patients' rights case, Rush Prudential HMO v. Moran, on Jan. 16. A number of the questions boiled down to requests for legal advice on specific disputes, or for help with homework assignments or specific legal research tasks. Even if I were qualified to give legal advice (and as a non-lawyer, I obviously am not), that is not the purpose of the column, and neither is doing research for term papers. I look for questions of broad interest, the answers to which are most likely to offer some general illumination about the court and its work. Please keep sending me those as the term heats up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, ARNOLD P.
description: GOLDSTEIN-Arnold P. Dr. Arnold P. Goldstein, 68, an international expert on non-violent conflict resolution, died February 16, 2002, at his home in Syracuse, NY. He was born in Brooklyn, earned his Bachelor's and Master's degrees at City College of New York, and his Doctorate at Pennsylvania State University. He was a Professor of education and psychology for over 30 years at Syracuse University, retiring in 1997. He wrote over 50 professional books and was Director of the Center for Research on Aggression at Syracuse University, and a co-founder of the International Center for Aggression Replacement Training. He was the recipient of the 2002 Devereux Massachusetts Legacy of Caring Award and was nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize the same year. He is survived by his wife of ten years, Susan Striepling, a daughter, Dr. Susan Goldstein and her husband, Paul Hisada, a daughter, Cynthia Goldstein and her partner, Gloria Shaffer, a step-daughter, Sarah Semelsberger, a step-son, Steven Semelsberger, two grandchildren, Lauren and Rachel Hisada and a sister, Phyllis Cohen. His first wife, Lenore, died in 1987. Memorial contributions may be sent to the International Center for Aggression Replacement Training (ICART), 118 Julian Place, #

title: The Search for a Missing Child
description: Dawn Davis, recovery center representative, above: ''This is the Danielle Search Center. It's the command center for the volunteer search. We've found that a large number of volunteers can cover a greater amount of land and distribute more fliers than law enforcement on their own. Because of the situation, emotions run high. We always tell people, 'Check your egos at the door; this is about one thing and one thing only, and that's the missing child.' As the days go by, hope diminishes, but that's why we're here. There's an urgency to this. We're a nonprofit organization called the Laura Recovery Center Foundation for Missing Children. This is what we do. You have a lot of people who say to you, 'When do you know which child?' When you look back at, for instance, the young lady our center was founded for, Laura Kate Smither, a 12-year-old girl who went out jogging one morning and did not return, she became our community's child; everyone wanted to find her. I've come to love her. And I think that's what's happening with Danielle. I am very hopeful, or I wouldn't be doing this. We have seen children come home.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEIND, CARL R., MD.
description: FEIND-Carl R., MD. The Columbia University Department of Surgery mourns the loss of our esteemed colleague, Dr. Carl Feind, Professor Emeritus of Clinical Surgery and Special Lecturer in Surgery at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. Following his graduation from P&S in 1950, he completed his internship and residency in this Department, and remained here for his entire career. He earned international renown for his outstanding scholarly contributions to the fields of head and neck, thyroid, and parathyroid surgery. He was beloved by his patients and colleagues, and by scores of students who knew him as both mentor and friend. We extend sincere condolences to his wife, Helen, and to his children, Carl Feind, Jr., MD, LeeAnn Mondloch, Ellen Sanford, and Susan Kelly, and 10 grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Friday, March 1, 4:00 PM, Presbyterian Hospital Chapel, 622 W. 168 St. Donations may be made to the Feind Research Fund, Department of Surgery, Columbia University, 177 Fort Washington Ave., NY, NY 10032.
