For years I lived in my glass box in the Hollywood Hills, striving to live under Modernist oppression, I mean, enlightenment, but ultimately I couldn't bear it another moment. It would always occupy a special place in my heart, but my love affair with Modernism was over. I knew there had to be something else. After an Olympic-style field day full of athletic activities and contests at my children's elementary school, all the medals won individually (by the fastest runner, highest jumper, etc.) were collected and the children were given a chance to pick medals out of a bag so that none would feel bad about losing. title: When Safety Concerns Warrant a Response
description: I read the Feb. 17 opinion essay [''Greasing Nassau's Squeaky Wheels''] with some amusement, but also some concern. Legally, municipalities must respond to constituent concerns about unsafe sidewalks and roads for liability reasons. State and local law holds municipal governments harmless for dangerous roadway and sidewalk conditions over which they have ''no prior notice.'' A municipality is placed on notice of a dangerous condition if a constituent sends a written complaint to the county, town, city or village attorney describing that danger. Once the municipality has actual notice of a dangerous condition on one of its roadways or sidewalks, it has a duty to protect the public against the reasonable and foreseeable risk of harm.

Ergen, the chief executive of EchoStar Communications. Now that I've won the case, they've stopped snickering. Actually, no, they haven't. But it bothers me a lot less.

That's not patience, it's the passage of time while they try desperately to fathom the complexities before them on the 64 squares.

description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 25  While Prime Minister Ariel Sharon is warily checking to see whether a surprise Saudi peace initiative is more than a public-relations stunt, the report that the Saudi ruler is prepared to normalize relations with Israel if it makes peace with the Palestinians has brought a welcome glimmer of hope to a land that has almost despaired of peace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATTERSON, JAMES BERTCH
description: PATTERSON-James Bertch. Died on February 22 in Florida. He was an adoring husband to Audrey, a devoted father to Lucy and Dolly, and a loving grandfather to Trevor. His spirit and love for life was felt by all who knew him. A celebration of James' life will be held at St. John's Episcopal Church in Washington, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Joslin Diabetes Center, 780 Litchfield St., Torrington, CT 06790.

title: Electoral Repair Work
description: In the next few days, senators will have a chance to greatly strengthen America's democracy. Beyond approving the House version of the campaign finance reform bill and sending it directly to the White House, the Senate should hasten to pass the election reform legislation it is scheduled to consider. Overwhelming support for these twin moves would send a strong signal that cleansing democracy is not a partisan issue, and would counter public cynicism about Washington's priorities.

title: With Victory Against U.S., Canada Completes a Quest
description: The coin is called a loonie, a Canadian dollar worth 63 cents in American currency and incalculable wealth in Canadian pride. Before the Olympic hockey tournaments, Canadian workers who make the ice in the E Center placed it beneath the frozen playing surface. After Canada won the men's gold medal with a 5-2 victory over the United States this afternoon, Wayne Gretzky held the coin in his fingers and said he would send it to the Hockey Hall of Fame.

The dances may not have been cutting-edge or the highest of high art. But Mr. Rbsam has his own imaginative and coherent approach to choreography. He knows how to move his dancers around the stage excitingly. Even better, the evening brimmed with infectious fun, a commodity in very short supply these days in dance.

Bird III of Laguna Niguel, CA, Cynthia McManmon of Spring Lake, NJ & Edward C.H. Bird of LaVeigne, TN also survived by six great grandchildren. Julie was a well known civic worker in Union County, NJ; born in Princeton, lived in Elizabeth 90 years; graduate of the Vail Deane School and Vassar College; social reporter for many North Jersey newspapers and magazines; served as V.P. of Elizabeth (NJ) Dramatic Club, Past President of Junior League of Elizabeth, President of the Executive Committee of NJ Junior Leagues & Trustee of the Vail Deane School, Elizabeth; Named Alumna of the Year Vail Deane School in 1981; Ass. Vestry Member Trinity Church, Elizabeth, 4th Ward Republican Committee woman (Elizabeth, NJ); listed in Who's Who in American Women; member of the Bay Head Yacht Club, Baltusrol Golf Club and the former Elizabethtown Country Club & Cotillion. Funeral Services will be held on Thursday, February 28, at 1:30 PM at St. John's Episcopal Church, Broad St., Elizabeth. Private Interment will follow in Evergreen Cemetery, Hillside. A Memorial Service will also be held in early summer at All Saints Church, Bay Head. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to All Saints Church, 500 Lake Ave., Bay Head, NJ 08742. For information, contact August Schmidt Funeral Home, Elizabeth, NJ.

description: The leader of Afghanistan's interim government, Hamid Karzai, visited Tehran today and appealed to Iran and the United States to put aside their differences and help build his war-ravaged country.

description: FOR the last two years or so, so-called Weblogs have slowly built a following among Internet users who like to dash off a few random thoughts, post them on a Web site and read similar musings by others. In the last two months, the universe of Weblogs has grown more quickly, with mainstream media analysts praising ''blogs,'' as the sites are known, for bringing a new type of expression to the Internet, and perhaps undermining the hegemony of global media giants.

title: India's Leading Hindu Party Suffers Losses in State Elections
description: The Hindu nationalist party that leads India's governing coalition suffered a string of losses in state election results announced today. The costliest defeat was here in Uttar Pradesh, India's most populous state and a powerhouse in the country's politics.

They knew that Marcus Camby was injured, that Larry Johnson was retired, that Jeff Van Gundy was gone and that the Knicks now play bad basketball. But they did not know that the Knicks' drop into the abyss had so snatched the life from Madison Square Garden that not even the Lakers' wondrous glow could revive it.

title: Shortchanging Libraries
description: On an average day in the city, Spanish-speaking New Yorkers are huddled around computer terminals in East Harlem's Aguilar branch library, learning English with state-of-the-art software, teenagers from poor Brooklyn neighborhoods are discovering the Internet in the Central Library's ''technology loft,'' and parents throughout the city are attending workshops on family reading offered by the innovative Connecting Libraries and Schools Project.

As Mr. Barrowman remembers in his debut cabaret act, ''Reflections From Broadway,'' it was ''George M!,'' the 1968 musical biography of George M. Cohan, starring Joel Grey.

title: Sports of The Times; Security Is an Issue For Future Games
description: ''THE best thing about these Games?'' Valentino Castellani asked before the likes of Willie Nelson and Kiss helped put another American Olympics to bed. ''I would have to say that I was able to experience a high level of security, but all of us were very relaxed here. You know, you can be very secure but also very anxious.''

title: Until the Next Olympiad
description: It is hard to say whether the Salt Lake City version of the Winter Olympic Games ended an era or began one. These Games may have done both at once. The International Olympic Committee, under its new president, Dr. Jacques Rogge, displayed a responsiveness it hadn't shown in at least three decades. That attitude was tested almost at once, with the controversy surrounding the disputed judging of the pairs figure-skating competition. The decision in that controversy -- awarding gold medals to the Canadian skaters in addition to the ones given to the Russians -- brought about a groundless protest from the Russians when Sarah Hughes won the gold medal in women's figure skating with an inspired performance. That protest reminded everyone that the Olympics remain games among nations as well as among athletes.

title: Argentina, Citing Revenue Drop, Says Workers Face Reduced Pay
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 25  The Argentine government says it will be unable to fully pay the monthly salaries of more than half a million government employees that are due this week, citing a precipitous drop in tax revenues as a result of the worsening economic crisis here.

title: Notes from Tuscaloosa; Alabamians Go by an Outdated Book
description: It's the second year of the 21st century, and Alabama is still fighting its old battles with prejudice and poverty, still trying to combat the image that it's a state where the only well funded education program is college football. Alabamians are not unnaturally backward in their social attitudes: they want tolerance, good schooling and good jobs.

title: Drug concerns cloud Games' final day : On the line:integrity
description: SALT LAKE CITY:  After two weeks of questions and concern about the integrity of the judging at these Winter Olympics, the focus on the final day of the Games returned to more familiar territory: concern about the integrity of the athletes.

title: Two Artists With a 'Single Musical Mind'
description: Late in ''Remembering Mel,'' the pianist George Shearing's tribute to Mel Torm, two video screens light up, and Torm, the singer, who died in 1999, is shown introducing Mr. Shearing at a JVC Jazz Festival concert, describing him as a musician with whom he shares ''a single musical mind.'' Sure enough, as the two perform an ebullient version of ''Pick Yourself Up'' that features some rapid-fire scat singing, which the pianist accompanies in unison, the two seem to be reading each other's minds. Midway in this video performance, Mr. Shearing, now 82, chimes in live.

title: NBC Hits Its Target

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREGORY, ANNE ELIZABETH
description: GREGORY-Anne Elizabeth. 65, of Manhattan and Southampton, died February 24 after a long battle with lung cancer. She had a distinguished career as a financial editor and investment manager in New York and was one of the first women to rise to vice president at Merrill Lynch. Born in Leamington, Ontario, on November 2, 1936, she was educated at St. Mary's School in Raleigh, NC, and Hollins University in Roanoke, VA, where she graduated in 1958. After joining Merrill Lynch that fall, she became a writer for its bi-weekly publication, Investor's Reader, and was named its executive editor in 1972. She went on to become the founding editor of The Merrill Lynch Market Letter, the firm's first subscriber-driven investment advisory service. She was named a vice president in 1974. After retiring in 1987, she opened her own money-management firm, Gregory Capital Management, which she ran until she became ill in the summer of 2000. An avid golfer, she was a member of Shinnecock Hills Golf Club and Yeamans Hall in Charleston, SC. She was also a member of The Meadow Club of Southampton and the Cosmopolitan Club in New York. The daughter of Herbert T. Gregory and the late Helen Elizabeth Gregory, she is survived by her father and his wife, Marion, of Leamington and by her brother, Herbert Jr. and his wife, Patti, of Oxford NC. An older brother, Francis, predeceased her. Funeral services will be on Wednesday, February 27, at 1 o'clock at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Oxford, with interment to follow at the family cemetery in nearby Stovall, where the Gregory family has engaged in farming since the early 19th Century. A memorial service will be held in Southampton this spring. The family requests that memorials be sent to a charity of one's choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOWNSEND, M. WILBUR
description: TOWNSEND-M. Wilbur. Retired chairman and CEO of Handy and Harman in New York City, died on February 7, 2002 in Ormond Beach, Florida at the age of 90 due to heart complications. Born in Oyster Bay, New York on January 17, 1912, Bill graduated from Choate in 1930 and from Wesleyan University in 1934 where he earned a Phi Beta Kappa key. During World War II, Mr. Townsend worked in Washington, D.C. at the War Manpower Commission. In 1946 he joined Handy and Harman and in 1964 became chairman, president and CEO. Under his leadership the company was listed on the New York Stock Exchange on May 1, 1967. Mr. Townsend was active as a member of the boards of Home Life Insurance Company, Lazare Kaplan, the Jewelers Security Alliance, the Jewelers Vigilance committee, the Jewelers Industry Council and the 24 Karat Club of NYC, president in 1972 and then chairman for 3 years. Married for 62 years to Barbara Hayden, they lived most of their lives in Scarsdale, N.Y. They were members of the Greenville Community Church where Bill was a Deacon and an Elder. He was a member of the Union League Club and the Westchester Country Club. In addition to his wife, Barbara, Bill was predeceased by his sister, Sally. He is survived by his two sons, Barrett Townsend of Greenwich, CT., and Philip Townsend of Eastchester, N.Y. Also surviving are 3 grandchildren & 4 great grandchildren.

Marshall, M.D. Dr. Marshall was a member of the Department for over 40 years and was respected and beloved by generations of pediatric residents and Weill Cornell medical students. Her many contributions to medicine include: Chief of Pediatrics at the Albert Schweitzer Hospital in Haiti, West Indies for 24 years; co-founder of the Program for Children and Adolescents with AIDS at New York-Presbyterian Hospital in 1985; and an integral part of the medical staff of the New York Children's Health Project. She was the epitome of the compassionate physician who devoted her life to the needy children in New York City and Haiti. We will all miss her. Maria I. New, Chairman Department of Pediatrics

title: LEVEL 3 COMMUNICATIONS AGREES TO ACQUIRE CORPSOFT
description: Level 3 Communications Inc., a telephone and data network operator, agreed to buy CorpSoft Inc., a business software seller, for $89 million to increase sales and avoid violating bank-loan terms. The shares rose 23 percent. The closely held CorpSoft had 2001 sales of $1.1 billion, Level 3 said. In addition to the $89 million, Level 3 will also assume $50 million in debt. Level 3 last month said it might violate terms of $1.13 billion in bank loans, which require the company to keep sales above a certain level, as early as next quarter's end. Buying CorpSoft will keep Level 3 sales in compliance with loan covenants until the second half of 2003, the company said. Level 3, which is based in Broomfield, Colo., also said it expected to meet or exceed first-quarter forecasts from last month. CorpSoft, which is based in Norwood, Mass., and uses the name Corporate Software, has about 800 employees.

A Deutsche Telekom spokesman, Ulrich Lissek, said the company received the final refusal.

ExpressJet Holdings, a Continental unit that postponed a planned initial offering after the Sept. 11 attacks, filed a new proposal to raise as much as $320 million.

title: Closing the Gender Gap Without Much Conviction
description: The flimsiness of the claim that the gender barrier has been broken in classical music is shown nowhere better than at a concert of pieces composed by women. Even now at the start of the 21st century, decades after the dawn of the contemporary feminist movement saw a rise in women's orchestras and gender-based musicological studies and long after the inclusion of a single piece by a female composer on a concert program has ceased to be remarkable, a whole concert of music by women, performed by women, still feels unusual. It remains an exception to the classical music norm, which is a concert of music written entirely by men.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Expands
description: Japan's trade surplus expanded in January, the first rise in 19 months, as imports fell by more than 9 percent. The surplus was 188 billion yen ($1.4 billion), reversing a deficit of 96 billion yen a year earlier. Exports also fell, but the decline, 1.8 percent, was the smallest in 10 months, reflecting improved demand for automobiles in response to the weakened value of the yen. The surplus with the United States rose 14.9 percent, with vehicle exports surging nearly 30 percent. Ken Belson (NYT)

The shift consolidates the Rogaine worldwide creative assignments at offices of BBDO; Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO in London handles Rogaine in Australia and Europe. Arnold McGrath continues to work with Pharmacia brands like Nasalcrom. Media buying for Rogaine continues at MediaCom Worldwide in New York, part of the Grey Global Group. At that, it can seem frivolous and coarse, a blunt instrument, alongside its chief source, Ryunosuke Akutagawa's brief and elegant story ''In a Grove.'' The author's subtle suggestion of the lustful bandit's mental state, for example, limned in parenthetical brush strokes (''an ironical smile,'' ''gloomy excitement''), gives way in the film to Toshiro Mifune's frequent bouts of manic laughter.

title: Priest Denies Abuse and Refuses to Resign
description: A priest suspended by Boston's Roman Catholic Archdiocese over an accusation that he sexually abused a child 31 years ago denied the charge today and refused to step down, calling Cardinal Bernard F. Law's new policy of removing accused priests ''unjust and inherently evil.''

title: Many in U.S. With H.I.V. Don't Know It Or Seek Care
description: About half of Americans infected with the AIDS virus either do not know they have it or do not receive the drugs that are improving the lives of other infected people, federal health officials said yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Accused Of 1995 Rape
description: The Brooklyn district attorney charged a parolee, Alex Virella, yesterday with what had been an unsolved rape from 1995. The district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, said the indictment was based on a match with Mr. Virella's DNA obtained before he was released on parole. Because of a five-year statute of limitations, prosecutors had filed charges against John Doe for the rape in October 2000, identifying the rapist with a DNA sample from the victim.

title: Known for His Charity And Barroom Brawls
description: Jayson Williams has largely been silent on the fatal shooting at his New Jersey estate, but in the past he happily talked about himself -- and his long history of scrapes with the law, tempered with big-hearted help offered to family, friends and charities.

title: Conserving Water
description: To the Editor:

title: Buoyed by Saudi Peace Proposal, Israelis and Arabs Resume Talks
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 26  American-brokered security talks resumed between Israeli and Palestinian officials in Tel Aviv today, and Prime Minister Ariel Sharon indicated a willingness to talk with Saudi Arabian officials about their surprise peace initiative.

title: Saudi's Idea Stirs Hope in Israel and Abroad
description: While Prime Minister Ariel Sharon is warily checking out a surprise Saudi peace plan, word that the Saudi crown prince may be prepared to normalize relations if Israel makes peace with the Palestinians has brought a welcome glimmer of hope to a land that has almost despaired of peace.

title: College Tuition: Sky's the Limit
description: To the Editor:

title: Optimistic Reports by G.M. and Lowe's Push Shares Up
description: Stocks rallied yesterday after General Motors and Lowe's said business was picking up and a report showed that existing homes sold at a record pace in January.

title: NATO Offers Russia New Relationship, but Without Any Veto
description: After months of internal discussion and dispute, NATO has offered Russia a new form of relationship that will see a Russian ambassador sitting between Portugal and Spain at meetings to discuss and decide significant issues of mutual concern, NATO officials and diplomats said today.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Strike Hits Trains And Power
description: The police searched for 37 union leaders after thousands of workers struck to stop the privatizing of the national railroad, electric and gas companies. Train and subway service were severely curtailed, and electric power was reduced in parts of Seoul and other cities. President Kim Dae Jung said the strike was illegal but union leaders threatened to expand it to other companies. The strike by 2,600 workers at the gas company was suspended after government negotiators promised to consider their demands. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: When Getting Higher Is About Heaven, Not Drugs
description: ''I'm just a freedom fighter, no remorse/Raging in a holy war.'' Those words, howled to the sold-out Continental Airlines Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., on Saturday night, weren't some Taliban battle chant. They came from ''Freedom Fighter'' by Creed, a multimillion-selling band from Florida that sets grand moral struggles to grunge power chords.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORTOF, MURRAY. PH.D.
description: ORTOF-Murray. Ph.D. Social worker, Director of Camp HurleyJuvenile, Assistant Commissioner for Education and Training, New York City Department of Social Services, faculty member at Columbia University, Executive Director University Settlement, vice president of Consumer Affairs H.I.P. A life dedicated to human service. For information, call: 631757-7706 or elkart1@aol.com.

title: Transcript of Senate Commerce Committee Hearing on Enron
description: The following is a transcript of a hearing of the Senate Commerce, Science and Transportation Committee focused on the collapse of the Enron Corporation and was recorded by The Federal News Service.

title: Home of the Heisman Pursues Two Plans to Rescue the Club
description: The Downtown Athletic Club, the home of the Heisman Trophy, is still seeking money to save itself from shutting down but is also looking to merge with another club.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: 2 Lawyers Named In Enron 401(k) Case
description: A federal judge here said today that she would name two Seattle lawyers as lead counsel for former Enron employees seeking restitution for retirement savings lost in the company's collapse.

title: The shine of success, dulled by misbehavior
description: SALT LAKE CITY  The hosts of the party were, despite a faux pas in the planning phase, close to impeccable. Only the guests occasionally misbehaved, including the two cross-country skiers who were stripped of their gold medals on the last day for failing drug tests.

title: Sports of The Times; Other Games Headed to Town
description: THE Olympic flame is out. Buses are streaming to the airport. Blue tarpaulin and chain-link fences are coming down. Some successful athletes are looking for agents. A few disgraced athletes are handing back their medals after failing drug tests. And the locals are describing an emotional hangover because the party has ended. The Winter Games are over -- but other athletes are coming to compete for their own medals, and to make a worldwide glow that will remind us of the Olympic flame. The Paralympic Games are for all of us.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOOTA, ANNABEL
description: KOOTA-Annabel. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Jack Koota. Adored by all. With love, Harold, Marjorie, Joan, Toby and Irving, and my children, grandchildren and great grandchildren. Harold Franks

title: Helping Children Break Out of Their Silence
description: ''The Silent Child,'' by Prof. Laurent Danon-Boileau, Oxford University Press, $25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIELY, MICHAEL J.
description: KIELY-Michael J. Of Bronxville on February 24, 2002. Brother of Elizabeth Peterson. Surviving are numerous nieces and nephews, grandnieces and nephews and great-grandnieces and nephews. Practicing attorney for over 70 years and formerly a senior partner at Wormser, Kiely, Galef and Jacobs. Calling hours at The Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 24 and 6-8 PM Tuesday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Wednesday February 27 at 10 AM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to The St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, New York 10708.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FROM, PHILIP
description: FROM-Philip. Died February 21. Born January 14, 1914. Survived by beloved wife of 58 years, Hilda (nee Glickstein), children, Susan (Javier), Isaac (Jessica), grandchildren, Jacqueline, Justin and Katie. Family sits shiva through Wednesday evening at the home of Susan and Javier DeFrutos. Funeral services private.

title: Working Through the Pain to Honor a Brother's Life
description: EACH day of her grim new career as the unpaid executive director of the Cantor Fitzgerald Relief Fund, Edie Lutnick, formerly a labor lawyer with Lutnick & Swomley at a World Trade Center office that no longer exists, shows up for work wearing a sweater that belonged to her brother Gary, who died on Sept. 11.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TREXLER, PASTOR CHARLES D., JR.
description: TREXLER-Pastor Charles D., Jr. 89. Passed away peacefully on February 20, after a brief illness. Beloved father to adopted son Wanchai Panmunin and loving uncle to Roderick E. Kerr, Jr. He was a leader in the liturgical renewal of the Lutheran Church in the United States and founding Pastor of Good Shepherd Church, Roosevelt, NY, where he served for 40 years. Prior to entering the ministry, he was an accomplished stage actor and Bronze Star winner for duties performed as a staff officer in WWII. A Liturgy of the Resurrection will be celebrated on Saturday, March 2, at Good Shepherd Lutheran Church, Roosevelt, NY at 11 AM. Memorial offerings may be sent to the church.

title: Seeking New Ways to Fight a Persistent Foe: Lice
description: In the Sacramento City Unified School District in California, Inger Lindholm is affectionately known as the Lice Queen.

title: Bench Presses for Older People's Brains
description: Teaching people memorization strategies that can encourage the brain to work more effectively may help reduce the memory loss that often accompanies aging, researchers say.

title: For Enron Executive, Big Profit on a Bad Deal
description: The investment looked like a sure winner.

title: World Business Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Interest Rate Increase
description: The Bank of Israel raised its monthly benchmark interest rate for the first time in more than three years in a bid to stem inflation, which has been accelerated by a two-month slide in the shekel. The central bank raised its March interest rate to 4.4 percent from a record low of 3.8 percent. The increase takes effect on Thursday. The bank last raised rates in November 1998. The decision will increase borrowing costs during Israel's worst economic slump in 50 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPOPORT, FLORENCE, NEE ROSENBERG
description: RAPOPORT - Florence, nee Rosenberg. Of West Hartford, CT, formerly of Great Neck, on February 23, at age 81. She leaves a loving husband, Carl Rapoport; two sons, Mark & Miles Rapoport; two daughters - in - law, Jane Hughes & Sam (Sandra) Luciano; and four grandchildren, Robert, Alison, Jeff, and Ross. Florence had an outstanding and varied career, as an English teacher at Great Neck North Senior High School; as a feminist leader and founder of WomanSpace in Great Neck; and as the host for seventeen years of Focus on Women, a Cox/Cablevision television show. The program's tapes are in the Women's History Collection at the Schlesinger Library at Harvard University. She will be missed by friends and family, and by all the students, women, and viewers whose lives she enriched. Funeral will take place at Weinstein's Mortuary in Hartford on February 26 at 1:00 P.M. Graveside service will take place at 1:00 PM, February 27, at United Hebrew Cemetery in Staten Island.

title: Home Resales Increased by 16% in January
description: Sales of previously owned houses rose more than expected in January, to a record pace, an industry group said today, indicating that housing was likely to contribute to an economic rebound.

title: The Reporter's Job, And the Soldier's
description: To the Editor:

title: ENRON EXECUTIVE SAID TO BE AIDING IN FEDERAL INQUIRY
description: A senior official from Enron's finance division, himself a subject of the criminal inquiry into the company's collapse, has begun cooperating with federal officials handling the case, people who have been briefed on the situation said yesterday.

title: F.B.I. Has a 'Short List' of Names In Its Anthrax Case, the U.S. Says
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has identified a ''short list'' of 18 to 20 people who had the means, opportunity and possible motive to have sent the anthrax-laden letters last fall, law enforcement officials said.

title: MetroStars' Howard Is Waiting His Turn
description: TIM HOWARD is a Jersey guy who does not mind waiting in line or, in the vernacular of the New York metropolitan area, on line.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: Hearing On Spousal Abuse
description: The City Council has scheduled a public hearing on domestic violence in immigrant communities. Committee Room, City Hall, Manhattan, 1 p.m. Information: (718) 345-3110.

title: A Spiraling Trail Back to Africa; DNA Is Breakthrough in Writer's Search
description: That she could trace her family history back to the 1700's in Jamaica using birth certificates and land deeds is remarkable in itself, given the poor records from the days of slavery that usually stall genealogists somewhere in the antebellum South.

title: Ordez Embraces New Role as a Hitter
description: Rey Ordez always tracks the Mets' off-season transactions because his name is often mentioned in trade discussions. This winter, General Manager Steve Phillips tried to fortify a slumbering offense, adding 19 players to the 40-man roster, but Ordez remained a Met.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SIRIUS SATELLITE RADIO, New York, said Sid Richardson Bass, a Texas billionaire, sold his remaining 3.4 million shares of Sirius, a provider of 100 channels of subscription radio, from June to Dec. 31, 2001.

title: A Daughter Of a Jester With Notes That Soar
description: In Verdi's ''Rigoletto'' the title character, a hunchback jester in the court of the licentious Duke of Mantua, dominates almost every scene. Yet the role of Gilda, the winsome daughter Rigoletto keeps secreted at his house, is so beautifully conceived for a coloratura soprano that a good Gilda can steal the show. That's what Ruth Ann Swenson did on Friday night in the Metropolitan Opera's revival of Otto Schenk's grimly powerful 1989 production.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: 2 Companies Announce Services Deal
description: I.B.M. announced yesterday a seven-year agreement to manage the computing systems of American Express. The deal is valued at more than $4 billion. Under its terms, American Express will pay I.B.M. for only the amount of computing services that it uses. This method, also known as the utility model, is an emerging trend in computer services, analysts say, and the American Express deal is the largest to date. ''We're on the journey to being a utility,'' said Ginni Rometty, a general manager for I.B.M. Global Services. As part of the pact, roughly 2,000 technology workers at American Express will be transferred to I.B.M. Steve Lohr (NYT)

title: Gordon Matthews Dead at 65; Invented Corporate Voice Mail
description: Gordon Matthews, who in the 1970's invented voice mail, which is now used by about 80 percent of large American corporations, died on Saturday in a hospital in Dallas. He was 65 and lived in Austin, Tex.

title: Image Is in the Eye of the Bank Account
description: Canadian researchers say that when they surveyed women about their body images, they found that women who lived in wealthier areas were more likely to be dissatisfied.

title: Screen Actors Guild Agrees to New Rules for Talent Agencies
description: The Screen Actors Guild and the associations representing talent agents have reached a tentative agreement on a pact that allows talent agencies to be owned in part by other companies and permits them to become more economically involved in production companies.

title: College Tuition: Sky's the Limit
description: To the Editor:

title: One by One, A Family Is Treated
description: For centuries, doctors have dreamed of curing families. We are all too aware of illnesses that pass from one generation to the next.

title: A Tender Hamstring Sidelines Giambi
description: In April, when a good team gets off to a bad start, the normal refrain is: ''It's early.'' And it usually is.

title: A Crowd-Pleasing Potpourri of Cabaret and Ballet
description: Works & Process at the Guggenheim, an increasingly popular series produced by Mary Sharp Cronson, often gives the public a taste of the current in the performing arts.

title: A Lincoln Center Tribute to Mingus, Based on the Trombone Instead of the Bass
description: A bass player was not the key figure in ''Scenes in the City,'' the program of Charles Mingus's music at Alice Tully Hall over the weekend. It would seem at first that the most direct route to Mingus is through his bass sound. But try to fill that order, and you're in for trouble.

title: Climate Plan Is Criticized As a Risky Bet
description: The White House statement on climate change read: ''President Bush announced today that the United States has agreed with other industrialized nations that stabilization of carbon dioxide emissions should be achieved as soon as possible. The United States also agreed that it is timely to investigate quantitative targets to limit or reduce carbon dioxide emissions.''

title: U.S. Faults 3 Nations on Anti-Drug Efforts
description: President Bush has determined that Afghanistan, Haiti and Myanmar ''failed demonstrably'' in the fight against drugs over the last year, officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIVERA, SYLVIA
description: RIVERA-Sylvia, Transgender activist, gay liberation pioneer. Services, February 26, at 7 PM, Metropolitan Community Church, 446 West 36th Street, afterwards, memorial procession led by horsedrawn carriage from Stonewall Inn, on Christopher Street to Hudson River, wreath-laying.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Kirch Names Advisory Panel
description: The Kirch Group, which is struggling to work out a deal with its bankers on its $5 billion in debt, said it had hired outside advisers to help it through a possible restructuring. The announcement came as Kirch executives outlined plans with the company's biggest creditors for an overhaul of a money-losing pay television subsidiary. But some of Germany's big banks are unwilling to trade in their existing loans for equity in the company and unwilling to extend new loans to keep the company afloat through a turnaround. Kirch's pay television unit, Premiere, is losing hundreds of millions of dollars a year and the company faces billions of dollars in obligations it cannot currently pay. But it also owns Germany's biggest commercial television networks, as well as stakes in the Formula One racing organization and the Axel Springer publishing company.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Tight Race For Party Leadership
description: In the nationwide vote held Sunday to choose a new leader for the Institutional Revolutionary Party, an unofficial ''quick count'' by the party showed Beatriz Parades, the party's leader in the lower house of Congress, neck and neck with Robert Madrazo, the former governor of Tabasco. Officials from the party, which governed Mexico from 1929 to 2000 but has been in disarray since losing the presidency, said the result might not be known until tomorrow. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Publisher Considers Unit Sale
description: Pearson, the publisher of The Financial Times and part owner of The Economist, said it appointed Lazard to advise it on its business publishing division, for which it has received several expressions of interest. Pearson, under the chief executive, Marjorie Scardino, has been selling noncore assets, like a stake in the European broadcaster RTL, to focus on education and financial publishing. That process has been accelerated by the steep decline in advertising revenue that has hurt Pearson's profits as well as those of other media companies. FT Business, the division up for sale, publishes personal and institutional finance magazines, including Investors Chronicle, The Banker and Money Management, and had about $43 million of revenue last year, analysts said. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Underground Life Forms

title: What Libraries Do
description: To the Editor:

title: Germans' Claim on Dark Matter Is Greeted With Skepticism
description: Cosmology, the science of the universe in the large, is coming to resemble the literary subgenre in which stories revolve around a shadowy character who never actually appears. Call it the Godot phase of cosmology, after the Beckett play. Or the T. J. Eckleburg phase, after the optometrist whose eyes mysteriously survey the world from a giant billboard in ''The Great Gatsby.''

title: Annan Plans Talks With Iraq on Inspections Plan
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan has agreed to meet the Iraqi foreign minister for talks next week, the first such meeting in more than a year. The talks with Foreign Minister Naji Sabri on March 7 will precede an Arab League ministers' meeting, Stephane Dujarric, a United Nations spokesman said today.

title: Drug Corruption Trial Begins For Former Police Commander
description: Nine months after a fast-rising police commander became one of the highest-ranking officials ever indicted in a drug corruption case, prosecutors argued in court yesterday that he had conspired with a drug dealer and a fellow officer to steal $60,000 from a drug supplier in the Bronx.

title: Some spots fell short, but other commercials during Olympics were worthy of the gold.
description: AS the sun slowly sets on the tantrums, Roots berets and disqualifications of the 19th Olympic Winter Games, we bid a fond farewell to the trillions of commercials that appeared on NBC, CNBC and MSNBC and collectively exclaim, ''Well, it could have been worse.''

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the ceramics artist Peter Voulkos on Thursday misstated the given name of the classmate with whom he established a pottery business early in his career. The classmate was Rudy Autio, not Randy.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: President's Foe Free To Campaign
description: The Supreme Court lifted an order that had prevented a leading opponent of President Leonid D. Kuchma, Yulia Tymoshenko, from leaving Kiev, where she faces corruption charges, to campaign for a seat in Parliament in the March 31 election. Ms. Tymoshenko is a close political associate of former Prime Minister Pavlo Lazarenko, who was arrested in the United States in 1999 on charges of laundering stolen Ukrainian money. She is accused of paying him an $80 million bribe and of hiding hundreds of millions of dollars in proceeds from an illegal natural gas deal. Ms. Tymoshenko says the charges are politically motivated. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  METZDORF, LYLE
description: METZDORF-Lyle. One of the most creative people in the advertising business perished in a fire aboard his sailboat. Survived by his wife Martha of Houston, TX, son Lance of Charleston, S.C., daughter Lisa, four grandchildren and two brothers Gary and Larry of Independence, MO. His friends in New York are devastated by this tragedy.

title: Angola Rebels Face Disarray Since Death Of Savimbi
description: Like a family that has lost its patriarch, the Angolan rebel group that has battled the government for nearly three decades is learning to live without Jonas Savimbi. If the earliest signs are any indication, it will not be easy.

title: Big East Bids Are Available for the Taking
description: In two weeks, the N.C.A.A. men's tournament will begin amid more confusion than certainty surrounding who has a shot at the national title. Once you get past Kansas, Maryland, and Duke, who most agree deserve the nation's No. 1, No. 2 and No. 3 rankings, arguments for contenders and pretenders are noisy, divisive and dependent on regional and institutional loyalties.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Waste-Water Cleanup
description: Thousands of gallons of waste water were released near a river in a suburb northwest of Seattle, but officials said the spill was mostly contained by cleanup crews and held back by an earthen berm. Early estimates put the spill at nearly 200,000 gallons, but King County officials said it might be as little as 30,000. The spill occurred when a pipeline carrying the waste from a landfill to a treatment plant ruptured on Saturday. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'LEARY, STEPHEN W.
description: O'LEARY-Stephen W. The Queens County Bar Association records with deep sorrow the passing on February 23, 2002 of its distinguished member and past president from 1988-1989. Viewing at Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset today and tomorrow 3-5 PM and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Thursday 10 AM, Saint Mary's Catholic Church, 1300 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset. Seymour W. James, Jr., President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITTRELL, JAMES FRANKLIN
description: LITTRELL-James Franklin, 74. Of Quogue, NY, formerly of Kansas City, MO, died February 19, 2002 after a long illness. Jim is survived by his devoted wife of 29 years, Mary Lou; loving sister Patty and her two children Cynthia and Preston; four loving children Cindy, Jeff, Vicki, and Jill; one grandson, four granddaughters, and one great-granddaughter. Jim will be sorely missed by all who knew him. The family requests that contributions be made in Jim's memory to Alzheimer's Association.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Auto Production Rises
description: Japan's largest automakers increased production and exports in January to meet demand in the United States. Toyota Motor, the market leader, increased worldwide production by 4.6 percent, while global output at Honda Motor was up by 7.4 percent. Mitsubishi Motors and Mazda Motor also had gains. Japanese carmakers have benefited from the zero interest financing campaigns introduced by their rivals in the United States. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article and the Sports of The Times column yesterday about Duke's 97-55 basketball victory over St. John's referred incorrectly in some copies to the ranking of the result among St. John's losses. It was the fourth worst loss in the university's history, not the worst.

title: BEST BUY SAYS PRESIDENT WILL SUCCEED CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: Best Buy Inc., the electronics chain, said yesterday that its vice chairman and president, Bradbury Anderson, 52, would take over as chief executive from the founder and chairman, Richard M. Schulze, on June 30. Allen Lenzmeier will replace Mr. Anderson as president and chief operating officer, the company said, and Michael Keskey will move into Mr. Lenzmeier's job as president of Best Buy Stores. Mr. Schulze, who started Best Buy in 1966, will remain active in the company, Best Buy said, and will be responsible for strategic business development.

title: Beijing Aide Suggests Impasse on Missiles Continues With U.S.
description: BEIJING, Feb. 26  Washington should take the next step to resolve the dispute over Chinese exports of missile technology, a senior Chinese foreign policy official said today, in remarks that suggested a continuing impasse over one of the most sensitive issues in Chinese-American relations.

title: Front Row
description: Whatever became of Pierre Cardin? Had you posed that question to a group of Americans with more than a passing interest in fashion just a few weeks ago, not many could have provided a knowing answer. Some, in fact, would have hesitantly inquired, ''Is he still among us?''

title: Jacobs's Indoor Career Approaching Conclusion
description: At 38, REGINA JACOBS is still running fast. Last Saturday, four weeks after she ran the fastest indoor two-mile race by a woman (9 minutes 23.38 seconds), she ran in a special open race during a high school meet at the Armory Track and Field Center in Manhattan and won with the fastest women's indoor time for three miles (14:44.11).

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BAUMAN, LIONEL R.
description: BAUMAN-Lionel R. Beloved partner, friend and colleague. Died February 27, 1987. Sorely missed by all. Eugene M. Grant & Co., LLC

title: After a Bottle for $2,000, The Real Spending Began
description: Mink isn't good enough for some people. They have to have ermine. For such types, BMW's are too common. They crave Lamborghinis. It's not about beauty or excellence, it's about rarity.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: Top Official's Death Seen As Suicide
description: The head of the national security council, a close aide to President Eduard A. Shevardnadze, was said to have committed suicide in his office after opposition forces in Parliament accused him of involvement in a series of unsolved assassinations and a former defense minister called him a homosexual. Nugzar Sadjaya, 60, was found shot in the head and died on a hospital operating table. Mr. Shevardnadze, who worked with Mr. Sadjaya for 30 years, called him a victim of ''moral terror.'' Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Political Memo; From Quiet Nomination to Noisy Test for Future Battles
description: When President Bush nominated Charles W. Pickering Sr. to a seat on the federal appeals court, no one expected that it would become the first full-fledged confirmation fight of this administration and the dress rehearsal for battles over anticipated Supreme Court nominations.

title: CREDITORS INVESTIGATE GLOBAL CROSSING SALE
description: A group of creditors of Global Crossing, the telecommunications company that has filed for bankruptcy protection, said yesterday that it was investigating the company's $3 billion sale of a unit to Citizens Communications last year. Nationwide Mutual Insurance, the U. S. Trust unit of Charles Schwab and the Knights of Columbus --a subcommittee of the creditors overseeing Global Crossing's bankruptcy -- are ''investigating the issues arising from the sale,'' according to papers filed in United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan. Citizens Communications agreed in July 2000 to buy about a million local phone lines from Global Crossing for about $3 billion.

title: Wines of the Week
description: If wine can speak to your soul then pinot noir whispers, shouts and seduces all at the same time.

description: A search committee of Lincoln Center executives has recommended Reynold Levy, president of the International Rescue Committee, as the next president of Lincoln Center.

description: To the Editor:

title: Devils And Evil Axes
description: ''Evil'' shadowed President Bush during his swing through Asia last week.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Sunday about the legacy of the Salt Lake City Olympics misstated the accomplishment of Vonetta Flowers of the United States in the women's bobsled competition. She was the first African-American to win a gold medal in the Winter Olympics, not the first to win any medal in them.

title: Rumsfeld Formally Disbands Office of Strategic Influence
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 - Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld disbanded the Pentagon's Office of Strategic Influence today, ending a short-lived plan to provide news items, possibly even false ones, to foreign journalists to influence public sentiment abroad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, HERB
description: RUBIN-Herb, 68. Of New York and Austin, TX. Beloved brother of Faith Rosalie and Dina. He was much loved and will be greatly missed.

title: Parisian Artworks, Not Always by Parisians
description: ''Paris: Capital of the Arts 1900-1968,'' at the Royal Academy of Art here, may sound like an amiable replay of favorites with which longtime visitors to Paris would feel at home. But this exhibition cuts an altogether wider swath. Major French names -- Braque, Matisse, Bonnard -- are there.

title: 'Hackers' Find No Bars to Indian Trust Files
description: Instructed by a federal district judge to determine whether the computer network at the Bureau of Indian Affairs was secure from malicious intruders, Alan Balaran decided to infiltrate it.

title: The American Way of Eating
description: To the Editor:

title: Stuffing the Pillowcase With Soft Money
description: Congressional leaders, including some who denounce unlimited contributions from big corporations to political parties, have been raising this so-called soft money as if it were going out of style, according to a report by the liberal interest group Public Citizen.

title: Longtime Yeshiva Coach Gains a Memory
description: The long, typically perplexing season ended last Thursday for Jonny Halpert, the coach of Yeshiva University, when his team lost in the semifinals of the Skyline Conference tournament. It was, however, a season to remember, though not necessarily one to make a Hollywood film about. One game stands out over the rest. ''If you sent Hollywood the script, they'd send it back,'' Halpert said. ''Too unbelievable.''

title: College Tuition: Sky's the Limit
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 U.S. Banks Vow to Assist Allfirst Case
description: Two large banks that have special trading agreements with the currency trader who lost $691 billion said yesterday that they were cooperating with the investigation. In addition, government investigators have subpoenaed records connected to their transactions and communications with the trader.

title: Signs of Great Floods, on Mars
description: Giant channels carved out of the plains of Mars tell of huge floods gushing from volcanic fissures, like Old Faithful gone haywire.

title: Why Blacks Support Vouchers
description: Urban black America favors school vouchers, but its leaders don't. Vouchers transfer authority over the use of a portion of government education funds from bureaucrats to parents, who then may use their grants to send their children to the schools, secular or religious, they believe will best educate their kids.

title: 21 Suspended After Hofstra Finds Grades Were Altered
description: Hofstra University has fired an employee for tampering with its computerized records to change the grades of at least 37 students, administration officials here said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELINKIE, MILTON H.
description: BELINKIE-Milton H. Connecticut's Superior Court Judge Milton H. Belinkie, 89, died January 29. He worked until the end and was predeceased by his wife Helen Jiler Belinkie, award-winning cookbook author. A graduate of Yale and Columbia Law schools, he did secret duty in WWII and gained notoriety for capturing Tokyo Rose, but refused to testify after the war. Milton loved poetry, Shakespeare, music, and played the violin in a symphony. He won trophies in tennis, squash, handball and played semi-pro baseball with a batting average of .422. He is survived by his daughter, actress, Carrie Jiler Belinkie, one brother and four sisters. He was loved by many and will be missed by all.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Bill To Ban Consent Searches
description: A bill has been introduced in the Assembly to ban what are known as consent searches, in which police officers ask a driver if they can search a car. Critics say such searches are prompted by racial profiling. More than 20 bills related to racial profiling foundered when Republicans held the majority in the Assembly. Last year, Democrats won control of the Assembly, and the new bill's sponsor, Assemblyman John McKeon of West Orange, a Democrat, said the Assembly would pass his bill, which was introduced on Friday. But Gov. James E. McGreevey, a Democrat, has said he is opposed to such a ban because it might hamper the police. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Oh, What Woes A Squirrel Can Start
description: The prominent symbols in ''Circumference of a Squirrel'' are a bagel, a doughnut, a Lifesaver, wreaths and an inner tube. What they share with this one-man play is emptiness at the core.

title: Editorial Observer; Preserving the West's Wild Horses
description: I remember watching, a few summers ago, a band of wild horses in the mountains above Lovell, Wyo. It was the first time I'd ever seen wild horses on open range. They came and went, grazing and bickering, always keeping a possible horizon in mind, just in case they wanted to gallop over it and out of human sight. I've looked at a lot of horses in my life, but I realized, as I stood on the slopes of Pryor Mountain, that this was the first time I'd ever seen them moving in the natural family groupings -- a stallion and a band of mares and foals -- that they would form in the wild. Domestication means breaking those bonds and thinking of horses as individuals.

title: ALADDIN GAMING ASKS COURT TO AUCTION ITS ASSETS
description: Aladdin Gaming, operator of an Arabian-theme Las Vegas resort, asked a federal bankruptcy judge for permission to liquidate the company's assets through a court-supervised auction. Aladdin, which is closely held, told Judge Robert C. Jones of United States Bankruptcy Court in papers filed last week that it ''intends to liquidate in one transaction all property and rights comprising the casino-hotel.'' Aladdin sought bankruptcy protection from creditors on Sept. 28, just 13 months after the $1 billion resort opened. Analysts blamed the resort's poorly designed entrance and a lack of a loyal customer base for the venture's problems.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Mpower Will File For Bankruptcy
description: The Mpower Holding Corporation said yesterday that an informal committee representing about two-thirds of bondholders had agreed to a recapitalization plan that included a Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing by the company, which is involved in telecommunications. The announcement confirmed a report in The Wall Street Journal. The company said the plan would eliminate $538.4 million in debt and all of its preferred stock. Mpower, a competitive local exchange carrier based in Rochester that provides telephone and Internet services to small and midsize businesses, came under attack last fall from a group of bondholders intent on persuading it not to deplete its cash reserves on expansion.

description: The police raided the Tehran office of the country's leading student movement and arrested 40 members. The movement, called the Office for Consolidation of Unity, has been an influential pro-reform group with branches around the country. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: In Forest Debris, the Odor of Dead Monarchs
description: Walking up the steep path through what remains of the montane forest at the Rosario sanctuary, it is hard at first to notice the monarch butterflies everywhere. Then the wind shifts and the smell of rotting insect corpses hits the steady stream of tourists going by. What had seemed at first to be fallen leaves and forest debris reveals itself as a lumpy carpet of millions of butterflies that perished in the largest known die-off ever of these insects.

title: No Nightclub, Just Saxophones, Artfully Competing
description: Aaron Fletcher, a 22-year-old saxophonist from Thibodaux, La., hears jazz in his head as splendiferous popular music, the kind that makes an audience cheer along. Loren Stillman, a 21-year-old from Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., hears it as a rare, exotic form whose notes inflate and wilt and trill, almost a kind of meditation on texture. Eli Digibri, 23 and born in Bat Yam, Israel, hears it as athletic and fractured, even to the point of having key notes expunged from a well-known melody.

description: A draft report by a consultant to Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy blames delays in building as many as two dozen badly needed New York City public schools on endemic waste and overcharging by the School Construction Authority.

description: A shooting in a dormitory at the State University of New York at Farmingdale yesterday left one former student wounded and a current student under arrest, the Suffolk County police said last night.

description: Maurice R. Greenberg, the chief executive of the American International Group and a strong advocate of government help in providing general terrorism coverage, urged yesterday that Washington get out of the business of providing terrorism coverage for United States airlines for damage on the ground.

title: DRILLING CONTRACTOR TO SPIN OFF OIL AND GAS BUSINESS
description: Helmerich & Payne, a United States-based drilling contractor, will spin off a subsidiary that produces oil and natural gas. The new company will acquire the Key Production Company of Denver in a $220 million transaction. Helmerich shareholders will receive 0.53 share of a new company called the Cimarex Energy Company for each Helmerich share, while Key investors will get one Cimarex share for each Key share, the companies said. Cimarex will be owned 65 percent by Helmerich shareholders and 35 percent by Key investors. Helmerich, which is based in Tulsa, Okla., sought the spinoff to separate exploration and production from its drilling business.

title: Tropical Cruises
description: Couples can save $300 on two cruises sold by Far & Wide and operated by High Country Passage. A 10-day trip to Costa Rica and the Panama Canal March 26 to April 4 features six nights on Le Ponant, a three-masted yacht, with stops at Costa Rica's national parks and the San Blas Islands and a canal transit; rates start at $5,340 a person, with discount. A nine-day trip from Trinidad to the Orinoco Delta in Venezuela April 7 to 15 includes seven nights on Le Levant, with excursions on Zodiacs to see macaws, toucans and spider monkeys; rates start at $3,145. Land accommodations, excursions and taxes are included; air fare and some meals are extra; www.farandwide.com .

title: 5 Bankers Fired From Barclays Over $62,700 Spent at Meal
description: Perhaps it was the bottle of 1947 Chteau Ptrus for 12,300 ($17,500). Or maybe it was the 1945 vintage from the same vineyard for 11,600 ($16,500). During dinner at a fashionable restaurant here, six investment bankers lapped up 44,000 ($62,700) in fine wines, and now they are suffering from a huge hangover.

title: Robert Strausz-Hup, Envoy And Cold-War Stalwart, 98

description: General Motors, citing a stronger-than-expected outlook for domestic auto sales, raised its estimate for first-quarter earnings today, increased production and set an aggressive profit goal for the middle of the decade.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 1993 Terror Attack Representative
description: The agency overseeing the rebuilding of the World Trade Center site agreed yesterday to add a representative from the families of victims of the 1993 terror attack on the twin towers. The agency, the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, said it would add Michael Macko, whose father, William J. Macko, a Port Authority mechanical supervisor, died nine years ago today, to one of its advisory committees. Senator Charles E. Schumer said he would ask President Bush to extend some benefits that are available to families of last year's victims to families of the victims of the 1993 attack. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

title: U.S. Is in Talks on Handing Over Of Suspect in Reporter's Killing
description: American and Pakistani officials have begun detailed talks on arrangements that could lead to Pakistan's turning over Ahmed Omar Sheikh, the chief suspect in the kidnapping and murder of Daniel Pearl, an American journalist, to the United States, officials from both countries said tonight.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Search For Suspected North Korean Ship
description: Using an underwater ultrasonic probe, Japan has started searching for a North Korean ship, suspected of being North Korean, that its Coast Guard sank in an exchange of gunfire last December in the East China Sea. The ship sank in about 275 feet of water in Chinese economic waters and Japan informed China in advance of the search. If the ship is found, Japan plans to use a remote-controlled television camera to try to determine its origin, mission and equipment. James Brooke (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBRIGHT, CHARLES W. CSP.
description: ALBRIGHT-Charles W. CSP. On February 21, 2002 at age 81. Born in Craig, Colorado he grew up in Salt Lake City, Utah. His assignments included years in Newman work at Berkeley, California, Detroit, New Orleans, Morgantown, West Virginia, Santa Barbara and Columbus, Ohio. Fr. Charlie also served at Good Shepherd Parish in New York City, five years at the American Parish in Rome, Italy, Santa Susanna and Old St. Mary's in San Francisco. From 1955 until 1964 he was the executive secretary for the National Federation of Newman Chaplains and received The Benemerenti Award for distinguished service to the Church from Pope John Paul XXIII. Viewing will be at Old St. Mary's Church, San Francisco at 6:00 PM followed by a Mass of Christian Burial at 7:30 PM on Tuesday, February 26, 2002. Burial will follow at Holy Cross Cemetery in San Francisco on Wednesday, February 27.

title: State Restricts Data on Internet In Attempt to Thwart Terrorists
description: The Pataki administration has quietly ordered state agencies to restrict information available on the Internet and limit its release through New York's Freedom of Information Law to prevent terrorists from using the material, which includes maps of electrical grids and reservoirs as well as building floor plans.

title: Missing Girl Case Is to Be Treated as Murder
description: Concluding that Danielle van Dam, 7, ''is no longer living,'' the San Diego County district attorney announced today that he would file a murder charge against the man charged last week with kidnapping her.

title: Hearing Set to Help Resolve Which Brother Is Killer
description: A Brooklyn judge agreed yesterday to hear testimony from a man who says he committed a killing for which his brother was convicted 13 years ago, setting the stage for a courtroom resolution of a long-running family drama.

title: There's a Lot Of Elaine In This Star's New Sitcom
description: Ellie looks like Elaine, sounds like Elaine, and when she declares triumph over a tow-truck driver by yelling, ''So long, sucka!'' she might as well be Elaine. That twinlike resemblance between Julia Louis-Dreyfus's new character on ''Watching Ellie'' and her old Elaine on ''Seinfeld'' is exactly why her sitcom is funny and engaging. It comes as close to resurrecting the old show as you can without hauling Jerry Seinfeld himself back on television. While Michael Richards and Jason Alexander's disastrous series led to the specter of a ''Seinfeld curse'' on the show's co-stars, Ms. Louis-Dreyfus has figured out that the best way to beat the curse is not to fight it.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Chief Of Internet Group Proposes Changes
description: The president of the group responsible for the Internet's address system, the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, proposed an overhaul of the organization's structure during a board gathering last weekend. The proposal, drafted by M. Stuart Lynn and available for public comment at www.icann.org, primarily aims to increase the role of national governments in Icann's activities by permitting them to nominate 5 members to a 15-member board of trustees, which would replace the board of directors. In a conference call, Mr. Lynn acknowledged that the group, which has often been criticized as slow-moving, could not achieve its goals without becoming more agile. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: TITAN TO BUY SCIENCE AND ENGINEERING ASSOCIATES
description: The Titan Corporation, which makes irradiation equipment used by the Postal Service to kill anthrax, agreed to buy the closely held Science and Engineering Associates Inc. for about $72 million in stock to gain its security products and military customers. The transaction is expected to close in the second quarter and add about $45 million to $50 million to 2002 sales, based on expected full-year revenue of about $90 million to $95 million, Titan said. Science and Engineering, based in Albuquerque, has contracts to supply research services and laser, sensor and imaging equipment to the military services and government agencies. Titan is based in San Diego.

title: Congo Factions Gather for Peace Talks
description: The adversaries in Congo's nearly four-year war met today for the first time to begin talks aimed at bringing peace and political unity to that Central African nation.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Official Cleared In Fight with Teacher
description: Assault charges have been dropped against an assistant principal after a fistfight in which a teacher is said to have repeatedly punched the assistant principal in front of shocked high-school students. Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn district attorney, said he was surprised that Thomas Greene, left, the assistant principal of Fort Hamilton High School in Bay Ridge, had been charged, and said the police were investigating why Mr. Greene was arrested. Mr. Hynes said he would continue to press assault charges against the teacher, Marie Neto. Another assistant principal, Susan Russo, was accused of aiding Ms. Neto, a physical education teacher, and has agreed to perform community service. Yilu Zhao (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JEANETTE, STEVE
description: JEANETTE-Steve, 71. Of Englewood Cliffs and Silver Beach, N.J., died February 23, 2002. He had a long and successful career working on the floor of the American Stock Exchange, and was a stock specialist and Vice President at Spear, Leads & Kellogg. Born in Brooklyn, N.Y. on July 15, 1930, he proudly served his country in the military during the Korean War, and was a member of the Honor Guard in Berlin. Beloved husband to Constance. Loving father to Eric and his wife Kim. Eva Marie and her husband Jason, and Stephanie. Doting grandfather to Tyler, Aimee and Alexandra. Devoted brother to Terry and Mary. Steve's undying love for his family was always apparent and enveloped us all in warmth and comfort. His quick wit, easy manner, kindness and generosity made him a faithful friend to nearly everyone he met. The light that Steve brought to our lives will never be extinguished, and his presence will remain as a steady guide to those he loved. Respects to the family can be paid at PattiMikatarian Funeral Home in Fort Lee, N.J. on Wednesday, February 27, between 3-5PM and 7-9PM. The funeral service will be held on Thursday, February 28 at St. John the Theologian, Greek Orthodox Church in Tenafly, New Jersey with interment to follow at George Washington Memorial Park in nearby Paramus, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Dover/Brick First Aid Squad, P.O. Box 172, Normandy Beach, New Jersey 07839.

title: Bush Praises Saudi Proposal for Arab Relations With Israel
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  President Bush called Crown Prince Abdullah of Saudi Arabia today and publicly praised, for the first time, a Saudi proposal for Israel to return to its pre-1967 borders in return for full normalization of relations between Israel and all Arab countries.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: NEC and KPN Start Phone Venture
description: The NEC Corporation and KPN Mobile of the Netherlands said they would begin selling cellular phones with Internet access, called i-mode service, this spring in Germany, the Netherlands and Belgium. The companies did not disclose the financial terms of the agreement. NEC of Tokyo said it would produce handsets designed for the European market for KPN Mobile's Internet service. KPN Mobile will be the first company in Europe to introduce the i-mode technology, which permits users to send and receive e-mail, play video games and check bank accounts via cellphone.

title: Keep It Cute, Despite Bootlegging
description: John Mayer plays the kind of mild acoustic rock that turns genres into vague adjectives: every song is sort of bluesy, a little bit jazzy, somewhat funky. When he took the stage at Irving Plaza on Saturday night, a precollegiate crowd screamed praise and requests, and the screaming didn't stop until nearly two hours later, when he murmured some boilerplate about how grateful he was -- ''It feels incredible to be a vital artist and playing music and having people listen to it'' -- and strolled offstage, promising to be back soon.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Conviction In 1989 Death
description: After three hours of deliberation, a jury convicted a homeless man of second-degree murder in the 1989 death of David Burns, a computer engineer who was stabbed to death in the vestibule of his Upper West Side apartment building. The defendant, Frank Barnes, was arrested just over a year ago after the New York Police Department's cold- case squad took over the investigation.

title: City Council Opens Hearings On Schools
description: In the opening of City Council hearings to debate school governance, former Mayor Edward I. Koch, the former head of Chicago schools and a real estate executive portrayed mayoral control as the salvation of the New York City schools yesterday while two of the borough presidents argued for a continued role by their offices.

title: After 11 Days, Former Nets Star Is Charged in Death of Chauffeur
description: Jayson Williams, the former star rebounder for the New Jersey Nets, turned himself in today to the police, who charged him with manslaughter in the fatal shooting of a limousine driver at Mr. Williams's Hunterdon County estate nearly two weeks ago.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Greenwich: Blumenthal Won't Stop Beach Fees
description: Richard Blumenthal, the attorney general, left, said he would not challenge Greenwich's new beach fee of up to $408 for nonresidents. ''The case involves no state statutes, no state property and no state authorities,'' he said. Last July, the State Supreme Court ordered Greenwich to end its residents-only beach policy. Earlier this month, Greenwich's Board of Selectmen voted 2 to 1 for a $308 seasonal pass and a $100 parking permit, with no daily passes. Ernest Newton II, the deputy majority leader of the House of Representatives, called the fees racist and criticized Mr. Blumenthal for not challenging them.

title: Picks, Pans and Nit-Picking From NBC's Salt Lake Nights

title: Temporary Memorials at Ground Zero

A permanent structure as part of the redevelopment of ground zero is years of planning and debate away. In the meantime, the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation and several nonprofit arts groups are considering two interim memorials that deserve serious and swift consideration.
