description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Feb. 26  Adding to pressure on Pakistan, the American Ambassador here met today with President Pervez Musharraf and directly raised the issue of a possible handover to the United States of the Muslim militant who is the prime suspect in the murder of an American reporter.

title: Letters
description: The American Way of Eating

title: 18 City Tax Assessors Indicted In Decades-Long Bribe Scheme
description: Eighteen current and former New York City tax assessors were indicted yesterday in a scheme that lasted decades in which they took millions of dollars in bribes to cut property taxes for the owners of office towers, residential buildings and warehouses, federal prosecutors said.

title: Footlights
description: Homage to Steinbeck

title: Corrections
description: Acorrection in this space on Saturday misattributed errors in an article on Wednesday about a new deployment of the Nepalese Army to deal with raids by Maoist guerrillas trying to overthrow the constitutional monarchy. The errors originated in editing, not in the version transmitted by Reuters.

title: Cigarettes' Many Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: Hyundai Narrows List of Sites for U.S. Plant
description: The Hyundai Motor Company has narrowed the list of sites for its first American plant to Montgomery, Ala., and Glendale, Ky., eliminating Ohio and Mississippi from consideration, a spokesman said today.

title: Top General Defends Raids In Which 16 Afghans Died
description: The commander of the military operation in Afghanistan today defended two American-led raids north of Kandahar last month, praising the ''discipline'' and ''professionalism'' of United States troops who killed 16 Afghans who proved to be neither Al Qaeda nor Taliban fighters.

title: Georgia Will Not Execute Mentally Ill Killer
description: A schizophrenic killer whose execution was repeatedly delayed because of concerns about his age and mental health was granted clemency today by the state parole board, which commuted his sentence to life in prison.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Shatner Returns To Priceline
description: William Shatner, the star of the ''Star Trek'' television series and movies, will resume his role as a spokesman for Priceline.com, the company said yesterday. Priceline.com, the name-your-own price Internet service, said Mr. Shatner would appear in radio advertising with its ''supercomputer that toils day and night to find airline tickets, hotel rooms and other travel products at discounts.'' Earlier this year, Mr. Shatner renewed his contract to appear in Priceline.com radio and television advertisements. ''Given the futuristic side of William Shatner, the new campaign is a natural and lends itself to both radio and TV treatments,'' said Brett Keller, chief marketing officer for Priceline.com.

title: Risky Business
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: BUSH WELCOMES SAUDI'S PROPOSAL ON MIDEAST PEACE
description: President Bush thrust himself into the Mideast peace effort today, calling Crown Prince Abdullah of Saudi Arabia and publicly praising his proposal for Israel to withdraw completely from the West Bank and Gaza in return for full normalization of relations with all Arab countries.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GEORGIA-PACIFIC CORP., Atlanta, the producer of forest products, said it would sell a wallboard paper mill in Delair, N.J., to the closely held National Gypsum Co., Charlotte, N.C., a maker of building products, to pay debt. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALINO, RABBI JEROME
description: MALINO-Rabbi Jerome. On Monday, February 25. Gifted preacher & respected leader of the Reform movement. Served United Jewish Center in Danbury, CT. for 66 years. President of Central Conference of American Rabbis 1979-1981. Lecturer in Homiletics at Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion. Will be greatly missed by loving wife, Rhoda, children, Dr. Frances Malino and Rabbi Dr. Jonathan Malino, grandchildren, Daniel Hoffman, 1st Secretary American Embassy of Estonia and Dr. Elizabeth Hoffman, Rabbi Tamar Malino, Daniel and David Malino, greatgranddaughter, Olivia Rae Emerson and many devoted in-laws.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANGTON, MICHAEL J.
description: LANGTON-Michael J., 59. Of Bahrain, beloved husband of Irene ''Gay'' (Maluski) Langton, died Friday (February 22, 2002) in Bahrain. Born August 12, 1942, in Baltimore, MD, son of the late Harold ''Irish'' and Dorothea (Griffith) Langton. He had lived in Matawan, NJ and St. Augustine, FL., and was a resident of Bahrain for the past eight years. Mr. Langton received his Master's in Business Administration from Fordham University and at the time of his death was Director of Bahrain Institute of Banking and Finance (BIBF). He had previously been Director of American Institute of Banking in New York City, Executive Officer of New York State Bankers Assoc., Executive fficer of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Mr Langton was a member of the Salmaniya Rotary Club, Chairman of the Board of the American Mission Hospital, founder and chairman of AAB/AMH Island Classic Golf Tournament, member of Bahrain Bankers Society, Founder of the TradeQuest Program for high school students. Besides his wife he is survived by a son, 3 daughters, 4 brothers, 4 sisters, and 2 grandchildren. A mass of Christian Burial will be held Saturday (March 2) at 11:00 AM in St. Dunstan's Church, Manchester Road, Glastonbury. Burial will be at the convenience of the family. Friends may call at the Mulryan Funeral Home, 725 Hebron Avenue, Glastonbury, Thursday from 5-8 PM and Friday from 2-4 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers memorial donations may be made to the Fordham Football Recruiting Fund, c/o Michael Fazio, Development Office, Fordham University, 113 West 60th Street, New York, New York 10023-7471.

title: In a 'Chick Flick,' Moving State to State and Man to Man
description: Lucy wants love, and she goes coast to coast looking for it in ''Quake,'' a play by Melanie Marnich that somehow manages to be nuttily inventive and oddly familiar at the same time.

title: Greenspan Says Economy Is Emerging From Recession
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 — The country's economy seems to be emerging from recession, but the recovery may be a gradual one, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's chairman, said today.

title: Hard Questions For Nominee To Rights Post
description: Seven months after his nomination to head the Education Department's Office of Civil Rights, Gerald A. Reynolds got his moment today before the Senate committee that would have to approve his appointment.

title: Giambi's Ailing Leg Could Be a Blessing
description: Jason Giambi was talking to someone who had recently watched the Mets, and he immediately wanted to know how Mo Vaughn, a fellow New York first baseman, was doing. How does Mo look? How does Mo feel?

title: Giuliani to Give Money Quickly In Shift on Twin Towers Charity
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani agreed yesterday to distribute promptly the $100 million remaining in the city's Twin Towers Fund to the families of 430 uniformed and civilian rescuers killed on Sept. 11. Mr. Giuliani's pledge came after weeks of criticism about his plans for the Twin Towers money, including threats of a lawsuit from police widows.

title: The World According to Enron's Ex-Chief
description: Jeffrey K. Skilling proclaimed his innocence again yesterday, but in the process he joined in the chorus of people who believe that something was rotten at Enron, the company he formerly ran.

title: Czech Decrees, Dating to 40's, Divide Europe
description: One of the unhealed sores from World War II is threatening the unity of four countries that have hoped to find their future, soon and as a bloc, in the European Union.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Trade Center Site Group Criticized
description: City Council members have scolded representatives of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, the agency overseeing rebuilding of the World Trade Center site, for not having a more racially and ethnically diverse board and staff. Council members also said on Monday that they wanted a greater voice in planning the redevelopment. James Sanders Jr., chairman of the Council's Committee on Economic Development, said the agency's 11-member board did not resemble ''the city that it hopes to rebuild.'' Louis Tomson, executive director of the agency, said he would work harder to recruit more women and minorities. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Montana: Superfund Listing
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said the town of Libby can be added to the national Superfund list as a significantly hazardous site. Libby is home to a vermiculite mine that many former workers and residents have blamed for illnesses and deaths. The designation, requested by Gov. Judy Martz will help obtain financing to clean up the mine. The public has 60 days to comment. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: New Degree in Health at SUNY
description: SUNY Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn is starting a Master of Public Health program. It will begin as a part-time program this summer and become a full-time program in 2004. PASCAL JAMES IMPERATO, a medical doctor who also holds a master's degree in public health, will direct the program; he is chairman of the center's department of preventive medicine and community health and a former New York City health commissioner. The program will be the third such master's program in the SUNY system, along with Albany's and Buffalo's.

title: Jury Out on Pornographer's Harassment Trial
description: The harassment trial of the pornographer Al Goldstein may not turn out to be the blockbuster First Amendment case the defendant says it is. But the case may be breaking legal ground of a different sort: it is already one of the longest misdemeanor trials that lawyers at Brooklyn Criminal Court can remember.

title: ImClone and Bristol-Myers Meet with F.D.A. About Drug
description: ImClone Systems and Bristol-Myers Squibb met with the Food and Drug Administration yesterday about the prospects for ImClone's cancer drug, but both companies declined to say anything last night about the outcome of the meeting.

title: The Little Terror Who Wasn't; No Bomb, but Expelled Boy Still Finds Zero Tolerance
description: It was an audacious, chilling crime, one with the potential to rival the horrors of Columbine. At least that is how it seemed a year ago last week, when the police arrested two 14-year-old boys in this affluent suburb and accused them of trying to blow up their middle school.

title: Milosevic Grills Witnesses Too Harshly, His Prosecutors Complain
description: Prosecutors sought today to clamp down on Slobodan Milosevic's lengthy cross-examinations, saying his grillings could deter future witnesses from testifying against him in his trial here for war crimes.

title: Technology; Congressional Broadband Fight Intensifies
description: Two weeks after the House of Representatives approved legislation to limit the influence of money in politics, the House is expected to approve a telecommunications bill that is largely shaped by the huge campaign contributions it has generated.

title: U.S. MAY SEND G.I.'S TO EX-SOVIET AREA
description: The United States is considering sending a ''sizable'' number of Special Operations forces to the former Soviet republic of Georgia to help train that nation's military in counterterrorism tactics, a senior military official said today.

title: Corrections
description: A biographical sketch on Sunday about a World Trade Center victim, Michael Patrick Tucker, a Cantor Fitzgerald employee known for his dedication to his wife and four children, misstated the sex of the twins, Morgan and Andy. They are girls.

title: Astacio Passes First Test In Mets' Intrasquad Game
description: Whenever Pedro Astacio picked up a baseball in the Dominican Republic last winter, chances are that a Mets official was there to examine the strain on his shoulder. The Mets watched Astacio stretch before his winter ball starts. They were allowed into what served as the training room of a creaky Dominican stadium when he received treatment. And they watched Astacio as he worked out the days after he pitched.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEMAN, MARY ANN
description: FREEMAN-Mary Ann. February 14th, 2002. Beloved daughter of Bernard (Barney) Martin and Catherine Martin, devoted sister of Donald Martin, Penny Misiak, and Lucas Van Eyk. Loving aunt of Carol Read. She was an Account Executive at Infinity Broadcasting. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Memorial service Friday, March 1st, 1:30 P.M., Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Care or to The Church of The Valley, Van Nuys, California.

title: Critics Say New Rule Limits Access to Records
description: Scholars and researchers say people will have a harder time getting information from the government because of a new Bush administration guideline on releasing federal records.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Urging Action On Mad-Cow Disease
description: The General Accounting Office urged the Food and Drug Administration to improve its efforts to prevent mad-cow disease. The accounting office, the investigative arm of Congress, said in a report that the agency has failed to properly inspect animal feed, which was the source of the disease in Europe. It also recommended more tests of cattle that die on farms and said the Agriculture Department and the Customs Service could do a better job of inspecting imported meats and live animals. Elizabeth Becker (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Idaho: Abortion Debate
description: The State Senate sent to the House two competing bills that have rekindled a debate on abortion rights. One, sponsored by Senator Harold R. Bunderson, a Republican, would cover embryos and fetuses under the state's murder, manslaughter and assault laws. The other, advanced by opponents of Mr. Bunderson, would increase penalties for attacks on pregnant women that result in miscarriages or stillbirths. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Baby Spared Mother's Fate By Genetic Tests as Embryo
description: A 30-year-old woman who is very likely to develop a rare form of Alzheimer's disease before she turns 40 has had a baby girl who will be spared that fate because she was genetically screened as an embryo before being implanted in her mother's womb, doctors are reporting.

title: I.B.F. Allows Lewis To Fight Tyson
description: The International Boxing Federation yesterday gave Lennox Lewis permission to fight Mike Tyson in his next bout, which has neither a permanent date nor site.

title: 4 More Years: NBC Signs Host Of 'Late Night'
description: NBC officially signed a new contract with its late-night star Conan O'Brien yesterday, extending his stay as host of its 12:35 a.m. show, ''Late Night,'' for another four years.

title: Consumer Confidence Declines On Concern About Employment
description: Consumer confidence fell this month as concerns about unemployment and the reliability of company earnings reports dimmed enthusiasm that had been building since September, a private research group said today.

title: A Demonstration That Dancing Is About More Than Legs
description: Edisa Weeks and Homer Avila

title: Towns to Sue Over Pollution From Airport In Teterboro
description: Thirteen Bergen County towns filed notice today that they would sue the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey over their fears that air pollution will increase along with traffic at Teterboro Airport.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Facing Drought, City Starts To Reopen Wells in Queens
description: Fearing an extended drought that could perilously lower water levels in New York's reservoirs this summer, the city is beginning to reopen and install filters in 10 to 25 closed wells in southeastern Queens.

title: Thomas Losee Jr., 62, Executive At Several Magazine Publishers
description: Thomas P. Losee Jr., a longtime executive for several large national magazine publishing companies in New York, died on Feb. 2 at Jackson Memorial Hospital in Miami. He was 62 and lived in Glen Cove, N.Y., and Gulfstream, Fla.

title: Tax Agency Was Suspected For a Decade
description: The indictment of 18 former and current city tax assessors on Monday was, it turns out, years in the making. While the investigation that resulted in the federal racketeering charges began five years ago, city and law enforcement officials have been concerned for at least a full decade by suspicions of corruption in the Finance Department, the city agency that oversees the process by which real estate taxes are assessed.

title: Mean, Nasty and Missing
description: A friend of mine, an 8-year-old, asked me the other day if I wanted to see her Glare. She gives good glare.

title: FORSTMANN LITTLE TO SELL PART OF STAKE IN CANDLE MAKER
description: Forstmann Little plans to raise about $200 million by selling one-third of its stake in the Yankee Candle Company. Forstmann, run by its founder, Theodore J. Forstmann, will sell about 10.7 million shares in the candle maker at $18.91 a share, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. That is more than four times the $4.25 a share it paid in March 1998, according to Yankee Candle regulatory filings. Forstmann Little will hold 43.7 percent of the company after the latest planned sale. Yankee Candle, which is based in South Deerfield, Mass., designs and manufactures scented candles. The company's net income fell 0.6 percent, to $43.3 million last year from $43.6 million in 2000.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Ebay Exits Japan For Taiwan
description: The online auction company eBay said it planned to buy a Web site in Taiwan, but also announced an intended pullout from Japan after failing to crack the market dominated by Yahoo Japan. EBay agreed to buy NeoCom Technology, which runs the popular Taiwan Web sites ubid.com.tw and bid.com.tw, for $9.5 million in cash and an additional sum to be determined when the deal closes. The deal is expected to lower second-quarter earnings by a penny a share, to 16 cents. Even as it entered Taiwan, Asia's third-largest e-commerce market, eBay said it would close its operations in Japan on March 31, laying off its 17 employees there. Kevin Pursglove, a spokesman for eBay, said the company had considered partnerships and acquisitions to improve its position, but had decided that Yahoo Japan, a partnership between the American company and the Japanese conglomerate Softbank, was too potent. ''We were late into the market, and they did a much better job at executing on their game plan,'' Mr. Pursglove said. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Change Of Venue Is Opposed
description: The assault trial of a man suspected of being a top aide to Osama bin Laden should not be moved out of New York City because of the Sept. 11 terror attack, federal prosecutors have told a judge. The defendant, Mamdouh Mahmud Salim, is accused of attacking a guard in the Metropolitan Correctional Center in November 2000 while awaiting trial on terrorism conspiracy charges. The guard was stabbed in the eye with a comb made into a knife. Mr. Salim has pleaded not guilty to all charges. In their court papers, filed Monday, prosecutors rejected claims that Mr. Salim could not receive a fair trial in New York. The assault case, they wrote, ''has nothing to do with terrorism in general or the World Trade Center attack in particular.'' Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: Message in a Recycled Bottle
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NALVEN, MAURICE A.
description: NALVEN-Maurice A. After a valiant battle with kidney cancer. Mal passed away peacefully on Feb. 25, 2002. Beloved husband of Beverley and devoted father of his sons, Glenn & Todd, and his stepsons, Dirk, Peter, and Chris vanDijk, and his daughtersin-law, Colleen, Svetlana, and Suki, loving brother of his sister Grace Schlein, and of his grandchildren, Alexandra, Zachary, Miranda, Jake, Torie, Jason and Daniel. Fond uncle of his many nieces, nephews, great nieces and nephews. Friends and family will gather for a memorial on Thursday, March 14, 2002 at 11 A.M. at The Larchmont Yacht Club. In lieu of flowers the family would appreciate contributions to The Cancer Research Foundation, C/O Dr. Janice Dutcher, 640 West 239th Street, Riverdale, New York 10463, or to The Cancer Support Team, 875 Mamaroneck Avenue, Mamaroneck, New York 10543.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWELL, GARETH ELKIN
description: NEWELL-Gareth Elkin. Of New York City and Southampton, NY. Husband of the late Kerrin Berger Newell. Son of Beatrice Elkin Blair and the late Vernon L. Newell. Vice President of Interstate Group, NYC. A memorial service will take place Thursday 1 PM at the Brick Presbyterian Church, 91st and Park Avenue, NYC. A celebration of life will follow the service at the Union Club, 69th and Park Avenue.

title: Big British Phone Company To Cut Prices for Broadband
description: The BT Group said today that it would reduce the price of high-speed connections to the Internet, a move seen by some analysts as a signal that the new management team is ready to attack some problems that have long plagued the company.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Car Restriction To Remain
description: The city announced yesterday that the morning ban on single-occupant cars crossing into parts of Manhattan would remain through the spring. Iris Weinshall, the transportation commissioner, said a new study -- to be released next month -- showed that car trips had been redistributed throughout the day, easing periods of peak traffic. Garage owners, retailers and restaurant owners say the ban has hurt them and damaged the city's already weak economy. Randy Kennedy (NYT)

title: Valuing Lunchroom Duty As a Teaching Resource
description: FOR years, New York City teachers patrolled lunchrooms -- keeping order and, when things were calm, chatting with students.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUGHES, KATHERINE V.
description: HUGHES-Katherine V. On February 24, 2002. Katherine leaves behind her cousins, their families and her friends. Retired Senior Vice President of Dancer Fitzgerald & Sample Advertising Co. Visitation will be held Thursday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. at Weigand Bros Funeral Home, 49 Hillside Ave., Williston Park, Long Island. Funeral Mass will be held Friday, 10 A.M. at Saint Aidan's R.C. Church. Interment to follow at Calvary Cemetery, Woodside, NY.

title: The Pearl Murder
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Foreign Brokers Penalized
description: Bear Stearns Japan Ltd. and Crdit Lyonnais Securities Europe were banned from trading on their own account for illegally selling Japanese stocks short, the latest in a series of penalties leveled against foreign brokers. According to the Financial Services Agency, the country's top regulator, both companies traded stocks on behalf of clients without checking whether the clients had shares in their possession. As a result, Crdit Lyonnais is banned from trading on its own account and via affiliates for two weeks. Bear Stearns cannot act as an agent for its affiliates for one week and cannot trade with them for four weeks. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Message in a Recycled Bottle
description: To the Editor:

title: Room, but Not to Maneuver, For Foes of Campaign Bill
description: Senator Tom Daschle today gave the Senate's Republican opponents of legislation to overhaul the campaign finance law a few more days to weigh their options, as signs grew that the opponents were losing support and running out of ways to block the measure from final passage.

title: In Zimbabwe, Mugabe Runs Against an Old Rival: Colonialism
description: The political banners proclaimed: ''Zimbabwe will never be a colony again.'' The crowd roared its willingness to fight the old enemy. When President Robert Mugabe finally stepped behind the microphone today at a campaign rally in a ramshackle township here, he was ready for battle.

title: INSIDE
description: Possible Access to Embassy

title: Where the Ebb and Where the Flow? A Ram Dass Portrait
description: The leading figures of San Francisco's 60's cultural revolution strode the earth with the impudence of punk-rock gods. Mickey Lemle's ''Ram Dass Fierce Grace'' is the saga of one of them as he comes to terms with his own deterioration.

title: For Democrats, a Continental Divide on Guns
description: He started hunting at 12, the legal age in Montana, up in the mountains around this little town at the headwaters of the Missouri River, and he shot a deer the first day. Forty years later, Mick McGuire still remembers the exact date, and he has taught his stepchildren and grandchildren to shoot, continuing what people here treasure as the state's family heritage of hunting.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Suspect Tied To 1984 Shooting
description: A man arrested on a criminal trespassing charge in Harlem on Friday night is wanted in connection with the shooting of a police officer in Albuquerque in 1984, the police said. The man, Lyle Moody, 53, was arrested at 429 Lenox Avenue, where the police were patrolling because of neighbors' complaints about loitering and drugs. He told the police his name was Fred Darden, but when his fingerprints were entered into the system, a warrant for his arrest was found, officials said. Mr. Moody is wanted in the nonfatal shooting of Officer Vic Webb. Officer David G. Myles, who took part in the arrest, said he had received a call from Officer Webb. ''He was thrilled,'' Officer Myles said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Minnesota: Budget Veto Stands
description: State representatives fell three votes short of overriding Gov. Jesse Ventura's veto of a bill passed last week to deal with the state's projected $2.3 billion shortfall for the next fiscal year. Mr. Ventura vetoed the bill on Monday, saying that lawmakers had been unpatriotic by failing to raise taxes in the face of growing state deficits. A state forecast this week projected a shortfall of $3.2 billion through 2005. Democrats in the House opposed the bill's cuts in education spending.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ISAACSON, H. HARDING
description: ISAACSON-H. Harding. February 26, 2001. Garden twilight. Birds fold their wings as if to bow. Bon nuit, My Love, but just for now. As Ever, Janet

title: Big Red Takes Title In ECAC
description: For the first time in 28 years, Cornell has won the Eastern College Athletic Conference regular-season championship. The Big Red (19-6-2) clinched the ECAC title with a 2-2 tie against St. Lawrence last Friday. Cornell was also ensured a share of the Ivy League title when Dartmouth was beaten by Yale, 4-2, on Saturday.

title: Out of Darkness, Bright New Flavor
description: BLACK trumpet mushrooms are the latest evidence that the chef's life is not an easy one. Just when they think they have a lock on a dramatic ingredient, New York City markets start selling it to amateurs.

title: Subpoenas for Anthrax
description: Seeking to narrow the pool of anthrax suspects, the Justice Department is sending subpoenas to microbiology laboratories across the country for samples of the Ames strain of Bacillus anthracis, the kind used in the letter attacks in the fall.

title: No More Mr. Mean
description: As mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani cultivated a reputation for combativeness. He prided himself on his ability to say no. Faced with opposition, he could be stubborn and immovable. Threatened with lawsuits or criticized in the press, Mr. Giuliani's usual reaction could be summed up in three words: Bring it on.

title: Anheuser-Busch to Feature Mascots
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies ( news/quote ) plans to expand its long-running campaign aimed at encouraging college students to drink responsibly by featuring the mascots of various colleges and universities in television advertising.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Prison Sentence In Computer Case
description: A man was sentenced to 41 months in prison for using a computer virus that wiped out millions of dollars worth of software at his former employer. The man, Timothy A. Lloyd, 39, of Wilmington, Del., was ordered to surrender on May 1 to begin serving his sentence. Mr. Lloyd was charged with activating a virus three weeks after his dismissal by Omega Engineering on July 10, 1996. Omega, a New Jersey maker of measuring devices, spent $2 million to recreate the computerized manufacturing programs and lost an estimated $10 million in anticipated sales, said V. Grady O'Malley, an assistant United States attorney. Mr. Lloyd's lawyer said the company's losses were far smaller and a result of poor management. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: A Red and White Standout in the Greenpoint Borscht Belt
description: GREENPOINT may occupy a position in the geographic center of New York, but it's a world away from the rest of the city. Tucked into the northern tip of Brooklyn, bounded by the East River to the west and Newtown Creek to the north, and not easily accessible by public transportation, this resolutely working-class neighborhood of Polish immigrants has the sort of isolation that makes it popular when politicians debate sites for sewage treatment plants.

title: Belgium Seeks Arms Dealer With Suspected Qaeda Ties
description: Belgian authorities have issued an arrest warrant for one of the world's most notorious arms traffickers, who is suspected of supplying weapons to the Taliban and Al Qaeda and of pouring huge arms shipments into Africa's civil wars.

title: Homeless Man Is Convicted Of Murder in 1989 Stabbing
description: More than 12 years after a young computer engineer was stabbed to death in the vestibule of his Upper West Side apartment building, a Manhattan jury convicted a homeless man yesterday of a second charge related to the slaying, concluding a case that had languished for years and that had ultimately been decided by the testimony of a fellow panhandler.

title: Anheuser-Busch To Feature Mascots
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies plans to expand its long-running campaign aimed at encouraging college students to drink responsibly by featuring the mascots of various colleges and universities in television advertising.

title: House Where 2 Sisters Lived Gives Up Its Secret: A Mummified Infant
description: For years, probably decades, the McClure household held a grisly secret that even death could not shake loose.

title: Gap Has Loss; Federated Net Off
description: Gap said yesterday that it had a fourth-quarter loss, and Federated Department Stores reported a 23 percent drop in earnings. The retailers had to cut prices deeply to attract shoppers.

title: Security in Pakistan Stepped Up After Attack on Shiite Mosque
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Feb. 27  The authorities in Pakistan tightened security around key religious sites and public places today, as mourners paid respects at a blood-stained mosque in Rawalpindi where 12 Shiite Muslims were slain on Tuesday night, and as the police reported a new threat related to the case of Daniel Pearl.

title: Rethinking Dire Warnings By Insurers After Sept. 11
description: Last fall, soon after the attack on the World Trade Center, the nation's insurance companies, supported by bankers, builders and real estate companies, warned that if Congress did not shield the insurers from losses in future attacks, terrorism coverage would vanish and the economy would grind to a halt.

title: Elephants Get a Big Thank You
description: Chris Ofili wanted to do something nice for the elephants who have long supplied an essential element in his art. As it turns out, he has been even nicer to them than he intended.

title: Mass strike threatens Seoul's bid to privatize
description: SEOUL:  More than 50,000 workers in major South Korean public and private industries went on strike Tuesday in a protest that jeopardized President Kim Dae Jung's program for privatizing bloated government-owned companies and that won the support of the conservative opposition.

title: Labs Are Sent Subpoenas For Samples Of Anthrax
description: In an important step for narrowing the pool of anthrax suspects, the Justice Department is sending subpoenas to microbiology laboratories across the country for samples of the Ames strain of Bacillus anthracis, the kind used in the letter attacks in the fall.

title: Black Actors: Still Keeping Their Eyes On the Prize
description: You might expect black Americans in the film industry to be jubilant after the recent Academy Awards nominations. For the first time in 30 years and only the second time in Academy Award history, 3 of the 10 acting nominees in lead roles are black: Halle Berry in ''Monster's Ball,'' Will Smith in ''Ali'' and Denzel Washington in ''Training Day.''

title: Merck Says AIDS Vaccine Shows Promise in Human Trial
description: Merck scientists reported promising findings today from the first human tests of its experimental H.I.V. vaccine, which some experts consider the best hope in the effort to slow the AIDS epidemic.

title: To Them, 2/26 Was Just as Bad as 9/11
description: Every year on Feb. 26, six families have gathered at the World Trade Center to remember the victims of the first act of terrorism there, in 1993.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAFFERTY, JAMES N.
description: RAFFERTY-James N. On Feb. 24, 2002, of New York City. Beloved husband of the late Margaret. Dear father of Mary Fracchia, Rodie Thompson and Jimmy. Loving grandfather of Shannon, Andrew & Blaine. Devoted brother of Catherine Rafferty. Father-in-law of Dr. John Fracchia and Page Thompson. Longtime member of the New York Athletic Club. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset. Funeral Mass Wednesday, 10:30 AM., St. Ignatius Loyola Church, 84th and Park, NY, New York. Interment St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, NY.

title: Unions Hope to Regain Attention of Lawmakers
description: As labor leaders gather here, they are grumbling that many of the issues that American workers care deeply about -- issues like soaring health care costs and safeguarding Social Security -- are largely absent from the nation's political dialogue, eclipsed by the war on terrorism and the Republican push for tax cuts.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about a dispute between Donald J. Trump and the Conseco insurance company over a deal to buy the General Motors Building referred imprecisely to Conseco's history. Although it became a major insurance company in the 1990's, it was never dominant in the industry.

title: Congo Talks Are Suspended On Second Day
description: A day after the opening ceremony for the Congo's long-delayed peace talks, they were suspended this morning because of wrangling over which political parties should be allowed to take part.

title: Proposal for Appointed Boards
description: Two members of Community School Board 2 in Manhattan, KAREN F. FEUER, the president, and ANNE MacKINNON, are pushing to replace the city's 32 elected local school boards -- including their own -- with district advisory boards consisting of appointed and elected members. Ms. Feuer and Ms. Mackinnon said they hoped to influence the Legislature as it considers abolishing the boards, as Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has urged.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Flexible Design Helps Firm Take Over a Building
description: One of the more striking corporate moves in the aftermath of Sept. 11 was the decision by the securities company Morgan Stanley Dean Witter not to move into its almost-complete building at 745 Seventh Avenue at 49th and 50th Streets. Instead it sold the million-square-foot structure to another securities company, Lehman Brothers, for about $700 million.

title: CBS CHANGES LINEUP
description: Boomer Esiason and Dan Marino, who were once rival quarterbacks, were named analysts for CBS's ''The NFL Today'' program, replacing Jerry Glanville and Mike Ditka. Ditka will have a different but smaller role.

title: New Name for Yeshiva's Campus
description: Yeshiva University will rename its main campus in Washington Heights for the Wilf family of Hillside, N.J., who have given the university $10 million. Most of the gift -- $8 million -- will be used to fix up the seven-block campus; the rest will be used for scholarships. JOSEPH WILF, one of the donors, is chief executive of Garden Homes Management, a real estate firm that he and his late brother, HARRY WILF, had founded. Joseph's nephew, LEONARD WILF, president of Garden Homes, and Leonard's sons, MARK and ZYGMUNT, also gave to Yeshiva. Karen W. Arenson

title: Another Blow to Image of T. rex
description: Every school child knows that Tyrannosaurus rex was the biggest, fiercest predator in the Age of Reptiles. No plant-eating Triceratops or duckbill dinosaur was safe when a hungry T. rex came around with sharp teeth ready to tear flesh.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHU, DR. FOO
description: CHU-Dr. Foo. Of Tarrytown, NY, passed away on February 22nd. The Board, Staff and neighbors of Hamilton Madison Settlement House mourn the loss of their longtime Board member and advisor. He made his most notable contributions to this Settlement in the development and establishment of its Behavior Health Services. He will be missed by all of us at the Settlement. Joseph P. Ritorto, President Frank T. Modica, Exec. Director

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a verdict against the Monsanto Company in a pollution case in Anniston, Ala., referred incorrectly to pending claims by more than 15,000 people against Monsanto in federal court. The cases have been consolidated into one lawsuit; they do not constitute a class-action suit.

title: The Catch of the Day Comes in a Tube
description: Here's another Swedish import by the name of Abba: seafood spreads in tubes. They are good to keep on hand for cocktail time, to squeeze swirls on crackers, hard-cooked eggs or cucumber rounds. Briny cod roe comes plain or seasoned with dill, smoked herring has a woodsy intensity and a bit of sweetness, and salmon is the richest one. The 5.3-ounce tubes are $5 each at Dean & DeLuca, and $4 to $4.50 at Amish Markets.

title: Survey Finds 'Extensive' Abuses Of Refugee Children in Africa
description: Children in refugee camps in West Africa are being widely exploited by locally hired camp officials who demand sex in exchange for the food and medicine the children need to survive, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees said today.

title: Jets Re-Sign Robinson but Release Jones and Burton
description: The Jets released two more defensive starters yesterday -- linebacker Marvin Jones and defensive tackle Shane Burton -- but they assured the return of their starting free safety, Damien Robinson, who signed a four-year contract.

title: 10th-Ranked Pitt Is Forced To Come Back in Overtime
description: Sometimes, these things don't make sense.

title: Firing Up Butter to a New Level
description: MELT a nugget of butter and pull it off the flame as soon as it dissolves into a foamy pool. Taste it. It will be milky and vaguely sweet, an unchallenging ingredient. Now, melt another knob of butter, but keep it on the heat. In just a few minutes it will turn golden, then ruddy and finally almost black. At each stage it will take on a new layer of flavor, gaining a delicious nutlike intensity.

title: Other Transit May Be Needed With Queens Bus Strike Likely
description: More than 120,000 Queens residents will probably need to find an alternate way to get to work this morning, as drivers of three bus lines are planning a strike starting at 5 a.m.

title: METRO-GOLDWYN-MAYER SEES DEEPER LOSSES THIS YEAR
description: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc. cut its first-quarter and 2002 forecasts because of disappointing box-office results this month from two of its latest films, ''Hart's War'' and ''Rollerball.'' MGM said it expected a first-quarter loss of 35 cents to 37 cents a share, compared with a Feb. 6 forecast for a loss of 20 cents to 22 cents. For the full year, MGM predicted a loss of 46 cents to 48 cents a share, more than the company's earlier estimate of 24 cents to 26 cents. The company, based in Santa Monica, Calif., said it expected full-year revenue in 2002 to grow 20 percent.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Hindu Temple Blocked
description: The government intends to block construction of a Hindu temple at Ayodhya, where militant Hindus demolished a 16th-century mosque in 1992, setting off Hindu-Muslim riots in which 2,000 people died. The World Hindu Council has threatened to begin construction on March 15 but the home minister, L. K. Advani, above, said: ''We will not allow 1992 to be repeated. We will not allow anything which will make us repent at a later stage.'' P. J. Anthony (NYT)

title: The Latest Mammogram Report
description: There was no doubting the sincerity of Tommy Thompson, the health and human services secretary, when he urged all women 40 and older last week to get regular mammograms. His own wife had breast cancer, and Mr. Thompson believes that mammography ''may well have saved her life.'' But in releasing a task force report that endorses regular mammograms and in putting the imprimatur of his office behind it, Mr. Thompson was acting precipitately. He was announcing his verdict before the evidence on which the task force relied is even available for public scrutiny.

In lieu of flowers donations may be made to City Meals On Wheels, 355 Lexington Avenue, NYC 10017.

title: Boys and Girls Team Sets Relay Record
description: Two weeks ago, the girls' distance medley relay team from Boys and Girls of Brooklyn missed the national high school record for the event by two-tenths of a second. Last night, at the 66th annual Eastern States indoor scholastic championships, the team won the medley in 11 minutes 50.86 seconds, smashing the national mark of 11:52.8 set by Mepham High of Long Island in 1983.

description: The remains of three Long Island brothers who joined Kosovo's fight for independence and were found last year in a mass grave in Serbia, will be returned to New York on Friday for burial next week, according to a group helping with the arrangements.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VINTON, JEAN R.
description: VINTON-Jean R. Died peacefully February 24, 2002 at her home in Lexington, MA, aged ninety-one. Vassar graduate, beloved wife of the late Alfred M. Vinton. She lived a life of service to family, church and community. Survived by sister Frances Baikow, Miami, FL; children, Alfred Jr. of London, John of Wellesley, MA, Helen Lally of NYC, Margaret Cole of Corinth, VT; thirteen grandchildren, four great-grandchildren, three nieces and two nephews. A memorial service will be held at Hancock Church, Lexington, MA, March 8, 11 AM. Memorial contributions may be made to United Hospital Medical Center, Port Chester, NY, or Vassar College.

description: Marcus Camby seems to be clinging to blind hope these days. An M.R.I. test on Monday showed that he would most likely miss the rest of the season, so Camby sought a second opinion today from Dr. David Altchek.

title: All the Gascon Riches (Except the Nap)
description: THE stores and offices still close after lunch in southwestern France, allowing people an opportunity to regain their energy after strenuous digestion. Well, how would you feel after a meal rich in duck or goose fat, with perhaps some foie gras or sausages on the side? If it were me, I'd want a nap.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Setbacks For Democrats
description: Democrats suffered two setbacks in a dispute over Congressional redistricting in the state. Justice Antonin Scalia of the Supreme Court rejected an emergency appeal by a Democratic lawyer, Rob McDuff, asking that Mississippi be ordered to implement a state judge's redistricting map. Earlier in the day, a three-judge federal panel ordered the state to put into effect an alternative map that it drew up because of delays in federal Justice Department approval for the state court plan. The panel said the state court had no authority to draw the map.

title: Syrah Seeks Its Own Identity
description: FOR years, the production of Rhone-style wines in California was limited to a small band of true believers like Randall Grahm, right, of Bonny Doon Vineyards, who were generally considered either visionaries or eccentrics. No matter how much they touted the virtues of Rhone grapes, though, it is fair to say that 10 years ago, nobody foresaw the explosion of California syrahs, made from the signature grape of the northern Rhone Valley.

Ken Belson (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Iowa: Making English Official
description: A bill that would make English the state's official language was passed by the House 56 to 42 and now awaits Gov. Tom Vilsack's signature. The bill, which passed the Senate last year, would require all state and local government documents to be printed in English. Mr. Vilsack has said he would sign the bill if more money was appropriated for English instruction. The House also sent a bill to the Senate that would increase financing for teaching English as a second language. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: Unraveling a Caviar Mystery
description: WHEN Russian sevruga caviar was selling for $20 to $30 an ounce a couple of years ago, a thought crossed my mind: How does Trader Joe's sell it for $11? I asked the same question for years when caviar wars in New York at Christmas produced unbelievably low prices. Now I think I have the answer.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Kashmir: Pro-India Politician Killed
description: Militants shot dead the local leader of the ruling pro-India National Conference Party, Abdul Rashid Dar, in Tailbal, outside Srinagar, a police spokesman said. It was the third killing this year of a ruling party politician in the Indian-controlled sector. P. J. Anthony (NYT)

title: HANOVER COMPRESSOR TO RESTATE EARNINGS OF TWO YEARS
description: The Hanover Compressor Company will restate earnings for two years after shareholders accused the company of inflating profits from its natural gas businesses. The company said regulators were investigating one of its joint ventures. Hanover, which provides compressors to gas pipelines and processors, will reduce earnings since 2000 by $8.9 million, the company said. The Securities and Exchange Commission asked for information about its Hampton Roads venture with the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, which owned a gas plant in Nigeria. The company, which is based in Houston, said it had booked a profit on $63 million in revenue before it was received, including the Nigeria project, which has not begun.

description: In its final weeks, the Hewlett-Packard proxy fight is becoming increasingly tough and increasingly personal.

description: The financial relationship between a group of Singapore investors and two Global Crossing directors became more extensive in the days after Global Crossing filed for bankruptcy protection.

title: On Enron, See No Evil
description: Jeffrey Skilling, the former Enron chief executive, does not like being compared to the captain of the Titanic. ''I got off in Ireland,'' he coyly told the Senate Commerce Committee yesterday. He was alluding to the fact that he resigned last August, before Enron's ultimate collapse. Mr. Skilling, who had cashed in $66 million worth of Enron shares over the previous two years, still says he thought that he was leaving the company in fine shape.

title: Mussina Hopes Midas Touch Returns This Year
description: Mike Mussina does not have a name for it. It is not a groove, not a wave, not a zone. Whatever it is, it is discussed in almost sacred terms. It is elusive, Mussina knows, and he lost it when the season ended last fall. Now he wants it back.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Central Islip: Charges Against Motorcyclists
description: Federal prosecutors began filing charges yesterday against scores of motorcycle gang members who clashed with the Hells Angels in a violent melee at a catering hall on Saturday that left one person dead. The federal charges involve racketeering and are separate from assault and other charges likely to be filed by the state authorities. The first 23 cases were processed yesterday against members of the Pagan Outlaw Motorcycle Club, rivals of the Hells Angels. In all, 73 Pagans were charged. A member of the Hells Angels has been charged with second-degree murder.

title: Excerpts From Testimony Before Senate Panel Investigating Enron
description: Following are excerpts from the testimony of Sherron S. Watkins, an Enron vice president; Jeffrey McMahon, formerly Enron's treasurer and now its president; and Jeffrey K. Skilling, Enron's former chief executive, before a hearing of the Senate Commerce, Science and Transportation Committee yesterday, as recorded by Federal News Service Inc. They were questioned by Senators Barbara Boxer, Democrat of California; John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana; Jean Carnahan, Democrat of Missouri; Byron L. Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota; Peter G. Fitzgerald, Republican of Illinois; Olympia J. Snowe, Republican of Maine; and Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon. A full transcript is available online: nytimes.com/business.

title: HONEYWELL WINS CONTRACTS WORTH NEARLY $2 BILLION
description: Honeywell International Inc., the nation's leading maker of cockpit electronics for aircraft, said it won aerospace and military contracts valued at about $2 billion. Honeywell, which also makes small engines, said the biggest contract was to provide engines for the Army's Chinook helicopters, valued at $1.1 billion over eight years if all options are exercised. The other agreements are with Airbus, two airlines and the Ministry of Defense of Britain. Last week, Honeywell named David Cote, the former head of TRW Inc., as president and chief executive. The company, based in Morris Township, N.J., also won a $710 million 15-year contract to provide safety, surveillance and power-distribution systems for the new Airbus A380 passenger jet. Honeywell will also supply BAE Systems with aircraft electronics, valued at $100 million over eight years.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Minnesota: Running For Governor
description: The State Senate's majority leader, Roger D. Moe, 57, said he would seek the Democratic nomination for governor instead of running for re-election. State Auditor Judi Dutcher and State Senator Becky Lourey are also seeking the nomination. Gov. Jesse Ventura, an independent, has not said if he will seek another term. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about the shootings of two pregnant women in Israel -- one an Israeli, the other a Palestinian -- referred incorrectly to the locations of the attacks. The Israeli woman was shot near the Noqdim settlement while riding in a car, and the Palestinian woman was shot when she was driven past a group of soldiers on her way to a hospital in Nablus. Neither shooting occurred at a checkpoint.

title: Manila Decides It Can Get Along With a Marcos Ally
description: Sixteen years ago this week, the People Power uprising toppled the corrupt dictatorship of Ferdinand E. Marcos, an event now remembered with a national holiday. So it is no happy coincidence that the same week that President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo lighted a torch to mark the anniversary, her government has been forced to compromise with one of Marcos's closest friends, Eduardo M. Cojuangco Jr.

title: Austrian Railpasses
description: Der, a travel agency in Rosemont, Ill., is offering extra days on Austrian Railpasses bought through its offices. Through April 30, purchasers will receive a fifth day free when buying a four-day pass, which costs $178 in first class and $122 in second. The extra day is also added on to five-, six-, seven- and eight-day passes. Besides unlimited rail travel in Austria, the rail passes are good for reduced rates on Danube cruises and bicycle rentals at 40 train stations; (800) 782-2424.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Sheldon B. Satin, 69, Cable TV Consultant
description: Sheldon B. Satin, who helped make cable television popular by consulting in marketing and customer service, died Friday in Stamford, Conn. He was 69 and lived in Pound Ridge, N.Y.

title: If the Computer Smiles, Leave a Big Tip
description: There are various tricks for calculating a restaurant tip. In New York, doubling the sales tax is one. Now Setocorp in Concord, Calif., has developed software for Palm hand-held computers that figures out the tip based on the quality of service. The user clicks on one of five faces in a range of smiles or frowns representing a tip of 10 to 20 percent. The software, Meal Tip, can be downloaded from www.setocorp.com; registration costs $7.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Not Guilty Plea In Girl's Slaying
description: David Westerfield, 50, pleaded not guilty to charges of murder, kidnapping and possession of child pornography in the disappearance of 7-year-old Danielle van Dam in San Diego. Mr. Westerfield waived his right to ask for bail. Danielle disappeared after being put to bed on Feb. 1. Her mother broke down in sobs at the brief hearing before Judge Peter Deddeh of Superior Court. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Tire Maker's Profit Falls
description: Hurting like its major competitors from slack demand for tires from global car and truck makers, the European tire maker, Michelin, reported a 28 percent decline in net earnings for 2001, to 314 million euros, ($271 million), on a 2.5 percent revenue increase, to 15.7 billion euros. Edouard Michelin, the chief executive, said that despite continued difficulties in 2002, income would revive because of higher prices for tires, layoffs at factories in the United States and Europe, and lower prices for raw materials. Michelin's share price rose more than 5 percent. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Bush Urges Work and Marriage Programs in Welfare Plan
description: Declaring that the 1996 welfare overhaul was a resounding success in ending generations of welfare dependency, President Bush called today for even stronger work requirements and $300 million annually to promote marriage and strengthen families among poor people.

title: Lands' End, in a new catalog, addresses the demand for stylish clothing for larger women.
description: MARJORIE MILES, a 65-year-old receptionist from Sedalia, Colo., has trouble finding clothes she likes in her size, which is 2X, or size 22. ''It's hard to find classic-looking clothes, and I'm still working, so I like that kind of thing,'' she said.

title: Rumsfeld Lists Outcomes For Detainees Held in Cuba
description: Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld painted an uncertain future today for the hundreds of prisoners of the Afghan war being held in Cuba, saying they might be returned to their own countries or might be held indefinitely to keep them from picking up arms again.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BAUMAN, LIONEL R.
description: BAUMAN-Lionel R. Beloved partner, friend and colleague. Died February 27, 1987. Sorely missed by all. Eugene M. Grant & Co., LLC

title: HOME DEPOT'S EARNINGS SOAR MORE THAN 50%
description: Home Depot said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit rose 53 percent, helped by cost controls and a sale that drew shoppers into stores. Net income in the quarter, which ended Feb. 3, increased to $710 million, or 30 cents a share, from $465 million, or 20 cents, in the period a year earlier, the company said. Sales rose 29 percent, to $13.5 billion. Home Depot, the largest home-improvement retailer, cut prices on some goods 40 percent in January, and ordered inventory through headquarters in Atlanta instead of through the nine regional offices to reduce expenses, the company said.

title: A Delightful Taste of Paris, by Way of Rochester
description: Pierre Herm, probably the premier pastry chef in France, is opening his own pastry and chocolate boutiques in Paris at a good clip. Mr. Herm, above, who spent years working at Fauchon and Ladure, the city's high-end fancy food and pastry places, opened his first shop in August at 72, rue Bonaparte, on the Left Bank. About two weeks ago he opened a pastry counter in the Korova restaurant, 33, rue Marbeuf, in a fashionable Right Bank neighborhood, and a third shop is scheduled to open in May at 185, rue de Vaugirard, not far from the Eiffel Tower and where he has a big kitchen.

title: Salt Lake Games End; Marketing Games Begin
description: Before the Winter Games in Salt Lake City began, only one United States Olympic sponsor, General Motors, had signed on through 2008. There was no need for any other company to follow G.M., and not a single one was signed up beyond the 2004 Summer Games in Athens.

title: Why Is There a Steel Tree in Central Park? Well, Times Have Changed
description: For purists, Central Park has always been a work of art in itself, and artists who have wanted to display their works there have often been rebuffed. But now that resistance seems to be melting away, and the biggest symbol of the change is a 50-foot stainless steel tree taking temporary root just east of the Sheep Meadow.

title: U.N. Security Council Debates Worsening Mideast Violence
description: A debate on the conflict between Israel and the Palestinians opened today in a Security Council gripped by a sense of urgency and frustration over rising Mideast violence, with the United States arguing against any Council action and pledging to send its own mediator, Gen. Anthony Zinni, back to the region as soon as possible.

title: Grants for Unusual Teaching
description: Eight middle school teachers in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx have each received $15,000 grants to reward teaching that defies the chalk-and-talk model. Winning lessons include history classes that travel throughout the Northwest Bronx and East New York and a Brooklyn science class that uses computers to care for a student-built greenhouse. The awards are financed by J. P. Morgan Chase & Company.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: ID Card Contract Awarded
description: Hong Kong awarded a government contract to manufacture digitally encoded identification cards to a consortium led by its local telephone company, Pacific Century CyberWorks. The closely watched contract, worth $21 million, calls for CyberWorks to supply 1.2 million ID cards, as well as related hardware and software. The cards will hold a chip that has a digital replica of the cardholder's thumbprint. Hong Kong plans to introduce the cards next year. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: Message in a Recycled Bottle
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Washington: Delay In Confirmation Vote
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee postponed for at least a week a vote scheduled for Thursday on the nomination of Judge Charles W. Pickering Sr. to a federal appeals court. The Pickering nomination has turned into the first major judicial confirmation fight of the Bush administration. Liberal groups hope that Democrats, who hold a 10 to 9 majority on the committee, will defeat the nomination. Judge Pickering has been criticized as hostile to civil rights plaintiffs, but his supporters say he has been a leading figure in racial reconciliation. Neil A. Lewis (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YASSER, MARTIN
description: YASSER-Martin. Born May 22, 1919, died peacefully in his sleep, February 26, 2002 in New York. Survived by daughter Jane Palmese of Manhattan and sisters Rose and Ann of Detroit. Service Friday, 11:30 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York City.

title: Lamb, Lentils And Time
description: LENTILS can be cooked quickly, unlike some other dried legumes, but that does not mean they need to be. In this dish they are combined with lamb shanks, red wine and not much else, and they cook for a couple of hours. While becoming beyond tender they also absorb the flavors of the lamb, the wine and the aromatics sprinkled among them. The result is a one-pot meal that takes some time but little work or attention.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAMSING, BYRON L.
description: RAMSING-Byron L. Died at his home in Palm Beach, Florida on Sunday, February 24, 2002 after a lengthy illness. He was 84 years old. Mr. Ramsing graduated from Yale University in 1941. He served two years in the United States Navy during World War II and retired with the rank of Lieutenant. A longtime Palm Beach resident, he founded the First Marine Bank in Riviera Beach and the First American Bank in North Palm Beach. He was co-owner and instrumental in the develpment of Old Port Village later to become Lost Tree Village in Palm Beach County. He was President of both The Bath and Tennis Club and The Everglades Club, a former director of the Seminole Club and a member of the Sailfish Club, all in Palm Beach. He was also a director of Good Samaritan Hospital of West Palm Beach, and The Buffalo Bill Cody Museum in Cody, WY, for many years. He was co-owner of Lee Stocking Island in the Bahamas and planted the very first coconut palms there. In New York City, he was a member of the Knickerbocker Club and The Links. An avid yachtsman, Mr. Ramsing was formerly a summer resident of Edgartown, Massachusetts. He owned the well known powerboat, ''Yellowbird'', which was his original design, and also participated in many ocean sailing races. He was also former owner of the A2Z Ranch in Cody, Wyoming where he raised Norwegian Fjord horses. Mr. Ramsing is survived by his wife of fifty-eight years, Annette Reynolds Ramsing, a brother, Thor H. Ramsing, a son, Byron L. Ramsing, Jr. (of Palm Beach) a daughter, Hope Ramsing Lynn (of Massachusetts) and four grandchildren, Kathryn Lynn, Margot Lynn, Byron Lynn and Louise Lynn. He is predeceased by a son, Kent in 1977. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Peggy Adams Animal Rescue League of the Palm Beaches, 3200 N. Military Trail, West Palm Beach, Florida 33409. For information call QuattlebaumHolleman-Burse Funeral Home, West Palm Beach, Florida.

title: Justices Hear 2 Arguments On the Right To Privacy
description: Two arguments for privacy clashed at the Supreme Court today in a case on whether a city can constitutionally require Jehovah's Witnesses or other door-to-door advocates for religious or political causes to identify themselves to the authorities and obtain a permit.

title: In a Modern 'Medea,' Jason Feels Free in the Arms of a Prince
description: The versions of ''Medea'' passed down by Euripides and Seneca portray the wild goddess from Colchis as a barbaric outsider who uses her magical powers to destroy Corinth and who thinks nothing of murdering her children to punish her faithless husband, Jason. The underlying message, it seems, is that civilized nations, like Greece and Rome, should be wary of unacculturated foreigners.

title: Message in a Recycled Bottle
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Aheadline yesterday about the shootings of two pregnant women in Israel  one an Israeli, the other a Palestinian  referred incorrectly to the locations of the attacks. The Israeli woman was shot near the Noqdim settlement while riding in a car, and the Palestinian woman was shot when she was driven past a group of soldiers on her way to a hospital in Nablus. Neither shooting occurred at a checkpoint.

title: Tales Twice Told: A Historian's Story
description: To the Editor:

title: Tough Competition At Grammys
description: Wednesday will be the biggest night of the year for the mainstream music world, the 44th Annual Grammy Awards, which will be presented at the Staples Center here and broadcast on CBS. The consensus is that the nominations for most of the main awards are likely to prevent a repeat of embarrassing episodes in which winners made the Grammys look out of touch.

title: Heroic Teachers and Schools
description: The Carnegie Corporation has given $1.85 million to downtown schools ''in honor of the teachers who played such a pivotal role for students in the wake of the attack on the World Trade Center.'' Of the grant, $800,000 is to build libraries in two schools within District 1, on the Lower East Side, and District 2, which runs from the Battery to Midtown. Another $300,000 goes to each of the two district superintendents for projects in consultation with teachers.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Strike Spreads To Vehicle Makers
description: A strike at government-owned corporations spread to the two largest motor-vehicle manufacturers, Hyundai Motor and its sister company, Kia Motors, jeopardizing the government's plan to sell its stake in money-losing companies. More than 50,000 workers were idle and train service was severely disrupted. President Kim Dae Jung, who has favored negotiating with labor leaders, denounced the strike as illegal. Leaders of the two largest labor groups called the strike last weekend after the government refused to negotiate on its sale of a number of companies. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, PEARL LEVY
description: COHEN-Pearl Levy. Treasured best friend, beloved wife and adored childhood sweetheart of Henry ''The Silver Fox'' for over 62 years. Born in New York City on January 31, 1920 and died on Feb. 25, 2002. Beloved daughter of the late Sadie and Philip Levy. Cherished and beautiful mother to Meredith Ann & Seymour Cohen and Jerry and Susan Cohen. The adored ''Auntie Mame'' and precious grandma extraordinaire to Suzanne, Daniel, Ross and Sarah. Loving sister and aunt to Dorothea Levy, Claire Stark and the late Stanley Levy and their children. Mother-from the RKO Palace on Broadway to the Radio City Music Hall-you were terrific! May you finally rest in everlasting peace-we all love you. Donations may be made to The Richmond Children's Foundations, Inc. 100 Corporate Drive, Yonkers, New York 10701, Attention: Carol Baron. Services will be held at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'' in Great Neck at 11:00 A.M., on Wednesday, February 27th.

title: Linking Two Very Different Composers in a Single Recital
description: In planning the program for his recital Monday night at Carnegie Hall, the pianist Garrick Ohlsson had to reconcile seemingly different objectives. The concert was part of Carnegie Hall's seasonlong ''Focus on Rachmaninoff'' retrospective. But Mr. Ohlsson also needed a fitting musical context for the premiere of John Adams's ''American Berserk,'' a Carnegie Hall Corporation commission written especially for him.

title: Business Travel; Despite federal rules, the airlines are still finding ways to speed favored passengers to their flights.
description: NOT so fast, big shots.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Insurer Posts Loss
description: The Swiss Reinsurance Company announced its first annual loss in more than a century, mostly because of the Sept. 11 attacks and the collapse of the Enron Corporation. The attacks contributed to an overall loss last year of $119 million. In the second half of the year alone, the Zurich-based company had a loss of $938 million. Its bottom line was also hit by an estimated $110 million in losses from Enron's demise as well as claims from Tropical Storm Allison and from weak stock markets, which hurt its investment income. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Consultant Slashes Work Force
description: The technology consulting company Sapient Corporation announced yesterday that it was eliminating 545 jobs, or 22 percent of its work force, and would take a restructuring charge of $50 million to $55 million in the first quarter. The company, which is based in Cambridge, Mass., also announced the departure of its chief financial officer, Edward G. Goldfinger, whose duties will temporarily be assumed by Susan D. Johnson, a senior vice president at Sapient who previously served as chief financial officer. Sapient, which reported a net loss of $189.8 million in 2001, expects first-quarter revenue to be at or slightly below previous guidance of $55 million to $60 million. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: 5 Dismissed Umps Are Close to Return
description: Five umpires who lost their jobs in 1999 could be working exhibition games as soon as Monday.

title: Smart, Generous, Low-Key And Indicted in Bribery Plot
description: He was the man who understood the arcana of an arcane process, a former tax assessor whom building owners could hire for a not inconsiderable fee and feel confident that they had retained the man who knew just what it took to convince an assessor to keep their tax bills down.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Jobless Rate Rises
description: Brazil's unemployment rate rose to 6.8 percent in January compared with 5.6 percent in December. With retail and construction suffering the most losses, unemployment also rose from 5.7 percent in January of last year as the economy was hobbled by electricity rationing and financial troubles in Argentina. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Investigation Of Phone Charges
description: The European Commission's top competition official said he was investigating the roaming fees that European mobile telephone companies charge customers who travel outside their home country. Mario Monti, the commissioner in charge of competition affairs, told a conference in Madrid yesterday that investigators are trying to determine whether mobile phone operators in different countries are colluding with one another to keep their fees high. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: Wall St. Analysts Tell Congress They Were Misled by Enron
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27  Wall Street analysts told lawmakers today that they gave independent and objective advice about the Enron Corporation just before its collapse but were fooled by misleading statements from the company.

title: The Reds That Britain Forgot
description: BORDEAUX wines have fallen on hard times in Angleterre. According to a new report from the Bordeaux wine trade, the consumption of Bordeaux in Britain has fallen by half over the last 10 years. Replacing claret, as the British call red Bordeaux, have been imports from what is still known in Britain as the New World: mostly Australia but also New Zealand, South Africa, Chile and even the United States.

title: WPP Group Names Leader for Chicago
description: Rick Kemp, senior vice president and executive creative director at the Toronto office of J. Walter Thompson, part of the WPP Group, was named executive vice president and executive creative director at the Thompson Chicago office.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We're at war against terrorists. You can't spend all your time fighting with your friends.''

title: Corrections
description: A picture yesterday with a report in the Metro Briefing column about the Connecticut attorney general's decision against challenging Greenwich's new beach fee was published in error. It showed Attorney General Tom Miller of Iowa, not Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut.

title: Investigators Show That U.S. Embassy Is Vulnerable
description: American and Italian investigators demonstrated today that terrorists might have been able to make their way through more than a mile of tunnels to the American Embassy here and place a chemical bomb in the water pipes.

title: Students Grade Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Added Touches Pay Off for an Arctic Retail Chain
description: Allan Hart works hard to persuade the 1,500 mostly Inuit residents of this remote Canadian Arctic hamlet that the Northern store he manages is an integral, caring member of the community.

title: AN ENRON EX-CHIEF USES DEFIANT TONE AT SENATE HEARING
description: Jeffrey K. Skilling, the former Enron chief executive, testified during a contentious hearing before a Senate panel today that he did not lie to Congress earlier this month about his role in Enron's collapse, and he criticized members of Congress for conducting their inquiry ''with a complete disregard for the facts and evidence.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORINASH, J.E.
description: FORINASH-J.E., Scottsdale, AZ, February 23rd, 90. Generous, kind, and courageous. Survived by his second wife, Eve; daughters, Melissa Buckingham, Phila, PA.; Meredith VonKohorn (Henry), Westport, CT.; granddaughters Isabelle and Emily VonKohorn; two brothers. Services February 28, 2002 Christ the Lord Lutheran Church, Carefree, AZ.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  IRELAND, ROBERT L., III.
description: IRELAND-Robert L., III. A memorial service will be held, Tuesday, March 5 at St. Thomas Church, New York City, (53rd and 5th Ave.) at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested that contributions in Mr. Ireland's memory be sent to The Boys' Club of New York, 287 E. 10th St., NY, NY 10009, or Freedom Institute, 515 Madison Ave., NY, NY 10022.

title: Brainpower
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Shop Owner Is Stabbed To Death
description: The owner of a television repair shop in Brooklyn was found dead in his store yesterday after what investigators believe might have been a robbery, the police said. The body of the owner, Ding-Hao Peng, 59, of Queens, was found just after midnight in the shop, Sun Electronics, at 1937 Rockaway Parkway, investigators said. His hands had been bound and he had been stabbed in the head and torso, investigators said. Kevin Flynn (NYT)

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Makeover Season

title: Elisabeth Luce Moore, 98, Philanthropist
description: Elisabeth Luce Moore, who was active in many philanthropic and educational organizations, died on Feb. 9 at her home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. She was 98.

title: Thumbprint ID Caution
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Raises Money for Elizabeth Dole
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Feb. 27  Two years ago George W. Bush and Elizabeth Dole were rivals for the Republican nomination for president, and when Mrs. Dole pulled out of the race she complained that "the message is money and that's too bad." Neither she nor Mr. Bush seemed concerned about that today, as the president came here to speak at a $1,000-a-plate lunch where he endorsed Mrs. Dole's run for the Senate, ignoring other Republican hopefuls, and raised nearly a million dollars for the state's Republicans.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Extending Law To Chad
description: Belgian investigators left for Chad to inquire into allegations of atrocities against the former dictator, Hissne Habr, who ruled from 1982 to 1990. The team plans to interview witnesses and victims and visit sites where hundreds of Chadians were reportedly tortured by Mr. Habr's forces. Victims are suing him under a sweeping Belgian law that allows crimes against humanity to be prosecuted there, regardless of where they were committed. Mr Habr lives in exile in Senegal. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a woman who died in a fire at her apartment in Queens misspelled her names. She was Caroline Browne, not Carolyn Brown.

title: The World According to Enron's Ex-Chief
description: Jeffrey K. Skilling proclaimed his innocence again yesterday, but in the process he joined in the chorus of people who believe that something was rotten at Enron ( news/quote ), the company he formerly ran.

title: Sports of The Times; Robinson's Bizarre Turnaround
description: WHEN he was the Devils' coach, Larry Robinson moved back and forth behind the length of the bench. But during most of last night's 4-3 victory over the Rangers at Madison Square Garden, he was squeezed near the far end of the Devils' bench. 'I'm in that small space now,'' he had said earlier, smiling.
