description: To the Editor:

title: Proposal for Appointed Boards
description: Two members of Community School Board 2 in Manhattan, KAREN F. FEUER, the president, and ANNE MacKINNON, are pushing to replace the city's 32 elected local school boards  including their own  with district advisory boards consisting of appointed and elected members. Ms. Feuer and Ms. Mackinnon said they hoped to influence the Legislature as it considers abolishing the boards, as Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has urged.

title: Technology Briefing
description: INTERNET

title: Freed After 38 Years, a Killer Struggles to Fit In
description: Thomas Trantino bounded into the suburban diner trailing a heavy cloud of cologne and a palpable aura of exuberance. Wearing a turquoise sweater and a heavy gold chain bearing the Hebrew word for life, he could have been mistaken for a Miami Beach used car dealer or an aging lounge singer. ''I love people, I love to be around them,'' he said, after ribbing a curmudgeonly waitress. Then, with an earnest sigh, he added ''Isn't life just wonderful?''

title: Singer Wears Paint, Pain And Beer
description: The band is called the Yeah Yeah Yeahs, and if you think the name connotes enthusiasm, you're probably saying it wrong. The Yeah Yeah Yeahs affect an attitude of world-weary blankness, as if the very idea of being in a rock band is almost too boring to contemplate. Last Wednesday at Brownies, the lead singer, Karen O, wore a strapless dress decorated with safety pins and gobs of white paint; she kept hiking up the hem and pouring beer down the bodice. All night she did something really shocking: she giggled nonstop.

title: Only Buffer Zones Can Protect Israel
description: It is doubtful that another case can be found in recent history of a nation that has been willing to take greater risks for peace than has Israel. Eight years ago, Israel embarked on a diplomatic experiment by agreeing to grant authority to the Palestine Liberation Organization, an organization whose founding charter called for Israel's annihilation, and to its leader, Yasir Arafat, in the disputed territories of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. It was hoped that the final political status of those lands, to which both Israel and the Palestinians had claims, could be resolved through direct negotiations.

title: Colombian Rebels Go on Killing Rampage
description: The final slaying happened this afternoon, when Cecilia Gallego was dragged from her home in front of her children, led to the backyard and shot at point-blank range.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: French Driver Sought In Big Robbery
description: The police are hunting a guard who is the prime suspect in what is thought to be Germany's biggest robbery. The driver of an armored truck, a 23-year-old Frenchman, is thought to have stolen at least $8.7 million he was to deliver to banks in Frankfurt. He threatened his co-driver with a weapon as the van stopped outside the city, the police said, and let in two accomplices. The three men loaded the cash in another vehicle and drove off. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Afghan Witnesses Say G.I.'s Were Duped in Raid on Allies
description: Up in these mountains in southern Afghanistan, a culture of blood revenge runs strong. Local officials and relatives of Afghans killed by United States Special Forces angrily reject the Pentagon's inquiry into the raid, on Jan. 24, insisting that men were shot without a chance to surrender and that in many cases the Americans, not the Afghans, fired first.

title: 1 Country, 2 Futures
description: An acquaintance here in Saudi Arabia told me this story: He was touring the countryside by car and got slightly lost. He saw a car down the road and approached it to ask directions, but each time he drew near, the car sped away. Eventually he caught up to it, the car pulled over, and a terrified driver jumped out to flee: it was a Saudi woman dressed like a man. In a country where it is illegal for women to drive, that's the only way for a lady to get behind the wheel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAVERMAN, JOHN
description: BRAVERMAN-John. Beloved husband, brother, mentor, selfmade man and friend, died on February 11, 2002.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: New Chief At Netratings
description: NetRatings Inc. said yesterday that William Pulver would become chief executive, replacing Dave Toth, who resigned to pursue other interests. The company, a provider of Internet measurement services, said that Mr. Pulver, left, would also become a director. He had been the president of ACNielsen eRatings.com before becoming president and chief operating officer in October.

title: China Says Next Move In Arms Talks Is Up to U.S.
description: The United States should take the next step to resolve the dispute over Chinese exports of missile technology, a senior Chinese foreign policy official said today in remarks that suggested a continuing impasse over one of the most sensitive issues in Chinese-American relations.

title: Alabama Governor Set for Tough Race
description: When Donald Siegelman became governor three years ago, there was much talk that a new day had dawned in Alabama politics.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORMAN, PATRICIA (FLOWER)
description: GORMAN-Patricia (Flower). Of Riverdale, New York suddenly on February 25, 2002. Beloved mother of Trisha Gorman, Tracey (Jim) Dwyer and Joy Gorman. Sister of Angela Frigiola. Reposing Flower Funeral Home, 714 Yonkers Ave, Yonkers, New York. Funeral Mass Friday, 11 A.M. at Mt. Carmel Church, Yonkers, NY. Interment St. Mary's Cemetery. Visitation Thursday 1-4 and 7-9 P.M.

title: Enron's Nondisclosure
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Jail Lawsuit
description: The American Civil Liberties Union is suing Jefferson County, saying conditions in its jail constitute cruel and unusual punishment. The federal class-action suit on behalf of inmates cites substandard facilities, medical care and staffing. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Dance in Review
description: ADemonstration That Dancing Is About More Than Legs

title: Last Lap for Campaign Reform
description: After years of using every parliamentary trick to block a fair vote on campaign finance reform, Senator Trent Lott sounded like the soul of cooperation yesterday. In a colloquy on the Senate floor with Senator Tom Daschle, and in comments to reporters later, Mr. Lott said he had no interest in obstructing a quick vote on the Shays-Meehan bill, which was passed by the House two weeks ago. That was good news, if Mr. Lott means it, but at this point only his actions count. The Senate needs to take up the bill quickly and reject maneuvers designed to kill it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OBERFELD, LAURA COHEN
description: OBERFELD-Laura Cohen. Of Port Chester, NY. Born August 8, 1915. Passed away Feb. 25, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Oscar Oberfeld. Loving mother of Edythe O. Levitt, mother-in-law of V. David Levitt, grandmother of Valerie L. Schmaier and Ondrea L. Schiciano, and loving greatgrandmother of Samantha Betty and Rachel Levitt Schmaier. Graveside services will be held at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Queens, NY, on Wed., Feb. 27, at 10:30 AM.

title: Teenage Drinking a Problem But Not in Way Study Found
description: After several news organizations reported a finding that under-age drinkers consumed a quarter of the nation's alcohol, the widely respected antidrinking organization that issued the finding acknowledged that it had not applied the usual statistical techniques in deriving that number, which would then have been far smaller.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Jason DeLand was named to the new post of senior vice president for business development at Catalyst, New York. He had most recently been senior vice president at Pacific Century Cyberworks, based in Hong Kong.

title: Bloomberg and Pataki Say Rebuilding of Downtown Should Wait for Overall Plan
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Gov. George E. Pataki suggested yesterday that a Manhattan developer should not go ahead with construction at 7 World Trade Center until completion of an overall development plan for Lower Manhattan.

title: Despite disputes, Games still glow as the flame dies out
description: SALT LAKE CITY:  The hosts of the party were, despite a faux pas in the planning phase, close to impeccable. Only the guests occasionally misbehaved, including the two cross-country skiers who were stripped of their gold medals on the last day for failing drug tests.

title: Ex-Chief of Enron Takes Defiant Tone at Senate Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  Jeffrey K. Skilling, the former Enron ( news/quote ) chief executive, testified during a contentious hearing before a Senate panel today that he did not lie to Congress earlier this month about his role in Enron's collapse, and he criticized members of Congress for conducting their inquiry "with a complete disregard for the facts and evidence."

title: Peca Keeps Gold Medal Form With Last-Second Goal
description: Michael Peca took a victory lap with his Olympic gold medal before the game, then put it away and picked up where he left off. He never stopped skating hard and rewarded the Islanders with another treat at the end of a tough night.

title: F.A.A. Is Accused of Ignoring Security Lapses
description: Accusations that the Federal Aviation Administration covered up and ignored security lapses at the nation's airports deserve a full investigation because they suggest a ''specific and substantial danger to public safety,'' the director of the government's whistleblower-protection agency said today.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Judge Delays Evictions
description: Up to 520 families in the Sacramento area received a temporary reprieve from eviction. Their Japanese landlord, Genshiro Kawamoto, notified tenants several weeks ago that they had 30 days to move. Judge Loren McMaster of Superior Court halted any eviction proceedings until March 20, when he is expected to decide on giving tenants an additional 120 days. James Sterngold (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Business Confidence Rises
description: A surprisingly strong increase in German business confidence provided new evidence that Germany's slumping economy may be close to a recovery. But economists cautioned that the country, which has Europe's largest economy, will probably not pull out of its mild recession until the second quarter of this year. The IFO Institute's index of business sentiment, based on a survey of 7,000 businesses, increased to 88.7 in February from 86.2 in January, more than economists had expected. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, DOROTHY
description: ROSEN-Dorothy. Died peacefully on February 26th in Bal Harbour, FL. at 84 years old. She was the wife of the late Leonard Rosen, devoted mother of Linda and Howard Sterling, Ronnie Rosen & Sandy Raymond, grandmother to eight wonderful grandchildren and seventeen great-grandchildren. Devoted friend to one and all, and uniquely to the downtrodden. Founder of the Miami Beach Hebrew Academy, and saleswoman extraordinaire. Graveside services on Thursday 12:30PM Rosedale Cemetery, Baltimore, MD. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to Special Olympics.

title: Academy Gets a New Leader
description: DIANE J. HULSE has been named head of the Staten Island Academy, a private school. Ms. Hulse, a graduate of Beloit College and New York University, has been head of the middle school at the Collegiate School in Manhattan since 1992. Peter Valdina

title: Supreme Court Eliminates a Barrier to Job Discrimination Plaintiffs
description: The Supreme Court today removed a legal obstacle to bringing employment discrimination suits, ruling unanimously that an initial complaint offering a bare-bones statement of the case is sufficient to withstand an employer's motion to have the case thrown out for lack of specific facts.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Store To Reopen Near Ground Zero
description: Century 21, a discount department store in Lower Manhattan that has been closed since Sept. 11, plans to reopen tomorrow at 11:45 a.m., store officials said yesterday. Eager customers showed up at the store yesterday at the old opening hour of 7:45 a.m., but despite rumors that it would be open, they found the doors still shut. ''I got up extra early just to be here,'' said Diane Lynch, a longtime customer who used to walk through the store every day on her way to work. The store is across the street from the World Trade Center site.

title: Downfall of Knicks Began When They Dealt Ewing
description: Before reminding the Madison Square Garden fans of what a franchise center looked like on Sunday, Shaquille O'Neal opined on the downfall of the Knicks. Simply and succinctly, he traced the Knicks' current plight to the trading of Patrick Ewing.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the cooperation of Citibank and Bank of America the investigation of a currency trader in Maryland whose employer says he tried to hide huge losses misstated the amount lost by the trader. It was $691 million, not billion.

title: Pakistan Is Willing To Give Up Suspect In Reporter's Death
description: President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan agreed in principle today to surrender the chief suspect in the killing of Daniel Pearl to the United States, but only after Pakistan concluded its criminal investigation and was confident that the handover would meet legal requirements, Pakistani officials with knowledge of the discussion said tonight.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: 'Spy' Ship Found
description: The Coast Guard has found a ship that sank in December in the East China Sea after exchanging fire with a Japanese patrol. An underwater camera filming the port side found two Chinese characters and the number 3705. The ship is believed to be North Korean. Chinese ships are monitoring the Coast Guard activity because, as the Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman, Kong Quan, explained, ''Salvage of the ship comes under the regulations and laws of China's exclusive economic zone.'' James Brooke (NYT)

title: Green Tea Prefers Cool Weather
description: An array of Japanese teas, as well as teas from several other countries, are sold by the ounce ($2 to $30) at Ito En, a sleek, serene new shop at 822 Madison Avenue (68th Street). Ito En is also the name of the large Japanese tea company that owns it. The company specializes in green tea, and so does the store, which keeps its green teas in a cooler. Rona Tison, the manager, said that because green tea is not fermented it is perishable, and should be kept cool and used within four months of purchase.

title: Budgeting With Smoke And Wagers
description: LET'S hear it for human frailty. Without it, how would New York's state and city leaders ever balance their budgets?

title: Some Say Ex-Nets Star Got Special Treatment
description: Say what you will about Jayson Williams, but he used his wealth and celebrity to help people in need, many of his neighbors said today.

title: Lemon-Grass Tastes Meet Peanut Butter at Choate
description: Chanin Changtor misses home, especially the pungent taste of lemon grass, the enduring aroma of durian and the sweetness of another fruit, a prickly rambutan. Instead of the dishes of his native Bangkok, Chanin eats pizza and pasta during the last year of high school at Choate Rosemary Hall, the private boarding school.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRASILOVSKY, MONROE
description: KRASILOVSKY - Monroe. Died peacefully Feb. 23, 2002. Survived by his wife Harriet (nee Pion), loving children Lois and Richard, cherished grandsons Scott and Max, caring son-in-law Paul, two sisters Betty Wheeler and Anne Gould. Graveside services on Thursday 11am Beth El Cemetery, Washington Township, NJ. For more information Wien and Wien Memorial Chapels, Hackensack, New Jersey, 800-322-0533.

title: Rib Cage Injury Will Sideline Yankees' White
description: The Yankees could be without two of their free-agent acquisitions when they play their first exhibition game on Thursday.

title: They Steal Napkins, Don't They? (And That's Just a Start)
description: ON a recent Friday night at Ten Penh, a sleek fusion restaurant in Washington, three friends gathered around a table of small luxuries: a tin of caviar the size of a hockey puck, many pink cosmopolitans and three mother-of-pearl caviar spoons.

title: Trustee Ends His Oversight Of District 37; Chief Chosen
description: The trustee who has run District Council 37 for three years in an effort to cleanse it of corruption announced last night that he was ending the trusteeship, confident that the union had been restored to health.

title: Kings Point Cadets Thrive on the Court
description: There was only one possible answer for Rear Adm. Joseph D. Stewart, who stopped cadets at random amid the lunchtime clank of silverware and dishes in the United States Merchant Marine Academy's Delano Hall last Saturday.

title: Enron Hid Big Loans, Data Indicate
description: Even as executives with the Enron Corporation were being privately warned last September that huge corporate debts were being hidden from investors, the company entered into a series of deals that appear to have disguised more than $350 million in new bank loans, according to internal company documents, court records and accountants.

title: Waiter, There's Beer in My Consomm
description: THE adventures of Paul Liebrandt continue. When last spotted, Mr. Liebrandt was working his brand of magic at Atlas, a luxurious cocoon on Central Park South, not the location one normally associates with high-flying, daring cuisine. After a falling-out with the owners, he has moved downtown, and downscale, to Papillon, a friendly bistro in the West Village whose owners obviously do not mind rolling the dice.

title: Miscellany
description: * The skater Sarah Hughes is being featured on boxes of Wheaties cereal, sold by General Mills. The company said she would be the only American medal winner to be on Wheaties packages after the Winter Games.

title: One-Acts Deal in Delicate Negotiations, in the Music Hall and Home
description: A couple of talented performers are having fun in a couple of vehicles coupled under the title ''Double Agency,'' playing through Sunday as La Mama Experimental Theater Club celebrates its 40th anniversary.

title: MSG's Post-Yankee Lineup Includes Mets and More Hours
description: Faced with a future without the Yankees as its centerpiece, the MSG Network announced an overhaul yesterday that includes the addition of 50 regular-season Mets games.

title: Steak With Style: Easy Does It
description: THERE is no country that produces better aged beef than the United States. And I know that you often do nothing more with a good steak than a simple grilling or broiling. Because the meat is so good, you can get excellent results that way. There are plenty of people who insist that doing anything more would ruin it.

title: Trading Off
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

Beach Lures Architects
description: Because of a big demand for light, voluminous spaces in Venice, Calif.,  there's a new breed of building: the architect-designed loft.

description: ''It seems that he doesn't want to forget 1982.''

title: 2 Utilities Say 9/11 Costs May Raise Rates
description: With their hopes of federal aid fading, Verizon and Consolidated Edison are warning that they may make consumers pay for hundreds of millions of dollars in losses they suffered as a result of the World Trade Center attack.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GREEN, WILMA
description: GREEN-Wilma. February 28, 1989 Remembering MY GREAT LADY

title: Interim Road To Reconnect Battery Tunnel
description: The city and state governments, which have come under increasing criticism for moving too slowly in the redevelopment of Lower Manhattan, yesterday announced that construction would begin immediately on a temporary six-lane road leading to the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel and on a temporary footbridge connecting Battery Park City to Lower Manhattan. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg also said that the city was close to having a temporary memorial for victims of the World Trade Center attack.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Bank Avoids Charges
description: One of France's largest banks, Crdit Lyonnais, reached an agreement in principle with the Justice Department to avoid criminal charges in connection with the bank's acquisition in the 1990's of a junk bond portfolio belonging to the failed American insurance company, Executive Life of California. In exchange, Crdit Lyonnais is expected to pay an as yet undetermined fine. Jeffrey B. Isaacs, the assistant United States attorney in Los Angeles, had proposed indicting Crdit Lyonnais, which was owned at the time by the French state, for conspiring with a group of investors to skirt federal laws prohibiting banks from owning insurance companies. Crdit Lyonnais still faces a civil suit for damages, brought in 1999 by the California insurance commissioner, and an investigation by the Federal Reserve into whether the bank violated reporting requirements. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Electronic Virtuosos Enliven Performances
description: THE modern trumpet acquired its familiar form in the early 1800's. In the 1990's, a classically trained trumpet player named Ben Neill gave the instrument a makeover. The result of Mr. Neill's tinkering was the mutantrumpet, a bulked-up version of a traditional horn, with a trio of bells, six valves instead of three and a trombone-like slide attached to the underside.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bank's Profit Declines
description: Britain's fourth-largest bank, HBOS, said that it would issue stock to increase reserves so that it can sell new mortgages and insurance policies, after profit last year fell 5.6 percent. HBOS, which was formed through the merger in September of the Halifax Group and Bank of Scotland, said that it would sell stock worth about 1.37 billion ($1.9 billion). Net income for all of 2001 fell to 1.68 billion, or 45.9 pence a share, compared with 1.78 billion, or 49.7 pence a share, a year earlier. The decline, which was larger than analysts had expected, was partly because of lower margins on mortgages. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AARON, HYMAN LAWRENCE
description: AARON-Hyman Lawrence. Of Cleveland, Ohio at age 89. Beloved husband of Phyllis, devoted father of Roger Aaron and Carolyn Ross, much loved father-in-law of Ginny Aaron and Elliot Ross; adored grandfather of Peter and Todd Aaron and Katie and Douglas Ross. Funeral services in Clevland. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the H.L. Aaron Research Fund, Alzheimers Association of New York, Attn: Lynne Raymond, 360 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10017.

description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Great Neck: Parade For Skating Medalist
description: Fresh from winning a figure skating gold medal at the Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City, Sarah Hughes will be honored by a parade in her hometown Sunday. The two-hour parade is scheduled to start at 11 a.m. just south of the Long Island Rail Road station in Great Neck and to end, a mile and half later, at Great Neck North High School, where Ms. Hughes, 16, is a junior. Gov. George E. Pataki and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton are scheduled to appear.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: AOL To Use Inktomi Product
description: Inktomi, a maker of Internet search and content delivery software, said yesterday that America Online had agreed to use new software from Inktomi that is intended to speed the delivery of Web pages by about 30 percent. The program, Inktomi Personal Edge, works through a combination of compression technology and caching. AOL will use it to speed performance for its 33 million subscribers. Officials of Inktomi, based in Foster City, Calif., cited industry analysts' projections that roughly half of all Internet users will still get access to the network via dial-up modems in 2005, despite assumptions that broadband connections will be widespread by then. Inktomi shares rose 36 cents, or 8.7 percent, to $4.48.

description: To the Editor:

title: Republicans Give Bankruptcy Bill a Push
description: Congressional Republicans are trying to bring momentum to months of negotiations with Senate Democrats to pass a bankruptcy overhaul bill.

description: Dear Crossword Puzzler,

title: Mayor Is Urged Not to Rule Out Tax Increases
description: A group of more than two dozen City Council members, along with union officials and leaders of the Working Families Party, made its first major foray into the budget debate yesterday, urging Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to consider raising taxes in an effort to close the city's huge projected deficit.

title: Engage North Korea
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: San Miguel Sale Approved
description: Shareholders of the San Miguel Corporation approved the sale of 15 percent of the Philippine beer, food and drinks conglomerate to the Kirin Brewery Company of Japan for 27.9 billion pesos ($543 million). The chairman of San Miguel, Eduardo M. Cojuangco Jr., called it a ''win, win, win arrangement.'' Winning the Kirin Brewery deal may have saved Mr. Cojuangco's job. Rather than block a critical foreign investment, the government agreed not to use its control of 44 percent of San Miguel's shares to oust him. The government has accused Mr. Cojuangco of using misappropriated public funds to buy control of the company during the rule of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Enterasys Fires 3 Over Accounting Lapse
description: Enterasys Networks Inc., under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission, fired three senior employees in its Asian unit after a doctored sales contract was given to auditors. The company, which makes office computer network switches, will not identify the fired workers, who were on leave, a spokeswoman said. Enterasys said earlier this month that the Asian office improperly booked a $4 million order in August, and the company had delayed its fourth-quarter results to review the sale. It said the contract was unrelated to the S.E.C. investigation announced at the same time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDONOUGH, DANIEL J.
description: MCDONOUGH-Daniel J. On February 27, 2002. Beloved husband of Mary, father of Daniel (Kerry), grandfather of Mickayla. Reposing, Hodder Funeral Home, 899 McLean Avenue, Yonkers, NY, on Thursday and Friday, 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM. Mass, St. Barnabas Church, Saturday, 11:15 AM.

title: Church, State, Vouchers
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Missouri: High Levels Of Lead In Children
description: Almost half of the children tested last year near the nation's largest smelter in Herculaneum have high levels of lead in their blood, and a fourth of those under 6 years old have lead poisoning, the State Department of Health and Senior Services has said. The department tested the lead levels in almost 1,000 children and adults in Herculaneum, about 30 miles south of St. Louis. The Environmental Protection Agency and the Doe Run Company, which runs the smelter, began cleaning up contaminated houses and yards last year and started relocating almost 100 residents last month. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: Astros' Ballpark No Longer Enron Field
description: Enron was once the Derek Jeter of American corporations -- young, dynamic, full of promise.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Please Don't Eat the Lilies

title: Contract Offers Look at How Global Played Influence Game
description: Even as Global Crossing ran into financial trouble last year, the Pentagon relaxed the security requirements for a planned military communications network in a way that allowed the company to remain in the bidding for the lucrative contract.

title: Don't Just Multitask, Gadgets Shout: Accessorize
description: It is clothing and accessories, not electronics, that Panasonic wants customers to think of when they see its new line of e-wear devices. Designed to be small enough to carry at all times, the new products include a miniature thermal printer and a combination audio-video recorder that is about the size of a business card. Both devices use Secure Digital memory cards for storage.

title: How Sept. 11 Changed Goals Of Justice Dept.
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft has been testifying before Congress this week, arguing for substantial spending increases for counterterrorism programs.

title: INSIDE
description: Tale of Two Economies

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Little Rock Chief Won't Step Down
description: Lawrence Johnson, the first black police chief of Little Rock, said he would not resign despite a second vote of no-confidence in as many months by representatives of the city's 560 officers. The Fraternal Order of Police said on Tuesday that Chief Johnson had shown favoritism toward black officers and had been unresponsive and insensitive to the needs of the officers. Chief Johnson criticized the organization's leaders as out of step with both their members and the community.

title: Thai Government Orders Expulsion of 2 Foreign Correspondents
description: Thailand has issued a rare expulsion order against two foreign correspondents, arousing cries of dismay and anger from both the local and foreign press here in one of the freest and most open societies in Asia.

title: Back to the Single Life, Because It's More Fun
description: ''Sex and the City'' has become less about sex, or even romance, and more about consequences since its debut four years ago. At the end of the most recent season, hard-boiled Samantha had fallen in love; no-nonsense Miranda (still unmarried) gave birth; softhearted Charlotte contended with infertility and divorce. Only Carrie, played by Sarah Jessica Parker, continued to long for romance, seeming more quixotic than ever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUGLIONE, BRUCE ROBERT
description: BUGLIONE-Bruce Robert. Age 55, on February 26, 2002. Esteemed Vice President and faculty member at Audrey Cohen College for more than 20 years. His dedication to the College and its students was exemplary. The Board of Trustees of Audrey Cohen College acknowledges his outstanding achievements as an administrator and teacher, and his passionate commitment to the College's mission. The Board and the entire Audrey Cohen College community extends its sincere condolences to his wife Vera, and the Buglione family on the passing of a man of extraordinary professionalism, spirit and leadership. Contributions can be made to The National Endowment for the Arts, General Counsel, 1100 Pennsylvania Ave. N.W., Washington, DC 20526. John S. Rodgers, Chairman, Board of Trustees Stephen R. Greenwald, President Audrey Cohen College

title: Big Winners at the Grammys: Alicia Keys, U2 and the Film 'O Brother'
description: Proving the contention that it is nearly impossible to ever predict the tastes of Grammy Awards voters, the CD that music fans assumed was least likely to succeed earned the night's top honor, album of the year. Beating out recordings from Grammy favorites U2 and Bob Dylan, the big winner at the 44th Annual Grammy Awards, held tonight at the Staples Center here, was a southern roots music album: the soundtrack to ''O Brother, Where Art Thou?''

title: National Briefing | Labor: Teamsters And Train Engineers Talk Merger
description: The Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers announced that it was exploring a merger with the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. James P. Hoffa, president of the Teamsters, said his 1.4-million member union would welcome a merger with the engineers, saying it would create a more powerful union that specializes in transporting goods. The engineers' union has 59,000 members. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Annan Vows Action On Sex Abuses
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan said that there would be ''zero tolerance'' shown to anyone sexually exploiting children in refugee camps in West Africa and that an investigation team was in the region looking into allegations of widespread abuse. On Tuesday, the United Nations high commissioner for refugees and Save the Children U.K. issued a report saying that children, mostly girls, were being forced into sex with locally hired camp officials and security guards to get food and other essential goods. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMPSON, JULIA MACY
description: THOMPSON-Julia Macy. Died peacefully at her Moss Cottage near Middleburg, VA, February 20, 2002. Beloved mother of Cary Nicholas (deceased) and Dick Macy Potter (deceased), Charles Henschel, Julia Dick, and Francis Thornton Thieriot, grandmother of Cary Nicholas, Jr., Christopher Kingsland, and Jennifer Potter, great-grandmother of Macy Lockheart, Nina Webb, and Nicholas Alonzo Potter. Born January 15, 1914 to Julia Dick and William Kingsland Macy, Republican Representative to the 80th and the 81st Congress. A direct descendant of Thomas Macy, one of the eight men to buy and the first to settle Nantucket Island, Massachusetts in 1635. Mrs. Thompson was a graduate of the Chapin School, 1932. A former member of the Colony Club, New York City, the Victoria Golf Club, British Columbia, the Tuscon National Golf Club, Arizona, and the Middleburg Tennis Club, Virginia. Memorial contributions may be made to Hospice Support of Fauquier County Inc, 42 North 5th Street, Warrenton, VA, 20186. Services private.

title: Orders Rose For Durables In January
description: Orders for big-ticket items rose in January for the third time in the last four months, while sales of new homes fell to the lowest level in one and a half years, the government said today, signaling that the economy is slowly gaining strength.

title: Arafat Says Saudi Plan Needs U.S. Backing
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank, Thursday, Feb. 28  Calling a recent Saudi Arabian proposal a "very strong platform" for a comprehensive Mideast peace, Yasir Arafat said today that its chances for success depended on immediate American support.

title: Designers Take Robots Out of Human Hands
description: THOSE battling robots on television may look fierce and formidable, but they are simply the digital successors to the Wizard of Oz, with humans pulling the levers -- or joysticks -- behind the scenes. It's a lot trickier to create robots that can cope with complicated jobs on their own.

title: Ann Arbor Township Journal; A Huge Crucifix Has This Small Town Abuzz
description: For the last few weeks, the talk here has revolved around a crucifix nearly the size of the Statue of Liberty.

title: But ex-president's past looms large : Giscard's new role at heart of Europe
description: BRUSSELS:  When he presides over the first session of the "Convention on the Future of Europe" on Thursday, Valery Giscard d'Estaing will return to the center of the European political stage after 20 years in the wings.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: $1.5 Million Tax Scheme Alleged
description: The owner and vice president of a Bronx car dealership were charged yesterday with evading more than $1.5 million in state and city sales tax payments. The dealers, Richard Gidron, 63, and Steven Chasan, 37, pleaded not guilty in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. If convicted, the two men face sentences of up to 25 years. They were accused of collecting, but not paying, sales taxes on cars they sold and leased at Dick Gidron Ford between 1995 and 2000. Their lawyer, Burton B. Roberts, a former Bronx district attorney and judge, declined immediate comment. Tax auditors discovered that the dealers reported sales taxes owed between 1991 and 1995 but did not pay them in full, prosecutors said.

title: Washington Wants Wall St. Changes. But How?
description: This just in: analysts for big securities firms are bullish about the stocks they cover. Many do not spend enough time on fundamental research. Some face pressure from their investment banking colleagues to maintain positive ratings on companies. Sometimes the pressure comes from the companies themselves, or even from big shareholders, who would rather not hear bad news.

title: The New Tweed Courthouse
description: Boss Tweed may not have been the right person to trust with New York City cash, but he knew how to make a memorable building. A case in point is the Tweed Courthouse, which is right next door to City Hall and has been undergoing a major, and very expensive, restoration. What workers found behind a beige maze of office-space brickwork was an architectural wonder, a reminder of the opulence, and the corruption, that marked Boss Tweed's dominance of this city in the 1860's. Having taken great trouble to restore this landmark, the city needs to make sure it is put to the best possible use.

title: Renovating With Industrial Strength Lace
description: IT'S Patricia Fox's world. We just live in it.

title: Investment Technology Plans to Buy Rival
description: The Investment Technology Group, which provides equity trading services to institutional investors and brokers, plans to announce today that it has agreed to acquire its rival, the Hoenig Group, for about $115 million in cash, according to executives close to the deal.

title: Nextel Will Underwrite TV Special on Attacks
description: Nextel Communications said yesterday that it would pay an undisclosed sum to be the underwriter of a two-hour special that will be on CBS on March 10 and is based on the videotape shot by two French filmmakers of the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center.

title: Who's Jed Bartlett?
description: Senator Paul Wellstone, who announced this week that he has multiple sclerosis, says he has never watched "The West Wing," where a recent plot featured the character of the president being censured by the Senate for having failed to reveal that he had multiple sclerosis during his campaign for the White House.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISELBERG, MARVIN
description: WEISELBERG-Marvin. My friend and partner for over 50 years. A gentle and sensitive human being. Thanks for the good times. Irma & Eddie Muller

title: Architecture's New Motto: Design Till You Drop
description: ASK Daniel Herman who designed the plaid shirt he's wearing to lunch in a TriBeCa restaurant, and he turns a little red. ''I don't know,'' said Mr. Herman, a 31-year-old architect based in Los Angeles. ''There's some designer's name on it.''

title: A Snow Lover's Lament: 'This Is Winter?'
description: Eli Cabbad, known as Victor, looked out the window yesterday morning and allowed himself to hope again.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Steven C. Gross was named vice president for marketing for the United States at Terra Lycos, Waltham, Mass., succeeding Jim Corboy, who left. Mr. Gross had been chief marketing and sales officer at the Saddle Brook, N.J. office of Arch Wireless.

title: Removal of Painting Irks Nursing Mothers
description: The nudity in the painting is hardly an unfamiliar sight: the slope of a woman's breast partly covered by a baby's mouth.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Privatization Continues
description: Braving recent electoral setbacks in state assemblies, India's federal government is pushing ahead with its privatization agenda. The government is scheduled to deregulate the oil and gas sector in April and, in July, to sell its stake in two more oil concerns, the refining and retailing companies Hindustan Petroleum Corporation and Bharat Petroleum Corporation. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: The Costs of Consolidation
description: Rules limiting media ownership are rapidly disappearing. If they are allowed to vanish, the nation's news landscape will change dramatically -- and not for the better.

title: Block's Profit Increases Sixfold
description: H & R Block Inc., the tax preparer, said its profit rose more than sixfold in its most recent quarter.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: ALBANY: VERIZON RATE RISE IS APPROVED The Public Service Commission yesterday approved a $1.85-a-month rate increase, or 4 percent, for the average Verizon telephone customer, beginning next month. The plan allows for an additional monthly increase of 65 cents in 2003 if Verizon meets performance goals set the commission. The rate increase is expected nearly to cover projected losses for Verizon as part of a commission plan to encourage more competition in Verizon's former monopoly on land line local telephone service.

title: CUNNINGHAM TO END SENATE BID
description: Ed Cunningham, a former N.F.L. offensive lineman whose campaign as a Democrat for the open Senate seat in Texas sparked a political movement in the league when players started political action committees to support him, said yesterday that he would end his Senate bid today.

International lawyer for more than 50 years & community figure, he will be sorely missed by his wife, Peggy; children Debbie, Stephen, Alan and Andrea; by his daughter and son-in-law, Maria and Tom; and his loving former spouses, Barbara and Shirley. Funeral services Friday, March 1st at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, at 10 A.M. Donations to Cabrini Hospice or Gramercy Neighborhood Associates.

title: 3 Days In the Future
description: What preternatural power can prompt Rupert Murdoch, Jeffrey Katzenberg, Richard Dawkins, Neil Simon, Art Buchwald, Frank Gehry and Quincy Jones to sit for hours in a hot room contemplating the nano-sized split ends on gecko toes?

title: Recovery Near, But Its Vigor Is in Doubt, Greenspan Says
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today that the recession appeared to be ending but that the recovery was likely to be sluggish.

title: Cruising the Danube
description: In April and May, KD River Cruises of Europe will deduct $150 a person on eight-day Danube cruises between Budapest and Nuremberg on the 102-passenger Heine. Departures are on alternate Saturdays and include the decade-old canal linking the Main River with the Danube. Ports of call include Kelheim, Regensberg, Passau and Vienna. With the discount, April rates are $1,250 to $1,690 a person, double occupancy; in May, $1,540 to $2,090. This includes all meals, beer and wine with dinner, excursions and port charges. Cabins have private bath and TV; there is an indoor pool. Information: (800) 346-6525 or www.rivercruises.com .

title: Times Appointment
description: Adam Cohen, a lawyer, author and journalist, has been appointed to the editorial board of The New York Times, the newspaper said yesterday.

title: A Long Time Ago, in a Lab Far Away . . .
description: STEVE RUSSELL sat in a darkened movie theater recently watching the army of credits roll by after a computer-animated Hollywood blockbuster.

title: Earthlink Is Dropping TBWA/Chiat/Day
description: EarthLink, an Internet service provider, said yesterday that it was ending its 18-month relationship with the Playa del Rey, Calif., office of TBWA/Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group. EarthLink eliminated the agency as it narrowed an account review. Billings were estimated at $40 million to $50 million.

title: In Caucasus Gorge, a Haven for Muslim Militants
description: Dozens of Afghan and Arab fighters are hiding in this 40-mile-long slash of rock and forest in the Caucasus Mountains, according to Georgian officials. They say at least some of the new arrivals are plotting terrorist strikes in Russia or seeking to reach Europe and the United States, possibly to mount attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOLAN, SEAN
description: BOLAN-Sean. Age 48. Died peacefully in his sleep February 27, 2002 after a long battle with multiple sclerosis. His courage, unfailing good spirit and goodness of heart inspired all who came in contact with him. Prior to his illness he worked for National Review & was an active member of Young Americans for Freedom. He authored ''The Jaws of the Red Navy''. He is survived by his parents, Marie and Thomas, brothers Douglas and William, sisters Mary and Jacqueline Engelhart, and five nieces and nephews. Reposing Quinn-Fogarty Funeral Home, 162-14 Sanford Ave., Flushing, NY (718) 353-5166. Visitation will be on Thursday 7-9 PM and Friday 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial on Saturday, 10:15AM, St. Andrew Avellino RC Church, Northern Blvd. and 158th St., Flushing, New York. Interment St. Charles Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Human Life Foundation, 215 Lexington Ave, New York, NY 10016.

title: Arafat's Words: 'A Push From Outside'
description: Following are excerpts from an interview conducted today by The New York Times with Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, as transcribed by The Times:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Wall Street Is Criticized For Enron Recommendation

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Agilent Executive Quits
description: Agilent Technologies said its chief operating officer, Alain Couder, was resigning to become chief executive of another company. Bill Sullivan, senior vice president of Agilent's semiconductor products group, will replace Mr. Couder, left, effective tomorrow, said Agilent, which makes electronic test and measurement equipment.

title: With Germany In Recession, Many Ask Why
description: Ten years ago, in the economic boom after German reunification, nothing seemed capable of stopping this country.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Ex-Teacher's Lawsuit Dismissed
description: A federal judge in Brooklyn dismissed a lawsuit by a former teacher at the Bronx High School of Science alleging that his dismissal was because of his membership in the North American Man-Boy Love Association and therefore violated his First Amendment rights. The association advocates release of convicted pedophiles and the abolition of laws declaring that minors cannot consent to sexual relations. But Judge Frederic Block noted that the former teacher, Peter Melzer, had taken a leadership role in the group. The judge ruled that Mr. Melzer had been discharged ''because of the likely disruption to the internal operations of the school as a consequence of the public exposure'' of Mr. Melzer's activities. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOTT, REVEREND ROBERT V.
description: LOTT-Reverend Robert V. Died February 27, 2002. The son of the late Margaret and Robert Lott. Survived by his aunt Emily LaFleur, and his cousins Joan Kliemisch, Barbara DiFiore, and Catherine Lewis. The Pastor of the Church of St. Francis deSales on East 96th St, and Administrator of the Church of St. Lucy on East 107th St, Chairman of the Board and President of the SFDS Development Corporation. A community advocate concerned about the elderly and low income persons in need of housing. The wake will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, Madison Ave. at 81st St., Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9PM. His body will lay in state in the Church of St. Francis deSales on Friday begining at 10:30 A.M. A Eucharist will be celebrated on Friday at 7:30 P.M. The Funeral Liturgy will be prayed at 10 AM on Saturday, March 2, 2002.

title: Support for the Saudi Initiative
description: The Bush administration is right to support suggestions put forth by Crown Prince Abdullah of Saudi Arabia on a Middle East settlement. The Saudi leader, whose views carry great weight in the Arab world, is talking about Arab diplomatic relations with Israel and a secure peace in exchange for Israeli withdrawal to a modified version of its pre-1967 borders. With the Oslo agreements in tatters and Yasir Arafat now embracing Prince Abdullah's proposal, the Saudi leader's remarks are the closest thing to a peace plan now circulating and resemble offers Israel considered 13 months ago.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: ONLINE DIARY
description: Numbers Game

title: SALES AT TWEETER FALL MORE THAN EXPECTED
description: The Tweeter Home Entertainment Group said yesterday that second-quarter sales at stores open at least a year fell more than expected as shoppers bought fewer electronics goods. As a result, earnings for the quarter should be 10 cents to 12 cents a share, about half the 20 cents of a year earlier and the 20 cents to 22 cents the company forecast last month. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call had forecast a profit of 21 cents. Sales at stores open at least a year were down about 8.5 percent through Monday and are expected to finish down about 9 percent for the quarter, which ends March 31, the company said. Tweeter, based in Canton, Mass., had forecast sales to be unchanged from the year-earlier period.

title: Bush Campaigns for Mrs. Dole in North Carolina Race
description: Two years ago, George W. Bush and Elizabeth Dole were rivals for the Republican nomination for president, and when Mrs. Dole pulled out of the race she complained that ''the message is money and that's too bad.''

title: The Last of the 3 Greatest Invitationals Dies
description: The economic downturn in Europe has had a disastrous impact on tournament bridge there. Sponsorship money has dried up, and the three greatest invitational tournaments in the world have died.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Hempstead: Arrest In Grade Tampering
description: A former employee of Hofstra University has been arrested on charges that he broke into a campus computer and raised dozens of students' grades, the Nassau County district attorney, Denis E. Dillon, announced yesterday. The former employee, Thomas Stewart, 25, has been charged with falsifying business records and computer trespass. Mr. Stewart, a Hofstra graduate student, was the assistant director of student accounts from July 2001 until he was fired last month. He raised the grades of 37 students as favors for friends, Mr. Dillon said. A lawyer for Mr. Stewart said that neither he nor his client had a comment. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BAUMAN, LIONEL R.
description: BAUMAN-Lionel R. Beloved partner, friend and colleague. Died February 27, 1987. Sorely missed by all. Eugene M. Grant & Co., LLC

title: For Those With a Disability, The Word Made Digital
description: A Napster-like file sharing site for electronic books has opened online, but it is unlikely to anger the publishing industry the way Napster did music companies. The site, Bookshare.org, already includes scanned copies of ''A Beautiful Mind,'' the ''Lord of the Rings'' trilogy and more than 7,500 other books. Volunteers are scanning hundreds more each month and adding them to the site's database. And it's all designed to be perfectly legal.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: COGENT COMMUNICATIONS GROUP, Washington, a provider of Internet access, said it would acquire the United States assets of PSINet Inc., Ashburn, Va., a bankrupt Internet access provider. Terms were not disclosed.

title: For a Chair, Plywood Outside, Nothing Inside
description: It's called Flounce, but this earthy chair of undulating plywood is far from frilly. Jonathan Racek modeled Flounce with a 3-D program, cut it by a computerized router, then laminated the 52 layers of plywood by hand. ''I attempted to derive a simple, beautiful form from a highly technological process,'' Mr. Racek said. The custom-made hollow 40-pound chair, which will be shown at the Milan Furniture Fair in April, can be stained any color and has a polyurethane finish. Flounce is one of a collection of sculptured plywood chairs by Stew, a furniture company based in Boston and Los Angeles that Mr. Racek runs with his brother Kevin. By mail order, Flounce is $3,200, plus shipping; (617) 359-1890.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Garden Q.& A. column last Thursday about camellias referred incorrectly to a catalog from Fairweather Gardens, in Greenwich, N.J. It is $4, not free.

title: Bush Approves Extra $508 Million in Medicaid
description: The Bush administration has agreed to provide New York an extra $508 million in federal Medicaid payments, delivering a victory to Gov. George E. Pataki, who must close a multibillion dollar budget gap.

title: Little-Used Sophomore Helps Lift St. John's
description: As on most nights, Marcus Hatten's contribution to St. John's showed up in black and white on the statistic sheet. He played all 40 minutes, scored 28 points, handed out 10 assists and grabbed 6 rebounds. The line on Curtis Johnson looked forlorn in comparison: no points, no shots, one rebound and four personal fouls.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transcription error, a front-page article in some editions yesterday about the possible deployment of American forces to the former Soviet republic of Georgia misidentified the destination of 10 UH-1 helicopters. The Pentagon has approved the transfer of the aircraft to the Georgian military, which will use them for training purposes, not to the Philippine armed forces.

title: A NATION CHALLENGED: Briefly Noted; MATERIAL-WITNESS LAWS
description: The chief judge of the Federal District Court in Manhattan said this week that people detained under the material-witness laws in the Sept. 11 investigation appeared promptly before judges and were offered the same right to counsel as criminal defendants. The judge, Michael B. Mukasey, said he was responding to assertions by critics that the court's response to the attacks was widespread secret detentions of people in violation of their rights. Judge Mukasey did not offer specifics about the material-witness hearings, but he said he was not surprised that detainees, who may speak about their cases, did not chose to do so. ''I think you can probably conclude,'' he said, ''it is because they and their lawyers believed that it is not to their advantage to go in front of a camera and say, 'You know what? My client was taken into custody in connection with the most ghastly crime ever committed in this society.' '' Judge Mukasey made his comments on Tuesday night before a panel on news media access to terrorism cases held at the Association of the Bar of the City of New York. The forum coincided with the ninth anniversary of the first attack on the World Trade Center, which killed six people. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: Knicks Off To Miami; Layden Off To China
description: Behind the doors at the Knicks' practice today, you could hear the sound of sneakers skidding, spirited shouts and screams of an intense scrimmage. Then it was time to pack the blue uniforms for Miami to try to stop a five-game losing streak.

title: Out of Jail, Into Temptation: A Day in a Life
description: Nando came home from jail to a small apartment in the Bronx that stank like a backed-up toilet.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Panel Approves Cloning Of Embryos
description: A House of Lords committee endorsed legislation, upheld by a court ruling in November, that permits the cloning of human embryos for medical research. The Select Committee on Stem Cell Research, whose decision gives the green light for cloning to proceed, said licenses to clone human embryos should be granted only to researchers who deposit cells in a stem cell bank and that health officials should be sure that no suitable cell line already exists. Research on cells taken from embryos could lead to cures for illnesses like Parkinson's disease and Alzheimer's disease. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: On Display, an Italian Modernist Who Learned From the Best
description: Manfredi Nicoletti has worked and studied with a Modernist architecture hall of fame: Buckminster Fuller, Walter Gropius, Louis Kahn, Pier Luigi Nervi and Eero Saarinen. And unlike many Italian architects, Mr. Nicoletti is actually building substantial projects. ''Manfredi Nicoletti: Architecture as a Metaphor of Nature,'' an exhibit of his work, is on display at the Italian Cultural Institute. Projects include his Helicoidal Skyscraper, an unbuilt design from 1974, and the Sports Palace, left, which was built in 1998 in Palermo, Sicily, with a wavelike sunscreen of giant stainless steel pipes. Through March 15, weekdays only, at 1023 Hilgard Avenue, Los Angeles; (310) 443-3250.

title: Corrections
description: An art review in Weekend on Friday about the annual Armory Show of work by contemporary artists misstated the Guggenheim Museum's plans for an exhibition of the work of Matthew Barney, whose photographs were in the show. The Guggenheim did not cancel the New York showing of ''Matthew Barney: The Cremaster Cycle,'' which is to tour Europe this year; the museum rescheduled it from this February until Feb. 13, 2003, after the European tour.

title: Washington Wants Wall St. Changes. But How?
description: This just in: analysts for big securities firms are bullish about the stocks they cover. Many do not spend enough time on fundamental research. Some face pressure from their investment banking colleagues to maintain positive ratings on companies. Sometimes the pressure comes from the companies themselves, or even from big shareholders, who would rather not hear bad news.

title: Utah Desert, Despoiled
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing
description: SOFTWARE

title: No Tears for Marks, Franks or Lire in Their Last Lawful Hours
description: The Schmidt family delicatessen is rich with tradition, offering venison, rabbit and wild boar from game hunted by the store owners themselves.

title: A Museum Even the Larcenous Old Boss Could Love
description: THE red brick facade of the Museum of the City of New York, described somewhat condescendingly in the A.I.A. Guide to New York City as ''a bland neo-Georgian building,'' stretches along Fifth Avenue from 103rd Street to 104th Street. Actually, it is only about half a building, since the ambitious plans of the fledgling museum, founded in 1923, were drastically scaled back as it was being built during the Great Depression.

title: The Beach Lures Architects, and Actors and Others Follow
description: In the 1960's, artists made Venice, Calif., their home. The once-shabby beachside neighborhood evolved into a mix of single-family bungalows, experimental houses and industrial buildings converted into artists' studios. Now, because of a big demand for light, voluminous spaces, there's a new breed of building: the architect-designed loft. Jack V. Hoffmann, a real estate broker specializing in Venice properties, said that ''a public starving for well-designed space'' had led to the creation of 149 lofts or condo units, which are either under construction or planned. These spaces, starting around 1,200 square feet and costing $500,000 to $2 million, have been designed by such architects as Frederick Fisher, Mark Mack, Steven Ehrlich and the team of Michael King and Diana Pollard. A four-loft complex on Horizon Avenue near the beach, top left, by Mr. King and Ms. Pollard, has balconies of German-made frameless glass. The 1,600-square-foot apartments, some with spiral stairs, top right, leading to the roof, have movable walls so they can be recombined; monthly rents are $3,950 to $4,950.

title: Writers Beware: History Is an Art, Not a Toaster
description: The mea culpas being offered lately by two popular historians caught plagiarizing are lame. They would have it essentially that, oops, mistakes were made because of the marketplace need for quantity and speed. An excuse? Not at all. An explanation? Well, barely.

title: Irving Kupfermann, 64, Professor Of Biophysics and Psychiatry
description: Dr. Irving Kupfermann, a leading student of the way that animals' nervous systems control their feeding behavior and motivational states like hunger, died on Feb. 19 at his home in Port Washington, N.Y. He was 64.

title: No Escape For Swells On a Gritty Boulevard
description: The Paul Taylor Dance Company returned to City Center on Tuesday night for a two-week season with two recent pieces, ''Black Tuesday'' and ''Piazzolla Caldera,'' as well as the 1962 ''Aureole,'' Mr. Taylor's signature work for many decades. ''Aureole'' will not be repeated during the run: it was featured as a treat at this gala opening. Sandwiched between two knockout performances of dynamic pieces, ''Aureole'' looked as cool as a mountain stream. Its lyricism and purity clear the air and the mind.

title: A Balinese-Style Space for Tonics and Contemplation
description: Sept. 11 was not an auspicious opening day for a cafe intended to spread positive energy, but Yon Idiart, owner and designer of the Buddha Garden Cafe, believes his Balinese-style restaurant, behind the Priv Salon and Ona Spa in Los Angeles, does just that. ''It was a very strange day, but people came to relax and feel more positive,'' said Mr. Idiart, former general manager of Patina and Citrus. He has created a walled garden with a retractable roof where customers can sip ganbie tonics (mood-enhancing mixtures of tea and fruit juice) and contemplate Buddha. The restaurant has antique Balinese benches, bamboo umbrellas and tableware from Bali and Thailand. Buddha Garden Cafe, 7373 Beverly Boulevard; (323) 931-4551.

title: A D.L.L. File Is Missing: Responding to the Alert
description: Q. My Windows 98 computer keeps giving me an error message about missing D.L.L. files. What should I do?

title: A. G. EDWARDS TO CUT 400 JOBS TO TRIM SOME COSTS
description: A.G. Edwards & Sons, a brokerage company based in St. Louis, is cutting about 400 jobs, primarily at its headquarters, as part of a cost-cutting plan announced in December, a spokeswoman said. The company did not disclose how many jobs would be cut when it announced the plan on Dec. 20 in conjunction with the release of third-quarter earnings, which fell 61 percent. Edwards aims to cut nonbranch salary expenses by 8 percent, or about $21 million. Cuts are being made through termination, attrition and voluntary retirement, the company said.

title: Hotel Guard Admits He Lied to Authorities
description: A security guard at the Millenium Hilton hotel, near the World Trade Center site, admitted yesterday that he had lied when he told investigators he had found an aviation radio in a safe in the room where an Egyptian student was staying on Sept. 11.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Invisible Ink Yields $800,000
description: A former secretary at Bear, Stearns & Company pleaded guilty yesterday to stealing $800,000 by writing checks in disappearing ink, then rewriting them made out to cash. The former secretary, Anamarie Giambrone, 34, of Flushing, faces two to six years in prison. She wrote checks requested by her supervisor, who signed them in regular ink. Mrs. Giambrone, who worked for Bear, Stearns for eight months, has been in jail since her July arrest. Investigators said she used some of the money to buy her husband, Salvatore Giambrone, a pizza parlor. Mr. Giambrone was arrested, released on bail and is due in court next Monday. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: Volcker Names 2 to Join Panel That Will Oversee Andersen
description: Paul A. Volcker, head of the oversight panel charged with overhauling the embattled accounting firm Arthur Andersen, announced yesterday that Charles A. Bowsher and P. Roy Vagelos would serve alongside him on the board.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Monday about pressure an appeals court has put on the Federal Communications Commission to increase the number of television stations one company can own misstated the number already owned by the Sinclair Broadcast Group. It is 50, not 48. The chart also erroneously included Sinclair on a list of companies and top markets. Sinclair does not have stations in New York or Philadelphia.

title: Computer Program to Help Determine Aid to the Poor
description: The Human Resources Administration will announce a pilot project today to use a new software program intended to help low-income families develop budgets and financial plans that will set them on the road to self-sufficiency.

title: Records Show Wide Variety In Lifestyles Of Assessors
description: At least two of them live with their mothers. One of them drives a beat-up brown Oldsmobile; another just bought a used Toyota Camry. One man, according to a colleague, has worn the same winter coat to work for 20 years.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: SWITZERLAND: CLARIANT'S PROFIT FALLS The Swiss specialty chemicals maker Clariant reported a sharp drop in net profit for 2001, to $82 million, as it struggled with declining sales amid the global economic downturn. Clariant said its debt was reduced by 20 percent as a result of cost-cutting. A revamping program should reduce debt further, the company said. Clariant, which was spun off from Sandoz before it merged with Ciba-Geigy to create Novartis, makes chemicals for the pharmaceutical and electronics industries. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Malibu Rum Being Sold By Diageo To Domecq
description: Diageo has agreed to sell its Malibu rum brand to Allied Domecq for 560 million ($793 million), the companies said today. The sale is expected to pave the way for final antitrust approval of last year's $8.15 billion acquisition of the Seagram wine and spirits business of Vivendi Universal of France by Diageo and Pernod Ricard.

title: Gamma Girls Rock! (Pass It On)
description: To the Editor:

title: Mining Cellphones, Japan Finds El Dorado
description: SABURO MASAOKA speaks with the enthusiasm of a Klondike prospector. In rapid-fire sentences that roll figures and the fanciful into one, he talks about panning for gold, silver, platinum and palladium. But Mr. Masaoka is no ordinary 49er. He is a salesman at Yokohama Metals, a scrap metal recycler whose mother lode is found on the dark side of the wireless revolution: the millions of cellular phones thrown in the trash heap each year.

title: Wall Street Analysts Faulted on Enron
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27  Lawmakers investigating the collapse of Enron ( news/quote ) turned their attention to Wall Street today, criticizing financial analysts for continuing to urge investors to buy Enron stock even as the company headed toward bankruptcy. Several members of Congress suggested that Wall Street firms' hunger for investment banking business and other conflicts kept them from leveling with investors.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Cancer Drug From ImClone May Receive New Review
description: ImClone Systems Inc. said yesterday that federal regulators might consider approving its cancer drug without requiring new clinical trials beyond one already under way in Europe. The announcement sent shares of the embattled company up 32 percent on hopes that the drug might reach the market sooner than some analysts had expected.

title: Japan Says It Will Double Its Annual Whale Harvest in Pacific
description: Japan plans to double the number of whales it kills in the North Pacific each year under a program that it describes as scientific research but that American and some European officials say is commercial whaling.

title: Ellis Jones, 80, Football Star In College With Just One Arm
description: Ellis Jones, an outstanding guard and linebacker for the University of Tulsa during the World War II years and a National Football League player despite having lost an arm in a childhood accident, died Sunday at a hospital in Greeley, Colo. He was 80.

title: That P in PC Now Stands For Picture
description: WHEN film cameras ruled the earth, it wasn't hard to devise a crisp, efficient system for organizing photos. Most people adopted variations on the Oscar Madison technique: 1. Stuff prints into shoe box. 2. Stuff shoe box into closet.

title: Body Is Found And Thought To Be That Of Girl, 7
description: Searchers combing a rural area east of San Diego today found the partly burned body of a child hidden in foliage, and the authorities said this evening they believed it was the body of Danielle van Dam, the 7-year-old girl who has been missing for almost a month.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Clariant's Profit Falls
description: The Swiss specialty chemicals maker Clariant reported a sharp drop in net profit for 2001, to $82 million, as it struggled with declining sales amid the global economic downturn. Clariant said its debt was reduced by 20 percent as a result of cost-cutting. A revamping program should reduce debt further, the company said. Clariant, which was spun off from Sandoz before it merged with Ciba-Geigy to create Novartis, makes chemicals for the pharmaceutical and electronics industries. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Powell Says U.S. Will Grab Chances at Mideast Peace
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27  Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that the Bush administration was prepared to pursue aggressively several new openings for peace in the Middle East and was not "giving Israel a green light" to respond militarily to Palestinian attacks. But he insisted that the onus for curtailing violence remained on Yasir Arafat.

title: World Health Organization Calls for Higher Taxes on Tobacco
description: Cigarettes are cheaper in developing countries today than they were a decade ago, according to a new study by the World Health Organization that warns that low prices will lead to a rise in smoking-related deaths.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Former Rabbi Pleads Guilty
description: A former New Jersey rabbi has pleaded guilty to charges he viewed child pornography on his computer. The former rabbi, Juda Mintz, 59, of Dunwoody, Ga., admitted that he had used a computer at the Mount Freedom Jewish Center in Randolph Township, where he was the rabbi, to download pictures of children engaged in sex acts. Under a plea deal, Mr. Mintz agreed Tuesday not to have contact with children without another adult present. He faces up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine when sentenced on June 12. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: National Briefing: Science and Health
description: CUTTING AGENT ORANGE HEALTH TIE A National Academy of Sciences panel is backing away from its conclusion last year that the children of veterans exposed to Agent Orange may have an increased chance of developing a form of leukemia. After reviewing additional data, including a corrected Australian study, the Institute of Medicine concluded that there is not enough evidence to establish a connection between exposure and development of acute myelogenous leukemia.

title: Moscow Fears G.I.'s Role Could Deepen Conflicts
description: Russia's foreign minister, Igor S. Ivanov, said today that an American proposal to deploy about 200 military specialists to train and equip Georgian armed forces to fight terrorism ''could further aggravate the situation in the region, which is difficult as it is.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  IRELAND, ROBERT L., III.
description: IRELAND-Robert L., III. A memorial service will be held, Tuesday, March 5 at St. Thomas Church, New York City, (53rd and 5th Ave.) at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested that contributions in Mr. Ireland's memory be sent to The Boys' Club of New York, 287 E. 10th St., NY, NY 10009, or Freedom Institute, 515 Madison Ave., NY, NY 10022.

title: Spike Milligan Is Dead at 83; Ringleader of Zany Comedians
description: Spike Milligan, progenitor of a lunatic brand of postwar British humor that blossomed as the 1950's radio hit ''The Goon Show'' and evolved into a blueprint for antic and inventive sketch comedy, died yesterday at his home in Sussex, England. He was 83.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORSINI, CRISTINA
description: CORSINI-Cristina. Died Feb. 26 after a brief illness. Survived by her husband, Lawrence Weppler, her mother, Ruth Saladrigas, her children, Benedetta Corsini, Lorenzo Corsini, Keith Weppler, Courtney and John Hammerton, her sister & brother-in-law, Cecilia and Ronald Shiftan, her niece and nephews, Elizabeth and Andrew Shiftan, James Shiftan, her grandson, Jacob Hammerton and grandniece, Margaret Shiftan. The family will receive friends Thursday evening, February 28 from 4 to 7 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Memorial service will be held 11 AM, Friday, March 1, at St. Stephen of Hungary Church, 414 East 82nd Street. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to City Meals On Wheels, 355 Lexington Avenue, NYC 10017.

title: Pakistan Tightens Security After Deaths
description: The authorities in Pakistan tightened security around major religious sites and public places today as thousands of mourners buried 11 Shiite Muslims who were slain on Tuesday night at a mosque in Rawalpindi. The police also reported a new threat related to the Daniel Pearl case.

title: A Truly Famous Unknown Writer
description: THE JOHN FANTE READER
