description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Scene; Lessons in keeping business humming, courtesy of Wal-Mart U.
description: WAL-MART STORES has just passed Exxon Mobil to become the world's largest company by sales and will thus top the Fortune 500. Wal-Mart's achievement is particularly striking as its once-mighty competitor, Kmart, struggles under bankruptcy protection.

title: Yanks' Only Questions Are About Makeup of Bench
description: The ball twisted in the wind as it descended toward the left-field corner. Cheers rose from the small crowd and the hitter contorted his chunky body in the batting cage, straining for a better look. When the ball scraped the fence just short of a home run, the hitter hung his head in mock shame. The crowd cheered even louder.

title: Labor Board Rules That N.Y.U. Denied Tenure to Union Backer
description: Officials in the regional office of the National Labor Relations Board said yesterday that they have decided to charge New York University with illegally denying tenure to a professor who had testified in favor of allowing N.Y.U. graduate students to unionize.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: Gamma Girls Rock! (Pass It On)
description: To the Editor:

title: Sale of Enron Asset in India Runs Into a String of Setbacks
description: The sale of the Dabhol Power project, one of the Enron Corporation's biggest assets overseas and one of its most troublesome, has become mired in delays and confusion, not least over who is in charge.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New London: Newspaper Drops Lawsuit
description: The Day of New London said yesterday that it had dropped a federal lawsuit challenging, on First Amendment grounds, a city policy banning the installation and use of newspaper-delivery tubes. The Day filed the suit in April, after the city removed some 140 tubes, which are stuffed with the morning paper. Officials said the mailbox-like tubes, standing between sidewalks and curbs, were unsightly and used public property. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

title: Eclectic Mix At Center In Newark
description: The New Jersey Performing Arts Center has announced its 2002-3 subscription season, which will continue to mix visiting orchestras, classical recitals, world music, jazz and dance, in roughly equal proportions.

title: Justices Hear an Argument For Not Hiring the Disabled
description: A Supreme Court argument in an important disability rights case today explored the sometimes elusive line between policies that protect a disabled worker's safety and those that embody an employer's notions of the work that employees with disabilities can do.

title: In Fierce Raids, Israeli Troops Battle Into 2 Palestinian Camps
description: BALATA REFUGEE CAMP, West Bank, Feb. 28  Israeli troops for the first time battled their way into this congested camp and into another camp north of here, in Jenin, killing at least 11 Palestinians and losing one soldier in some of the fiercest fighting of the 17-month conflict.

title: Cigarette Tax Increase
description: To the Editor:

title: Nets Fall Behind Again, but This Time There's No Comeback
description: The Nets have developed a dangerous habit recently, and it cost them tonight.

title: U.S. Seeks Source for Some bin Laden DNA
description: The United States is trying indirectly to obtain samples of DNA from relatives of Osama bin Laden for possible future use in identifying his remains, American officials said today.

title: Electric Power System Is Called Vulnerable, and Vigilance Is Sought
description: The computers that control the electric power system around the nation have been probed from the Middle East, and terrorists may have inspected the physical equipment, said experts at a conference on the security of the electric system.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Rail Strike Ends
description: Railroad workers ended a two-day walkout after their union accepted the government's proposal for reducing the number of hours they have to work and improving working conditions. The agreement did not cover the government's plan to privatize the system. Union members at the Korea Electric Power Company remained on strike, maintaining that privatization would jeopardize thousands of jobs. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Vanbiesbrouck Stellar in Return
description: John Vanbiesbrouck officially ended his retirement tonight, and he looked remarkably sharp for a 38-year-old goaltender who had not played for almost 11 months.

title: Payton Finds Advice and a New Swing
description: It was a chance encounter back in December. Jay Payton was visiting a training facility in Atlanta, where he spends the off-season, when he bumped into Mike Lum, a former major leaguer who is now a roving hitting coach with the Chicago White Sox.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUSTER, ROBERT
description: SCHUSTER-Robert, 81. On February 25, 2002. Beloved husband of Luba, loving father of Richard and Madeline, Stuart, and Joyce and Scott, cherished grandfather of Gena, Brian, Paul, Zachary, Jason, Alex and Kyle. Services today at 12:30 Gutterman's, Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, New York.

title: Achilles' Heel Found in Legs Of the T. Rex
description: Every school child knows that Tyrannosaurus rex was the biggest, fiercest predator in the Age of Reptiles. No plant-eating Triceratops or duckbill dinosaur was safe when a hungry T. rex came around with sharp teeth ready to tear flesh.

title: A Printer That Paints With Bursts of Laser Light
description: LIKE the personal computers they are tethered to, laser printers first appeared in the 1970's and took off over the next two decades. More than 60 million are now installed in the United States, making laser models the most popular printing technology in the workplace.

title: BANKNORTH BUYS IPSWICH TO EXPAND IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: The Banknorth Group, Maine's biggest bank, has agreed to buy Ipswich Bancshares Inc. for $41.1 million in an effort to expand in Massachusetts. Ipswich shareholders may receive $20.50 in cash for each of their shares or exchange them for Banknorth shares, the company said. Banknorth, which is based in Portland, Me., expects to complete the transaction by midyear. Banknorth, which has branches in Connecticut, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, New York and Vermont, plans to convert 49 percent of the company's shares into the right to receive cash. Ipswich is based in Ipswich, Mass.

title: Young Pole-Vaulter's Final, Fatal Jump
description: He was confident. He was relaxed. He was looking, naturally, to soar to the moon. He was, in short, Kevin Dare as ever, a 19-year-old sophomore pole-vaulter competing Saturday afternoon for Penn State in the Big Ten men's indoor track and field championships in the University of Minnesota field house.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Economic Growth Stalls
description: For the first time in a decade, the economy of Britain stalled, recording zero growth in the final quarter of last year. It was the first stagnant period since a recession in the early 1990's. The National Statistics Office said manufacturing, long in decline, shrank by a further 1.7 percent, while services, which account for two-thirds of the economy, failed to grow as much as expected. The slowdown meant Britain's economy grew 1.7 percent from the period a year earlier, compared with expectations of 1.9 percent. The figures also suggested that a consumer binge, inspired by seven reductions in interest rates last year, may now be easing. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; A Lesson Well Applied By Hatten
description: IN the aftermath of a 42-point loss to Duke last Sunday, the $24 million question in St. John's circles was how the team would respond to that humiliating loss on a national stage. Would the Red Storm players come back strong, or would they fold their tents? Specifically, Coach Mike Jarvis wanted to know how Marcus Hatten, his star guard, would respond to the first glitch of his brilliant first season.

title: City Opera Considers Move to Ground Zero
description: The New York City Opera has begun discussions with other cultural institutions and with government officials to create a plan for a major arts complex it would be part of that would rise as a centerpiece of the World Trade Center site.

title: Gamma Girls Rock! (Pass It On)
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel Tries Legislator For Praising Hezbollah
description: An Israeli Arab lawmaker went on trial today on charges of voicing support for a terrorist organization, the first time a member of the Israeli Parliament has been prosecuted for remarks made in office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREED, RONALD
description: FREED-Ronald. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Kurt Weill Foundation for Music mourn the loss of Ronald Freed, who died February 20, 2002. As President of European American Music, Weill's principal publisher, he contributed greatly to the revival of interest in Weill's music. Mr. Freed was a wise consultant and great friend to the Foundation, and he will be deeply missed. The exhibition ''Making Music Theater,'' currently on display at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts, has been dedicated to his memory.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Hackensack: Defendant Completes Tests
description: Ronald J. Popadich, the man accused of mowing down 26 people in two hit-and-run attacks, leading to one death, has left 11 days of psychiatric evaluation and been returned to the Bergen County jail. A spokesman for the Bergen County sheriff's office would not disclose the tests' outcome but said that Mr. Popadich, 39, was being housed in the mental health unit. Mr. Popadich is also accused of shooting a neighbor and a cabdriver. So far, he has been charged with attempted murder, possession of a firearm, carjacking and attempted kidnapping, a Bergen County prosecutor said. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: To City's Burden, Add 11,000 Tons of Daily Trash
description: New York City's trash disposal system, a creaking industrial giant even in the best of times, is emerging as yet another trouble hotspot -- political, logistical and financial -- for a new mayor and a city that seem to have troubles enough as it is.

title: Yet Another Jab At Windows
description: MICHAEL ROBERTSON, who found himself at the center of the digital music revolution as chief executive of MP3.com, has moved to a new battleground. He wants to build a powerful, crashproof computer operating system that runs all the most popular programs flawlessly and is one-third the cost of Microsoft Windows.

title: Ailing Dragila Out Of Championships
description: The women's pole vault has been part of the national indoor track and field championships for six years, and Stacy Dragila, the Olympic and world champion, has won every time. The streak will end in this year's championships tomorrow and Saturday at the Armory Track and Field Center in Upper Manhattan because Dragila, 30, who has been fighting the flu for weeks, withdrew yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Verizon Rate Rise Is Approved
description: The Public Service Commission approved a $1.85-a-month rate increase, or 4 percent, yesterday for the average Verizon telephone customer, beginning next month. The plan allows for an additional monthly increase of 65 cents in 2003 if Verizon meets performance goals set the commission. The rate increase is expected nearly to cover projected losses for Verizon as part of a commission plan to encourage more competition in Verizon's former monopoly on local service. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Two Digital Cameras Raise the Megapixel Stakes
description: Consumer cameras have broken through another barrier. Nikon and Canon have introduced their first digital six-megapixel cameras, and both are intended for the home user.

title: Shadowed by Fighters, Airliner Lands in New York
description: An Air India plane from London was escorted into Kennedy International Airport yesterday by fighter jets, even though law enforcement officials say they had already discounted a tip that one of its 378 passengers resembled a terrorist.

title: Museum May Rethink 3 Works in Holocaust Show
description: A group of Holocaust survivors spent nearly two hours yesterday morning with administrators of the Jewish Museum, and -- in their words -- wept, argued and pleaded for the removal of three pieces they find especially offensive in a forthcoming exhibition on Nazi imagery.

title: Error
description: We're sorry, but you are not eligible for this NYTimes.com promotion.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: TRENTON: FORMER RABBI PLEADS GUILTY A former New Jersey rabbi has pleaded guilty to charges he viewed child pornography on his computer. The former rabbi, Juda Mintz, 59, of Dunwoody, Ga., admitted that he had used a computer at the Mount Freedom Jewish Center in Randolph Township, where he was the rabbi, to download pictures of children engaged in sex acts. Under a plea deal, Mr. Mintz agreed Tuesday not to have contact with children without another adult present. He faces up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine when sentenced on June 12.

title: Trying to Breathe Life Into a Corporate Corpse
description: Enron's ex-employees have every right to be angry, says Stephen F. Cooper, the bankruptcy expert who is working to salvage what's left of the company after what he calls its ''implosion.'' After putting their time and energy into the hard-charging Enron, ''all of a sudden, they get 'bageled,' '' as he put it in a interview this week. ''If it happened to me, I'd be livid.''

title: A Portrait of the Dancer, Perfectionist and All
description: Gene Kelly's first film success, ''For Me and My Gal,'' came when he was 30, past his prime as a dancer. By the time he was 40, Kelly had transformed the movie musical with classics like ''On the Town,'' ''An ''American in Paris,'' and ''Singin' in the Rain.'' In his 50's and 60's, Kelly's output and career dwindled.

title: Pledge to Canadian Unit Is Now Haunting AT&T
description: AT&T thought that it was protecting itself against the excesses of the high-technology boom when it promised in June 1999 to buy all the stock of AT&T Canada that it did not already own, at a price that would rise gradually over four years, once Canadian law was changed to allow it.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: PANEL APPROVES CLONING OF EMBRYOS A House of Lords committee endorsed legislation, upheld by a court ruling in November, that permits the cloning of human embryos for medical research. The Select Committee on Stem Cell Research, whose decision gives the green light for cloning to proceed, said licenses to clone human embryos should be granted only to researchers who deposit cells in a stem cell bank and that health officials should be sure that no suitable cell line already exists. Research on cells taken from embryos could lead to cures for illnesses like Parkinson's disease and Alzheimer's disease.

title: Witness at Milosevic Trial Says He Saw Serbs Kill Scores
description: Halit Barani, an Albanian activist, said in court today that he had been arrested 76 times over the years, so he was more than sure the Yugoslav police did not like him. But just how little they liked him emerged from a document he handed over to the court here, which carried this blunt, typewritten title: ''List of Shiptars in Kosovska Mitrovica who need to be summarily liquidated.''

title: June 5 Is Hunger Day To Help Feed Poor
description: With thousands of new families asking for food relief every week, private charities announced a new national Hunger Day today as part of an emergency effort to fill the depleted stocks in their soup kitchens and food pantries.

title: A Bill of Rights For Rockers Too
description: There is little doubt that Tuesday night's all-star concert fund-raisers for the newly formed Recording Artists Coalition were a major step toward promoting musicians' interests. No longer will rock stars be satisfied with just sex, drugs and rock 'n' roll. They want more cash, better contracts and more rigorous copyright protection, too. In other words, they want to be treated not just like stars but like intelligent people as well.

title: Death Penalty's Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAVIN, NICK (NORMAN)
description: LAVIN-Nick (Norman). After a courageous battle with pancreatic cancer, Nick passed away peacefully on February 27, 2002 at his home in Larchmont, NY. Beloved husband of Monica, devoted father of Sondra and David, and loving brother of Michael. Contributions in Nick's memory may be made to the Lustgarten Foundation for Pancreatic Cancer Research, 1111 Stewart Avenue, Bethpage, New York 11714. A Funeral Service will be held on Sunday 1:15 P.M. at John J. Fox Funeral Home in Larchmont, New York.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: New Combatants on 'Crossfire'

title: WALL ST. ANALYSTS FAULTED ON ENRON
description: Lawmakers investigating the collapse of Enron turned their attention to Wall Street today, criticizing financial analysts for continuing to urge investors to buy Enron stock even as the company headed toward bankruptcy. Several members of Congress suggested that Wall Street firms' hunger for investment banking business and other conflicts kept them from leveling with investors.

title: Lines Are Redrawn, And Battles Renewed; In Redistricting, Cries of Politics
description: Sure, being a Republican lawmaker in the Democrat-dominated State Assembly is something akin to being a bottle of near-beer at a frat party. Still, Roy McDonald thought he could do well by the 100th District, which includes the town of Wilton, N.Y., near Saratoga Springs, where he had been supervisor for 23 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VINTON, JEAN R.
description: VINTON-Jean R. Died peacefully February 24, 2002 at her home in Lexington, MA, aged ninety-one. Vassar graduate, beloved wife of the late Alfred M. Vinton. She lived a life of service to family, church and community. Survived by sister Frances Baikow, Miami, FL; children, Alfred Jr. of London, John of Wellesley, MA, Helen Lally of NYC, Margaret Cole of Corinth, VT; thirteen grandchildren, four great-grandchildren, three nieces and two nephews. A memorial service will be held at Hancock Church, Lexington, MA, March 8, 11 AM. Memorial contributions may be made to United Hospital Medical Center, Port Chester, NY, or Vassar College.

title: James R. Dolan Sr. -- Manager, 74
description: James R. Dolan Sr., a circulation manager for The New York Times in the 1970's, died on Tuesday at his winter home in Fort Pierce, Fla. He was 74.

title: To Rebuild Afghanistan, Look Next Door
description: One of the best hopes for a prosperous Afghanistan is also the least appreciated: Iran. Its ties to Afghanistan are deep. As Hamid Karzai, interim leader of Afghanistan, told Iran's Parliament on Monday, the two countries have ''a common culture and language and these bonds have made our friendship eternal.'' The occasion may have led Mr. Karzai to exaggerate, but not by much.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Rescuing Memories Trapped in Old Film
description: AFTER my mother moved north and married, she missed her hometown in Kentucky so much that my father decided to recreate it in our basement.

title: Global Crossing: 2 Different Worlds
description: As 5,000 Global Crossing employees around the country were busy considering whether to accept the company's severance-pay offer or take their chances by staying on the payroll, there was also a flurry of activity at the house of the company's chairman.

title: Chief Leaving Swiss Life; Profit Plunges
description: Manfred Zobl, the chief executive of Swiss Life, stepped down today amid investment losses that caused a sharp drop in profit last year at the company, the nation's largest life insurer.

title: Reform Struggle in Massachusetts
description: The voters of Massachusetts, seeking to reduce the toxic role of money in electoral politics, have been struggling for three years with recalcitrant legislators over the financing of a path-breaking ''clean elections'' law. The voters embraced the election initiative in 1998 by two to one but have been frustrated by the refusal of the Legislature -- a club of largely unopposed Democrats -- to finance the law. On Monday, the state's highest court came to the voters' aid, ruling 5 to 2 that candidates who qualify under the law should get their public financing. It is now up to the acting governor, Jane Swift, to offer available state funds to give this vital initiative the life it deserves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, BERNARD S.
description: WEISS-Bernard S. Of Riverdale, NY, and West Palm Beach, FL. Beloved father of Jonathan and Stephen. Grandfather of Andrew. Principal Evander Childs H.S. and J.H.S. 13M, music teacher DeWitt Clinton H.S. and H.S. of Music and Art. His legacy will endure through the many lives he has touched.

title: Mazatln Journal; The Bloodstain's Secret: Is Cartel Enforcer Dead?
description: The remains of Frankie O's disco are a scar on this once-beautiful beachfront, a dung-colored pile of concrete collapsing like a child's sand castle washed by the tide.

title: Ingram and Fraser Are All-Americans
description: Elijah Ingram of St. Anthony High School in Jersey City and Jason Fraser of Amityville High School on Long Island were selected for the 2002 High School McDonald's All-American team, the only New York metropolitan area players picked. The McDonald's All-American Game will be played April 4 at Madison Square Garden.

title: Records Dispute Kissinger On His '71 Visit to China
description: Henry A. Kissinger used his historic meeting with Prime Minister Zhou Enlai of China in 1971 to lay out in detail a radical shift in American policy toward Taiwan in exchange for China's help in ending the war in Vietnam, previously classified documents show.

title: Closer to Home; Phones in the Drawer or in the Trash, or to a Good Cause
description: ANYONE who has upgraded to a new cellphone has grappled with the question of what to do with the old one. Stick it in a drawer somewhere? Toss it in the trash can?

title: While Burning Music on CD's, A Drive Also Burns Rubber
description: For disc-burning demons who also like to tinker inside their computers, the PCRW 3210 internal CD-RW drive from Philips Electronics may satisfy both cravings. The drive, which works with Windows-based computers, can copy recordable discs at a speed up to 32x, burn rewritable CD's at a speed up to 10x and read discs at 40x.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTINE, MARCY
description: GOLDSTINE-Marcy. Unexpectedly and too soon on Feb. 25, 2002. Loving wife of Robert Mongioi, cherished daughter of Jerome and Fredricka, devoted stepmother of Adam and Mathew, dear sister of Susan and Bob, favorite aunt of Samantha, Ryan and Steven. Her historic accomplishments include: being the founder of Super Glue Corporation presiding as President for 16 years, and being the first woman account executive on the commodities desk at Merrill Lynch. She blazed the trail for others to follow but most of all, her wit, style, compassion and unconditional love will be etched forever in the hearts and minds of her family and dear friends. Services held on Friday at her sister's home in Beverly Hills, California.

title: Near Success, Election System Overhaul Stalls
description: An effort to overhaul the nation's election system stalled in the Senate today in a dispute that exposed the raw politics that have long made changing the system a difficult matter: how to curb fraud at the polls without disenfranchising voters. The matter goes to the heart of who votes and who does not, or more precisely, who gets elected and who does not.

title: Levy Considers Offering Buyouts Or Retirements to Administrators
description: Chancellor Harold O. Levy has told his senior staff that he is considering offering early retirement or buyouts to administrators within the city school system, as a way of coping with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's proposal to cut 7 percent from the Board of Education's budget.

title: Judge Orders Release of Energy Panel's Files
description: In a setback to the Bush administration, a federal judge has ordered the Energy Department to release thousands of documents related to Vice President Dick Cheney's national energy task force.

title: Top Senate Democrats Question Bush's Handling of War Efforts
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  In the strongest Democratic criticism yet of the Bush administration's war on terrorism, the Senate majority leader and two powerful committee chairman are questioning whether the White House is expanding its military effort without a clear explanation of its aims.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transcription error, a front-page article in some editions yesterday about the possible deployment of American forces to the former Soviet republic of Georgia misidentified the destination of 10 UH-1 helicopters. The Pentagon has approved the transfer of the aircraft to the Georgian military, which will use them for training purposes, not to the Philippine armed forces.

title: Logan Workers Accused of Lying on Applications
description: Federal officials charged 20 people at Logan International Airport here today with giving false information to get jobs or security badges.

title: It's Not Easy Being Mean
description: Weekly highlights from 150 forums -- from mean girls to Peter Carey's comments to readers.

title: Saluting the Tape Cartridge
description: To the Editor:

title: Tyco Says Expense Prepayment Used in '99 Deal
description: Tyco International said yesterday that it had encouraged Raychem, an electronic components maker that it bought in 1999, to prepay some expenses before the acquisition was completed.

title: Powell Says U.S. Will Grab Chances at Mideast Peace
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that the Bush administration was prepared to pursue aggressively several new openings for peace in the Middle East and was not ''giving Israel a green light'' to respond militarily to Palestinian attacks. But he insisted that the onus for curtailing violence remained on Yasir Arafat.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: PHILIPPINES: SAN MIGUEL SALE APPROVED Shareholders of the San Miguel Corporation approved the sale of 15 percent of the Philippine beer, food and drinks conglomerate to the Kirin Brewery Company of Japan for 27.9 billion pesos ($543 million). The chairman of San Miguel, Eduardo M. Cojuangco Jr., called it a "win, win, win arrangement." Winning the Kirin Brewery deal may have saved Mr. Cojuangco's job. Rather than block a critical foreign investment, the government agreed not to use its control of 44 percent of San Miguel's shares to oust him. The government has accused Mr. Cojuangco of using misappropriated public funds to buy control of the company during the rule of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Areport in the Garden Q.& A. column last Thursday about camellias referred incorrectly to a catalog from Fairweather Gardens, in Greenwich, N.J. It is $4, not free.

title: Fire Dept. Postpones Plan to Cut E.M.S. Shifts
description: The Fire Department and the union for city emergency medical technicians agreed yesterday to forestall the elimination of 75 ambulance shifts around the city, a cut that had been included in the city's plans to close its $4.76 billion deficit.

title: Daschle in '04? Not From His Lips
description: Senator Tom Daschle says his instructions to his staff have been unambiguous: Do not utter a word of speculation about whether he will run for president in 2004.

title: Fire Started on Train Carrying Hindu Activists Kills 58
description: An angry Muslim mob Wednesday morning set fire to a train loaded with Hindu activists who are seeking to build a temple on the site of a demolished mosque, killing 58 people and raising anxiety that the attack would set off a spiral of religious violence.

title: Writer Leaves 'NewsHour' in Furor Over Book
description: Under fire for inappropriately copying passages in a 1987 book, the historian Doris Kearns Goodwin has taken a leave of absence from her role as a commentator on the ''NewsHour With Jim Lehrer.'' In addition, the University of Delaware has withdrawn an invitation to Ms. Goodwin to be the commencement speaker this year.

title: For Last-Place Texas, Yet Another Overhaul
description: To find the new Texas Rangers at Charlotte County Stadium, sign in and walk past a clubhouse security guard, through a set of double doors, past the coaches' room and turn left. Once inside the clubhouse, most sets of eyes gravitate toward the right because a chunk of the team's mighty offense is planted against that wall.

title: Mexican Party Elects Leader in Close Race
description: Roberto Madrazo, the former governor of the state of Tabasco, appeared tonight to have won a narrow victory in the election for president of the Institutional Revolutionary Party.

title: A Reporter's Duty
description: To the Editor:

title: Gardeners, Prepare Your Beds
description: THE Philadelphia Flower Show, which starts on Sunday, is sure to have some surprises, its own little Sarah Hugheses that seem to come out of nowhere and grab top prizes. But no matter what plant wins, the plant wizards of this green city have some surefire showstoppers up their sleeves: Japanese cobra lilies to make the collector's heart beat faster; rediscovered annuals like lion's ear, a jaunty soul with tiers of purple flowers going up its stem; a wild pink geranium on stilts from the island of Madeira; and a splendid hollyhock to satisfy the current rage, called Mystic Merlin Mix.

title: An Upstart Auctioneer Digs In
description: Collectors and dealers stood cheek by jowl at Phillips's Chelsea showroom on Friday night to view the contemporary art and 20th-century design objects to be offered by that auction house in May.

title: Abstinence-Only Initiative Advancing
description: Like most groups devoted to curbing the spread of AIDS, the AIDS Resource Center of Wisconsin has spent years promoting condoms. So it was with some surprise that the center received a grant from the Bush administration to persuade teenagers to say no to sex, at least until they are married.

title: Pornographer Guilty in Harassment Case
description: With a split verdict, the trial of Al Goldstein, the pornographer accused of harassing a former employee over her decision to resign, ended yesterday just as it began, with a lot of theatrics and free-flowing expletives.

title: Mixed Signals in Senate Battle Over Appeals Court Nominee
description: For a time, it appeared today that Senator Trent Lott, the Republican leader, was sending a classic Washington public hint to a friend.

title: Hewlett's Chief Urges a Key Audience to Back Deal
description: In a performance by turns spirited, combative and reflective, Carleton S. Fiorina pleaded the case yesterday for Hewlett-Packard's planned purchase of Compaq Computer before a few hundred industry analysts and large investors in New York.

title: PRUDENTIAL UNIT IN VENTURE TO BUY CORPORATE PROPERTY
description: The property unit of Prudential Financial has formed a joint venture to acquire real estate from corporations, taking advantage of the rising interest among companies in selling properties to raise cash. Prudential Real Estate Investors, based in Parsippany, N.J., and the closely held Corporate Realty Investment Company of Boston plan to buy $400 million of properties a year from companies and lease them back, said Marjorie Palace, a principal of Corporate Realty.

title: ARAFAT SAYS PLAN OUTLINED BY SAUDI NEEDS U.S. BACKING
description: Calling a recent Saudi Arabian proposal a ''very strong platform'' for a comprehensive Mideast peace, Yasir Arafat said today that its chances for success depended on immediate American support.

title: A Class Schedule to Make the Head Spin
description: To the Editor:

title: Adelphi Focuses on Success in the Postseason
description: After his team's 85-68 victory over Molloy tonight, Adelphi Coach Jim Ferry stood near midcourt of Woodruff Hall with his 4-year-old son, James, clamped to his leg. Ferry, who was named the coach at Long Island University last week, had just coached his final game at Adelphi's charming relic of a gym. The realization had yet to sink in, Ferry said, because he and the players had so much more to accomplish this season.

title: Paying Homage to a Champion Of Pueblo-Style Santa Fe Homes
description: There are many places for innovative design, said Chris Wilson, a cultural historian in Albuquerque. But residential architecture might do well to reinterpret what he calls ''time-honored patterns.'' Thus his book on John Gaw Meem, a Brazilian-American architect known for his Spanish Pueblo-style designs in Santa Fe from the 20's through the 50's. Mr. Wilson brings Meem to life in ''Facing Southwest: The Life and Houses of John Gaw Meem'' (W. W. Norton & Company, $60), describing the architect through the eyes of his clients. Included are designs -- from floor plans to fireplaces -- similar to the ones the pattern-style architects and builders relied on in the pre-Modernist era. ''Meem believed in the value of precedent,'' Mr. Wilson said. With 100 photographs by Robert Reck of Albuquerque.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a speech that President Bush made in China urging freedom of religion misidentified his residence in Beijing. He and his wife stayed at the St. Regis Hotel, not the Diaoyutai State Guesthouse.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Jabil To Buy Compaq Factory
description: Jabil Circuit Inc., which builds electronic equipment for brand-name companies, agreed to buy a Compaq Computer factory in Scotland and to supply parts to Compaq for three years. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed. But an analyst, Jerry Labowitz of Merrill Lynch, estimated that Jabil paid $30 million to $50 million for the circuit-board factory, and put the value of the parts contract at about $150 million.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: UtiliCorp Sues Chubb Over Surety Bonds
description: WARREN, N.J., Feb. 27 (Bloomberg News)  The insurer Chubb Corporation ( news/quote ), which lost about $220 million by guaranteeing work that was not completed because of the collapse of the Enron Corporation ( news/quote ), is demanding that some purchasers of so-called surety bonds put up collateral.

title: Software Rage
description: It doesn't seem possible, but I may just have found an issue on which every man, woman and child can agree, regardless of politics, age or income: Lousy tech support.

title: Not an Accountant, Just the Chief
description: To the Editor:

title: Earthlink Is Dropping TBWA/Chiat/Day
description: EarthLink ( news/quote ), an Internet service provider, said yesterday that it was ending its 18-month relationship with the Playa del Rey, Calif., office of TBWA/Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group ( news/quote ). EarthLink eliminated the agency as it narrowed an account review. Billings were estimated at $40 million to $50 million.

title: Father of 5 Slain Children Recalls Wife's Depression
description: In a day of emotional testimony in the murder trial of Andrea Pia Yates, her husband, Russell, described his wife as a wonderful mother who relapsed into a severe depression after her father died and failed to respond to psychiatric treatment, including an appointment two days before she drowned her five children in a bathtub.

title: Notes From Youngstown; The Angry Voice of a City Left Behind
description: To those outside Youngstown, Rep. James A. Traficant Jr. must seem alien -- a curious figure, in his cowboy boots and long sideburns. Mr. Traficant, notorious for thumbing his nose at Beltway convention with his bombastic one-minute speeches on the House floor and his contrived bad-boy costume, is currently defending himself against a 10-count indictment on charges of bribery and obstruction of justice in a federal court in Cleveland. If convicted, the nine-term congressman could face more than 60 years in prison and $2 million in fines.

title: City Opera Seeks Partners For Move to Ground Zero
description: The New York City Opera has begun discussions with other cultural institutions and with government officials in an effort to create a plan for a major arts complex it would be part of that would rise as a centerpiece of the World Trade Center site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KISHEL, SIMHA
description: KISHEL-Simha. Heartfelt condolences to Roz Landsman, Meryl Schneider and families on the loss of their beloved mother and grandmother.-Mina, Israel Srebro, Rose Weinrib and families.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Profit Falls At Health Care Group
description: Roche Holding posted a 4 percent decline, to $2.8 billion, in its net profit for 2001, as its investment income fell. The Swiss health care group said it was reviewing options for its vitamins unit, raising the possibility it could be spun off. The company, which is based in Basel, raised provisions, by some $475 million, to cover its exposure to lawsuits over its role in a conspiracy to fix bulk vitamin prices. Roche Holding, which has suffered from product setbacks and a weak product pipeline, said revamping its pharmaceutical business should help raise margins as much as 25 percent in the next three years. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELLI, CHARLES R., JR.
description: MELLI-Charles R., Jr. Age 59. Of Ridgewood and Sea Girt, N.J. Died February 26, 2002. Loving husband of Sheila O'Shea Melli. Cherished father and hero of Kathleen Mary Melli and the late Andrew Shea Melli (June 2001). Big brother and best friend of Mark A. and Jan Melli. Dear son of the late Mary (Corcoran) and Charles R. Melli, Sr. Dedicated son-in-law of Julia O'Shea. Devoted brother of Patrick J. Melli (1997), Francis E. Melli (1972), Regina Woods and Ellen Powley. Beloved uncle of sixteen nieces and nephews. Charles graduated from Seton Hall and received his LL.B. from Saint John's University Law School, and he was a Thomas Moore Fellow. His law career began in New York City with the firm of Reilly and Reilly. He was the Founder and Senior Partner of the law firm of Melli, Guerin and Melli of Paramus, N.J. He was a Fellow of the American College of Trial Lawyers. After being Trustee and Vice Chairman of the Board of Trustees at Holy Name Hospital, he continued his association as General Counsel to the Hospital. He was a strong supporter of Bergen Catholic High School in Oradell, N.J., having served as a member of the Board of Trustees and President of the Alumni Association. For many, many years, he chaired the Annual Golf Outing and major fund raiser for Immaculate Conception Seminary. He was a member of the New York Athletic Club, the Hackensack and Spring Lake Golf Clubs, and the Upper Ridgewood Tennis Club. Family and friends will meet Saturday, March 2nd at the Church of the Assumption, Emerson, N.J., for the celebration of the Mass of Christian Burial at 10AM. Interment to follow at George Washington Memorial Park, Paramus. Friends may call Friday, 3-9PM at the Feeney Funeral Home, 232 Franklin Ave, Ridgewood, N.J. The family has asked that, in lieu of flowers, contributions be made to the Sister Patricia Lynch Regional Cancer Center at Holy Name Hospital, 718 Teaneck Road, Teaneck, New Jersey 07666.

title: Broadband Bill Advances, but Its Survival Is Doubtful
description: The House overwhelmingly approved a measure today to unshackle the nation's largest telephone companies from regulations that impede their expansion into the high-speed Internet market.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Court Doesn't Faze Government
description: Ten days before the presidential election, the Supreme Court threw out a new law restricting election monitors, saying that Parliament had passed it improperly. But since it did not rule that it was unconstitutional, government officials said they would issue regulations to put it into effect. The law bars nongovernmental organizations from monitoring elections and said all local monitors had to be drawn from the civil service. It was criticized by the opposition, who said civil servants would be biased in favor of President Robert Mugabe. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: And the Grammy Award Goes to . . .
description: Single Record of the Year:

title: Boosted by Spending, Economy Stronger Than First Thought
description: Propelled by robust consumer and government spending, the nation's economy surpassed Wall Street's expectations and experienced significant growth in the fourth quarter of 2001, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Bush Tries to Head Off Fight Over Raising the Debt Ceiling
description: President Bush urged Congress today not to play politics with his request to increase the legal limit on the national debt, invoking the war on terrorism to suggest that the two parties should not squabble over who is to blame for the nation's deteriorating fiscal condition.

title: Bus Drivers for 3 Companies Strike in Queens
description: Bus drivers at three companies that serve a sprawling area of southeastern Queens went on strike yesterday morning, leaving as many as 165,000 riders scrambling for alternatives, vying for parking spaces near subway stations, and, in some cases, hitchhiking. And after negotiations ended after 9 last night with no progress reported, the strike appeared likely to continue today.

title: BP's Chief Says the Oil Company Is Ending Its Political Donations
description: As corporate leaders mull the lessons of the Enron debacle, BP, the world's third-biggest oil giant, said tonight that it would halt all political contributions from its corporate coffers ''anywhere in the world.''

title: National Briefing | Washington: Lawmaker Drops Outs Of Whip Race
description: Representative Ray LaHood, Republican of Illinois, said he had pulled out of the race to succeed Tom DeLay of Texas as House Republican whip in the next Congress. That leaves the field clear for Mr. DeLay's candidate, Representative Roy Blunt of Missouri, left. Tim Butler, a spokesman for Mr. LaHood, said the congressman realized he lacked enough support to win the leadership position. The job of the whip is to count votes and round up support for the party's position. When Dick Armey said in December that he would retire as majority leader at the end of his term, Mr. DeLay swiftly established himself as the overwhelming favorite to replace him. Robert Pear (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOKOL, DORIS
description: SOKOL-Doris. Beloved wife of the late Joseph, devoted mother of Diane (Jay) Levy, & Louise Sokol, loving sister of Bill Mardo and Marion Bakst, the late Jack Bloom and Theodore Bloom, adored grandmother of Jill Kara (Sam) Friedman and the late Allison Kim Levy. Services 1:30 Thursday at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York. ''Bear'' always in our hearts.

title: A Class Schedule to Make the Head Spin
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRIFFITHS, RUTH BAKER BAINES
description: GRIFFITHS-Ruth Baker Baines, 99. Died Tuesday, Feb. 26, 2002 at her home in Farmington, CT. Born October 17, 1902 on her grandparents' farm in Leyden, MA, she was the daughter of Ellen Budington Baines-Griffiths and David Baines-Griffiths and sister of the late Hugh Budington Griffiths and Walter Denison Griffiths. At age 3, she moved to Spuyten Duyvil, where her father was minister of Edgehill Church. She lived in Spuyten Duyvil and Riverdale until 1998 when she moved to Farmington. A graduate of St. Agatha's School and Vassar College Class of 1924, Miss Griffiths worked at Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital until her retirement. She was a member of the Shakespeare Club, Riverdale Yacht Club, and Edgehill Church. Enthusiastic about hiking and canoeing, she enjoyed vacations in the Adirondacks and in later years on the Coast of Maine. She is survived by her niece Kathleen Griffiths Anderson and her husband Sherwood L. Anderson; Hal Reynolds husband of her late niece Desire Griffiths Reynolds; her nephew, David H. Griffiths and his wife Joyce Griffiths; her nephew Robert B. Griffiths; her niece Ruth Griffiths Doyle and husband William Doyle; her niece Marion Griffiths Demcisak and husband John Demcisak. She also leaves 13 great nieces and nephews and her cousin, William Budington and his wife Irma Budington. A memorial service will be held Saturday, March 2 at 10:30AM at Edgehill Church, Spuyten Duyvil, New York. Donations may be made to Edgehill Church in her memory.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Minnesota: Ventura Faces Test On Veto
description: On its second try in two days, the House of Representatives voted to override Gov. Jesse Ventura's veto of a bill to deal with a projected $2.3 billion shortage. An override attempt on Tuesday in the House came up three votes short of the needed two-thirds majority. House leaders, who had drafted the bipartisan bill as an alternative to Governor Ventura's plan to raise taxes, pushed for the new vote, and several Democrats switched their positions. The Senate is to act on the override this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINNIGEN, WILLIAM GURNEE
description: SINNIGEN-William Gurnee. Died in Vermont on January 26, 2002. He was a member of the History Department at Hunter College from 1962 until his retirement in 1990, serving as Chair for six years. His B.A., M.A., and Ph.D. in Ancient History were earned at the University of Michigan. He was the Rome Prize Fellow for two years at the American Academy in Rome. After completing his doctorate Professor Sinnigen served in the United States Army in Germany. He was the author and editor of several scholarly books including the History of Rome to AD 565 (which went through many editions), The Roman Secret Service, The Officium Of The Urban Prefecture during the later Roman Empire and The Origins of the Frumentarii, and of numerous articles on classical history. He also starred in the German film Der Ruf (The Last Illussion) a reflection of post-war antisemitism in Germany, written and directed by the celebrated actor Fritz Kortner with Josef De Baky. Jennifer J. Raab, President Hunter College

title: Three Convictions Overturned in Louima Torture Case
description: Afederal appeals court today overturned the convictions of three New York City police officers who had been found guilty of torturing a Haitian immigrant in a stationhouse nearly five years ago.

title: A Terrorism Suspect Is Questioned About Manila Bombings
description: A prime suspect in a plot to blow up the American Embassy in Singapore appeared before investigators today in connection with separate bombings in Manila in December 2000. The circuslike atmosphere and proceedings at the preliminary hearing vividly illustrated the obstacles investigators face in looking into potentially deadly terrorist incidents.

title: After Deaths, Childproofing
description: AN empty Lane Home Furnishings cedar chest, so inviting to children playing hide-and- seek, may lock automatically from the inside, causing suffocation.

title: Metro Matters; After Election, Health Bill Loses Allure
description: JUST a few weeks ago it was all the rage, remember? The women's health care bill. Two of them, actually. In a rare case of Albany acting quickly, both chambers approved viable bills, trying to grab the advantage in the special State Senate election on Manhattan's East Side between Assemblyman John Ravitz, a Republican, and Liz Krueger, a Democrat.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Another Mayoral Switch In Compton
description: An appellate court has temporarily reinstated Eric J. Perrodin as mayor of Compton. Mr. Perrodin was removed earlier this month after a challenge to his election last June by the former mayor who lost by 281 votes, Omar Bradley. On Feb. 8, a Los Angeles Superior Court judge put Mr. Bradley back in City Hall after finding that election officials had erred by not placing candidates' names randomly on the ballot. Mayor Perrodin's reinstatement is temporary pending an appeal. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: Unlocking $100 Million
description: Rudolph Giuliani has now agreed to the prompt distribution of $100 million in the Twin Towers Fund to the families of 430 uniformed and civilian rescuers who perished on Sept. 11. This is a wise move. It not only ensures the families' rapid payment, but also defuses an embarrassing confrontation that threatened to sour the positive note on which Mr. Giuliani ended his mayoralty.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Intel Shows Pentium 4
description: Intel showed off a Pentium 4 processor that runs almost twice as fast as today's best. The Pentium 4 for personal computers remains the company's workhorse. Intel, which says that complex video and audio tasks are made easier by the chip, is ratcheting up the processor's speed. The chip demonstrated yesterday runs at 4 gigahertz, while the current best Pentium 4 reaches 2.2 gigahertz.

title: Stages Explore the Drama of the Civil Rights Story
description: In a new play that has been drawing crowds here, three middle-aged black women, dressed in their Sunday finery despite oppressive summer heat, board a city bus in Atlanta for a ride downtown. They are not going to work or shop or visit friends but to integrate an all-white lunch counter.

title: A Reduction in Music Is Considered at WNYC
description: For much of its recent history, the quirky 77-year-old radio station WNYC-FM (93.9) in New York has been devoted mainly to the decidedly noncommercial format of classical music. But that may be about to change. Management at the station has presented several proposals to the program committee of WNYC's board that would drastically alter the station's long-standing identity.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HART, JACK
description: HART-Jack. Thou wast that all to me, love, For which my soul did pineA green isle in the sea, love, A fountain and a shrine... Moll

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANIEL, CAROLE
description: DANIEL-Carole. Dr. Charles Nechemias, the office staff and all our patients mourn the loss of a devoted colleague and caring friend, who lovingly served our practice for 24 years.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Residential Sales column last Thursday about a co-op in the Excelsior, at 303 East 57th Street in Manhattan, misstated the date of the building's construction. It was 1967; the building is not ''prewar.''

title: Madden Seems Close to Deal With 'M.N.F.'
description: After eight seasons with Fox Sports, John Madden is close to signing a deal with ABC's ''Monday Night Football,'' three sports broadcasting industry executives said yesterday. Fox released Madden from his contract, which had one year to go, to enable him to negotiate with ABC Sports.

title: Radio Transmitter To Oppose Hussein Wins U.S. Support
description: The Bush administration is prepared to finance the construction of a radio transmitter in the Kurdish enclave in Iraq or in neighboring Iran so that the Iraqi opposition can begin broadcasts to encourage opposition to Saddam Hussein, State Department officials said today.

title: Return Of the Clintonites
description: Can former Clinton cabinet members and White House aides who tasted fame and power in Washington find happiness in humdrum lives back home? If not, is a Clinton connection a political plus or the mark of Cain?

title: Savoring A Comeback Moment
description: They called her the Black Venus: in 1961 she was the first black singer at Bayreuth, and her triumph in Wagner's ''Tannhuser'' helped propel her into a nearly legendary international career. Now Grace Bumbry is 65 and rarely sings. But she emerged last Thursday night, trailing clouds of glory and a long tulle train, to present a recital program conceived in homage to her teacher, the German soprano Lotte Lehmann, at Alice Tully Hall.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Dealing With Government Online
description: The Bush administration said it had redesigned its official Internet portal, FirstGov.gov, to make it easier for people to find information and to conduct business with the government. The redesign cost $350,000. In addition, the Office of Management and Budget announced a two-year effort to expand government functions online, which it says will save billions of dollars by reducing inefficiencies, spending and paperwork.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about an art dealer and fine art publisher misstated his first name and omitted a survivor. He was Herbert Dietrich Schutz, not Heinrich. The survivor is a daughter, Elizabeth Schutz Lydon of Manhattan.

title: A Tricky Val d'Isre Lures the Adventurous
description: When you open the curtains on the south-facing windows of Le Blizzard, the hotel where I stayed three weeks ago at Val d'Isre, France, you will see the Bellevarde Face. It haunted me throughout my visit. Would I ski down it?

title: Guilty Plea By Suspect In Web Theft
description: A Philadelphia man described as a ringleader of an international Internet piracy gang that involved students at some prestigious colleges and universities pleaded guilty today to a federal conspiracy charge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COVIELLO, JOSEPH N.
description: COVIELLO-Joseph N. Of North Bergen, NJ on Tuesday, February 26, 2002. Beloved husband of the late Katharine J. (nee Telesca); devoted father of Dr. Marylu A. Coviello; dear brother of Catherine Montella, the late William A. Coviello and Anna M. Coviello; dear brother-in-law of Rose F. Coviello; loving uncle of Dr. Joseph Montella, William J. Coviello, Pattilu Montella Donohue and Thomas Donohue. Funeral Friday, March 1, 2002 at 9AM from the Vainieri Funeral Home, 5923 Kennedy Blvd. (corner of 60th St), North Bergen. Funeral Mass St. John Nepomucene RC Church at 10 AM. Interment Madonna Cemetery. Visitation Thursday 2-4, 7-9. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Rocco's RC Church, Union City, or Spirit of Memorial High School Scholarship Fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCARTHY, DANIEL F.
description: McCARTHY-Daniel F. On February 25, 2002 of Whitestone, NY. Beloved husband and best friend of Jean. Loving father of Daniel, Jr., Eileen, Kevin and Timothy. Beloved father-in-law of Kathy, Barbara and Amy and three grandsons. Devoted brother of Monica Smolenski. Reposing at Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 10-25 150th St., Whitestone. Mass of Christian Burial is on Saturday at 10:30 A.M. at St. Luke's Church. Interment at Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery. Visiting Thursday 7-10 PM and Friday 2-5 and 7-10 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions to Family Circle of Ozanam Hall, 4241 201st St., Bayside, NY 11361, would be greatly appreciated.

title: A drop in advertising at ITV of Britain prompts the companies behind it to think of joining forces.
description: HIT by a falloff in advertising revenue, Carlton Communications and the Granada Group, the dominant players in the ITV Network, a commercial broadcaster in Britain, acknowledged yesterday that they had held secret merger talks but failed to agree on a union.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: MISSOURI: HIGH LEVELS OF LEAD IN CHILDREN Almost half of the children tested last year near the nation's largest smelter in Herculaneum have high levels of lead in their blood, and a fourth of those under 6 years old have lead poisoning, the State Department of Health and Senior Services has said. The department tested the lead levels in almost 1,000 children and adults in Herculaneum, about 30 miles south of St. Louis. The Environmental Protection Agency and the Doe Run Company, which runs the smelter, began cleaning up contaminated houses and yards last year and started relocating almost 100 residents last month.

title: A Class Schedule to Make the Head Spin
description: To the Editor:

title: Footlights
description: Stepping Out

title: Russia Using Brutality to Suppress Chechens, Rights Group Says
description: About the same time the United States began its war on terrorism last fall in Afghanistan, Russia resumed a harsh campaign of torture, abductions and political killings in Chechnya, Human Rights Watch said today.

title: Jets Are Saving Money But Losing Their Defense
description: The Jets will be forced to release strong safety Victor Green today because he and the team cannot reach terms on a renegotiated contract. And nickel back Ray Mickens said last night that he believed he would probably have to be released today, too, because his agent and the Jets ''just haven't gotten anything done'' on his renegotiation.

title: Chronology: Louima Case
description: Aug. 9, 1997: After a night of dancing to live music at Club Rendez-vous on Flatbush Avenue, Abner Louima, a 33-year-old Haitian immigrant, joined a swirling crowd outside the club, watching two girls fight. In the confusion, Mr. Louima ended up in a scuffle with police officers and was handcuffed and placed in the back of an unmarked police car. Later, while in custody at the 70th Precinct stationhouse, Mr. Louima was beaten and tortured, according to prosecutors.

title: Cremation Case Calls for Creative Prosecution
description: After the bodies began turning up at the Tri-State Crematory two weeks ago, state officials were furious that the law provided no serious penalty for the desecration of corpses. With dozens of families demanding justice, the local prosecutor all but apologized for his meager legal arsenal.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: SWITZERLAND: CLARIANT'S PROFIT FALLS The Swiss specialty chemicals maker Clariant reported a sharp drop in net profit for 2001, to $82 million, as it struggled with declining sales amid the global economic downturn. Clariant said its debt was reduced by 20 percent as a result of cost-cutting. A revamping program should reduce debt further, the company said. Clariant, which was spun off from Sandoz before it merged with Ciba-Geigy to create Novartis, makes chemicals for the pharmaceutical and electronics industries. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Mother Charged In Death
description: A Brooklyn woman was charged with second-degree murder early today in the scalding death of her 4-year-old daughter, the police said. The woman, Tarajee Davis, 27, surrendered to police at the 67th Precinct stationhouse at 12:15 a.m. Her daughter, Dajhane Davis, 4, was burned in a bathtub in the family's apartment in East Flatbush on February 3. Dajhane died February 22. Ms. Davis was also charged with endangering the welfare of a child. The medical examiner ruled the death a homicide yesterday, said Sgt. James Foley, a Police Department spokesman. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: The Rangers' Fleury Raves On
description: Theo Fleury was unrepentant even defiant -- a day after again lashing out at National Hockey League's officials and threatening to retire.

title: Country Splendor for the Budget-Minded
description: HERE is good news for those who love toile, the colorful cotton fabric patterned with country scenes and luxurious foliage. A perennial favorite, toile has arrived in stores just in time to spruce up for spring, and it is enjoying new life as an inexpensive material.

title: A Beleaguered Fraschilla Struggles
description: Fran Fraschilla knew he was in for a challenge when he took the job as the University of New Mexico's men's basketball coach in this desert city three years ago. Now, with dust storms swirling around him, on and off the court, he remains resolutely upbeat.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Stalemate Continues
description: The government and the two main rebel groups remained in a deadlock over which political parties should be allowed to take part in talks in Sun City, South Africa. The dialogue was suspended on Tuesday, one day after the opening ceremony, because the two sides could not agree on the representation of the political parties, which will play an important role in deciding the shape of the future government. The rebel groups also accused the government of mounting an attack in southeastern Congo; the government denied the charge and said the rebels were seeking an excuse to abandon the talks. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: A NATION CHALLENGED: Briefly Noted; ID FRAUD
description: A Jordanian native who lives in Clifton, N.J., was arrested yesterday on federal charges that he falsely obtained Virginia identification documents -- ID's that list him as living at the same address as six of the airline hijackers in the Sept. 11 attacks. The man, Abdel Rahman Omar Tawfiq Alfauru, who had been in the custody of the Immigration and Naturalization Service at the Hudson County jail in Kearny since Oct. 1, was formally charged with identification document fraud in United States District Court in Newark. Magistrate Susan D. Wigenton ordered him transported to Virginia, where the United States attorney there is conducting an investigation of a fake-ID ring that appears to have assisted many of the hijackers. It was not clear what if any role beyond sharing with some of the hijackers the same address in Falls Church, Va., that Mr. Alfauru played in the ring that provided the illegal identification or in the Sept. 11 attacks. According to an affidavit filed in the court here by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents, at the very least some of the hijackers benefitted from the work of the same ring that aided Mr. Alfauru. The affidavit also said that Mr. Alfauru helped the ring assist others seeking phony identification by using his newly obtained credentials to vouch for them and falsely attest to their identities and residences. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, HARRY
description: MEYER-Harry. Died on February 27th, 2002. Devoted husband of Shirley. Loving father of Carol, Andrea and Warren. Cherished grandfather of Jordan, Ross and Matthew. Services Friday, 10 AM at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels,'' 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about Harvard University's decision to give college credit for advanced placement courses only when students score a five -- the top score -- on examinations, rather than a three, four or five, misstated the newspaper that first reported on the decision. It was The Harvard Crimson, not The Boston Globe.

title: Opening of Long Island Children's Museum Is Preface to More
description: Hundreds of youngsters scampered into a renovated airplane hangar here today and soon were gleefully enveloping themselves in giant soap bubbles, watching their reflections in fun house mirrors, smashing rocks into grains of sand and crawling up a wavy ramp suspended in air by a steel cable web.

title: And Now, a Word from Our Sponsor
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
